DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 1, or the 28th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1868: Mongkut, king of Siam, dies at the age of 64. In only 17 years he implemented sweeping political, economic and social changes with help from the West.
1916: Peking University Professor Hu Shih's proposal that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style wins quick acceptance.
1918: T.E. Lawrence, the British officer known as "Lawrence of Arabia, " and the Arab forces of Emir Faisal capture Damascus from the Turks.
1920: The Peking government cracks down on Russian settlements in China.
1921: The Chinese Communist Party sets up a branch in Hunan Province with Mao Tse-tung as its secretary.
1924: Jimmy Carter, an American peanut farmer who became the 39th president of the United States, is born. He was instrumental in getting Israel and Egypt to sign the Camp David agreement ending hostilities between the two countries.
1936: Gen. Francisco Franco Bahamonde, 44, is proclaimed "Chief of the Spanish State" by the nationalist military junta trying to seize power in Spain.
1946: The International War Crimes Tribunal in Nuremberg sentences 12 Nazi leaders to death.
1947: The Japanese Ministry of Education abrogates the name of Kyoto Imperial University.
1949: The Chinese communists set up a regime in Beijing with Mao Tse-tung as party chairman. The regime was recognized by the Soviet Union the next day.
1956: The ROC government implements regulations governing distribution of land to retired servicemen.
1958: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, a U.S. government agency that conducts and coordinates research on flight within and beyond the earth's atmosphere, is formally set up as an independent agency headquartered in Washington, D.C.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Nigeria.
1964: Japan's "bullet train" makes its first journey from Tokyo to Osaka.
1965: A coup attempt by Indonesian communists is crushed by Suharto, an army officer who becomes president of Indonesia two years later.
1969: The sound barrier is broken by the Concorde 001 during a test flight in France.
1972: Louis Leakey, British archaeologist and anthropologist, dies in London at the age of 69. He discovered the 1,750,000-year-old Zinjanthropus fossil at Olduvai Gorge and the contemporaneous "Homo habilis" at Lake Natron in Tanzania between 1959 and 1964.
1974: The annual three-day meeting of the Sino-U.S. Cooperation Science Program is held in Taipei.
1975: Muhammad Ali beats Joe Frazier in a rematch in Manila. Ali had recaptured the world heavyweight title after defeating the fearsome George Foreman in a sensational upset in 1974. Frazier had beaten Ali in 1971.
1976: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung leaves for Lesotho to attend a ceremony marking the kingdom's independence.
1982: Helmut Kohl is sworn in as West Germany's sixth chancellor.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of society.
1997: Gul Mohammed, the world's shortest man at 56 centimeters tall, dies. 1999: Taiwan announces the termination of flights to and from the Philippines after negotiators from the two sides failed in last-ditch efforts to address a stormy dispute over passenger quotas.
2000: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew says he is "less pessimistic" about cross-strait ties than he had been before his recent visit to Taiwan.
2001: A six-day conference of Asian Aborigines sponsored jointly by the Asian Indigenous People's Pact (AIPP) and Taiwan Aborigines concludes in Taitung, eastern Taiwan with a statement supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations Indigenous People's Workshop.
2001: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) approves the opening of electronic commerce insurance services for domestic insurance companies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Every system of moral law must be based upon man's own consciousness. It must be verified by the common experience of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STILL HAS ROOM TO EXPAND RELATIONS WITH OTHER NATIONS: CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Abu Dhabi, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By S.J. Taai and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan can expand its diplomatic horizons, regardless of obstacles put in its way by China, ROC President Chen Shui-bian said Friday in Abu Dhabi.
The president made the remarks while meeting with reporters to talk about Taiwan's current diplomatic difficulties and its relations with the United Arab Emirates (UAE).

Chen, at the head of a group of high-ranking officials and business leaders, arrived in the UAE capital earlier in the day for a 29-hour transit stop on his way back to Taiwan after a 13-day visit to the ROC's diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean.

Noting that he was deeply touched that ROC national flags were flying upon his arrival at the international airport of the UAE, a country which is not the ROC's diplomatic ally, the president said that he wanted to thank the Arabian nation.

"I was really moved to see ROC national flags flying over the airport, particularly given that China has never stopped trying to prevent Taiwan from joining the international community and strengthening its relations with other countries," Chen said.

According to the president, although Beijing protested strongly to the UAE about his stopover, the protest was ignored since the UAE has what he said are its own principles and methods to deal with the matter.
"Some say that this is a very significant breakthrough in relations between Taiwan and the UAE... I'll treasure this," he said.

Talking about his successful transit visit to the capital of the UAE given Taiwan's diplomatic difficulties, Chen said, "This is not an Arabian Nights' story, but shows that Taiwan still has room to develop its relations with other countries."

"Taiwan still can act in various places around the world as there are many issues that the island can raise and discuss with other nations, " he also said. "Taiwan can start down the road to success only if it makes a concerted effort."

The president also said that his transit stop in Abu Dhabi is "a very important visit" as many high-ranking ROC officials who were accompanying him, including Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, were to hold bilateral talks with their UAE counterparts on the strengthening of economic, trade and investment cooperation between the two countries.
Chen also rebutted media reports that said that he had lied when he said he was going to stop over in San Francisco; adding, however, "Even if it was a lie, it was one of goodwill."
Reporters were told that the president planned to fly to San Francisco rather than Abu Dhabi for a stopover on his way back to Taiwan Oct. 1.

Claiming that he did not lie to the media or to the public, the president said that he hopes that the media can understand that as a head of state, he was not able to confirm any information when matters related to his transit stopover in a country with no diplomatic relations with Taiwan were still being arranged.
The president also said that he does not care about the reports because what he did was in the nation's interest, and that achieving a diplomatic goal is most important.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO FORM SPECIAL TASK FORCE TO ADDRESS HIGH-SPEED RAIL ISSUES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday the Cabinet will set up a special task force to help tackle a host of problems involved in the nation's first high-speed railway construction project.
Hsieh made the remarks amid rising concerns about whether the nation's long-awaited high-speed railway will open next October as scheduled.

Acknowledging that the high-speed rail system construction project has encountered many problems, including financing, technology as well as legal rights and liabilities incurred by Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) in the course of construction, Hsieh said he feels the need to form a special task force to make an overall evaluation and work out response measures.

According to Hsieh, the high-speed rail task force will comprise transportation and financial management experts as well as consultants familiar with Japanese affaris. THSRC reportedly has had rifts with Japan-based Taiwan Shinkansen Consortium (TSC) , the main contractor of the Taiwan high-speed railway's mechanical and electrical system and the supplier of train carriages.
In addition to helping address any crisis that THSRC may face, Hsieh said the team will also cope with variables that may arise in the future.

The multimillion-dollar railway system is Taiwan's first infrastructure project being built under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model in which private investors build the system and will return control of the project to the government after a specified period of operations.

The 345-km high-speed railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south will form the backbone of western Taiwan's mass rapid transportation network. Travel time between Taipei and Kaohsiung is expected to be cut to 90 minutes after the railway is inaugurated at the end of October, 2006.
The high-speed railway will connect eight metropolitan areas between Taiwan's two largest cities and will be able to transport at least 300,000 passengers daily when it becomes fully operational.

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Roberts Is Sworn In as Chief Justice. Hours after the Senate confirmed him overwhelmingly, John G. Roberts Jr. took the oath Thursday as the 17th chief justice of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CAUTIONS RESIDENTS TO TAKE COVER FROM TYPHOON LONGWANG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has urged people to stay alert during strong Typhoon Longwang, Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday.

Hsieh said President Chen called him last night from Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates, where he was on a transit stop on his way back home after an official trip to Central America and the Caribbean.

The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land alert for the typhoon early Saturday, predicting the whole of Taiwan could expect strong winds and heavy rain, with Hualien and Ilan in the eastern part of the island facing the worst of the storm.

The bureau forecast that the mountainous areas in Hualien and Ilan would receive rainfall between 600 mm to 800 mm, while those in Kaohsiung and Pingtung in southern should receive between 500 mm to 700 mm.
Taipei City is estimated to receive rainfall between 250 mm to 450 mm.

The center of Typhoon Longwang was located at 22.7 degrees north latitude and 125.6 degrees east longitude at 1 p.m. Saturday -- about 430 kilometers east-southeast of the eastern Taiwan city of Hualien.

With a radius of 200 km, the typhoon was moving west-northwest at 25 kilometers per hour, packing center winds of 184 kph and gusts of up to 227 kph. It is estimated to reach the seas around 70 kilometers west-southwest of Hualien by 11:00 a.m. Sunday, according to the CWB forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Koizumi's Yasukuni trips are ruled unconstitutional

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING ON KOIZUMI'S YASUKUNI VISITS WELCOME, BUT MORE NEEDED: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A Japanese high court's ruling that Japanese Primer Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visits to the Yasukuni Shrine for WWII dead are unconstitutional was welcome news, said aboriginal Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei who is fighting to have Taiwanese soldiers' names removed from the controversial shrine, but that the court's decision to reject compensation claims was unfortunate.
Kao Chin made the remarks at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon her return from Japan.

Kao Chin made a short stop in Osaka to hear the verdict from the Osaka High Court on the case after a visit to the headquarters of the United Nations in New York to protest against Japanese atrocities against Taiwan's aboriginal people during its colonial rule of the island from 1895 to 1945.
The Osaka High Court ruled on Friday that Koizumi's visits to the Yasukuni Shrine violate an article of the Japanese Constitution calling for the separation of political affairs from religion.

However, the court turned down the compensation request of 10,000 yen (US$88) by each of the 188 plaintiffs, which included Kao Chin and families of those Taiwanese aboriginal people who died fighting for the Japanese army during WWII.

Kao Chin sued the Japanese government in 2003 on the grounds that the Taiwanese aboriginal soldiers were forced to fight for the Japanese army, and worse yet, their memories were enshrined at the Yasukuni Shrine together with those who persecuted them, along with various Japanese war criminals.
The lawmaker had demanded that the Japanese government remove the tablets of the dead Taiwan aboriginal soldiers from the shrine.
The plaintiffs alleged that Koizumi's visits to the Yasukuni Shrine were unconstitutional and caused serious psychological pain to them, demanding compensation of 10,000 yen each.
The court rejected the compensation demand, finding that legally, the interests of the plaintiffs were not harmed.
This was the second ruling following the one made by the Kukuoka District Court in April last year that said the prime minister's Yasukuni visits violated the constitution.
Noting that she and fellow aboriginal people all heard the "voice of justice" from the Osaka High Court, Kao Chin said although the voice was weak, it represented a blow to militaristic politicians.

However, the lawmaker noted that the Japanese government still refused to apologize and pay a token amount of compensation for its aggression and atrocities committed in the past against its neighbors, and she will keep working with her people to fight for their cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BRACES FOR STRONG TYPHOON LONGWANG

TEXT.P: Packing sustained winds of 184 kilometers per hour, Typhoon Longwang is expected to make a direct hit on the center of Taiwan and Premier Frank Hsieh has directed residents of the island to brace for the worst.
Hsieh reminded residents to stock up on drinking water and candles and for those living in areas prone to mudslides or flooding to seek higher ground or be prepared.
Taiwan is hit by an average of 3.5 typhoons each year.

Hsieh inspected the Taipei-based Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center with Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan and Minister of Agriculture Lee Chin-lung on Saturday after the facility was activated to prepare for the strong typhoon.
Similar disaster prevention and relief centers in counties and cities around Taiwan also have swung into action.

Talking about a possible surge in vegetable prices after the typhoon, Hsieh said that price hikes come about only because of public expectations. He believes there will be an abundant supply to meet demand in the next few days.

Typhoon Longwang ("Dragon King" in Chinese) , the 19th tropical storm this year, is moving west-northwest towards Taiwan at 25 kilometers per hour. The storm, packing center winds of 184 kilometers per hour and gusts of up to 227 kilometers per hour, is expected to hit Taiwan Sunday. The Central Weather Bureau has issued a land warning for the whole of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL PARTIES URGED TO STAND TOGETHER FOR NATION'S INTERESTS
DOC.DATELINE: Abu Dhabi, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Friday urged all political parties in Taiwan to cooperate with each other to help protect the nation's security and diplomatic interests.

The president made the appeal while criticizing those who have tried to introduce the so-called "one China" principle and the "1992 consensus" into law during a meeting he had with reporters to talk about Taiwan's diplomatic difficulties and its relations with the United Arab Emirates (UAE).

Chen, heading a delegation consisting of high-ranking officials and business leaders, arrived in Abu Dhabi earlier in the day for a 29-hour transit stop on his way back to Taiwan after visiting Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean.

Claiming that if the "one China" principle and the "1992 consensus, " which have not been accepted by Taiwan, become the law of Taiwan, they will also become a Taiwan-version of the Anti-Secession Law enacted by China in March of this year, the president said that although the political parties in Taiwan are allowed to hold different views about internal affairs and public policies, they must stand together in their determinations to defend the nation's security and diplomatic interests.

In response to questions raised regarding whether he has sent representatives to Beijing to express his wishes to resume cross-strait dialogue, Chen said that the cross-strait relationship is not Taiwan's only option and that the public should not pay too much heed to it.

Touching on pressure by China on Taiwan in the international community and Beijing's attempt to lure the island's diplomatic allies to severe their ties with Taipei, Chen warned that Taiwan people should not continue to have illusions about mainland China's huge market as such illusions will bring nothing to the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL INFIGHTING HURTING TAIWAN: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: Political infighting is hurting the country and Taiwan must develop a new governing mechanism based on inter-party cooperation to ensure political stability and sustainable national development, Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday.
Hsieh made the appeal in a speech delivered at the closing ceremony of a seminar on pluralistic society, political reconciliation and consensus democracy.

Noting that Taiwan has so far not found a way out of its domestic political impasse, Hsieh said the nation most needs to cultivate a culture centered on reconciliation and mutualism and develop a coalition government or a new ruling mechanism based on inter-party cooperation.
"With our society and culture becoming ever more open, diverse and pluralistic, we need a reconciliatory mechanism which should be an asset, not a liability," Hsieh said.

Over the past five years, Hsieh said major domestic political parties have been embroiled in a war of attrition, with the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party using their slim majority in the legislature to boycott the Democratic Progressive Party administration's policy initiatives at nearly every turn.

"So far, we have not found a way out of this, and the way things are going it seems that Taiwan is on the decline, " Hsieh lamented, adding that Taiwan's political arena will stabilize only if it can develop a coalition government mechanism or a framework for inter-party cooperation based on mutualism.
According to Hsieh, inter-party reconciliation and cooperation should be based on four principles -- equality, ground rules, a reasonable distribution of resources and basic mutual trust.

Hsieh pointed out that ideological confrontation and conflict of interests have been the greatest obstacles to inter-party reconciliation and cooperation. For instance, bills related to taxation reform, cancellation of income tax exemptions for military servicemen and public elementary and junior high school teachers and a minimum tax system have been stonewalled in the legislature because of opposition from vested interests.
Noting that the ruling party may lose power one day and an opposition party may come to power, Hsieh said the establishment of a viable, efficient governing mechanism is very important.
While crafting a "good governance" system, Hsieh said it is imperative to maintain neutrality in judicial and educational systems as well as within the police and media.
Hsieh further said political parties and social groups should adopt a win-win mentality or a mutualistic spirit in dealing with each other instead of attempting to destroy each other.

"During my tenure as mayor of Kaohsiung, my approval rating rose from 28 percent to 82 percent over a period of six years. Whenever my approval rating rose, the approval rating of the Kaohsiung City Council went up too, and vice versa," he added.

New York Times: Phone Call With Source and Deal Led Reporter to Testify

Wall Street Journal: In Shakeup, Disney Rethinks How It Reaches Audiences Robert Iger, who takes over today as Walt Disney Co.'s chief executive, is shaking up the Magic Kingdom by pushing a mandate for the digital age: Consumers must be able to use Disney content whenever and wherever they want it. Iger, who succeeds 21-year incumbent Michael Eisn er, faces enormous challenges as he rethinks Disney's business model. Consumer spending plunged in August at the steepest monthly rate since the 2001 terrorist attacks as Hurricane Katrina slashed incomes, fanned inflation and caused $170 billion in losses from property damage, the Commerce Department reported yesterday in its first tally of the storm's economic effects, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY OPEN TO SELF-REFLECTION AND REFORMS: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The head of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) information and cultural department claimed Saturday that the DPP is an open and reform-embracing political party willing to soul-search and examine all its administrative policies implemented in the past six years since assuming power.

Cheng Wen-tsan made the remarks in response to a proposal titled "The New DPP, " from two DPP thirty something politicans who are calling for party reforms -- Luo Wen-chia, a former legislator and Hakka Affairs Council chairman who is running for Taipei County magistrate, and former Legislator Tuan Yi-kang.
Saying that only the DPP has the courage to face up to its faults, and desires to engage in reforms, Chen said the DPP will make a humble review of itself as a ruling party.

He noted that discussions and self-examinations will be made to find out whether the DPP's ideas, including seeking the identity of Taiwan, creating a society with multiple cultures, democracy and human rights, fairness and justice, and sustainable development, have all been carried out or are in the process of becoming a reality.
The DPP welcomes any suggestions and criticisms, Cheng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS RECONCILIATION AND NOT CONFRONTATION WITH CHINA: MAC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is willing to cooperate with China through consultations at any time to improve cross-Taiwan Strait ties, a high-ranking official of the Cabinet-level Mainland affairs Council (MAC) said Saturday.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks at a forum on peace and development on the two sides of Taiwan Strait organized by the Ketagalan Institute, an academy founded by President Chen Shui-bian in 2003 to cultivate future leaders of the country.
Wu noted that the biggest problems in cross-strait affairs are the lack of political consensus within Taiwan and the lack of understanding of the island by China.
"China still harbors a great deal of hostility toward Taiwan, and is making many barriers in cross-strait negotiations," Wu went on.

Noting that there are potential risks in China, such as the increasing gap between the rich and the poor, Wu said that the Chinese authorities may tighten controls on the media and may misuse nationalism.

As a result, internal conflicts in China may cause anti-Taiwanese sentiments on the mainland, bringing serious negative impacts to Taiwanese entrepreneurs at a time when they have made investments worth more than NT$100 billion (US$3 billion) on the mainland, Wu said.
Taiwan business people make a total of three million visits to China annually, according to Wu.
Despite China's barriers to consultations and negotiations, the ROC government still insists on its principle of "goodwill reconciliation, active cooperation and lasting peace" in dealing with China.

The government on Taiwan is encouraging more Chinese people to visit Taiwan to better understand the island, as evidenced by the implementation of the "mini three links" between Taiwan's outlaying islands and some Chinese ports, allowing Chinese people to visit Taiwan for sightseeing tours, the opening of cross-strait charter flight services for Taiwanese businessmen to return home for the Chinese New Year holiday, allowing Chinese journalists to be stationed on Taiwan, as well as frequent educational and cultural exchanges between the two sides, Wu said.
"We are hoping to sow the seeds of democracy in China through the series of opening measures," Wu went on.

In response to the concern expressed by the students of the Ketagalan Institute over the frequent visits by Taiwan's opposition lawmakers to China, Wu claimed that the visits are good if they are made for the benefit of the country.
However, Wu said some politicians are visiting China or other countries criticizing the leaders of Taiwan, and these people and such visits should be held up to public scrutiny.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK MAY TOP NT$300 BILLION
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The production value in the Southern Taiwan Science Park is expected to reach NT$300 billion (US$9.04 billion) by the end of this year, Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration Director-General Dai Chien said Saturday.
Dai noted that since the establishment of the park in 1998, its production has almost doubled annually, with the value reaching NT$259 billion last year.
In only the first eight months of this year, the production value in the park totaled NT$208 billion, Dai said, adding that the number of employees in the park tops 40,000.
The optoelectronics industry has become the backbone of the park.

According to Dai, the park administration has approved the investments of 48 optoelectronics enterprises in the science park, including domestic optoelectronics giants such as Chi Mei Group and companies from the United States and Japan.

With the complete supplier chain in the optoelectronics industry, the production value of the industry is expected to reach NT$200 billion by the end of this year, becoming the largest optoelectronics bloc on the island.

In addition, Dai went on, the Southern Taiwan Science Park has created many records in the country, such as being the science park with fastest growth rate in production value, the largest with most complete planning, the best integration among TFT-LCD manufacturers, producing the largest size TFT-TVs in Taiwan, and the park with the largest number of eight-inch and 12-inch wafer manufacturers.
The Southern Taiwan Science Park can be considered the largest optoelectronics bloc in the world, Dai noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESTAURANTS BOOMING IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Chou Huei-ying & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese-operated restaurants are popping up like mushrooms in China with ever more exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The Taiwanese-run restaurants appearing on the streets of Beijing in recent years include chain outlets of the Taipei-based Din Tai Fung Dumpling House, Shin Yeh Taiwanese Restaurant, Wang Steak House, and the Bullfighter Steak House.
Lukang Xiaozhen, which has two branches in Beijing, is also a Taiwanese-invested restaurant serving Taiwanese and Hakka cuisine.

Compared with local restaurants, prices at the Taiwanese-run eateries are not cheap. However, prices are obviously not the concern of Beijing gourmets since most of the Taiwanese restaurants are usually packed.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP 'YOUNG TURKS' PUSH FOR 'NEW DPP MOVEMENT'

TEXT.P: A group of reform-minded thirty-something politicians in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are planning to launch a "new DPP movement" to push the party to resurrect its core values through soul-searching and innovation.

Luo Wen-chia, a core member of the group who is running for Taipei County magistrate, said Saturday during a campaign rally that a spate of recent negative news events, including controversies surrounding the Kaohsiung rapid transit system construction project, have prompted him and several young like-minded DPP members to call for intraparty self-reflection.

Noting that the DPP grew from an opposition movement against the Kuomintang's corrupt authoritarian rule, Luo said the DPP should never forget its core values of "freedom, democracy, fairness and justice" and should make every possible effort to realize them now that it is in power.

"The DPP has been known for its courage to accept criticism, make self-examinations and pursue reform and innovation. We have still three years to go in power. We must adjust our priority goals with more emphasis given to promoting fairness and social justice, " said Luo, who once served as a legislator and chairman of the Hakka Affairs Council.

The results of a string of opinion polls show that the DPP's approval rating has been on the decline after the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system to protest what they perceived as unreasonable treatment from their Taiwan management, Luo lamented.
In his view, Luo said, the incident has tarnished the DPP's image as a reform-centric ruling party.
"Crisis usually implies changes and opportunities. When we come under social criticism, it's time for us to make self-examinations, " Luo said.

Claiming that senior DPP officials have tried to shift the blame instead of soul-searching, Luo said he and former DPP Legislator Tuan Yi-kang and several other thirty-something DPP aspirants decided to launch a "new DPP movement" to press for a resurrection of the party's core values and live up to public expectations.

Luo said the proposal will be put forth for discussion at the party's national congress to be held later this month. The DPP congress was originally scheduled for Sunday but was postponed indefinitely due to the approach of Typhoon Longwang.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TOURS UAE SCENIC SPOTS
DOC.DATELINE: Abu Dhabi, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian telephoned Premier Frank Hsieh from the United Arab Emirates (UAE) again Saturday to call for contingency preparations as Typhoon Longwang is forecast to make a direct hit on the center of Taiwan Sunday.

Chen arrived in the UAE capital of Abu Dhabi from the Caribbean nation of St. Vincent and the Grenadines Friday for a one-day transit visit en route back to Taiwan after a five-nation diplomatic tour to Central America and the Caribbean.

Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang, who is accompanied Chen on his current tour, said Chen first called Hsieh Friday night and gave Hsieh another phone call Saturday morning while touring Al Ain, the UAE's second biggest city located some 160 kilometers away from Abu Dhabi.

"President Chen is concerned about pre-typhoon contingency preparations, " Huang said, adding that Chen has also asked Vice President Annette Lu by phone to visit the Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center to convey his regards to all emergency relief staff there.

Chen toured the Abu Dhabi downtown districts Saturday morning in the company of UAE officials. Accompanied by the UAE tourism minister, Chen traveled to Al Ain by helicopter to tour an old royal palace.
According to Huang, Chen will also travel to Dubai, the most prosperous city in the UAE.

Chen and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei Sunday. Asked whether the schedule will be affected by Typhoon Longwang, Huang said it's up to China Airlines (CAL) to decide whether the flight scheduled should be adjusted because of the storm.

During an informal meeting with Taiwan reporters covering his current journey earlier in the day, President Chen said his transit stop in Abu Dhabi is an utterly significant event as many members of his entourage, including Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, would hold talks with their UAE counterparts on the strengthening of economic, trade and investment cooperation between the two countries.

Chen also said he was truly moved to see ROC national flags flying over the Abu Dhabi International Airport upon his arrival, particularly given that China has spared not efforts to block Taiwan's international presence.
Sheikh Hamed Bin Zayed Al Nahyan, a younger brother of UAE President Sheikh Khalifa Bin Zahed Al Nahayan, greeted Chen upon his arrival in the oil-rich Middle East country Friday.

The UAE gave President Chen a red-carpet welcome. All of Chen's entourage and reporters were given courtesy treatment. Sheikh Hamed Bin Zayed Al Nahyan hosted a dinner at the hotel where Chen stays in honor of Chen and his entourage.
The UAE diplomatically recognizes Beijing, but has maintained friendly substantive ties with Taiwan.

Tan Sun Chen made a low-profile visit to the UAE in April this year, and Sheikh Hamed Bin Zayed, who is in charge of UAE economic affairs, visited Taiwan in June during which time he met with President Chen.
President Chen was originally scheduled to make a transit stop in San Francisco, but dropped the plan and flew directly from St. Vincent and the Grenadines to Abu Dhabi.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S REPUTATION TO BE AT STAKE IF HIGH-SPEED RAIL FAILS: HSIEH

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Saturday defended his decision to bail out cash-strapped Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) , saying that Taiwan's international reputation will be at stake if the nation's first high-speed railway can not be completed.
Hsieh made the remarks while taping a TV talk show to be broadcast on Chinese Television System Sunday.
Opposition lawmakers have slammed Hsieh for the government's decision to help source investments for the high-speed railway project.

Hsieh said in the taped TV talk show that the government must step in keep the project running because if the THSRC collapses, the government would have to be forced to buy the project out with over NT$300 billion according to the BOT (build-operate-transfer) contract.
As the project is already 87 percent complete, Hsieh said the government is choosing the lesser of the two evils by helping to bail the THSRC out of its financial straits.
Hsieh further said he didn't meet with THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing last week as media reports claimed.

The premier claimed that he decided to have two government-related foundations -- the China Aviation Development Fund (CADF) and the China Technical Consultant Inc. (CTCI) -- invest in the high-speed rail project -- only after he read all relevant data and information.

Noting that the 345-km high-speed railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south will form the backbone of western Taiwan's mass rapid transportation network, Hsieh said if the project cannot be completed smoothly, western Taiwan's development would be affected and the people's confidence would also be dented.
Worse still, Hsieh said, Taiwan's international reputation and credibility would be at stake.
Hsieh said the Cabinet will set up a special task force to strengthen supervision of the high-speed railway project.

"We'll definitely ask THSRC's original shareholders to assume responsibilities for completing the project, " Hsieh said. The multimillion-dollar railway system is Taiwan's first infrastructure project being built under the BOT formula in which private investors build the system and will return control of the project to the government after a specified period of operations.

THSRC issued a press statement late Friday, saying that its last fund-raising move before the system's scheduled inauguration next October has been completed, with the CADF investing NT$4.5 billion and the CTCI investing NT$3 billion.

With the new funds, the THSRC's paid-in capital has increased to NT$104.5 billion. The THSRC press release said a bank consortium will lift its freeze on a NT$60 billion loan to the company following the CADF and CTCI investments. As a result, it said the company will have enough funds to ensure a smooth completion of the project.

According to THSRC tallies, the company's founders (or original shareholders) will hold a 28.52 percent stake; the government and state-owned enterprises will jointly control a 11.89 percent stake; foreign institutional investors will hold a 3.34 percent stake; other institutional shareholders, including the CADF and the CTCI, will control a 41.25 percent stake; and individual investors will have a 15 percent stake.
The high-speed railway will connect eight metropolitan areas between Taiwan's two largest cities and will be able to transport at least 300,000 passengers daily when it becomes fully operational.

Acknowledging that the high-speed rail system construction project has encountered many problems, including financing, technology as well as legal rights and liabilities incurred by THSRC in the course of construction, Hsieh said Saturday he feels the need to form a special task force to make an overall evaluation and work out response measures.

According to Hsieh, the high-speed rail task force will comprise transportation and financial management experts as well as consultants familiar with Japanese affairs. THSRC reportedly has had rifts with Japan-based Taiwan Shinkansen Consortium (TSC) , the main contractor of the Taiwan high-speed railway's mechanical and electrical system and the supplier of train carriages.
In addition to helping address any crisis that THSRC may face, Hsieh said the team will also cope with variables that may arise in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: 17 THAI WORKERS MAY BE INDICTED FOR AUG. 21 RIOT

TEXT.P: Police authorities have asked the Kaohsiung Prosecutor's Office to determine whether 17 Thai workers should be indicted for their roles in the Aug. 21 riot at a foreign laborers living quarter in southern Taiwan, sources said Saturday.

Kaohsiung County police said they have completed probes into the rare mass violent case and discovered that 17 Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung City mass rapid transit system should be held responsible for either obstructing performance of public duties, endangering public safety or theft in the case.
Six of the 17 alleged "masterminds" fled into hiding Sept. 30, police said, adding that they have launched a manhunt.

One of the accused, identified as Mueangjan Phon, was alleged to have stolen about 600,000 bahts and NT$750,000 in cash from a safe at Huapan Co.'s office at the Thai laborers' living quarters in the southern county of Kaohsiung after the Aug. 21 riot, police said.

Over 100 Thai workers rioted against what they called "unfair and unjust" management in Kaohsiung County's Kangshan township by burning houses, cars and facilities, and attacking police Aug. 21 night.

Initial investigations showed that the incident occurred when several Thai workers returned to their dormitory with liquor and cigarettes, which were banned from the premises. When they were prevented from entering the dormitory, they vented their anger by burning houses, breaking glasses and throwing stones at the management staff, some of whom were beaten up.
The incident has tarnished Taiwan's image and led to the resignations of acting Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chi-mai and Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu to assume political responsibility.

1870: Rome becomes the capital of Italy.
1871: Cordell Hull, American statesman, diplomat, and the secretary of state under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, is born. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1945.
1909: A 220-km railway from Peking to Changchiakow (Kalgan) in Inner Mongolia, the first railroad built and owned by China, is opened to traffic.
1918: The world's first public health college is established at John Hopkins University in Baltimore.
1920: U.S. marines, sent by President Woodrow Wilson to Haiti to restore order, clash with rebel forces and kill their leaders.
1924: The League of Nations in Geneva adopts a protocol for the peaceful settlement of international disputes.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is appointed commander-in-chief of the Northwestern Communist-Suppression Army, and Chang Hsueh-ling is appointed the deputy commander-in-chief, with their headquarters located in Sian.
1942: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's special envoy, Wendel Willkie, arrives in Chungking to confer with Chinese leaders.
1945: George Smith Patten Jr., American general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany, is demoted by U.S. Army Chief-of-Staff Dwight D. Eisenhower.
1973: Siri Siriyodhin, Thai speaker of the House of Representatives and head of an 11-member parliamentary mission, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: A total of 319 model soldiers are cited to mark the ROC's 21st Armed Forces Day.

1996: A Peruvian plane crashes into the Pacific Ocean, killing all 20 people on board.
1998: Sanjaasuregiin Zorig, a popular government minister and the leading figure in Mongolia's peaceful democratic revolution, is murdered.
1999: Overseas Chinese communities around the world donate a total of NT$540 million (US$16.9 million) for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake in Taiwan.

2004: Iraqi insurgents shoot down a U.S. military helicopter near Baghdad, killing 36 soldiers and crewmen aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "During the examination of every system of moral laws with the teaching of acknowledged great and wise men of the past, there must be no divergence. Applying the examination to the operations and porches of nature in the physical universe, there must be no contradiction."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DETOURS TO BALI ON WAY BACK HOME

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian detoured to this Indonesian resort island on his way back from Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates, to Taipei Sunday after Typhoon Longwang forcing the closure of the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport near Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.
Chen and his entourage arrived here on 10 a.m. local time (3 a.m. GMT) , hours after a series of powerful boombs ripping through three crowded restaurants on the island and killing at least 32.

Chen is slated to stay here for eight hours before departing for Taiwan at 6 p.m. (11 a.m. GMT) He will arrive in Taoyuan at 11 p.m. (3 p.m. GMT) when Taiwan is expected to be free from the influences of Typhoon Longwang.
The president made the detour to Bali after rounding off a five-nation trip to the Central America and Caribbean with an unannounced visit to Abu Dhabi Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MOTHERBOARD MANUFACTURERS DIVERSIFY TO STAY COMPETITIVEBy Maubo ChangCNA Staff Writer

TEXT.P: Motherboard manufacturing used to be the goose that laid the golden egg for Taiwan's electronics manufacturers, but market saturation and differing consumer demands has sent companies scrambling to diversify their product lines to stay competitive.

Taiwan once turned out more than 90 percent of the world's motherboards, but has seen its output grow by only a single digit in recent years, and local manufacturers are trying to diversify their products to keep afloat. The percentage of revenue coming from motherboards has dipped to less than 50 percent of major local producers' overall incomes.

IDC, a global provider of market intelligence and advisory services for the information technology and telecommunications industries, has forecast a 10 percent global growth in the personal computer market this year, with an output of 195 million units, including 130 million desktop computers, 58 million notebooks, and 64 million servers.
Taiwan is expected to take the lion's share of this in light of its huge production capacity and well-developed supply chain.

However, fierce competition among manufacturers has driven down profits significantly, and ASUS, the giant motherboard manufacturer, has vowed to hunker down and fight hard against all competitors from low to high-end products. It is also keeping an eye on the inroads made by Honhai, which used to make motherboards only for well-known brands.

ASUS traditionally concentrated on the high-end market, which presented the opportunity to make bigger profits, rather than fight for a broad market share, but company Chairman Shih Chung-tang found that the policy of bypassing the low-end market was taking its toll on his company's revenues and decided to expand its market share.

Citing Intel and Samsung as examples, Shih said he believes only by leading other competitors and dominating the market can a company survive in a business environment where profits have been cut to a trickle.
Therefore, ASUS is diversifying its products in the hope of getting toeholds in what is commonly referred to in Chinese as "3C": computers, communications and consumer electronics.

ASUS, which already leads all competitors in the output of motherboards, graphic cards and optical disk players, is now aggressively expanding its capacity to manufacture notebook computers, servers, broadband equipment, wireless broadband communications, and mobile phones.
As a result, revenues from the sale of motherboards now account for only about 30 percent of ASUS's overall income.

In response to ASUS's expansion, Giga-Byte Technology, which is devoted to developing its own brands, decided to shift the production of its motherboards to Honhai to cut the costs of production and make up for its shortfalls in output capacity.

As to its notebook computer business, Giga-Byte decided to spin this unit off by setting up another company called Vimgate Network Technology Co. and farmed out its production to other large manufacturers.

Micro-Star International, which used to manufacture motherboards for other brands, is now developing its own MEGA brand of MP3 PMPs, notebooks and other consumer electronic devices. The company is expected to turn out 1.5 million MP3 players, and 300,000 to 400,000 notebooks this year, which would represent a significant growth over the previous year.

EGS, which is also a contracted motherboard manufacturer, is helping its clients, mainly middle- and small-sized computer manufacturers, to diversify their products. The company has won orders from Walmart in the United States and Haier in China, and is cooperating with Lenovo in producing servers.

As the world's production of motherboards is increasingly concentrate in a few giant producers, and the profit margins are small, many manufacturers that lack sufficient economies of scale have to change or alter their products or face the possibility of being swallowed up by bigger producers.

Even those who have tried to survive by diversifying their products may still suffer big losses with the new lines. Infinity, which ventured into the manufacture of ACPs, is one of only a few success stories. Their new products have increased its profits in the first half of this year 4.5 times and are expected to account for 70 percent of its whole-year revenues this year.

Another motherboard manufacturer, SOYO, which was renamed Wonten Technology Co. after being taken over by new management, has also turned the corner after it began to produce hyper-linkers and won orders from AMP, which is a subsidy of hyper-linker giant TYCO.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TAIWAN CASUALTIES IN BALI BLASTS: MOFA, TRAVEL AGENTS ASSOC.

TEXT.P: None of the 1,500 Taiwan tourists in Bali were hurt in the series of explosions that rocked the Indonesian resort island Saturday, the Travel Agents Association of the ROC, Taiwan said Sunday.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Michel Lu confirmed that no Taiwan tourists or businesspeople were among the dead or injured in the series of bomb blasts widely believed to be the work of terrorists.
The Travel Agents Association based its statement on reports from its 50-odd member agents, who keep track of Taiwan tourist groups and individuals visiting the area.
Lu's statement was based on reports by ROC officials stationed in Indonesia.
The MOFA spokesman also urged Taiwan nationals traveling abroad to be vigilant for their personal safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MAKES UNEXPECTED STOPOVER IN BALI

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian made an unexpected stopover Sunday on the Indonesian resort island of Bali following one-day stop in the United Arab Emirates on his way back from a 12-day diplomatic tour of Central America and the Caribbean.

Chen's plane, which had been scheduled to land at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan at 9: 40 a.m. Sunday, made the detour due to the closure of the airport because of Typhoon Longwang which made landfall in Taiwan Sunday morning.
Chen and his entourage were greeted by ROC Representative to Jakarta Lin Yung-lo and a group of Taiwan expatriates after his plane touched down at the airport in Tuban, Bali at 10 a.m. local time.

The president's arrival came one day after a series of bomb blasts ripped through three crowded restaurants on the resort island, killing at least 32 people. The blasts are widely believed to be the work of terrorists.

After being greeted at the airport, Chen was whisked away to a nearby hotel for rest. Journalists accompanying the president on his trip were warned not to leave their hotel rooms because of the uncertain situation following the bomb blasts.
Chen's unscheduled stop in Bali comes on the heels of an unannounced stopover in the United Arab Emirates' capital of Abu Dhabi following his five-nation visit to Central America and the Caribbean.
The president's plane departed Abu Dhabi at 8 p.m. Saturday for Taiwan but then turned southward toward Bali over the city of Bangkok, Thailand when it ran into heavy turbulence.

The president's deputy chief of staff, James Huang, who is a member of his entourage, didn't explain why Bali was chosen as the stopover destination, only saying that "it was a decision made after careful consideration."

Meanwhile, in Taipei, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu thanked Indonesian authorities for allowing the president to take refuge in Bali from the typhoon despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Chen is expected to stay in Bali for eight hours before heading back to Taiwan. His plane is scheduled to arrive at CKS Airport at 11 p.m. Sunday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MISSED GOOD CHANCE TO FORM COALITION GOVERNMENT: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The executive director of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Central Policy Committee said Sunday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) missed a good opportunity to form a coalition government late last year when the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, People First Party (PFP) and New Party won a majority of legislative seats.

Tseng Yung-chuan was responding to Premier Frank Hsieh's comments Saturday that Taiwan might have to establish a mechanism for forming a coalition government as there has been no way out of the current political impasse. The Cabinet's major bills, including those for special budgets for critical weaponry and flood control, have been stalled in the legislature.

Hsieh's spokesman, Cho Jung-tai, explained that Hsieh was hoping the opposition parties would initiate a no-confidence motion to dissolve the Legislative Yuan so that after elections, the majority party, or a grand coalition of parties, could form a government by nominating the premier who would be appointed by the president.

Tseng said the DPP's minority rule has proved a failure. "The country's Constitution says we are a dual-heads-of-government country" whose government should be formed by the majority party or parties in the legislature.
"Instead of doing so, the DPP insisted on having a minority government, causing itself the current embarrassment," he added.

He said the ruling party should take the responsibility for the difficulties it has encountered, not the opposition parties, adding that "it makes no sense at all to ask the opposition to initiate a no-confidence motion against the premier" and that "the biggest problem for the DPP is that it must abide by the Constitution."

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON LONGWANG BARRELS THROUGH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Longwang barreled through Taiwan Sunday morning, killing one person and injuring 36 others as well as cutting electricity to some 740,000 households.

The center of the strong typhoon, packing gusts of up to 60 meters per second, made landfall in Hualien, eastern Taiwan at about 5 a.m. Sunday. It moved off the island near Chiayi in western Taiwan at about 10 a.m., according to the Central Weather Bureau.

Hualien, which bore the brunt of the storm, recorded gusts of 64.9 meters per second, or 230 kilometers per hour -- a record high in 45 years in Taiwan. Thirty-four people in the eastern county were injured, with one person later dying of his wounds. Over 200 power line poles and one pylon were knocked down in the storm, leaving 140,000 households in the county without power.
The streets of Hualien City were littered with fallen trees and broken branches and debris from falling billboards and other structures Sunday morning.
Among the 750,000 households which suffered a power outage in the typhoon, 430,000 saw their power restored by Sunday afternoon.
Longwang also brought heavy downpours, with some mountainous areas seeing up 708 millimeters of rainfall in just 14 hours from midnight Saturday.
Because of the Central Mountain Range, the typhoon lost strength as it moved across the island, being downgraded to a medium typhoon by Sunday afternoon.

As of 2 p.m. Sunday, the center of Longwang was located 50 km north of the Penghu island, moving westward at a speed of 14 km per hour. Taiwan proper is expected to be free of the typhoon's influence by midnight Sunday.
Because of the typhoon, the island's airports were closed to all domestic and international flights until 3 p.m. Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MAKES COMPROMISE PROPOSAL REGARDING NCC MEMBER SELECTION

TEXT.P: In a bid to break an impasse over the naming of National Communications Commission (NCC) members, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) made a concession Sunday by proposing that a "review group" for recommending NCC members be formed in accordance with the percentage of seats in the legislature held by each political party.
William C.T. Lai, secretary-general of the DPP legislative caucus, said the ad hoc "review group" is a Kuomintang (KMT) idea for selecting members of the Control, Examination and Judicial Yuans.
Since his proposal is based on the KMT idea, Lai said the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" allies -- the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party -- have no reason to oppose it.
If the idea works, the nominees recommended by the multi-party "review group" would be selected by the premier for approval by the Legislative Yuan, Lai said.

As the DPP has made a concession over the long-stalled NCC member selection, it hopes the opposition "pan-blue alliance" will reciprocate by giving up the KMT's intention of keeping the Broadcasting Corporation of China in its control.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said the KMT legislative caucus would not accept Lai's proposal as the party still thinks appointing NCC members according to the "parties' proportional representation system" is the best idea.
Both the KMT and PFP fear the government will try to "meddle" in the NCC's operations if its membership does not reflect the strength of each of the parties in the legislature.

Sun Ta-chien, deputy convener of the PFP legislative caucus, said the opposition actually has been forced to adopt "the most stringent rules" to stop the government from interfering in NCC operations because the DPP government "has set too many examples of anti-democratic practices."

As an alternative, Sun said the opposition's version of the NCC composition rules clearly excludes anyone from becoming a member who has in the previous year held a public office, a party job, or even merely run for an elected office on a party ticket.
He said that if the DPP cannot put forth a better proposal than the "review committee, " a show-down vote in the legislature over the NCC organic bill will be unavoidable.

The Taiwan Solidarity Union, a minority party in the "pan-green camp" with the DPP, opposes both the "pan-blue alliance's" party representation idea and the DPP's "review committee" idea, saying both ideas harbinger "legislative intrusion in executive branch power" and would create constitutional chaos.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RETURNS HOME AFTER 8-COUNTRY TOUR
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Su-jun Tsai and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taiwan late Sunday after an unexpected stopover in Bali, Indonesia earlier in the day caused by Typhoon Longwang that forced the closure of Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, where his special flight was scheduled to land at 9:40 a.m.

The Indonesia detour add to an unannounced stopover in Abu Dhabi, capital of the United Arab Emirates, and the scheduled transit in the United States, making a record of eight countries that he has visited during the 12-day trip that was intended to bring him to five ROC diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean.

While staying in a Bali hotel, he was welcomed by Indonesian Vice President Muhammad Kalla's special adviser, who arranged a telephone talk between Chen and Kalla. Two Indonesian parliamentarians also extended their greetings to Chen at the hotel.
When he toured a cultural park on the island, he met a group of Chinese tourists, one of whom asked to take a photograph with him.
Chen also took time to meet a group of Taiwan businessmen working in Indonesia, hearing reports from them about Taiwan investment in the southeast Asian country.
According to his staff, when he was walking on the beach near the hotel, he told them that it was time for him to return to Taiwan and that any more delay in returning home would incur condemnation.

Indeed, in just the last 30 years, the U nited States has created something never before seen in its history and unheard of around the globe: a booming population of prisoners whose only way out of prison is likely to be inside a coffin. DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER SUGGESTS NEW WAY TO RESOLVE DOMESTIC POLITICAL IMPASSE

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker suggested Sunday that Premier Frank Hsieh and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng jointly call a meeting of party caucus whips across the political spectrum to seek a breakthrough to the current domestic political impasse.

By holding such a meeting, Legislator Lee Chun-yi said, Hsieh and Wang can "make political consultations" with caucus whips of ruling and opposition parties on a list of bills that must be addressed during the present legislative session.

While the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party has used its slim majority in the legislature to boycott the DPP administration's major policy initiatives nearly at every turn, the DPP administration has also rejected some of the pan-blue alliance-proposed bills.
Against this backdrop, Lee said he thinks that the two camps can make some political deals to break the deep deadlock that has hurt the nation's overall development.
"I'm hopeful that Hsieh and Wang will respond to my suggestion and call a meeting of ruling and opposition caucus whips to jointly seek a way out of the current limbo," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASSIDUOUS DIPLOMATIC EFFORTS TO PAY OFF: PRESIDENT CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Su-jun Tsai, S.C. Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday he believes his assiduous diplomatic efforts will pay off and bear fruit.

Chen made the remarks upon his return to Taipei late Sunday after a 13-day overseas tour that took him to five ROC diplomatic allies and three other countries that do not maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

"This is a record-setting journey that spans 49,000 kilometers. The tour has taken us from glaciers to deserts, from polar regions to temperate regions and tropical regions. Although the trip might be tiring and difficult, it would certainly pay off, " Chen said in an in-flight broadcast to his entourage and the media group covering his eight-country journey.
Chen made an unexpected stopover in Bali, Indonesia earlier in the day caused by Typhoon Longwang that forced the closure of Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan,

The Indonesia detour added to an unannounced stopover in Abu Dhabi, capital of the United Arab Emirates, and the scheduled transit in the United States, making a record of eight countries that he has visited during the 13-day trip that was originally intended to bring him to five ROC diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean.

While staying in a Bali hotel, he was welcomed by Indonesian Vice President Muhammad Kalla's special adviser, who arranged a telephone talk between Chen and Kalla. Two Indonesian parliamentarians also extended their greetings to Chen at the hotel.
When he toured a cultural park on the resort island, he met a group of Chinese tourists, one of whom asked to take a photograph with him.
Chen also took time to meet a group of Taiwan businessmen working in Indonesia, hearing reports from them about Taiwan investment in the southeast Asian country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON LONGWANG CAUSES ONE DEATH, 53 INJURIES

TEXT.P: Typhoon Longwang headed toward China after barreling through Taiwan Sunday, leaving one person dead, one missing and 53 others injured, the Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center said.
According to the Central Weather Bureau, Longwang has weakened to a light typhoon and Taiwan had cleared of its threat by 8 p.m.

"The damage and casualty situation right now looks as if we have had some good fortune in the midst of this misfortune," Premier Frank Hsieh said during an inspection tour of the central disaster response center earlier in the day.
The eastern county of Hualien bore the brunt of the storm, where one person was killed and 33 others injured.
More than 760,000 households around the country suffered a power blackout due to typhoon. Power supply resumed to most of those households by Sunday evening.

Typhoons frequently menace Taiwan, Japan, the Philippines, Hong Kong and eastern China during the storm season that lasts from early summer to late autumn. Typhoon Haitang killed 12 people in Taiwan in July, with three still listed as missing.
In 2001, one of Taiwan's deadliest years for storms, Typhoon Toraji, killed 200 people. A few months later, Typhoon Nari caused Taipei's worst flooding on record and killed 100.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAN FIND 'OASIS IN DIPLOMATIC DESERT': CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday he is confident that Taiwan can find an "oasis in diplomatic deserts" so long as its people stand united and pool resources to promote "trade diplomacy" and "humanitarian diplomacy."
Chen made the appeal in a brief speech delivered at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after his return from an unprecedented eight-country journey.

"This is a record-setting journey that spans 49,000 kilometers. The tour has taken me from glaciers to deserts, from polar regions to temperate regions and tropical regions. Although the trip might be tiring and difficult, it would certainly pay off and bear fruit, " Chen said confidently.
Chen made an unexpected stopover in Bali, Indonesia earlier in the day because Typhoon Longwang forced the closure of Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

The Indonesia detour added to a surprise 29-hour transit visit to the United Arab Emirates and the scheduled transit in the United States, making a record of eight countries that he has visited during the 13-day trip that was originally intended to bring him to five ROC diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 3, or the first day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln officially designates the last Thursday of November a national holiday, to be called Thanksgiving Day.
1867: Elias Howe, the U.S. inventor and manufacturer who designed early sewing machines, dies at the age of 48. He patented the sewing machine and made about US$2 million from the patent, subsequently winning patent-infringement suits against a number of manufacturers, including Isaac M. Singer.
1888: Carl von Ossietzky, the German journalist and pacifist who won the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, is born. He was imprisoned for exposing Germany's military buildup.
1929: Yugoslavia becomes the official name of the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.
1932: Iraq becomes independent after the British mandate ends.
1952: The first British atomic weapon is exploded off the Monte Bello Islands, west of Australia.
1963: President Ramon Villeda Morales of Honduras is overthrown in a military coup.
1966: Lesotho, which was formerly governed by Britain as the Protectorate of Basutoland, becomes independent.
1970: "Yu Chao," the first 100,000-ton oil tanker built in Taiwan, is launched. "Yu Chao" is the name of a legendary Chinese ruler who taught the people to build tree houses for protection against wild beasts.
1972: Armando Yoshida Vaca, new Bolivian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1972: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko sign a pact limiting the number of defensive missiles of their respective countries to 200.
1973: Gen. Robert E. Cushman, commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The sixth World Chinese Pharmacists Amity Conference opens in Taipei.
1975: The 10th World Chinese Traders Conference opens in Taipei with more than 900 overseas Chinese from 57 countries and areas attending.
1976: ROC Finance Minister Walter H. Fei leaves for Manila for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
1976: Jack Davis, president of Rotary International from 1977 to 1978, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1977: Former Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is arrested on corruption charges.
1989: Troops loyal to Panamanian strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega crush a coup attempt by junior officers.
1990: Singapore and mainland China establish diplomatic relations.
1990: East and West Germany formally unite to become the single nation of Germany, with Berlin as its capital and Helmut Kohl as provisional chancellor.
1995: Manuel Saturnino da Costa, prime minister of Guinea-Bissau, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1997: A powerful earthquake rocks central Italy, causing more damage to the frescoed interior of the 13th-century Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi.
1997: Japan's magnetically levitated train breaks the world speed record for a manned train when it is clocked at 451 kilometers per hour on an experimental track west of Tokyo.
1999: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs extends its appreciation for the efforts of the 25 countries that support membership in the United Nations for the ROC.
2000: Premier Tang Fei announces his resignation after a four-month period in office, the shortest premiership in ROC history.
2001: Dr. Chern Jeng-shing, an official with the Republic of China's Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC), is elected a member of the prestigious International Academy of Astronautics (IAA).
2001: The Hong Kong branch of the Taiwan-based United World Chinese Commercial Bank (UWCCB) opens, becoming the eighth Hong Kong branch of Taiwan-funded banks.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Confronted with the spiritual powers of the universe, a man must be able to maintain moral law without any doubts. He must be prepared to wait a hundred generations without any misgivings for the coming of a man of perfect divine nature to confirm moral law."

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP WATER MANAGER OPTS AGAINST OPENING OF PINGLIN INTERCHANGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan Water Co. Chairman Hsu Hsiang-kun said Monday that from the pure water conservation perspective, he would opt against the opening of an interchange linking the village of Pinglin in Taipei County with the Peiyi Freeway.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Hsu said he would suggest that the administration not give the green light to the opening of the Pinglin interchange if the country is resolute in protecting a good water catchment area and the nearby natural environment.

Hsu made the remarks in response to a question from opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao regarding whether it would be better for the environment that the Pinglin interchange not be opened. The interchange would make it easy for visitors to access by car Pinglin, a quiet village at the center of the catchment area of the Feitsuei Reservoir -- the major reservoir supplying running water to Taipei City and Taipei County.

The issue of whether the Pinglin interchange should be opened has been the heart of political tug of war which has escalated from the local level to the national level over the past several months as opening the interchange would obviously boost Pingling's tourist numbers and consequently promote commercial development there, inevitably leading to pollution of the reservoir.

Because of Pinglin's location in a catchment area, its commercial development is severely restricted -- to the great displeasure of many of its residents who hope the interchange linking the village and the Peiyi Freeway will boost the local economy.

Their desire has won the sympathy of Chen Din-nan, a former justice minister who quit his post earlier this year to run in the year-end election for the magistracy of Yilan County which is where the Peiyi Freeway ends.

Chen wrote to Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san and Environmental Protection Administration Minister Chang Kow-lung, asking them to open the interchange to facilitate the development of Yilan and Pinglin.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications decided Sept. 16 to allow a maximum of 4,000 vehicles to use the interchange through Pinglin per day, but the move only prompted traffic jams because too many vehicles wanted to use the interchange.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMES A FOUNDATION FOR TAIWAN IN KNOWLEDGE ECONOMY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Monday lauded Taiwan's small and medium-sized enterprises for their outstanding performance, saying they are a foundation for helping Taiwan compete with other countries in the "knowledge economy" of the 21st century.

Chen, who returned Sunday from a 13-day visit to Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean, made the comments while addressing the opening of Taiwan's first national small and medium-sized enterprises development conference, which is being held at the International Conference Center in Taipei.

The two-day conference, which has been organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, is aimed at helping the island's SMEs to respond effectively to the challenges posed by the changing international economic environment.

Saying that Taiwan's SMEs are dynamic and innovative and can quickly adapt to changing situations, the president noted that according to the government's "Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises White Paper 2005, " the island has more than 1.164 million SMEs, employing some 7.55 million people and generating total gross revenue of more than NT$9.35 trillion.
"This shows that SMEs are not only a foundation for the island's economic development, but also one of the most important forces in terms of social stability and job creation," he further said.

As the growth of the knowledge economy and globalization are major economic trends, Taiwan's SMEs should cluster together and promote innovation, Chen continued, promising that the government will continue to pour more resources into helping boost the SMEs' global competitiveness and developing the island's economy.

Although Taiwan's economy is filled with creativity, dynamism and competitiveness, the president said that "although we cannot be complacement about this, it doesn't hurt to give ourselves some applause and encouragement."

Noting that the strength of Taiwan's SMEs helped shield the island to a large extent from the Asian financial crisis of 1997, the president said that in order to maintain Taiwan's international competitveness, the island must continue to work to promote the superiority and dynamism of its small and medium-sized enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR COUNCIL TO RELAX RESTRICTIONS ON IMPORT OF CAREGIVERS

TEXT.P: Medical authorities will professionally assess whether long-term medical care is needed to warrant the employment of a foreign caregiver in an attempt to loosen restrictions on who can import labor, the head of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday.

CLA Chairman Lee Ying-yuan also said that the council will scrap the Barthel index used to determine whether a local family can hire a foreign caregiver. The Barthel index assesses the degree of disability in a particular individual. From now on, certificates issued by medical authorities will be the main criterion.
Lee said that he has already contacted the Department of Health (DOH) and that medical authorities will make the decision on who will require long-term care.

As for which medical sector will have the final say, and whether doctors, nurses and social workers will form an assessment team to decide on the matter, this will be left for the DOH to conclude, Lee said.

Hopefully, he said, the new review system will be put into place as soon as possible to remedy the situation of people with seriously ill family members having to cajole doctors into fudging medical reports so that they can qualify to employ a foreign caregiver.

Lee also said that the CLA will provide training to local people wishing to be caregivers and advertise for local workers when the need arises. The council is also studying the feasibility of subsidizing locals wishing to hire Taiwanese to work as caregivers, he added, with social welfare authorities acting as middlemen between the local people and employers.
Under the plan, if no local people come forward within two weeks of an advertised position, then the CLA will open the vacancies to foreign caregivers, Lee added.
