DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOUNDRY INDUSTRY REMAINS STRONG DESPITE GLOBAL COMPETITIONBy S.C. ChangCNA Staff Reporter

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TMSC) and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC), the world's leading contract chip makers, will remain strong and competitive in spite of rising competition from such ambitious foreign competitors as Grace Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (GSMC) and Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp. (SMIC) of China, Chartered Semiconductor (CS) of Singapore, Samsung Electronics of South Korea, and IBM of the United States.

Analysts say the key to Taiwan's foundry strength is the two leading companies' technological leadership and financial strength that have helped them maintain their edge in the highly competitive market.

Huang Chun-hsun, a research fellow at Industrial Technology Research Institute, said the biggest asset for TSMC and UMC is their accumulation of technological know-how and investor capital. Each of them has some NT$100 billion (US$3 billion) in cash, far surpassing that of their key competitors. And they have managed to keep manufacturing processes at least one generation ahead of their rivals, meaning that the two foundries are basically in a secure position in the world market, Huang noted.

TSMC and UMC faced threats from GSMC and SMIC which, with the help of the Chinese government and their foreign partners, have been rapidly expanding their production capabilities and chipping away at the market shares of the Taiwan makers. Still, TSMC and UMC's joint market share in 2005 is forecast to remain at about 70 percent, with TSMC keeping the top spot.

Taiwan's foundry giants are facing unusual pressure for their fourth quarter revenues because of the low-price strategy adopted by SMIC and CS as the recovery of the global semiconductor industry has been slower than expected and heavyweight IC designing houses have been unable to bring down their inventory levels, triggering market worries that IC designers will reduce their orders to manufacturers.

Both TSMC and UMC have worked aggressively to maintain their competitive edge by upgrading their technology. In this regard, TSMC announced in Dec. 2004 that it was using the industry-leading Nexsys 90 nanometer process in volume production for such leading companies as Altera Corp. and Qualcomm Inc., the only foundry process to feature copper interconnect, low-k dielectrics, and 12-inch wafer production.

In April this year, TSMC unveiled another latest semiconductor manufacturing process -- the 65 nm Nexsys Technology for SoC Design -- at a symposium attended by over 400 of the industry's leading companies, and said its first wafers to be produced by this process are expected in December 2005. The new technology allows designers to build logic devices with double the density of the company's industry leading 90 nm technology, enabling market movers across the IC industry to save significant costs.

UMC, for its part, also announced its leadership in the 90 nanometer manufacturing process, an achievement that has won it big orders from such IC designing firms as TI, ATi, nVidia, and Qualcomm. In late August, UMC said it had reached a "milestone" of having shipped over 100,000 customer wafers using the 90-nm process technology, becoming a leader in terms of the total number of 90-nm wafers shipped as well as in revenue generated from 90-nm sales.

As TSMC enjoys high satisfaction from such key IC designing houses as TI, ATi, nVidia, Microsoft, Freescale, Sony and Altera, it is quite unlikely that it will lose major orders to UMC, market analysts said.

TSMC's prowess was proved when it received the 2005 Outstanding Nanotech Award, the first in Taiwan's history, on Sept. 21. It was honored for its successful production of fully functional 90-nm devices using immersion lithography tools and its development of 65-nanometer technology.

TSMC Senior Vice President for R&D S.Y. Chiang, when receiving the award on behalf of his company, repeated TSMC's vision to be the "most advanced, innovative and largest provider of foundry services and in partnership with its customers." He estimated that in 2006, TSMC's 90-nm orders could top NT$50 billion (US$1.5 billion).

TSMC and UMC's technological lead was further proved when nVidia withdrew all its orders from IBM, which launched an aggressive campaign to wrestle orders from the two Taiwan manufacturers in 2003, and directed them all back to TSMC and UMC. TSMC has started volume production of nVidia's orders in the third quarter of this year using the 90-nm process, and UMC is set to start volume production of nVidia orders in the first quarter of next year.

TSMC's R&D efforts are producing another likely result for 2006 and beyond: merging IC process technology with microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) , a platform whose market value researchers estimate will grow from US$8 billion this year to US$14 billion by 2009.

According to an Electronic Engineering Times report, if TSMC succeeds in integrating the IC and MEMS design processes, it will be a major step forward for MEMS designers. The company's larger resources would not only improve economies of scale, but also bring a standard infrastructure to the table, the EE Times noted.

Analysts said Taiwan foundries can also use their technological and capital resources in a marketing strategy that would "scare away" potential rivals. For example, they can wage a price war over a certain customer or a specific manufacturing process, or even over a production capacity project.

And they will be able to do so because their capital base is sound enough for them to generate cash that will be used to acquire new equipment and invest in R&D, boosting their production capacity and competitiveness. As a TSMC official told CNA, his company will begin 65 nm production by the end of this year, and start volume production next year, again as a global leader.

To be sure, competition for attracting investment and developing new technologies will continue in the high-tech industry, and TSMC and UMC will never run short of aspiring competitors in the foundry industry. The two's operations will be affected by old and new rivals in the market. Long-term prospects for the two leading companies look good as they are likely to maintain their technological and financial edges over competitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY WINNERS IN FRUIT EXPORTS TO CHINA ARE COUNTERFEITERS: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Monday said that the only winners in Taiwan's fruit exports that are not supervised by the government to China are those who are now profiting from Taiwan's name while selling " counterfeit" produce on the mainland.
The president asked farmers to trust that the administration has their best interests at heart and to support the government's stand on Taiwan fruit exports to China.

Speaking at a training workshop for officials in farmers and fishermen's associations, Chen said that since certain Taiwan fruits have been allowed duty-free treatment by China, copycats have been spotted on the market in the mainland under the guise of "grown in Taiwan."

The president said that after the initial fascination by the public in China for Taiwan-grown fruits and the local advocacy of the move to export by some opposition parties and special interest groups, the only ones who are reaping long-term benefits are the Chinese counterfeiters -- not Taiwan farmers.

Chen said that the counterfeiting issue, which is cause for a major trade dispute, cannot be sorted out simply by opposition politicians or a few private farmers' representatives, adding that domestic farmers should listen to the government and support its stance on Taiwan fruit exports to China.

The government's stance is that Taiwan does not oppose local farmers exporting fruit to China, Chen said, but that officials from the two sides should first talk on matters regarding the shipments, including tariff tables, quarantine regulations and customs inspections.
The government feels that these exports should be conducted in an orderly and transparent manner so that the farmers' maximum long-term interests can be ensured, Chen argued.

Quoting a recent media report from Beijing that said that 90 percent of " Taiwan fruit" currently found on Beijing store shelves are "counterfeit, " Chen wondered how opposition politicians and the few private farmers' representatives would be able to handle this kind of trade dispute.

China began to allowed duty-free imports of fruits from Taiwan in early August as a response to former Taiwan opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's high-profile visit to China in spring. Chen said this was a move by China to give the impression internationally that it is apeace-loving country on the one hand and to lure Taiwan's opposition politicians and civic groups into the Chinese fold on the other.

Without the government's supervision and assistance, Taiwan farmers have begun to ship their fruits to the mainland, Chen said. Now that their fruits have been hijacked by those profiting from Taiwan's name while selling non-Taiwan-grown produce, where should the farmers who trusted the opposition turn to now?

Chen urged farmers to stop this risky way of selling, asking that they cooperate with the government to boost Taiwan's fruits exports to other places beyond China, such as Japan, Singapore, Europe and the United States, markets where people observe the rule of law.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DENIES IT WILL 'CONDITIONALLY' AGREE WITH ARMS PURCHASE BUDGET

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus denied a newspaper report Monday that their party will "conditionally" refer the Executive Yuan's budget bill for a U.S. arms purchase to a committee of the Legislative Yuan for review.
KMT caucus whip Tseng Yung-chuan said the United Daily News report is baseless.

Meanwhile, the deputy chief of the KMT caucus, Legislator Pan Wei-kang, said she has not been informed of any changes to the KMT's approach to the budget bill, a matter that should be taken up by the caucus rather than KMT authorities.

KMT Legislator Shuai Hua-ming, who is named by the United Daily News as a member of a panel that recommended the party to give a "conditional" green light to the budget bill at the end of this year, said the idea disclosed by the newspaper "is quite good."
However, the KMT's political ally in the legislature, the People First Party (PFP), which is firmly against the budget bill, reacted angrily to the report.

PFP lawmaker Sun Ta-chien said at a news conference Monday that the report vindicates his party's long-standing fear that the KMT could betray its followers and the PFP by softening its opposition to the budget.

Noting that the KMT administration accumulated NT$2 trillion (US$60.18 billion) in government debt in its nearly five decades of rule up to 2000, Sun said the debt has grown to nearly NT$5 trillion (US$150.31 billion) under the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration in just five years, and his party will never agree to the arms purchase.
The DPP government plans to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries from the United States.

There has been speculation that the KMT had softened its opposition to the bill under pressure from the U.S. government and in consideration of the fact that the Ministry of National Defense agreed in September to list the financing for the Patriot anti-missile batteries in the regular budget, causing the proposed special budget in the bill to drop to NT$340 billion.

Sun reiterated his party's line against the purchase of the Patriot anti-missile batteries, claiming that the purchase has already been rejected in a referendum held in conjunction with the 2004 presidential election.
Also, Sun said his party opposed the purchase of 12 P3-C anti-submarine airplanes and eight submarines through a special budget, which will be financed mainly by government loans.
PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said the party would regret the news, if it were true, that the KMT has backpedaled on its opposition to the arms purchase budget bill.

If the KMT believes the public does not want to see the budget killed, the spokesman said, "The Kuomintang should come out in favor of the budget now rather than reverse its stance after the year-end elections so that the public can make its voice known through the ballot box."
Ironically, the PFP spokesman's views were shared by its political rival, the DPP.

DPP legislative caucus whip William Lai dared the KMT to ask its members in the Rules Committee of the Legislative Yuan to let the budget be referred to the Defense Committee for review immediately if the party feels that the people wish to see the budget approved.
"Defense issues are above partisan interests, and the KMT should deal with these with the public interest in mind rather than being hold hostage by the PFP," Lai said.
The KMT and PFP command a slim majority in the legislature and have joined hands in the Rules Committee to block the budget bill 30 times in the last two years.

The United Daily News said in a story Monday that the KMT under newly elected chairman Ma Ying-jeou is mulling softening its opposition to parry the DPP's criticism that it opposes the arms purchase budget simply because it is an opposition party.

Under the KMT's plan, the paper said, it should favor the purchase of anti-submarine aircraft and submarines as long as they are financed by the Defense Ministry's regular budget, but not the purchase of Patriot missiles before the Executive Yuan comes up with explanations to bypass the referendum result. However, the paper said, the KMT cannot afford to part ways with the PFP now when it still needs the latter's cooperation in the year-end elections.
Therefore, the paper said, the KMT is planning to modify its approach to the budget after the year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S POSITION ON CONTROL YUAN ISSUE NOT CHANGED: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) has never wavered from wanting President Chen Shui-bian to renominate members of the Control Yuan, the KMT Central Policy Coordination Committee chief said Monday.

Tseng Yuang-chuan, also a legislator, noted that the alliance did not even consider spending time looking over the list to approve only half the names nominated for the country's supreme watchdog body, and leaving the rest to be dealt with by the next president in 2008.

Tseng made the remarks after a Monday news report said that the KMT has mapped out two proposals as part of its efforts to find ways out of the Constitutional deadlock that has since Feb. 1 stopped the function of the Control Yuan in supervising government operations.

Before the Control Yuan underwent its regular personnel change-over Feb. 1, President Chen presented a list of nominations for the new president, vice president and 27 members of the institution for the approval of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan in line with the Constitution. However, the legislature has declined to screen the list and has instead asked the president to come up with a new list by claiming that most of the nominees are not up to the expectations of the public.
Chen stuck to his guns, insisting that such a request infringes upon his power of nomination, which is enshrined in the Constitution.

Tseng stated that to ensure the Control Yuan's independence, both the KMT and PFP suggested last week the formation of a "recommendation" panel based on the proportions of political parties in the legislature, and that the president should make his nominations from a list of the panel-recommended persons.

The "pan-blue alliance" believes that such a process would ensure a highly political consensus on the nominations, Tseng said, adding that the KMT caucus in the Legislative Yuan will also push for an amendment to the law to lift the ceiling of the number of legislators in approving the Control Yuan nominees from 50 percent to two-thirds of the 225 legislative seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOOGLE GETS AN EARFUL FOR CALLING TAIWAN A PROVINCE OF CHINA

TEXT.P: Google's listing of Taiwan as a "province of China" on its map section has raised the ire of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , which is asking the public to e-mail the popular search engine in protest.

At a news conference, TSU legislators Huang Shih-cho, Tseng Tsan-deng and Huang Tsung-yuan lashed out at Google for succumbing to China's pressure. Taiwan is not a province of China, they claimed, and saying as much is a tremendous affront to Taiwan's sovereignty.

The TSU lawmakers called for Taiwan citizens at home and abroad to e-mail Google to protest its rudeness and insensitivity by lying about Taiwan's sovereignty simply to curry favor to enter China's large Internet market.
They said that Google's behavior should not be condoned any longer. Otherwise, they said, Taiwan's sovereignty will be unwittingly infringed upon.
They want Google to immediately change Taiwan's map description from "Taiwan, Province of China" to "Taiwan, An Independent State in Asia."
Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Government Information Office who were also present at the news conference agreed with the TSU legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTER-YUAN TALKS MAY HELP LEGISLATIVE STALEMATE: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Monday that a meeting between the Legislative and the Executive Yuans could be one of the options to solve the impasse in the Legislative Yuan.

Wang made the remarks amid reports that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , out of the concern that numerous bills are being stonewalled in the legislature because of constant bickering between the ruling and opposition parties, had suggested that Wang and Premier Frank Hsieh invite the legislative caucus whips across the party spectrum to meet.
The DPP said that the consultations will be of a "political nature" to decide on which bills should be handled in this session, the reports said.
Wang said that he doesn't know if the proposal will help solve the current impasse, but he said that if Hsieh is present at the consultations, maybe it will be helpful to learn the DPP's stance.
He said that as the president of the Legislative Yuan, he should provide more occasions for the heads of rival parties to sit down and talk.

He also said that he will invite legislative caucuses to discuss the proposed national communications commission (NCC) bill Tuesday, and if there is still no result after one or two meetings, then a vote will be unavoidable.

At stake is the composition of the commission; the opposition parties want the NCC to be comprised of members in proportion to the number of seats each party holds in the legislature, while the DPP insists that political parties should keep their hands off and let experts and scholars serve on the commission, so that media freedoms will not be affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL REFORMS AIMED AT HELPING ENTERPRISES: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: The second stage of national financial reforms will help small- and medium-sized enterprises, Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday.

Speaking at the opening of a conference called to help the development of the country's small- and midium-sized enterprises, the premier said that Taiwan's banks cannot compete against their foreign counterparts because of their relative small capital and size.

The Executive Yuan's second phase of financial reforms encourage banks to merge and thereby sharpen their competitiveness, which will in turn strengthen their ability to serve small- and medium-sized enterprises.

The premier also disputed allegations that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party associates closely with business tycoons, saying no businessmen have ever served on the party's Central Standing Committee.
On the contrary, Hsieh said, many businessmen double as members of the Central Standing Committee of the opposition Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: CGA HEAD VOWS TO DISPLAY ROC SOVEREIGNTY OVER EAST CHINA SEA

TEXT.P: Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Minister Shi Hwei-yow vowed Monday to display Republic of China sovereignty over the oil and gas reserves in the East China Sea by periodically sending patrol vessels to the area, where China and Japan are locked in a dispute over the exploitation of resources.

Shi made the pledge while answering questions from lawmakers of the main opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party Party during an interpellation session, who expressed deep concern over Taiwan's role amid the festering China-Japan dispute over East China Sea oil exploration.

Stating that the gas and oil reserves in the East China sea are under ROC sovereignty, Shi said that the dispute should be resolved through diplomatic means and promised that the CGA will dispatch patrol vessels to the area periodically in part to underscore ROC sovereignty and in part to collect information.

"This will be done to protect the ROC's maritime rights in the national economic waters and to avoid practices undermining the country's interests by other countries from taking root, " he explained, adding that "the move will also be significant in terms of proclaiming internationally that Taiwan has not given up its rights in the East China Sea."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-WRITER-CHOREOGRAPHER SELECTED A TIME MAGAZINE 'ASIAN HERO'

TEXT.P: Famed Taiwan writer-turned choreographer Lin Hwai-min, who founded the internationally acclaimed Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, was chosen by Time magazine as one of the 25 "Asian Heroes" in 2005.
Lin, who is also the artistic director of Cloud Gate, is the only person from Taiwan that made Time's 2005 Asian Heroes list.

The Asian edition of Time magazine has selected and published "Asian Heroes" for the last four years, choosing men and women it considers as either courageous, extraordinarily distinguished in their performances or good role models to inspire other people.

Introducing Lin, the magazine said that Lin's troupe once attracted over 60,000 people to watch an outdoor performance; in Europe, members of the audience cried while watching Cloud Gate performances.
Lin and his Cloud Gate dancers were on their way home Monday to Taiwan from Geneva, Switzerland, where they were videotaped for the theatre's latest piece, "Wild Grass II."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI LINKS' HAVE DIFFERENT FUNCTIONS FOR TAIWAN, CHINA: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The "mini three links" set up between two Taiwan offshore islands and two Chinese ports have played different roles for the two sides, with passenger transport services being the major function for Taiwan and product shipments being the main function for China, according to government statistics.

Since the direct trade and shipping links were opened between the Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the Fujian ports of Xiamen and Mawei in January 2001, ships using the route have made a total of 15,000 port calls at Matsu and Kinmen, with 44.3 percent being Taiwanese vessels and 54.5 percent being Chinese ships, according to the tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

During the same period, more than 951,000 passengers traveled via the "mini links" route, with 94 percent of them being Taiwanese, while 2.3 million metric tons of products were handled at the Kinmen and Matsu ports, with 2.298 million metric tons -- mainly gravel and construction materials -- coming from China. The remaining 1 percent of China-bound products were Kinmen-produced liquor and sugar.

Over half of the visitors from China entering Kinmen and Matsu via the "mini links" came for academic, religious or business purposes, while the other half came for reunions with their Taiwanese spouses or family members or for tourism.

A total of some 48,000 Chinese tourists have been allowed to sight-see in Taiwan as of the end of June, with 77 of those tourists overstaying their visas in Taiwan. Thirty-three of these remain at large in Taiwan, according to the DGBAS tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC MARINE POLLUTION CONFERENCE TO BE HELD IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The 2005 Asia-Pacific conference on marine pollution control and prevention will open Oct. 4 in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, with experts from the United States, Japan, South Korea and Australia in attendance.
Most relevant government ministries and agencies are co-hosting the three-day event due to the importance of marine environmental protection, according to the organizers.

They include the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Environmental Protection Administration, the Coast Guard Administration, the Fisheries Agency under the Council of Agriculture, the National Science Council, the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Kaohsiung City Government and the county government of the island of Penghu, as well as National Chungshan University.

Discussions are expected on issues about ways to deal with regional marine pollution, as well as those on marine fishery cultivation and marine resources management, the organizers said, adding that they hope an international communication channel will be established, through which Taiwan and other regional countries can request assistance in addressing marine pollution along their coasts.
About 30,000 oil tankers sail on the seas near Taiwan every year, which threaten the marine ecology, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORLD TRADE CENTER OPENS IN BANGKOK
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By S.C. Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan World Trade Center in Bangkok opened Monday in the Thai capital, the 38th of its kind run by the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Center (TAITRA) overseas.

Addressing the opening, TAITRA Secretary-General Chao Yung-chuan called it a significant move that will help Taiwan businesses further explore the Thai market based on the existing booming exchanges and jockey for good positions in the markets of the Association for Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

Thailand's keen efforts to develop its electronics, automobile, telecommunications and biochemical industries provide Taiwan with an extraordinary chance to further strengthen its role in two-way cooperation and exercise greater leverage among the ASEAN member states, Chao said.

According to Chao, Taiwan hopes to completes market deployment in ASEAN member states through setting up world trade centers in Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand to take advantage of the rise of an ASEAN common market.

Taiwan is the third-largest foreign investor in Thailand behind the United States and Japan, TAITRA statistics show. Taiwan channeled nearly US$6 billion in investment into Thailand last year, pushing its total investment capital up to US$11.2 billion. There are more than 3,000 Taiwan companies in Thailand.
Taiwan also is the principal foreign investor in Vietnam, the second-largest in Indonesia and Cambodia, the fifth-largest in Malaysia and the sixth-largest in Indonesia.

Peter Cheng, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Thailand, praised Thailand's increasing leadership role within ASEAN and voiced his belief that the Taiwan world trade center in Bangkok will help attract greater Taiwan investment in Thailand.

Thai dignitaries, including Satit Sirrangkamannont, secretary-general of Thailand's foreign trade and investment promotion board, Thira Tayangno, an executive with the Bangkok Bank, and lawmaker Chaowarin Latthasaksiri were also present.
Thailand is the third leg of a trade-promotion group led by Chao on a tour of three Southeast Asian nations. It has already visited Indonesia and Malaysia.
As part of its global exploration campaign, TAITRA also has recently opened offices in Bulgaria and Romania.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN BASEBALL PLAYER FOR COBRAS FOUND DEAD IN DORMITORY

TEXT.P: A foreign player who helped the Makoto Cobras win the Chinese Professional Baseball League first season title this year was found dead in his dormitory in Tamshui, Taipei County, Monday.
Mario Encarnacion, 30, of the Dominican Republic, failed to show up for a regular practice session this morning. He was found on his bed with the TV in his room still on and his refrigerator open.
Makoto Cobras manager Chao Shih-chiang said that closed circuit TV in the dormitory showed that he went out at around 6 p.m. Sunday and there was nothing out of the ordinary.
Encarnacion played centerfield in 66 of the 100-game season. He hit. 307 with 45 RBIs and was second in the league in homers with 17.
Makoto Cobras officials said that they will comment further only after the coroner makes a statement.
Encarnacion had claimed in late July that he inadvertently took a banned substance after a cold, and he was banned for two games by the league.
He then cut his finger while cooking and was benched again. He couldn't play last week because of gastroenteritis. But after recovering, he had played well, with three hits at four at-bats.
Prosecutors are now questioning the team doctor about his medical record and what medicines he was taking.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL ASSOCIATION INKS AGREEMENT WITH ESTONIA COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Medical Association (TMA) signed bilateral cooperation agreements with its counterparts in Lithuania and Estonia Monday, promising to strengthen wide-ranging exchanges and cooperation in various fields of medical care and promote human rights related to health.

TWA President Wu Nan-hei said that the Estonia medical association has since 2004 exerted a substantial influence in its domestic health, foreign affairs ministries and parliament over the issues of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization.
With the signing of the bilateral agreement, it will be a boost to Taiwan's effort to join the WHO, Wu said.

As this is the first time that the TWA established cooperative relations with an international health organization, Wu stressed that the move will help forge partnership relations with more European countries and engage in various levels of medical exchanges so that they will have a better understanding of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 33 DESIGN BIDS FOR CONSTRUCTION OF TAICHUNG OPERA HOUSE

TEXT.P: Thirty-three design bids have been made for the construction of an opera house in Taichung, central Taiwan, city government officials announced Monday.
The officials said that of the 33 bids, 10 are local while 23 come from the United States, Japan and European countries.
The officials said they announced the bidding Sept. 1 and are glad the event has raised the international profile of the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE REPORTERS INVITED TO COVER DOUBLE TEN CELEBRATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Two foreign correspondents stationed in Japan and five senior Japanese newspaper reporters have been invited to attend celebrations for the Republic of China's Oct. 10 National Day, officials of the ROC representative office in Japan said Monday.

Khaldon Azhari and Pio D'Emilia, two vice presidents of the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan, are among the invited guests, the officials noted. Azhari works for Jordan's Petra News Agency, while Pio D'Emilia is the Far East correspondent for Italy's Il Manifesto.
The foreign correspondents club held a video conference with President Chen Shui-bian July 26, making Chen the first Taiwan president to be interviewed by the organization.

Meanwhile, four Japanese papers -- the influential Sankei Shimbun, the Sekai Nippo, the Fuji Sankei Business Daily and the English-language Japan Times -- have all planned to release special issues Oct. 6 to mark Double-Ten Day, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC SHOULD INCLUDE THE VOICE OF THE PEOPLE: CIVIC GROUPSBy S.C. ChangCNA Staff Reporter

TEXT.P: Two civic groups dedicated to improving the nation' s media culture suggested that a mechanism be set up for citizens and consumers to have a voice in the National Communications Commission (NCC), which has been bogged down in the legislature.

Media Watch-Taiwan and Campaign for Media Reform said a "citizens council" made up of representatives from civic groups should have a say when the NCC reviews an application for a license to operate a new media or for renewing a license. In such cases, the council's views must be considered by the NCC, the two groups said. The council can also help the NCC answer complaints from citizens and consumers.
Members of the council could come from consumer, media watch, human rights, community and less privileged groups, said Media Watch-Taiwan and Campaign for Media Reform.

They said including such a council in the NCC would help it carry out its missions of maintaining market order, inducing fair competition, protecting consumer interests and promoting multi-cultural values while avoiding inappropriate political and business interference.
As to the members of the NCC itself -- the cause of a deadlock in the legislature -- the two groups recommended two solutions.

First, keep one seat for a consumers' representative who would sit with other professionals with humanities, education, telecom, information, mass communications, legal and economic backgrounds. A gender balance should also be considered for these "regular" professional members.
Second, the ceiling for partisan representatives in the NCC should be lowered from one-half to one-quarter of the total membership so that political controversies can be minimized.

The two groups were joined by such cable news stations as TVBS and Eastern Multimedia Group in calling for a "revolving door" provision in the NCC organic law that would ban members from participating in activities promoting the interests of political parties or candidates.

Members would also be banned from accepting donations from political parties or leading research projects for the government, political parties or candidates. They would not be able to work for any media and within three years after leaving the NCC, they would not be allowed to work as a board member or supervisor for a profit-making entity the nature of whose main business is related to the member's job at the NCC.

Media Watch-Taiwan and Campaign for Media Reform said they made the suggestions in the hope that ruling and opposition politicians will put the public interest ahead of their partisan interests and adopt a resolution to the impasse as soon as possible.

Academics also urged the "pan-blue" and "pan-green" political elite to look at the "fundamentals of legislation, " respect grassroots' views and talk with each other in a rational manner to build an institution that will operate for the benefit of all.

Liao Yuan-hao, professor of law at National Chengchi University, said the "pan-blue alliance's" insistence on naming NCC members according to the percentage of seats each party holds at the legislature contradicts the NCC's prime goal of de-politicization.

Liao suggested that one way out of the deadlock would be to have a rule on the qualifications and criteria for candidates and obligations of successful candidates who will be appointed by the premier to be NCC members.

Lai Hsiang-wei, assistant professor of mass communications at Chinese Culture University, said that instead of arguing about how to select NCC members, lawmakers should think about elevating the NCC's status to the level of the U.S. FCC -- the Federal Communications Commission is at the Grand Justice level in Taiwan, much higher than the currently defined Cabinet level. An FCC-level NCC would be "truly supra-partisan and independent, " he noted.

With regard to appointing truly independent and competent NCC members, Lai suggested that the government nominate twice the number of candidates, half of whom would be eliminated by public polls, a process that he said would remove "political hitmen" from the list to be finally appointed to the NCC.

Other scholars noted that a "screening and recommending committee" could be formed by the legislature in accordance with party proportional representation that would be charged with selecting NCC members through secret ballot.

Under such a proposal, the committee members should be experts from the telecom and other professional industries, who will select NCC members from a list of candidates, no more than a quarter of whom could belong to one political party. The committee would eliminate half of the candidates on the list put forward by the Executive Yuan.

In view of the lack of trust among Taiwan's politicians, senior journalist Yang Hsien-hung suggested that NCC members be decided on by a draw. "Only those chosen by heaven can stop quarrels in the human world," he said.
Yang also suggested that NCC membership be a non-paying job with a six-month term, during which members must not participate in any political activity.
Some others proposed the jury model used in the U.S. for selecting NCC members, as candidates can be vetoed by either side.
As the selection of members is the focus of partisan fighting, academics suggested that more attention be paid to building a sustainable institution by making it fair, objective and responsible.

For that purpose, they said, another rule can be made to define a procedure that must be followed by NCC members in making major decisions, a procedure that would include cautious, neutral and transparent public hearings. If the NCC fails to follow such a strictly defined procedure, its decisions could be declared null and void by a court, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 5.31 points to close at 6,123.92.
The bourse opened at 6,128.97 and fluctuated between 6,139.22 and 6,090.78 during trading. A total of 2.97 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$80.67 billion (US$2.43 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.6 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent.

The other five major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares both moving down at 0.5 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.4 percent and plastics and chemicals shares and construction issues both at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 504 to 438, with 143 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.058 to close at NT$33.246.
A total of US$735 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.288 and fluctuated between NT$33.130 and NT$33.325.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved up 23 points to close at 6,118, with 21,930 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved up 35 points to end at 6,125, with 173 contracts traded, while December futures gained 38 points to finish at 6,128, with 36 contracts traded. March futures remained unchanged at 6,102, with two contracts traded, while June futures moved up 21 points to close at 6,127, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,095 for October, 6,090 for November, 6,090 for December, 6,102 for March and 6,106 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
October TE futures moved up 1.6 points to close at 257.6, with 3,401 contracts traded, while November TE futures gained 1.4 points to finish at 257.5, with 16 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

October TF futures lost one point to finish at 911, with 1,849 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 0.8 points to end at 911.4, with 41 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down five points to close at 906.2, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD LASHES OUT AT OPPOSITION-PROPOSED CROSS-STRAIT BILL

TEXT.P: An opposition-proposed cross-Taiwan Strait peace promotion bill would bypass the executive arm and plunge the nation's democracy into difficulties, Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu claimed Monday.
The nation's top China policy charter made the remarks when he received Georg Jarzembowski, chairman of a pro-Taiwan group in the European Parliament.

Wu noted that the first article of the bill proposed by the opposition People First Party has the so-called "'92 consensus" as its premise, an issue on which he said there is no clear agreement in Taiwan.

For the opposition, the "'92 consensus" means a tacit agreement on different interpretations as to the meaning of "one China" reached in the wake of a cross-strait meeting in Hong Kong 1992, which paved the way for the first high-ranking meeting across the Taiwan Strait in nearly five decades the following year.
Wu said that for China, the consensus means the fleshing out of its cherished "one China" principle.

If the bill were to be passed, Taiwan politics would be thrown into chaos immediately, he claimed, adding that the country would then be in a very unfavorable situation faced with strong military pressure from China.
In addition, a cross-strait consultation committee would be set up under the proposed peace promotion bill that would enjoy enormous executive power, thus pushing the executive branch aside, Wu said.

If the executive branch will not accept its resolution, it is likely to be turned over to the judicial authorities, which Wu said would destroy the spirit of the checks and balances mechanism between the executive and legislative branches under the Constitution.
Jarzembowski for his part expressed his vehement opposition to the military threat posed to Taiwan by China and his opposition to the lifting of a 16-year-old European Union arms embargo on China.

He also said he was baffled to learn that Taiwan's opposition parties have continuously obstructed the review of a major arms procurement package from the United States, and that the E.U. is concerned about Taiwan's defense security.

He pointed out that political parties in democratic countries may bicker over differences on domestic issues, but claimed they are in unison when it comes to national security or foreign affairs issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN CAMP' AGREES ON SINGLE CANDIDATE FOR KEELUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Legislator Wang Tuoh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) announced Monday his decision to bow out of the race for the Keelung mayorship and asked his supporters to back Chen Chien-ming, the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) candidate for the post in the year-end election.
Wang, a veteran lawmaker from the Keelung constituency, made the announcement in the company of DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang.
Wang said he would immediately stop all campaign activities and would throw his support behind Chen's bid for the mayorship of the northern port city.

Wang's withdrawal marked a major breakthrough in the "pan-green camp's" efforts to integrate its forces to back a single ticket for Keelung and several other hotly contested cities and counties ahead of the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections.
"I have decided to quit the race in the hope that the 'pan-green camp' of the DPP and the TSU can win the Keelung mayoral election through unity and consolidation," Wang said.

Commenting on Wang's withdrawal, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Liao Feng-teh, who concurrently heads the KMT's organizational development department, said it remains to be seen whether Wang's supporters will be willing to switch their support to the TSU candidate.
Liao said he believes Wang's decision to bow out was made mainly because his support rating is low.
Claiming that the results of a string of public opinion polls show that Wang's support rating has been hovering at around 10 percent, Liao said his withdrawal from the competition was understandable.

With Wang's withdrawal, the Keelung mayoral election will be a three-way race, with the TSU's Chen and People First Party (PFP) standard-bearer Liu Wen-hsiung challenging incumbent Mayor Hsu Tsai-li, a KMT stalwart.

The KMT and the PFP are close allies commonly known as the "pan-blue alliance, " but Liao said it is regrettable that the two parties cannot come to terms on fielding a single ticket in the upcoming Keelung mayoral election.
Besides Keelung, Liao said, the KMT and the PFP will also have to fight on their own in the races for three other constituencies -- Taichung City, Hualien County and Miaoli County.

Eight years ago, DPP candidate Lee Chin-yung won the Keelung mayorship because the "pan-blue alliance" fielded two hopefuls. Four years later, Lee losthis re-election bid as the "pan-blue alliance" managed to field a single ticket.

Political analysts said it remains unclear whether TSU's Chen can win the year-ened election following Wang's withdrawal. In their views, Chen's grassroots support is not solid because he moved his domicile to Keelung only several months ago. Other variables include whether Wang's supporters would be willing to back Chen and whether the "pan-blue alliance" can strike a last-ditch deal to field asingle candidate.
Previous elections showed that "pan-blue alliance" supporters outnumbered "pan-green camp" loyalists in Keelung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT WINS HEALTH CARE SUBSIDY SUIT

TEXT.P: The nation's highest administrative court reversed a high court decision Monday by ruling that the Taipei city government does not have to return a disputed NT$10.8 billion it allegedly owed to the Bureau of National Health Insurance.
The bureau had sued the city government for owing the amount between 2000 to 2002 and won a high court decision in its favor.
The city government appealed, arguing that subsidies for health care insurance should be charged on the basis of where the insured live, not based on the addresses of the companies that employ them.
Many Taiwan firms are headquartered in Taipei, but their employees may not work in the capital city, and the local governments are obligated to pay for the medical bills of its residents.
Shuai Yu-ling, director of the city's Labor Bureau, thanked the administrative court for handing down a fair verdict, which is final.
She said the verdict exempted the city from the alleged duty of paying for non-residents' medical bills.

Health Minister Hou Sheng-mao said he was "flabbergasted" by the court reversal but said he will respect the rule of law. He said that if his department cannot appeal, he may request a constitutional interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-SPEED RAIL TASK FORCE TO REINFORCE SUPERVISION

TEXT.P: The Cabinet's high-speed rail task force held its first meeting Monday, with Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) Chairwoman Nita Ing delivering a report on the project's current state.
The task force was formed amid rising concerns that the nation's first high-speed railway is not coming on line as smoothly as scheduled.

Premier Frank Hsieh serves as convener of the special task force and Vice Premier Wu Rong-i as its deputy convener. It comprises officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of the Interior, the Public Construction Commission, the Council of Labor Affairs and other relevant government agencies.

The task force's main functions include supervision of progress in the high-speed railway construction, crisis management, crafting a comprehensive supervisory mechanism and land development in the vicinity of various high-speed rail stations.

During Monday's meeting, Ing told the task force members that the project is 86 percent complete and that THSRC negotiations with its core mechanical and electrical system contractor -- the Japan-based Taiwan Shinkansen Consortium -- will resume soon.

After Ing's report, Hsieh said the THSRC should recruit more government and state enterprises representatives as its board members in proportion to their investment in the company. He also asked the THSRC's three independent directors -- Lin Chen-kuo, Hu Ting-wu and Lin Wen-yuan -- to exercise their functions and strengthen supervision of the company's operations.
The administration has come under fire recently for the its decision to help source investments for the high-speed railway project.
On Saturday, Hsieh defended his decision to bail out cash-strapped THSRC, saying that Taiwan's international reputation will be at stake if the nation's first high-speed railway cannot be completed.

Hsieh said the government must step in to keep the project running because if the THSRC collapses, the government be forced to buy the project out for over NT$300 billion, according to the BOT (build-operate-transfer) contract.

Hsieh said he decided to have two government-related foundations -- the China Aviation Development Fund (CADF) and the China Technical Consultant Inc. (CTCI) -- invest in the high-speed rail project only after he read all relevant data and information.

Noting that the 345-km railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south will form the backbone of western Taiwan's mass rapid transportation network, Hsieh said that if the project cannot be completed smoothly, western Taiwan's development will be affected and the people's confidence will be dented.
Hsieh said the high-speed rail task force will strengthen supervision of the project and ask THSRC's original shareholders to assume responsibility for completing the project.

The multimillion-dollar railway system is Taiwan's first infrastructure project being built under the BOT formula, in which private investors build the system and return control of the project to the government after a specified period of operations.

THSRC issued a press statement late Friday saying that its last fund-raising move before the system's scheduled inauguration next October has been completed, with the CADF investing NT$4.5 billion and the CTCI investing NT$3 billion.

With the new funds, the THSRC's paid-in capital has increased to NT$104.5 billion. The THSRC press release said a bank consortium will lift its freeze on a NT$60 billion loan to the company following the CADF and CTCI investments. As a result, it said the company will have enough funds to ensure completion of the project.

According to THSRC tallies, the company's founders (or original shareholders) will hold a 28.52 percent stake; the government and state-owned enterprises will jointly control an 11.89 percent stake; foreign institutional investors will hold a 3.34 percent stake; other institutional shareholders, including the CADF and the CTCI, will control a 41.25 percent stake; and individual investors will have a 15 percent stake.
The high-speed railway will connect eight metropolitan areas between Taiwan's two largest cities and will be able to transport at least 300,000 passengers daily when it becomes fully operational.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON-INDUCED AGRICULTURAL LOSSES ESTIMATED AT NT$260 MILLION

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses caused by Typhoon Longwang have reached an estimated NT$260 million, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday.
According to COA tallies, rice, bananas, Chufeng grapes and leafy vegetables were hardest hit, with 8,244 hectares of farmland affected.

As the eastern county of Hualien bore the brunt of the storm, COA officials said, the government will offer soft loans for farmers in the county to rehabilitate their typhoon-damaged rice paddies, vegetable farms and orchards.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Macabre Clues Advance Inquiry in Bali Attacks In the first
Investigators in Bali made rapid progress on Sunday in the first 24 hours after a series of bombs killed 22 people in a restaurant on a busy street and in two beachfront restaurants five miles away, in part owing to a macabre bit of luck. As they sifted through bodies and body p arts, they say, they found the heads of three men and three sets of legs, with no middles, the forensic signature of suicide bombings. One head was more than 75 feet from the rest of the body.
Wall Street Journal: Lowering the Wall, China Irks U.S. as It Uses Trade To Embellish Newfound Clout
Since March, Beijing has opened free-trade talks with South Korea, Pakistan, Australia and Iceland. In November, it inked deals with Thailand, Malaysia and eight other Southeast Asian countries. Even though China's government still controls large swaths of the country's economy, it has sealed or is seeking free-trade pacts with 25 countries -- up from zero two years ago. Having created a credible army and a boomin g economy, China is positioning itself as a leader of global trade and investment, rivaling the U.S. in one of its traditional spheres of influence. As a result, China's market clout is making it a rallying point for countries looking for a counterweight to the world's lone superpower. All this is raising alarms within the Bush administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN HOLD AVIATION TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Officials from Taiwan and Japan met in Tokyo Monday to discuss the possibility of increasing air routes and the number of flights between the two countries, a spokesman for the Republic of China's representative office in Japan said.
The spokesman would not elaborate on the content of th talks on the ground that the two sides have yet to finalize their negotiations.

According to the official, the number of Taiwan tourists to Japan has increased significantly since Japan offered visa-free treatment for Taiwan citizens in March, resulting in difficulties for Japanese passengers to secure flight seats to Taiwan.

Both of Taiwan's two largest carriers -- China Airlines and EVA Airways -- hope to operate flight services to more Japanese destinations, the official said, adding that Japan is more active in seeking the right to extend its Japan-Taiwan cargo flights to more foreign destinations.
The Taiwan delegation to the aviation talks comprises six officials from aviation and foreign affairs departments, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 4, or the second day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1669: Rembrandt van Rijn, Dutch painter whose works are unmatched in their portrayal of subtle human emotions, dies at the age of 63.
1777: U.S. forces led by George Washington attack the British at Germantown but are repulsed.
1822: Rutherford B. Hayes, the 19th president of the United State, is born. Winning the controversial election of 1876 by one electoral vote, he pacified the South by removing federal troops in 1877, supported the welfare of minority groups, and reformed the civil service.
1824: Mexico becomes a republic.
1830: Belgium becomes an independent state after being part of the Netherlands since 1815.
1878: China opens its first embassy in the United States when Chen Lan-pin presents his credentials to President Rutherford B. Hayes.
1904: Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, French sculptor and the creator of the Statue of Liberty, dies at the age of 70.
1905: Orville Wright, American aviator, is the first person to fly an aircraft for more than 33 minutes.
1910: Portugal is proclaimed a republic as King Manuel II flees to Britain.
1924: Charlton Heston, American actor, is born. He was best known for his appearances in such film epics as "El Cid" as well as "Ben Hur" for which he won an Oscar.
1947: The Russians successfully launch Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite.
1947: Max Planck, German physicist, dies in his home in Gottingen at the age of 89. He won a 1918 Nobel Prize for discoveries in connection with the quantum theory.
1949: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the USSR.
1949: The U.S. State Department reaffirms its recognition of the Nationalist government as the only legal government of China.
1952: The pacemaker, an external device developed by Dr. Paul Zoll of Harvard Medical School, is for the first time fitted to a human, David Schwarts, to control his heartbeat.
1969: Anthony Grey, a Reuters correspondent, is freed from house arrest after being held in Beijing by the Communist China for 20 months.
1974: The 75-member Peiping opera troupe leaves Taipei for the United States on a 72-day performance tour.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1978: The ROC Ministry of National Defense announces the successful development of the "Hsiung Feng" missile.
1986: A 12-member political reform group of the Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT) decides to announce the lifting of the emergency decree at the appropriate time and passes legislative principles for the National Security Law during the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: An Israeli cargo plane crashes into a residential area in Amsterdam, killing more than 200 people.
1993: Russian troops loyal to President Boris Yeltsin capture the parliament building in Moscow after two days of fighting in which more than 300 die. Vice President Alexander Rutskoi and other parliamentary leaders are herded into Lefortovo prison.
1994: An undersea earthquake rocks Russia's Kuril Islands, killing more than 16 people.
1999: Taiwan's U-Land Airlines forges a cooperation relationship with Vietnam's Pacific Airlines to operate flights between Taipei and Ho Chi Minh City.
2000: Yu Kuo-hwa, former premier of the ROC, dies of respiratory failure at the age of 87 at Taipei Veterans' General Hospital.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian appoints Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to take the place of Tang Fei as premier.
2001: A local basketball team financed by Chinese-language Internet portal Sina.com announces that it is officially quitting the basketball scene in Taiwan and relocating to mainland China.
2001: New Palau Ambassador to the Republic of China Johnson Toribiong presents the credentials to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
2001: The Republic of China government spokesman expresses welcome for U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks that the United States will not make deals against Taiwan's interests, describing it as "a very friendly statement" toward Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is true of the really great moral man that every act of his life becomes an example for generations, that everything he does becomes a statute for generations, and that every word he utters becomes a law for generations."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA 'NOT AWARE' OF PREMIER'S PLANNED VISIT TO ROC ALLIES IN AFRICA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is "not aware" of Premier Frank Hsieh's planned visit to Republic of China diplomatic allies in Africa with transit stops in European countries, a ministry spokesman said Tuesday.
Michel Lu made the remarks when he was asked about media reports that Hsieh will make his first overseas visit since assuming the premiership in February.
According to the reports, Hsieh will visit Chad and Burkina Faso in mid or late October and might make a stopover in the Czech Republic, Germany or Austria.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW IDEAS TO BE RAISED IN SUPPORT OF NEW DPP MOVEMENT

TEXT.P: A leader of the New Tide faction of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has said that he will continue to pour new ideas into the party reforms that he requested last week.

Tuan Yi-kang, convener of the New Tide faction, and Luo Wen-jia, a member of the DPP's Justice League faction and the party's candidate in the year-end Taipei County magistrate election, who said they are worried about the corruption and loss of ideals and capabilities of their own party that they claimed seems impotent in running the government and the nation, launched last week a New DPP movement in a bid to save the party.

The movement immediately encountered severe criticism within the DPP. Some party members even questioned Luo's motive in launching such a campaign, saying that he might use the movement to help him win the election.

Pointing out that they are not surprised to face such criticism from members of their own party, Tuan and Luo, however, made a statement Monday to express their determination of never giving up their idea to push for reform of the DPP.
In the statement, the two young DPP heavyweights said that they hope those who have questioned and criticized their reform ideas within the party can also "listen calmly to other voices."

Admitting that the movement they launched is certainly related to the year-end elections as Luo is a DPP candidate and Tuan is helping other DPP candidates to run their campaigns, they also said that the DPP has disappointed its supporters and voters' expectations, adding that "we have strong feelings about that."

Emphasizing that they have no intention of avoiding the responsibility that the DPP has to face since they have more opportunities than others to participate in the party's decision-making processes and to share more of the party's glory, they said they should be responsible for the quality of the DPP's governance and not allowed to only protect themselves without doing something for the party.

They further said that the increasing gap between rich and poor on the island is a fact, adding that the DPP should push with more sincerity and better plans for those policies that are in line with social justice and fairness as well as the public's expectations.

Claiming that they will never give up any chance to help re-establish the people's confidence in the government even though the ruling party only has a limited time to do so, they said that "currently, we only hope those who still want to support the DPP can first and honestly face the crisis and difficulties of the ruling party and then help revive the party."

Tuan said while responding to media questions that there are no big differences between the reforms that he and Luo have suggested and those of the other DPP members who have criticized their reform proposals, adding that "we and the other DPP members only differ over priorities and emphasis regarding party affairs."
Tuan also said that he and Luo would like to have further discussions with other DPP members on their reform ideas within the framework of the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

The Washington Post: DeLay Is Indicted on Two New Charges; Money Laundering Alleged in Texas.
A Texas grand jury indicted Rep. Tom DeLay (R-Tex.) yesterday for alleged involvement in money laundering related to the 2002 Texas election, raising new and more serious allegations than the conspiracy charge lodged against the former House majority leader last week, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCTOBER DESIGNATED AS 'BRANDING TAIWAN MONTH'

TEXT.P: To help Taiwan businesses build their own brand names and further sharpen their international competitiveness, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Tuesday that October has been designated as "Branding Taiwan Month."

A series of activities will kick off later the same day after President Chen Shui-bian unveils the list of Taiwan's top 10 brand names, MOEA officials said, adding that various executives from leading companies at home and abroad, as well as academics and experts will attend forums slated for Wednesday and Oct. 13 to explore brand name-building and value-creating strategies.

The month-long activities, jointly organized by the MOEA and the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , form part of the government's keen efforts to help push for Taiwan's industrial upgrading, as local businesses are increasingly facing falling profits due to their contractor roles, MOEA officials said.

The domestic economy must be further upgraded, and building brand names is the answer, as Taiwan is seeking to transform itself from a manufacturing powerhouse to a research and development center, they explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 18.2 points to close at 6,142.12.
The bourse opened at 6,141.74 and fluctuated between 6,158.68 and 6,114.02 during trading. A total of 3.23 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$86.71 billion (US$2.61 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 0.8 percent and foodstuff issues gaining 0.4 percent.

The other six major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares, both at 0.5 percent, cement stocks at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 521 to 408, with 154 stocks remaining unchanged.

La Repubblica: Squabbles erupted in ruling House of Liberty.
Squabbles erupted in the ruling coalition House of Liberty with Marco Follini, head of the United Christian Democratic Party, who accused Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of mobilizing politicians and media to attack him. He said that he would not be intimidated to change his idea. DOC.HEADLINE: RAYTHEON WILL PROVIDE SERVICE FOR SOME OF TAIWAN'S MISSILES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Raytheon Co. will provide full service support for the standard missile 1 (SM-1) program for U.S. allies, which will include Taiwan, the U.S. Department of Defense said Monday.
SM-1 is an anti-air weapon. Taiwan's Chengkung class frigates -- a modified version of U.S. Perry class frigates -- are equipped with the weapon.

The Pentagon said that the Arizona-based company has been awarded a US$36,862,686 firm-fixed-price modification under a previously awarded contract to exercise an option to provide full service support requirements in support of the SM-1 program, among them, Taiwan will account for 44 percent, or around US$16.22 million of the amount.
The modification also supports Egypt, Turkey, Chile, Italy, Spain, France, Bahrain, the Netherlands and Poland under the Foreign Military Sales Program.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60 SWISS PILOTS TO WORK FOR CAL: REPORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Swiss International Air Lines (SWISS) has reached an agreement with Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) on the transfer of some of its pilots to the Taiwanese carrier, according to recent reports in various French-language and German-language newspapers in Switzerland.
According to the reports, the Swiss airline is expected to dissolve its SAAB-2000 fleet during the coming winter, which is expected to lead the airline to lay off some of its pilots.

A spokesman of the carrier also said that the conditions set by CAL for the 60 pilots it needs are suitable for those pilots working for Crossair, a Swiss airline which was merged with Swiss International Air Lines' forerunner, Swiss Air, a few years ago.

Swiss Air, which was one of world's leading airlines, was merged later on during a recession in the world airlines sector by Swiss International Air Lines that now faces the fate of being swallowed by Germany's Lufthansa Airlines.

CAL apparently wants 40 pilots to serve its B-747 fleet and 20 pilots for its A330 and A340 fleet, but the Crossair pilots specialize in flying small, short-range aircraft to serve regional passengers.

The reports also said that those Swiss pilots who are interested in joining CAL have begun to apply for the new jobs. Swiss International Air Lines has also been actively helping its pilots find jobs with other airlines, including Etihad Airways of the United Arab Emirates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-UAE TIES A SHOWCASE FOR THE ARAB WORLD: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Sound relations between Taiwan and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) will encourage the rest of the Arab world to better understand Taiwan, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman (MOFA) Michel Lu said Tuesday.

Speaking at a regular news briefing, Lu thanked the UAE for its approval of a one-day stopover by President Chen Shui-bian in its capital -- Abu Dhabi -- last weekend en route back to Taiwan after concluding a diplomatic tour of various Republic of China allies in Central America and the Caribbean.

Lu also appreciated the protocol that the UAE accorded to Chen in his capacity as a head of state and hailed the country's courage to shrug off fierce protests from Beijing, stressing that the ROC government appreciates very much the UAE's cooperation and assistance.

The two countries are set to step up bilateral trade and investment, and Taiwan plans to open a representative office in Abu Dhabi, Lu said, adding that Taiwan's strong economic clout and its success in turning the once impoverished island into a rich country is the main reason driving the UAE to forge closer ties with Taiwan.
Taiwan-UAE interactions will help other Arabian countries gain a better understanding of the country and more Arabian countries are likely to "follow the UAE's example," he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR PENSION FUND NOT INVESTED IN STOCK MARKET UNTIL LAW PASSED: CLA

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs Minister Lee Ying-yuan said Tuesday the newly launched labor pension fund will not be invested in the stock market until a bill governing the fund's supervisory board has been passed by the legislature.

Lee made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in response to Premier Frank Hsieh's hope to establish a mechanism for hiring financial experts to buy blue chip stocks with government-controlled funds to boost their lackluster performance.

Not only the labor pension fund, but also all other funds such as the life insurance fund, should be invested in the stock market, Hsieh said, noting that most of Taiwan's public funds make only 3 percent to 4 percent in annual profits, compared to 9 percent to 10 percent by those of other countries.

He said it is wrong to invest Taiwan's funds in foreign markets because it indicates a lack of confidence in Taiwan, so he suggested making it normal to invest part of the government-controlled funds in the local capital market.
Lee said the new pension system, launched in July, is increasing between NT$200 million and NT$300 million each day and that can be used only to buy bank certificates of term deposits.

The CLA estimates that in July alone, NT$6.7 billion has been collected into the labor pension fund. Meanwhile, NT$76.4 billion in the "old system" pension fund is waiting be to invested in the stock market, a CLA official said.
Lee urged the Legislative Yuan to pass the bill for the fund's supervisory board as soon as possible so that the government can better manage it for the benefit of employees.
He promised that the supervisory board will work in a transparent manner to maximize profits and minimize risks for workers while being monitored by the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTD-RENMINBI CURRENCY EXCHANGE SERVICES BEGIN ON KINMEN, MATSU

TEXT.P: New Taiwan dollar-renminbi currency exchange services officially opened Tuesday on a trial basis on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, with travelers using the "mini three links" swarming to buy the mainland currency at Kinmen's Shueitou Port.

Six financial institutions in Kinmen and Matsu have been granted permission by the government to offer the currency exchange service. They include the branch offices of two government-run banks in Kinmen -- the Bank of Taiwan and the Land Bank of Taiwan -- and the Kinmen County Credit Union.
In the first hour after the new service began, more than 110,000 renminbi (US$13,590) was purchased at an exchange rate of NT$4.199 to one renminbi, according to bank officials.

A Taiwanese businessman operating in China said that he is happy to see the opening of the official currency exchange service because before he had to risk losses when buying the Chinese currency on the black market.
Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng said the move was a good one and suggested that everyone be entitled to use the NTD-RMB conversion service.

Premier Frank Hsieh announced last month that the NTD-RMB conversion program would begin, underscoring that it would only be opened in Kinmen and Matsu conditionally -- only local residents of Kinmen and Matsu; Taiwan residents who can travel between the offshore islands and China's Fujian province under the "mini three links" regulations; and Chinese citizens who are allowed to visit Kinmen and Matsu will be allowed to convert NT dollars into the Chinese currency or vice versa at legal banking institutions on the two Taiwan-held islands.
Hsieh said a ceiling of 20,000 renminbi per transaction would also be set.

In a bid to help facilitate private exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, the Ministry of Finance announced Feb. 28, 2004 that Taiwan citizens or foreign visitors entering Taiwan can bring a maximum of 6,000 renminbi into Taiwan per person.
