DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER LAMBASTES KMT LAWMAKER FOR CALLING HIM 'EVIL LAWYER'

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh lashed out at Kuomintang Legislator Wu Den-yih for making ad hominem arguments against him at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday, after Wu called the premier an "evil lawyer."

"You can ask questions, but you cannot stage a character assassination. You must abide by the law, so how can you say that I am evil? " Hsieh asked Wu after Wu accused him of being an "evil lawyer most of the time."

The war of words erupted when Wu, a former mayor of Kaohsiung who was beaten in an election and replaced by Hsieh, questioned Hsieh about the appropriateness of demanding two government-controlled foundations to chip in NT$7.5 billion to help the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) tide over its financial difficulties.

Wu said that instead of letting THSRC Chairperson Nita Ing find the money herself, the government demanded that the China Aviation Development Foundation and China Technical Consultant, Inc. (CTCI Foundation) come to the rescue, which resulted in Ing "dragging the government down with her as she went down a well."
And yet, Wu continued, the premier had the audacity to compare his actions to the rescue of well-digger Liu Ching-teh, who was buried alive for 26 hours several days ago.
At that point, Hsieh tried to answer but was interrupted by Wu, who asked the speaker of the legislature to prevent Hsieh from replying.

Wu then quoted lawyer Chen Chang-wen as questioning the justification of the government to move so large an amount of money into the high-speed rail project, claiming that Chen is a righteous lawyer and "you're most of the time an evil lawyer."

After protesting Wu's character assassination, Hsieh fired back saying, "When an evil man looks at a righteous man, the righteous man becomes evil in his eyes; when a righteous man looks at an evil man, the evil man remains so."
In reply to independent Legislator Li Ao's allegation that he was "shouldering the responsibility for President Chen Shui-bian, " Hsieh said it was his duty to "take full responsibility as premier."
Li said he suspected that Hsieh has been the scapegoat for many of the scandals that should be blamed on the president, and the high-speed rail fiasco is but one of them.
Li said under the current circumstances, Hsieh has two options: step down, or "rise up against" his boss, which Li claimed would greatly benefit Taiwan.

Later, Hsieh told reporters that he was taking questions from the legislative floor because it was his constitutional duty, but standing there to be insulted by lawmakers was not. He added that personal attacks are "not permitted by the law."

DOC.HEADLINE: ARTIST ENVISIONS LINK WITH MAINLAND VIA BEAMS OF LIGHT

TEXT.P: An artist will bridge the frontline island of Matsu and mainland China with beams of light on Saturday to celebrate Taiwan's Double Ten National Day.
Hsia Hsueh-li a professor at National Taiwan University of Arts, said the program, initiated by him and sponsored by the local government to mark the national day, consists of two parts.

In the first part, Hsia said, he will install 36 searchlights on Chingpi, a small scenic fishing village in Peigan, Matsu, and project the high-intensity beams of light toward the sky over Fujian province across the narrow strait from Matsu.
The searchlights will be turned on at 8: 08 p.m. on Oct. 8 and project at an angle of 56 degree into the air for eight minutes.

The professor said the 36 searchlights represent the 36 islands constituting Matsu, also known as Lienchiang County. The 56 degree angle symbolizes the 56 years after 1949 when Taiwan and the mainland were ruled by separate governments.
The second part of the program will take place on Dec. 31, the eve of the new year.

In addition to the 36 searchlights projecting from Matsu toward the mainland, Hsia said he hopes the Chinese authorities will project searchlights in the same number at the same angle from Fujian toward Matsu to form a bridge of light.
The light bridge would mark the determination of the two sides of the Strait to forsake war and to march toward peace together, Hsia claimed.

The professor said the idea came to him when he visited Matsu to conduct a class last week. His local students told him that the frontline island is suffering from economic recession because the Ministry of National Defense has cut the number of soldiers posted there and will withdraw them altogether in two years.
Local businessmen are trying to survive by developing tourism but the island's two airports are often closed in the winter because of heavy clouds, which scare away tourists, the students complained.
Hsia said the clouds, which often cover the islands, gave him the idea of using the searchlights, which will reflect from the clouds.
With the support of the local government, Hsia said he will approach the Fujian authorities in the hope that they will cooperate with him in the art performance.
If they refuse, Hsia said, the Lienchiang County Government will try to install searchlights in Fujian themselves.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT PACKAGE BLOCKED FOR 31ST TIME IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Opposition "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) used their slim majority in the Legislative Yuan to block the Executive Yuan's arms procurement package from being put on the legislative agenda for the 31st time Tuesday.
The package contains three big-ticket items, including eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

Also blocked were confirmation of President Chen Shui-bian's nominations for Control Yuan members and two bills drafted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its " pan-green" camp ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , concerning ill-gotten political party assets.
But the Procedure Committee put the draft National Communications Commission (NCC) bill on the top of the agenda of the legislature's next meeting.
The controversial NCC may soon face a vote as a mandatory four-month consultation period among various parties has expired.

At stake is the composition of the commission; the opposition parties want the NCC to be comprised of members in proportion to the number of seats each party holds in the legislature, while the DPP insists that political parties should keep their hands off and let experts and scholars serve on the commission, so that media freedoms will not be affected.
Several "pan-blue alliance"-initiated bills were put on the agenda.

These include the cross-strait peace promotion bill, condemnation of Premier Frank Hsieh, the 319 "truth investigation commission," the draft Central Election Commission organic law and draft amendment to the court organic law.
A draft anti-aggression peace bill proposed by the legislative caucus of Taiwan Solidarity Union was also put on the agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MARK WORLD ANIMAL DAY WITH MOVIE FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: A group of local animal and environmental protection organizations will celebrate the Oct. 4 World Animal Day by opening a film festival on Oct. 14 showcasing movies and documentaries on animals to remind people to respect all forms of animal life.

The free 21 movies and documentaries will open in Taipei Oct. 14 and then travel to Taichung Nov. 1-3 and Kaohsiung Nov. 5-12. Detailed information is available at www.east.org.tw/animal-movie/index.htm.

According to the president of one of the organizers, Chu Cheng-hung from the Environment and Animal Society of Taiwan (EAST) , the films will help people to think over the close relationships between human beings and other animals.
Unfortunately, the most direct contact most people with animals are "eating their flesh, drinking their blood and wearing their furs, "Chu added.

Around 300 million chickens are slaughtered and cooked each year in Taiwan, with that number being a small portion of the 46 billion chickens killed worldwide, EAST executive member Chen Yu-min said, noting that chickens are the second-most eaten animal by humans, behind fish.

World Animal Day was started in 1931 at a convention of ecologists in Florence, Italy as a way of highlighting the plight of endangered species. Since then it has grown to encompass all kinds of animal life and has been widely celebrated in many countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: BNHI TO SEEK CONSTITUTIONAL INTERPRETATION ON HEALTH SUBSIDY DISPUTE

TEXT.P: The Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) will request a constitutional interpretation in connection with a health care subsidy dispute with the Taipei city government, a bureau official said Tuesday.

According to BNHI Vice President Chou Li-fang, the bureau will file its petition with the Council of Grand Justices after it receives the written judgment from the country's highest administrative court on the dispute.
The bureau had unsuccessfully sued the city government for NT$10.8 billion (US$324.42 million) in National Health Insurance subsidies it claimed was owed by the city government.

The Supreme Administrative Court ruled a day earlier that the city government owes nothing, supporting the city government's argument that the subsidies should be charged on the basis of where the insured register their residence, not based on the addresses of the companies that employ them.
Many Taiwan firms are headquartered in Taipei, but their employees may not live in the capital city, and the local governments are therefore obligated to pay for the medical bills of their residents.
Commenting on the case during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan, Premier Frank Hsieh claimed the administrative court ruling will "turn the entire nation upside down."

Hsieh pointed out that many companies such as the Chinese Petroleum Corp. and Formosa Plastics Corp. pay their business taxes to the Taipei city government because they are headquartered in the city, although their polluting factories are located elsewhere.
Hsieh said the Cabinet might mark down the ratio of tax revenues to be allocated to Taipei City in order to fill the financial shortfall in the National Health Insurance program.
In response, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou claimed it would be "completely unlawful" for the Cabinet to do so, because health insurance subsidies and tax revenue allocation are two different issues.
Moreover, Ma added, the Cabinet is in no position to deduct the amount, since the administrative court has determined that the city government does not owe the BNHI the amount in question.

On the BNHI's decision to request a constitutional interpretation, Ma said he believes the ruling by the administrative court is correct because it is based on a previous interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices on a similar issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF EXTENDS SYMPATHY TO CHINA OVER TYPHOON LOSSES

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) sent a letter to its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), Tuesday, expressing sympathy for the devastation caused by Typhoon Longwang in Fujian Province.

The SEF said it was deeply concerned about the reports of heavy typhoon damage in Fujian and that the SEF requests ARATS to relay its sincere condolences to the families who lost loved ones, and sympathy to those displaced or who suffered great property damage.
The SEF also thanked ARATS for its kind gesture to the SEF two days earlier over the damage to Taiwan by the same typhoon.
Longwang, the 19th typhoon this year, hit Taiwan last weekend, causing two deaths and injuring 53 people before moving across the strait to make landfall in Fujian Province.

According to wire service reports, at least 15 people there died in flooding caused by torrential rain brought by the typhoon. The typhoon also forced 537,000 residents to evacuate from Fujian and destroyed some 5,500 houses and crops on over 45,000 hectares of farmland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, PHILIPPINES TO BEGIN AGRICULTURAL TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Philippines, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Emerson T. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: After more than four years of efforts, Taiwan and the Philippines finally signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on agricultural and fishery cooperation, setting the stage for substantive talks in the field, Republic of China Representative Wu Hsin-hsing said here Monday.

Wu, Taipei's top liaison official to the Philippines in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two countries, made the remarks to the CNA after presenting an ROC national flag to an overseas Chinese group that will take part in the Oct. 10 national day celebration activities in Taipei.

According to Wu, the MOU was inked Sept. 30 in Taipei by Wu and the Philippine representative stationed there. ROC Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Lee Jen-Chyuan and his Philippine counterpart were also present.

Under the terms of the pact, a technical task force will be formed on each side soon and the two teams are required to start bilateral negotiations on cooperative ventures and hold a preparatory meeting for the first Taiwan-Philippines agricultural cooperation conference, he said, adding that the Philippine side also asked Taiwan to open up its market to farm produce from the Philippines such as bananas, pineapples, mangoes and coconuts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR BRAND NAMES MADE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian hailed Tuesday Taiwan's success in developing into a knowledge economy and called for joint efforts to create high quality "made in Taiwan" brands.
Chen made the call in a ceremony marking the start of "Branding Taiwan Month, " in which he presented valuation certificates to Taiwan's top 10 companies in 2005.

Addressing the ceremony, Chen encouraged Taiwan companies to pursue value-added transformation at a time when the country is facing huge economic challenges following a grave recession in recent years.

Taiwan must break into the world market competitively with its own distinguished brand names to sustain its economy, Chen said, adding that "made in Taiwan" now means high quality, rather than the synonym for cheap products the phrase represented in the past.
Chen expressed his strong belief that Taiwan enterprises will achieve the goal as they are flexible, adaptable and strong in innovation, design and creation.
"Keeping roots in Taiwan, exploring the global market" will be the government's No. 1 economic agenda, and creating own-brand names is the approach, he said.

The president also unveiled a list of the Taiwan's top 10 companies in the ceremony in line with the "Branding Taiwan Month" -- a series of activities jointly being organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

Trend Micro (US$1.077 billion) , Asus (US$882 million) , Acer (US$759 million), BenQ (US$354 million), Masterkong (US$317 million), Maxxis (US$264 million) , Giant (US$253 million) , Synnex (US$239 million), Zyxel (US$236 million) and D-link (US$225 million) are the top 10 companies creating the largest brand name values, in that order.
The combined value of these 10 companies is around US$4.606 billion for 2005, a rise of 11.5 percent over the previous year's level.

The leading three companies have maintained their ranking for two consecutive years, with Trend Micro's brand name value exceeding the US$1 billion level for the first time, a 14 percent increase over its 2004 level.

BenQ registered the largest increase of 27 percent in its brand name value, organizers said, attributing BenQ's growth to its acquisition of Siemens cell phone operation and predicting that the company will further prosper due to the booming business prospects of third-generation mobile phones.
Synnex recorded the second-largest growth of 20 percent, thanks to its foreign market deployment and improved post-sales services during last year, organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA PLANNING SCHEME TO PUSH LOCAL BUSINESSES TO BUILD BRAND NAMES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is launching a series of efforts this month to push Taiwan manufacturers to build their own brand names for the world market, Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday.

A "brand Taiwan" development project will be announced that will specify the efforts, including establishing a brand-name investment fund to encourage businesses to spend money on developing brand names, providing favorable loans for such investment, setting up an assessment system for the value and competitiveness of brand name and organizing a training program for talent in the branding business, Ho noted.
The minister made the announcement at a ceremony to name Taiwan's top 10 brand names of the year.

The output of Taiwan's top 20 brand names of the year totaled some NT$180 billion (US$5.4 billion), marking a growth of 30 percent over the level of the previous year, Ho said, adding that she expects larger growth next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN STUDENTS WANT TO PURSUE ADVANCED STUDIES IN U.S., CHINA

TEXT.P: The United States and China are the destinations most favored by Taiwan students wishing to pursue advanced studies, according to the results of an online survey released Tuesday.
The survey, conducted by Career.com.tw, found that the United States was the top choice at 43.7 percent, followed by China at 15.4 percent and Britain at 15.1 percent.

Despite the government's refusal to recognize academic qualifications issued by Chinese colleges and universities, 63 percent of those polled said that this will not affect their willingness to study there.

The survey also found Peking University to be the most popular, with 38 percent of the respondents saying they would like to study there, followed by Tsinghua University at 14 percent and Fudan University at 9.5 percent.
The survey found that employment considerations are the biggest drive for pursuing studies in China, with business administration the top choice.

Also, because the universities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait excel in their own distinctive ways, China, which excels in the humanities, international relations and Chinese medicine, also attracts a lot of Taiwanese students.

The survey found that Taiwanese students are curious about studying in China, although in comparison with other countries, the channels for studying there are not very open. This, according to the website, is why many inquire about studying in China but few actually go.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES FROM TYPHOON LONGWANG TOP NT$300 MILLION

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses caused by Typhoon Longwang had increased to some NT$320 million (US$9.61 million) , according to the latest estimate released Tuesday by the Council of Agriculture.
The amount includes NT$312 million in crop losses and NT$9 million in losses from damage to farming facilities.

The agricultural sectors in 13 counties are affected by the typhoon, with the hardest-hit being Changhua County, which suffered NT$183 million in agricultural losses. Other hard-hit areas are Hualien, Chiayi and Tainan counties.
The affected crops include rice, grapes and leafy vegetables.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUDITOR GENERAL FINDS 6 'MAJOR FLAWS' IN KAOHSIUNG MRT PROJECT

TEXT.P: Auditor-General Su Chen-ping said Tuesday that six "major flaws" have been found in the construction of Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit system, a finding that will be referred to the Control Yuan.
However, no-one will handle the case at the Control Yuan, as its members that President Chen Shui-bian has tried to appoint have been rejected by the Legislative Yuan.
According to Su, the first problem with the MRT is that the "build-operate-transfer" (BOT) model adopted to build the system has not been effective in attracting private investment.

The second problem is that Siemens AG, one of the shareholders, has not invested the amount set by the investor selection committee, while its conditions for its collection of royalty fees are "not reasonable," Su claimed.

Thirdly, the government has incurred losses as a result of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) failing to implement provisions regarding the adjustment of building costs in accordance with the contract.
The fourth flaw is KRTC's failure to monitor and manage the engineering consultant firms contracted to build the system, resulting in their lack of care and inadequate manpower.
The fifth is failing to check if all building fees have been paid on time as there have been reports of delays in payment.
The sixth is failing to test drive in accordance with the schedule, while even schedule setting and monitoring are a problem.
Su made his statements in reply to opposition People First Party Legislator Chang Hsien-yao's question about the government's budget for the project.
He said the six defects were found during an investigation into the city's budget for the BOT project from March to April this year.
In fact, he added, the Ministry of Audit also made some suggestions to the city government after reviewing its implementation of the fiscal 2002 and 2003 budgets.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF EXPRESSES REGRET OVER DEATH OF CHINESE SPORTS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) expressed deep regret Tuesday over the death of a Chinese sports official who succumbed to a heart attack Oct. 2 although doctors in a hospital in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, tried to save his life in a surgery that lasted 20 hours.

Li Liyan, a researcher of the state-run China Institute of Sports Science, was in Taiwan as a guest of the Taipei Physical Education College. He suffered a heart attack Sept. 29 while he was having dinner and was immediately rushed to the Kaohsiung Medical College Hospital.

According to an SEF spokesman, the SEF activated its emergency mechanism shortly afterward, seeking authorization from the Mainland Affairs Council under the Cabinet to notify related Chinese government agencies while making arrangements for Li's family to come to Taiwan.
Li's wife and two daughters were granted visas that same day and arrived in Taiwan Sept. 30. However, Li died two days later.
His wife and daughters left Taiwan for China Tuesday with his ashes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG COUNTY MAGISTRATE ANNOUNCES SUPPORT FOR DEPUTY

TEXT.P: In a last-minute upset as registration for the year-end city and county head elections closed Tuesday, Taitung County Magistrate Hsu Chin-yuan did not register for re-election but instead threw his weight behind his deputy, Liu Chao-hao.
Liu, a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , could only run as an independent because he only threw his gauntlet into the ring at the last minute.
Liu's rival, Wu Chun-li, though caught off-guard, said he would "take the news in his stride."
Hsu, who earlier served notice that he would run for re-election, was rumored to want to bow out and that his deputy could replace him Monday.

Hsu invited around 40 or 50 core supporters, including aboriginal legislators Lin Chun-teh and Lin Cheng-er and opposition Kuomintang and People First Party elected officials to a luncheon Tuesday afternoon in which he announced that Liu would run for county magistrate, stunning all on hand.
Liu, 38, was a lawyer, a Kaohsiung District Court judge and a Taitung District Court Judge before serving as Hsu's deputy.

Although Liu has no election experience, he has prepared himself fo the post, Hsu said, adding that he has observed Liu for four years and has found him to have ability and integrity. He also claimed that the decision will encourage young people in Taitung to care about public affairs.

Hsu said that he will retire Dec. 20 and stressed that he will not run again, adding that he has seen too much of the vicissitude in politics. Hsu was originally a member of the Kuomintang but has not received much support from the party and was forced to leave to run on his own. He said he was tired after fighting with the KMT over the past two decades and that he wanted to "close the chapter with the party."

Hsu withdrew from the KMT to run for legislator and county magistrate. He supported James Soong, who ran as an independent in the 2000 presidential election, because of his friendship with Soong. In the legislative elections in late 2004, he switched support to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP'S) candidate, who later lost, in order to win central government support for expansion work of the South Bend Highway and Fukang Harbor.
He went out of his way to pave the way for Liu and went to great lengths to remove the hurdles set up by the DPP and the KMT.

He created the impression that he would run for re-election to prevent the KMT from recruiting Legislator Huang Chien-ting, who won in the 2004 legislative election, and the DPP from recruiting another candidate.
After making sure that Wu will represent the KMT, he then announced that Liu will run.

According to supporters, Hsu feels it will be best for Liu to run against Wu, who is still mired in a graft lawsuit. Otherwise, he might have to face the more seasoned Huang in the next county magistrate election.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER THREATENS TO FREEZE BUDGET AS DOUBLE-DIPPING CONTINUES

TEXT.P: An opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union lawmaker threatened to propose a freeze on NT$123.6 billion in government budget Tuesday if it continues to turn a blind eye to what she claimed is double-dipping that costs tax payers at least NT$80 billion a year.

Lai Hsing-yuan was referring to retired government employees who find other jobs at government-funded non-profit organizations, getting two salaries at the expense of the less privileged and in violation of the law as well as a Legislative Yuan resolution.

She claimed that at least 58 retired officials are working at such government-funded organizations as the Institute for Information Industry and Taiwan Grains and Feeds Development Foundation, getting paid between NT$100,000 and NT$300,000 a month while receiving their pensions from the government at the same time.
Many of Taiwan's government retirees get a pay check for their monthly pension, in addition to enjoying 18 percent interest on part of their pension, a privilege that has long been criticised.

Lai said for these 58 retired officials alone, the government is "wasting" NT$80 million a year, a cruel injustice to the middle-aged and elderly people who account for one-fifth of the nation's unemployed.
She said that if the government does not do something about it soon, she will ask the legislature to cancel the NT$123.6 billion budget for the 143 non-profit organizations.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) agreed that the law bans government employees and political appointees from taking two paychecks after leaving government posts, but said that according to reports by the non-profit groups, there have been no violations of the law.

According to the law, it said, government retirees hired by non-profit organizations over half of whose operation fees comes from government budget must not get their original retirement pension, including the 18 percent "preferential" interest.

The government retirees in question include former teachers and soldiers whose pensions are provided by the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of National Defense, although there are some exceptions, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN FIRST' CRUCIAL TO RE-ELECTION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the concepts of "Taiwan first" and "Taiwanese identity" that he promoted during his 2004 presidential campaign were the most crucial aspects to his re-election.

Speaking during a meeting with Georg Jarzembowski, the leader of a pro-Taiwan group in the European Parliament, Chen said the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was able to win the support of more than half of the voters in the election because it was standing on the side of the majority opinion in Taiwan.

Unlike the past, when the rest of the world confused Taiwan with China, the international community has been better able to differentiate Taiwan from China over the past five years since the DPP came to power, Chen claimed.
He pointed out that the DPP is different from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) in that it believes Taiwan must renounce the idea of "one China."

While visits to China by then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong in April and May were unhelpful to boosting the two parties' campaigns in the May 14 National Assembly election, public support for the DPP has not been affected despite the obstruction by opposition parties of government policies, Chen said.
Chen reiterated his opinion that the so-called "1992 consensus" claimed by the KMT and PFP is totally non-existent.

Although Lien and Soong claim that the "1992 consensus" means Taiwan and China are each allowed to maintain their own interpretations of the meaning of "one China, " Beijing insists the "1992 consensus" means that the two sides both agree on "one China, " according to Chen.
He accused Beijing of attempting to divide Taiwan and isolating the government of Taiwan by inviting Lien and Soong to visit China but refusing to start dialogue with the DPP government.
The president said he has not visited China because he refuses to accept the "one China" precondition set by Beijing.

Chen said it would mean recognizing Taiwan as part of China and as a local government of China if he were to accept the precondition, which he claimed is unacceptable to the 23 million people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP EXPECTS TO WIN ELECTIONS IN 13 COUNTIES/CITIES

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which has entered candidates in 19 out of 23 counties and cities for the year-end election of local government chiefs, said it expects to win in 13 counties and cities.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang told a news conference at the end of the registration of candidates Tuesday that his party is expected to achieve the goal set by President Chen Shui-bian to control more than a half of the 23 city or county halls up for grabs.

Among the 13 constituencies considered by the DPP as shoo-ins are the counties of Ilan, Taipei, Miaoli, Nantou, Changhua, Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingdong and Penghu, and the cities of Chiayi and Tainan.
Lee said the DPP candidates are also fighting in the counties of Hualien, Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Taichung, and in the cities of Hsinchu and Taichung.
Lee said his party is facing fierce competition from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the elections, especially in Ilan County, Taipei County and Chiayi City, which the DPP considers must-wins.

However, he said, his party is optimistic about victory in the three areas in light of the fact that Ilan County has been ruled by the DPP for 24 years, not to mention that DPP candidate Chen Ding-nan has served as magistrate of that county before being named as minister of justice and is respected nationwide.
Chiayi City in central Taiwan will be a difficult fight for the KMT, which has never won an election there, Lee went on.
In Taipei County, the KMT followers might outnumber DPP supporters, but DPP candidate Lo Wen-chia has so far avoided confrontation between the two political blocs.
Instead, Lee said, Lo is trying hard to win over voters with his clean image and his Hakka origins. The Hakka account for a significant part of the population of Taipei County.

In southern Taiwan, which is the DPP's power base, the party enjoys steady support despite KMT attempts to win over farmers there by advocating exports of farm produce to China, according to Lee. Lee said his party will canvass voters for its candidates around the island, touting the achievements of the DPP administration over the last five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: When a President Is Not Spoiling for a Fight
In naming Harriet E. Miers to the Supreme Court, President Bush revealed that he has no appetite for an all-out ideological fight. By settling on a loyalist with no experience as as a judge and little substantive record on abortion, affirmative action, relion and other socially divisive issues, President Bush shied away from a direct confrontation with liberals and in effect asked his base on the right to trust him on this one.
Wall Street Journal: Bush's New Supreme Court Pick: A Loyal Aide With Scanty Record
In nominating White House Counsel Harriet Miers for Supreme Court justice, President Bush chose a candidate more likely to delight his business backers than his conservative base: a longtime loyal aide with little in her past to excite Republicans of offer Democrats a target. President Bush has sought a nominee who can help put his mark on the Supreme Court without kicking off an ideological battle. If successful, the move would help a weakened White House avoid a debilitating political fight.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 5, or the 3rd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1830: Chester A. Arthur, the 21st president of the United States, is born. Arthur became president after the assassination of James A. Garfield.
1908: Bulgaria declares its independence from the Ottoman Empire with Ferdinand I assuming the title of czar of Bulgaria.
1922: Tsao Kun is elected president of the Peking government.
1930: The first Balkan Conference is held in Athens, with representatives from countries from the Balkan Peninsula and Turkey taking part.
1941: Chinese forces heavily defeat Japanese invaders near the Milo River in northern Hunan Province, killing or wounding nearly 80,000 Japanese troops.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek accepts General George C. Marshall's proposal for a 10-day cease-fire to pave the way for a resumption of peace talks. Marshall arrived in Chungking on Dec. 22, 1945 as U.S. President Harry Truman's special envoy.
1951: The Republic of China's Legislative Yuan passes regulations providing farmland to soldiers.
1958: The United States delivers a batch of "Hercules" ground-to-air missiles, known in Taiwan as the "Goddess of Victory" missiles, to help improve the ROC's national defense.
1970 Anwar Sadat becomes the president of Egypt following the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Togo.
1973: Taiwan's first case of coronary artery surgery is performed at National Taiwan University Hospital.
1974: The third World Chinese Christian Conference opens in Taipei.
1976: The fifth World Chinese Tourism Amity Conference opens in Taipei with E. T. Chu, chairman of the Taiwan Visitors' Association, presiding.
1978: More than 20,000 boy scouts and brownies from Taiwan and 10 foreign countries launch an eight-day series of camping activities in the 5th National Jamboree held in Kaohsiung.
1980: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi arrives in Taipei to take part in the 16th Conference of the Asian Parliamentarians Union.
1983: Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: Premier Lee Huan instructs the Executive Yuan to set up special task forces to study problems concerning law and order, communications, environmental pollution, public housing, and economic crimes.
1991: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev pledges to match the United States in scraping tactical nuclear weapons.
1991: Cheng Kung, the first guided missile frigate built in Taiwan, is launched.
1993: Communist China breaks its moratorium on nuclear testing.
1996: Some 50 countries adopt a declaration calling for the earliest possible agreement on a global ban on anti-personnel land mines.
1998: The Judiciary Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives votes to recommend an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton's action during the Monica Lewinsky case.
1999: The U.S. House of Representatives passes a bill in favor of Taiwan's participation in international organizations, especially the World Health Organization.
2000: Hung Chien-hsiung, a 27-year-old man, donates 60 percent of his liver to his father in a transplant operation that is the only way to save the older man's life.
2001: Gao Xingjian, who won the Nobel Prize in literature in 2000 -- the first Chinese writer to win the prestigious award, shows his other talent by opening an exhibition of his paintings in Taipei.
2001: Republic of China Presdient Chen Shui-bian receives visiting U.S. economist Lester Thurow, exchanging views with him on the economic problems faced by Taiwan and the rest of the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The fact that a man is able to confront the spiritual powers of the universe without any doubt, shows that he understands the will of God. The fact that he is prepared to wait a hundred generations after him for the man of perfect divine nature without any misgiving, shows that he understands the nature of man."
