Los Angeles Times: Bush Selects Close Ally for Court.
President Bush on Monday nominated White House Counsel Harriet E. Miers, an old friend and political ally with a distinguished legal resume but no judicial experience, to replace retiring Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Bro. Eddie arrest ordered
Justice Secretary Raul Gonzalez yesterday ordered the National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) to immediately effect the arrest of Bro. Eddie Villanueva based on a warrant issued by a Mandaluyong trial court against the leader of the religious group Jesus Is Lord Movement in connection with a case for estafa.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: DoJ: Arrest anti-Arroyo evangelist Villanueva
Justice Secretary Raul Gonzalez has ordered the National Bureau of Investigation to arrest Brother Eduardo "Eddie" Villanueva on charges of estafa filed by a cousin of First Gentleman Jose Miguel Arroyo's in connection with the operation of Channel 11 on free TV.
The Philippine Star: 'Clear and present danger of terrorist attack in RP'
There is a "clear and present danger" of a terrorist attack in the Philippines in the wake of last weekend's suicide bombings that left 26 people dead in Indonesia's island resort of Bali, Interior and Local Government Secretary Angelo Reyes warned yesterday.
The Manila Times: Rest of Imelda's jewelry 'pillaged'The pieces of jewelry that belonged to Mrs. Imelda Marcos and that the Presidential Commission on Good Government wants to auction were only "leftovers," Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile said Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: Putin Strikes Visa Deal at EU Summit President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday hailed an agreement on visas as a step toward free travel between Russia and the European Union and pledged to be Europe's reliable partner as an oil supplier.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: EU opens historic talks on Turkey's entry to bloc
Turkey and the EU struck an eleventh-hour deal and launched membership talks Tuesday despite deep public skepticism over whether the wealthy western bloc would ever manage to absorb the populous Museum nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WANTS TAIPOWER CUT COSTS TO HELP LOWER POWER RATES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh gave Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) several directives Wednesday, instructing the state-run key power supplier to lower its overheads and electricity generation costs so as to help alleviate the pressure for power rate hikes.

Hsieh said he wants Taipower to lower its power plants' installation capacity rate from the current 20 percent of reserve margin to 16 percent, a move which he said could save the company some NT$40 billion (US$1.2 billion).

The premier also suggested that Taipower adjust its co-generation payment structure on its purchases of electricity from private power generators to further cut costs. The buying rates should be calculated based on fuel variety instead of on kilowat hours, he said.
Furthermore, Hsieh said, Taipower should also seek to improve or overhaul its power distribution systems nationwide to reduce unnecessary waste in power consumption.
The premier also urged members of the general public to do their best to try to conserve energy, saying that electricity is money.
Hsieh saw to it that commodity taxes on three types of oil products were cut in late September to avoid price increases at gas pumps amid spiralling international crude oil prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Bali hunt widens; dozens taken in by police.
Indonesian police have hauled up dozens of people for questioning as the hunt widens for those behind the suicide bombings which killed 22 people in Bali.
The Lianhe Zaobao: PM Lee confident of Indonesian resolve on Bali bombs.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has no doubt about Indonesia's resolve to investigate and apprehend the perpetrators of Saturday's bomb attacks on Bali.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICY ADVISER RESIGNS OVER ALLEGED INVOLVEMENT IN KRTC SCANDAL

TEXT.P: A national policy adviser to President Chen Shui-bian has resigned over alleged involvement in a suspected racketeering involving the hiring of Thai laborers for the Kaohsiung MRT construction project, the Presidential Office said Wednesday.

Chen Che-nan, a national policy adviser who also once served as a Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, tendered his resignation after prosecution authorities launched probes into his alleged role in Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp.'s (KRTC's) controversial hiring practices involving Thai workers, the Presidential Office said in a press release.
According to the press statement, President Chen has already accepted Chen Che-nan's resignation "in consideration of the sternest government ethical standards."
It is hoped that law enforcement authorities can uncover the whole truth behind the scandal as soon as possible, the press release said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Evacuee Hotel Program Extended; Post-Hurricane Lodging Costs U.S. $8.3 Million a Day.
More than 400,000 people left homeless by Hurricane Katrina will remain in hotel rooms beyond the Oct. 15 deadline set for their relocation, the Red Cross and the Federal Emergency Management Agency said yesterday, extending a program that is costing an estimated $8.3 million a day, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY LAUNCHES 'WALK TO SCHOOL' PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education launched a "Walk to School" program Wednesday to encourage school children to get more physical exercise by walking to and from school.

According to Ho Cho-fei, head of the ministry's Department of Physical Education, the "Walk to School" campaign was first launched by social groups in Europe and the United States for environmental and health concerns, and Taiwan is now following suit.

Ho said the ministry has designated Lilin Elementary School in Taipei County as the "demonstration school" where the program will be initiated for a two-month trial period. He added that other schools will be invited to take part in the program if the trial is successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD PAY MORE HEED TO BEIJING'S EXPAT STRATEGY: OCC HEAD

TEXT.P: A high-ranking Republic of China official in charge of the nation's expatriate affairs warned Wednesday that Taiwan should pay more heed to the strategy that Beijing has worked out to attract overseas Chinese and Taiwanese and to further diplomatically suppress Taiwan.

Chang Fu-mei, minister of the Overseas Chinese Commission (OCC) under the Executive Yuan, made the warning while reporting the commission's administrative work to the Foreign Affairs and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee of the Legislative Yuan.

Noting that China has upgraded the level of its strategy in dealing with matters related to overseas Chinese and Taiwanese in order to "further block Taiwan's room for survival in the international community, " the minister said that Beijing has also used its "united front" propaganda combined with economic development issues to actively try to get control over the educational resources of overseas Chinese and Taiwanese.

Beijing has also tried to drum up overseas Chinese and Taiwanese' support by attracting them to invest in China and to expand its influence over them, she also said, adding that it has also used pro-China media abroad to distort Taiwan's image.
"We must closely watch this and be on alert against it, " Chang stressed.

Chang also said that the Chinese leadership has not only attached great importance to its overseas "united front policy, " but has also made decisions to gradually apply the policy in the traditional overseas and Chinese communities, adding that by penetrating into various overseas Chinese and Taiwanese groups, China is trying to expand its sphere of influence.

According to the minister, China has also decided to set up 100 Confucius Institutes in various countries around the world to serve as its overseas base camps to promote the Chinese language and Chinese culture as well as to cooperate with the United States to develop a set of online Chinese-language learning materials in an attempt "to gradually monopolize the entire market of Chinese-language education."

Talking about the future direction of her commission's administrative work, Chang promised that the commission will continue to work on consolidating overseas Chinese and Taiwanese communities and to help promote freedom, democracy, human rights and peaceful ideas.

"We will also hold various activities to strengthen our work relating to overseas Chinese and Taiwanese education as well as to help the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace to promote freedom, democracy, human rights and peace in order to maintain Taiwan's superiority in this regard, " she further said, adding that "the commission will also help overseas Chinese to develop their businesses and encourage them to invest in Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE THAI OFFICIALS SAID INVOLVED IN KRTC LABOR SCANDAL
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Wu Hsieh-chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An investigative committee under Thailand's Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs said Wednesday it has discovered evidence showing that three ministry officials were involved in a labor brokerage fee scandal regarding the employment of Thai workers for Taiwan's mass rapid transit system project in Kaohsiung.

Three Thai labor brokerage companies -- namely Sincere International, PT United and BSB Co. -- were also found to have overcharged Thai laborers they sent to the southern Taiwan port city to work on the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) project, according to the committee.

The investigations, initiated by Thai Labor Affairs Minister Somsak Thepsuthin after some 100 Thai workers rioted in Kaohsiung in August to protest what they claimed was "unfair and unjust" management by a Kaohsiung-based labor firm, found that three Thai labor affairs officials were involved in the brokerage fees overcharging, committee members said.

The investigators, who have traveled to Taiwan to talk with the Thai laborers, discovered that the three Thai firms charged each Kaohsiung-bound Thai worker 150,000 baht (US$3,750) in brokerage fees instead of the officially-allowed 95,000 baht.

The committee will report these firms to the ministry shortly. The firms could have their business operation licenses revoked and be forced to repay the money they made in overcharging the Thai laborers, according to the committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULATION POLICY GUIDELINES TO BE ESTABLISHED BY YEAR-END

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said Wednesday that a population policy guideline will be established by the end of this year.

Su made the remarks at a Health, Environment and Social Welfare Committee meeting in the Legislative Yuan in a report on the social welfare operations of his ministry and the priority bills the ministry hopes to pass this legislative session.
Legislator Ho Tsai-feng of the opposition Kuomintang said that the population is declining and aging, with the number of elderly now accounting for nearly 10 percent of the total population.
Many Taiwanese women do not want to have children, and foreign spouses of Taiwanese men are "contributing to the birth rate in Taiwan, " Ho said, without explaining the relevance of her statement.

Su said the government is revising its population policy guidelines and that they should be established by the end of December. After that, the government will formulate a population policy white paper, mapping out the suitable population, the upgrading of what he described as "population quality" and its distribution around the country.
A government official recently said that Taiwan is estimated to become an "aged society" by 2018, as its population is aging at more than double the pace of developed countries.

Kao Hsien-kuei, vice director of the Performance Evaluation and Overall Planning Department under the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said Taiwan will change from an "aging society" to an "aged society" by the time the ratio of people aged 65 years or above surpasses 14 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLIANCE PROMOTES LAW TO IMPROVE QUALITY OF JUDGES

TEXT.P: An alliance comprising several local legal groups announced Wednesday that it will push for the passage of a law to regulate the qualifications of judges in the country.
Alliance leader Lin Yung-sung said the law will be aimed at protecting excellent judges and replacing incompetent ones to enhance the quality of judicial trials.

According to a draft law completed by the alliance, instead of recruiting judges through examinations as is now the case, judges will be selected from among law scholars or prosecutors and lawyers with at least six years of experience.

While a foundation will be set up to evaluate and monitor judges, the draft law also stipulates that a court made up of grand justices, judges and independent individuals will be responsible for screening out judges who are considered incompetent.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS URGE FINE INCREASE TO PREVENT CHINESE ABSCONDING

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , said Wednesday that the government should increase fines to prevent Chinese tourists from absconding while in Taiwan.

The legislators made the remarks at a Transportation and Communications Committee meeting in the legislature, where officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Mainland Affairs Council were invited to report on Taiwan's planned full opening to Chinese tourists and other complementary measures.

Tourism Bureau Director-General Hsu Wen-sheng said that currently, Taiwan travel agencies have to post NT$1 million (US$30,300) bonds when arranging for Chinese tourists to come to Taiwan and that after the full opening, the bonds will be raised to NT$2 million.

If one Chinese tourist absconds, then NT$100,000 from the bond will be confiscated and the government will also discuss with Chinese travel agencies in an effort to persuade them to pay an additional NT$80,000 for the estimated expenses of sheltering and repatriating each absconding tourist who is caught.

DPP Legislator Lee Kun-tse said the fines should be increased, adding that since the partial opening to Chinese tourists in 2002, Chinese have made 62,952 visits. Eighty-five Chinese tourists have absconded and 36 of them remain at large, Lee said.
If the government is planning for full opening, the number of absconding cases is expected to increase, he said.
"Fines should be dramatically raised in view of national security and social stability," Lee said.

TSU Legislator David Huang expressed doubt that the immigration authorities will be able to verify the identities of Chinese tourists. This and the past absconding of Chinese tourists have given rise to misgivings and the feeling that bonds should be further increased, he added.
Huang also said that Tourism Bureau should not target only Chinese tourists for its "doubling tourist arrivals by 2008" campaign, and should try to attract more tourists from Japan and South Korea.
Legislator Tsao Erh-chang of the opposition Kuomintang said that if Taiwan does not fully open to Chinese tourists, the campaign will be nothing but a slogan.
"Full opening to Chinese tourists is the last resort to reinvigorate the economy," he claimed.
Taiwan first opened its doors to Chinese citizens with permanent foreign residency or Chinese students studying abroad Jan. 1, 2002.

The government later allowed Chinese who have traveled overseas for business or pleasure to come to Taiwan, along with those who have resided in Hong Kong or Macau for more than four years and have work permits there.

The government announced in June that it plans to fully open Taiwan to Chinese tourists, adding that the complementary measures have been mapped out and that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should consult on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: LACK OF SELF-EXAMINATION HARMFUL TO DPP'S FUTURE

TEXT.P: If the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) remains unchanged and without undergoing self-examination, its long-term development will be seriously harmed, a DPP legislator said Wednesday.
Lin Cho-shui made the comments in response to a media question regarding his opinion about the "New DPP movement" launched by two young DPP members last week.

Tuan Yi-kang, convener of the New Tide faction, and Luo Wen-jia, a member of the DPP's Justice League faction and the party's candidate in the year-end Taipei County magistrate election, who said they are worried about the party's corruption and loss of ideals and ability to govern, launched the movement in a bid to save the party and get its "core values" back.

Lin claimed that a lack of self-examination will make the public less likely to support the party, which he said will not only be harmful to its long-term development, but also to the future of the nation.
The legislator also said that the ruling party should face its problems honestly.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT TO VISIT WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui will call on U.S. congressmen, meet with think tank scholars and Taiwan expatriates during a visit to Washington D.C. later this month.

Sources said that Lee's visit will take place Oct. 17-20. He is expected to call on the Heritage Foundation, a noted U.S. think tank, Oct. 18, meet with Taiwan expatriates over dinner Oct. 19, and meet with the press at the National Press Club (NPC) Oct. 20.
The NPC said earlier that Lee will give a speech at the club and take questions from the audience afterward.

The Formosan Association for Public Affairs, a Washington-based group promoting international support for Taiwan and which is in charge of Lee's itinerary while in Washington, has also arranged for him to give a brief speech at a luncheon on Capitol Hill.
Lee will probably meet with Alaska Governor Frank H. Murkowski in Anchorage before flying on to New York, Washington and Los Angeles, sources said.

Lee visited the United States in 1995 when he spoke at his alma mater, Cornell University, in his capacity as ROC president, which triggered a vehement protest from Beijing. After his retirement in 2000, he revisited his alma mater in June 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACEFUL TAIWAN STRAIT SAID IN RUSSIA'S INTERESTS
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A peaceful Taiwan Strait is not only beneficial to people on either side of the strait, it is also in Russia's best interests, visiting Taiwan-Russia Association President Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.
Substantive bilateral engagement between Taiwan and Russia will not be affected by the joint military drills conducted by Russia and China recently, Chang said.

In fact, he added, the Taiwan-Russia Association will continue to promote substantive bilateral ties between the two countries, despite China passing its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan and its holding joint military drills with Russia.

The signing of business contracts worth an estimated US$375 million during the visit to Russia by the Taiwan-Russia Association delegation over the past week is a concrete move telling the Russians that maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is also in the interests of Russia, Chang continued.

The contracts include one between Chinese Petroleum Corp. and the Russian Institute of International Relations on a joint crude oil exploration project; Taiwan Fertilizer Corp.'s purchase of urea (carbamide) from Russia; and Ho Tung Chemical Co.'s procurement of crude oil, according to Chang.

Chang, a former premier and currently a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said that in addition to continuing to promote the holding of the Taiwan-Russian Cooperation Forum, his association has also made efforts to increase Taiwan's procurement from Russia.
Such procurement, began with US$40 million in 2002, increased to US$250 million in 2003 and hit a record high of US$375 million this year, Chang noted.
Two-way trade between Taiwan and Russia stood at US$1.6 billion in 2003, a figure that rose remarkably to nearly US$3 billion in 2004, up 90 percent over the year-earlier level. Chang said.

He attributed the noticeable increase -- which he claimed was an eye-opener for the Russian authorities -- to strenuous efforts by the representative offices of the two countries and to the Taiwan-Russia Association.

Chang and his 20-member Taiwan trade delegation, which arrived in Moscow early last week to promote bilateral exchanges and cooperation in energy resources research, trade, economic development and financial reform between Russia and Taiwan, departed Moscow Tuesday for home via South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, edging down 7.11 points to close at 6,135.01.
The bourse opened at 6,136.66 and fluctuated between 6,171.87 and 6,125.11 during trading. A total of 3.34 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$95.54 billion (US$2.87 billion).
Only three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp stocks moving up 1.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares up 0.3 percent and construction issues up 0.2 percent.

The other five major stock categories lost ground, with both textiles and plastics/chemicals stocks moving down 0.7 percent, banking and financial shares down 1.1 percent, cement stocks down 0.5 percent, and foodstuffs down 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 509 to 401, with 177 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi calls for swifter electoral reform.
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi exhorted leaders of the ruling coalition Tuesday that the proposed electoral reform bill should be approved soon, otherwise the government will be in crisis. He warned that the general elections might be held ahead of the schedule without revisions to the electoral law.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DROPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar weakened against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0. 06 to close at NT$33.238.
A total of US$707 million changed hands during the day's trading. The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.298 and fluctuated between NT$33.209 and NT$33.298.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH AUTHORITIES TRACING CONTAMINATED BEEF FROM NEW ZEALAND

TEXT.P: Health officials of the Taipei city government seized seven boxes of imported beef from New Zealand Wednesday that contains endosulfan -- an organochlorine insecticide harmful to human health.

The contaminated beef is part of 77 boxes of New Zealand beef imported by three Taiwanese trade companies in September, each box weighing 25 kg. The health officials traced seven of the eight boxes that entered Taipei, leaving one box unaccounted for. Employees at the import company that bought the beef from New Zealand claimed they had "probably" consumed the beef themselves.

The Taipei health officials took the action after being notified by the Department of Health (DOH) that tests conducted in South Korea found that the endosulfan level in New Zealand beef reached 0.5 ppm, much higher than the allowed limit of 0.1 ppm in Taiwan.

The DOH contacted the New Zealand government, which found that all the contaminated beef was supplied by the AFFCO meat company, which sprayed its cattle with endosulfan to get rid of cattle ticks, causing the insecticide to be absorbed by the beasts.
The New Zealand government also informed the DOH of the three Taiwanese companies that imported the 77 boxes of beef from AFFCO in September.

The DOH called on health authorities in Taiwan's cities and counties to help trace the imported beef and urged meat stores to notify their local health authorities if they see any meat product marked with the number: 470309023629.
Endosulfan is a highly toxic pesticide that affects the central nervous system. Its use has been banned or severely restricted in many countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM CHAIRMAN TO SHUN CONTROVERSIAL BONUS

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Ho Chen-tan said Wednesday that he will shun an extra but controversial bonus and instead leave it to the company's coffers so that all Chunghwa Telecom staff members can share it.
Ho said at the Legislative Yuan that he will not take home a single penny of company bonus that would be controversial.

He made the remarks after he was accused by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Huang Chao-shun of possible maneuvering to receive excessively extra pay from Chunghwa Telecom by having the company's board of directors pass a resolution in September making Ho Chunghwa Telecom's CEO in addition to chairman.
According to company regulations, Ho is now entitled to a 5 percent share of Chunghwa Telecom's pretax profits annually as a CEO under a bonus system designed to boost company morale.

Answering a question by ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Wei-che on why the Chunghwa Telecom board of directors passed such a resolution to make the chairman a CEO as well, Ho claimed the decision was made in line with U.S. regulations, since Chunghwa Telecom is now a U.S.-listed company.

The legislators bickered about Ho's new CEO title after China Steel Corp. (CSC) Chairman and CEO Lin Wen-yuan was questioned by other lawmakers the day before as to whether Lin received salaries and bonuses that might exceed NT$50 million last year, which is much higher than most senior officials receive.
Premier Frank Hsieh promised Tuesday that he will see to it that compensation for state-invested company executives appointed by the administration is reviewed.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh suggested Wednesday that the Ministry of Finance review the CSC compensation system since CSC has been privatized and its part of company shares that are still held by the government are now under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Finance.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION WANTS MORE REGULATION OF GROUPER FISH SAFETY

TEXT.P: Consumers' Foundation demanded Wednesday that the government make an overall inspection of aquaculturists and regulate more rigorously the issuing of safety certification for fish.

The foundation made the appeal one day after an urgent announcement by the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture that a sample of groupers with safety certification being sold on the market had been found to contain malachite green.

The possible carcinogenic substance is a synthetic dye used to color silk, wool and leather. It is also an effective medication for the control of various external parasites of freshwater and marine fish. In animal tests, it has been shown to be harmful to the liver.

Fishery officials said the groupers in question were tracked down to an aquacultural pond in Fangliao, Pingtung County, where the owner claimed that he had asked another aquaculturist to provide him with smaller groupers as requested by buyers, so that some fish that had not been inspected were mixed with the certified fish from his pond.
Consumers' Foundation Chairman Lee Fang-ao said that the fact that traces of malachite green were found shows that the practice has not yet been rooted out, despite claims to the contrary.
The government needs to make an across-the-board inspection of aquaculturalists, Lee said.

Foundation official Wu Chia-cheng said the government should fund and commission private institutions in the inspection of fish and insurance of safety certificates, while a third independent party should also monitor the process of certification.
Meanwhile, a supermarket chain store where the problematic groupers were found voiced displeasure over the government's lax inspection of the fish.

Lee Li-li, Carrefour manager in charge of public affairs, said that groupers sold in the store have safety certificates and that store management were stunned to learn that they were in fact contaminated.

She noted that Carrefour had no intention of selling the expensive fish at first, but at the request of the Fisheries Administration, started to sell the fish Sept. 22 after the administration banned and later resumed the sale of the fish, promising that their safety was assured.
As consumers were not keen on the fish, the shop sold less than 100 of them and stopped selling them Sept. 28.
Hong Kong first blew the whistle on Taiwan groupers in late August, but the Taiwan authorities denied at the time that there was a problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO INFORMATION ON CHANGES IN U.S. ARMS DEAL: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Lee Jye said Wednesday that the government has not received any information indicating that the United States might change its arms deal with Taiwan.

Lee was responding to a Japan Times report in which William J. Fallon, commander of the U.S. Pacific Command, is said to have urged Taiwan to forgo high-tech offensive weapons, including the diesel-electric submarines that Washington offered to sell Taiwan.
Fallon instead encouraged Taiwan to acquire more defensive weapons such as defensive missiles, mines and helicopters, according to the report.

Lee speculated to lawmakers during a National Defense Committee session at the Legislative Yuan that the United States is worried that hi-tech weapons it sells to Taiwan would be obtained by China after Taiwan unifies with China.

Washington also fears Taiwan might lack the resolve to defend itself in light of the delay in the passage of the budget for its NT$480 billion arms procurement package from the United States, according to Lee.

He said such fear is unwarranted because Taiwan has purchased armaments such as long-range early warning radar and Kidd-class destroyers from the United States, although the procurement of the submarines, anti-submarine aircraft and anti-missile systems is still pending legislative approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPA GETS NEW DEPUTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: A former Kaohsiung city government department chief has been named deputy director-general of the Construction and Planning Administration (CPA) under the Ministry of the Interior, government sources said Wednesday.

Huang Ching-mao, 49, graduated from National Cheng Kung University's urban planning department and has a master's degree in regional and urban planning from the Asian Institute of Technology in Bangkok.

During his tenure as director of the Kaohsiung city government's department of maintenance, Huang oversaw a review of the southern port city's urban planning and renewal projects, as well as the drafting of a plan to relocate the city's Hungmaokang community to make way for new Kaohsiung Harbor container wharves.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 12 points to close at 6,130, with 24,357 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 15 points to end at 6,129, with 338 contracts traded, while December futures lost 21 points to finish at 6,124, with 54 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,142 for October, 6,144 for November, 6,145 for December, 6,145 for March and 6,157 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lowered.
October TE futures moved down 0.55 points to close at 259.95, with 4,993 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 0.80 points to finish at 259.85, with 48 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

October TF futures lost 8.6 points to finish at 898.8, with 2,135 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 7.6 points to end at 899.6, with 118 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 8.0 points to close at 900.4, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA REFORM ALLIANCE MAKES SUGGESTION ON STALLED NCC BILL

TEXT.P: A reform alliance of 66 civic groups urged the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Wednesday to address the opposition's "lack of trust" in a government-proposed national communications commission (NCC).
The Citizen Participating in Media Reform Alliance also called for the establishment of a professional and citizen's participation mechanism in the proposed NCC as soon as possible.
Alliance members were commenting on the most controversial part of a proposed NCC bill -- the composition of the commission -- during a discussion in a seminar held in Taipei.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) want the NCC to be comprised of members in proportion to the number of seats each party holds in the legislature, while the DPP insists that political parties should keep their hands off and let experts and scholars serve on the commission, so that media freedoms will not be affected by political party interests.

The alliance said that if the lineup of the commission follows the version of the Executive Yuan, then the Legislative Yuan could monitor them, but if the proportional representation model is observed, no-one will be able to monitor the NCC members.

To address the opposition's lack of trust in the ruling party, the alliance suggested procedural legislation to ensure that the NCC members are named in an objective manner, that the legislation also stipulates that NCC members follow public hearing procedures and that professional and civic groups participate in such hearings.
KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu claimed that proportional representation in the NCC "will not be a problem" because political forces will not interfere if citizens participate in the hearings.
Legislator Lee Yung-ping admitted that the opposition version is far from perfect, but claimed it would stop the ruling party from dominating the commission members.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG JEWELER GETS NT$6 MILLION FINE FOR UNLICENSED SHIPMENT

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong jeweler was required by Taiwan customs authorities on Wednesday to pay a NT$6 million (US$180,723) fine after he was discovered to have tried to bring a shipment of jewelry into the country without an import permit.

More than 500 pieces of jewelry worth approximately NT$30 million were found in his suitcase when the jeweler was going through customs inspection on arriving at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport together with his wife, customs officials said.

The jewelry was immediately impounded by customs authorities, and the jeweler was asked to pay the fine equal to four times the business tax that is due on the shipment before he can reclaim the jewelry.
The jeweler claimed the jewelry is not for sale in Taiwan and that he had no idea it is illegal to bring it in without an import permit.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70 DPP LEGISLATORS ISSUE STATEMENT IN SUPPORT OF NEW DPP MOVEMENT

TEXT.P: Seventy legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) declared their support Wednesday for a new DPP movement to revive the party's core values amid public criticism that the DPP is becoming corrupt faster than the Kuomintang it replaced as the ruling party in 2000.

The idea of a new DPP movement was first raised last weekend by Tuan Yi-kang, convener of the New Tide faction of the party, and Luo Wen-jia, a member of the DPP's Justice League faction and the party's candidate in the year-end Taipei County magistrate election. However, old guards of the DPP immediately jumped on them, saying that their motives are election-minded.

DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung issued a statement in support of the new DPP movement. Of the 89 DPP legislators in the 225-seat legislature, 70 have signed the statement, which calls on the party to reflect upon itself and "enter a rebirth."

Lee appeared with four of his sponsors at a news conference Wednesday. They said their support for the new DPP movement has nothing to do with the year-end elections, and that the DPP must heed the voices of the public and insist on being a party that takes care of the less privileged and maintains the principles of equality and justice.

The statement said that the DPP cannot always blame objective factors for the problems it has encountered as the ruling party, and that the party should re-examine itself and respond to the complaints from different corners of society and to the expectations of DPP supporters.

The statement also urged the government to take swift action to pinpoint those responsible for alleged corruption in a number of scandals, including the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit project in protest of the inhumane treatment by their employers and management.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRAND NAMES VITAL TO COMPANY SUCCESS: ACER FOUNDER

TEXT.P: Creating a brand name is the key to a company's success, and Taiwan's small businesses should adopt the strategy to pursue value-added transformation and secure sustainable growth, Stan Shih, former chairman of the Acer Group, said Wednesday.

Shih, "godfather" of Taiwan's PC industry and founder of Acer Inc., which is Taiwan's largest computer company, issued the call at a forum jointly organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council -- one of the activities for the "Branding Taiwan Month" that kicked off a day earlier and will run through October.

Pointing out that small businesses are usually more flexible in establishing their own brand names, Shih urged Taiwan companies to enhance their presence and upgrade their image in the global market through brand forging.
"I believe that Taiwan's small businesses are capable of doing so because they are flexible and adaptable, " he said, claiming that "one year will be enough to engage in such a task."

However, product competitiveness and business management are the two major factors that will decide the fate of a new trade name, he said, suggesting that Taiwan companies sharpen their business management to accomplish the goal.

The secret for a business to succeed resides in jockeying for an advantageous position in the market and Taiwan enterprises should rethink their roles as contractors, because "Taiwan brands build Taiwan image," he concluded.

Acer was proclaimed Monday the third-biggest of Taiwan's top 10 brand names, with its brand name value estimated at US$759 million and behind Trend Micro with US$1.077 billion and Asus with US$882 million. Acer computers are popular at home, in Europe and in Latin America.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHRINKING TRADE SURPLUS TEMPORARY: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's imports have grown faster than the country's exports so far this year and a shrinkage in the trade surplus as a result is just a short-term phenomenon, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Wednesday.

Ho made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan while answering question from opposition Kuomintang lawmaker Lee Jih-chu, who voiced grave concern over Taiwan's decreasing trade surplus and asked whether it might persist over the long term.

According to Lee, Taiwan has posted continued declines in outbound shipments over the past four years, ranking the country the second from the bottom out of 10 Asian countries in terms of export growth rates.

Taiwan's losing momentum in exports is not merely a temporary effect; rather, than it is an unavoidable trend due to dwindling competitiveness that in turn has driven away foreign investment, which Lee argued is a serious problem. She urged Ho to respond to the issue quickly and adequately.

Ho asserted that Taiwan's trade surplus shrinkage will narrow in the future after imported machinery facilities for IC and TFT-LCD production begin contributing to the domestic economy and soaring oil prices have stabilized.

The economics minister also pointed to Taiwan companies' relocations overseas as a leading factor that has led to lagging exports. For instance, she said, Taiwan's notebook computer makers have all moved to China in search of cheaper production costs.

Taiwan recorded a combined trade surplus of US$1.17 billion for the first eight months of this year, a 79 percent plunge compared to the previous year's level, government statistics show. It has been estimated that the country's full-year trade surplus will not exceed US$2 billion for 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELDERLY POPULATION HITS NEW HIGH IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: There were 292,000 people aged 65 or older in Taipei City at the end of August, accounting for 11.14 percent of the population in the capital city, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Taipei City Government.

The aging index in Taipei City, calculated by dividing the number of people aged 65 or older by the number of people aged below 15, stood at 64. The level is much higher than that for the entire Taiwan region, which registered 58.4 during the same period.
These figures represent a new high as the aging of the city's population is becoming more and more obvious, officials said.

There were 286,000 people aged 65 or older in the city at the end of 2004, up 3.1 percent compared with the end of 2003. The aging index stood at 61 at the end of 2004, which was 3.55 percentage points higher than that at the end of 2003.
At the end of 2004, 63.77 percent of senior citizens in Taipei City remained married, while 26 percent were widowed, 3.95 divorced and 6 percent single.
Meanwhile, 5,150 senior citizens in Taipei City were living alone at the end of August, accounting for 1.77 percent of the city's elderly population.

DOC.HEADLINE: PINGTUNG MAGISTRATE CANDIDATE TARGET OF VOTE-BUYING ALLEGATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung County, southern Taiwan (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: An independent candidate running for Pingtung County magistrate is being investigated by local public prosecutors on charges of vote-buying.

The public prosecutors searched the campaign office of Sung Li-hua and 74 other locations and found that since July, Sung's camp has given away more than 400 gifts at large parties through lot-drawings, including 229 bicycles, 70 electric fans, nine TV sets, 10 DVD players, seven microwave ovens, four refrigerators, two washing machines and one air conditioner.
The prosecutors questioned 67 people who attended the parties and 10 people who served as emcees at the parties held in various townships of Pingtung County to boost Sung's chances of being elected.

Chuang Jung-sung, one of the prosecutors, disclosed that the prosecutors' office confiscated 47 gift items from registered voters' homes and seized meeting minutes from Sung's campaign office that detailed instructions reminding staff members that all evidence about the lot-drawings must be destroyed one month before the election takes place.

The prosecutors wanted to question Sung, but could not locate her. Her husband, Tsai Hao, insisted that the parties had been sponsored by her supporters and that she had nothing to do with the giving away of gifts at these parties.
Tsai also said that Sung will speak for herself at a news conference Thursday morning and then go to the Pingtung District Public Prosecutors' Office to explain everything.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SUPPORTS JUDICIAL PROBES INTO KRTC SCANDAL: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian wholeheartedly supports judicial investigations into suspected racketeering in the hiring of Thai laborers to work for the Kaohsiung rapid transit system construction project, the president's chief of staff said Wednesday.
Yu Shyi-kun made the remarks after President Chen accepted earlier in the day the resignations of two of his advisers over their alleged involvement in the suspected profiteering scandal.

"Chen Che-nan, a national policy adviser to President Chen, and Chen Min-hsien, a Presidential Office adviser, tendered their resignations early this morning, " Yu said, adding that one resignation was faxed to the Presidential Office and the other was forwarded by a messenger.

According to Yu, President Chen swiftly approved the two advisers' resignations because he thought that the cases should be handled with the "strictest ethical standards." He further said the president didn't meet with either of the two advisers before signing off on their resignations.

Chen Che-nan, who once served as a Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, and Chen Min-hsien, who used to be vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) , are suspected of involvement in an illegal profiteering racket between the employer -- KRTC -- and a labor brokerage firm that has exploited Thai laborers.

The alleged racketeering surfaced after a group of Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit construction project rioted on Aug. 21 in protest what they perceived as unfair and unjust treatment by their management. Law enforcement authorities have been investigating the cause of the riot and all possible irregularities involved in the employment and management of the Thai workers.
"The advisers' resignations indicate their respect for prosecutorial investigations, " Yu said, adding that President Chen himself also fully supports judicial investigations into the case.
Yu further said it is hoped that judicial authorities can get to the bottom of the case as soon as possible. "President Chen will definitely respect the verdicts of the court," he added.

As to opposition lawmakers' call that Premier Frank Hsieh, who launched the Kaohsiung MRT construction project during his tenure as mayor of Kaohsiung, should take a leave of absence to facilitate judicial probes into his role in the case, Yu said since Hsieh has given a detailed account to clarify wild speculations surrounding the case, lawmakers and other social quarters as well should respect his explanations.
"We believe judicial authorities will investigate the case in a fair and impartial manner," Yu said.

Since the beginning of the KRTC scandal, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) approval rating has shown signs of decline, prompting a group of 70 party legislators to sign a statement of intent to reform and reinvigorate the party.

Yu said every political party in a democratic country should make self-reflections and self-improvements constantly because people can use their votes to decide which party should be in power or be ousted.

Claiming that the DPP is the most democratic and most active in self-reflection, Yu said the DPP will definitely be able to weather its current challenges and emerge even stronger through its internal soul-searching and self-examination mechanism.

Yu also denied that the KRTC labor scandal has tarnished the DPP's clean image, claiming that the DPP has never wavered from its reform-centric platform or its commitment to clean politics, transparency and accountability.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND PHASE OF FINANCIAL REFORM FREE OF FAVORITISM: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE

TEXT.P: The second phase of financial reform is by no means favoring a few domestic large financial groups as claimed by opposition parties, President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff said Wednesday.

"President Chen disagrees in no uncertain terms with opposition criticism that the nation's ongoing second phase of financial reform favors a few private financial groups at the expense of overall public interests, " Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said.

Acting on President Chen's directive, Yu said, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, Finance Minister Lin Chuan, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng and Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Kung Jao-sheng will co-host a news conference Thursday afternoon to expound on the significance of the second phase of financial reform.
Yu said President Chen's resolve to carry out the second-phase financial reform will not be sullied by unfounded criticism.
In his view, Yu said critics of the financial reform are mostly narrow-minded and short-sighted pundits and politicians.
As Taiwan is obligated to open its financial market to foreign investors in line with its World Trade Organization entry, Yu said more foreign banks will set up branches in Taiwan.

"If local banks fail to merge or integrate to generate economies of scale, they will eventually go bankrupt amid ever more intense foreign competition, " Yu said. Noting that major goals of the second phase of financial reform are to encourage local banks and financial institutions to merge so as to expand their market shares, Yu said the privatization of state-owned banks is by no means aimed at giving favors to private business groups as claimed by detractors.
"The privatization is instead aimed at improving operational efficiency and upgrading their global competitiveness," Yu explained.
According to Yu, U.S.-based Citibank's return on investment (ROI) reaches an average of 34 percent, while all Taiwan banks' average ROI is a mere 8 percent.
"Given this figure, how can our banks compete with their foreign counterparts if the government fails to take active steps to encourage mergers and restructuring," Yu said.
When he took over as premier Feb. 1, 2002, Yu recalled that Taiwan banks had a record-high non-performing loan (NPL) rate.

"Thanks to our successful first phase of financial reform, the NPL rate has been lowered substantially and most local banks now no longer face financial crises," Yu said, adding that he believes that the second phase of financial reform will further enhance local banks' global competitiveness so long as the reform goals can be realized.

Major reform goals include halving the number of state-owned banks from 16 to eight and halving the number of local financial holding groups, Yu said, adding that the goals were one of the conclusions reached at a cross-party national economic conference on Aug. 26, 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO STUDY NT DOLLAR-RENMINBI EXCHANGE TRIAL: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan-China currency exchange services that began Monday on Kinmen and Matsu islands on a trial basis have gained warm public response and the government will further study the issue to better service the people, Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday.

Hsieh issued the instruction during a weekly Cabinet meeting, in which relevant government agencies, such as the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Central Bank of China, were required to conduct an assessment which will serve as a foundation for future government policy-making after the current trial period has ended.
The government will move ahead with the service and gauge the possibility of establishing a currency settlement system between the new Taiwan dollar and the renminbi, the premier said.

The new Taiwan dollar-renminbi exchange services began Monday on the outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands, from where China-bound passengers, mainly Taiwan businessmen and tourists, can use their direct shipping links to Xiamen and Fuzhou in China's Fujian province -- popularly called the "mini three links" that were opened in January, 2001.
Transactions were sluggish on the first day due to a bypassing typhoon, but trading worth more than 700,000 renminbi was made on Tuesday.

Taiwan passengers highly praised the service, saying that the measure helps them save a lot of trouble in exchanging renminbi and provides them with a legal channel to get rid of fake Chinese currency despite the fact that the exchange rate is a little higher on Kinmen and Matsu than on Chinese black markets.

In the past, Taiwan visitors had to approach local tourist agencies on Kinmen and Matsu or black markets in China to exchange new Taiwan dollars to renminbi -- a practice that made many of them suffer monetary losses when taking in fake notes.

DOC.HEADLINE: BARRIER TO TAIWAN-SWISS JUDICIAL AID REMOVED
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 5 (CNA) (BY Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The barrier to judicial aid between Taiwan and Switzerland was removed Wednesday with Switzerland's supreme court ruling that bank documents relating to a corruption case should now be turned over to Taiwan because the Republic of China government has guaranteed it will not use the death penalty.

The Lausanne-based Federal Tribunal ruled last year that Taiwan should be given access to the bank documents, but later upheld an appeal from the family of former Taiwan arms dealer Andrew Wang that previous assurances from Taiwan that it would not invoke the death penalty against Wang were non-binding and had to be improved.
ROC Premier Frank Hsieh has gave new assurances Aug. 26 and the court was satisfied that they were binding, enabling the transfer of the documents, a Swiss federal tribunal judgment said.
Taiwan has charged Wang with murder, corruption, money laundering and fraud. The "no death penalty" guarantee covers members of his family, even though they are not charged with the same crimes.

The case concerns allegations that the French firm Elf Aquitaine used kickbacks in the early 1990s to persuade French authorities to approve the sale of six Lafayette-class frigates to Taiwan, and to encourage Taiwan to buy the warships in a deal worth US$2.8 billion.

Wang was an agent in Taiwan for Thomson-CSF, the French firm that sold six Lafayette frigates to Taiwan for US$2.8 billion. He fled Taiwan following the death of an ROC Navy captain, Yin Ching-feng, who was widely believed to have been murdered when he was about to blow the whistle on colleagues for allegedly taking kickbacks in the Lafayette deal.
The ships had all been delivered to Taiwan by the mid-1990s, and both Switzerland and Liechtenstein have frozen funds in Wang's and his son's accounts allegedly linked to the case.
The investigations began when Taiwanese authorities concluded from the inflated price that the deal constituted a serious case of international corruption.
France, Liechtenstein and Taiwan, investigating whether the case had violated their laws, asked the Swiss authorities to hand over the bank documents to facilitate their investigations.

According to media reports, some US$500 million remains frozen in 46 accounts with different banks in Switzerland as part of a Swiss investigation into alleged money laundering linked to the Lafayette case. Authorities in neighboring Liechtenstein have frozen around US$27 million as part of their own investigations, the reports said.

With the Swiss supreme court ruling, the biggest obstacle to Taiwan's access to Swiss bank files has been removed. As to when the documents can be transferred to Taiwan's judicial authorities, it's up to a final decision by the Swiss Federal Commission.
The Federal Commission is not expected to make a negative decision against the document handover, but it remains unclear when the commission will handle the case.
A Swiss official said the soon-to-be-realized first-ever judicial exchange will mark a significant development in relations between Taiwan and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSPECTS HIGH-SPEED RAIL TESTING TO LAND SUPPORT FOR PROJECT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh reviewed a 200-km train ride testing on Taiwan's first high-speed railway Wednesday to accentuate his support for the problem-ridden construction project.

Hsieh told Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) staff present at the railway's Tainan station in southern Taiwan where the 200-km ride testing was held that all difficulties will be overcome with perseverance and the project will have a lasting effect when it is completed.

The high-speed railway will connect eight metropolitan areas between Taiwan's two largest cities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- and will transport at least 300,000 passengers daily when it becomes fully operational by the end of October, 2006.

It was a pivotal personal transformation for the woman now named for a seat on the United States Supreme Court. Some evangelical Protestan ts were heralding the possibility that one of their own would have a seat on the court after decades of complaining that their brand of Christianity met condescension and exclusion from the American establishment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 6, or the fourth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1552: Mateo Ricci, Italian Jesuit missionary in China, is born. He spent the last 30 years of his life in China.
1807: English chemist Sir Humphrey Davy discovers a new metallic element and calls it potassium.
1860: A Franco-British force captures Beijing. China's Ching court is thus compelled to make further concessions in the 1860 Treaty of Beijing.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai forces the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander in chief of the Canton military government and begins to launch the second eastern expedition.
1927: The International Stock Exchange Center of the New York Stock Exchange is formally opened.
1937: The League of Nations condemns Japanese aggression against China.
1937: The U.S. State Department condemns Japan's invasion of China.
1939: Chinese troops win the first battle of Changsha in Hunan Province against invading Japanese forces.
1946: The Chinese communists turn down Gen. George C. Marshall's cease-fire proposal.
1958: Seawolf, a U.S. nuclear submarine, surfaces off New England's coast after setting a world record by remaining submerged for two months.
1963: President Hubert Maga of Benin and his wife arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The ROC and Uruguay sign a treaty of amity in Taipei.
1973: As Israelis begin to observe Yom Kippur, one of the holiest days in the Jewish calendar, a joint Egyptian-Syrian invasion force begins an attack on Israel on two fronts, triggering the fourth Arab-Israeli war.
1975: The 11th General Assembly of the Asian Parliamentarians Union opens in Taipei with more than 80 delegates and observers from nine countries taking part.
1976: Shiroshichi Kimura, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for a 16-day visit.
1980: The first World Congress of Chinese Medicine and Pharmacology sponsored by the National Union of the Chinese Medical Doctors' Association opens in Taipei.
1981: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is assassinated by Islamic extremists while reviewing a military parade in Cairo. He was succeeded by Vice President Hosni Mubarak on Oct. 13.
1986: The ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs decides to invest NT$1.2 billion in developing anti-pollution technology over the next three years.
1987: The National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center, comprising the National Theater and National Concert Hall, is inaugurated after six years of construction costing NT$7.5 billion.
1991: An Indonesian military plane crashes into a government building in Jakarta, killing 102 people and injuring more than 5,000 others.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin demands the resignation of his opponents in the provinces after putting down rebellious legislators.
1999: Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's most notorious criminal who raped and killed the 17-year-old daughter of television celebrity Pai Ping-ping in April 1997, is executed after being sentenced to death for his crimes.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian explains that the "stone" in his earlier comment that "the stone has been removed from the path" of his four-month-old government actually referred to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party itself and not to any specific person.
2001: A local banker urges Taiwan consumers to use "plastic currency" more often amid outrage against increasingly rampant currency counterfeiting.
2001: Some 40 representatives from the overseas chapters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) participates in a three-day joint meeting in Bangkok.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of apprehension, intelligence, insight, and understanding: qualities necessary for the exercise of command."
