DOC.HEADLINE: OVER NT$72 M. IN SCHOLARSHIPS, SUBSIDIES GIVEN TO ABORIGINAL STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The government approved a total of NT$72.44 million (US$2.18 million) in scholarships and subsidies for aboriginal students in the first half of this year, the head of the Council of Indigenous Peoples said Thursday.
Council Chairman Walis Pelin made the remarks when reporting at the Home Committee in the Legislative Yuan.

The NT$72.44 million in scholarships and subsides has benefited 15,967 aboriginal students, including 2,154 studying at colleges or universities and 13,813 studying at high or elementary schools, he said.
The government also provided NT$55 million in subsidies for pre-school aboriginal children during the same period, he said.

In addition, to nurture aboriginal professionals, the council approved 915 applications for scholarships and subsidies in the first six months of this year, while eight aboriginal students have been provided with full government funding to study overseas.
The government is also providing a subsidy of US$300 dollars per month to 38 aboriginal students pursuing master's or doctoral degrees abroad, he continued.

Meanwhile, Legislator Huang Chao-shun of the opposition Kuomintang said during the committee meeting that several officials from the council came to her office for business Wednesday afternoon and that some of them "reeked of alcohol." She asked if it is permissible to drink during office hours.
Walis Pelin said that drinking is not allowed during office hours and promised to look into the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILLING TO BRIEF LEGISLATURE ON ARMS PACKAGE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he is willing to expound on his administration's long-stalled arms procurement package in the Legislative Yuan to win opposition support for all relevant bills.
Chen made the remarks while addressing the opening of the "Shih Ming-teh Chair" at National Taiwan University's Political Science Department.
Noting that "investment in national defense is tantamount to investment in peace, " Chen said Taiwan must beef up its defense capability to ensure lasting peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen said it is his earnest hope that the opposition-controlled legislature can pass bills related to the government's plan to procure three big-ticket weaponry items from the United States.

For more than a year, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party has used its slim majority in the legislature to stonewall two bills regarding the robust arms procurement package for various reasons, including political bickering with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and fears of sparking a cross-strait arms race and squeezing funds for other national development plans.
Listed in the procurement package are eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine P-3C aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOOGLE URGED TO RESPECT TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Members of a pro-Taiwan independence group accused the online search engine company Google Inc. Wednesday of kowtowing to Beijing by referring to Taiwan as a "province of China" on its Google Maps service.

According to Wu Ming-Chi, president of the Washington-headquartered Formosan Association for Public Affairs, Google has deliberately ignored the fact that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state just to facilitate its plan to open a research center in Beijing.
Wu said the move is unforgivable and has damaged the company's reputation. He urged Google to stop yielding to political pressure for business interests.
A few days ago in Taiwan, the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union asked the public to e-mail Google to protest.
However, a spokeswoman for the company reportedly said that listing Taiwan as a "province of China" is consistent with international naming conventions such as those followed by the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATED IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Lilian Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York held a cocktail reception Wednesday to celebrate the ROC National Day and the opening of the office's new building in Manhattan.
Approximately 600 U.S. politicians and business people, members of various countries' United Nations missions, as well as Taiwanese expatriates in New York attended.
A ribbon-cutting ceremony was held to mark the opening of the 16-story building.
Andrew L.Y. Hsia, director of TECO in New York, said he is considering naming the building the "Taiwan Plaza."

DOC.HEADLINE: TONGLIT LOGISTICS BECOMES FIRST FIRM TO SET UP IN TAIPEI HARBOR FTZ

TEXT.P: Tonglit Logistics Co. became the first business to station itself in a free trade zone at Taipei Harbor since the harbor received approval from the Executive Yuan in mid-September to begin operations in the free trade zone.
Premier Frank Hsieh and Tonglit Logistics Chairman Hung Cheng-tung jointly unveiled the company plaque in a ceremony at the free trade zone.
Hsieh expressed the hope that more companies will follow suit and invest in the free trade zone, saying that Taipei Harbor has great potential.
Taipei Harbor received approval in May to plan a free trade zone with an area of 79 hectares. The harbor's free trade zone operations will mainly center around the logistics business.

The Executive Yuan approved the free trade zone project Sept. 14. It is estimated that the harbor will handle a volume of about 8,000 TEU (twenty-foot equivalent unit) containers per year and that annual production value will be NT$650 million (US$19.57 million). The free trade zone is expected to create around 400 jobs.
Tonglit Logistics was founded in 2002, and its business mainly focuses on auto component packing and build-up (BU) vehicle logistics.
In addition to serving as Keelung Harbor's auxiliary port, Taipei Harbor in Pali, Taipei County is also expected to become an international logistics and resurging center.
A 110-hectare warehousing center at Taipei Harbor is now under construction. When it is completed in March 2008, it will become anther free trade zone.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Experts Unlock Clues to Spread of 1918 Flu Virus
The 1918 influenza virus, the cause of one o f history's most deadly epidemics, has been reconstructed and found to be a bird flu that jumped directly to humans, two teams of federal and university scientists announced yesterday. John Oxford, a professor of virology at St. Bart holomew's and the Royal London Hospital who was not part of the research team, said "It's a huge breakthrough to be able to put a searchlight on a virus that killed 50 million people. I can't think of anything bigger that's happened in virology for many years."
Wall Street Journal: As Russia Squeezes Big Business, A Tycoon Decides to Pick a Fight
Russian President Vladimir Putin has largely succeeded in his campaign pledge to make oligarchs -- the powerful tycoons who emerged in the chaos of post-Soviet Russia -- disappear "as a class." Now, most of the country's super-rich are either packing up or hunkering down and tryin g to stay on the government's good side. Except Mikhail Fridman. Using bare-knuckles business tactics, the 41-year-old built an US$8 billion empire spanning oil, telecoms, banking and retail. Now, he's picking a fight with Leonid Reiman, Russia's telecommunications minister and a longtime Putin friend.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi urges allied party to support amendment to electoral law.
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi urged the United Christian Democratic Party (UDC), one of the ruling coalition party, to support a proposed amendement to the electoral law which will allow the implementation of a proportional system in the next year's general elections. He warned that the ruling coalition should make the revisions approved, otherwise it should be prepared to receive consequent results.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Senate Supports Interrogation Limits; 90-9 Vote on the Treatment of Detainees Is a Bipartisan Rebuff of the White House.
The Senate defied the White House yesterday and voted to set new limits on interrogating detainees in Iraq and elsewhere, underscoring Congress's growing concerns about reports of abuse of suspected terrorists and others in military custody, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING, OPPOSITION LEADERS HEAP PRAISE ON FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN SHIH

TEXT.P: Ruling and opposition parties were in unison in applauding Shih Ming-teh, former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , and his advocacy of ethnic harmony, inter-party reconciliation and cross-strait peace.
They made the remarks at the launch of the "Shih Ming-teh Chair" at National Taiwan University's Political Science Department.

In addition to President Chen Shui-bian, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, Legislative Yuan President and former KMT Vice Chairman Wang Jin-pyng, and New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming were on hand to greet Shih.

"The Shih Ming-teh Chair" plans to promote a series of research programs and lectures centered on the themes of ethnic harmony, political reconciliation and cross-strait peace each year and present scholarships.

Su lauded Shih for being a brave and humorous man with a rich life, calling him a prophet. He recalled Shih being involved in the Kaohsiung Incident in his younger days as a dissident, and his term as DPP chairman during which he promoted reconciliation to avoid inter-party bickering.
Both Ma and Wang said that Shih's ideals can help Taiwan overcome its difficulties.
Ma said that the most admirable personality trait of Shih is his consistency. He said that the public trusts Shih when he promotes ethnic harmony, partisan reconciliation and cross-strait peace.
"Although it is uncertain whether these ideal can be fulfilled, at least we should try to realize them," Ma said.

He also said that Taiwan's problems are not economic or diplomatic, and that if there were some improvement in ethnic harmony, partisan reconciliation and cross-strait peace on the island, Taiwan wouldn't have fallen behind South Korea in national development in such a short time.

Regarding the president's proposal that Shih coordinate a meeting between ruling and opposition party leaders, Ma said that inter-party reconciliation will not be easy given the fact that the perceptions on various issues is so far apart among the various parties.

Wang noted that Shih, who was imprisoned for 25 years in the days of KMT authoritarian rule, chose tolerance and forgiveness toward his political enemies after being freed. Moreover, when his party was finally leading the nation, he did not shy away from criticizing the ruling party if he felt it was warranted.
Shih is truly a man who pursues and dedicates himself to democratic ideals, Wang added.
For his part, Yok said that Shih has a broad vision and a romantic nature, traits that have aided him in pursuing his goals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REQUESTS PRIVILEGES FOR FORMER PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taipei has requested Washington to grant former ROC President Lee Teng-hui due diplomatic courtesy during his visit to the United States next week, ROC Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee said Wednesday.

Lee said he has sent a letter to the U.S. Department of State and has also held talks with Department of State officials to ask the U.S. government to facilitate the former president's immigration and customs clearance and provide him with security.
The U.S. government is expected to reply to Taiwan's request very soon, Lee said.
The former president is planning to visit Anchorage, New York, Washington, D.C. and Los Angeles.

During his stay in Washington, D.C., which is scheduled to take place Oct. 17-20, Lee will meet with members of the U.S. Congress, scholars and Taiwanese expatriates. He is also expected to visit the National Achieves and the Jefferson Memorial.
Asked about the issue on Wednesday, a U.S. Department of State official reiterated that any visits by Lee would be private in nature.
"Mr. Lee is a private individual, and we will view any visit in that regard," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR COUNCIL MAY OFFER SUBSIDIES TO ENCOURAGE DOMESTIC CAREGIVERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is planning to offer subsidies to encourage Taiwan households that need long-term caregivers to hire local people, a CLA official said Thursday.

The CLA may offer NT$5,000 a month to each household hiring a Taiwanese caregiver for 12 consecutive months as an incentive, said Kuo Fang-yu, director-general of the CLA Employment and Vocational Training Administration.

Several social activist groups have expressed concern that the CLA was considering lowering the threshold for hiring foreign nationals as household caregivers by Taiwan health care institutions or families that have elderly, babies or patients with chronic diseases. The liberalized policy, the activists said, will impede the development of Taiwan's own caregiving system, which has burgeoned only in recent years.

Kuo said that the activists need not worry, adding that the government has been working to help Taiwan nationals in a three-pronged approach via health, social and labor affairs to work as household caregivers and is building a human resources network for this.

At a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan, Wu Yu-chin, secretary-general of the Taiwan Elderly Welfare Promotion Alliance, lashed out at the CLA's plans to further relax restrictions on foreign caregiver employment in Taiwan, saying that the policy is tantamount to a hard slap across the face to the country's burgeoning caregiving industry.

Chen Yu-fang, secretary-general of the Taiwan Household Caregivers Association, questioned the meaning of the vocational training provided by the Employment and Vocational Training Administration to Taiwanese residents to make them trained caregivers.
Can the CLA provide job opportunities as well to these people? Chen asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY LEADERS SHOULD POINT OUT DIRECTION, GIVE FAITH: FORMER DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: Former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Shih Ming-teh on Thursday urged political leaders to show wisdom by leading the people in the right direction and giving them faith in their leadership.
Shih made the remarks at a ceremony to announce the opening of the "Shih Ming-teh Chair" at National Taiwan University's Department of Political Science.

Shih said that political leaders should have the wisdom to point out a direction, adding that if the DPP only wants to cling to power forever and the opposition parties only seek to return to power, then they will be locked into a single goal, which is not a direction.

Shih, who was twice sentenced to life in prison on charges of sedition and jailed for 25 years before being freed, also said that political leaders should stand their ground on their respective directions.
Political leaders should also have a discerning eye to put the right men in the right positions, and that they should also have leadership charisma to give faith to the people, Shih said.

The "Shih Ming-teh Chair" will promote a series of lectures along with research programs centered on the themes of "ethnic harmony, political reconciliation and cross-Taiwan Strait peace" each year and present scholarships.
David Laitin, a Stanford University professor who specializes in ethnic issues, has been invited to speak in the academic series.

Frederik Willem de Klerk, former president of South Africa, has been invited to speak in the program's political speech series. De Klerk was awarded the Nobel peace prize along with Nelson Mandela in 1993 for his abolition of ethnic segregation and his dedication to solving ethnic enmity during his term as president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 39.2 points to close at 6,095.81.
The bourse opened at 6,094.18 and fluctuated between 6,105.05 and 6,075.67 during trading. A total of 2.86 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$77.25 billion (US$2.32 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.6 percent and cement stocks and paper and pulp issues both at 0.3 percent.
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up at 0.7 percent and foodstuff issues gaining 0.4 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 588 to 343, with 151 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 30 points to close at 6,100, with 20,362 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 32 points to end at 6,097, with 513 contracts traded, while December futures lost 35 points to finish at 6,095, with 27 contracts traded. March futures moved down 51 points to close at 6,082, with 27 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,130 for October, 6,129 for November, 6,130 for December, 6,133 for March and 6,145 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

October TE futures moved down 0.75 points to close at 259.2, with 4,573 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 0.85 points to finish at 259, with 62 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 1.7 points to end at 258, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

October TF futures lost 10.2 points to finish at 888.6, with 3,286 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 11.6 points to end at 888, with 180 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 13.6 points to close at 886, with nine contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.022 to close at NT$33.260.
A total of US$620 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.238 and fluctuated between NT$33.185 and NT$33.260.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI SCHOOLS REQUIRED TO OPEN COMPULSORY CHINESE LANGUAGE CLASSES
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By H. C. Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: All high schools in Thailand are required to open compulsory Chinese language classes by 2008 as part of the government's efforts to heed the strong demand for Chinese amid its fast growing popularity, the Thai Education Ministry announced Thursday.

The program will begin immediately, probably from next semester, after Education Minister Dr. Chaturon Chaisang gives his approval, Education Ministry Permanent Secretary Chun-Ying Kasama Varawarn Na Ayutthaya said, adding that it is hoped that there will be at least one high school in each administrative district that provides compulsory Chinese classes by the end of 2007.

The Education Ministry hopes that all high schools across the nation will open mandatory Chinese classes in 2008, while the ministry will supply Chinese language teaching materials and staff in the first three years starting from that year to help schools overcome the difficulties in finding qualified teachers and textbooks, he said.
The Chinese language is of significant importance for Thailand's future economic development, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WANTS GOVERNMENT TO SUSPEND SECOND PHASE OF FINANCIAL REFORM

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Thursday urged the government to suspend the second phase of its financial reform plan, saying that the government needs to clear public suspicions that the plan is favoring specific large financial groups in the name of privatization.

At a news conference in the Legislative Yuan, Pan Wei-kang, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, said that Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun should have explained Wednesday how the government intends to cope with Taiwan's deteriorating economic climate, instead of just declaring that President Chen Shui-bian is determined to implement the second phase of financial reform.

Noting that the president had asked Yu rather than Premier Frank Hsieh to make the announcement, KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao wondered if there was something wrong with the relationship between the president and the premier.

Meanwhile, Lai Ching-te, a whip of the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), defended the financial reform plan, saying that the aim of the plan is to increase the competitiveness of Taiwan's banks in the global market.

He pointed out that the five largest banks in Taiwan have a collective market share of only 38 percent. However, the market share for the five largest banks in Hong Kong is 78 percent; in South Korea, the share is 89 percent.

At a meeting of the legislature's Finance Committee, the debate on the financial reform plan turned into loud quarrels between DPP and KMT legislators, with the opposition side questioning whether the president has the right to intervene in the Cabinet's domain and cause confusion in the nation's constitutional system.

The second phase of financial reform, announced by the president last year, aims to halve the number of state-owned banks to six and cut the number of financial holding companies by half to seven through mergers.

The plan requires the joint assets of any three banks to exceed 10 percent of the total value of Taiwan's banking sector. It also plans to let at least one bank be run by a foreign financial institution.
The government has insisted that the reforms are necessary because Taiwan has too many small banks, which have a high percentage of bad debts and lack the ability to compete in the global market.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN-THAILAND COUPLES ARE MARRIAGES OF CONVENIENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By H. C. Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Thai women generally marry Taiwan men as a way to work legally in the country, not out of love, sources familiar with the matter said Thursday.

So far, over 12,000 women from Thailand have entered Taiwan through marriages of convenience to obtain permanent residence and get a job, according to a source at a Taiwan expatriates association in Bangkok.

Taiwan men and Thai women form the second-largest number of marriages of convenience in Taiwan, behind only Taiwan husbands and Chinese wives, the source said, adding that many Thai women first divorce their Thai spouses at home to marry again in Taiwan.

These "fake Thai brides" usually make money in Taiwan by giving Thai-style massages, but many do other things to try to earn enough to repay their brokers, who charge them about US$7,500 to bring them into Taiwan, the source said. That amount is roughly equal to 3.5 years' income for the average Thai in Thailand.

Bangkok municipal officials said that they pay attention to relevant developments and vigorously screen marriage registrations by Thai women and foreigners. Currently, such marriage registration numbers have dropped to about 10 per month from more than 200 in the past, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES TO REDUCE FREQUENCY OF ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections are an important landmark in the government's efforts to reduce the frequency of elections in the country.

Making the comment in the latest issue of his online newsletter, Chen noted that the government has long been studying the feasibility of combining the existing elections in such a way that central-level elections could be held at the same time and local-level elections be held separately at the same time.

The government's decision to hold the elections for city and county chiefs, city and county councilors, as well as township and village heads at the same time is a major step toward that goal, Chen said.
Chen pointed out that elections have been held almost every year in Taiwan since 2000, which he said has been very tiresome both to himself and to the public.

On public concern that combining the elections might complicate law-enforcement authorities' efforts to crack down on vote-buying, Chen said he does not think there is a correlation between the two matters.
Chen said it is the government's job to make all necessary preparations beforehand to eliminate corrupt practices to build up an election culture that is not tainted by money or violence.
Chen stressed that democracy is not all about elections and that whether a country is democratic or not does not depend on how many elections it holds.
Repeated elections will only damage the unity of the people and increase their confrontation, Chen said.
According to the president, elections should be a process of seeking majority consensus, and everyone should accept the results after the elections are over.

If elections are held too frequently, the losers will have a hard time recovering from the bad feeling of defeat, which is unfavorable to political stability and the development of the country, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. THINK TANK TO SPONSOR TWO SEMINARS ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES, EU ROLE
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Two seminars will be held later this month to discuss cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the role the European Union can play, an E.U. think tank announced Thursday.

The European Alliance for Asian Studies (Asian Alliance) said that scholars from Britain, Germany, Sweden, Japan, Taiwan, China and Belgium, E.U. officials as well as European parliamentarians will be invited to attend the seminars to explore the present cross-strait situation and the future relations between the E.U., Taiwan and China.

Alliance officials said that the seminars will be co-sponsored with the Brussels-based European Institute for Asian Studies (EIAS) and the London-based School of Oriental and African Studies of the University of London.

Taiwan participants will include assistant professor Tsai Ming-yen of National Chung Hsing University, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng and former Executive Yuan Secretary-General Liu Shyh-fang.
EIAS officials had originally wanted to invite Taiwan legislators to come and had contacted Hsiao Bi-khim, although she will be unable to go because of other engagements.
The seminars will be in on London Oct. 18 and in Brussels on Oct. 20.

The European Alliance for Asian Studies (Asia Alliance) is a cooperative framework of European institutes specializing in Asian Studies. The aim of the Asia Alliance, established in 1997, is to contribute to bringing together the fragmented forces in Europe on Asian Studies to establish scholarly excellence in central areas of research and expertise on Asia, to the benefit of the institutes' national research environments and the European community at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINAL POLICEMAN-WRITER NOW A MOVIE STAR

TEXT.P: Yajunglong Sakenu, an indigenous policeman-writer who insists on using his Paiwan tribal name instead of a Han Chinese name, has become a movie star after the motion picture, "The Sage Hunter, " a screen adaptation of his own novel of the same name, was shown in Hollywood and was well received.

Sakenu, a Paiwan tribesman who writes novels in his free time as a policeman in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, played the lead role of "The Sage Hunter, " a story about a Paiwan hunter who became aware of his duty as a member of his tribe to protect the village and its forest when the "outsider" government was planning to develop a highway leading to the quiet mountainous village.

"The Sage Hunter" was shown at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in late September, where it was favorably received by critics. Sakenu attended the premiere and met the audience of over 1,000 people who showered him with a wide variety of questions about his novel, the movie and life in Taiwan.
Impressed by the movie and Sakenu's performance, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences even asked Sakenu whether he is interested in coming to Hollywood to join the U.S. film industry.
"The Sage Hunter" was also shown in a black community in Los Angeles, where many were amazed with what they saw in the movie about Taiwan.

After the Hollywood debut, "The Sage Hunter, " a movie about environmental protection, has been invited to join the U.S. Temecula Valley International Film and Music Festival; the Green Film Festival in Seoul; and the Planet in Focus: International Environmental Film and Video Festival in Canada.
The motion picture, the first Taiwan movie exclusively about Taiwan's indigenous people and their environment, is scheduled to be shown at various theaters around Taiwan in November.

At a debut ceremony in Taipei held Thursday, Sakenu was asked by reporters whether he will consider going to Hollywood to start a new career. His answer was a definite "no, " saying that being a policeman in Taitung is the most interesting thing that he does besides being a Paiwan hunter.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTMENT FEVER IN CHINA SUBSIDING: REPORT

TEXT.P: Foreign investment fever in China might have subsided, as the figure for foreign direct investment (FDI) there has posted the first-ever decrease, according to a report issued Thursday.

FDI in China totaled US$37.99 billion in the first eight months of this year, a decline of 3.02 percent year on year and the first such fall since 1999 -- an indication that suggests foreign investment fever in China might have calmed, according to the report by Chung-hua Institution for Economic Research researcher Ku Ying-hua, which appeared in an electronic newspaper run by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
During the same period, Taiwan investment in China also dwindled by 18.3 percent to US$3.593 billion in value for 853 investment plans -- an annual drop of 42 percent, the report said.

Ku ascribed Taiwan's sliding investment in China to the effects of China's efforts to cool down its overheated economy and to a fading investment pattern, given that almost all Taiwan businesses suitable for relocation have already moved out of Taiwan.

The foreign investment rush in China over the past few years was mainly a result of China's much-anticipated entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) , Ku said, pointing out that the fever was set to be on the wane after China joined the WTO at the end of 2001.

Before 2000, foreign companies focused their investment on export-oriented processing businesses, but such investment has become increasingly unprofitable due to rising labor costs in China and its WTO entry, which Ku pointed out allows foreign traders to directly purchase in China at lower prices thanks to reduced customs duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RENEWS CALL FOR INTER-PARTY DETENTE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian renewed his call for an end to domestic political bickering Thursday, saying that ethnic harmony, inter-party reconciliation and lasting peace across the Taiwan Strait are the common aspirations of the Taiwan people.

Chen made the appeal while addressing well-wishers of different political stripes at a ceremony marking the creation of the "Shih Ming-teh Chair" at National Taiwan University's Department of Political Science.

Among the audience were Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma ying-jeou, pro-unification opposition New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming and ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang.
In his speech, Chen claimed that the occasion was like a rare cross-party summit meeting.

"I admire Shih Ming-teh for his efforts to bring all of us together to celebrate the creation of the special academic forum to promote ethnic harmony, political reconciliation and cross-strait peace, " Chen said, adding he is hopeful that Shih will help set the stage for him to "savor the coffee of amity" with two opposition heavyweights -- Ma and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong.

Shih, a political dissident-turned politician who was jailed for 25 years during the KMT administration, once served as DPP chairman but quit the party a couple of years ago due to different political views with DPP leadership.

Noting that Taiwan's ethnic strains lie in the "2-28 Incident" and the 38-year martial law era under the KMT's authoritarian rule, Chen said ethnic harmony holds the key to Taiwan's efforts to become a "normal" and consolidated country.
According to Chen, all the contradictions and animosity among different ethnic groups will be eased if the historical truth can be clarified and established.
Touching on political reconciliation, Chen ascribed the present domestic political impasse mainly to the absence of an effective mechanism to resolve deadlocked issues.

In 1994, Taiwan revised the Constitution to pave the way for the first direct presidential election in 1996. In 1997, another round of constitutional amendments canceled the Legislative Yuan's right to approve the presidential nomination of the premier, leading the constitutional system to tilt toward a presidential system.

Under the present constitutional system, Chen said, the president is authorized to appoint a premier and the whole Cabinet without the consent of the legislature. On the other hand, he said, the Constitution does not prescribe that the majority party in the legislature can form a Cabinet.
"Against this backdrop, a political deadlock tends to happen when the president's party fails to control a majority in the legislature. We are right now mired in such a predicament," Chen said.

Noting that both the ruling and opposition parties are obliged to promote sustainable national development and the people's well-being, Chen said he aspires to cooperate with the opposition in crafting a viable constitutional system that fits Taiwan's needs and political reality.

To show the sincerity of his desire for political reconciliation, Chen offered to deliver a report to the legislature on a long-stalled arms procurement package to seek support for all relevant bills.
Claiming that "investment in national defense is tantamount to investment in peace, " Chen said Taiwan must beef up its defense capability to ensure lasting cross-Taiwan Strait peace.
"I am willing to personally deliver a report to the legislature on the arms deal," Chen said.
Hopefully, Chen said, the opposition-controlled legislature can then pass bills related to the plan to procure three big-ticket weaponry items from the United States.

For more than a year, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP has used its slim majority in the legislature to stonewall two bills regarding the robust arms procurement package for various reasons, including political bickering with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, fear of sparking a cross-strait arms race and aversion to squeezing funds for other national development plans.
Listed in the procurement package are eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine P-3C aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE WILL DECIDE IF PRESIDENT CAN ADDRESS IT: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: It is up to the Legislative Yuan to decide if and when it will invite President Chen Shui-bian to brief the legislature, Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.

If Chen opts to visit the Legislative Yuan and address the legislators, he should emulate his U.S. counterpart in delivering a state of the nation speech in the Legislative Yuan at the beginning of the first session of each year by common consent of a majority of the legislators, as stipulated in the Constitution, Wang pointed out.

Chen said earlier in the day that he is willing to expound on his administration's long-stalled arms procurement package in the Legislative Yuan in an attempt to win opposition support for all relevant bills.

Commenting on Chen's offer, Wang said that should the president be allowed to address the legislature, his speech should be a state of the nation address encompassing all major issues of the country rather than only the arms procurement bill.
Besides, Wang added, it is a matter to be decided by the legislators themselves, not the president.
Wang said he will see to it that arrangements are made if the legislators agree to invite Chen to make a legislative address.
The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party proposed last year that the Legislative Yuan invite Chen to address the legislature, but the motion was quashed.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD FIRST: TAIWAN DRONE FLIES THROUGH TYPHOON LONGWANG

TEXT.P: A pilotless plane launched by Taiwan flew through the eye of Typhoon Longwang last weekend to obtain information about the typhoon at first hand -- the first time such an undertaking has been successfully carried out anywhere in the world, the National Science Council (NSC) under the Cabinet said Thursday.

The research project, codenamed "Aerosonde, " has been going on for seven years with the participation of the Department of Atmospheric Sciences of National Taiwan University, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) and the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology under the auspices of the NSC. It came to fruition Oct. 1-2 when Typhoon Longwang was approaching Taiwan.

According to the NSC, a few hours after a test flight over the southernmost tip of Taiwan, the drone headed directly toward Longwang. It flew into the eye of the typhoon and hovered around the center for nearly an hour.

At 3,000 meters, the plane recorded the speed of the center winds at 52 meters per second, almost exactly the same as the speed recorded by the CWB at sea level. It also recorded a drastic change in atmospheric temperature from 20 degrees Celsius at 1,500 meters to 24 degrees C at about 500 meters.

While the plane was leaving the radius of the typhoon, its equipment detected a maximum wind speed of 70 meters per second at 3,000 meters -- comparable to 252 kph. However, just as the drone was about to get out of the storm's radius, its engine stalled and it plunged from 4,300 meters into the sea.

The NSC said scientists will continue to use drones to gather information about atmospheric changes so that correct warnings can be issued in time to minimize losses during typhoons or in the rainy season.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO CALL SEMINAR ON GOOD AQUACULTURE PRACTICE

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) will hold a seminar Friday to find ways to scrutinize the safety of Taiwan's aquaculture produce following a series of incidents that have impacted the industry, a COA spokesman said Thursday.

The seminar will focus discussions on wiping out the use of chemical residues and pollutants in fishery products in order to revive the glory of the industry, which has been seriously affected after the discovery of banned substances found in fishery exports to the European Union and Japan a few years ago, the spokesman said.

Recently, several batches of groupers for sale in the domestic market were also detected to contain malachite green -- a synthetic carcinogenic dye used illegally by unscrupulous fishpond operators as an antibacterial, he added.

The Fisheries Administration hopes to establish a set of criteria on limiting chemical use and avoiding pollution in Taiwan's fishery produce through discussions with local aquaculturalists and experts in the seminar to better protect consumers and secure Taiwan's food safety, he said.

As one of the world's major fish suppliers, Taiwan must effectively step up its food safety controls and management to meet high international standards and to ensure that the domestic industry can enjoy sustainable growth, he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NEW DPP MOVEMENT' WELCOMED

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu expressed support Thursday for the "new DPP movement" that 70 legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) endorsed the day before aimed at calling on the DPP to reflect upon itself and "enter a period of rebirth."

Lu said that the "new DPP movement" coincides with her open appeal to the country two months ago for political reforms and rejuvenation to help Taiwan meet the severe challenges it faces in the 21st Century.
The vice president added that not only should the DPP change and reform, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should also do the same.

Seventy DPP legislators declared their support Wednesday for the "new DPP movement" to revive the party's core values amid public criticism that the DPP is becoming corrupt even faster than the KMT it replaced as the ruling party in 2000.

Legislator Lee Wen-chung, one of the initiators of the movement, said the DPP must heed the voices of the public and insist on being a party that takes care of the less privileged and maintains the principles of equality and justice.

When asked Thursday by reporters if President Chen Shui-bian, a former DPP chairman, will be unhappy with the initiation of the movement, Lu answered: "Absolutely not, " adding that "it is our common ideal."
In response to the initiation of the movement, former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh expressed admiration for the sponsoring DPP legislators, describing the move as a "good political phenomenon."

DOC.HEADLINE: 50% OF TRADERS SATISFIED WITH TAIWAN'S BUSINESS ENVIRONMENT: POLL

TEXT.P: A total of 50.7 percent of traders polled in Taipei have expressed satisfaction with the country's business environment, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei.
While 44.2 percent of the respondents said they are unsatisfied, 5.2 percent offered no opinion.
The survey was conducted from July 22 to Aug. 10 among 600 importers and exporters in the Taipei area. It had a margin of error of 4.1 percent.

The survey results show that 61.5 percent of the respondents are not optimistic about Taiwan's economic outlook in the coming year, compared with 31.2 percent who expressed optimism. The remaining 7.3 percent had no opinion.
On the global economic outlook for the coming year, 51 percent of the respondents said they are optimistic, while 36.3 percent said they are not. The remaining 12.7 percent had no opinion.

Compared with the results of a similar survey conducted in 2004, the ratio of traders who are optimistic about the global economic outlook has increased by 7.8 percentage points, while that of those who are not has decreased by 16.1 percentage points.
Meanwhile, 79.3 percent of the respondents said soaring international oil prices has impacted their business, and 53.2 percent said the rise in China's currency has affected their operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE PASSENGER LINER TO MAKE UNPRECEDENTED PORT CALL AT MAKUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Makung, Penghu County, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Japanese passenger liner Nippon Maru is scheduled to sail into the port of Makung, the capital city of the island county of Penghu Sunday, for an unprecedented port call, the Makung Harbor authorities said Thursday.

The 22,000-ton Nippon Maru will have 300 Japanese tourists and 130 crew members aboard when it anchors off Makung Harbor, ushering in a new era for Penghu in terms of international tourism, harbor officials said.
According to the officials, the Nippon Maru departed the port of Yokohama Tuesday and visited the Japanese island of Kagoshima before heading for Keelung, a port city in northeastern Taiwan.
After making a brief port call at Keelung Saturday, the liner will sail around Taiwan before arriving in Makung the following day.
The Japanese tourists are scheduled to make an eight-hour tour of Penghu Sunday and the liner will then embark for Hualien in eastern Taiwan, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER DEFENDS 'NO DEATH PENALTY' VOW IN LAFAYETTE KICKBACK CASE

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin defended Premier Frank Hsieh's "no death penalty" guarantee in handling a kickback case involving Taiwan's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates from France in the early 1990s.

"The premier's promise will help upgrade our national image but will not affect judicial independence, " Shih said while attending a seminar on the campaign against vote-buying ahead of the year-end "three-in-one" elections.

Shih's clarification came a day after Switzerland's supreme court ruled that bank documents relating to the Lafayette kickback case should be turned over to the Taiwan authorities because the Republic of China government has guaranteed that it will not invoke the death penalty against Andrew Wang, a key suspect in the scandal.
Hsieh gave the "no death penalty" assurances Aug. 26 and the Swiss court was satisfied, enabling the transfer of the documents, a Swiss federal tribunal judgment said.

The Swiss court's ruling immediately drew a backlash from some opposition Taiwan lawmakers, who claimed that Hsieh has infringed upon judicial power and undermined Taiwan's sovereignty and international image by making such an assurance.
In response, Shih said such criticisms are unjustified because the premier made a comprehensive evaluation before signing the assurance.
"The assurance is mainly related to prosecutorial power and has nothing to do with judges' independent exercise of their power," Shih claimed.
Describing the Lafayette kickback case as very complicated, Shih said the collection of Swiss bank files is expected to offer valuable and useful clues to the truth.
"The kickback case involves a large sum of money. If we can retrieve the cash, it would benefit our national coffers," Lin pointed out.

Switzerland has long abolished the death penalty. Many other advanced countries are also moving in that direction and Shih said he believes that Hsieh's "no death penalty" vow will not tarnish Taiwan's international image.
Meanwhile, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Hsieh carefully weighed national interests and due process of law before making his decision.

The premier signed the judicical aid pact with Switzerland mainly because he believes the move will facilitate the investigation into the corruption case and the retrieval of the kickbacks, estimated at more than NT$10 billion, Cho said.
Moreover, Cho said, Hsieh conducted extensive consultations with law enforcement authorities before making the move.
"The decision neither violates due process of law nor basic human rights principles," Cho added.

Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-hua said the government should have Wang extradited back to Taiwan to serve as a suspect-turned-prosecution-witness to facilitate the probe into whether any Taiwan politicians or military officials obtained illegal kickbacks from the Lafayette deal.

The case concerns allegations that the French firm Elf Aquitaine used kickbacks in the early 1990s to persuade the French authorities to approve the sale of six Lafayette-class frigates to Taiwan, and to encourage Taiwan to buy the warships in a deal worth US$2.8 billion.
Taiwan has charged Wang with murder, corruption, money laundering and fraud. He was an agent in Taiwan for Thomson-CSF, the French company that sold the frigates to Taiwan.

Wang fled Taiwan following the death of ROC Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng, who was widely believed to have been murdered when he was about to blow the whistle on colleagues for allegedly taking kickbacks in the deal.
The ships had all been delivered to Taiwan by the mid-1990s, and both Switzerland and Liechtenstein have frozen funds in Wang's and his son's accounts that are allegedly linked to the case.
The investigations began when the Taiwanese authorities concluded from the inflated price that the deal constituted a serious case of international corruption.
France, Liechtenstein and Taiwan, investigating whether the case had violated their laws, asked the Swiss authorities to hand over the bank documents to facilitate their investigations.

According to media reports, some US$500 million remains frozen in 46 accounts with different banks in Switzerland as part of a Swiss investigation into alleged money laundering linked to the case. Authorities in neighboring Liechtenstein have frozen around US$27 million as part of their own investigations, the reports said.

With the Swiss supreme court ruling, the biggest obstacle to Taiwan's access to Swiss bank files has been removed. As to when the documents can be transferred to Taiwan's judicial authorities, that is up to a final decision by the Swiss Federal Commission.
The Federal Commission is not expected to make a negative decision against the document handover, but it remained unclear when the commission will handle the case.
A Swiss official said the judicial exchange, the first of its kind, will mark a significant development in relations between Taiwan and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S INTER-PARTY RECONCILIATION PROPOSAL DISMISSED

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) Thursday dismissed as "phony" President Chen Shui-bian's proposal for reconciliation between the opposition and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Responding to Chen's call in a speech for an end to domestic political bickering, PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said it is phony for the president to mention reconciliation after he unilaterally scrapped the conclusions reached at a meeting he had with PFP Chairman James Soong in February, thereby ruining the opportunity for reconciliation.

Hsieh said that in meeting with the president, Soong resisted mounting pressure and risked being "misunderstood by the public." However, he added, barely a few months later, the president not only trashed the pledges he made in his agreement with Soong, but also made "false accusations" about Soong meeting with a ranking Chinese official in secret in the United States.
The PFP spokesman criticized the president for lacking the courage to apologize to Soong, saying that Chen is not sincere in seeking reconciliation.

On Chen's willingness to go to the Legislative Yuan to discuss a controversial arms procurement plan, Hsieh said the plan was already voted down in a referendum held alongside the presidential election in March last year and that the president should respect the conclusion reached in a democratic manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET VOWS TO STEP UP FINANCIAL SUPERVISION TO AVERT FAVORITISM

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Thursday the government will keep close tabs on the implementation of the second phase of financial reform to prevent any irregularities or favoritism.
Wu made the pledge at a news conference aimed at allaying public misgivings that the reforms might favor specific large financial conglomerates in the name of privatization.

Also present at the news conference were Finance Minister Lin Chuan, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng and Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Kung Jao-sheng.

Wu said the government will oversee every step of the privatization of state-owned banks and mergers among them to prevent any private financial conglomerate from gaining unfair or illegal favors in the reform process.

The second phase of financial reforms, announced by the president last year, aims to halve the number of state-owned banks to six and cut the number of financial holding companies by half to seven through mergers.

The plan requires the joint assets of any three banks to exceed 10 percent of the total value of Taiwan's banking sector. It also plans to let at least one bank be run by a foreign financial institution.

Speaking on the same occasion, CEPD Chairman Hu said he is confident that the goal of halving the number of state-owned banks will be realized by the end of this year as scheduled, despite a setback in selling off the Medium Business Bank of Taiwan earlier this year.

He said it is hoped that success in halving the number of state-owned banks will encourage private financial holding companies to accelerate mergers among themselves so as to realize the goal of halving their number to seven by the end of next year.
Meanwhile, FSC Chairman said local banks and financial institutions must merge or integrate to generate economy of scale if they are to survive the ever-intensifying global competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, BURKINA FASO SIGN AVIATION PACT

TEXT.P: Taiwan signed an aviation agreement with its African ally of Burkina Faso Thursday, marking a step forward in their bilateral friendship and cooperation.
The agreement was signed in Taipei by Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Oliver F. L. Yu and his Burkina Faso counterpart Patrice Nikiema on behalf of their governments.
Under the agreement, the two sides can designate their carriers to operate flights between the two countries. The numbers of carriers and flights will be decided by market demand without any caps.
For the time being, Taiwan carriers have no plans to open flight services between the two countries, civil aviation officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 7, or the fifth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1900: Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo, and from 1929, Adolf Hitler's second-in-command, is born.
1913: Henry Ford, the leading manufacturer of U.S. automobiles in early 1900's, creates the world's first assembly line to build the model T cars.
1919: KLM, the national airline of the Netherlands and the world's first airline, is established, and flights are scheduled to begin in 1920.
1949: East Germany, or the German Democratic Republic, is proclaimed, with Wilhelm Pieck as president and Otto Grotewohl as prime minister.
1950: Communist Chinese troops enter Tibet.
1958: Communist Chinese begin to launch a mass movement in Tientsin to make iron and steel, in which about 100 million people would eventually participate. The movement, which proved to be a waste of both human and material resources, resulted in the loss of 100 billion yuan in industrial production.
1959: Mario Lanza, U.S. tenor and film actor, dies at the age of 38. His films included "The Great Caruso."
1961: Two Communist Chinese pilots, Shao Hsi-yen and Kao Yu-tsung, arrive in Taipei from Seoul.
1974: A 90-member Japanese calligraphic mission led by Akira Koyama arrive in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: U.S. President Gerald Ford, already under fire for pardoning the disgraced Richard Nixon, tells the public on prime-time television that "there is no Soviet domination of eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford administration."
1982: Jimmy Wei, the national policy advisor to President Chiang Ching-kuo and former president of the Central News Agency, dies of a heart attack at the age of 77.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo tells Katherine Graham, head of the board of the Washington Post and Newsweek, in an interview that the Republic of China government will soon propose lifting martial law to actively promote democracy, but adds that new political parties should abide by the ROC Constitution and anti-Communist policy. He also emphasizes the ROC will never negotiate with the Communist Chinese.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of the society.
1998: Thousands of Russians take to the streets to protest against unpaid wages and to call on President Boris Yeltsin to resign.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan confirms that the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau will formally phase out its controversial "political surveillance" work soon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of magnanimity, generosity, benignity, and gentleness: qualities necessary for the exercise of patience."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOOGLE TO 'LOOK INTO' MAP DESCRIPTION MATTER
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Chiang Chun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Google Inc. international affairs spokesman said Thursday that the company only received a letter of concern from Taiwan authorities a day earlier complaining about Google Maps service's reference to Taiwan as a "province of China."

The spokesman said that Google Inc., headquartered in Silicon Valley, California, was unaware of Taiwan's ire prior to receiving the letter. He referred to Google's reference to Taiwan as a province of China as being in line with international naming conventions based on the United Nations ISO country codes.
He told the CNA that Google has since begun looking into the matter.

The spokesman, however, denied accusations that Google would go to any lengths to get into China's online market, including describing Taiwan in a way that would not draw the ire of Beijing, saying that it is impossible for Google to use misleading information on its Maps services.
He added that the Google Maps' Taiwan section is purely aimed at providing users with data such as business locations and driving directions and that the Taiwan map has nothing to do with China.

Reports from Taiwan said that Taiwan authorities and legislators are up in the arms over the Google Maps description of Taiwan as a province of China. Reports said that Taiwan's liaison offices in the United States have been asked since Sept. 19 to convey Taiwan's concern and indignation to Google Inc. about the matter, but the requests have "all fallen on deaf ears."

Taiwan's complaint is not the first that Google Maps has received. Last year, South Koreans protested Google's use of the name "Sea of Japan" to describe the sea between Japan and South Korea, instead of the name "East China Sea." Following the protests, Google decided to use both names on its maps in a bid to calm protests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SETS GOAL OF ATTRACTING 3.2 MILLION FOREIGN TOURISTS IN 2005

TEXT.P: The government has set the target of attracting at least 3.2 million tourists from abroad this year under the "doubling tourist arrivals by 2008" goal announced in 2002, Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh said that Taiwan saw 2.9 million tourist arrivals from abraod last year and that the figure is expected to grow by 300,000 this year to reach 3.2 million.
He noted that foreign tourist arrivals are also expected to grow by double-digit percentages annually in the years leading up to 2008.
Should this be realized as planned, the goal of doubling tourist arrivals to 5 million will be achieved by 2008, he added.

Hsieh made the remarks in response to concerns expressed by Legislator Tsai Chi-chang from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party about whether the goal of doubling tourist arrivals can be achieved by 2008 as related costs in Taiwan have risen while the administration's efficiency has declined.

Reviewing the balance sheets of major government-run tourist attractions nationwide, Tsai said that most have been breaking even at best. He suggested that the government lease the tourist attraction operations to private operators.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said that he has not been very satisfied with what Taiwan has done in running advertisements abroad to attract tourists to Taiwan.

Lee Chin-lung, minister of the Council of Agriculture, said that as far as he knows, many officially-owned tourist attractions are already being operated by private operators under contract. He reminded the public that in the process of further promoting tourism, the issue of over-development should be considered so as to prevent the natural environment from being compromised.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO CONVENE TEAM TO LOOK INTO MRT PROJECT

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan announced Friday the formation of a five-member team to look into the controversial mass rapid transit (MRT) construction project in the southern port city.
Yeh made the announcement in a press conference one day after reports cited ranking government officials as saying that President Chen Shui-bian has asked Yeh to form a team to look into the matter.

The team will see whether any of the Kaohsiung mayors who have served since 1990, including current opposition Kuomintang Legislator Wu Den-yih and Premier Frank Hsieh, should take administrative responsibility for the MRT construction project, and whether a former Presidential Office adviser and a Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) official were involved in profiteering in the project, the reports also said.

Yeh said that the team will be convened by herself and that the members are two vice mayors -- Tang Chin-chuan who is specializes in legal affairs, and engineering specialist Cheng Wen-lung -- as well as Kaohsiung city government Secretary-General Hao Chien-sheng and Department of Government Ethics Director Huang Sheng-yi.
The team will complete its investigation report by Oct. 20 and then report to the general public, Yeh said.

She said that although judicial authorities have begun investigations, there are still misgivings among members of the public, and President Chen is concerned about the matter and is in support of the formation of the team.

Yeh said that the team will look into whether there have been any kickbacks or racketeering involved in the MRT construction project, and that former mayors, government and KRTC officials will all be targets of investigation.
"The team will seek the truth and make a clear account so as to assuage any misgivings the public might have," she said.
Meanwhile, Fang Lai-chin, director of the Bureau of Labor Affairs under the city government, has tendered his resignation, Yeh said, adding that she has approved the resignation.
Fang was recently questioned by prosecutors and released on a NT$200,000 bail (US$6,020) for his alleged involvement in the MRT construction project.
Two key figures in the controversial MRT construction project -- Chen Che-nan and Chen Min-hsien -- also tendered their resignations earlier this month.

Chen Che-nan, who once served as a Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, and Chen Min-hsien, who used to be vice chairman of the KRTC, are suspected of involvement in an illegal profiteering racket involving the employer -- the KRTC -- and a labor brokerage firm that has exploited Thai laborers.

The alleged racketeering scandal surfaced after a group of Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit construction project rioted on Aug. 21 in protest against what they perceived as unfair and unjust treatment by management. Law enforcement authorities have been investigating the cause of the riot and all possible irregularities involved in the employment and management of the Thai workers.

: The Straits Times: Police give stern warning to protester.
The Case Of The Eight White Elephants has finally been wrapped up.
The punishment for putting up eight cutouts of cartoon elephants in front of Buangkok MRT station to protest against its non-opening: Astern warning from the police.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Next General Election could be called anytime before June 2007: PM Lee.
Is the next General Election could be called in next year? Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong still remained coy of the timing of the elections which must be called by June 2007.
That could be anytime for elections, including the possibility in next year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS OF RULING PARTY RALLY AGAINST OPPOSITION-INITIATED BILL

TEXT.P: A group of 50 lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rallied Friday in front of the Legislative Yuan to show their determination to block a bill initiated by the opposition People First Party (PFP) to promote peace with China.
Legislator William Lai, the whip of DPP legislative caucus, said the so-called cross-strait peace-promotion bill is "seeking false peace while in fact surrendering to China."

He said that while Taiwan should unite to face up to China's threat, especially in the face of Beijing's enactment earlier this year of its so-called Anti-Secession Law giving Beijing the "legal" option of taking Taiwan by force, the PFP and its political ally the Kuomintang (KMT) have in fact been trying to supplicate to China by coming up with the peace-promotion bill.
Lai led his caucus members in chanting "false peace, actual surrender," saying that his party will fight tooth and nail to thwart it, despite being a minority party in the legislature.

The two opposition parties, which between them command a slim majority in the legislature, are expected to try to steamroller the bill through the legislature next week as the imperative four-month period of political negotiations among the political parties has expired.
The last attempt to put the bill to a vote was disrupted by the DPP Sept. 27 when DPP lawmakers occupied the podium and paralyzed the legislative session.

The bill has triggered controversy because it would give the legislature the power to open transportation links and to form a free trade zone with China, which the DPP claims should be under the authority of the executive branch.
