DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO CONTINUE FINANCIAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh pledged Friday that the government will continue its efforts to reform the country's financial system, despite public differences over the reforms.

Speaking during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh pointed out that the reforms are based on a consensus reached during the economic development conference in 2001 and that the first phase of the reforms has successfully lowered the non-performing loan ratio of domestic banks from 8 percent to 2 percent.

Although some are opposed to the second phase of reforms, which involves the privatization of state-owned banks and mergers between banks, they must continue for the sake of the country's development, Hsieh said.
He said it is out of date for the government to operate banks, noting that none of the banks in the United States or Japan are owned by the government.
Also, it was a mistake that the government did not encourage earlier mergers of domestic banks, he said.

According to the premier, the number of banks in Taiwan is too high compared with other countries and the situation has undermined the competitiveness of domestic banks and has reduced their profit margins.

In the second phase of reforms, the government plans to halve the number of state-owned banks to six by the end of this year and hopes to have at least three domestic banks increase their market shares to more than 10 percent.
In addition, the government aims to cut the number of financial holding companies by half to seven by the end of next year. It also plans to allow at least one bank to be run by a foreign investor.

However, some lawmakers from the opposition Kuomintang have accused the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government of favoring certain pro-DPP financial conglomerates in the privatization process of state-owned banks and have demanded that the reforms be postponed.

Vice Premier Wu Rong-i promised a day earlier that the government will oversee every step of the privatization and mergers to prevent any private financial conglomerate from gaining unfair or illegal favors in the reform process.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT CALLS ON TZU CHI FOUNDER

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui called on Buddhist Master Cheng Yen, founder of Taiwan's largest charity organization the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, in Hualien, eastern Taiwan Friday.
Lee was accompanied by Hualien Magistrate Hsieh Sheng-shan in a closed-door meeting with Cheng Yen.

Lee expressed concern about the organization's relief work in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, which devastated large areas of the southern United States, while Cheng Yen elaborated on the latest relief efforts, a Tzu Chi Foundation spokesman said after the meeting.
Lee, who will embark on a visit to the United States later this month, returned to Taipei after the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR WILL NOT SEEK MEDICAL ATTENTION IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu clarified Friday that he will not seek medical attention in China during his visit there to attend an Asia-Pacific regional cities summit.
It had been rumored that Hu, who suffered a minor stroke several years ago, would take advantage of his visit to China next week to see a doctor.
Hu said that if people are suspicious about his trip, they are welcome to join him, as he will keep an open and transparent itinerary.

The Taichung mayor, who visited Beijing June 8-10 this year to attend a city and local government conference, is scheduled to depart Taiwan Oct. 10 to attend the Asia Pacific Cities Summit slated for Oct. 11-14 in Chongqing, in China's southwestern province of Sichuan.

After the Chongqing summit, Hu and his city government group are planning to head for Shanghai, where they will promote specialties from Taichung City, including a traditional Taiwanese cake called sun cake.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO AGGRESSIVELY DEVELOP SERVICE INDUSTRY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The service industry will be made another major column, along with the high-tech sector, propping up Taiwan's sustainable economic growth, Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.

Developing the service sector will be one of the pivotal directions for national development in years to come, Hsieh said in his address delivered during a ceremony marking the establishment of the Association of Service Industry Development, Taiwan.
By 2008, he said, production in the service sector is expected to constitute 71 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) or higher, compared to the current level of 68 percent.
The service industry basically encompasses every sector and serves every member of society, Hsieh said.

Against this backdrop, he added, finding ways to expand the scale and prowess of the service industry and sharpen its international competitiveness has become one of the most urgent and imperative tasks for the administration.
Hsieh said Taiwan can no longer rely on exports of low-end labor-intensive products "like umbrellas" to sustain its economy forward.

Taiwan also cannot rely solely on the high-tech industry as the only foreign exchange earner, since the industry hires fewer workers in general than other sectors, Hsieh said. This, he added, is why many industrially advanced countries suffer high unemployment.

For the best solution, he said, Taiwan should continue to develop its high-tech industry on one hand while striving to develop the service industry on the other, which will provide huge numbers of jobs and help arrest rising unemployment.

Hsieh offered his congratulations upon the establishment of the Association of Service Industry Development, Taiwan, which is poised to serve as an arm in Taiwan's service industry development and also as abridge between the government and the private sector.
The premier said the association should feel free to contact the administration and perhaps maintain a regular meeting system with the government for better communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN VOWS CONTINUED REFORM TO PAVE WAY FOR RETURN TO POWER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said in an interview with Japan's Sankei Shimbun published Friday that he will continue to push for party reforms to create favorable conditions for the party's return to power in the 2008 presidential election.
On the year-end "three-in-one" elections, Ma said the party will not endorse anyone found to be involved in corrupt "black gold" politics in the race.
He also touched on the controversial party assets issue, saying that the assets will be handled in a transparent manner and that the issue will be dealt with overall by 2008.

On cross-strait relations, Ma said both sides of the Taiwan Strait should put aside the issue of sovereignty and develop economic exchanges, saying that both sides should focus on economic exchanges to expand substantive cross-strait relations based on the conclusion reached between former KMT Chairman Lien Chan and his Chinese counterpart Hu Jintao in late April in China.
He also said the establishment of a confidence-building mechanism between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is an urgent task.
Although Taiwan cannot ignore the 700 missiles deployed by China against Taiwan, Ma said arms procurements will not help solve cross-strait relations.
Ma said he believes that cross-strait relations are strained because China thinks the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration wants to change the status quo.

On economic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Ma noted that Taiwan exported around US$40 billion to China last year, which is greater than its total exports to Japan, the United States and Europe. He predicted that the close cross-strait economic exchanges will not change.
On whether it will be possible for him to visit China, he said this will hinge on necessity and conditions but he did not rule out the possibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARMFUL CHEMICALS FOUND IN SOME DISPOSABLE CHOPSTICKS

TEXT.P: Ten out of 37 samples of disposable chopsticks available on the market have been found to contain traces of sulfur dioxide, a chemical harmful to humans, the Consumer's Foundation said Friday.

In a news conference called to unveil the results of the tests on disposable chopsticks used commonly by local restaurants and also sold with instant noodles, the foundation said the sulfur dioxide is the residue of bleach used to whiten the chopsticks and prevent them from getting moldy.
More worrying still, some of the chopsticks claimed on the packaging to be bleach-free still contain chemicals.
Most of the sulfur dioxide, after being digested, is converted into sulfuride and discharged from the body with the urine, but some can combine with calcium and damage the bones.
Too much sulfur dioxide can also cause asthma, difficulty in breathing, vomiting and diarrhea.

There is no law regulating the tolerance of sulfur dioxide in chopsticks, and four of the 10 samples tested positive for sulfur dioxide had up to 200 ppm, which is much less than the 4,000 ppm found in some dried day lily flowers.
Also, the foundation said, one of the 37 samples was found to have more than 100 ppm lead, which was rubbed off on the chopsticks from the paint on the plastic bag used to wrap them.
Four of the samples were found to have residue of fluorescent brightening agent, a carcinogen, which is used to make the chopsticks look brighter, the foundation said.
Eighteen of the 37 chopsticks did not reveal the manufacturers' name and address, even though this is required by law, said the foundation.

The foundation suggested that the public should use their own chopsticks when eating out or dip the disposable chopsticks in hot water for a few second before using them, as the sulfur dioxide residue dissolves in hot water.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT PEACE-PROMOTION BILL UNHELPFUL TO PEACE: FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: A private group promoting peace urged the country's two main opposition parties Friday to stop their plan to steamroller a cross-strait peace-promotion bill through the legislature.

According to Chien Hsi-chieh, a leader of the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan, the bill is unhelpful to peace and will intensify confrontation between the ruling and opposition parties because of a lack of consensus on the legislation.

Chien expressed his disapproval of the "special cross-strait peace consultation committee" that the bill stipulates will be formed by representatives of various political parties, calling such a committee an anti-democratic organization designed merely for partisan interests.

The bill would also give the legislature the power to open transportation links and to form a free trade zone with China, which the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claims should be under the authority of the executive branch.

The opposition People First Party and Kuomintang, which together control a slim majority in the legislature, are expected to make a second attempt to put the bill to a vote next week after their last attempt was disrupted by the DPP Sept. 27.
A group of 50 DPP lawmakers rallied Friday in front of the Legislative Yuan to show their determination to block the bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN FIRM TO HELP TAIWAN IT MAKERS SET UP ODC IN INDIA

TEXT.P: An Indian software company said Friday it looks forward to helping at least 10 Taiwan IT corporations to set up offshore design centers (ODCs) in Bangalore, India's software industry stronghold, in the coming year.

G.K. Pramod, country manager in Taiwan of SPA Computers Ltd., said he is convinced that Taiwan IT companies will be able to cut their research and development (R&D) costs through establishing ODCs in Bangalore.
Moreover, he went on, the practice will also enable Taiwan to use Bangalore's rich software development resources to design highly sophisticated and competitive computer chips.

SPA opened its Taiwan office four years ago and has emerged as the largest service provider for embedded software in Taiwan. The company provides IT solutions for semiconductor applications and its clients include a number of noted local high-tech giants such as Inventec, iEi, TSMC and PSC.
With Taiwan's expertise in electronics, hardware and telecommunications and India's expertise in software and services, Pramod said a perfect synergy can be built between the two countries.
"So SPA sees plenty of opportunities for its growth in Taiwan, " Pramod said, adding that his company will continue to expand its cooperation with Taiwan business groups in the coming year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 13.97 points to close at 6,081.84.
The bourse opened at 6,090.99 and fluctuated between 6,112.83 and 6,076.15 during trading. A total of 2.62 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$67.51 billion (US$2.03 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up at 0.3 percent and cement stocks gaining 0.1 percent.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.7 percent, textile stocks at 0.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent.
Plastics and chemical shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 549 to 374, with 165 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION BLASTS GOVERNMENT DECISION TO INVESTIGATE MRT CASE

TEXT.P: The government's decision to form a five-member team led by acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan to investigate possible profiteering in the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit project met strong criticism from opposition parties Friday.

The criticism followed Yeh's announcement that the team's members include two vice mayors -- Tang Chin-chuan, who specializes in legal affairs, and engineering specialist Cheng Wen-lung -- as well as Kaohsiung City Government Secretary-General Hao Chien-sheng and Department of Government Ethics Director Huang Sheng-yi.

The team will present a report in two weeks after probing whether the two former mayors of Kaohsiung -- incumbent opposition Kuomintang Legislator Wu Den-yih and Premier Frank Hsieh -- and former acting Mayor Chen Chi-mai, as well as officials of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp., were involved in profiteering from the project.

Commenting on the new development, Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said that as the acting mayor of Kaohsiung, Yeh's power to investigate is very limited compared to that of public prosecutors.
Ma stressed that the focus should be on the ongoing judicial investigation rather than an administrative investigation.
KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen termed the decision "absurd," saying that it should be up to the public prosecutors or the Control Yuan -- the highest watchdog body of the government -- to do the job.

Chang Hsien-yao, a legislator of the opposition People First Party (PFP) and director of the PFP Policy Center, told a press conference that team lacks credibility and is unlikely to unearth the truth because the targets being investigated by Yeh and her team are either their superiors or predecessors.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP COOPERATION IN DECEMBER ELECTIONS LEAPS AHEAD

TEXT.P: Cooperation between the two "pan blue alliance" parties, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally, the People First Party (PFP) , in December's city and county chief elections have leapt ahead after the PFP withdrew its candidates in several constituencies.

Although the PFP had pledged that it would field candidates in every constituency regardless of KMT rivals' presence, three PFP hopefuls -- Hsieh Chang-chieh in Changhua County, Cheng Mei-lan in Illan County and Chiu Ching-chun in Hsinchu County -- announced Tuesday they were quitting the race to avoid a split in the alliance.

"Pan blue" supporters fear that such a split would leave the "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) with too great an advantage in the elections, which are widely seen as a prelude to the next presidential election in 2008.

Hsieh bowed out of the Changhua County magistrate election on his own volition, while Cheng and Chiu did so under PFP Chairman James Soong's instruction in a last-minute effort before the deadline for registration for the election, to ensure that KMT candidates would beat "pan green" rivals in these areas.

PFP Secretary-General Chin Ching-sheng expressed hope that the party's self-sacrifice for the sake of overall interests will not be met by disappointment and called on the KMT to show sincerity in bilateral collaboration by compromising in Keelung City and Miaoli County in favor of PFP candidates.
The PFP is keen to initiate a new pattern of cooperation between the two parties through the Dec. 3 election, Chin said.

Dismissing mounting skepticism that the KMT is reluctant to give way to any PFP aspirant, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said the KMT has given up the idea of putting forth a candidate in Lienchiang County (Matsu Island), where incumbent magistrate Chen Hsueh-sheng is a PFP member.
The KMT respects Chen's re-election willingness and claimed that his party does not mean to "take it all," he added.

However, the hurdles have not all been removed for across-the-board KMT-PFP cooperation in the elections, as the two parties also have failed to present a single candidate in Taichung City, Hualien County, Keelung City and Miaoli County.

KMT Organization Development Commission head Liao Feng-teh said the party will do its best to maintain power in eight local governments and that chances are favorable in Miaoli County, Taitung County, Yilan County and Chiayi City.
The KMT and the PFP can consider setting up joint campaign teams and forming ruling coalitions if elected, he suggested.
The elections will serve as a litmus paper to test the water for Ma, who assumed the KMT chairmanship in August amid fervent expectations from supporters that he could win back power in 2008.

At present, the two "pan blue alliance" parties have not fared well in putting forth a common candidate in 11 cities and counties out of the total of 23. A total of 77 aspirants have registered to run in the elections with each side vying to seize at least half of the seats.

Meanwhile, the ruling DPP has tried hard to set the tune for the elections as "purely regional" to counter the opposition's gambit of making the race a "polarized duel" at a time when the ruling party is ridden with various alleged corruption scandals.

Critical to the elections will be the two camps' performances in central cities and counties, and either side will be viewed as victorious if it beats the other in the central region, due to the fact that the "pan blue alliance" enjoys an advantage in northern Taiwan while the "pan green camp" enjoys firm backing in southern Taiwan, observers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.028 to close at NT$33.232.
A total of US$646 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.210 and fluctuated between NT$33.166 and NT$33.255.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down five points to close at 6,095, with 14,818 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November moved up three points to end at 6,100, with 450 contracts traded, while December futures lost 14 points to finish at 6,102, with 13 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,100 for October, 6,097 for November, 6,116 for December, 6,103 for March and 6,115 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
October TE futures moved up 0.3 points to close at 259.5, with 3,001 contracts traded, while November TE futures gained 0.35 points to finish at 259.35, with 127 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

October TF futures lost 4.6 points to finish at 884, with 2,539 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 4.6 points to end at 883.4, with 194 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down seven points to close at 880.8, with 11 contract transactions, while March TF futures lost 7.6 points to finish at 882, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP LAUNCHES ARMS PURCHASE FUND DRIVE

TEXT.P: A civic group announced Friday that it will launch a fundraising drive in which it hopes to persuade 1 million people to each donate NT$100 (US$3) to help pay for the nation's arms purchases from the United States.

North Society executives made the announcement as a government arms procurement package was blocked for the 31st time in the Legislative Yuan this week because of obstruction by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.
The executives claimed that the drive will "help fund" the arms purchase, cement national defense and highlight the Taiwan people's determination to defend the country.

According to them, it will also "whip up patriotism" and apply pressure on the "pan-blue alliance, " which has used its slim majority in the legislature to stonewall the government's proposed arms procurement package for more than one year.
The package includes three big-ticket items of weapons of eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries.
North Society President Wu Shu-ming criticized the "pan-blue alliance" for boycotting the arms procurement package, saying that "their deliberate obstruction will bring downfall to the nation."

Wu claimed that his drive will raise the awareness that everyone is responsible for the nation's defense, adding that the drive will not only raise NT$100 million, but will be a manifestation of Taiwan's identity.

Society Vice President Yang Chi-wen noted that civic groups marched late last month to express their aspirations to strengthen national defense and claimed that President Chen Shui-bian has continued to show goodwill toward the opposition parties, but the "pan-blue alliance" has stuck to its guns.
He was referring to a Sept. 25 march by an estimated 50,000 local people, mostly from pro-independence groups, to support the arms procurement package.

Society Secretary-General Yang Wen-chia said the legislature has "turned into" an arena of political bickering that has hindered the passage of the package and that his group has resorted to the fundraising drive to drive home its voice.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO MOBILIZE LAWMAKERS FOR VOTES ON CONTROVERSIAL BILLS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) decided Friday to mobilize all its members to show up for next Tuesday's legislative session when two controversial bills are expected to be put to a vote by the opposition parties.

The caucus will demand thorough discussions on a bill governing the formation of the National Communications Commission (NCC) before it is put to a vote, and if the caucus fails to vote down the bill, it will seek to have the legislature reconsider the bill some other time or request a constitutional interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices, according to Chao Yung-ching, the caucus convener.

As for an opposition cross-Taiwan Strait peace-promotion bill, the DPP will argue with the opposition parties on the basis of "sound reason" and will not provoke physical clashes with opposition lawmakers, he said.

His remarks appeared somewhat at odds, however, with the ideas of a group of female DPP legislators, who prepared for violent clashes by borrowing protective gear from the police beforehand in order to protect themselves in the chaos and violence they are sure will mar Tuesday's proceedings.

DPP lawmakers occupied the podium and paralyzed the legislative session amid scenes of violence when their rivals from the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party were attempting to take advantage of their slim majority to steamroller the two bills through the legislature Sept. 27.

The DPP disagrees with the KMT and PFP on the composition of the NCC. While the two opposition parties want the NCC to be comprised of members in proportion to the number of seats each party holds in the legislature, the DPP insists that political parties should keep their hands off and let experts and scholars serve on the commission.

Meanwhile, the DPP is opposed to the cross-strait peace-promotion bill because it would give the legislature the power to open transportation links and to form a free trade zone with China, which the party claims should be under the authority of the executive branch.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: New York Named in Terror Threat Against Subways
Security in and around New York City's subways was sharply increased yesterday after city officials said they were notified by federal authorities in Washington of a terrorist threat that for the first time specifically named the city's transit system.
Wall Street Journal: Radicals in Iraq Begin Exporting Violence, Mideast Neighbors Say
Some Middle East intelligence and security officials worry that the violence of Islamic militants in Iraq is beginning to bleed out into the neighboring region. U.S. President Bush also voiced concern yesterday that al Qaeda and others want to make Iraq a base from which to launch operations against the U.S. and other secular governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SCHOLARSHIPS OFFERED FOR 713 FOREIGN STUDENTS THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: A total of 713 foreign students from 18 countries will be able to study in Taiwan this year on scholarships provided by the Republic of China government, a spokesman for the Ministry of Education said Friday.

Chang Chin-sheng, director of the ministry's Bureau of International Cultural and Education Relations Department, said that the 446 male and 267 female foreign students will study at 51 universities across Taiwan. Eighty and 223 of them will pursue doctoral and masters degrees, while 149 and 261 will study at universities and language centers, respectively, he added.

The largest number of 43 scholarship recipients will come from Paraguay, followed by 37 from Thailand, 34 from Japan and 28 from Mongolia. Panama, Honduras and Vietnam each will send 26 students, while India and the United States each has 25, and Nicaragua 22.

The Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the National Science Council began offering the scholarships to 555 foreign students last year, Chang said, adding that the number will be increased to 1,000 next year.

The scholarship program forms part of the government's efforts to increase Taiwan's contacts with the international community and serves as a means of introducing pluralistic and exotic elements to Taiwan's society, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE SURPLUS ESTIMATED AT 23-YEAR LOW FOR 2005

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade surplus for 2005 has been estimated to reach a level between US$3 billion and US$2.6 billion -- a 23-year low, a government official said Friday.

Hsu Kuo-chung, head of the Department of Statistics under the Ministry of Finance, made the evaluation based on tallies released earlier the same day by the ministry showing that Taiwan exports and imports in September totaled US$16.2 billion and US$15.49 billion, respectively, marking a monthly trade surplus of US$710 million and bringing the total trade surplus for the first nine months to US$1.94 billion.

Hsu forecast that the trade surplus for 2005 will hit around US$2.6 billion and possibly as high as US$3 billion, helped by booming outbound shipments in the fourth quarter. Even so, the full-year figure for this year will be the lowest since 1982, when the figure stood at US$3.3 billion, he pointed out.

The September export value was the second-biggest monthly high, representing an 18.5 percent growth rate year on year, while the month's import value recorded an annual increase rate of 9 percent, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN NOT PREPARED FOR RECONCILIATION: KMT CHAIRMAN MA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is not really prepared for inter-party reconciliation, Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), claimed Friday, even though the president expressed his willingness Thursday to have a reconciliation meeting over coffee with leaders of opposition parties.

Asked to comment on the president's overture of reconciliation, Ma said that honesty and trustworthiness are pivotal to ethnic harmony, political reconciliation and cross-Taiwan Strait peace, and that a man of integrity would need to put action behind his words.
"So far, I don't see that President Chen is prepared for reconciliation," he added.

The KMT chairman, who is also Taipei mayor, said the current gridlock between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition on a number of issues cannot be blamed on any single party. However, he continued, the party that controls more resources and is thus in a better position to resolve problems must shoulder a greater share of the responsibility.
In order to have inter-party reconciliation, a political leader's words must count, and he "should not manipulate power and be insincere from the very beginning," he said.

Asked whether he is willing to sit down for coffee with the president and talk about reconciliation, Ma said that sipping coffee together is really unnecessary, because people can feel if reconciliation is being strived for as a reflection of good government policy implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACE-PROMOTION BILL ENDANGERS CROSS-STRAIT STATUS QUO: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh warned Friday that the so-called cross-strait peace-promotion bill that the opposition parties plan to push through the legislature next week would put the status quo across the Taiwan Strait in peril.
Hsieh said during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan that the bill, if passed, will make Taiwan lean toward China and force Taiwan to give up many of its long-standing policies.
The cross-strait status quo will thus become hard to maintain, Hsieh said, adding that he believes the public will support the government and will not allow such a bill to pass.

The bill would give the opposition-controlled legislature the power to open transportation links and to form a free trade zone with China, changes which supposedly should be under the authority of the executive branch.
The opposition Kuomintang and People First Party are expected to take advantage of their slim majority to make a second attempt to put the bill to a vote on Tuesday.
Their last attempt failed on Sept. 27 when lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party occupied the podium and paralyzed the legislative session amid scenes of violence.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TOURISM CHIEF WELCOME TO TAIWAN: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday he would extend a hearty welcome to Chinese tourism officials if they really want to visit Taiwan in the near future as some reports have said.
Chen made the remarks in an exclusive interview with Reuters Global Managing Editor David Schlesinger at the Presidential Office in Taipei.

The president said he has outlined three priority topics for negotiations with China: Taiwan's farm produce exports to China, allowing Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes and opening direct charter cargo and passenger flights across the Taiwan Strait.
As all these involve the exercise of public authority, Chen said they should be addressed by officials from both sides or officially-designated groups or units.

Noting that his administration has commissioned appropriate bodies to negotiate with China on the three issues, Chen said Beijing is not entitled to unilaterally name Taiwan organizations to conduct the talks.
Asked whether negotiations have gotten underway or have made any progress, Chen said the two sides have been in touch.
Senior Chinese officials in charge of tourism affairs could visit Taiwan in the near future, Chen said, adding that if that happens, he would extend a warm welcome to them.
Hopefully, Chen said, the two sides can have more contacts, more dialogue and more consultations.

Chen said the opening of direct cross-strait charter flights during the Lunar Chinese New Year holiday earlier this year indicated that with sincerity, the two sides could achieve a breakthrough in their contacts.

Regrettably, Chen said, China's passage of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan shortly after the conclusion of the unprecedented non-stop, two-way cross-strait charter flights in February cast a shadow over bilateral engagements.
In the interview, Chen reiterated that he will never waver from his basic principle of "reconciliation without flinching" in dealing with cross-strait affairs.
"We want to hold a firm stance without becoming confrontational," he said, adding that reconciliation is by no means surrender or compromise on Taiwan's sovereign status.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S TOURISM BUREAU TO SEND DELEGATION TO VISIT TAIWAN THIS MONTH

TEXT.P: China's National Tourism Administration (NTA) is scheduled to send a delegation to Taiwan late this month to look into the local tourism market in preparation for allowing Chinese citizens to visit the island for sightseeing purposes, travel sources said Friday.

At the invitation of Taiwan's Travel Agent Association, NTA Director Shao Qiwei will head a 60-member delegation on a 10-day fact-finding visit to Taiwan in late October, the sources said, adding that the delegation will comprise NTA staff members and tourism chiefs in major Chinese provinces and cities.
In addition to touring Taiwan's major scenic spots, such as Sun Moon Lake, Alishan and Hualien, the delegation will also visit Taiwan's tourism administration offices.
According to the sources, NTA applications have been sent to the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Mainland Affairs Council for approval.

The Republic of China government has decided to open its door to ordinary Chinese citizens to make pleasure trips to Taiwan and has commissioned the Travel Agent Association to negotiate technical details with Chinese authorities.
The NTA delegation is expected to touch on the issue during its upcoming visit to Taiwan, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HON HAI'S SEPTEMBER REVENUE REWRITES EARNINGS RECORD

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., Taiwan's largest IT manufacturer, which also boasts the title of No. 1 electronics manufacturer worldwide, recorded a revenue of NT$68.16 billion (US$2.05 billion) for September, setting a single month record for any listed company in Taiwan.

Hon Hai, which makes a wide range of electronic products both under its own trade name Foxconn and for such companies as Apple, Cisco, Dell, Nokia and Sony, released statistics Friday for its September performance, showing NT$68.16 billion in revenue for the month, which represents an increase of 34.16 percent over August and a growth of 65.4 percent compared with September last year.

For the first nine months of this year, Hon Hai's revenues totaled NT$440.7 billion, representing an increase of 59.32 percent over the same period of 2004 and surpassing its entire revenue of NT$421.67 billion for last year.

Executives of Hon Hai attributed the brilliant performance to the correct policy adopted by Terry Gou two years ago. Gou is chief executive officer of the company and was the one who orchestrated mergers with other companies in different countries.
Most of Hon Hai's factories are in China, with others in Czechoslovakia, Hungary and other countries. The company employs about 100,000 people in China alone.
Since its listing in 1991, Hon Hai has grown significantly in terms of revenues and profit. It has a market capitalization of over US$12 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN WARNS CHINA NOT TO MEDDLE IN TAIWAN'S POLITICS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Beijing would gain nothing by meddling in Taiwan's domestic politics and elections and doing so would not improve relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the remarks in an exclusive interview with Reuters Global Managing Editor David Schlesinger at the Presidential Office in Taipei.

In the interview, Chen was asked to comment on speculation that Beijing may not heed his call for resuming cross-strait talks until after 2008 when his independence-leaning Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) may no longer be in power and another party may take the helm.

In response, Chen claimed that if Beijing pins its hope on Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), to return the pro-unification KMT to power by winning the 2008 presidential election, its dream would not come true.

When he first assumed the presidency in 2000, Chen said, Beijing expected his early ouster. In the run-up to the 2004 presidential election, Beijing hoped that the joint ticket of the KMT and the People First Party could trounce his re-election bid. Beijing's wish didn't materialize.
Since Taiwan began direct presidential elections in 1996, Chen said none of the Beijing-favored candidates have managed to succeed.
Given China's undemocratic, opaque one-party dictatorship, Beijing leaders can't understand Taiwan voters' mindset, Chen said.
It is the 23 million Taiwan people, not a handful of Beijing leaders, who would choose their national leaders, Chen said.
He further said that unless Beijing shows sincerity to genuinely improve cross-strait relations, it cannot narrow the divide with the Taiwan people nor will it win their hearts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PACKAGE TO CLEAR LEGISLATURE AFTER YEAR-END ELECTIONS: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday he believes that his administration's long-stalled arms procurement package can clear the legislature after the year-end "three-in-one" elections.
Chen made the optimistic forecast during an exclusive interview with Reuters Global Managing Editor David Schlesinger at the Presidential Office in Taipei.

For more than a year, the Chen administration's plan to procure three-big ticket items of weapons from the United States has been blocked by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) which controls a slim majority in the Legislative Yuan.
Chen attributed the "pan-blue alliance's" opposition to the package in part to its antagonism toward him and its attempt to curry favors from China.

Another reason is PFP Chairman James Soong's opposition, Chen claimed. According to Chen, Soong has threatened to push for the passage of a bill to force the KMT to return its ill-gotten party assets to national coffers if the KMT dares to soften its stance against the arms procurement package.
Chen said it is regrettable that the KMT puts its ill-gotten party assets above the arms package which he said is critical to Taiwan's defense and overall national interests.

As the KMT needs the PFP's support and cooperation in the run-up to the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections, Chen said he sees little chances for the package to clear the opposition-controlled legislature.
Nevertheless, he added that he believes the legislature would eventually begin to screen the package after the year-end elections.
The arms package includes eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCTOBER 8 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, October 8:
06:50, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will take part in a national mountain climbing day activity at the plaza in front of Grand Hotel in Taipei.
09:10, President Chen Shui-bian will visit a centenarian citizen, Lin Chen-jih, in Taipei.
09:20, Vice President Annette Lu will attend the opening of Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing's campaign headquarters.
12:30, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a ceremony marking the 100th anniversary of Chuwang Temple in Penghu.
13:00, A Double Ten National Day celebrations rehearsal will be held at the Presidential Office plaza in downtown Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 8, or the sixth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: John Hay, U.S. statesman and diplomat, is born. As secretary of state from 1898 to 1905, he promoted the "Open Door Policy" toward China.
1858: The "Arrow Incident" occurs, in which a Hong Kong-registered ship, the Arrow, is searched in Kwantung by Ching soldiers and 12 of the vessel's sailors are arrested. The incident led to an Anglo-French expedition against Peking and the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1869: Franklin Pierce, 14th president of the United States, dies at the age of 65. He was unable to reconcile the issue of slavery that divided his country.
1895: Queen Min of Korea, who had tried to stem the tide of Japanese domination, is assassinated in her palace at the instigation of the Japanese.
1897: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., a New York news agency, comes up with the novel idea of charting general trends in the trading of stocks and bonds on Wall Street. The agency computes a daily industrial average by using a list of 12 stocks and dividing their total price by 12.
1912: Montenegro declares war on Turkey, starting the first Balkan War.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the National government of the Republic of China.
1954: Communist Vietnamese forces occupy Hanoi.
1960: Lei Chen, publisher of the "Free China" monthly magazine, is sentenced to 10 years in prison for involvement in an insurrection.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Senegal.
1965: The Asian Christian Anti-Communist Conference is opened in Taipei.
1967: Clement Attlee, British politician, dies at the age of 84. As Labour prime minister from 1945 to 1951, he established the National Health Service, expanded public ownership of industry, and granted independence to India and Burma.
1970: Russian novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.
1973: Thai Air Force Marshal Boon Choo Chandrubekas arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1974: Economic Minister Y.S. Sun leaves for the United States to attend the China Week Celebration at Expo 74 in Spokane, Washington.
1974: Eisaku Sato, Japanese politician who served as prime minister from 1964 to 1972, is awarded the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts toward nuclear disarmament.
1981: A team of 10 divers recovers 431 gold bars worth US$83 million from the wreckage of the "Edinburgh," a British cruiser sunk by German destroyers and a U-boat in the Barents Sea in 1942.
1981: Costa Rican President Rodrigo Carazo Odio, Madame Carazo, and their 12-member entourage arrive in Taipei for a five-day official visit.
1984: Beijing announces a plan to make primary school education compulsory by 1990 and to eradicate adult illiteracy by 1995.
1992: A chartered plane carrying tourists from Taiwan, Europe, and China crashes in northeast China, killing 13 people and injuring four others.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks Sumatra, Indonesia, killing more than 100.
1997: Tung Chee-hwa becomes the first Chinese leader to address Hong Kong's Legislature, 100 days after Britain ceded the territory to Communist China.
1998: The U.S. House of Representatives approves the launching of a formal impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton, only the third such investigation against a U.S. president in the country's history.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei says the ROC is determined to proceed with a plan to develop its own anti-missile defense even with no outside aid in the face of Beijing's growing missile threat.
2000: Direct air links between Taipei and Manila resume after a protracted dispute over air rights.
2000: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen throws his weight behind the island's controversial fourth nuclear power plant despite the fact that the Cabinet seems determined to stop its construction.
2001: Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao reaffirms that the Republic of China government is opposed to any form of terrorism and that it will "actively participate" in the anti-terrorism campaign launched by the United States.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian receives Japanese Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka, the head of a Japanese delegation for the ROC National Day celebrations.
2001: The National Police Administration (NPA) instructs police to strengthen protection of foreign personnel stationed in Taiwan following the attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of originality, energy, strength of character and determination: qualities necessary for the exercise of endurance."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
