Police officer involved in corruption case to continue to be held after being mistakenly reported that he might have been wrongly detained.
The United Daily News:
President Chen Shui-bian orders probe into several scandals lest they adversely affect year-end elections.
The Liberty Times:
IAEA, ElBaradei win Nobel peace prize.
The Taiwan Daily:
Consultation on new premier needed before toppling the Cabinet: premier.
The Central Daily News:
Opposition parties lambastes president for appointment of a probe team into Kaohsiung MRT project.
The China Post:
Chen appoints acting mayor to lead MRT probe.
The Taiwan News:
Panel to probe MRT woes.
The Taipei Times:
No rush on cross-strait talks: Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: New York Steps Up Subway Security.
City officials Thursday increased security in New York's subways, citing what they called a credible terrorist threat against the nation's largest mass transit system. But authorities with the Department of Homeland Security in Washington downplayed the seriousness of the threat, saying it was of doubtful credibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times IAEA, Eibaradei win Nobel Prize
Mohamed Eibaradei and the International Atomic Energy Agency that he heads won the 2005 Nobel Peace Prize on Friday for their efforts to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Racist bloggers jailed.
The two young men who posted inflammatory racist and vicious remarks about Muslims and Malays on the Internet were given landmark jail sentences yesterday.
The Lianhe Zaobao: New buildings won't be allowed to have gutters.
New buildings won't be allowed to have gutters, the authorities have decided for against dengue and mosquito.
The reason for targeting gutters? They are possibly the most fertile breeding ground for mosquito, being difficult to reach and maintain.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON'S POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN REMAINS UNCHANGED
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of Defense said Friday that its policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged and that the weaponry the United States plans to sell to the country are defensive rather than offensive.
The Pentagon made the remarks in response to a Japan Times' report related to the U.S. military's stance on Taiwan's defense.

According to the report, U.S. military officers who asked not to be named have said that the new commander of American forces in Asia and the Pacific, Adm. William J. Fallon, has quietly encouraged Taiwan "to strengthen its defenses with increased spending, a better command structure, and defensive missiles, mines and helicopters."
The report also said that at the same time, the commander has urged Taipei to forgo high-tech offensive weapons.

Officers in the U.S. Command headquarters have suggested that an arms package featuring weapons such as diesel-electric submarines and destroyers that the Bush administration offered to sell Taiwan in 2001, be allowed to fade away, the report further said, adding that the arms package has languished in Taiwan's legislature due to stonewalling by the opposition.

However, the U.S. Defense Department said it has not changed its policy toward Taiwan and that it remains firmly committed to fulfilling the security and arms sales provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).
"We will continue to assist Taiwan in meeting its legitimate self-defense needs in accordance with our obligations under the TRA," it continued.
The Pentagon also rebutted other parts of the report, pointing out that labeling some items of the arms package as "offensive" weapons is false.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT PEACE PROMOTION BILL VIOLATES THE CONSTITUTION: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday that if a cross-strait peace promotion bill initiated by the opposition People First Party (PFP) becomes law, it will be against the Constitution and complicate the administrative system.
The PFP has put forward the bill in the Legislative Yuan for further review.
Bluntly questioning the contents of the bill, the MAC said that even if it is enacted, it will not be possible to implement it.

If adopted, it will become "Taiwan's version of the Anti-Secession Law enacted by China in March of this year, " it further claimed, adding that the public will question whether Beijing is intervening in Taiwan's legislation process and whether the opposition wants to publicly carry out Beijing's tactics by forcing the government to accept their initiatives.

The council also criticized the PFP bill's intent to legalize the so-called "1992 consensus, " which is not recognized by the Taiwan government, and its interpretation of President Chen Shui-bian's "five noes" statement out of context.

Claiming that the passage of the bill would be a disaster for Taiwan as it would "bring political parties into conflict and the nation into instability," the MAC said that the enactment of the bill would also lead the nation into a constitutional crisis.
So far, the bill has been stalled in the legislature due to opposition by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SUSPENDS APPLE EXPORTS FROM INFESTED ORCHARD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States has temporarily stopped issuing quarantine clearance for a packaging plant that was responsible for processing a shipment of apples destined for Taiwan that were infested with coddling moth, Taiwan officials in the United States said Friday.
The orchard where the apples were produced has also been banned from exporting its fruit to Taiwan for a year, the officials said.
The action was taken after coddling moth larvae were discovered a day earlier by Taiwan quarantine authorities in a shipment of apples from Washington State.

According to Liu Hsing-shan, deputy chief of the economic affairs section at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, the U.S. authorities will provide Taiwan with information concerning the affected orchard and packaging plant within two days and work out an investigative report within one week.
Taiwan imported 63,000 tons of apples worth US$45 million from the United States in 2004, accounted for 50 percent of the country's total apple imports.

According to an agreement signed between Taiwan and the United States in 2003, the United States is required to suspend apple exports to Taiwan if coddling moths are found three times in apple shipments within a year.
Taiwan last banned apple imports from the United States in December 2004 and only lifted the ban in April this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET URGED TO BETTER EXPLAIN FINANCIAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan should seize every opportunity to explain in detail the issues related to the government's ongoing financial reforms, participants in a high-ranking meeting said Friday.

The Presidential Office invited Executive Yuan Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Executive Director of Policy Committee Ker Chien-ming, DPP legislative caucus whip William C.T. Lai and DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang to participate in the meeting.
The participants pointed out that the opposition parties have continued to criticize the second phase of financial reforms, which makes the daunting task even more of a challenge.
The Executive Yuan, the DPP and the DPP legislative caucus should step up their defense and debate of the issue, they said.

The reforms refer to the government's goal of making the joint assets of any three banks exceed 10 percent of the total value of Taiwan's banking sector and to cut the number of 12 state-owned financial institutions in half to six by the end of this year, and to halve the 14 financial holding companies and have at least one bank run by a foreign financial institution by the end of 2006.

On the barrage of media criticism of the scandals surrounding the Taiwan high-speed railway and the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit projects, the participants also claimed that there are "gaps between the reports and the truth, " showing that there is a need for the government to step up its role as an exponent of its major policies.

The participants cited the example of the National Communications Commission bill, saying that it aims at reforms, which should be an issue beneficial to the DPP, but the party has failed to seize an early opportunity to explain it to the public, causing it to lose public support.

The participants also said that reports about China Steel Corp. (CSC) Chairman Lin Wen-yuan receiving an annual bonus of around NT$44 million (US$1.32 million) has further cast the ruling party in a bad light. Lin represents the government in the CSC, which has been privatized, but the government still has a stake in the firm.

The Executive Yuan should also address the questions posed by opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lai Shin-yuan about retired government officials serving in lucrative posts in government-donated foundations, the participants added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EFFORTS TO LOWER SUICIDE RATE NEED TO BE IMPROVED: RESEARCHER

TEXT.P: An Academia Sinica Institute of Biomedical Sciences researcher said Saturday that the government's efforts to reduce the national suicide rate from 14.2 in 100,000 to 11.3 in 100,000 faces many practical challenges.

The challenges include that fact that existing methods of epidemiological surveys on suicides are rough and inaccurate, Cheng Tai-an said in a report on Taiwan's suicide control and prevention framework at a conference held by the National Health Research Institute to map out strategies for suicide control and prevention.

Cheng said he found the actual number of people who kill themselves might be higher than those officially published because in many cases concerning people who die of poisoning or suffocation by toxic gas, prosecutors tend to record the cause of the death as accidental rather than suicide.
In addition, Taiwan has never listed charcoal-burning as a suicide method, even though it became a very common method after a woman killed herself by burning charcoal in Hong Kong in 1998.

The researcher cited official statistics as saying that he found the number of the people in Taiwan who committed suicide by means of "other gas " -- mostly by burning charcoal -- has significantly increased since 2001. In 2003, the number of suicides caused by "other gas" accounted for about 18 percent of the total, a figure that surged to 22.5 percent in 2004.

Even though "other gas" suicide was recorded as the third-most-common suicide method, following hanging and taking poison, no research has been done as to how many people kill themselves by burning charcoal in a year, Cheng said.
Since 2002, suicide has ranked ninth in terms of cause of death in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE WANT CROSS-STRAIT PEACE, STABILITY, GOOD ECONOMY: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Most Taiwan people want a peaceful and stable cross-Taiwan Strait relationship and a good economy, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday.

Expressing his opinions about President Chen Shui-bian remarks in a recent interview on issues related to cross-strait relations and the controversial arms procurement package, Ma said that "Taiwan and China must maintain a stable and peaceful environment as this is the expectation of the Taiwan people."
Ma made the remarks in Yunlin County, where he was wooing support for KMT candidates in the year-end county mayor and magistrate elections.

Even though the president mentioned in the interview his idea of "delaying but engaging in a dialogue without fear" in dealing with cross-strait problems, Ma said that in order to stabilize cross-strait relations, Taipei and Beijing should hold talks as soon as possible.

Touching on Chen's comments that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" stance against the arms procurement package stems from their opposition to him as well as their eagerness to please Beijing, Ma described them as "irresponsible, " claiming that the procrastination over the arms deal in the legislature is the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's "own fault."
According to Ma, the DPP government only put forward the arms procurement bill to the legislature in 2004, although the Bush administration agreed to sell the weapons to Taiwan in 2001.
"It is clear that the DPP has caused many problems on the issue, even though it wants to shift the blame onto the opposition, " he claimed.
He also said the government should do whatever it can to develop the economy, as Taiwan might experience a record low trade surplus this year and a trade deficit next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-GRAFT CAMPAIGN TO TARGET HIGH-TURNOUT AREAS, CAPITAL FLOW

TEXT.P: An anti-graft campaign this year will target areas of high turnout in previous elections and the capital flow of the aspirants, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Saturday.

MOJ officials made the remarks as campaigning for the year-end "three-in-one" elections -- referring to elections of city and county chiefs, councilors, and village and township chiefs -- is gearing up.

They said that to prevent candidates linked to corrupt "black gold" politics from winning elections through vote-buying, the ministry has instructed law enforcement agencies islandwide to keep close tabs on those areas where turnout rates are high, where votes overwhelmingly go to a single candidate and where candidates who have no special relationship to their constituencies are running.
On candidates who are likely to buy votes, the ministry will keep track of the flow of their capital so they will be unable to use their money to buy votes.

The ministry said the anti-graft campaign over the past two months has borne fruit, noting that several aspirants who had originally wanted to register in the elections bowed out, while other aspirants who had wanted to embark on "gift-giving" campaigns during the Mid-Autumn Festival to curry favor with voters had been scared away from doing so.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECTION OF FINANCIAL REFORMS CORRECT: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that the direction of the government's financial reforms is correct, although she admitted there might be flaws in the process of their implementation.

Lu said the second phase of financial reforms that is under way is part of the government's efforts to narrow the wealth disparity and promote economic justice, adding that the government will make sure that the financial system is not monopolized by business conglomerates.
She made the remarks while addressing the opening of Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing's re-election campaign headquarters.

The second phase of financial reform involves the privatization of state-owned banks and mergers between banks, with a goal to halving the number of state-owned banks to six by the end of this year and having at least three domestic banks increase their market shares to more than 10 percent.
Opposition lawmakers have accused the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government of favoring certain pro-DPP business conglomerates in the privatization process.
Also Saturday, Lu visited a shipyard in Kaohsiung City.
Han Pi-hsiang, owner of the yard, took the opportunity to urge the government to put more effort into developing the country's yacht-building industry.
According to Han, the quality of yachts produced in Taiwan is not inferior to that of Europe and the United States, but they are relatively cheaper.
Han said the yachts produced by Taiwan are also more competitive and popular than those produced by China because of their luxurious appearance and facilities.
He called on the government to relax its regulations and build more marinas to facilitate the development of the yachting industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CONTINUE TO PLAY MAJOR ROLE IN GLOBAL VILLAGE: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By C.C. Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to play "an indispensable role in the global village" with its strong competitiveness, ample pool of talent and democratic achievement, Taiwan's representative to South Africa Richard Shih said Friday.
Shih made the remarks when he addressed nearly 300 guests taking part in a banquet to mark Taiwan's Oct. 10 Double Ten Day, or National Day.
He noted that the World Economic Forum in its latest global competitiveness report placed Taiwan fifth among the 117 countries surveyed.
Taiwan has used good management to help people get out of poverty, while its entrepreneurial culture and efficient government have also given rise to a rich pool of high-tech talent, he added.

He said Taiwan will continue to strengthen relations with friendly countries such as South Africa based on its democratic achievement and economic strength and will continue to take part in international affairs through humanitarian assistance, economic cooperation and cultural exchanges.

On bilateral trade in 2004, Shih said Taiwan exported US$655 million-worth of goods to South Africa, up 19 percent from the previous year, while South Africa exported US$1.048 billion-worth of goods to Taiwan, up 40 percent, with South Africa enjoying a trade surplus of US$393 million.
But Shih said trade with South Africa only accounted for 0.5 percent of Taiwan's total trade last year, showing that there is ample room for improvement.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS TRUST IN PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday his trust in Premier Frank Hsieh is beyond question.

Chen's remarks came a day after acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan announced the establishment of a five-member Kaohsiung MRT investigative team to look into controversies surrounding the massive construction project.

Speculation about Chen's trust in Hsieh arose following Yeh's announcement. It was widely believed that Yeh was acting on Chen's directive in launching the inquiry into the problem-ridden project, which got underway during Hsieh's tenure as mayor of Kaohsiung.
Responding to a media query as to whether he still trusts Hsieh, Chen said firmly: "Of course I trust him."
Chen made the response after paying a visit to a 102-year-old resident of Taipei, Lin Chen Jih, as part of celebrations of Senior Citizens' Day which falls on Oct. 11 this year.

The controversies surrounding the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system construction surfaced after a group of Thai laborers working on the project rioted Aug. 21 in protest over unfair and inhumane treatment by their management. Law enforcement authorities have been investigating the cause of the riot and all possible irregularities involved in the employment and management of the Thai workers.

The riot has already led to the resignations of Chen Chu as Council of Labor Affairs chairwoman and Chen Chi-mai as acting Kaohsiung mayor. Earlier this week, two of President Chen's advisers -- Chen Che-nan, who once served as a Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, and Chen Min-hsien, who used to be vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) -- also resigned amid speculation that they might be involved in an illegal profiteering racket between the employer -- KRTC -- and a labor brokerage firm that has exploited Thai laborers.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) approval rating has shown signs of decline since the Aug. 21 riot. As a damage-control measure to prevent the alleged KRTC scandals from affecting the DPP's support rating ahead of the year-end "three-in-one" elections, President Chen reportedly asked Yeh to form a special investigative team to probe the administrative accountability of past Kaohsiung mayors, including Wu Den-yih, Hsieh and Chen Chi-mai, in the controversies.
Yeh said Friday that the five-member team's investigation will be conducted "without any limitations."
"All related personnel, be they former mayors or government officials and the KRTC itself, will be targets of our inquiry, " Yeh told a news conference.
The team, composed of legal and construction experts, will look into alleged conflicts of interest impartially and selflessly and release its findings Oct. 20, Yeh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE SURPLUS DROP DUE TO DECREASED MARKET SHARE IN CHINA: BOFT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's decreased market share in China was the major reason behind a sharp 69.5 percent year-on-year drop in its foreign trade surplus in the first nine months of this year, Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) officials said Saturday.

In the January-September period, the amount of Taiwan's foreign trade accumulated to US$272.36 billion, registering a growth of 8.9 percent over the same period of last year, according to Customs statistics.
The tallies show that exports reached US$137.15 billion in the nine-month period, a growth of 6.9 percent over the previous year, while imports recorded a growth of 10.9 percent to US$135.21 billion.
In September alone, the amount of foreign trade totaled US$31.69 billion for a surplus of US$710 million.

Explaining the surplus decrease, BOFT officials cited statistics released by China's customs authorities as saying that China's general imports from January to August recorded a growth of 15.13 percent over the previous year.
In terms of Taiwan's exports to China, a 10.11 percent increase was registered in the first eight months of this year, smaller than those of South Korea, Singapore, Russia, Australia and Thailand.
Taiwan's market share in China also dropped to 11.04 percent in the eight-month period from the level of 11.54 percent in the same period of last year.
Taiwan lagged behind Japan and South Korea as the third-largest source of imports for China, the officials said.
With the signs showing Taiwan's export dependence on the china market falling, the BOFT will boost its efforts to assist Taiwan exporters to try opening other markets, they added.

According to Taiwan' own customs statistics, the nation's exports to Hong Kong and China totalled US$51.36 billion in the first nine months of this year. The number accounted for 37.4 percent of the island's total exports, posing a growth of 8.4 percent, while the growth of the total exports was 6.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN TO VISIT BRITAIN

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will leave for Britain Sunday to attend a birthday celebration for former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, a PFP lawmaker said Saturday.
Hwang Yih-jiau, who concurrently serves as the PFP legislative caucus whip, said Soong is scheduled to return to Taipei Oct. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MARKET SHARE IN U.S. DROPS: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The market share of Taiwan products in the United States decreased to 2.13 percent in the first seven months of the year from the level of 2.36 percent in 2004 and the 2.51 percent of 2003, according to statistics released Saturday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Taiwan's market share in Japan also dropped, with that of the first eight months of this year shrinking to 3.58 percent from 3.66 percent in 2004 and 3.72 percent in 2003.

Canada, China and Mexico were the three largest exporters to the United States in the first seven months of this year, with the U.S. market share of Canada recorded at 17.7 percent, that of China at 14.04 percent and that of Mexico at 10.24 percent, DGBAS officials said.

The officials attributed China's significant position in the U.S. import market to its low-cost manufacturing, noting that China surpassed Mexico to become the U.S.'s second-largest source of imports in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CONSIDERATION OF PRESIDENCY IN ARMS STANCE: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou claimed Saturday that his party supports "reasonable" arms procurements and will not consider the issue from the point of view of a possible future ruling party.

Ma was responding to media reports that KMT staff recently proposed in a report on the party's response to the controversial arms procurement package that Ma consider the necessity of arms procurement from the angle of a "para-ruling party" head.

Ma said on the sidelines of a trip to Yunlin County to call on KMT Legislator Chang Li-shan, that the long-standing stance of the party has been to support reasonable arms procurements, adding that this is the mainstream party view.

As to what constitutes "reasonable" arms procurements, Ma said only that he has to listen to the voices from all quarters and that "the KMT legislative caucus has been working on an integration process with its ally parties," and the KMT will publicize the result after the integration process completes.

On a reported suggestion that he consider the issue from the angle of the next leader of the nation, Ma said the time-span for the arms procurement is up to 15 years, which covers more than just one presidential term, and for this reason, the presidency term will not be a factor.
He said that arms procurements have to take into consideration Taiwan's defense needs and the maintenance of the necessary deterrent force, as well as the government's financial situation.

The package refers to the purchase of three big-ticket weaponry items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC -III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine P-3C aircraft -- from the United States. For more than a year, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) has used its slim majority in the legislature to stonewall the review of the package.

Ma's staff suggested that the missiles should continue to be blocked, noting that a national referendum held simultaneously with the 2004 presidential election nixed the proposal and that the same proposal could not be posed within three years, while the submarines and anti-submarine planes can be included in the national defense budget starting from 2007.

In the 2004 referendum, the question of whether Taiwan should step up national defense faced with Beijing's missile threat was considered invalid because fewer than half of the eligible voters voted, although over 90 percent of those who did vote answered in the affirmative.

In this way, Ma's staff reasoned, it will avoid being smeared by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for showing no concern for national security and will also avoid being taken hostage by the PFP, which has emerged as the consistent opponent to the arms deal after reports that the KMT might cave in and reconsider its opposition stance.
The PFP has said it opposes listing the arms procurement under a special budget, and that as long as it is listed under the regular budget, there is no reason for the party to oppose it.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG PEOPLE RESPOND ENTHUSIASTICALLY TO TAIWAN RICE

TEXT.P: Response to Taiwan rice has been enthusiastic at a Taiwan rice expo in Hong Kong, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Saturday.

The rice expo, sponsored by TAITRA at the commission of the Council of Agriculture, is being held at a Hong Kong department store Oct. 6-17, the first time Taiwan has organized a rice-promotion activity there.

TAITRA officials said more than 30 kinds of rice products from Taiwan are being displayed, including the premium Chishan rice from Taitung, eastern Taiwan, which won the top prize in a recent rice competition.

Hong Kong customs tallies show that the former British colony imports over 300,000 tons of rice every year from overseas, mainly from Thailand, and the officials said the Hong Kong market is worth tapping by local rice producers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS DENY CHANGING POSITION ON U.S. ARMS DEAL

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators denied Saturday a report that the party is considering dropping its opposition to the government's controversial arms procurement package from the United States.

Members of a KMT panel studying the arms procurement plan, who include Shuai Hua-min, Ting Shou-chung and Su Chi, said the group has not met lately and that the party has not made a final decision as to how it will deal with the package.

According to a proposal reportedly put forth by a key KMT member, the party, in preparation for a possible return to power in 2008, should demand that the government include the plan to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft in the regular annual budget from 2007.
As to the plan to purchase six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, the KMT should continue to block it within the three years since a referendum was held on the issue.

President Chen Shui-bian called the referendum alongside the presidential election on March 18, 2004 to let the people vote on whether to purchase more anti-missile armaments. The referendum was declared invalid because fewer than half of the eligible voters took part in the poll. According to the country's referendum law, no referendum can be held on the same issue within three years of it being voted on.

Ting claimed that the three weapons are unnecessary in light of the cross-Taiwan Strait and international situations, adding that whether the KMT will support the arms procurement plan is not related to whether it will return to power.

In response to the report, opposition People First Party (PFP) legislative caucus convener Huang Yi-chiao said the PFP will remain opposed to the arms procurement plan as long as it is financed by a special budget instead of the regular annual budget.

However, Huang said, the PFP will not support the plan to purchase the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, even though the Ministry of National Defense has included it in the government's annual budget for 2006, because the plan is inconsistent with the result of the referendum.
He said the KMT would be making a "serious mistake" if it were to consider the issue from the perspective of whether it will return to power.

Meanwhile, William Lai, the leader of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucus, said the report, if proven true, would indicate that the KMT is ready to continue to delay the arms procurement.

Lai urged the KMT and PFP not to misinterpret the result of the referendum, saying that the fact that the referendum is invalid does not mean the people are opposed to the purchase of anti-missile armaments.
DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung warned that Taiwan might have problems obtaining the weapons if the opposition parties continue to block the procurement plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE CONDEMNS OPPOSITION LAWMAKER FOR MUDSLINGING

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office denounced a controversial lawmaker's speculation Saturday that a Kaohsiung MRT system contractor might have won contracts because of his ties with the first family.

Legislator Chiu Yi, who collaborates with the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) caucus in the legislature after quitting the People First Party earlier this year but who has so far not yet become a formal KMT member, claimed at a news conference Saturday that all suspicious irregularities surrounding the Kaoshiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) are related to Huang Chang Co., whose chairman has close ties to first lady Wu Shu-jen.

Chiu further claimed that Huang Chang Chairman Chiang Cheng-jin got acquainted with President Chen Shui-bian when both of them were serving jail terms in the 1980s. Chen was once imprisoned for a libel suit during Taiwan's martial law era.
"Chiu's insinuation that Chen gave favors to Chiang is a mudslinging tactic, " said Chen Wen-chung, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department.
According to Chen Wen-chung, President Chen got acquainted with Chiang during his tenure as Taipei mayor because Chiang's company was a contractor of various Taipei MRT construction projects.
"Chiang won all those Taipei MRT contracts during the mayorship of Huang Ta-chou, Chen's predecessor, " Chen Wen-chung said. Huang, a KMT stalwart, lost his mayoral bid to Chen in 1994.

After Ma Ying-jeou, who now doubles as KMT chairman, took the Taipei City Government's helm in 1998, Chen Wen-chung said, Chiang still managed to win many infrastructure construction contracts in the capital city.
Chen Wen-chung further said President Chen didn't know whether Chiang had been jailed, not to mention whether they had served jail term at the same time.

Stressing that President Chen has on many occasions thrown his wholehearted support behind judicial probes into whether any conflicts of interest, kickbacks or other irregularities were involved in the multibillion-dollar Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system construction project.

Meanwhile, William Lai, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said Chiu is notorious for making false accusing. Among others, Lai said, Chiu once accused a prosecutor investigating the KRTC scandals as a womanizer. But it was later proved that the prosecutor named by Chiu was a woman.

Lai said Chiu should present evidence to back his accusations against President Chen. "Otherwise, he should make an apology, " Lai said, adding that the DPP caucus plans to ask the legislature's disciplinary commission to discipline Chiu for making false accusation against the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ARTS FESTIVAL OPENS AT WORLD FINANCIAL CENTER IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Sofia wu and Eric Tseng)

TEXT.P: A five-day Taiwan Arts Festival opened at the World Financial Center in New York Friday to introduce modern and traditional Taiwanese arts to New Yorkers and tourists as well.

The festival marks the first time that the Taipei Culture Center under the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York and the World Financial Center's arts activity department have co-organized an event.
It is also the largest and most representative Taiwan arts activity in New York in recent memory.

During the five-day period, four performances of ancient Nankuan "Southern Winds" music, traditional Taiwanese tea ceremony and weaving of bamboo strips will be presented everyday from noon. Each performance will span about 40 minutes.
The venue is decorated with calligraphic and painting works created by Taiwan artists as well as butterfly orchids and other potted flowers and bamboo trees from Taiwan.

Liu Pei, director of the Taipei Culture Center, said the World Financial Center provides the place for free and has assisted in marketing and publicity posters designing and production. The World Financial Center also promised to sponsor a large-scale Taiwan arts festival next summer, Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEGETABLE VENDOR DONATES NT$4.5 MILLION TO ALMA MATER

TEXT.P: A vegetable vendor in the eastern city of Taitung received a citation from Premier Frank Hsieh Saturday for donating her personal savings to her alma mater to build a library.

Chen Shu-chu, 56, began to sell vegetables at a traditional marketplace in Taitung City at the age of 16. Over the past 40 years, she managed to save NT$4.5 million which she donated to her alma mater -- Jen Ai Elementary School in Taitung City -- last month to help finance the school's library construction project.
Premier Hsieh flew to Taitung Saturday to present a citation in honor of Chen.
Noting that Chen has set a good model for other people to emulate, Hsieh said he admires Chen's generosity.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Casini: Majority has right to decide.
Rebutting criticism from the opposition over the ruling coalition's plan to revise the electoral law, House of Deputies Speaker Pierferdinando Casini said Friday in a rally that the majority has the established right to decide in accordance of the principles of democracy and that his role is to keep the legislation under the framework of the constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE

TEXT.P: THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Bush Plan Shows U.S. Is Not Ready for Deadly Flu
A draft of the plan says that an outbreak that began in Asia would likely reach the U.S. within "a few months or even weeks."

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTION OFFICE CLARIFIES STANCE

TEXT.P: The State Public Prosecutor General's Office (SPPGO) reiterated Saturday that prosecution authorities have no preset stance on the investigation into all alleged scandals in the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) system construction.

As the investigation is still going on, the nation's highest prosecutor's office said in a press release that prosecution authorities can not publicize the content of its inquiry and all reference materials and data at the moment.

The SPPGO issued the statement after the legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) held a news conference earlier in the day to demand that the SPPGO explain in detail progress in its probes into the alleged Kaohsiung MRT scandals in 10 days.

KMT lawmakers claimed at the news conference that the SPPGO " has deliberately skipped key points" in its Friday press release about progress in its inquiry into whether any irregularities or conflicts of interests were involved in the Kaohsiung City Government's decision to adopt a BOT (build-operate-transfer) formula for the city's MRT system.

They also made some suggestions for prosecutors responsible for investigating the case, including whether any high-ranking officials other than former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan, were involved in the alleged scandals.
The SPPGO said it will convey the KMT's opinions to the special prosecutorial task force in charge of the case.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, October 9:

09:30, President Chen will hold talks with Maduro at the Presidential Office.

18:30, President Chen will host a state dinner in honor of Gambia President Jammeh at Tayih Landis hotel in Tainan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 9, or the seventh day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1192: King Richard the Lion-hearted abandons the Holy Land after an unsuccessful Crusade, leaving Jerusalem in Muslim hands.
1701: Yale University is founded in New Haven, Connecticut.
1944: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrives in Russia to talk with Joseph Stalin in the Third Moscow Conference.
1944: The United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the Republic of China promulgate a draft for the Charter of the United Nations.
1958: Pope Pius XII, originally Eugenio Pacelli, dies at the age of 82. He headed the Roman Catholic Church during World War II.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Congo Republic.
1962: Uganda gains formal independence after nearly 70 years of British rule.
1965: ROC Ambassador to the United States and Representative to the United Nations Tsiang Ting-fu dies of liver cancer in New York at the age of 71.
1967: Ernesto "Che" Guevara, the Argentine-born revolutionary who helped Fidel Castro gain power in Cuba, is shot dead after being captured by Bolivian army troops. He was 39.
1967: Indonesia severs diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1970: Dissident Soviet writer Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize for literature, turns down an invitation to Stockholm to attend the award ceremony in December.
1970: Cambodia declares itself the Khmer Republic.
1972: Prime Minister Tupua Tamasese Lealofi IV of Western Samoa arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Mayor Chang Feng-shu of Taipei leaves for Honolulu to attend a council meeting of the Asian and Pacific Area Conference of Mayors.
1974: A two-day post-congress symposium of the first conference of the World Nuclear Medicine Federation opens in Taipei.
1975: Soviet dissident and human rights activist Andrei Sakharov is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Alberto Nogues Perez, foreign minister of Paraguay.
1983: South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan escapes unharmed when 17 members of his entourage, including Foreign Minister Lee Bum Suk, are killed in a bomb blast in Rangoon.
1984: A famous Cantonese opera performer from mainland China, Hung Hung, 40, announces her defection in a press conference held at the Free China Relief Association in Taipei.
1986: The Executive Yuan passes the Program for Taroko National Park, in which NT$4 billion is to be invested in developing the park over six years.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Task Force approves the first draft of the Temporary Provisions Governing Relations between the People of the Mainland Region and Taiwan Region.
1998: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government resigns after losing its 31st vote of confidence.
1999: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui urges mainland China to promote relations with Taiwan based on a "special state-to-state relationship."
2000: Haitian President Rene Preval and his wife, leading an official delegation, arrive in Taipei to attend celebration activities marking the ROC's Double-Ten National Day.
2001: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taiwan holds a party to mark the 50th anniversary of its founding.
2001: The five-day 2001 Taipei International Electronics Show kicks off with the number of international buyers in the first day down significantly compared with the previous year's figures.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of dignity, noble seriousness, order and regularity: qualities necessary for the exercise of self-respect."

Massive Earthquake In S. Asia Kills 2,000; Temblor Measures 7.6; Pakistan Is Hit Hardest.
Rescuers struggled to reach victims of the devastating earthquake that struck near the Indian-Pakistani border in the disputed Kashmir region Saturday. The quake killed at least 2,000 people, most in remote parts of northern Pakistan.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Palace sees less tension
Malacanang is anticipating the end of the weeks-old political row between the executive and the legislature due to several confidence-building measures taken by both sides recently.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Break silence, US urged
THREE senior administration lawmakers urged the United States government yesterday to break its silence on the espionage case of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and immediately identify the brains so they could be charged before Philippine courts.
The Philippine Star: DOJ probes local links of FBI spy
The Department of Justice has ordered an investigation into possible links between opposition leaders and Filipino-American FBI analyst Leandro Aragoncillo, arrested for stealing confidential information from the White House.
The Manila Times: Quake jolts South Asia
A magnitude 7.6 earthquake jolted South Asia on Saturday, killing scores people and injuring hundreds of others in Pakistan, Afghanistan and India.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN SOONG DANCES AROUND ISSUE OF RUNNING FOR TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: To run or not to run -- that is the question the public was pondering Sunday regarding a possible run for Taipei mayor by People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, after a local paper speculated that he would throw his hat in the ring for the year-end election.
Soong tried to dodge the media Sunday morning before hopping a plane to London. However, he did address claims that he was over the hill when it came to running against younger candidates.

The 63-year-old said his critics were using a double standard. Soong claimed that when he was urged to be Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's running mate in the 2004 presidential election -- which Lien and he lost -- he was younger than Lien. "Lien was senior to me, but now you say I am a bit too old to run for Taipei mayor."

He added that a candidate's ability and willingness to serve society is more important than his age, but refused to confirm or deny that he was planning on running for Taipei mayor. However, he did say that he appreciated the support for the idea from his followers.

Then, seemingly to ensure that no one could be clear on his exact intention, Soong turned to PFP Legislator Lee Ching-an who was at the airport to see him off and said that Lee ought to make a bid for the mayorship, "That is, if I don't run myself," Soong said.

Although Soong, a former Taiwan provincial governor, would be setting a precedent by stooping to run for the lesser position of mayor, the China Times said he was likely to be a candidate since it would be the only way that Soong could regain any political clout, which would give his ailing KMT spin-off party a lifeline.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Devastating earthquake kills thousands in Pakistan.
A 7-6-magnitude earthquake hit border area between Pakistan and India in Kashmir Saturday morning, killing thousands people. A village near the epicenter was totally destroyed and some 400 students were killed in a school where classrooms collapsed. The casualty toll is expected to continue to rise.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME NOT RIGHT TO ENACT PFP VERSION OF CROSS-STRAIT PEACE LAW: MAC

TEXT.P: Now is not the time to legislate a law to promote peace between Taiwan and China as proposed by the opposition People First Party (PFP) , a ranking Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Sunday.

MAC Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng quoted a Taiwan ThinkTank survey as warning that if the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), joins hands with its political ally, the PFP, to pass the bill in the legislature, it will exacerbate social divisions and confrontations between the ruling and opposition parties.

Huang made the comments at a Taiwan ThinkTank news conference to announce the finding of a survey it conducted, which found that just over 60 percent of respondents who were familiar with the PFP-sponsored bill said that if it is forced through the legislature, it would accelerate social divisions.
He added that if the bill is enacted as it stands, it will become a "bylaw" of China's Anti-Secession Law that threatens to use "non-peaceful means" to settle cross-strait issues.
He said the PFP bill runs counter to the principles of consensus, public support and constitutional rule, and the MAC "firmly opposes and will never accept it."

"People will question if China has meddled in the legislative process of the bill; they will also wonder if some elements in Taiwan are openly carrying out China's strategy of 'using civilians to force the government's hand' and 'using the opposition parties to bully the ruling party,'" Huang said.

He explained that the bill has a "serious fallacy" in that it will formally incorporate into law the so-called "1992 consensus" as well as a biased interpretation of President Chen Shui-bian's commitment to his "four noes" policy -- no changes to the title of the Republic of China, no declaration of Taiwan independence, no referendum on Taiwan's future, and no amendment to the Constitution to show that the relations between Taiwan and China are special "state-to-state" in nature.

The "1992 consensus" refers to the concept that both China and Taiwan belong to "one China, " with both sides free to interpret the meaning of the term. Many officials in Taiwan, particularly from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its allies, say that no consensus was ever reached on the matter.

According to the Taiwan ThinkTank poll, more than 50 percent of Taiwan's public do not know that the "pan-blue alliance" of the PFP and the KMT are pushing the PFP version of the bill, but of those who know, 63 percent feared it will worsen social divisions if the "pan-blue alliance" rams it through the Legislative Yuan, where the alliance enjoys a slim majority.
In view of this, Huang said, now is not the right time to legislate such a law given that it might induce cross-strait relations to develop in an unreasonable direction, rather than promoting peace.

Professor Chen Ming-tung of National Taiwan University called on KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, a law professor-turned politician, to stop the bill from being passed because it violates the principle of constitutional rule and the principle of political responsibility.

Hsu Sze-chien, an assistant research fellow at Academia Sinica, pointed to the international implications of the PFP bill, saying that its initiation alone indicates that the ruling-opposition confrontation at the legislature is reaching a peak, and the world will interpret this as the collapse of Taiwan's internal mechanism to settle differences through the political process.

"This certainly would tarnish Taiwan's image since foreigners think that Taiwan is a polity that is incapable of taking responsibility for its own actions, " Hsu said. He urged the opposition not to do something that would result in consequences that would be unbearable.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY SHOWS LOW JOB APPROVAL RATINGS FOR ALL POLITICAL PARTIES

TEXT.P: The public has a low opinion of the performance of all major political parties and President Chen Shui-bian's job approval rating has hit its lowest level since he became president in 2000, according to results of an opinion survey released Sunday.

The poll, conducted by the United Daily News Oct. 7-8, shows that Chen's overall job approval has dropped to 25 percent, a sharp contrast to the 79 percent approval rating he received shortly after he became president in 2000.
Chen's 25 percent approval rating represents a 9 percent slide from a month ago. Respondents who said they are dissatisfied with his performance also reached a new high -- 54 percent.
The approval rating of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) also plunged to 24 percent, with 56 percent of the respondents saying they are dissatisfied with the party's performance.

The poll comes on the heels of allegations of corruption by some DPP officials regarding a profiteering case brought to light because of the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit system in protest of their inhumane treatment by a manpower management company.

Sixty-one percent of those polled believe that the DPP has lost its core values. Forty-nine percent see the DPP as a corrupt party, while 45 percent view the party as having neglected the people's wishes, with 43 percent blaming the DPP for not paying attention to social justice.
The survey also found that 72 percent of the respondents believe there has been collusion between certain government officials and private companies for mutual profiteering.

The other three main political parties did not fare well in the poll either. Although the Kuomintang (KMT), the largest opposition party, received the highest approval of 35 percent, the rate represents a 14 percent drop from July, when the party was preparing to hold its election for chairman.
The People First Party, an ally of the KMT in the "pan-blue alliance," had an approval rating of 20 percent, while the Taiwan Solidarity Union's performance was approved of by only 19 percent.
The poll, based on telephone interviews with a randomly selected sample of 1,088 people, was taken Oct. 7-8. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA PROMISES TO LEAD KMT SELF-REVIEW TO REGAIN PUBLIC CONFIDENCE

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said Sunday that he will lead a review to find out why the party's approval rating fell 14 percent from July to the current 35 percent, as shown by results of a new poll.

Chairing a meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee, Ma said the approval rating fall is a warning for the KMT, although the party scored better than the other parties in the poll, conducted by the United Daily News Oct. 7-8.

According to results of the survey released Sunday, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) had a 24 percent approval rating, while the People First Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) received 20 percent and 19 percent, respectively.

Fifty-six percent of the respondents said they are dissatisfied with the performance of the DPP. The numbers were not much better for the KMT, the PFP and the TSU, who scored negative ratings of 43 percent, 53 percent and 46 percent, respectively.

Ma stressed that the KMT must not be complacent even though the other parties fared even worse than the KMT in the poll, and that as a party with the ability to reflect upon itself, the KMT must find out what factors caused the plunge in its approval rating if the party is to regain the confidence of the public.

The KMT chairman cautioned party members that when the ruling and the opposition parties are being compared in terms of whose performance is worse, voters who are dissatisfied with the other parties may not necessarily become supporters of the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT PEACE BILL A MYSTERY TO HALF OF RESPONDENTS IN POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of the people responding to a Taiwan Thinktank-sponsored survey had no idea that the People First Party (PFP) was sponsoring a bill advocating cross-strait peace, and 63 percent who were aware of the legislation felt that it would only fuel divisions in Taiwan.

Moreover, the poll released Sunday showed that the same 63 percent said that the bill, which would give the opposition-controlled legislature the power to call the shots in forming policy toward China, would intensify the confrontation between the legislature and the executive branch.

The survey conducted by the Focus Survey Research Corporation found that 55.6 percent of those interviewed didn't know the opposition PFP, with the support of the Kuomintang (KMT), is pushing for a cross-strait peace-promoting bill, let alone that it was going to try to ramrod the bill through the legislature this Tuesday.
However, 57.9 percent said that, being informed of the situation, they are concerned about the bill.
The survey also showed that 50.9 percent said that they are unsatisfied with the way the Legislative Yuan is pushing for peace with China.

As to the question of who is better suited to represent Taiwan in negotiations with China, the president or the legislature, 40.2 percent said the president, against 32.5 percent opting for the legislature.
Also, 60.5 percent said they do not favor writing the "one China" principle into law as the proposed bill would do.

Citing the survey, the Taiwan ThinkTank said the PFP and KMT are running against public opinion by pushing for the legislation, which would empower the legislature to dictate China policy to the administration.

The survey conducted Oct. 7-8 by telephone, gathered 1,130 valid replies, with the make-up of the respondents mirroring the ratios of the various political parties in the legislature with a error margin of plus or minus 2.92 percentage points, the author of the poll claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HONORS GAMBIAN HEAD OF STATE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian welcomed visiting Gambian President Yahya Jammeh and his wife with military honors in the plaza of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall opposite the Presidential Office.
The Jammehs are in Taiwan to attend the celebration of the Republic of China's 94th Double Ten National Day as guests of the ROC president.
Chen told Jammeh that the ROC and the Gambia have entered the 10th year since the two countries resumed diplomatic relations, and that both countries are facing some new challenges.
He said he would use the opportunity of Jammeh's visit to discuss issues of mutual concern, including the current world situation and regional problems.
Chen expressed the hope that the two countries will further strengthen their relationship and help promote world peace and international justice.
The current visit is Jammeh's sixth visit to the ROC and his third visit in three consecutive years.

Chen later accompanied Jammeh on a tour to Tainan County in southern Taiwan to see the operations of the Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center. He will entertain the Gambian president and his entourage at a tourist hotel in Tainan Sunday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO 'FIGHT TO THE VERY END' TO STOP PFP PEACE BILL IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) vowed Sunday that its legislative caucus will "fight to the very end" to resist the opposition's attempt to pass a bill proposed by the People First Party (PFP) to promote peace between Taiwan and China.

William C.T. Lai, DPP caucus secretary-general, said the PFP bill as it stands is nothing but a by-law of China's Anti-Secession Law which threatens to use "non-peaceful means" to settle disputes between Taiwan and China.

He accused the PFP of proposing a bill that, if enacted, would usurp power from the executive branch of government to formulating China policy, which would instead be vested in the opposition-controlled legislature, resulting in Taiwan's "actual surrender to China in the name of peace."

Therefore, in spite of the opposition's slim majority in the Legislative Yuan, the DPP caucus has issued a "class-A" alert for all members to be present on Tuesday, when the PFP-initiated bill is due for a show-down vote.
"We will fight to the end, although we will not provoke anyone, " Lai said.

He urged the PFP to realize that any legal structure promoting peace between Taiwan and China must first obtain the support from a broad cross-section of the public, and if it and its "pan-blue alliance" ally, the Kuomintang, railroad the bill through the legislature, it will not help solve problems between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lai accused the PFP of threatening to pass the bill even at the price of blood, adding that he fears that bloody clashes might occur in the legislative hall.

Chao Yung-ching, DPP caucus convener, said only one article in the PFP bill has passed at the legislature's home affairs committee, so the "pan-blue alliance" should not use "numerical violence" to push the entire bill through the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 UNIVERSITIES TO SHARE NT$50 BILLION GRANT TO IMPROVE QUALITY

TEXT.P: The government announced Sunday the 12 universities who will share NT$50 billion (US$1.5 billion) in grants to elevate them to the ranks of the world's best 100 universities.
Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng announced the winners after a six-month assessment by the ministry.

Among the winners, 10 were national universities, including National Taiwan University in Taipei, National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu City, National Chao Tung University in Hsinchu City, National Cheng Kung University in Tainan City, National Yang-Ming University in Taipei, National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan, National Sun Yat-sen University in Kaohsiung City, National Chung Hsing University in Taichung City, National Chengchi University in Taipei City, and National Taiwan University of Science and Technology in Taipei City.
Only two private universities were on the list; they are Chang Gung University in Linko, Taoyuan County, and Yuang Ze University in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
The grant program was created by the government to increase the academic level of local universities to that of world-class institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKER ADVOCATES SUITING UP FOR RUMBLE IN THE LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Expecting a lawmakers' version of "Kung Fu Hustle" over the vote of the bill for the National Communications Commission (NCC) Tuesday in the Legislative Yuan, an opposition lawmaker Sunday advised fellow party lawmakers wear karate uniforms to be ready to thwart any ruling party attempts to take over the proceedings by force.

Huang Yi-chiao, convener of the People First Party's (PFP) legislative caucus, revealed his party's strategy to prevent ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators from commandeering the speaker's quarters and paralyzing legislative proceedings as they did on Sept. 27.

Huang recommended that KMT lawmakers come to the floor wearing martial arts gees like the one the youngest member of the KMT, Huang Chih-hsiung, was wearing when he won the silver medal in taekwondo at the last Olympics, and join the PFP's Chang Hsien-yao and Hsieh Kuo-liang, who are martial arts students, to "maintain order on the legislative floor" Tuesday.
Huang said the PFP is a "modest and reasonable" party that does not seek violence. "However, we are not afraid of any violent provocation," he declared.

He noted that if the DPP uses violence to stop the legislature from dealing with the NCC organic bill, "We believe that Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng will call in the police as he sees fit."

Both PFP and its "pan-blue alliance" ally, the Kuomintang (KMT), have issued a "class-A" alert to their caucus members, readying them for a possible clash during the show-down vote. The alliance enjoys a slim majority over the "pan-green" camp of the DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee and caucus whip, called on the DPP to give up its intention to "unreasonably filibuster" and to allow a free vote on the bill so that Taiwan's media industry can have a "clean environment" in which to develop.

Tseng said the "pan-blue alliance" caucuses have made a concession to the "pan-green" camp by giving up some pre-registered spots to speak on individual articles of the bill, so that a representative from each party can speak for an equal amount of time before putting the bill to a vote.

As to the focus of the controversy -- the composition of NCC members -- Tseng said the "pan-blue alliance" will not change its basic position that members be selected in accordance with the percentage of legislative seats each party holds.
"We are insisting on this simply to keep the ruling party from manipulating the media by appointing all the president's men to the NCC," he said.

He repeated the KMT-PFP version of the bill regarding the appointment of members -- they would come from such backgrounds as humanities, telecommunications, mass communications, finance and economy and they must not have held any political party job within the last three years.
"This is our proposal regarding the qualifications and ethical requirements for NCC members, a proposal we believe will stand the test of public opinion," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PITCHES FOR FREE TRADE AGREEMENT WITH HONDURAS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made a pitch for the signing of a free trade agreement with Honduras during a state banquet host by him for visiting Honduras President Ricardo Maduro Sunday.

Noting that a free trade agreement between the United States and Central America, as well as the Dominican Republic will take effect on Jan. 1, next year, Chen said his country is eager to tap the American market via its Central American allies, not the least Honduras.
Honduras can work together with Taiwan more closely in exploring the North America market if a free trade agreement is concluded between the two countries, hopefully during Maduro's term, Chen said.

He reiterated a promise he made on Sept. 22 in Guatemala City when he was on a trip to five Central American states that his country will offer US$250 million in aid to its allies there and encourage Taiwan businessmen to invest there.
The president admired Maduro as a successful entrepreneur and a statesman with vision, adding that he hopes he will enjoy his time in Taiwan.
Maduro arrived in Taiwan earlier in the day for the celebration of Taiwan's Double Ten National Day on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOOM TIME EXPECTED TO CONTINUE IN TAIWAN'S HOUSING MARKET

TEXT.P: The significant increase in the number of real estate brokers in Taiwan in the past years signifies that the boom in Taiwan's housing market is likely to continue, a major real estate broker predicted Sunday.

In a research report, Sinyi Real Estate quoted statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior as showing that the number of real estate brokers in Taiwan increased 40 percent in 2004, and is expected to rise another 30 percent this year.

The number of real estate brokers registered with the Ministry of the Interior stood at 2,825 as of Oct. 5, with Taipei County ranking first with 492 brokers, followed by Taipei City with 489 and Taoyuan County, which has 307 brokers, surpassing Taichung City and Kaohsiung City for the first time.
Researchers at Sinyi said they believe that the increase in the number of real estate brokers is a clear indication of their confidence in the prospect of Taiwan's housing market.

Figures compiled by Sinyi show that housing transactions in Taiwan increased 19.6 percent in 2004, with continuous growth in each season. The housing market recorded a 23.5 percent growth in 2002, its first positive growth in six years. The year 2003 saw a growth of only 9 percent, due mainly to the influence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD: DPP WILL PECK OUT 'BAD GUYS' LIKE WOODPECKER

TEXT.P: Chairman Su Tseng-chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) compared his party Sunday to a woodpecker that will peck out "bad elements" within the party to project its image as a political party capable of self-reflection and self-renewal.

Su made his remarks while campaigning for Luo Wen-chia, DPP nominee for Taipei County magistrate -- Taiwan's largest county. The race is being viewed as a critical bridgehead to keep the party's ruling power in 2008, as a published poll indicated that about 46 percent of the respondents think the DPP is not a party of integrity. The poll also showed that President Chen Shui-bian's popularity is at an all-time low.

Su said a party's popularity rises and falls, so it's normal to see survey figures go up and down; the upcoming elections are for local governments, and the voters attach importance to the candidates themselves, not to the parties that nominate them. He said he believes that DPP candidates are "competent" and that their chances for getting elected will not be affected by polls.
However, he also admitted that the DPP needs to be humble and listen to the voice of the people and act like a woodpecker to "peck out bugs that are hurting the tree."

"The biggest enemy of the DPP is itself, " said Su, "so we must face ourselves and seek boldly to reform." He stressed that President Chen will never halfheartedly do the task of "getting at the bad elements" in the party.

Su said the president will use the "quickest and most forceful" way to tackle alleged corruption cases involving party members, "so please believe in his determination and give the DPP another chance."

Luo, who along with a DPP faction leader, Yuan Yi-kang, recently launched a drive to "renew the DPP, " said they did so merely to invite party members to think over recent incidents and try to recall the party's core values that can be summed up as "freedom, democracy, fairness and justice."

As to allegations that he was doing this simply in a bid to save his election campaign, Luo said he had just said what he needed to say and did what he should have done. "Now I feel totally at ease and clear in my mind," he added.

Los Angeles Times: 30 Reported Dead as Strong Quake Hits South Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS UNAWARE OF CABINET RESHUFFLE PLAN

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is not aware of any plan by President Chen Shui-bian for a partial reshuffle of the Cabinet, a whip of the DPP caucus said Sunday.
News reports quoted a source in the DPP as saying that a reshuffle is inevitable and is likely to take place before the December elections of mayors and country magistrates.

Asked to comment, Legislator Lai Ching-te, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said the party should be introspective and institute intra-party reforms if need be, but he added that a Cabinet reshuffle before the elections would be unnecessary.
He said the DPP caucus believes reports about a reshuffle are nothing more than opposition parties' tactics.

Also commenting on the reports, Legislator Huang Shih-cho, convener of the legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union -- an ally of the DPP in the "pan-green" alliance -- suggested that the DPP government should try to maintain political stability in Taiwan before the year-end elections by avoiding such a reshuffle.

Meanwhile, Sun Ta-chien, deputy convener of the opposition Kuomintang's legislative caucus, said the reports about the reshuffle plan signify that the president is not happy with the performance of the Cabinet led by Premier Frank Hsieh.

Sun added that he believes that a series of scandals and disputes, including the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project, have apparently created negative impacts on the DPP's election campaign.

He said the ongoing investigation led by acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan into possible roles played by three former Kaohsiung mayors, including Hsieh, in a profiteering case involving the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project at the instruction of the president has become a threat to the premier's political future.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOW POPULARITY FOR ALL PARTIES INDICATES 'JOINT DESTRUCTION': PREMIER

TEXT.P: An opinion poll published on the eve of the National Day rocked the nation Sunday, with Premier Frank Hsieh saying low support rates for both the ruling and opposition parties indicate people's aversion to politics, pointing to "joint destruction."

Making his "Report to the People" in Chiayi County, central Taiwan, Hsieh referred to the United Daily News survey which shows President Chen Shui-bian's popularity had dipped to an all-time low and public support for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party also dropped to just 24 percent.

But he also cited statistics of the same poll showing that support for the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) fell by 14 percent to 35 percent from July, when the party was preparing to elect a new chairman. Support for the second largest opposition People First Party was at 20 percent, while that for the minor opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) was at 19 percent.
The low popularity for all political parties is an indication of the people's dislike of politics, "and this is joint destruction, " said the premier.

His pessimism was shared by Vice President Annette Lu, who in Taipei told the media before attending a music concert in celebration of the Double Ten National Day that some media just like to criticize from different perspectives, making people wonder "what is our nation's future?"

Chang Fu-mei, chairwoman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, sponsor of the concert, said media polls or criticisms should be seen as an effort to "rectify things out of true love of the country." So the DPP, as the ruling party, will "reflect deeply on itself," Chang added.
She also urged the media to report more on the DPP government's "positive performances" instead of merely muckraking.

In Tung-shih town, Chiayi County, Hsieh urged the media not to use "double standards" to look at the government's performance. He cited a media report naming Hwang Chang General Contractor Co. as a "new friend of the DPP government" while the company has been cited by Taipei City Government, whose mayor is now KMT chairman.
Even if Hwang Chang were in any way involved in any unlawful activities, it should be investigated by the prosecution, and should not be alleged by the media, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RED CROSS RAISING FUNDS TO HELP S. ASIA QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China launched a fund-raising campaign Sunday to help the victims of a disastrous earthquake that hit Pakistan and India, killing more than 20,000 people.

Meanwhile, the Red Cross Society has asked its rescue team members as well as volunteers to stand by for calls any moment to provide emergency assistance to the survivors in the affected areas, said Lin Hsiu-fen, director of the society's public affairs department.

For those interested in donating through the post office, please remit any sum of money to the Red Cross Society of the ROC at account number 14341596, noting the fund is for "earthquake in India and Pakistan, South Asia."

People in Taiwan can also go to the society's website (www.redcross.org.tw) for more information about ways and means of showing love and concern, including using cell phones to make up to NT$1,000 in donation.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has asked the country's top envoy to India Kao Chen-chun to forward Taiwan's sympathy and condolences to India and Pakistan while the ministry was mapping out a plan to render assistance.
