DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO CLEAN GOVERNMENT AND REFORMS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his commitment to keep his administration clean and to press ahead with reforms in his Double Ten National Day address Monday.

In a defense of his administration which has lurched from scandal to scandal and has been facing mounting criticism about its drive for its second-stage financial reforms recently, the president said that his administration brooks no systematic or structural corruption and that members of his ruling team should be measured by the highest possible moral standards.
The lawyer-turned-president warned that anyone involved in any irregularities would be persecuted to the full extent of law regardless of their political background and rank in the government.

Noting that he was swept to power in 2000 on his promises to implement reform, the president said that his administration was born out of the people's desire for reform and that it would live up to the people's expectations by continuing reform in six fields as outlined by his administration.

Noting that the country has developed many systematic imbalances during its all-out pursuit of economic growth over the last five decades, the president said his administration will address these problems while keeping the economy growing.
Chen delivered the address at a ceremony held at the Presidential Office in celebration of the Republic of China National Day.
Following is the full text of the president's address:
Vice President Lu, government Officials from Taiwan, distinguished guests, colleagues, fellow citizens, ladies and gentlemen: Congratulations and greetings to each and every one of you!

Today, on the 94th National Day of the Republic of China (Taiwan), we gather here to celebrate the birthday of our nation, our hearts filled with both solemnity and jubilation as we wholeheartedly wish our beloved Taiwan a splendid future.

As we look back on the history of Taiwan's developments over the past half century, we see that World War II had devastated people's livelihoods and left the country's infrastructure in ruins, waiting to be rebuilt. For the survival of the nation and the stability of society, the government at that time set economic development as its highest priority.

Through the collective efforts of its people, Taiwan has created great economic miracles that have won the acclaim of the world community. Nevertheless, what lies beneath this brilliant economic performance are many institutional and structural imbalances.

Various social movement groups, including those formed by farmers, laborers, women, indigenous peoples, and environmentalists, have made repeated appeals for reform, demanding that the government uphold fairness and social justice as it pursues economic growth.

These appeals for reforms not only ignited the Taiwan people's strong desire to strive for the betterment of our society, they constituted one of the major causes that eventually led to the first transfer of power between political parties in Taiwan in 2000.

We may say that the new government formed in 2000 was born to carry out reforms and that it exists to realize fairness and social justice. These missions represent the most solemn mandate from the 23 million people of Taiwan, and they embody the true meaning of the historic transfer of power between political parties.

However, shortly after we completed the first-ever transfer of power between political parties in Taiwan's history, the bursting of the Internet bubble, the 9-11 terrorist attacks, the ensuing anti-terrorism struggles, and the U.S.-led war in Iraq all precipitated serious recession in the world economy.

Owing to these factors, Taiwan also saw its first negative economic growth since the end of World War II. Meanwhile, with its unemployment rate on the rise and the health of its financial system rapidly declining, Taiwan could have suffered domestic financial crises at any time.

In this precarious environment, the government set "economic revitalization" and "comprehensive reform" as its paramount tasks. With these objectives in mind, the government pushed for deregulation of various economic and trade sectors, actively pursued revitalization of the economy, and created more job opportunities, so as to improve the well-being of the vast unemployed population.

The tasks to accomplish "economic revitalization" and "comprehensive reform" are meant to create win-win situations for employees, employers and the government. They are not, as alleged by some, government policies that lean toward the business community or big corporations. We pursue economic prosperity in order to enhance the people's quality of life. Wealthy people living in a poor country cannot retain their fortune for long, whereas a wealthy society that turns its back on the continual existence of poor people is by no means a fair and just society.

With the gradual revitalization of the economy and the continuous lowering of the unemployment rate, the government shall adjust its priorities step by step. In the next two-and-a-half years, my administration will further execute reforms in six priority areas.

The Six Reform Priorities are: financial reform, tax reform, reform to change the preferential interest rates of 18 percent, media reform, investigation into properties inappropriately seized by political parties, and constitutional reform. These reforms aim to balance " economic prosperity" with "social justice" in Taiwan's comprehensive development.

Since the government set the so-called "2-5-8 financial agenda" in 2002 to reduce the average non-performing loan ratio (NPLR) to less than five percent and raise the average capital adequacy ratio to eight percent within two years, the NPLR for domestic banks, which once reached a record high of 8.09 percent, had been lowered to 2.83 percent by August 31, 2005.

Moreover, the average capital adequacy ratio has been raised to more than 10 percent. Non-performing loans, with a total amount of NT$1.4694 trillion, have been dissolved. This accomplishment, which has helped our nation avert possible financial crises, is lauded by the country's business community as the most successful financial reform over the past 20 years.

The first-phase financial reform has been completed; the second-phase financial reform has started. We hope that through the merger and integration of public and private financial institutions, we can accelerate the inflow of foreign capital investments to our country and attract foreign managerial teams to enhance the competitiveness of Taiwan's financial industry in the global community.

Although the second-phase financial reform has encountered certain challenges and there is still room for improvement in executing the policy, the direction of the financial reform is entirely correct. The healthy development of our country's financial service sector not only indicates that Taiwan's industrial structure has been moving toward the level of that of advanced countries, it also offers our people more competitive capital management and financial services.

The second-phase financial reform is one of the government's most imperative policies at the moment. I would like to ask all related government agencies to rise above every challenge and achieve our financial reform goals in due course so that our financial industry can be well-equipped to respond to future challenges brought by globalization.

Over the years, preferential measures to encourage investment and promote upgrading of industries have not been routinely re-examined, which, coupled with tax exemptions for certain groups of people, has turned our country's tax system into an unfair one and seriously affected our people's confidence in the preservation of social justice.

To address this problem, the Executive Yuan has sent the revised version of the Income Tax Law and regulations regarding the Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) system to the legislature for review. The move manifests the government's effort and determination to improve our unfair taxation system. Through re-examining and adjusting related tax items and rates, we aim to effectively improve the government's capacity to carry out major national development projects and offer more resources for the disadvantaged groups.

The reform of our taxation system will certainly encounter all sorts of difficulties and challenges, but our people's expectation of the realization of fairness and justice in our society provides the most forceful impetus propelling us forward. The government will try to engage in extensive communication with our people and do its utmost to implement comprehensive tax reform step by step.

On July 1, 2005, the "new pension system, " which has been postponed for 14 years, was eventually implemented. More than 90 percent of the nation's workers, numbering more than 7 million, are now eligible to obtain pensions under the new system. The establishment of the system is the most significant breakthrough in Taiwan's history of building up a social safety net.

However, even with this new system in place, there are still many unreasonable practices in Taiwan's overall pension programs. After the implementation of the "new pension system, " ordinary workers can enjoy 54 percent of pension replacement rate after 30 years of work. However, some retired military personnel, civil servants and teachers who enjoy the 18 percent interest rates can have 100, 120 or even 130 percent pension replacement rate of pre-retirement income. This situation exposes the unreasonable and unfair practices in our old pension system.

So far, related government agencies have studied possible measures to limit the amount of savings to which the 18 percent interest rates can be applied; other potential approaches to reduce the pension replacement rate of pre-retirement income for retired military personnel, civil servants and teachers to no more than 90 percent have also been considered.

These efforts are taken to address the unreasonable situation where some retired military personnel, civil servants and teachers receive pensions that are higher than their pre-retirement income, and to narrow the gap between pensions received by these individuals and workers from other walks of life.

According to a survey conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, more than 60 percent of the public believes that it is unreasonable that some certain individuals should enjoy 100 percent pension replacement rate of pre-retirement income. The survey also revealed that nearly 50 percent of the public believes it is acceptable that pension replacement rates for these retired military personnel, civil servants and teachers be lowered to 90 or 80 percent.

Proposals to improve our pension system will be sent to the Examination Yuan for review, and I would like to urge members of the Examination Yuan to make decisions on these proposals as soon as possible to meet the public's expectations.

It has been five years since the completion of the first-ever transfer of power between political parties; however, many problems inherited from past authoritarian regime -- under which a single party's control deeply entrenched the government's operations -- have yet to be completely resolved.

These problems include but not limit to: the handling of inappropriately acquired assets by political parties and the all-out elimination of the influence of political party, government and the military in the media. Although the executive branch has already sent relevant bill proposals to the Legislative Yuan for review, however, to date, these proposed bills have never been put to discussions or deliberation.

In the process of its recent internal power re-shuffling -- notwithstanding the expectations from our society and the appeals made by public discourse, calling for reformed conducts and returning of the seized properties to the people -- the political party responsible for inappropriately seizing the nation's assets not only has refused to comply with the public's expectations, but has instead rushed to sell off these properties at a low price.

Their actions provide a glaring confirmation of their lack of sincerity in acknowledging and making amends for their past mistakes. The handling of assets inappropriately acquired by political parties has set the stage for the competition between those who advocate for reforms and those who oppose them.

I want to hereby solemnly proclaim our commitment to employ all possible means to return to the people of Taiwan and our country properties seized inappropriately by political parties, because these properties are not single party's assets and the transfer of their ownership does not automatically legalize the possession of these properties.

Also, pursuant to the amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Law, all political parties, government, and the military must withdraw their remaining clout in the media by December 26th of this year. However, the deliberation of bills concerning the release of government-owned shares in the media proprietorship have not been completed in the Legislative Yuan, thereby barring the continuation of follow-up actions.

Relevant government agencies must continue to strive for the legislation of these proposed bills expeditiously; more importantly, greater efforts must also be devoted to completely eliminate the influence of government from the media by appropriate means and within the time limit mandated by the revised Broadcasting and Television Law, in order to push forward a constructive development of Taiwan's media industry and democracy.

Over the past five years, my administration has never wavered in our commitment to implement reforms. To this end, we have neither hesitance nor reservation in our resolve. However, the political reality confronting a minority government -- which does not represent the majority in the Legislative Yuan -- continues to hamper the implementation of various reform measures, undercutting the efficacy of these reforms.

The current state of affairs with regard to reforms has exposed the deficiencies in our constitutional system -- deficiencies that constitute the greatest resistance and impediment to our reform projects. Our current constitutional system is one that does not provide the mechanism to effectively deal with political stalemate, and one that has rendered our nation and our government idling in a state of incessant quibbling. In order to strengthen good governance and upgrade our nation's overall competitiveness, we must continue to make headway in comprehensive constitutional reforms.

With the first phase of the constitutional re-engineering project completed on June 7th, the right to hold referendum has been incorporated in the statues governing the procedures for constitutional amendments. Henceforth, all future constitutional re-engineering projects will be carried out by adopting a "bottom-up and outside-in" approach; that is, relevant proposals will be first initiated by the social groups before political parties are involved.

The social groups may even take the lead in the constitutional reform processes with the government playing a mere supporting role and helping to map out the procedures and channels for popular participation, as well as to encourage extensive discussions on constitutional reforms among people from all walks of life. Finally, through deliberative democracy, we hope to step-by-step assemble a concrete constitutional reform plan, which will be proposed and put to vote in the Legislative Yuan, and its final ratification approved by the people of Taiwan through referendum.

The era of constitutional reforms dictated by one-person or one-party, or with the participation and consultation of party elites only, has ended. Future constitutional re-engineering project must engage popular participation, for that its success necessarily hinges on the support and acceptance of the people.

Currently, our Constitution is neither timely, nor suitable, nor viable. In order to lay a solid foundation for political stability in Taiwan and for our nation's long-term stability and sustainability, there must be comprehensive constitutional reviews and revisions.

I would like to hereby call upon all our fellow citizens to pro-actively take part in the constitutional re-engineering process. What we strive to accomplish together, after all, is a Constitution that belongs to each and every one of us. Let us, therefore, galvanize our collective wisdom and strength to engender a timely, suitable and viable new Constitution for Taiwan.

Dear fellow citizens, the abovementioned Six Reform Priorities stand at the top of my administration's agenda; more importantly, these are the "Contracts with the people of Taiwan." Rest assured that everyone in the government will spare no effort to achieve these reform objectives, unopposed by any difficulty or obstacle.

The first step of reform rests upon the reform of the government itself. Since the completion of the transfer of power between political parties, our government has imposed upon ourselves the highest moral and ethical standards, based on which we have endeavored to ensure a political system free of corruption and an administration proactive and assiduous.

Despite criticisms we faced along the way, we will forge ahead courageously, while humbly and with an open-mind, reflecting and readjusting to pursue improvements. Furthermore, we pledge to impose zero tolerance for any systematic or structural corruption. In the event of any individual found to violate the laws of our nation -- provided that there is evidence substantiating such allegation -- he or she will be sanctioned by the law; and any corruptive misconduct will be subject to actions taken by our legal authorities, irrespective of the background, credentials or social status of the persons involved.

To this end, our resolve to eliminate corruption sees no bounds. As for any judicial personnel found to have violated the law or to be ill-suited for his or her position, tougher yet are the standards that will be applied to establish impartial review procedures to expedite the removal of these individuals from the judicial system, so as to restore the confidence and trust our people have in the quality of our judicial system and in our democratic rule of law.

Historical developments have set Taiwan on the course of becoming the safe haven as well as the homeland for the 23 million people of Taiwan. Furthermore, over the last half century, people of Taiwan -- in their struggle for freedom, democracy, equality and justice -- have been brought together by a shared destiny.

Each time we take an aerial view of the beautiful land of Taiwan, it always stirs the deepest emotions we have for this land we call home. On this land, Taiwan stands as an integrated and indivisible entity; on this land, people of Taiwan are united by our shared destiny intrinsically connected to our land; and for better or worse, our people have, and will continue to walk alongside one another through thick and thin.

For the future of Taiwan and for the well-being of our future generations, we must unite as one and consolidate the strength of our people to deepen and expand the scope of our reforms; and in continued prosperity and progress, we must, and we will, vigorously persist on the path to attain equality and justice.

In closing, let us wish the Republic of China (Taiwan) a happy birthday and sustained prosperity. And to all my fellow citizens, dear friends and honorable guests, may health and happiness be with you always. Thank you

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 10, or the eighth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1911: A revolt against the Manchu (Ching) dynasty erupts in Wuchang and is followed by revolutionary activities throughout China. The government of the Republic of China formally announced on Sept. 28 that Oct. 10 is henceforth to be observed as ROC National Day in commemoration of the Wuchang Uprising, which led to the establishment of the ROC on Jan. 1, 1912.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, who forced the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China on Oct. 6, formally assumes the presidency.
1919: The Chunghua Kemingtang (Chinese Revolutionary Party) is reorganized by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as the Chungkuo Kuomintang (KMT), also known as the Nationalist Party.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes the writing of "Plans for Industrial Development."
1925: The National Palace Museum is inaugurated in Peiping (now Beijing).
1928: Chiang Kai-shek assumes the chairmanship of the National Government in Nanking.
1934: The main forces of the Chinese communist troops flee northwest from their bases in Kiangsi, starting their so-called "Long March."
1942: The U.S. and U.K. governments announce their intention to relinquish extra-territoriality and related rights in China.
1943: Chiang Kai-shek is sworn in as chairman of the National Government.
1954: Ho Chi Minh returns to Hanoi as the French evacuate.
1958: The ROC air force shoots down five mainland MiG-17 fighters and damages two more off the mainland coast, losing one Saber jet in the battle.
1962: Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd., the first commercial television station in the Republic of China, goes into operation.
1970: Fiji, a British colony in the southern Pacific sine 1874, becomes an independent member of the Commonwealth.
1973: Spiro Agnew, 54, twice chosen by U.S. President Richard Nixon to be vice president, resigns before appearing at a federal district court in Baltimore to face charges of income tax evasion.
1974: A mass rally of 250,000 celebrate the 63rd anniversary of the Republic of China.
1975: A military parade of 35,000 members of the ROC armed forces and reserves highlight the observance of the 64th National Day of the Republic of China, with more than 13,000 overseas Chinese and foreign dignitaries joining in the celebration.
1976: A quarter of a million people assemble in the Presidential Square for National Day ceremonies with more than 15,000 overseas Chinese from over 50 countries and areas taking part in events marking the 65th anniversary of the Republic of China.
1978: More than 12,000 members of the Chinese armed forces brave driving rains to stage the largest military parade in many years during National Day celebrations.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo accepts the people's gift of 18 F-5E jet fighters with a pledge to recover the mainland at a huge rally attended by 250,000 people to mark the Double Ten National Day.
1980: A strong earthquake rocks Algeria, killing more than 12,500 people.
1986: An estimated 250 thousand people gather before the Presidential Building to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the Republic of China. President Chiang Ching-kuo addresses the nation in person, promising that the ROC will accomplish his ultimate objective of reunifying China.
1993: An overloaded ferry capsizes off the coast of Pusan, in southern South Korea, killing 292.
1997: The International Campaign to Ban Landmines and American Campaign coordinator Jodie Williams win the Nobel Peace Prize.
1999: On behalf of the government and people of the Republic of China, Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese community leaders from around the world for their patriotic deeds and generous donations after the Sept. 21 earthquake.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian urges his fellow citizens to strive fearlessly forward on the path of freedom, democracy and human rights.
2001: A Republic of China Double Ten National Day parade is held at Yokohama's Chinatown, with more than 300 pro-Republic of China overseas Chinese residents and friendly Japanese people participating.
2001: Steven Newman, the Guinness world record holder for the most number of countries traversed on foot completes his 27th conquest when he arrives at the southern-most tip of Taiwan.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says in his National Day message that the ROC government has not only strongly condemned the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, but has also supported "all necessary United States actions to fight international terrorism."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man never upholds a man because of what he says, nor does he discard what a man says because of the speaker's character."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 4,500 ROC EXPATS RETURN FOR NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS

TEXT.P: Nearly 4,500 overseas Taiwanese have returned to Taiwan for this year's festivities marking the Double Ten National Day of the Republic of China, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) reported Monday.

OCAC officials said that a total of 4,434 Taiwan expatriates and their dependents living abroad had registered their arrival and planned participation in the celebrations marking the 94th ROC National Day as of Sunday.

The OCAS hosted a concert Sunday exclusively to entertain the Taiwan expatriates from around the world. These guests were also invited to attend all-day national day festivities scheduled to be held at the Presidential Office plaza and related locations on the national day on Monday, OCAS officials said.
During their official three-day, two-night national day stay, the Taiwan expatriates are also expected to travel to other tourists attractions around the island, the officials said.
The number of Taiwan expatriate arrivals for this year's national day celebrations marked a year-on-year increase of 16.71 percent, they added.

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: S. Asia quake toll nears 20,000 as casualities rise
About 20,000 people in Pakistan and India had been confirmed dead in Saturday's huge earthquake, officials said Sunday as they warned that the death toll could be much higher.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: For GOP, Election Anxiety Mounts; Candidates Need Convincing for '06.
Republican politicians in multiple states have recently decided not to run for Senate next year, stirring anxiety among Washington operatives about the effectiveness of the party's recruiting efforts and whether this signals a broader decline in GOP congressional prospects, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REITERATES PROMISE TO PRESS AHEAD WITH REFORMS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Monday to press ahead with further reforms during his last two years in office, saying these reforms will help bring "prosperity" and "justice" to Taiwan.

Addressing the ceremony marking the 94th founding anniversary of the Republic of China held at the Presidential Office, Chen spoke of his great determination to carry out reform of the island's financial, tax, media and constitutional systems as well as in matters related to a controversial interest rate system that has given preferential treatment to certain groups of retirees and to recovering assets inappropriately acquired by political parties.

Although Taiwan experienced its first-ever transfer of political power between political parties in 2000, Chen said that the bursting of the dot-com bubble, the 9-11 terrorist attacks on America, and the subsequent global war on terrorism and the U.S.-led war in Iraq caused a setback for the world economy, resulting in Taiwan experiencing negative economic growth for the first time since the end of World War II.

Pointing out that in this precarious environment, his administration set "economic revitalization" and "comprehensive reform" as its top priorities, the president said the Cabinet then made efforts to deregulate economic and trade rules in order to stimulate economic recovery and create more jobs as well as a "win-win situation" for employees, employers and the government.

Chen said the tasks to accomplish economic revitalization and comprehensive reform are aimed at upgrading the standard of living of all Taiwanese, and are "not, as alleged by some, government policies that lean toward the business community or big corporations."

"Wealthy people living in a poor country cannot retain their fortune for long, whereas a wealthy society that turns its back on the existence of the poor also goes against the principle of social justice and fairness, " he said.
Chen also said that with the gradual revitalization of the economy and the continuing lowering of the unemployment rate, the government will adjust its priorities step by step.

Talking about financial reform, the president said that after completing the first stage of reform, the government has begun the second-stage of reform by consolidating public and private financial institutions in order to accelerate the flow of foreign investment and financial management into the island which will upgrade the international competitiveness of Taiwan's financial sector.

Although the second-stage financial reform has encountered some difficulties and there is still room for the government to improve its policies in carrying out the reform, the president said that he has requested that the authorities concerned do whatever they can to achieve the goal of reform in order to respond to the challenges of globalization that the financial sector will encounter in the future.

Concerning tax system reform, the president said that the Executive Yuan has put forward the " revised version of the Income Tax Law and regulations regarding the alternative Minimum Tax system" to the Legislative Yuan for review.

"The reform of our taxation system will certainly encounter all sorts of difficulties and challenges, but the public's expectation of the realization of justice and fairness in our society provides the most forceful impetus propelling us forward," the president said.

Criticizing the so-called preferential interest rates of 18 percent given to some retired teachers, civil servants and military personnel, the president noted that ordinary workers only enjoy a pension replacement rate of pre-retirement income of only 54 percent after 30 years of work, while some civil servants enjoy a rate of over 100 percent, which he said is "unreasonable and unfair."

According to Chen, relevant governmental agencies have studied possible measures to limit the amount of savings to which the 18 percent interest rates can be applied, with other potential approaches to reduce the pension replacement rate of pre-retirement income for retired military personnel, civil servants and teachers to no more than 90 percent also being considered.

"Proposals to improve our pension system will be sent to the Examination Yuan for review, and I would like to urge members of the Examination Yuan to make decisions on these proposals as soon as possible to meet the public's expectations," he added.
The president also said that many of the problems "inherited from the past authoritarian regime" have yet to be resolved.

These problems include the handling of inappropriately acquired assets by political parties and the elimination of influence of political parties, the military and government in the media, Chen said. He promised that the government will use "all possible means" to return to the people and the nation all properties seized inappropriately by political parties.

Touching on the legislature's delay in deliberating on bills concerning the release of government-owned shares in media organizations, the president called for related government agencies to continue to work on the legislation of these bills and on eliminating completely the influence of the government in the media by appropriate means and within the time limit mandated by the revised Broadcasting and Television Law.

Admitting that the minority government has been continually hampered in trying to implement various reforms in the nation since he took office in 2000, the president said that this proves that the Constitution's deficiencies "constitute the greatest resistance and impediment to our reform projects."

"Our current constitutional system is one that does not provide the mechanism to effectively deal with political stalemate, and one that has rendered our nation and our government idling in a state of incessant quibbling, " he also said, adding that "in order to strengthen good governance and upgrade our nation's overall competitiveness, we must continue to make headway in comprehensive constitutional reforms."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATS IN D.C. CELEBRATE DOUBLE TEN DAY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Nearly 400 Taiwanese expatriates in the United States attended a ceremony Sunday morning in front of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association in Washington, D.C. to celebrate the Republic of China's Oct. 10 National Day.

An ROC national flag was raised before ROC Representative to the U.S. David Lee giving a speech to the audience. He reiterated the ROC government's unyielding efforts in constructing a democratic regime in Taiwan, saying that the 23 million people of Taiwan will always stand for freedom and democracy and spare no efforts to try to promote the universal principles to the 1.3 billion people of mainland China.

On Sunday afternoon, the Formosa Aboriginal Song and Dance Troupe of Taiwan gave a dance and music performance at the Freer Gallery of Art in Washington D.C. as part of the Double Ten Day celebrations.

Meanwhile, a photo exhibition dedicated to the celebration of the ROC National Day opened at the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission-run cultural center in the U.S. capital Saturday, with some 200 works of overseas Taiwanese living in the D.C. area on display. The exhibition will run for two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REITERATES NEED FOR CONSTITUTIONAL RE-ENGINEERING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Monday that it is imperative to accelerate constitutional re-engineering, saying that only well-designed constitutional paradigms will form the bedrock of an efficient and long-lasting state system.

In his National Day address, Chen stressed that in order to lay a solid foundation for political stability in Taiwan and for the nation's long-term stability and sustainability, there must be a comprehensive review and revision of the Constitution.

Currently, Taiwan's Constitution is neither timely, nor suitable, nor viable, he said, adding that the era of constitutional reforms dictated by one person or one party, or with only the participation and consultation of party elites, has ended.

Chen said the current state of affairs in Taiwan with regard to the reforms has exposed the deficiencies in the nation's constitutional system, claiming that these deficiencies represent the greatest impediment to his administration's reform projects.

He said the current constitutional system does not provide the mechanism to effectively deal with political stalemate, adding that the system has rendered the nation and government "idling in a state of incessant quibbling."

Chen maintained that as a responsible government, he and his Democratic Progressive Party administration have deeply perceived the imperative for building a new political order in a swiftly changing society like Taiwan's.

Constitutional re-engineering is a pressing issue and a "sacred mission" of the administration that must be carried out in order to complete Taiwan's transition from an authoritarian to a stable democratic system, he said.
The constitutional re-engineering project must include popular participation as the project's success depends on the support and acceptance of the people, he added.

With the first phase of the constitutional re-engineering project completed June 7, the right to referendum has been incorporated into the statutes governing the procedures for constitutional amendments, Chen said, adding that henceforth, all future constitutional re-engineering will be carried out by adopting a "bottom-up and outside-in" approach. That is, he said, relevant proposals will first be initiated by social groups before political parties get involved in the process.

The social groups may even take the lead in the constitutional reform process, with the government playing a mere supporting role and helping to map out the procedures and channels for popular participation, and to encourage extensive discussions on constitutional reforms among people from all walks of life.

Finally, he said, "through deliberative democracy, we hope to step-by-step assemble a concrete constitutional reform plan, which will be proposed and put to a vote in the Legislative Yuan, with its final ratification approved by the people of Taiwan through referendum."

"I'd like to hereby call upon all our fellow citizens to proactively take part in the constitutional re-engineering process. What we strive to accomplish together, after all, is a Constitution that belongs to each and every one of us. Let us, therefore, galvanize our collective wisdom and strength to engender a timely, suitable and viable new Constitution for Taiwan, " the president proclaimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, TSU LEGISLATIVE CAUCUSES POSITIVE ABOUT PRESIDENT'S REFORMS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucuses of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , were positive Monday about the six reforms espoused by President Chen Shui-bian in his Double Ten National Day message.

President Chen stressed in the message his administration's resolve to continue with reforms. He said the six reform priorities are financial reform, tax reform, reform to change the preferential interest rate of 18 percent for certain pensioners, media reform, investigation into properties inappropriately seized by political parties, and constitutional reform.

William C.T. Lai, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said that every aspect of Chen's message has "met the needs of the nation" and demonstrated that the DPP is the best defender of the nation's security and the top choice for carrying out reform.

On President Chen's affirmation that he will have "zero tolerance" for any corruption, Lai said that this shows the president's concern for the matter and that he will address the flurry of recent scandals, including the high-profile Kaohsiung mass rapid transit construction scandal.
Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union said Monday that the six reforms outlined by the President Chen "are the right direction and conform with social justice."
However, Ho Min-hao, the TSU caucus whip in the legislature, also said that reforms can only be carried out if related bills have been passed by the legislature.

Given the fact that the legislature is still controlled by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, Ho said that he is pessimistic about pushing through the reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Death toll from earthquake in Pakistan ranged between 30,000 and 40,000.
The death toll from the 7.6-magnitude earthquake that hit the Pakistan-India border area in Kashmir Saturday is estimated between 30,000 and 40,000. Pakistani President Pervez Musharaaf called for international help. Rescuers try to reach devastated area.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S NATIONAL DAY REMARKS 'POLITICAL SLOGANS': KMT, PFP

TEXT.P: The "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) shrugged off President Chen Shui-bian's comments during the ROC's national day as "political slogans" that were unlikely to resonate with the public.

Celebrating the Republic of China's 94th national day, Chen said from the Presidential Office that over the remaining two years of his term, he will see that the government does whatever necessary to reform the financial sector, make the taxation system fairer, better govern operations of media, correct the unfair preferential interest rate of 18 percent given to certain minority retirees and recover assets that have been taken inappropriately by political parties.
However, the "pan-blue alliance" considered the president's words to be of no value.
Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee, said that even though Chen's remarks were forceful, they were still just " political slogans."

"The president must set an example for the public by taking concrete actions rather than chanting slogans; the reforms must be applied, not just talked about, " Tseng said. The people will not trust him, Tseng said, if the president continues "giving lip service instead of actually doing something."
Meanwhile, Daniel Hwang, convener of the PFP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) "can only govern the nation by sloganeering."

Although the people have given the president and his party five years to make reforms a reality, they have failed to run the nation efficiently, the legislator said, adding that the public has lost confidence in the government. "People are probably not even paying attention to the president's recitation of his intention to make reforms," he said.

During the last five years, the gap between the rich and the poor has grown and the nation is also suffering a high rate of unemployment, he further said, adding that the ruling party can only chant slogans ahead of various elections to excite voters rather than seriously contemplate measures on how to solve the problems that the people are concerned with.

What the public currently wants most is a more equal distribution of wealth and an incorruptible government, he continued, adding that the government's slogans have disappointed the people and that the president has lost his honesty and the people's trust. "It is the president's personality and honesty that need to undergo a reform, " Hwang noted.
He also said that Chen's remarks are an attempt to steer the DPP away from the current "turbid situation" related to its campaigns for the year-end county mayor and magistrate elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADERS FROM VARIOUS COUNTRIES HELP ROC CELEBRATE NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: Political leaders from home and abroad gathered at the Presidential Office Plaza Monday to watch the 94th Republic of China National Day celebrations.
The Double Ten National Day celebrations were presided over by Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, with President Chen Shui-bian delivering a keynote National Day address.

Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou was also present at the ceremony, marking the first time that an opposition leader has taken part in a National Day ceremony at the Presidential Office since the completion of the first-ever transfer of power between political parties in Taiwan five years ago.

Other heads of states and political leaders from abroad, including the presidents of the Gambia and Honduras, were also on hand to offer their congratulations to the Republic of China on its birthday.

In his address, Wang said that the nation's forefathers came from the Chinese mainland to Taiwan 500 years ago by risking their lives to cross the Taiwan Strait. After settling on Taiwan, they concertedly cultivated the lands without ethnic tensions and made Taiwan a diverse society where everybody enjoyed freedom and equality.
Wang called for the country to emulate their forefathers and jointly strive for Taiwan's future and its international competitiveness while discarding ethnic differences and political quibbling.

On the development of cross-strait relations, Wang said that since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are originally "one family," sharing a common history, culture, traditions and languages, the two sides should bury the hatchet and avoid the recurrence of strife between rival political entities that has been occurred over the past decades.

As private cross-strait exchanges have been unavoidable in recent years, but the two sides officially remain in a position of political stalemate, Wang said that only when rulers from the two sides forsake their arm races and political intimidation can they cooperate and create a win win situation for both.
Following the National Day ceremony a festive gala was held featuring a variety of performances by students and private groups from around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WARNS OF DANGERS OF LACK OF SELF-DEFENSE RESOLVE

TEXT.P: A lack of self-defense determination is the biggest threat to Taiwan's security, and the inactivity of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is a result of caving in to pressure from another political party, President Chen Shui-bian said Monday.
Chen made the remarks while speaking at a ceremony at the Presidential Office marking the Double Ten National Day of the Republic of China.

Despite the huge challenges that lie ahead, Chen vowed again to pursue "conciliation, cooperation and ever-lasting peace" in terms of cross-Taiwan Strait ties, and said that "beefing up Taiwan's defense capability and protecting peace in the strait" is something the government must do to echo the fervent calls from the international community for the reopening of peace talks between Taiwan and China.

The president lamented that the KMT "has been snatched away by another party" from granting approval to a major arms procurement bill in the Legislative Yuan -- an apparent reference to the People First Party (PFP) , which together with the KMT and New Party forms the "pan blue alliance."

Pointing out that the major weaponry purchase plan dates back to the days when the KMT was in power, Chen called on the KMT to reverse its stance of opposition to the plan and not turn a blind eye to public opinion.

The administration has made adjustments to the major arms deal which the opposition camp had repeatedly claimed was too expensive, but the KMT has failed to respond positively by cooperating on the issue in the legislature, Chen said, attributing this to the PFP's foot dragging.

At a time when the United States and Japan have been on increased alert over China's rapid military modernization and expansion which has widely been viewed as a significant risk to peace and security in the Asia-Pacific, Taiwan has displayed no confidence or resolve in safeguarding itself, Chen said, calling this "extremely regrettable and a grave concern."

The "pan blue alliance" and the "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, have been engaged in fierce political wrangling virtually since the time that President Chen was first elected in 2000.

The opposition "pan blue alliance" has blocked the major arms purchase bill at the legislature 31 times since the middle of last year. The bill would allow the government to use a special budget to buy eight diesel-electric submarines and 12 P-3C Orion anti-submarine aircraft for NT$340 billion (US$11 billion) -- down significantly from the original NT$680 billion projected by the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

The MND has agreed to finance the purchase of the third item in the arms procurement package -- six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries -- with the ministry's regular annual budget, instead of through a special budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE GROUPS SAY PFP 'PEACE BILL' INCONSISTENT WITH CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Society and the 21th Century Constitutional Reform Association lambasted a bill Monday proposed by the opposition People First Party (PFP) that purports to promote peace with China, claiming it is inconsistent with the ROC Constitution.

Huang Hsiou-tuan, president of the Taiwan Society and a professor at Soochow University, said this "peace-promoting" bill, which envisions the formation of a special commission to negotiate peace with China with its members mirroring the ratios of various political parties in the legislature and its budget examined by the legislature, would be counter to the constitutional principle concerning the division of the executive and legislative branches.

Under the bill, the commission would be in charge of negotiations with China for peace, with the power to conclusion treaties. This would encroach on the constitutional rights of the president and the Executive Yuan, Huang said.
Political parties should propose bills for the general good of the people rather than for their partisan interests, and should always keep in mind constitutional principles, Huang went on.

Noting that political power transfers are common in democracies, Huang warned opposition parties that by "digging a hole" by enacting this legislation, "they may find themselves one day falling to this very hole should they win the next presidential election and form the next administration."

Hung Yu-hung, a professor at National Yangming University and the convener of the 21th Century Constitutional Reform Association, said the political impasse between the legislature and the executive branches results from the country's ill-conceived governmental system, with both the opposition, which controls the legislature, and the ruling party, which controls the presidency, believing they have the sole mandate to form policy.

The contradiction in provisions in the Constitution have led to this ridiculous legislation, Hung said, citing the opposition-sponsored Organic Statute of the 319 Truth Investigation Commission as another example of an ill-conceived bill.
To avoid confusion, Hung said, his association advocates rewriting the Constitution to redefine the roles of the executive and legislative branches.

He echoed Huang in warning the PFP and its political ally, the Kuomintang (KMT) , against ramming the bill through the legislature because this would only intensify the confrontations between the opposition and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
They made the comments one day before the KMT and the PFP, which control a slim majority in the legislature, are set to put the bill to a vote in the legislature in defiance of the DPP's objections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG CITY CHIEF HEADS FOR MAYORS' SUMMIT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu headed for Chongqing, Sichuan province in western China Monday for the 2005 Asia-Pacific Mayors Summit, which will be held Oct. 11-14.
Hu said he would make an overnight stopover in Hong Kong before flying on to Chongqing Tuesday.

The former foreign minister said he will deliver a speech at the summit on Wednesday, noting that it is a great honor to have the opportunity to introduce the city he comes from at the summit, which will bring together the chiefs of more than 100 cities in the Asia-Pacific area.

On the sidelines of the summit, the mayor said he would approach Chinese officials in Sichuan province to try to persuade them that Taichung would be the ideal place to house the pair of pandas China has promised to give Taiwan.
After the summit, Hu said he would fly to Shanghai on Oct. 14 for a trade promotion trip which will feature a briefing on Oct. 15, during which he will showcase Taichung's well-known foods.
Hu said he will be make some of Taichung's famous "sun cakes" and share them with the people present at the news briefing.

On his way back home via Hong Kong, Hu said he would ask authorities in Hong Kong to back the resumption of charter flights between Hong Kong and Chinchuankang Airport in Taichung, which stopped only a month after they were opened in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN MA HAS NO IMMEDIATE PLAN TO VISIT CHINA: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said he is not currently planning to visit China, a spokesman of the Taipei City Government said Monday.

Lo Chih-cheng, director of the Department of Information of the Taipei City Government, quoted Ma as saying that his long-standing stance has been that he "will not rule out the possibility" of visiting China sometime in the future, and that the premise would have to be a necessity and the timing would have to be appropriate.

Hong Kong's Takungpao newspaper said in a report from Changsha, in China's Hunan province Monday that Liu Zhaoli, one of Ma's cousins, cited Ma's mother while she was visiting China recently as saying that Ma would be visiting China after stepping down as Taipei mayor in 2006.

Ma, who concurrently serves as the chairman of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), said that he isn't planning to visit China now, and that Liu's remarks are probably wishful thinking.

The former chairman of the KMT, Lien Chan, made a high-profile visit to China in late April during which he met with Chinese President Hu Jintao, marking the first time the leaders of the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) had met in more than five decades after the KMT was defeated by the CPC in a civil war. Hu doubles as the CPC's general secretary.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMAN FINDS THE MEANINGS OF HER LIFE IN CAMBODIA
DOC.DATELINE: Poipet, Cambodia, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Hsu Yu-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Many people donate to the poor or the needy from the comfort of their homes, but few like Yang Wei-ling, a flight attendant-turned-philanthropist, have chosen to live with those in need to better their lives.

An attractive China Airlines' (CAL) flight attendant, who doubled as a volunteer with Taipei's 119 Emergency Hotline, Yang became aware of what she wanted at the age of 22 and quit her well-paid CAL job in 1989 and set up the Field Relief Agency (FRA) , non-profit NGO group devoted to humanitarian relief work overseas.
Since 1999, Yang has divided her time between traveling around Cambodia helping the poor and the needy there and raising money and collecting donated books in Taiwan.
Staying with orphans, the handicapped and the homeless in Cambodia over the past 10 years or so, Yang is now an expert on Cambodia and knows the country better than most Cambodians themselves.

In her latest book about her experiences in Cambodia, Yang said that the really strong people are not political leaders who turn countries into slaughterhouses but those who love and serve the poor and the needy.

Yang established an orphanage in Poipet, a poverty-stricken border town in northwestern Cambodia, in 1999, followed by a vocational training center in the same town in 2001, in an effort to provide homes for the homeless kids and help housewives without incomes learn some skills which can help earn them a living in a country that was bathed in bloodshed several decades ago.
In September, five Taiwan charity organizations joined the FRA and offered humanitarian relief to the people of Poipet by sending representatives there.

The "Love of Taiwan" delegation, comprised of members of the FRA, the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC) , Compassion International, the Eden Social Welfare Foundation and the Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation, arrived in Poipet on Sept. 25 to deliver humanitarian relief to the locals.
In two days, delegation members had offered free medical services to more than 700 people in Poipet.

The delegation had brought with it some 600 kilograms of medication and medical aid materials, including wheelchairs, crutches, walking aids and white sticks for the blind, as many people in Poipet are victims of landmines that were planted secretly there when Poipet was a war zone.

Due to poverty and poor sanitation, many youths aged around 15 in Poipet weigh only 20kg to 30 kg, while many men, due to long-term coolie labor, suffer problems with their joints and most women have gynecological problems, according to TRMPC medical professionals.
In addition, a large number of Poipet residents suffer from vision problems, some of whom have suffered eye problems since their childhood, said an eye doctor with the TRMPC.

Sept. 26 was a "big day" for the Poipet locals, particularly the children and youths, because the town's first high school was inaugurated, thanks to Yang's devotion and compassion to the Cambodian people over the past decade.
The Cambodian-language high school, the first of its kind in northwestern Cambodian, is capable of allowing more than 1,000 youths to attend school free of charge.
Yang managed to raise US$120,000 to build the school, which offers junior and senior education for youths aged over 12.

Knowing that Cambodian teachers tend to give closer academic attention to their students in paid after-school classes in order to make extra money, Yang decided to pay the teachers at the high school salaries twice or three times more than ordinary levels, hoping that they will focus their teaching on the new school.

Yang offered her gratitude to the Taiwan International Lions Club 300-A2 for a donation of US$80,000 to fund the hardware development in the new school and to Compassion International for donating 18 standard blackboards ready to be installed in the school's 18 classrooms.
The FRA will finance 80 percent of the cost of maintaining the school, including teachers' salaries, while Cambodia's education authorities will finance the remaining 20 percent, according to Yang.
Meanwhile, the FRA has also launched a campaign to have 500 bicycles donated to help children and youths in Poipet to go to school. "Each bike means a boy or a girl can go to school, " she added.

Believing that education is the best way to help people surmount poverty, Yang has continued to build schools in Cambodia and she even coined the phrase, "Education changes a child's fate, " the motto of the new school.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Pakistan Fears 18,000 Died in Quake. More than 18,000 people were killed when a powerful earthquake struck northern Pakistan, a military spokesman said today, in a disaster that entombed hundreds of children in their schools, flattened a high-rise apartment building in the Pakistani capital and devastated an untold number of villages.

DOC.HEADLINE: 14 CREWMEMBERS OF SOUTH KOREAN FREIGHTER RESCUED AFTER COLLISION

TEXT.P: All 14 crewmembers were rescued from a South Korean freighter that overturned Monday after colliding with a Hong Kong freighter early Monday.

Taichung Harbor Bureau officials said that South Korean freighter, "Samho Brother," a 2,761-ton freighter, collided with "TS Hong Kong," a 10,925-ton freighter registered in Liberia, in waters off Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan.
Coast guardsmen rescued all 14 crewmembers from the South Korean freighter, while the "TS Hong Kong" was towed to Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan.
The "Samho Brother" was carrying 85 tons of fuel oil, 16 tons of diesel and 3,000 tons of methyl benzene.
Sweden-based P&I Insurance, which covers oil pollution for the South Korean freighter, is commissioning a Taiwan company to take care of the compensation matters.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 HAKKA ARTS FESTIVAL TO STRAT IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The 2005 "a-ha" Hakka Arts Festival will be held around the country in November, Lee Yung-te, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs, said Monday.
The two-month event will be dedicated to introducing to the public Hakka artistic features by inviting artists to put on a large variety of performances of music, theater, dance and folk arts.
A total of 25 performances will be held in various cities and counties during the period.

As part of the event, the council will invite Lin Chao-liang, a world-famous Hakka violinist, to collaborate with Evergreen Symphony Orchestra to perform musical pieces with a Hakka flavor at the National Concert Hall in Taipei Dec. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT IS ACTING AGAINST PUBLIC OPINION: PFP SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the opposition People First Party (PFP) on Monday branded President Chen Shui-bian as a head of state who is self-contradictory and acts against public opinion.
Hsieh Kung-ping made the remarks in response to Chen's Republic of China Double Ten National Day speech, which was delivered in a celebration rally held in front of the Presidential Office.

In the speech, Chen blamed opposition parties -- referring to the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP -- for blocking bills concerning the government's multi-billion NT dollar U.S. arms procurement proposal from being put on the legislative agenda 31 times in a row.

Hsieh said that President Chen upholds the right of referendum on one the one hand, but on the other spares no effort to push for the arms procurement, which he claimed has already been defeated in a referendum held at the same time as the 2004 presidential election.

The referendum was considered "invalid" because the required 50 percent of voters participation was not met. However, of the roughly 45 percent who did vote, over 90 percent said "yes" to the following question: "The people of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, would you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

Hsieh claimed that the fact that the "pan-blue alliance's" clear stand against the "arm purchase of the rich" helped them win a majority of legislative seats in last year's election reflects the public's opposition to the proposal.

"President Chen's attempt to revive the procurement is not only a move contradicting his own political idea, but a defiant move against democracy, " Hsieh claimed, adding that the president is "acting against public opinion."

Mentioning Chen's promise in his National Day speech to continue efforts to promote a wide range of reforms, Hsieh said that the PFP believes this is nothing but a slogan. "President Chen is himself in need of reform," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COLLEGE STUDENTS LACK FOREIGN LANGUAGE ABILITY: POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly half of Taiwan's university seniors due to graduate within a year view their lack of foreign language ability as their major shortcoming, a recent Internet survey has found.

According to the results of the poll conducted by the headhunting Web site -- www.1111.com.tw -- 59 percent of the senior students at universities across Taiwan surveyed said that they have readied themselves for commencement, while 48 percent pointed to their lack of foreign language ability as their greatest vulnerability in the workplace.
Some 40 percent said that they felt they have not acquired enough professional knowledge, while 26 percent complained about having no special skills, the survey shows.

More then 70 percent said that they will try to increase their foreign language ability, while 38 percent and 27 percent, respectively, said that they will sharpen their professional knowledge and interpersonal relationship skills.

As to the question of what they will do after graduating, 41 percent said that they will try to find work, ahead of 31 percent who said that they will continue studying and 11 percent who said that they will take part in state and aptitude certificate examinations.
The poll was carried out from Sept. 10 to Sept. 27, recovering 1,260 valid questionnaires. It had a margin of error of 2.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NATIONAL DAY BANQUET HELD IN SINGAPORE
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Around 500 dignitaries took part in a national day cocktail reception sponsored by the Republic of China representative office in the city-state of Singapore to mark its Double Ten National Day Monday.
The dignitaries included several Singaporean parliamentarians, ranking military officials, members of the diplomatic corps as well as Taiwan expatriates.

Compared with last year's Double Ten reception when China vented its displeasure over then-Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's visit to Taiwan in July 2004 prior to his taking the post of prime minister, the number of dignitaries taking part in this year's banquet was bigger, especially Singaporean political and military figures, showing that Taiwan-Singapore relations have returned to normal in the wake of being pressured by China after Lee's visit, local analysts said.

ROC Representative to Singapore Hu Wei-jen said that since assuming his job in July, he has called on Singaporean government officials, business leaders and several civic groups, and has been impressed by the unique, sincere and friendly relations between the two countries.

He said that he took part in Singapore's 40th founding anniversary activities this August, and was very impressed by the nation's visionary plans for its future, respect for history, ethnic harmony and law-abiding consciousness of the people, adding that the two countries have a lot to learn from each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN EXPECTED IN LEGISLATURE OVER NCC, PEACE-PROMOTION BILLS

TEXT.P: The legislative causes of the various political parties are bracing themselves for a showdown and possible bloodshed in the legislature Tuesday over whether two controversial bills should be put to a vote.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), in the "pan-green camp" are opposed to the National Communications Commission (NCC) Organic Bill and an opposition People First Party (PFP)-proposed bill that aims to promote peace across the Taiwan Strait.
However, the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP, which enjoys a slight majority in the 225-seat legislature, hopes to pass the two bills as soon as possible.

The Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU), which holds 11 seats and calls itself the "pivotal minority, " has expressed its support for the two bills. Lin Ping-kun, convener of the NPSU caucus, said the two bills should be allowed to become law because, he claimed, they have "considerable support" from the people. However, he added that "if the public reaction is not good," the bills can always be amended in the future.
The DPP caucus, which used drastic measures to obstruct the legislative proceedings of the two bills Sept. 27, has made some concessions on the NCC bill by agreeing to debate it before the vote.

Chao Yung-ching, convener of the DPP caucus, said Monday that if the bill gets passed, the "pan-green camp" will try to have the bill overturned or seek a final judgment from the Council of Grand Justices based on the Constitution. However, on the peace-promotion bill, he was adamant that the DPP caucus will do whatever it can to prevent it from becoming law.

Ho Min-hao, convener of the TSU legislative caucus, told reporters Monday that the TSU legislators are "combat-ready" and will use the "most radical" means to block the passage of the peace-promotion bill.

The KMT and PFP caucuses have proposed a clause-by-clause debate before the two bills are put to the vote. Their whips said the pan-blue side will tolerate reasonable filibustering by DPP and TSU legislators.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jing-pyng said he will arrange a pre-meeting consultation between the two sides. Pan-blue caucus leaders have indicated that if no agreement is reached at the consultation, the KMT and the PFP caucuses will force a vote on the two bills.
The PFP caucus has advised its legislators to wear casual clothes and sneakers and to be prepared for possible conflict and bloodshed.

The controversy over the NCC Organic Bill is mainly about the composition of the commission. The pan-green side is strongly opposed to the NCC members being selected in proportion to the number of seats each party holds in the legislature, while the pan-blue side insists that this is designed to keep the ruling party from manipulating the media by appointing all the president's men to the NCC.

As for the so-called peace-promotion bill, the pan-green side believes that if it is enacted in its present form, the bill will become a "bylaw" of China's Anti-Secession Law that gives China the legal means to use "non-peaceful means" to settle cross-Taiwan Strait issues. However, Huang Yi-chiao, convener of the PFP legislative caucus, claimed that the bill is aimed at preventing the ruling party from "dominating cross-strait affairs" and hurting Taiwan people's interests by clinging to the DPP's political ideology.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT TO DEPART FOR U.S. VISIT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will depart for the United States Tuesday for a two-week visit to meet with "old friends," his aides said Monday.

Lee will visit four U.S. cities -- Anchorage, New York, Washington, D.C. and Los Angeles -- where he will meet with senior executives of major Taiwanese associations as well as American politicians, think tank scholars and opinion leaders.

An outspoken critic of China's military threat and diplomatic suppression of Taiwan, Lee will take advantage of his visit to arouse attention to the possible impact of China's rise on the peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, the Asia-Pacific region and the entire world, Lee's aides said.
Lee, an active advocate of Taiwan's separate national identity, will also urge the international community not to condone China's increasingly evident attempts to annex Taiwan.
Meanwhile, his aides said, Lee will discuss with Taiwanese community leaders how to pool resources at home and abroad to defend Taiwan's national interests.
He will also exchange views with influential U.S. congressional members, think tank researchers and social opinion leaders on the latest developments in the general international situation.

Beijing has branded Lee a separatist for supporting Taiwan independence. He retired in 2000, but Beijing still warns foreign governments against granting him visas, saying that the former leader seizes any opportunity to advocate Taiwan independence.

Lee will be in Washington from Oct. 17-20, during which he is scheduled to deliver a speech at the National Press Club. During his tenure as Republic of China president, Lee made a rare visit to the United States in June 1995, which sparked a fierce protest from China. Beijing accused him of using a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University, to advance his political agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ROTARIANS DONATE FUNDS FOR GAMBIAN CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Rotary Club Taiwan donated NT$1 million Monday to help finance a sponsorship program for impoverished schoolchildren in the Republic of China's African ally, The Gambia.
Gambian Minister of Foreign Affairs Bala Gaye accepted the donation on behalf of his country in a ceremony held at a Taipei hotel.

Gambian President Yahya Alphonse Jamus Jebulai Jammeh, who is on a state visit to Taiwan to attend the ROC's Double Ten National Day celebrations, and Vice President Annette Lu were on hand to witness the donation.
Addressing the ceremony, Lu said the fund will help finance education programs for 1,000 needy Gambian schoolchildren.

"Education is a meaningful investment in manpower resources development. It is our hope that the donation will help cultivate a pool of talent to boost The Gambia's national development, " Lu said, adding that she looks forward to seeing the fund help nurture a new generation of career women in The Gambia.
During the ceremony, Gaye presented a citation to Rotary Club Taiwan supervisor Chang Nai-liang in appreciation of his groups's generous aid to the African country.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARMFUL CHEMICAL IN CAPSIZED VESSEL A HAZARD TO FISHING BOATS

TEXT.P: The South Korean cargo ship Samho Brother that overturned following a collision off Hsinchu on Taiwan's northwest coast, carries 3,140 cubic meters of benzene, which could pose a hazard to fishing vessels operating in the area, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) warned Monday.

CGA officials said they had notified the Chemical Disaster Prevention Center for northern Taiwan to send experts to inspect whether the harmful chemical has leaked into the sea. At the same time, fishery radio stations were asked to warn fishing vessels to stay away from the area, located about nine nautical miles west of Hsinchu.
In addition to benzene, the ship was carrying 85 tons of fuel oil and 16 tons of diesel. An oil slick on the surface of the sea could been seen clearly from TV pictures.

Benzene, made mostly from petroleum sources, is toxic and highly flammable, and can dissolve slightly in water. It is used for manufacturing rubber, lubricants, dyes, detergents and pesticides. The chemical is known to cause leukemia in humans when its fumes are breathed at industrial exposure levels.
The Environmental Protection Administration formed an emergency task force in an attempt to control the pollution.
The 3,561-ton freighter collided with a container ship -- believed to be the 13,629-ton TS Hongkong registered in Liberia -- early Monday morning. It overturned nine hours later.
The CGA sent four boats and two helicopters and rescued all 14 crew members from the ship.

The TS Hongkong is now in Keelung Harbor, northern Taiwan. Experts from the CGA who examined the ship found clear collision marks on its starboard side and are trying to determine the responsibility for the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER EXPRESSES SYMPATHY FOR SOUTH ASIAN QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen on Monday offered his condolences for the loss of life and the suffering caused by a devastating earthquake in Pakistan and neighboring India Saturday.
Chen offered his sympathies on behalf of the government in a speech delivered at a cocktail reception at the Taipei Guest House in celebration of Double Ten National Day.

In his speech, Chen also extended his heartfelt appreciation for all Republic of China allies for their support for Taiwan's bids to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization over the past year, despite China's fierce opposition.

Stressing that Taiwan is willing and able to assist needy countries in their national development, Chen urged the major countries around the world to support Taiwan's efforts to defend its democratic way of life, prosperity and peace in the Taiwan Strait in the face of China's threats and containment attempts.

About 3,600 dignitaries, including foreign heads of state, members of the diplomatic corps, senior government officials, lawmakers and media executives, attended the National Day reception at the newly refurbished Taipei Guest House.
Chen officiated at the reception, which was organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs according to custom.

At the beginning of the reception, President Chen Shui-bian led foreign dignitaries in appreciating the architectural style and interior decor of the Baroque-style Taipei Guest House, a government property located on Ketagalan Avenue that is mainly used by the president to entertain VIP guests or by the government for important functions.
Presentations of traditional Taiwanese folk arts, including dough figurine making, capped the reception.

In the past few years, the National Day cocktail reception was held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall but with the completion of Taipei Guest House refurbishment project, this year's reception was relocated.
The Taipei Guest House was constructed from 1897 to 1901 and remained the governor's residence throughout the Japanese occupation, which ended in 1945.

The house is a rectangle oriented along an east-west axis, with a U-shaped two-story main structure. On the first floor is a reception room in the east wing and a banquet hall in the west. The second floor is also for receiving visitors. The interior features ornately carved columns. The whole space looks tasteful and imposing, thanks to the columns topped with carving of spirals and leaves, the friezes, crystal lamps and chandeliers hanging from the ceiling, and delicate arches carved with deer heads or leaves.
The house is surrounded by gardens, in particular the backyard, laid out with ponds and dense foliage in an imitation of the Chinese legendary abode of the immortals.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DAY FIREWORK SHOW HELD AT NEW PORT IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A dazzling firework show was held at the new Hsingta fishing port in the southern county of Kaohsiung Monday in celebration of Double Ten National Day.

President Chen Shui-bian, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsiung and acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan jointly pushed a button to start the eyecatching firework show.
Addressing the occasion, Chen said he was convinced that Monday's sunshine in Taipei after several rainy days symbolized a bright future for Taiwan.

"After the wet weekend, the National Day celebration rally at the Presidential Office plaza this morning was bathed in bright sunlight. I believe this was a good omen for our national development, " Chen told a large crowd of southern Taiwan residents who turned out to watch the fireworks, the first time that a National Day firework show had been held in Kaohsiung County.
Meanwhile, a National Day evening party took place in the central county of Changhua, with Premier Frank Hsieh and many other senior government officials in attendance.

It marked the first time that a National Day evening party took place in Changhua County as part of the central government's efforts to promote a more balanced national development. In the past, National Day celebration activities were mostly help in the capital of Taipei.
Speaking on the occasion, Hsieh said a recent survey by the World Economic Forum showed that Taiwan ranks fifth in the world in terms of its national competitiveness.

"We'll not be complacent with this rating and humbly redouble our efforts to better services for the general public and further accelerate national development, " Hsieh said, adding that he hopes local people will trust the government and have confidence in the nation's development prospects.
The evening party featured singalongs, acrobatic shows and dances presented by schoolchildren, professional and amateur troupes. Many pop idols also sang in the show.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACE-PROMOTION BILL TO AGGRAVATE SOCIAL DIVIDE: MAC

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party-proposed "Peace Promotion Bill" will aggravate social schism in Taiwan and thus hinder the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait, the Mainland Affairs Council warned Monday.

Claiming that the bill in its present form violates a national consensus on cross-strait relations, the council said if the bill is passed by the opposition-controlled legislature, it would violate constitutional principle of the division of powers
The council urged the PFP and its "pan-blue" ally of the Kuomintang to take a second thought and give up their plan to railroad the bill through the legislature at Tuesday's plenary session.
