DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 11, or the ninth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1727: George II, King of Great Britain and Ireland and elector of Hanover, is crowned in London. His 1743 victory at the Battle of Dettingen was the last time that a British monarch led troops in the field.
1821: Sir George Williams, English social reformer who founded the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA), one of the largest nonprofit voluntary organizations in the world, is born.
1834: Sir William Napier, Britain's Chief Superintendent of Trade in China, dies in Macao at the age of 48. He had recently returned from Canton after a disastrous attempt to persuade the imperial government of China to trade directly with Britain rather than through Hong Kong merchants.
1896: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is enticed into and placed in confinement at the Ching embassy in London. He was later rescued by his British friends.
1900: Winston Churchill, British politician and writer, is elected a member of the House of Commons, beginning his long political career. As prime minister, he led Great Britain during World War II. He published several works, including "The Second World War," and won the 1953 Nobel Prize for literature.
1939: U.S. scientists, including Albert Einstein, outline to President Franklin D. Roosevelt the possibility of developing an atomic bomb.
1945: A joint declaration by the government and the Chinese communists announces that an agreement between the two sides has been reached after six weeks of negotiations and that unsolved problems are to be settled by a political consultative conference.
1946: ROC government troops capture Kalgan (Changchiakow) in Inner Mongolia from the Chinese communists.
1957: The world's largest steerable radio-telescope goes into operation at the Jodrell Observatory of the British University of Manchester. The instrument has an 81-meter diameter parabolic bowl mounted on a trunnion 58 meters above ground level.
1968: Apollo 7, carrying U.S. astronauts Walter Schirra, Don Eiselle and Walter Cunningham, is launched.
1972: West Germany establishes diplomatic ties with Communist China.
1975: A two-day national conference on "Building a New Asia Through Moral Rearmament" opens in Taipei.
1976: Qiang Qing, the third wife and widow of Mao Tse-tung, is arrested with three associates. The so-called "Gang of Four" are charged with plotting a coup after Mao's death.
1978: The 1978 World Women's Football Invitational Tournament opens at the Taipei Municipal Stadium with 13 teams from Asia, Australia, Europe, the Americas and the Pacific competing.
1980: Soviet cosmonauts return to Earth after a record 185 days in space in the Salyut 6 spacecraft.
1986: A National Development Exhibition in celebration of the centennial of late President Chiang Kai-shek's birthday is opened at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
1986: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and Soviet Communist Party General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev hold a summit meeting in Reykjavik, Iceland.
1986: A display of ROC military power in the "Kuo-kuang Maneuvers" is held at the Hukou Army Base in Hsinchu.
1990: The Ministry of the Interior reiterates that the Tiaoyutai island group belongs to the Republic of China. The chain of eight uninhabited islets, located in the East China Sea, is also claimed by Japan and Communist China.
1991: Direct air service between Australia and the Republic of China begins.
1992: President Lee Teng-hui and Panamanian President Guillermo Endara sign a joint communique on expanding bilateral cooperation.
1997: Leaders of some 40 nations end a rare Council of Europe summit with pledges regarding human rights and human cloning.
1999: Some 7,000 people gather at a stadium in Linkou on the outskirts of Taipei to mourn the death of 2,321 people in the devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21.
2000: Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Chang Yu-hern confirms that Spain, Denmark and the Czech Republic have agreed to exchange "temporary aviation rights" with the ROC to facilitate bilateral visits.
2001: Chang Siao-yueh, spokeswoman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs says that the ROC government supports the U.S.-launched war against terrorism and has taken steps to prevent terrorists from laundering money in Taiwan.
2001: The results of the first stage of a nationwide English evaluation examination for people with a junior high school education background are unveiled. The tests are part of a government drive to urge people to improve their English-language ability levels in order to better compete in a rapidly globalizing economy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he in this world who is possessed of absolute truth that can order and adjust the great relations of human society, fix the fundamental principles of morality, and understand the laws of creation of the Universe."

Los Angeles Times: Quake Rescue Anxiety Grows.
Pakistan President Pervez Musharraf pleaded for international help to hurry rescue equipment and relief supplies to tens of thousands of earthquake victims in Pakistan, while desperate survivors begged for government aid that still had not arrived in large areas of the quake zone.

President Arroyo ordered yesterday the release of R17.5 billion for local government units (LGUs) , the amount representing their withheld Internal Revenue Allotment (IRA) shares, before a large gathering of local officials on the 14th anniversary celebration of the Local Government Code at the Manila Hotel.

DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: Peruvian Student Killed in Voronezh A group of young men stabbed and beat one Spanish and two Peruvian students in Voronezh in what appeared to be the latest in a series of xenophobia-related attacks. One of the Peruvians an 18-year-old first-year student, died on the way to the hospital. [By Chang Hung kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA VISIT BY KMT CHAIRMAN MA NOT RULED OUT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou does not exclude the possibility of visiting China after his term as Taipei City mayor ends, KMT Vice Chairman Wu Pah-hsiung said Monday.
Wu made the comments while responding to media questions in Guangzhou, China. The vice chairman is currently in China for a visit.
He said that Ma might visit China in the future, depending on whether such a visit would make an important contribution to cross-strait peace and would be in the interests of the Taiwan people.
According to Wu, Ma is not expected to visit China during his term as Taipei mayor nor visit simply for the purpose of sightseeing.
The Taipei City mayoral election is set to be held in December next year.

Pointing out that his current China visit has significance in terms of paving the way for a possible visit by Ma in the future, Wu said that he was also asked during his last visit to China five years ago whether that visit was to arrange for a visit by then KMT Chairman Lien Chan. Lien eventually visited China in May this year.

Wu also expressed the hope that high-ranking officials of the Communist Party of China (CPC) will be able to participate in an economic cooperation forum to be jointly held by the KMT and the CPC in Taipei in the near future.
"The two parties can easily reach consensus if the CPC can send high-ranking officials to Taipei to take part in the forum, " he added.

However, he said that whether the high-ranking CPC officials can participate in the forum depends on whether the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will allow them to visit the island as "the KMT cannot make any decision on that matter."

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS URGED TO HOLD PUBLIC HEARINGS ON NCC BILL

TEXT.P: More than a dozen civic groups demanded Tuesday that the Legislative Yuan convene public hearings to listen to the voice of the people before reviewing the National Communications Commission Organic Bill.

Representatives from the civic groups, including the Taiwan Women's Link and the Taiwan Labor Front, gathered outside the Legislative Yuan as lawmakers from the ruling and the opposition parties braced themselves for a showdown over the controversial bill.

Tsai Wan-feng, secretary-general of the Taiwan Women's Link, said that although the bill is closely related to the interests of the public, the majority of the people have very little knowledge about the functions of the commission, which she said demonstrates that the bill has not been treated as a public issue for discussion from the beginning. She added that this has deprived the people of the opportunity to participate and express their views.
For this reason, the public must fully discuss the matter before the bill is reviewed, she said.

Tsai said that in order to break the stalemate between the ruling and opposition parties and to expand public participation in the formulation of public policies, both the ruling and opposition parties, based on the people's interests, should suspend the review until after listening to the voices of the people through public hearings.

The Washington Post: Overwhelmed at Quake's Ground Zero; At Least 10,000 Estimated Dead in Capital of Pakistani-Controlled Kashmir.
The earthquake that ripped through this once-picturesque town Saturday did more than topple houses and send hillsides tumbling onto the streets. It also destroyed the main government hospital, so the injured were taken to a soccer stadium instead, the paper reported from Muzaffarabad, Pakistan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 900 ILLEGAL CHINESE IMMIGRANTS DETAINED IN FIRST 8 MONTHS

TEXT.P: A total of 890 illegal immigrants from China were arrested by Taiwan authorities during the first eight months of this year, with most of them being caught in northern and northeastern Taiwan, according to government tallies.

Of that total, 716 were arrested within Taiwan, including 341 in Taipei, 148 in Ilan and 124 in Keelung, according to statistics compiled by the Bureau of Immigration under the National Police Administration.
Another 119 were discovered trying to illegally enter Taiwan aboard ships heading for the island, while an additional 55 were caught near Taiwan's coasts, according to the tallies.
All of the caught illegal Chinese immigrants, including 550 males and 340 females, are currently being held at detention centers in Hsinchu and Illan, police authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA STILL PUSHING FOR PRESIDENT'S PARTICIPATION IN APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will continue to do all it can to arrange for President Chen Shui-bian's participation in next month's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum summit meeting in Pusan, South Korea, a MOFA spokesman said Tuesday.

Lu Ching-lung made the comments in response to questions raised at a press conference on a media report that South Korean President Roh Moo-hyun will soon send another special envoy to Taipei to discuss issues relating to who will represent Taiwan at the summit.
Without denying the report, Lu reiterated that the MOFA and Taiwan's representative to South Korea will continue to make efforts to push for Chen's presence at the summit.

A special envoy sent by Seoul to Taipei in July of this year had met with Taiwan's head of state and handed over Roh's invitation letter to Chen. In response, the ROC president publicly expressed his wish to participate in the summit.

Asked whether Lee Yuan Tseh, president of Academia Sinica, who has represented Chen at several APEC summit meetings over the past few years, will do so again at the upcoming summit if Chen is unable to attend, Lu said that "this should be decided by the Presidential Office."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: House of Deputies to discuss electoral reform bill today.
The House of Deputies is to discuss a draft bill proposed by the ruling coalition on electoral reforms Tuesday. The proposed bill is aimed at changing the existing electoral system into a proportional one. The opposition camp announced that they would introduce 550 amendments to the electoral law to obstruct the ruling parties from rushing through their proposals.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT SEEKS TO BOOST SALES OF TELECOMMUNICATIONS, TEXTILES

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) has set its sights on pushing up exports of telecommunications and textile products in a bid to revive the country's sliding outbound shipments, a BOFT spokesman said Tuesday.

To that end, the BOFT has invited foreign buyers to visit local exhibitions such as the annual Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show (TITAS) and the Computex Taipei show, the spokesman said, adding that trade promotion delegations have also been organized to boost sales overseas.
The activities have shown initial fruit in a gradual manner, as this year's TITA and Computex shows both drew large numbers of foreign buyers, the BOFT official noted.

More than 2,000 foreign buyers visited TITAS from Sept. 29 to Oct. 1, including executives from heavyweight companies like Nike and Stafnal. Orders worth US$3.04 million were placed with domestic companies on the spot, while the value of follow-up orders were estimated at around US$15 million.

The elimination of a global quota system at the beginning of this year was widely believed to impact Taiwan's textile industry due to aggressive competition from China, and it has increasingly shifted focus to value-added functional products, he said.

The BOFT is planning to turn TITAS into a world-class trade fair that enjoys similar global acclaim as Computex -- the world's second-largest computer show -- in three years to push the slogan "Think Functional Textile, Think Taiwan," the official said.

The two categories of products have shown heavy declines in exports since the start of this year, with the total value of telecommunications exports for the first nine months dwindling by 20 percent year on year to US$7.562 billion. During the same period, the value of textile product outbound shipments also contracted by 6.2 percent to US$8.89 billion, customs statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS INJURED IN SCUFFLE OVER NCC BILL

TEXT.P: Two legislators were injured in a scuffle that broke out prior to a showdown on the National Communications Commission (NCC) Organic Bill in the Legislative Yuan Tuesday.

Around 30 legislators from the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity, and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) scuffled in front of the podium as DPP legislators hoisted placards in protest when Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng announced the beginning of a clause-by-clause debate of the controversial law.
KMT Legislator Chang Shuo-wen received cuts to his eye and accused the DPP lawmakers of wielding cellular phones and the sticks supporting their placards to attack him.

Legislator Lee Ming-hsien of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) accused Chang of starting it by kicking him, injuring his nose, knees and lips. Both Chang and Lee were sent to the hospital for treatment.

Wang convened an inter-party consultation on the two controversial bills -- the NCC bill and a bill supposedly designed to promote cross-Taiwan Strait peace -- but to no avail. Two "pan-blue alliance" legislators -- the KMT's Hung Hsiu-chu and the PFP's Lee Yong-ping -- took to the podium in the meantime to criticize the KMT and PFP caucus whips for being "tied down" by the DPP and "wasting time with consultation."
As the two sides stalled, Wang put the question of whether to stop discussion on the bill and the result showed 79 in favor with seven against and two abstentions.

But the DPP legislative caucus said the vote was invalid because the number of legislators present was less than half of the 225. DPP legislators at one point tried to climb on to the podium to grab the speaker's gavel, forcing the meeting to go into recess.
When the meeting reconvened, Wang announced a clause-by-clause debate on the NCC bill, and the legislators from the ruling and the opposition parties then began fighting.

Before the meeting began, several "young turks" from the "pan-blue alliance, " including Olympic Taekwondo medalist-turned-Legislator Huang Chih-hsiung and Kao Su-po of the PFP, donned taekwondo attire to "underscore their determination to defend the dignity of the legislature and maintain smooth proceedings."

KMT Legislator Justin S. Chou, one of the group, pointed out that the last time the DPP legislators occupied the podium when discussing the NCC bill, they made Taiwan a laughing stock in the international community.

Around a dozen TSU legislators donned military fatigues, singing and shouting slogans before the meeting to "demonstrate that they are like valiant soldiers defending Taiwan" and that they oppose the cross-strait peace promotion bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES BLAME EACH OTHER FOR LEGISLATIVE VIOLENCE

TEXT.P: The ruling and opposition parties were unanimous in condemning the violence that erupted in the legislative hall Tuesday over the organic bill of the National Communications Commission (NCC) but that was the only thing they agreed upon.

Beyond that, the parties denounced each other for initiating physical violence against two lawmakers -- one each from the two camps -- who were injured and hospitalized following a schoolyard brawl in full view of the media cameras.

Bleeding opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chang Shuo-wen, who suffered a cut eye, told the media before being sent to the hospital that he was attacked by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker Lee Ming-hsien, who used a cell phone and a placard in the rough-up. Lee himself was injured to the face and knees.
"My personal injury is a minor matter, but the DPP should apologize to the people of Taiwan, " said Chang, whose constituency is in Changhua County.

Independent Legislator Chang Li-shan, also from Changhua County, came out in support of Chang Shuo-wen, claiming that his antics were really attempts to "safeguard" Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng.

William C.T. Lai, DPP legislative caucus secretary-general, said he could produce film evidence that Chang Shuo-wen made the first strike and that therefore the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party (PFP) should take the largest share of responsibility for the incident.

Lai accused the "pan-blue alliance" of planning in advance of Tuesday's meeting to have Chang, KMT Legislator Pai Tien-chih and PFP Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang act as "hit men." He also said he sent urgent messages to all DPP caucus members advising them not to resort to violence.
Lai and Chao Yung-ching, DPP caucus convener, said the violence had been anticipated.

He said the DPP caucus had repeatedly reminded the "pan-blue alliance" that Article 4 and Article 9 in their version of the bill contradicts the Law on the Basic Structure of the Executive Yuan and the administrative remedial procedure, and yet the alliance insisted on keeping these unreasonable articles for a show-down vote.

After visiting Chang Shuo-wen at the hospital, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou claimed that Chang's attack was "well planned" by the ruling party while he was trying to protect the speaker, whose gavel was taken by lawmakers of the "pan-green camp" that includes the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
Ma said the KMT "vehemently denounces" and has deep regret over the violence.

The legislature is a place for debating policy, he said. If out of fear of violence lawmakers dare not discuss issues at the legislative hall, then "an immediate and clear damage has been done to democracy," he added.
Ma said if violence erupts again during the legislative procedure, police should be called in to restore order and to prevent further injuries.
DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang also denounced the violence and expressed regret over the incident.
Su said the NCC bill has become a sacrifice of "unreasonable parliamentary politics" as a result of the "pan-blue alliance's" parochial and partisan domination of the legislative process.

He pointed at the KMT's attempts to continue to own a broadcasting company and a TV channel as evidence of the "pan-blue alliance" reneging on its commitment to "withdrawing party, political, and military influences from the media."

The "pan-blue alliance" version of the bill would foil the country's consensus on reforming the media, he said, going on to accuse the alliance of trying to use "majority violence" to railroad the bill through the legislature.
Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee and caucus whip, said the DPP caucus' actions prove it had a plan to stop the NCC bill from being passed by any means.
Tseng claimed that the DPP does not want the NCC to be established officially because it is trying to use the Government Information Office (GIO) to continue its grip on the media and press freedom.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng denounced the violence, stressing that it must be stopped by all means, including strictly banning any objects that could harm people from being taken into the legislative hall.
However, he then said that banners can be brought into the hall but not bullhorns, which he said would "interfere in the proceedings."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SEEKS TO RAISE APPROVAL THRESHOLD FOR CONTROL YUAN NOMINATIONS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Tuesday proposed raising the approval threshold for Control Yuan, Judicial Yuan and Examination Yuan nominations from a majority vote to a two-thirds vote to ensure the acceptability of the nominees.

Ma pointed out that members of the Control Yuan and Examination Yuan, as well as grand justices, are required to exercise their duties independently and therefore must be nominated based on their professionalism rather than from political considerations.
According to Ma, raising the approval threshold to a two-thirds majority will help shut out "politicians who are not supposed to get in."

Ma's proposal was intended to resolve a deadlock in which the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has over the past year refused to consider a list of Control Yuan members nominated by President Chen Shui-bian.

The KMT and its ally, the People First Party, are dissatisfied with the nominations, especially that of Clement C.P. Chang, who was nominated for Control Yuan president. Chang resigned from the position of transportation and communications minister in 1991 over corruption allegations and his nomination has been criticized by the opposition as representing the degeneration of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
The opposition has asked that the list be changed, but the request has been rejected by the president.
KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said Chen's "abuse of his power as the president and his refusal to renew the list" is to blame for the deadlock.

The KMT hopes to reform the existing system to prompt the president to take different opinions into consideration to protect the independence of the Control Yuan and prevent the president from abusing his power, Cheng said.

Also commenting on the proposal, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said the proposal could be a solution to the deadlock, but he urged the party to consider the matter properly before moving to amend the law governing the operation of the legislature to raise the approval threshold.

Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao proposed that a recommendation panel be formed by representatives of the political parties and that the president nominate the Control Yuan personnel according to the recommendations from the panel.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, rising NT$0.03 to close at NT$33.262.
A total of US$677 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.283 and fluctuated between NT$33.250 and NT$33.294.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 40 PERCENT OF TAIWAN PEOPLE OPPOSE ARMS BILL: PFP POLL

TEXT.P: More than 40 percent of the people in Taiwan oppose a major arms procurement bill, while 52 percent think that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has become corrupt, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by the opposition People First Party (PFP).

PFP officials claim that 42 percent of those polled said they are opposed to the major military procurement bill, now valued at NT$340 billion (about US$11 billion) after the Ministry of National Defense (MND) slashed the spending from originally projected NT$610.08 billion in response to the opposition's strong criticism.

In contrast, 34 percent favor the bill that would allow the government to use a special budget to acquire eight diesel-electric submarines and 12 P-3C Orion anti-submarine aircraft from the United States.

The MND has agreed to drop the third item in the weaponry procurement plan -- six PAC III anti-missile batteries -- from the special budget list. Instead, it would buy the item with the ministry's regular annual budget.

Around 60 percent of the respondents want to have direct trade, transport and postal links with China and believe that a cross-Taiwan Strait peace promotion bill advocated by the PFP at the Legislative Yuan meets high public expectations, the poll shows.
Meanwhile, 25 percent are not in favor of setting up direct links with China before Beijing publicly renounces the use of force against Taiwan.

About 52 percent of those polled term the DPP as corrupt after a series of alleged scandals related to the construction of the mass rapid train system in Kaohsiung erupted in recent months, the survey finds.

Some 56 percent answered "yes" to a question of whether the ruling party pays greater attention to the needs of vested groups, well ahead of 21 percent and 17 percent, respectively, who contended that the DPP is devoted to reform and taking better care of the ordinary people.

As many as 68 percent of the respondents to the PFP survey said that they are not satisfied with the pace of prosecutors' investigation into the building of the Kaohsiung mass rapid transport system, while 64 percent said that former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, now premier, should assume the largest share of responsibility in the alleged scandal.
The survey was carried out Oct. 6 - Oct. 7 by telephone, recovering 983 valid samples from among Taiwan residents aged over 20.

In a related development, the major arms procurement bill for the 32nd time failed to clear the floor of the legislative Rules Committee after being killed jointly by lawmakers of the PFP and the main opposition Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 15.25 points to close at 6,066.59.
The bourse opened at 6,097.88 and fluctuated between 6,112.68 and 6,065.57 during trading. A total of 2.29 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$55.94 billion (US$1.68 billion).

Four out of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by banking and financial stocks at 1.1 percent, cement shares at 0.3 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent.
Three stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.7 percent and paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent.
Plastics and chemical shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 595 to 313, with 184 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved up four points to close at 6,099, with 17,179 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved down one point to end at 6,099, with 471 contracts traded, while December futures lost 12 points to finish at 6,090, with five contracts traded. March futures increased two points to close at 6,100, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,095 for October, 6,100 for November, 6,102 for December, 6,098 for March and 6,110 for June.
Trading in electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, was mixed Tuesday.
October TE futures moved down 1.9 points to close at 257.6, with 3,525 contracts traded, while November TE futures dropped 1.65 points to finish at 257.7, with 154 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

October TF futures grew 10 points to finish at 894, with 3,099 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved up 9.8 points to end at 893.2, with 224 contracts traded. December TF futures surged nine points to close at 892, with four contract transactions.
No transactions were registered for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHALLENGES PRESIDENTIAL ADVISORY GROUP TO DEBATE FINANCIAL REFORM

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang's legislative caucus challenged the Presidential Economic Advisory Group Tuesday to debate the government's second phase of financial reforms program, one day after President Chen Shui-bian claimed that the direction of the reforms "is entirely correct."

In his National Day address, Chen said the first phase of reforms has been completed and that the second phase has started. Although the second phase has encountered "certain challenges" and there is still room for improvement in executing the policy, it's direction "is entirely correct," he said.

However, the KMT caucus claimed that the second phase of reforms, if implemented as planned, will lead to the nation's financial industry being dominated by conglomerates, to which the party is opposed.

KMT Legislator Fei Hung-tai, convener of the caucus' second phase financial reform group, questioned the president's wisdom in his decision to push ahead with the program whose direction, Fei claimed, the Finance Ministry and the Financial Supervisory Commission are not clear about.
He also challenged the Economic Advisory Group to an open debate about the program.

Fei's deputy, Legislator Lee Chi-chu, said that if the reforms go wrong, it could trigger a financial crisis. If government officials who drafted the plan dare not debate it with experts and scholars, that means "something is not quite right" about the reform program, she claimed.

Chen said the second phase of reforms will center on the merger and integration of public and private financial institutions, which he hopes will "accelerate the inflow of foreign capital investment and attract foreign managerial teams to enhance the competitiveness of Taiwan's financial industry in the global community."

The first phase, a so-called "2-5-8 financial agenda," was set in 2002 to reduce the average non-performing loan ratio (NPLR) to less than 5 percent and to raise the average capital adequacy ratio (CAR) to 8 percent within two years. The task was completed by Aug. 31, 2005, when the NPLR was lowered to 2.83 percent and the CAR was raised above 10 percent, with NT$1.45 trillion-worth of bad loans dissolved, he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT DEPARTS FOR U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Y.F. Low and Chou Hui-ying)

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui left for the United States Tuesday for a two-week visit to meet with who his aides described as "old friends."

According to Su Chin-chiang, chairman of the opposition, pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union of which Lee is the so-called "spiritual leader, " Lee's U.S. trip will be "purely personal" and has been arranged at the invitation of some members of the U.S. Congress and of the Taiwanese expatriate community in the United States.
The purpose of the trip is mainly to catch up with these "old friends" and Lee will keep his tour simple and low-profile, Su said.

Lee is scheduled to visit the U.S. cities of Anchorage, New York, Washington, D.C. and Los Angeles, where he will meet with leaders of major Taiwanese associations, American politicians, think tank scholars and opinion leaders.
Lee will be in Washington, D.C. from Oct. 17-20, during which he will deliver a speech at the National Press Club.

He reportedly will promote Taiwan's democratic experience and call the international community's attention to China's threat to the peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, the Asia-Pacific region and the entire world.
Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Lee's itinerary has been arranged by his office and that the ministry has not participated in the process.
However, the Republic of China representative office in the United States will provide Lee with all necessary administrative assistance, Lu said.
David Ta-wei Lee, ROC representative to the United States, confirmed last week that the government has requested that the United States grant the former president diplomatic courtesy during his trip.

Lee made a rare visit to the United States in June 1995 during his tenure as president, sparking a fierce protest from China, which accused him of using a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University, to advance Taiwan independence.
Also Tuesday in Beijing, China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Kong Quan said Beijing opposes Lee's visit, no matter what form it takes, as he will be promoting his pro-independence ideas.

Calling Lee a "troublemaker" who did serious damage to Beijing-Washington relations in the past, Kong urged the United States to follow the three communiques with China and the "one China" policy so as "not to send the wrong message to the Taiwanese separatists."

DOC.HEADLINE: ITA OPERATIONS UNAFFECTED BY EARTHQUAKES

TEXT.P: The India-Taipei Association (ITA) is faring well and Taiwan visitors are welcome to visit India, despite devastating earthquakes that have killed thousands of people there in recent days, a spokesman for the association said Tuesday.

Stressing that the earthquakes will not hinder normal business and travel activities in India, the spokesman also thanked the people and the government of Taiwan for their assistance and aid to the rescue and relief operations that are still being carried out in the three affected South Asian countries that also include Pakistan and Afghanistan.
The northwestern region of Jammu and Kashmir is the hardest-hit region in India, but is located far from New Delhi, the country's capital, he noted.
The ITA is India's representative office in Taiwan, responsible for bilateral exchanges in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGENTS QUESTION FORMER KRTC VICE CHAIRMAN OVER KICKBACKS

TEXT.P: Agents of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice questioned a former vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KTRC) Tuesday after finding more than 60 illegal transfers of funds in large sums from four non-profit organizations under his control.

Earlier in the day, agents from the Kaohsiung section of the Investigation Bureau searched the office of the Southeast Cultural Foundation and took away its accounting records and other related documents, hoping to trace some of the recipients of the funds.

A spokesman for the Investigation Bureau's Kaohsiung section said that all the documents have been sealed for safekeeping, and will be examined by former KTRC vice chairman Chen Min-hsien himself in hopes that the money trail will be uncovered.

Chen, currently chairman of the Southeast Cement Corp., has been under judicial investigation on suspicion of illegally profiting from the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project and hiring Thai laborers for the construction project. He resigned his post as KRTC vice chairman in September after the irregularities were brought to light by the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers protesting their maltreatment by the KTRC employers and Huapan Administration Consultant Co.

When he was first questioned by Kaohsiung district prosecutors on Sept. 5, Chen categorically denied any wrongdoing in bringing in Thai laborers to work on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project. He also denied that he went with a brokerage operator to Thailand on luxury trips, claiming that he only went to Thailand once in recent years and that was with a friend last November during which he paid his own expenses.

However, subsequent investigation into the accounting records of Huapan Co. unearthed airplane tickets and hotel bills showing that Chen was with the Huapan owners on at least three overseas trips -- twice to Thailand in 2002 and once to South Korea in 2004.

Meanwhile, news media are calling for an investigation into why Chen, as a shareholder owning only 7 percent of the total investment in the KRTC, was able to control the entire company, in which NT$150.8 billion in public funds account for 83 percent of the company's total capital.

Chung Chung-hsiao, spokesman for the task force charged with the investigation of the profiteering case, acknowledged that it will be a very laborious and time-consuming process to trace the destinations of the kickbacks and unlawful gains from the exploitation of more than 1,700 Thai laborers.

He said the Investigation Bureau's section dealing with money laundering has doubled the number of agents working on the case to 20 people, and that they have conducted nearly 100 interviews with both suspects and witnesses and examined details in hundreds of bank accounts.

An investigation report by the Investigation Bureau has confirmed that there is clear evidence that Wang Tsai-pi and Yen Shih-hua, the owners of Huapan Co., received kickbacks from contractors using the service of Thai workers. The couple have been detained by order of the Kaohsiung District Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME TAIWAN BUSINESSES'S CHINA INVESTMENTS SCRUTINIZED BY MOEA

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday that the ministry has commissioned credit information service institutions to investigate Taiwan businesses that have invested in China illegally for years.

Ho was responding to media reports that the ministry has recently commissioned private credit institutions to look into those businesses that have invested in the mainland in violations of the law under the government's "active opening, effective management" policy regarding investment in the mainland. Ho was speaking on the sidelines of the 2005 Taipei International Electronics (TAITRONICS) exhibition.

Ho said the media reports were "not totally true, " saying that the ministry is not randomly targeting Taiwan businessmen, only looking into those businesses that the ministry suspects have invested in China without obtaining prior approval, and on which the ministry has not been able to get further information.
The government has commissioned credit information services to investigate and to collect this information," Ho said.

On reports that the economics ministry investigation is targeting around a dozen listed or over-the-counter companies, especially those in the flat-panel sector that are currently prohibited from investing in the mainland, Ho said that she was not aware of this, adding that as far as she was aware, the flat-panel sector has followed regulations.

Ho said that there is no reason to doubt the fairness of the credit information service institutions. In addition, the information collected will be judged by the ministry and the ministry will also listen to the responses of the Taiwan businesses.
"If anyone has a better suggestion as to how to obtain this information, the ministry is all ears," Ho added.

The Investment Commission under the economics ministry said the credit information service firms commissioned by the ministry are large, not small institutions, and the ministry has followed the Government Procurement Law for open bidding. This practice has been going on for four or five years, and is not a new measure as reports have said. More than a dozen Taiwan businesses have been disciplined because of these checks, commission officials said.

Meanwhile, Hsu Sheng-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association, expressed the hope that the government can have a clearer management mechanism for local businesses to follow.

Hsu said on the sidelines of the electronics show that he has yet to learn of the details, but Taiwan businesses are now reaching out around the globe and the government should use different approaches to achieve effective management. The commissioning of credit information services to check on Taiwan businesses doesn't seem suitable, Hsu added.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang said Monday that the ministry has commissioned legal credit institutions to investigate whether Taiwan businessmen's investments in the mainland are legal, and the credit institutions have sent officials to the mainland to get first-hand information or collect information on capital flows of the Taiwan businessmen overseas through cooperation with international institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANANA EXPORTS FALL TO FIVE-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan banana exports totaled US$10.29 million in 2004, a five-year low, the Directorate General of Budget, Account and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.

DGBAS officials said that bananas have been the mainstay of Taiwan fruit exports and almost all of them are shipped to Japan, but current exports to Japan are a far cry from the past because of rising production costs in Taiwan, competition from cheap produce from the Philippines and Central and South American countries, as well as Japan's scrapping of preferential tariffs for Taiwan products.

They noted that banana exports of US$10.29 million last year was a dramatic decrease from the US$30.73 million in 2000. In addition to steep international competition, other factors including low temperatures early this year and strong winds and torrential rains brought by typhoons in mid-year, resulted in the volume of bananas grown falling by 14.9 percent, with exports being cut by 47.4 percent in terms of value.

The ratio of banana exports accounted for only 26.8 percent of Taiwan fruit exports in 2004 compared with 65.6 percent in 2000. If the trend continues, the officials said that they worry that the exports could fall below US$10 million this year.

But the silver lining is that although banana exports are dropping, other premium Taiwan fruits have emerged and mangoes have shown dramatic growth, mainly exports to Japan, Hong Kong and Singapore. Mango exports totaled US$4.82 million in 2004, up 30.5 percent from the previous year, replacing lychees to become the second-biggest export fruit, accounting for 12.5 percent of total fruit exports.

Taiwan exported US$38.49 million in fruits in 2004, down 11.7 percent from 2003. In terms of exporting countries, Japan accounted for 44 percent of Taiwan's exports, followed by the United States and Hong Kong, with the three accounting for around 85 percent of Taiwan's exported fruits. China only accounted for 0.9 percent of the total exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONWIDE ONE-WEEK CAMPAIGN TO KILL RATS TO BEGIN OCT. 17

TEXT.P: The government has the ubiquitous rat in its crosshairs and has designated Oct. 17-23 as national "Rat Extermination Week, " according to the sponsors of the event, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) and the Council of Agriculture.

The EPA has distributed poisoned bait to local government officials in counties, cities, townships and villages around the country, which will be used by organizations, schools and households to try to put a dent in the rat and mouse population.

Rats and mice are not only a nuisance but are also a vector in the spread of diseases such as hantavirus, hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome, and salmonellosis to humans. These rodents can also carry parasites like trichinosis and tapeworms.

Local governments are urging residents in their cities and counties to clean their houses and surrounding areas during this week. They are also reminding them to keep their foodstuffs in safe places, so that hungry rodents will have nothing but poisoned bait to feed on.
However, the EPA officials warned people placing the poisoned bait to take extra precautions to avoid accidental poisoning of pets or children.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PASSES ARTICLE ONE OF COMMUNICATIONS BILL

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed Article One of the organic bill of the National Communications Commission (NCC) in the second reading by an 111-2 vote Tuesday after ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers failed to stop the speaker from putting it to a vote.

The article deals with the purposes of setting up the NCC -- to realize the constitutional provisions on the protection of freedom of expression, to honor the commitment of "withdrawing partisan, political and military influences from the media, " and to maintain a professional and autonomous environment for the healthy development of the media industry.

After calling off the meeting, which was boycotted by the DPP and its "pan-green" camp ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said the boycott "hurt the DPP greatly."

He was referring to the "pan-green" camp's obstruction in the morning, which led to a scuffle in which two lawmakers were lightly injured and hospitalized, and some DPP lawmakers' attempts to crawl up onto the speaker's quarters in the afternoon which were stopped by legislators Yen Ching-piao and Lin Ping-kun of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union.
Wang urged the ruling party and its ally not to boycott or interfere in meeting procedures again, since it is normal for the legislature to resort to balloting when negotiations break down.

After the bill is passed, the government can request the legislature to "reconsider" or ask for a constitutional interpretation of the newly passed law, Wang said. But if the DPP keeps on boycotting proceedings dealing with the bill, it will further hurt itself, he warned.
He noted that President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to meet with DPP lawmakers on Thursday, by which time he said he hopes "things will turn for the better."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-TAIWAN CROSS-STRAIT WAR SIMULATION POSTPONED TO EARLY NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: A Ministry of National Defense official said Tuesday that the United States has postponed an annual computer-assisted war simulation with Taiwan because of a recent personnel change at the Pentagon's strategic planning department.

As part of U.S.-Taiwan military exchanges, Taiwan military officials have been invited to visit the headquarters of the U.S. Pacific Command in Hawaii annually over the past years for a simulation of a war across the Taiwan Strait.

According to ministry spokesman Liu Chih-chien, this year's simulation, which was originally expected to be held in late September, has been postponed to early next year, because William J. Fallon, the new commander of the U.S. Pacific Command, needs some time to familiarize himself with the new position.

Liu said other military exchanges and cooperation between Taiwan and the United States have not been affected and that the postponement of the war simulation has nothing to do with the delay in Taiwan's latest arms procurement package from the United States.

Taiwan's plan to buy eight diesel electric submarines, six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft has been stalled over the past year owing to objections by the opposition-controlled legislature. The U.S. side has expressed much concern over the situation and has urged Taiwan to show its resolve to defend itself by speeding up the procurement.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL RANDALL SCHRIVER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Randall Schriver, former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state in charge of East Asia and Pacific affairs, will visit Taiwan again on Oct. 23, officials said Tuesday.

According to Lai I-chung, director of the international affairs department at the Taiwan Thinktank, Schriver has been invited to take part in a U.S.-Japan-Taiwan Trilogue seminar to be held by the think tank Oct. 23-25.

A government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Schriver will also give a speech at the Mainland Affairs Council and meet with high-ranking officials in the ROC government to discuss issues concerning security across the Taiwan Strait and Taiwan's latest arms procurement package from the United States.
Schriver last visited Taiwan in July, when President Chen Shui-bian conferred upon him the Order of Brilliant Star with Violet Grand Cordon in recognition of his promotion of Taiwan-U.S. relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Kashmiris Are Paying Heaviest Price in Earthquake
In the hardest-hit area of Kashmir, teams from the world over sought survivors under the rubble, and the first signs of aid arrived.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Two Ford Executives Resign Before Expected Revamp Of North American Group
Ford Motor Co. Chairman and Chief Executive William Clay Ford Jr. and his new head of American operations, Mark Fields, are planning another shake-up of the auto maker's North American management, and at least two vice presidents have decided to leave in advance.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO PROBE IF CHEN CHE-NAN VIOLATED PARTY DISCIPLINE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) formed a task force Tuesday to investigate whether Chen Che-nan, a former deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, violated party discipline because of his alleged involvement in the exploitation of Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project.

DPP Secretary-General Li Yi-yang disclosed after a meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee that party Chairman Su Tseng-chang introduced the motion to form the task force which was passed by all those present unanimously.

Li indicated that despite continuous media allegations about Chen's involvement in the illegal profiteering racket between the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) and the brokerage firm Huapan Co. that exploited the Thai laborers, Chen has not clarified the situation effectively, thus hurting the image of the DPP.
Li said that after being notified about the DPP's decision to question him, Chen expressed understanding of the party's position and agreed to cooperate.
He added that there is no timetable for the investigation, although the sooner it is done, the better.

Chen resigned last week as national policy adviser to the president after evidence showed that he took two trips to Thailand with Chen Min-hsien, former vice chairman of the KRTC, and the owners of Huapan Co. while he was deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.

The profiteering case exposed by the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers to protest their maltreatment by KRTC and Huapan Co. has already led to the resignations of Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu and acting Kaohsiung mayor Chen Chi-mai, son of Chen Che-nan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HELP WITH RELIEF OPERATIONS AFTER EARTHQUAKE IN SOUTH ASIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan joined other countries Tuesday in promising aid to earthquake refugees in India and Pakistan.

Three days after an area straddling India and Pakistan was rocked by a magnitude 7.6 earthquake, a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said the Department of Health has promised to donate 27 tons of medical materials to those in need in the disaster area.
Lu said the Council of Agriculture has promised to send an unspecified amount of rice to the two countries.
Taiwan's private groups are sending rescue teams to the two countries and the Foreign Ministry is helping them to get the necessary travel documents, Lu said.
However, the spokesman said, Taiwan has not yet decided whether to donate cash.
Reports say the death toll from the earthquake could top 80,000 with many more homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION MILITARY FINANCE PLAN WOULD SET BACK MILITARY 10 YEARS: MND

TEXT.P: The ROC military's development will be set back 10 years if the opposition has its way and lumps all items in the U.S. defense purchase into the ministry's regular budget, the defense ministry said Tuesday.

Hours after the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan rejected a motion to review the special budget of NT$340 billion (US$10.23 billion) for the arms package for the 33rd time, the ministry said the weaponry in question is vital to boosting the country's defense capabilities, and that this is only a part of the ministry's efforts to strengthen the nation's defense.
The U.S. package refers to the purchase of 12 anti-submarine aircraft, eight submarines and six patriotic PAC-3 batteries.

Other hardware, such as search and surveillance radar, Kidd-class guided missile destroyers, and Clouded Leopard armored vehicles, should be acquired simultaneously for the effective defense of the country, the ministry said in a statement.

If all three major items in the U.S. package are financed from the ministry's regular budget, as requested by the opposition parties in the legislature, the other arms procurement programs would have to be put on the back burner for at least 10 years and would expose the country to China's military threat for quite a long time, the statement said.

China's military threat against Taiwan consists mainly of its missiles and jet fighters, the statement said, adding that Beijing has deployed in southeastern China more than 700 missiles within the range of the whole of Taiwan.

Also, the ministry said, Beijing has about 120 jet fighters stationed in its coastal provinces across Taiwan, and another 660 jet fighters in provinces in central China, all within striking range of Taiwan.

Patriot missiles proved to be an effective anti-missile weapon in the Iraq War, and can help shelter Taiwan from Beijing's missiles; but its price, NT$130 billion, is simply too much to be incorporated into the regular defense budget, the statement said.

Citing the country's purchase of 150 F-16 jet fighters from the United States and 60 Mirage jet fighters from the French in 1992, the ministry said the huge outlays for them were financed by a special budget over nine years.
In order to complying with the opposition's request, the ministry has included the Patriot missiles in its regular budget while leaving the other two items in a NT$340 billion special budget.

But its efforts have failed to soften the opposition's objections. They have refused to budge in their opposition to the special budget, and do not agree with the Patriot missiles in the regular budget on the grounds that this was already rejected by the public in a 2004 referendum, a claim the Executive Yuan denies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 12, or the 10th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: After a month of experiencing mirages of land, explorer Christopher Columbus and his three ships sight "terra firma" at dawn today.
1822: Brazil becomes independent from Portugal.
1866: Ramsey McDonald, Scottish statesman and first Labour prime minister of Britain, is born.
1870: Robert E. Lee, Confederate general in the US Civil War, dies in Lexington at the age of 63. He won victories at Bull Run (1862), Fredericksburg (1863), and Chancellorsville (1863), before surrendering to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox in 1865.
1899: The Boer states respond to Britain's despatch of troops to South Africa by issuing a declaration of war, and the British military garrison at Mafeking, under Colonel Robert Baden-Powell, is under siege by Boer forces.
1901: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, renames the Executive Mansion "The White House." He won the 1908 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War.
1920: Bertrand A. W. Russell, British philosopher, mathematician, social critic, and writer who won the 1950 Nobel Price for Literature, arrives in Shanghai as a visiting professor. He had profound influence on the development of symbolic ligic, logical positivism, and the set theory of mathematics.
1935: Adolf Hitler bans American jazz from German radio, calling it decadent.
1949: The ROC government moves its seat from Canton to Chungking.
1949: Euginie Anderson is appointed US ambassador to Denmark, becoming the first female US envoy.
1951: Florence Chadwick, US swimmer, breaks the cross-English Channel record with a time of just 13 hours 33 minutes.
1959: The United Nations General Assembly votes for a full-scale debate on Chinese communist bloodshed in Tibet.
1960: Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev, angered during a debate on colonialism at the United Nations General Assembly, takes off his shoe and ponds his desk with it several times.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a frienship treaty in Taipei.
1968: The 19th Olympic Games opens in Mexico City, capital of Mexico.
1968: Equatorial Guinea becomes independent after 190 years of Spanish rule.
1968: Omar Torrijos Herrera, a military officer, takes control of Panama and bigins to rule as a dictator.
1971: Dean Acheson, US politician and secretary of state from 1949 to 1953, dies at the age of 78. He promoted the Marshall Plan and helped established NATO.
1974: Juan Pao-shan, a Chinese student from Taiwan, is stabbed and killed in Los Angeles by leftists at a party in celebration of the Double Ten National Day of the Republic of China.
1976: Communist China's Prime Minister Hua Guofeng becomes chairman of the Chinese Communist Party.
1979: Fidel Castro, head of the Cuban governdment, deliver a speech at the United Nations General Assembly, requesting more UN aid for third world countries.
1983: A Tokyo district court sentences former Japanese Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka to four years' imprisonment for his part in the Lockheed bribery scandal.
1984: In a move to further expand bilataral trade and economic relations, the ROC-Australia Trade Association and the Chinese-New Zealand Business Council are formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1986: A summit meeting between US President Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev ends in Reykjavik without any agreement on arms control being reached.
1986: During a display of ROC military power in the "Kuokuang Maneuvers," a combat skills exercise is held at a southern naval base.
1987: South Korea adopts a new constitution allowing direct election of the president by the people rather than by the electoral college.
1989: The Republic of China and Belize announce the establishment of diplomatic relations.
1989: Direct telephone links between Taiwan and the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu are completed.
1989: King Mswati III of Swaziland arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1992: Strong earthquake rocks Cairo, killing 552 people and injuring nearly 10,000 others.
1992: Premier Hau Pei-tsun receives Austrian Minister for Economic Affairs Wolfgang Schussel.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is unobstrusive and yet it grows more and more in significance; whereas the life of the vulgar person is ostentatious, but it losses more and more in significance until it becomes nothingness."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN ANCHORAGE FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and his wife Tseng Wen-hui arrived in Anchorage, Alaska Tuesday on the first leg of their private visit to the United States.

Accompanied by Wu Li-pei, an adviser to ROC President Chen Shui-bian, and Huang Kun-hui, secretary-general of the Taiwan Advocates, which promotes Taiwan's interests, Lee and his wife were greeted at the airport by staff from Taiwan's representative office in Seattle, Washington as well as a group of Taiwanese expatriates living in Alaska.
When they arrived at their hotel in Anchorage, the Lees were greeted by Alaska Governor Frank Murkowski who later hosted Lee and his delegation on a yacht tour of a nearby fjord.
Lee even tried his hand at steering the yacht briefly during the 90 minute boat ride.

The governor will take Lee and his delegation on a train trip Wednesday to Grandview to enjoy the view of glaciers there and invite Lee to give a speech to the Alaska World Affairs during a luncheon Thursday.
Anchorage is the first leg of Lee's two-week U.S. trip which will also take him to New York, Washington, D.C., and Los Angeles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEXTILE MAKERS URGED TO PREPARE FOR MORE U.S. ORDERS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh urged Taiwan's textile and garment exporters Wednesday to grab the opportunity presented by U.S. authorities' ongoing investigations into whether to impose import tariffs on textile imports from China.

Speaking during a regular Executive Yuan meeting, Hsieh said that as a result of the U.S. investigations, many textile and garment orders have been flowing out of China to other countries, including Taiwan.
Hsieh instructed relevant government agencies to quickly come up with measures to facilitate textile and garment exports to the United States by Taiwan manufacturers and exporters.

The Bush administration reportedly has accepted petitions from the U.S. textile industry to launch investigations into whether quotas should be imposed on 26 categories of clothing and textile imports from China, including wool suits, coats, cheesecloth and polyester filament fabric.

U.S. and Chinese negotiators met last week in a third round of talks on reaching a comprehensive deal to limit Chinese clothing imports, which have been flooding the United States since global quotas were lifted last January.

Since the trade dispute began, export orders from the United States have been flowing to Taiwan, and manufacturers in the Tainan area in southern Taiwan are now operating at full capacity to meet these orders, Hsieh said.

He instructed the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Council of Labor to work out measures to help Taiwan's textile industry take on as many textile and garment orders released from China as possible.

For example, he said, textile and garment manufacturers can be encouraged to move their operations into the Chang Ping Industrial Park in central Taiwan where many plant openings are available and where operators are entitled to governmental investment incentives.
Meanwhile, the Taiwan Sweater Industry Association has also voiced interest in relocating some investment abroad back to Taiwan, he noted.

According to MOEA officials, Taiwan's textile and garment exports have averaged about US$12.5 billion annually in recent years, compared with US$2.6 billion in imports, giving Taiwan a trade surplus of roughly US$9.9 billion annually in this sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO NAME LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER TO ATTEND APEC SUMMIT MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will appoint Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to attend the annual informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Busan, South Korea in November, the president's chief of staff said Wednesday.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said President Chen expressed to a special South Korean envoy earlier in the day that he would like to attend the summit meeting himself but that he has instead decided to appoint Wang to go to Busan to attend the summit on his behalf in order not to put the host country in a difficult position.

James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, noted that Wang has rich political experience and is well respected by both the ruling and opposition parties as the speaker of the nation's legislative branch.
Wang has gladly accepted President Chen's invitation to attend the summit, Huang said, adding that Taiwan has informed South Korea and the United States of the decision.

The United States, which supports Taiwan's participation in the APEC summit, responded positively to the decision, saying it is a "creative move" to send the legislative speaker to attend, according to Huang.
For his part, the legislative speaker said that he would be glad to attend the summit if it will benefit the country.

Wang, a former vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), also said that he is still a KMT member and that he will have to report the matter to the party as well as to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.
The politically-savvy Wang stressed that he is willing to work for the benefit of the nation, but added that everything is still "under arrangement" and that he wouldn't speculate about the outcome.
If all goes well, it will be the first time that Wang represents the ROC's head of state in attending the annual APEC summit.

In line with long-established protocol, the 2005 APEC summit organizing committee sent a special envoy to Taipei in July to forward an invitation to Chen. While meeting with the special envoy, Chen said he looks forward to attending the summit meeting in the name of the leader of "Chinese Taipei" -- Taiwan's official APEC designation.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that admit both Taipei and Beijing. Because of Beijing's opposition, the Republic of China's head of state has been unable to attend previous APEC annual informal leadership meetings and has instead had to name a proxy to attend on his behalf. Lee Yuan-tseh, Nobel laureate and the president of nation's highest research institute Academia Sinica, has represented Chen over the past few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES TO LAUNCH CODESHARE SERVICE WITH GERMAN RAIL

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) announced Wednesday that it will launch a codeshare service with Deutsche Bahn AG (DB) , Germany's national railway company, from Oct. 30.

The service will allow passengers flying between Taiwan and Germany to enjoy convenient high-speed rail connections between Frankfurt Ariport and seven German cities, including Hamburg, Cologne, Dusseldorf, Hanover, Munich, Nuremberg and Stuttgart, according to a CAL press statement.

Passengers using the codeshare service will only need to pay an extra NT$1,000 (US$30) for a single rail trip, which is cheaper than domestic air connections, and they can also enjoy access to DB's VIP lounges in the railway stations, the statement said.
CAL is currently offering various preferential programs to promote the service, including free upgrades, bonus mileage and price discounts.

However, owing to immigration and customs restrictions, passengers using the codeshare service will not be able to check their baggage to their final destination in Germany, nor will they be able to enjoy through check-in. Also, CAL's Dynasty Flyer members will not be able to accumulate DB mileage.
In addition to CAL, DB also maintains codeshare partnerships with American Airlines, Air Portugal and All Nippon Airways.
Other codeshare partners of CAL include Delta Air Lines, Alitalia, Thai Airways, Garuda Indonesia and Vietnam Airlines.
