DOC.HEADLINE: EXPATS GATHER AT GOOGLE HEADQUARTERS TO UPHOLD TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Chiang Chun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Scores of Taiwan expatriates residing in the Silicon Valley area swamped the headquarters of the search engine giant Google Tuesday in a display of support for Taiwan as a sovereign country.

Despite the fact that Google Inc. removed its reference to Taiwan as a "province of China" from its Google Maps service over the weekend after the Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Taiwan nationals living in the United States voiced their concerns about the reference, the Taiwan expatriates still decided to gather in front of Google's headquarters in Silicon Valley to make known their stance of upholding Taiwan's sovereignty.
The protesters waved banners that read "Taiwan is an independent country" and "One China, One Taiwan."

After receiving a letter of concern from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, a de facto Taiwan consulate office, Oct. 6 complaining about Google Maps service's reference to Taiwan as a "province of China, " Google removed the reference from the service Oct. 9.

Reports from Taiwan have said that Taiwan authorities and legislators were up in the arms over the Google Maps description of Taiwan as a province of China. The reports also said that Taiwan's liaison offices in the United States had been asked since Sept. 19 to convey Taiwan's concern and indignation to Google Inc. about the matter but that the requests had "all fallen on deaf ears."

One of the protestors, Hung Shun-wu, a former Taiwan national assemblyman representing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, expressed his appreciation to Google for listening to the Taiwan public's call "to present the facts as they are."

Noting that Taiwan is an independent state, Hung said that while striving to boost its business expansion in China, Google's services should also portray the truth, such as the political reality of Taiwan.

Hung added that the Taiwan expatriates' demonstration in front of the Google headquarters was also aimed at notifying other high-tech companies ready to head to China not to make the same sort of mistake.

A Google Inc. international affairs spokesman would not confirm Tuesday whether Google changed the Taiwan map reference due to pressure from Taiwan, only saying that the map service is a pure American product and that the change was made in response to concerns expressed by Web site visitors about the user interface (UI).

Taiwan's complaint is not the first that Google Maps has received. Last year, South Koreans protested Google's use of the name "Sea of Japan" to describe the sea between Japan and South Korea, instead of the name "East China Sea." Following the protests, Google decided to use both names on its maps in a bid to calm protests.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFERS TO COMPROMISE WITH OPPOSITION ON CONTROVERSIAL NCC BILL

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) offered Wednesday to compromise with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) on the controversial organic bill of the proposed national communications commission (NCC).

Legislator Jao Yung-ching, convener of the DPP legislative caucus, challenged the KMT and PFP to agree with a proposal presented by a private group on the makeup of the NCC one day after the opposition-initiated bill was blocked by the DPP in a violent confrontation in the legislature.
Jao said that his party, which has insisted that the NCC members be named by the Executive Yuan, would agree with the private group's proposal, if the opposition were to do the same.

Under the private group's proposal, the nine members of the NCC should be selected by a panel consisting of scholars and representatives of independent civil groups from a list of 27 candidates-- 18 of which are named by the legislature and nine by the Executive Yuan-- and approved by the premier.

The members of the panel in charge of preparing the final list of nine NCC members should be appointed by the political parties in proportion to the number of seats each of the parties holds in the legislature.

The list of candidates named by the legislature and the Executive Yuan should cover nine different fields, including education, communications, law, economics and so on, with the legislature naming two candidates from each of these fields and the Executive Yuan naming one from each of the fields.
Under the opposition's bill, the NCC members should be named by political parties in proportion to the number of legislative seats each party holds.
The differences between the ruling and opposition parties on the makeup of the NCC has resulted in a political impasse which has paralyzed the legislature for weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR COOPERATION AFTER CLASHES IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh urged the ruling and opposition parties Wednesday to put aside their disagreements and cooperate with each other in the wake of violent clashes between the rival camps in the legislature.

Hsieh noted that the struggle between the ruling party and the opposition has thrown the approval rating of the Cabinet to a low of 20 percent, while that of the Legislative Yuan has declined to just 8.7 percent.
The situation proves that it is a mistake for both sides to try to destroy each other through such extreme means, Hsieh said.

Fistfights broke out again Tuesday in the Legislative Yuan when opposition lawmakers made a second attempt to steamroller through a bill governing the formation of the National Communication Commission (NCC).
Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chang Sho-wen and ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lee Ming-hsien were injured amid scenes of violence.
The two parties continued to trade accusations Wednesday, blaming each other for provoking the clashes.
William Lai, a leader of the DPP legislative caucus, said the party condemns the violence and regrets that lawmakers were reduced to exchanging blows over a bill.
He suggested that the ruling and opposition parties continue their negotiations on the bill rationally to "maintain the dignity" of the legislature.
However, KMT lawmakers said the DPP should be held responsible for creating the confrontation.

They said it was the DPP that has made the Legislative Yuan an international laughing stock by occupying the podium and attacking opposition lawmakers with shields, pipes, mobile phones and wooden clubs to obstruct legislative proceedings.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES PARTY ASSETS BILL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved a bill for handling political parties' "ill-gotten" assets at a meeting Wednesday, two days after President Chen Shui-bian announced that the government will focus on six major reforms that include investigations into property inappropriately seized by political parties.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who is also Taipei mayor and in that capacity attended the Cabinet meeting, did not voice his objection during the meeting but told the media later that the KMT "basically does not quite agree" with the bill, which is aimed at "purging" the KMT of its assets.
Ma claimed that the bill violates legal principles and is unconstitutional.

Under the Cabinet's draft law, all party assets except membership dues, campaign funds donated by the public and businesses, and government subsidies for elections, will be defined as "ill-gotten" assets that must be returned to the national coffers or local governments.

A provision in the draft law says that any property given gratis or sold at unreasonable market prices after April 6, 2001 by political parties and their affiliated groups will also be defined as ill-gotten assets. The provision aims to stop political parties, especially the KMT, from selling out their assets before the bill becomes law.

The bill says all political parties must report their assets within six months of the law becoming effective, including those listed by the Control Yuan in its April 6, 2001 report to the Executive Yuan, as well as those entrusted to third parties. Violations will be subject to fines of between NT$500,000 and NT$2.5 million. Those who refuse to conform will be fined every 10 days and after five fines, their assets will be defined as ill-gotten.

After the law's promulgation, political parties and their affiliated organizations will be banned from handling any assets except membership dues, political donations, election subsidies paid by the government, and "spending needed to run a party." Violations will be subject to fines one to three times the value of the disputed assets.

The draft law proposes that a political party assets investigation and handling committee be established with 11 to 13 members whose expertise covers prosecution, law, economy, finance, accounting and land administration, with the rest being well-respected and fair-minded persons. No more than a quarter of the members should come from any one political party; they will be nominated by the premier and appointed by the president.

However, the draft bill still needs to be sent to the Legislative Yuan, where it has little chance of passing as the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party enjoys a slim majority.
KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen claimed that the bill is nothing but a tool of the DPP government to purge civic groups of their assets and is "evidently unconstitutional."
She said Chen and the government are sending a threatening message to people interested in buying KMT assets and claimed that the KMT has been handling its assets in a "legal and transparent manner."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST APEC CONFAB ON RECYCLING

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been chosen to host the 2005 Conference on Recycling under the framework of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, officials from the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Wednesday.

The APEC Conference on Recycling, scheduled to be held in Taipei Thursday and Friday, is expected to tackle all issues concerning recycling, including challenges and problems in promoting recycling; the sharing of successful recycling experience; and building websites, EPA authorities said.
Experts from Canada, Japan, Mexico, New Zealand, Thailand and Taiwan are expected to attend the two-day meeting.

According to EPA officials, Japan recommended earlier this year that the conference be held in Taiwan as it has made noticeable progress in recycling in recent years. The 2005 APEC Conference on Recycling is part of the activities under an APEC project to build APEC economic entities' recycling prowess, sponsored by Japan.

As global trade expands continuously and its impact on the Asia-Pacific region grows, industrial products are sold and used across borders, resulting in the fact that products that are manufactured in one country can end up having to be recycled in another, the EPA officials said.
This cross-border recycling issue will be one of the major topics to be discussed at the conference, the officials added.

In addition to attending the conference, the participants from abroad are also scheduled to visit the EPA headquarters, exchange views with their Taiwan counterparts on the ideal "zero waste" issue and make field trips to a number of recycling sites for used home electrical appliances, motorcycles and automobiles in the following two days, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA HAS `NO RIGHT' TO VETO APEC CANDIDATE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chan Shui-bian said Wednesday that he will appoint Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to attend the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Busan, South Korea next month, and claimed that China has "no right" to veto the representative he chooses.

Chen told South Korean APEC envoy Yun Hai Jung at the Presidential Office that he is keen on attending the summit meeting in person, but in order not to put the host country in a difficult position, he will send Wang instead.

As a member of the APEC forum, Taiwan has the same rights and obligations as other members and that as the leader of Taiwan, he has the right to attend the summit meeting. His exclusion is the biggest regret and most unfair discrimination against the 23 million people of Taiwan, Chen said.

On rhetoric that Taiwan leaders will not attend the summit meeting because there was a tacit agreement or understanding when it was admitted into the regional organization, Chen said this "was totally wrong."

When Taiwan entered APEC, it did not reach any tacit agreements or sign any kind of memorandum of understanding with other members, Chen said, adding that his inability to attend the meeting is purely due to China's persistent obstruction.

The president explained that Taiwan, China and Hong Kong were admitted to the regional organization in 1991 with the assistance of South Korea and that they became formal members in 1992. At the initiative of former U.S. President Bill Clinton in 1993, an APEC informal leadership meeting was inaugurated.
There is no tacit agreement or practice to prevent Taiwan's heads of state from attending the summit meeting, Chen stressed.
For this reason, Chen said, Taiwan protests China's high-handed obstruction and wants to know on what basis Taiwan's leader is shut out of the meeting.
He said the APEC forum belongs to all members, including Taiwan, and not to China, and that Beijing has no right to decide on whether Taiwan's president can attend or not.

Meanwhile, Ma Ying-jeou, Taipei mayor and opposition Kuomintang chairman, said Wednesday that he felt slighted when he learned that Chen will appoint Wang, a former KMT vice chairman, to serve as his envoy at the APEC meeting. Wang earlier said that as a KMT member, he still has to report the matter to the party and Ma.
Asked if felt disrespected upon learning that Chen had appointed Wang without a prior consultation with him, Ma said "of course."
Ma said he had yet to hear the details of the matter and that he will discuss the issue with Wang.

In line with protocol, the 2005 APEC summit organizing committee sent a special envoy to Taipei in July to extend an invitation to Chen. While meeting with the special envoy, Chen said he looked forward to attending the summit meeting in the name of the leader of "Chinese Taipei" -- Taiwan's official APEC designation.

Because of Beijing's opposition, the Republic of China's head of state has been unable to attend previous APEC annual informal leadership meetings and has instead had to name a proxy to attend on his behalf. Lee Yuan-tseh, Nobel laureate and president of the nation's highest research institute, Academia Sinica, has represented Chen over the past few years.

APEC, which is dedicated to promoting free flow of information, trade and investment, groups 21 economies, including Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD MAKE KNOWN STANCE ON OILFIELD DISPUTES: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: The government should make known its stance on the ongoing dispute over exploration in the Chunxiao oil and gas fields in the East China Sea, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday.

Speaking during a regular Executive Yuan meeting, Ma said that since the Chunxiao field is located in one of Taiwan's five major undersea crude fields, the administration should make known Taiwan's stance on the dispute, which presently mainly involves China and Japan.

Ma made a similar call later in the day when he met with a visiting delegation from the U.S. Republican National Committee at Taipei City Hall. He said the Chunxiao field is located in the third Republic of China-claimed undersea field and that Taiwan should not stay silent in the dispute.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) made an announcement in August that disputes over exploration in the Chunxiao field should be tackled through negotiations by all the nations who have an interest in the area.

At issue is the problem of differing sovereignty claims and economic interests, with both China and Japan wishing to develop the area that has potentially large reserves of oil and natural gas, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, rising NT$0.1O7 to close at NT$33.369.
Market turnover reached US$971 million during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.312 and fluctuated between NT$33.3 and NT$33.39.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE SPEAKER URGES PARTIES TO COMPROMISE ON CONTROVERSIAL BILL

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jyn-ping urged the ruling and opposition parties Wednesday to sort out their differences over a bill on a national communications commission (NCC) by compromise.

In order to try and ensure that the NCC bill is passed in two weeks, the speaker said both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) should stop thinking that each has a corner on the truth with regard to the makeup of the NCC.
Wang pointed out that the DPP is in the minority in the legislature and cannot block the bill for ever.

The KMT and PFP should not refuse to budge on the sticking point in the bill -- the actual members of the NCC -- adding that the fracas between the two sides in the legislature the previous day only puts the country to shame.

The president was referring a brawl between rival lawmakers in the legislative chamber when DPP lawmakers scrambled to occupy the speaker's podium and grabbed his gavel in an attempt to prevent him putting the bill to a vote, which led to a fistfight with opposition lawmakers that left two people injured.

The speaker defended his decision of not calling in the sergeant-at-arms to restore order in the chamber, claiming that the legislature can "settle its own disputes" and it would disgrace the legislature to pass a bill with the help of the sergeant-at-arms.

At the center of the dispute is the method to be used to name the NCC members. The opposition wants them named by political parties in proportion to the number of seats each holds in the legislature, while the DPP insists that the Executive Yuan should have the right to name them.
In order to prevent the KMT and PFP from steamrolling the bill through, the DPP occupied the speaker's podium Sept. 27 to paralyze the session, a move it repeated Tuesday.
The legislature is set to act again on the bill Oct. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 95 points to close at 6,004, with 34,386 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 93 points to end at 6,006, with 3,936 contracts traded, while December futures lost 93 points to finish at 6,006, with 44 contracts traded.
March futures moved down 86 points to close at 6,010, with five contracts traded. June futures slid 129 points to close at 5,985 with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,099 for October, 6,099 for November, 6,099 for December, 6,096 for March and 6,114 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
October TE futures moved down 7.6 points to close at 250, with 7,727 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 7.5 points to close at 250.2, with 881 contract transactions.
December TE futures gave up 6.35 points to close at 250.8, with two contracts traded. March TE futures lost 8.9 points to close at 249.05, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

October TF futures lost 2.8 points to close at 891.2, with 304 contract transactions, while November TF futures moved down two points to close at 891.2, with 304 contracts changing hands. December TF futures moved down 1.4 points to close at 891, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 79.19 points to close at 5,987.4.
The bourse opened at 6,042.15 and fluctuated between 6,045.73 and 5,987.4 during trading. A total of 3.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$72.66 billion (US$2.17 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile shares and plastics and chemical shares both moving up at 0.6 percent.

Five other stocks lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares losing the most at 2.2 percent, followed by construction shares at 1.8 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.7 percent, cement issues at 0.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent and paper and pulp stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 733 to 223, with 140 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Aid Fails to Reach Thousands in Pakistan Quake Zone
Four days after an earthquake devastated northern Pakistan, pelting hail and rain, along with a shortage of helicopters, prevented rescuers from reaching thousands of survivors still trapped in isolated Himalayan villages on Tuesday, Pakistani officials said.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Apple Booms, but iPod Disappoints
Apple Computer Inc. said its quarterly profit more than quadrupled on a 57% increase in revenue, but sales of the company's iPod portable music players weren't strong enough to satisfy some investors, and Apple shares fell sharply in after-hours trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE EXPERT UNVEILS DRAFT OF 'JAPAN-TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT'
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Japanese expert unveiled Wednesday a draft law governing relations between Japan and Taiwan that is aimed at strengthening friendship and exchanges between both countries in the absence of official ties.

Kazuo Asano, a professor at Heisei International University, said the legislation is intended to be the Japanese equivalent of the Taiwan Relations Act enacted by the United States in 1979 following the severance of diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Asano said it is necessary for Japan to review its relations with Taiwan 33 years after diplomatic ties were cut and that he hopes the bill can be passed during the remaining one-year tenure of Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi.
According to the draft, the objective of the legislation is to bring stability and prosperity to the Asia-Pacific region and to develop trade and cultural exchanges between Japan and Taiwan.
Taiwanese will continue to enjoy the rights and protection they are entitled to under Japanese law as long as they do not violate the public interests of Japan, the draft states.
It says the Japanese government can provide the government of Taiwan with the necessary intelligence to protect peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

Affairs concerning Japan and Taiwan will be dealt with according to the agreement between the Tokyo-based Interchange Association and the Taipei-based East Asia Relations Commission, which includes the protection of the property and physical safety of Japanese and Taiwanese as well as matters related to economic, trade, tourism, academic, cultural and sports exchanges between both countries, the draft stipulates.
It says the Japanese government can grant staff of the East Asia Relations Commission privileges and immunities equal to those enjoyed by foreign diplomats in Japan.

Commenting on the draft law, ROC representative to Japan Koh Se-kai said its content is very solid and practical and that the law will be helpful in establishing a legal basis for Taiwan-Japan relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS WANT CHINA STEEL CHAIRMAN TO RETURN BONUS STOCK

TEXT.P: Ninety-four legislators of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union issued a statement Wednesday demanding that Lin Wen-yuan, chairman of China Steel Corp., return his bonus stock valued at NT$44 million (US$1.32 million) to the national coffers.

The statement said that Lin is leading China Steel as a representative of the government, which owns 23.5 percent of the privatized company, and that he should voluntarily return the bonus stock, totaling 1.5 million shares, to the national treasury.
Lin has worked as chairman of China Steel since December 2002 and receives an annual salary of about NT$8 million.

The pan-green lawmakers said in their statement that in line with President Chen Shui-bian's declaration of a reform plan in a Double Ten National Day address, the conduct of government officials and representatives should be held to above-normal moral standards.
They demanded that the government send Lin a letter within 10 days demanding the return of the windfall to the national treasury.
In a rebuttal in his own defense, Lin said he saw nothing wrong in accepting the bonus stock because, as CEO of China Steel, he was merely enjoying the same treatment as his three predecessors.

He insisted that he has always been law-abiding in his 20-year career as a public servant. However, he added that he is willing to relinquish the bonus stock if the Ministry of Finance wants it returned to the national coffers.

In response to the demand by the pan-green legislators, Cabinet Secretary-General and spokesman Cho Jung-tai said the matter will be handled by the Finance Ministry, which will work out a solution within 10 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTS INDICTED FOR SELLING PASSPORTS TO ILLEGAL CHINESE IMMIGRANTS
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: One woman and two men were indicted Wednesday for selling Taiwan passports to illegal Chinese immigrants to help them enter Canada.

Prosecutors said Cheng Mei-hua was the mastermind behind the fraud scheme. Cheng, working with Weng Tien-ling and his sister Weng Su-emi, and another man, identified as Hsi Tien-lin, used a steak house run by the Wengs in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, as a facade to solicit staff or patrons willing to supply passports.

The foursome offered those who complied with their wishes the chance to tour Southeast Asia, where they met with illegal Chinese immigrants who would familiarize themselves with the backgrounds of the Taiwanese travelers in order that they would not arouse suspicion on the part of Canadian customs authorities.
The Hualien Prosecutors' Office said the suspects used the same method to help illegal Chinese in Vietnam and Malaysia to enter Canada three times between September 2004 and January 2005.
The prosecutors indicted Hsi and the two Wengs and issued an arrest warrant for Cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER URGES WAR ON GOVERNMENT DEFICIT

TEXT.P: Legislator Lai Shin-yuan of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) urged a war Wednesday on the government deficit, but a government agency dismissed the worries about leaving debts to future generations, saying that the nation's financial situation has continued to improve.

Lai, who called a press conference to outline her speculation that 2008 may be the "doom" year of the nation's public debts, said that accumulated government debts will reach more than NT$3.9 trillion (US$117.11 billion) this year, near the public debt ceiling under the law.
The economic researcher-turned-legislator said that for every NT$100 the government appropriates, it has to use NT$15 to pay debts, and even so, it will take 65 years to clear all debts.

She said that the government has listed the deficit for next fiscal year as NT$195.7 billion and claimed that if the Legislative Yuan approves it, then the accumulated debts will reach NT$3.93 trillion, approaching the debt ceiling of 40 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP), or around NT$4 trillion, stipulated under the public debt law.
She noted that the government has appropriated NT$192 billion this year to pay public debts -- with NT$60 billion paying for the principle and NT$132 billion paying for the interest.

If the trend continues, then "in 2008, the government will reach the legal ceiling of the debts, " Lai said, adding that unless the government resorts to accounting techniques to conceal debts or the lawmakers agree to raise the debt ceiling, the government will be unable to appropriate a legal budget for 2008.

In addition, judging from the financial shortfall of the government's budget and debt payments over the past five years, the government can only pay NT$56.6 billion on the principle and interest a year, but has incurred an additional NT$200 billion in debts on average, Lai said.
"The government is paying its debts by raising more debts, " she claimed.

She said that if the government can achieve a fiscal balance next year, and pay debts at a speed of NT$56 billion a year, then it still "will take 56 years to clear all debts." She expressed worry for leaving huge debts to future generations.

Lai said that ending the budget deficit and not leaving huge debts to future generations are the responsibilities of legislators irrespective of their party affiliation and she expressed hope that they will rigorously review the government's budget and work toward budgetary balance, starting this year.

However, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) pointed out that as of the end of this year, the outstanding debts will reach NT$3.9367 trillion, or 37.3 percent of the GDP on average over the past three years, well within the bounds of 40 percent.
In addition, the debts are used for public construction and there is no question of leaving the debts for future generations, DGBAS officials said.

They said that the government attaches great importance to improving the nation's financial situation, saying that according to a financial reform project approved by the Executive Yuan in April 2003, the reforms goals included raising the total tax revenues as a percentage of the GDP by 1 percent every two years, controlling expenditure to zero growth and reaching a fiscal balance of revenues and expenditures in between five and 10 years.
Related agencies are also promoting short-, middle- and long-term thrift measures, they added.

They stressed that compared with other nations, the proportion of Taiwan's outstanding debts to the GDP, currently at 35.9 percent, is lower than France' 58.7 percent, Britain's 48.9 percent and Japan's 154.7 percent, showing that Taiwan is not a high-debt country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESCUE TEAM NOT ALLOWED TO FLY FROM BANGKOK TO PAKISTAN

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Wednesday that they are checking why a Taiwan search and rescue team offering to help in the aftermath of the massive earthquake in South Asia were told not to head to Pakistan.

Thirty-eight members of the International Headquarters S.A.R. Taiwan, who had flown to Bangkok to prepare to transfer to Pakistan, returned home earlier in the day after they were told not to enter the disaster area because traffic was disrupted by rainy weather.

According to MOFA spokesman Michel Lu, the officials from the Pakistan embassy in Thailand, who had promised to assist with the members' trip, did not show up, and Pakistani authorities only had airlines workers pass the message to the team members.

Lu said the ministry is investigating why another 15-member rescue team from Taiwan was able to reach Pakistan on the same flight while members of the International Headquarters S.A.R. Taiwan were blocked.
A MOFA official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said problems relating to their visa applications could be the reason why they could not board the plane.
The Pakistani government reportedly had promised to grant the team members visas upon arrival but apparently changed its mind.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SECTOR GIVING HELPING HAND TO TEXTILE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The government sector has swung into full gear to help Taiwan's textile industry break into Central America, where experts said it stands a good chance of reaping handsome profits, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.

The MOEA, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will each set up an ad hoc group by the end of this month to serve that end, according to officials at the MOEA's Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC).

IDIC Director-General Ou Chia-juey said that some Taiwan companies have shown strong willingness to invest in Central America, which is widely viewed as especially suitable for Taiwan textile and garment makers after the CAFTA-DR (Central American Free Trade Agreement-Dominican Republic) takes effect.

The domestic industry has been hit by the abolishment of a global quota system at the beginning of this year, with its exports in the first nine months of this year falling by 6.2 percent year on year to US$8.89 billion.

The CAFTA-DR is a comprehensive trade pact that will immediately eliminate tariffs on more than 80 percent of U.S. exports of consumer and industrial products. Eighty percent of CAFTA-DR exports already enter the United States duty free under the Caribbean Basin Initiative.
Central America is also where many of Taiwan's diplomatic partners are located.

At present, Nicaragua has attracted most investment from Taiwan's textile industry, which has swelled to US$170 million and provides jobs for nearly 30,000 employees, MOEA statistics show. Honduras is the second-largest destination, drawing US$40.88 million in Taiwan capital and providing 5,045 jobs. Taiwan companies have channelled in US$38.7 million and employ 7,402 workers in El Salvador.
Taiwan investment has also gone to Guatemala, Belize, the Dominican Republic and Haiti, the same tallies show.
The task force teams to be set up by the MOEA and the CEPD will be devoted to studying investment climates in Central American countries and Taiwan investment cases, respectively.

The MOFA will establish "investment service groups " in Central American nations that will be headed by Republic of China ambassadors in their host countries. The cooperation and Development Fund under the MOFA will also help Taiwan companies with personnel training.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG SAYS HE WILL TALK TO MA IF CHOSEN AS PRESIDENT'S APEC REP

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that he will talk to Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou regarding the possibility of President Chen Shui-bian sending Wang to this year's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum summit as his envoy.

Wang made the remarks while answering questions from reporters on his chances of serving as President Chen's envoy at the APEC summit slated for mid-November in Busan, South Korea, after Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang said that President Chen had told a South Korean envoy earlier the same day of his intentions.

Huang said that President Chen has asked the envoy to relay his wish to South Korean President Roh Woo-hyun. Roh first sent an envoy to extend an invitation to Chen in July, with Chen replying that he hoped that he could take part in the summit himself.

Admitting that he would only be able to take part in the summit after President Chen makes a formal decision, Wang said that he would undoubtedly report to Ma when everything is cleared. "November is still some way off," he said.

"I believe that Ma will take the nation's overall interest into consideration while weighing the issue, " Wang said, adding, "I will personally elaborate on the issue to Ma when it has fully been decided that I will represent the president at the APEC summit."

According to Wang's aides, the issue regarding Wang's representation as Chen's special envoy at the APEC leadership meeting will be widely assessed from both international and domestic perspectives, which will include Washington's and Beijing's viewpoints and the political atmosphere at home.
Media reports said that Ma was uncomfortable about not having been notified of the president's consideration of Wang.
The head of the Legislative Yuan is a KMT heavyweight, who competed against Ma, also Taipei mayor, in the party's historic direct vote for KMT chairman in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME CHINESE MEDICINES BEING CUT WITH DRUGS: CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation said Wednesday that 27 percent of Chinese medicines it had tested contain pharmaceutical elements that may cause health problems over the long term.
The foundation said of the 122 Chinese medicines it had tested, which are considered more organic and thus less harmful to patients, 33 had foreign chemicals added.

Out of 79 samples that consumers asked the foundation to test for heavy metals, four contained more than 100 ppm (parts per million) of mercury, the safety limit set by the Department of Health. Lead is an accumulative poison.
Most of the Chinese medicines found to contain questionable levels of drugs were brought in to Taiwan from abroad or sold at local Chinese medicine shops, according to the foundation.

More and more cases of "doctored" Chinese medicines have been discovered in prescriptions from traditional medicine shops, an indication that some manufacturers have been trying to boost the efficacy of their products by illegally adding drugs to them.

The medicines claiming to be effective for curing accumulations of uric acid -- the cause of gout, pain killers and rheumatism fighting compounds are most likely to contain drugs, followed by those for colds, coughs and nasal inflammations, the foundation said.
Drugs found in Chinese medicines include caffeine, diuretics, pain killers and antipyretics -- all illegally added to boost the effectiveness of the Chinese medicines, the foundation said.

The foundation said consumers who are interested in having their Chinese medicines tested can send samples to its Taipei headquarters. Application forms can be downloaded from the foundation's Chinese-language Web site at www.consumers.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP MAKES VEILED THREAT TO KMT OVER STANCE ON ARMS BILL

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) renewed a thinly veiled threat Wednesday that if its ally, the Kuomintang (KMT) , relents in its opposition to the arms procurement bill, it will not get the PFP's help in blocking the party assets bill in the legislature aimed at depriving the KMT of its "improperly obtained" assets.

Sun Ta-chien, a whip of the PFP legislative caucus, reiterated the PFP stand after the Cabinet approved the party assets bill, which will soon be introduced in the legislature by the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Sun said the PFP caucus has also drafted its own version of the party assets bill but will refrain from introducing it as long as the KMT caucus does not let the arms procurement bill get out of the Procedure Committee for a vote in the Legislative Yuan meeting.
He said he is confident that the KMT and the PFP are equally resolute in their positions regarding the two bills and will work hand in hand to block them from being passed.
The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP enjoys a slim majority in the 225-seat legislature, but the KMT caucus must depend on the support of the 34 PFP legislators to maintain this advantage.
The KMT claimed Wednesday that the party assets bill approved by the Cabinet is nothing but a tool of the DPP government to purge civic groups of their assets and is "clearly unconstitutional."

The arms procurement bill is requesting a special budget of NT$610.8 billion to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries from the United States.

However, opposition legislators have blocked the bill 32 times in Procedure Committee meetings on the grounds that the cost is too high and that the money should come out of a normal budget rather than a special one.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE DEFENDS APPOINTMENT OF SPEAKER AS APEC ENVOY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was following a set protocol in naming Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng as his proxy to attend this year's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, his chief of staff said Wednesday.

Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun was responding to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's remark's that he felt disrespected by the Presidential Office's decision to appoint Wang as Chen's proxy at the 2005 APEC summit to be held in the second-largest South Korean city of Busan in November. Wang is a KMT stalwart who once served as a KMT vice chairman.

President Chen told South Korean APEC envoy Yun Hai Jung earlier in the day that if he is still barred from attending the upcoming APEC summit in person, he intends to appoint Wang to attend on his behalf.
According to Yu, President Chen had long sought Wang's consent to serve as his proxy at the Busan APEC summit. Yu said he believes that Wang will brief Ma on the matter later.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that admit both Taiwan and China. Because of China's opposition, Taiwan's president has been barred from attending the annual APEC summit and has had to name a surrogate to attend on his behalf.

In the past few years, Chen appointed Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, to be his envoy to the annual APEC informal leadership meeting. This time around, Lee politely rejected Chen's invitation to serve as his envoy.
Wang said earlier in the day that he will talk with Ma about the APEC summit attendance when he has the chance.
In his view, Wang said this is just the beginning. "When the time is ripe, the Presidential Office will also talk with the KMT headquarters over the issue," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CKS AIRPORT PASSENGER VOLUME RANKS 14TH IN ASIA-PACIFIC

TEXT.P: Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, ranked 14th among the 120 major international airports in the Asia-Pacific region in terms of passenger volume in 2004, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Wednesday.
The airport's 2004 ranking was up two notches from its year-earlier level, MOTC officials said, adding that its passenger volume posted a roughly 30 percent year-on-year growth.
Taiwan's other international airport -- Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan -- ranked 33rd in terms of its passenger volume last year, down four notches from its 2003 ranking.

According to MOTC tallies, passenger volumes reached 20.08 million at CKS Airport in 2004, up 29.5 percent from the year-earlier level. The growth rate was the fifth-highest among the 120 major Asia-Pacific international airports studied.
In comparison, Kaohsiung International Airport only registered a passenger volume of 7.59 million, marking a 14.2 percent year-on-year growth for the 33rd ranking.

Japan's Haneda International Airport continued to top the list in terms of passenger volume in 2004, followed by Thailand's Bangkok Airport, the New Hong Kong International Airport, China's Beijing Airport, and Japan's Narita Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPANESE ACTIVISTS PROTEST IN TOKYO OVER TEXTBOOK REFERENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese and Japanese political activists protested in front of the Japanese Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology Wednesday over the listing of Taiwan as China's territory in some Japanese high school textbooks.

The demonstration was jointly organized by several Taiwanese and Japanese groups, including the Japanese chapter of the Taiwan Solidarity Union and the Taiwan Research Forum, a Japanese academic society.
Hideki Nagayama, a resident of the Taiwan Research Forum, said the Japanese ministry of education should not have approved the publication of the textbooks.

Lin Chien-liang, editor in chief of the Voice of Taiwan magazine in Taiwan, said the Japanese ministry should demand the publishers of the textbooks correct the mistake because Taiwan is an independent country, not China's territory.
The demonstrators ended their protest peacefully after a Japanese education ministry official accepted their petition letter and promised to pass it to his superior.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT FORUM TO BE HELD IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A forum aimed at introducing Taiwan's investment environment and financial reforms is scheduled to take place at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel in New York Oct. 13-14, organizers said Wednesday.
The seminar, dubbed "Taiwan: the Gateway to the Region," is being organized by Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC, EII.
A Taiwan delegation, composed of government officials, bankers and business executives, will travel to New York to attend the seminar.

Kong Jaw-sheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission, will brief prospective foreign investors on Taiwan's ongoing second phase of financial reforms and its general investment environment and incentives for foreign investors.

Senior executives of nearly 20 top-notch Taiwan high-tech companies, telecommunications conglomerates and financial holding groups will introduce their corporations' development prospects to attract foreign investors during the two-day seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CALLS FOR NEW NATIONAL IDENTITY THROUGH DEEPENING OF DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he is hopeful that Taiwan can forge a new national identity through the deepening and consolidation of its young democracy.
Chen made the appeal in the preface of a new book, "Green Era, " published the same day on Taiwan's democratic movement from 1975 through 2000.
Recalling Taiwan's evolution from authoritarian rule to a prosperous democracy, Chen said he is confident that Taiwan can "have its day in the sun."

"The process of Taiwan's democratization is a moving and successful story. I'm convinced that the people of Taiwan will be able to forge a new common national identity through deepening and consolidating its democratic system," Chen wrote.

More than 100 politicians of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , including Premier Frank Hsieh, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun attended the book's presentation ceremony at the Red House Theater in downtown Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR MEETS WITH JIA CHIEF

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan met with Japanese Interchange Association Masaji Takahashih Wednesday for wide-ranging talks.

Yeh told Takahashih, who is currently on a visit to Taiwan, that Kaohsiung has completed many urban renewal projects in recent years. The city is also undertaking many new infrastructure construction projects, including a mass rapid transit system, in preparation for the 2009 World Games.

Noting that she is determined to develop Kaohsiung into a clean, beautiful, convenient, safe and secure city based on its current foundation, Yeh said she hopes more Japanese citizens can make sightseeing trips to the southern Taiwan port city.

For his part, Takahashih said Taiwan and Japan are good old friends. Japan's granting of visa-free privileges for short-term Taiwan visitors is a sign of cordial ties between the two countries, he said, adding that he is willing to help promote Kaohsiung as a good tourist destination for Japanese citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCTOBER 13 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, October 13:

09:10, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will deliver a keynote speech at the opening of a seminar on old challenges and new developments in Asia-Pacific security at Grand Formosa Regent Hotel.
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a groundbreaking ceremony for a library in Hsikou, Chiayi County.
11:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will meet with a group of Mongolian officials who are attending an advanced study program in Taipei at the Executive Yuan.
14:00, Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao will host a news conference on the participation in a book fair in Frankfurt, Germany.
19:20, Vice President Annette Lu will deliver a speech at the opening of a forum on Asian women's political participation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SUPPORTS WANG'S ATTENDANCE AT APEC AS PRESIDENT'S ENVOY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou supports Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng's attendance at this year's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said Wednesday.

Cheng quoted Ma, who is also mayor of Taipei, as saying that he would be pleased to see Wang smoothly attend the 2005 APEC summit meeting to be held in Busan, South Korea in November as President Chen's proxy.
Ma was also quoted as having said that the KMT would offer all necessary assistance to Wang.
Cheng said Ma will meet with Wang later to exchange views on this matter.
President Chen said earlier in the day that if he is still barred from attending the 2005 APEC summit, he would name Wang to attend the meeting on his behalf.
Because of Beijing's obstinate opposition, Taiwan's president has been barred from attending the annual APEC summit in person and has to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 13, or the 11th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
A.D. 54: Claudius I, 64, Roman emperor and historian, dies after supposedly consuming poisoned mushrooms dished up by his fourth wife, his niece Agrippina. Shortly before his death, Claudius had agreed to acknowledge Nero, Agrippina's son from a former marriage, as his heir instead of his natural son, Britannicus.
1792: U.S. President George Washington lays the foundation stone of the White House.
1812: British forces under Sir Isaac Brock defeat the Americans at the battle of Queenston Heights, helping to put an end to the U.S. attempt to invade Canada.
1884: Greenwich, England, is adopted as the universal meridian from which standard times throughout the world are calculated.
1913: Representatives from China, Britain and Tibet attend a meeting held in Simla, India, to discuss various problems concerning Tibet.
1923: Ankara becomes the capital of Turkey.
1925: Margaret Thatcher, British Conservative politician and prime minister from 1979 to 1990, is born. Her administration was marked by anti-inflationary measures, a brief war in the Falkland Islands (1982), and the passage of a poll tax.
1939: Adolf Hitler tries without success to persuade U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt to mediate peace between Germany, France and Britain.
1943: Italy declares war on Germany, its former Axis partner.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Canton.
1960: The Institute of History and Philology of the Academia Sinica begins excavations at dwellings of the Yin people in Anyang County, Hunan Province, once the capital of the dynasty before 1200 B.C.
1964: Three Soviet cosmonauts operating Voshkod, the world's first multi-seat spacecraft, land safely after a 24-hour journey.
1968: Liu Shao-chi, state chairman of Communist China, is purged at the 12th Plenum of the 8th Chinese Communist Party Central Committee held in Beijing.
1970: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severance of diplomatic relations with Canada.
1974: U.S. Senator Hiram Leong Fong of Hawaii arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1980: President Pieter W. Botha of South Africa is presented with the Key to the City of Taipei by Mayor Lee Teng-hui upon arrival for a state visit.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui presents a Key to Taipei to Mayor Leon Amon of the Ivory Coast's Dimbokro City.
1988: The Shroud of Turin, for centuries regarded as the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, is shown by carbon-dating tests to date from between 1260 and 1390 in the Middle Ages, a period rife with forgeries.
1993: The United Nations Security Council decides to resume an oil-and-arms embargo against Haiti after Haitian military leaders fail to follow an agreement to allow President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to return to office and restore a democratic government.
1995: Joseph Rotblat, the nuclear physicist who devoted his life to trying to ban the bomb he helped create, wins the 1995 Nobel Peace Prize.
1995: France rejects appeals to abandon nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
1998: Daniel Chee Tsui, professor at Princeton University and a member of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, becomes one of the three co-winners of the 1998 Nobel Prize for physics.
1999: A Jordanian Royal Air Force transport plane airlifts 14,600 kilograms of relief goods to Taipei to help surviving victims of the devastating earthquake that rocked Taiwan on Sept. 21.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian hails the decision to grant the 2000 Nobel Prize in literature to self-exiled mainland Chinese writer Gao Xingjian, saying that the honor marks Gao's greatest achievement.
2001: The rampancy of counterfeit bank notes in circulation in Taiwan prompts the Central Bank of China (CBC) to add two items on its Web site's home page to teach the public the different ways to distinguish fake bills from real ones.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is plain, and yet not unattractive; it is simple, and yet full of grace; it is easy, and yet methodical."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SHOWING GOODWILL TO CHINA BY NAMING WANG FOR APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was showing goodwill toward China when he decided to appoint Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng as his special envoy to the upcoming APEC informal leaders' summit in South Korea, a ranking official said Thursday.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Wang's appointment also creates a chance to "say hello" to China's top leader, Hu Jintao, in addition to serving as a "starting point" for domestic reconciliation.
"For China, this should be goodwill (from Taiwan) that is acceptable," Wu said.
Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou told Wang the party would like to help him complete his mission as the president's APEC envoy.
The KMT is ready to use its influence to persuade China to help Wang, a key KMT member, to attend the APEC summit in Busan, South Kora, Ma said.
Ma has also asked KMT think tanks to prepare all background information for Wang concerning the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
Wang said he is "grateful for" Ma's decision to help him, a decision that he believes was made for the sake of the nation's overall interests.
Wang said that when he told Ma's predecessor, Lien Chan, who now serves as honorary chairman of the KMT, of the president's decision, Lien expressed that he was happy to hear about it.

Lien told Wang that it would be "very significant" for him to represent the people of Taiwan at the APEC summit in his capacity as the president of the Legislative Yuan, the nation's highest lawmaking body.

Wang said he is not sure whether China will try to obstruct him from participating in the meeting. He added that if he is able to represent Chen at the summit, he would like to "not only shake hands with Hu, but also exchange views with him."

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CHIEF TAKES UP CHALLENGE TO DEBATE 2ND-PHASE FINANCIAL REFORM

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng accepted opposition lawmakers' challenge Thursday to debate the government's second-phase financial reform program.
In reply to independent Legislator Chiu Yi's challenge in the legislature, Hu said he would gladly accept it "at any time you choose, the sooner the better."
Hu said he is confident that the number of publicly owned banks can be halved by the end of the year, and "if not, I am willing to take the responsibility."

In response, Chiu asked which three banks would be "reduced" in the halving process, to which Hu replied that he was not at liberty to answer as doing so would involve divulging information that would put him in violation of the stock trading law.

Meanwhile, Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker Tsai Chi-fang said President Chen Shui-bian's second-phase financial reform program is aimed at clearing up irregularities from the previous government.
The opposition allegation that the DPP government is trying to benefit big conglomerates by selling public banks is not fair, Tsai said.
If public banks are being sold at unreasonable prices, private bankers will not buy them, so "we cannot say the program is aimed at benefiting conglomerates," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA FEARS FOR PASSAGE OF TAIWAN AFFAIRS ACT BY CANADA PARLIAMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Toronto, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By C.Y. Chang and P.C.tang)

TEXT.P: Beijing has great fear that the Canadian Parliament will pass a "Taiwan Affairs Act" to provide a better framework for further improvement of relationship between the people of Canada and the people of Taiwan.
Chinese Ambassador to Canada Lu Shumin warned Wednesday the Canadian Parliament against passing a Taiwan Affairs Act, saying that doing so would seriously affect relations between China and Canada.

Addressing a luncheon at the Canadian National Press Club, the envoy said that a change in Canada's "one China" policy would certainly undermine relations between the two countries as their diplomatic relationship is based on a consensus on the Taiwan issue. Canada switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1970.

The Canadian Parliament has been discussing passing a Taiwan Affairs Act to provide a better framework for further economic, trade and cultural exchanges and other initiatives between the people of Canada and the people of Taiwan.

Canadian Member of Parliament Jim Abbott put forward a few months ago Bill C-357 in the House of Commons, requesting that the legislature enact a Taiwan Affairs Act to strengthen the relations between Canada and Taiwan.
According to the lawmaker, enactment of the bill would provide a statutory framework for economic, trade, cultural and other initiatives between the people of the two countries.

The Canadian government is also currently trying to further promote its trade relations with China as leverage in its trade dealings with the United States, which has imposed what Ottawa considers unfair import tariffs on Canadian cork products.

According to Lu, China, with a huge market of 1.3 billion people and a rapidly growing economy, is likely to import ever greater amounts of construction raw materials, including cork goods, from Canada in the coming years.

Statistics released by Chinese customs authorities show that two-way trade between Canada and China amounted to US$7 billion in 2000, representing a 45-percent increase over the 1999 level. The figure mushroomed to US$15.5 billion for 2004.

Nevertheless, the human rights issue, including Beijing's repression of the Falun Gong, as well as several cases of Chinese industrial espionage in Canada in recent years have presented obstacles on the path to further development of relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COUNTRY CAN MEDDLE IN PRESIDENT'S RIGHT TO APPOINT APEC REP: MOFA

TEXT.P: Appointing a special envoy to the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit is the exclusive right of the Republic of China president and cannot be meddled in by any other country, Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen said Thursday.

Chen made the statement in reply to Kuomintang Legislator John Chiang's question as to whether the government has a back-up plan to assigning Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng as the president's envoy to the APEC summit in South Korea.

Chiang said the selection of Wang could be a problem if any of the APEC members offer a different interpretation of the memorandum of understanding Taiwan signed in 1992 for joining APEC. He noted that former Vice President Lee Yuan-zu had been prevented from attending an APEC summit in the past because of this.
Chen responded by saying that attending the summit is the right of every member and that no member can be deprived of this right by any other member.
"If President Chen Shui-bian himself cannot attend, appointing someone to represent him is his right which cannot be meddled in, " the minister said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW POLICY ON FOREIGN CAREGIVER EMPLOYMENT SET TO START 2006

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairman Lee Ying-yuan affirmed Thursday the government's plan to implement a new policy on the employment of foreign caregivers from Jan. 1, 2006.

Under the new policy, Taiwan families which intend to hire foreign caregivers to take care of sick or elderly family members will have to first pass an assessment by medical institutions proving that they require 24-hour care.

Social service authorities will then help these families look for local workers who are willing to accept the jobs. A family will only be permitted to hire a foreign worker if no local worker can be found to fill the position.

Delivering a report on the policy to the legislature, Lee said the CLA is planning to provide a subsidy of NT$5,000 to NT$10,000 to families hiring local caregivers, who are more expensive than foreign workers.
According to Lee, there are approximately 330,000 elderly people who need long-term care in Taiwan, 130,000 of whom require care around the clock.
Lee noted that there are currently some 130,000 foreign caregivers in Taiwan, and he predicted that the number will increase by 5,000 to 10,000 in the near future.
However, opposition Kuomintang Legislators Hou Tsai-feng and Yang Li-huan called the policy poorly planned.
They questioned the feasibility of the policy, saying the CLA did not even make an estimate as to how much will be needed to fund it and how many local caregivers will benefit from it.
