DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 27.29 points to close at 5,960.11.
The bourse opened at 5,970.1 and fluctuated between 5,974.03 and 5,928.86 during trading. A total of 2.78 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$69.76 billion (US$2.08 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up the most at 0.9 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks and paper and pulp issues, both at 0.3 percent.

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.8 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 619 to 322, with 162 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTRY STUDYING ISSUE OF CSC CHAIRMAN'S BONUS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that the Ministry of Finance is studying whether China Steel Corp. Chairman Lee Wen-yuan has violated any laws in accepting a huge bonus in company stocks.
If it is determined that he has violated the law, the bonus will have to be returned, the premier added.
In the event that it is determined that acceptance of the bonus was inappropriate even though no law was broken, then the law and relevant regulations will have to be amended, Hsieh further said.

Also under study, according to Hsieh, are the questions of how much of the bonus should be returned, and if Lin is to return all or part of the bonus, should his predecessors also be required to return the bonuses that they had received.

Lin's company stocks bonus worth about NT$44 million has become a heated topic of discussion in the country as a large group of "pan-green camp" lawmakers signed a motion Wednesday demanding that Lin give up his bonus stocks and return them to the national coffers.

Chairman Su Tseng-chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that even though Lin is not a DPP member, he is a member of the ruling team and must be judged by a high moral standard and subject to relevant laws and regulations.

Cheng Wen-tsan, director of the DPP Department of Culture and Information, noted that compensation packages for government appointed leaders at state-run enterprises, government-invested businesses and government-subsidized non-profit organizations must be "reasonable and legal" and acceptable to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO PAVE WAY FOR WANG'S ATTENDANCE AT APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou urged the government Thursday to pave the wave for Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng's attendance on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian at this year's informal APEC leadership summit.

Ma said that he phoned Wang earlier the same day to express his support for Wang's participation as Chen's special envoy at the summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) slated for Nov. 18-19 in Busan, South Korea.

Stating that KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang and the party's think tanks will assist Wang in making the necessary preparations to take part in the APEC summit, Ma urged the government to help facilitate Wang's trip to Busan. Chiang has participated in APEC summit meetings as the president's envoy several times in the past.
Although South Korea has expressed agreement with the idea of having Wang attend on Chen's behalf, Ma said that the government still needs to work to remove other hurdles.

Ma beat Wang to become the KMT's chairman in a historic direct election for the party's top post in July. Both Ma, who is also Taipei mayor, and Wang were vice chairmen of the main opposition party at the time of the election. Wang did no accept Ma's invitation to serve as his deputy after Ma took the KMT's helm.

President Chen informed Wang in August of his intention of dispatching Wang as his envoy to take part in the APEC leadership meeting, but Wang did not notify Ma of the matter. Media reports said a day earlier that Ma was uncomfortable about not having been told about the president's consideration of Wang.

According to Wang's aides, his participation in the APEC summit as the president's envoy will be broadly evaluated from international and domestic viewpoints, including Washington's and Beijing's reactions and the domestic political atmosphere.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: House of Deputies voting over electoral reforms.
The House of Deputies voted over a series of proposals for electoral reforms Wednesday. The ruling coalition won over most of duels against the opposition, but was defeated in an amendment it proposed to increase the female quota in the parliament to not less than 30 percent. Premier Silvio Berlusconi is optimistic over the reforms, while the opposition criticized them as back to the last century. The duel between the ruling and opposition camps over the controversial eletoral reform is extending.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO DPP LAWMAKERS CLAIM INNOCENCE IN HEALTH INSURANCE SCAM

TEXT.P: Two ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators who also run hospitals claimed Thursday that they were not involved in reported health insurance frauds, and one of them pledged to resign if he is found to have taken any illicit money from the Bureau of National Health Insurance.

Both Lin Chin-hsing and Chiu Yung-jen said their hospitals might have been used as a tool to swindle insurance companies by people who have feigned to be in-patients. They claimed that they themselves were "victims" in the scams.

According to media reports, prosecutors have found that suspect Wen Tsung-ming and his 31-member family bought insurance policies before colluding with five hospitals in Tainan and Kaohisung, getting documents "proving" they were hospitalized so they could claim money from insurance companies while the hospitals claimed fees from the Bureau of National Health Insurance.
The Wens have been doing this over the past 10 years, reaping a total of NT$30 million in illicit profits, according to a newspaper report.

The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) demanded that the bureau get to the bottom of the situation, and if the two DPP legislators' hospitals were found to have claimed insurance money from the bureau by cheating, it should cancel contracts with them and turn them over to prosecutors.

Caucus deputy secretary-general Pan Wei-kang said the Yung-jen Hospital owned by Chiu was accused of swindling the Bureau of National Health Insurance of money with false accounts last month; now this new scandal is implicating his hospital.
If the cheating is found to be true, then the "cheating lawmaker" should be charged according to law, she said.
Chiu claimed that he never cheated the bureau of any money and that he is a victim in the reported scam. If he had violated any law, he said, he would immediately quit as a lawmaker.
He said he has handed all hospital records about the Wen family to investigators, hoping they will clear his name soon.
Lin said his hospital is well managed and he was "purely out of luck" to have been implicated in the fraud. Lin claimed he has never cheated a cent from the Bureau of National Health Insurance.

Lin noted that when the prosecution authorities searched his hospital Wednesday, only one of the 51 in-patients were not on the hospital grounds, indicating that the hospital was managed as it should be.
As to Wen's testimony that he had been Lin's assistant at the Legislative Yuan, Lin said none of the 31 members in the Wen family had been his legislative assistant.

The DPP legislative caucus, which has been reeling from a number of scandals involving the ruling camp, asserted that any member found to have broken the law to make illicit profits would be kicked out of the caucus.
William C.T. Lai, caucus secretary-general, called for calm while the nation waits for the investigation results. "We support an intensive investigation into alleged violations of the law," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD HAS NO INTENTION OF BECOMING DEFENSE FORCE: CGA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's coast guard has no intention of becoming a " second naval force" during wartime nor is such a move supported by law, regardless of what a lawmaker might think, ROC Coast Guard Administration (CGA) authorities said Thursday.

Noting that the CGA was established to protect the seas off Taiwan, maintain order along the nation's coastline and ensure national security, CGA officials said that currently, the CGA is incapable of playing a defensive role or being a combat force supporting the Ministry of National Defense.

CGA officials denied an allegation by an unidentified member of the Legislative Yuan who said on Oct. 7 that the CGA had contingency plans to become a "second navy" of the Republic of China should war erupt in the Taiwan Strait.
The CGA, with its current manpower and equipment, could not be transformed into a fighting force should the national security situation change, CGA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA PRESIDENT ADMITS FAILURE OF EDUCATION REFORMS

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh admitted Thursday that it was his fault that education reforms in Taiwan over the past decade have failed to relieve the stress on students but has instead put them under heavier pressure.
Lee made the remarks during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's science and information committee, where he was asked if he has made any mistakes over the past 10 years.

Lee, who headed an education reform committee under the Cabinet, pointed out that public expectations were too high regarding what the committee could achieve and that they were unaware that the committee was only responsible for putting forth a proposal and had no power over the implementation of the reform measures.
Commenting on the issue, education reform activists agreed that the reforms have failed to meet expectations but said Lee should not take all the blame.

According to National Teachers' Association Chairman Wu Chung-tai, Lee's remarks are "belated justice" for all the students and parents who have suffered under the reforms, but substantial actions are required to correct the mistakes made.

One of the aspects that needs adjustment is the government's teacher-training policy, Wu said, adding that cooperation and the inclusion of different opinions are crucial to the success of the reforms.

Feng Chiao-lan, executive director of the Humanistic Education Foundation, noted that the government has focused the education reforms on changing the school curriculum and the model for students to advance to a better school, while there has been little change involving "individuals."

Feng said teachers have not changed their teaching methods but have continued to use supplementary books in their teaching and instil students with the concept of getting grades to advance to a better school, which she said is the source of students' pressure.
Pao Chung-min, head of the Parents Association in Taipei, urged the government to review the reforms to find out what went wrong, as he said the reforms have obviously failed to achieve their goal.
Pao said parents still expect education reforms to continue regardless if the measures implemented over the past 10 years have been right or wrong.

Hsiao Hui-ying, chairwoman of the National Alliance of Parents Association, said it is true that the pressure on students has not lessened after the reforms were launched and that teachers and parents are the sources of this pressure.
Hsiao said future reforms should focus on the expansion of government-funded education from nine years to 12 years to help reduce the pressure on students.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT TAKES TRAIN RIDE WITH ALASKA GOVERNOR AS GUIDE
DOC.DATELINE: Anchorage, Alaska, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Y. C. Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui began his second full day in Anchorage, Alaska Wednesday by boarding a train to see a glacier, with Alaska Government Frank Murkowski serving as his guide.

Lee was warmly greeted by Murkowski when he arrived at the railway station from the hotel where he is staying. The governor was also elated to see Wu Li-pei, a senior advisor to President Chen Shui-bian whom he has known for three decades.
Murkowski talked of the landscape along the way, calling everyone's attention when two reindeers were spotted on the plain.
Lee, while enjoying the views, said the weather in Anchorage was very cold. He wouldn't divulge further the contents of their conversations.
Murkowski said the former ROC president is young and energetic, hardly looking like an octogenarian.

Murkowski, who is a staunch supporter of Taiwan, also said that it was good to see President Chen make a transit stop in Miami on his way to Central America last month, and for Lee to visit the United States.

He said that Alaska and Taiwan have close relations mainly because Anchorage is between Asia and America, and that his state has rich energy, mineral and fishery reserves which can be complementary to those of Taiwan.
Wu echoed his view, saying that Taiwan could form joint ventures with Alaska to tap energy resources, saying that it will help stabilize domestic oil prices and create economic stability.

Wu said that his friendship with Murkowski dates back to the Alaska National Bank where Murkowski served as a president before being elected to the U.S. Senate in 1980 and serving in Alaska for 22 years. During his tenure in the U.S. Senate, Murkowski served as Subcommittee Chairman of Pacific and East Asian Affairs on the Foreign Relations Committee, further deepening his understanding of Taiwan.
Saying that Murkowski is a man who attaches importance to friendship and principles, Wu said that he is indeed a friend Taiwan needs.

Anchorage is the first leg of Lee's two-week U.S. trip which will also take him to New York, Washington, D.C., and Los Angeles, where he will meet with leaders of major Taiwanese associations, American politicians, think tank scholars and opinion leaders.
Lee will be in Washington, D.C. from Oct. 17-20, during which he will deliver a speech at the National Press Club.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT AIR LINKS IMPOSSIBLE BEFORE 2006: MAC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The opening of direct air links between Taiwan and China seems unlikely before 2006, but the government will still do its best to eliminate hurdles to two-way talks on the issue, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday.

Wu made the remarks while answering questions from reporters about a newspaper report that cross-Taiwan Strait air links might be set up before the beginning of the next year. Calling the report groundless speculation, he said that it is too early to talk about the matter when concrete results have yet to be worked out.

Bilateral negotiations on direct charter cargo and passenger services and on allowing Chinese tourists to sightsee in Taiwan have remained in gridlock, Wu said, quoting sources as saying that Beijing is attempting to postpone the talks until after Taiwan's city and county chiefs elections on Dec. 3.
If what the sources said are true, it would be a very unwise move by Beijing -- a situation which the MAC chief said is not in the interests of the people on either side.

There are elections almost every year in Taiwan, and Beijing must not weigh bilateral negotiations from that viewpoint, he said, citing concerns of some people that Beijing might be seeking to put off the talks until the next presidential race in 2008 has ended in anticipation that the opposition "pan blue alliance" candidates would win.

"If this is true, the efforts that we have made are in vain, and it is extremely unwise for Beijing to adopt that approach since it will not benefit the people in Taiwan -- something contrary to the Beijing leaders' repeated claims that they will do whatever they can to accomplish all tasks that are beneficial to the Taiwan people, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 19 points to close at 5,985, with 22,831 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 19 points to end at 5,987, with 3,504 contracts traded, while December futures lost 26 points to finish at 5,980, with 21 contracts traded. March futures moved down 63 points to close at 5,943, with seven contracts traded, while June futures moved down 19 points to close at 5,966, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,004 for October, 6,006 for November, 6,006 for December, 6,006 for March and 5,985 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

October TE futures moved down 1.05 points to close at 248.95, with 3,344 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 1.3 points to finish at 248.9, with 603 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 5.5 points to end at 247.6, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

October TF futures gained 4.8 points to finish at 896, with 3,078 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved up five points to end at 896.2, with 469 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down six points to close at 885, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORK AFFECTS HEALTH BUT 2/3 WON'T CHANGE THE WAY THEY WORK: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Ninety-three percent of the people in the job market said work affects their health but 64 percent said they will not change the way they work because of health concerns, according to a survey conducted by Winner magazine.

The magazine surveyed 1,237 people between Sept. 2 and Sept. 21 over the Internet and found that 77 percent of the respondents attributed their main health problem to pressure at work, 56 percent blamed abnormal dieting while others complained that they work too long and exercise too little.
The most immediate health problem for office workers is not enough sleep, followed by irritation/depression, overweight, constipation and dizziness, according to the survey results released Thursday.
The results show that in spite of the fact that work is affecting their health, over two-thirds of the respondents still will not change the way they work.
The survey also found that almost one-third of those in the job market agree health is the most important thing in life, with 28 percent saying money is more important than health.

Thirty-five percent of those polled hope their companies will give them more paid leave, 28 percent hope to have company paid medical check-ups, 26 percent wish to cut the hours they work, and 10 percent hope to go on a long leave without pay.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE YUAN-TSEH 'DISAPPOINTED' WITH RULING PARTY'S PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's sole Nobel laureate said Thursday that he is disappointed with the performance of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Lee Yuan-tseh, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, revealed his feelings when answering questions from independent Legislator Li Ao at a meeting of the legislature's Science, Technology and Information Committee in his capacity as president of Academia Sinica.

Lee obviously played an important role in President Chen Shui-bian's victory in the 2000 presidential election by a narrow margin over opponents James Soong and Lien Chan, in part because only days before the voting, he openly threw his support behind Chen.
He was asked by Li whether he owed an apology to the people for supporting Chen, whose popularity rating has plunged from 75 percent to 25 percent, as indicated by a recent poll.

In reply, Lee acknowledged that the policies of the DPP government are "not accurate enough" and have been "formed in the rough." In addition, he added, some officials ought to do better in terms of their integrity.
He admitted that he is "disappointed" that the DPP government has not done better during its five years in power.

Asked to comment on Lee's feelings about the DPP, William Lai, a whip of the DPP caucus in the legislature, said the Nobel laureate's words will propel the DPP toward reform, and that the party will be introspective and improve its performance. (By Han Nai-kuo) E

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN ABORIGINES SAY THEY ARE TAIWAN'S 13TH INDIGENOUS GROUP
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of aboriginal people from Hualien went to Taipei Thursday to appeal to the government to recognize the "historical truth" and officially designate them the 13th indigenous group in Taiwan.
Group members, calling themselves the Sakizaya tribesmen, traveled in two buses to Taipei to promote their "identity movement" that was initiated in May this year.

According to Kao Hsing-yi, movement initiator, the Sakizayas had traditionally lived in areas today known as Hualien City more than 127 years ago until an ethnic purge incident occurred in 1878, known as the "Dagubuwan Incident, " when many Sakizaya people were killed by Ching dynasty soldiers.
Survivors of that incident were so scared that they moved and hid behind false identities, mostly as Amis, technically making themselves disappeared from the planet, according to Kao.

Although the Sakizayas had "vanished," the group had continuously lived in Hualien over the past 127 years discreetly, maintaining their traditions, culture and language, which are completely different from those of the Amis, Kao said.
With Taiwan becoming more and more democratic, Kao said, the Sakizayas have increasingly craved for their own identity.

Since the Sakizaya identity movement was launched in May, more than 5,000 letters have been endorsed by Sakizaya offspring, confirming that they are Sakizayas instead of Amis and demanding that the Sakizayas be recognized by the central government as the 13th indigenous group in Taiwan, Kao said.
Meanwhile, Hsu Cheng-wan, an activity leader, said that the Sakizayas owe the Amis much for their magnanimity over the past century by not revealing their secret so that the Sakizayas could survive.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS MASS PRODUCTION OF BIODIESEL IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian hailed Thursday the mass production of biodiesel by a local company, describing it as the first step toward Taiwan's long-held dream of energy self-sufficiency.
Chen made the remarks during an inspection tour of a biodiesel demonstration factory in Chiayi County's Minghsiung Industrial Zone in southern Taiwan.

The factory was established by Taiwan NJC Corp., a joint venture of the Nice Group of Taiwan and New Japan Chemical Co. of Japan, with the assistance of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Industrial Technology Research Institute.

It is Taiwan's first biodiesel production facility using waste edible oil and oil-rich plants such as soybeans and sunflowers, to produce biodiesel, which is a renewable energy source. The plant can turn out 3,000 tons of biodiesel annually.
Chen said he was very pleased to see the factory's smooth operation.

"Taiwan relies on imports for 95 percent of its energy demand. Compared with other countries, we have lagged behind in developing renewable energy. We should now catch up and invest more in eco-friendly energy resources development. It is hoped that Taiwan can succeed in developing clean, efficient, renewable and sustainable energy resources and finally joining the ranks of oil-producing countries," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION MIXED ON CHINA'S OPPOSITION TO APEC ENVOY

TEXT.P: Reports about vehement opposition from China on President Chen Shui-bian's choice of Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng as his representative to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in South Korea has drawn mixed reactions from the opposition parties Thursday.

Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said that as there is a tacit agreement that Taiwan sends ministerial-level heads with financial and economic backgrounds to represent Republic of China heads of state at the APEC meetings, he had some worries when he first learned that Chen had appointed Wang as his envoy.

Ma noted that Chen has in the past tried getting higher-level officials to attend APEC on his behalf, including former Vice President Li Yuan-zu and former Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, without success, proving, he said, that "his misgivings are not unfounded."

Ma said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) owes an explanation to the nation -- whether Taiwan has agreed to accept the tacit agreement on whom to send in the past, whether the tacit agreement is binding and if it is, what are Chen's considerations in naming Wang -- who has no financial or economic background.

He said that if Wang, a former KMT vice chairman, can go, the party will be happy for him to make the trip. But, he went on, as Wang is not in charge of foreign affairs, Chen should "pave his way to Busan, and not ask him to take the adventure."

However, Chen Shui-bian noted Wednesday that when Taiwan entered APEC in 1992, it did not reach any tacit agreements or sign any kind of memorandum of understanding with other members, adding that his inability to attend the meeting is purely due to China's persistent obstruction. Former U.S. President Bill Clinton initiated the APEC summit meetings in 1993.
Cheng Li-wen, a spokeswoman of the KMT, said that the party will feel regret if Wang cannot make the trip.

She claimed that Taiwan has in the past dispatched mostly "economic officials" to attend the APEC summit and that any approach other than this has invariably failed, saying that Chen's appointment of Wang is "basically a child's game."

Cheng also claimed that Chen's announcement of Wang as his envoy before making certain he can actually make the trip is "immature, " adding that the approach will not achieve a diplomatic breakthrough but will only show "disrespect to Wang."

The legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party expressed the hope that China will view Wang in a "broad-minded way," saying that as the legislative speaker, he will convey the voice of Taiwan on cross-Taiwan Strait issues and will not have a negative impact on bilateral relations.
The PFP legislative cause will explain to China through various channels such as the media, scholars and the party-to-party communication platform that Wang is a suitable envoy, Sun said.

The legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP, said that China has no right to meddle in Taiwan's internal affairs and expressed the hope that the government will stick to its guns on Wang and not bow under pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNOUNCEMENT OF APEC ENVOY PREMATURE: KMT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian should not have made the announcement that he will send Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng as his envoy at the informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in South Korea until Wang's attendance becomes certain, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said Thursday.

Commenting on news reports that China had voiced vehement opposition to Wang's assignment, Cheng said the premature announcement not only is unhelpful to making a breakthrough for Taiwan on the diplomatic front, but also amounts to disrespect to the speaker of the legislature.
She said the KMT will feel regret if Wang cannot attend the summit as a result of China's opposition.

Beijing has based its opposition on the grounds that according to a memorandum of understanding signed in 1992 before Taiwan -- formally designated in APEC as Chinese Taipei -- joined the organization, Taiwan can only send its "minister in charge of APEC-related economic affairs" to attend the meeting, and that since then, APEC "has operated on this basis."
Chen has insisted that no other country should tamper with his exclusive right to appoint his representative to the APEC leadership summit.

Wang's attendance at the summit appeared to hang in the balance and it will be up to the government of South Korea to decide whether it will succumb to pressure from China to make Wang's trip impossible.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT OFFICIAL REAFFIRMS U.S. COMMITMENT TO PROTECTING ASIAN SECURITY

TEXT.P: A top official at the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) reaffirmed Thursday the United States' commitment to protecting security in Asia, where the rise of China has raised much regional concern.

Douglas Paal, director of the AIT's Taipei office -- the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan -- pointed that how to deal with China's rising power is a central question in American foreign policy and that the United States now needs to encourage China to become a responsible stakeholder in the international system.

The United States respects China's interests in Asia and recognizes the useful role of multilateral diplomacy in the region, but concerns will grow if China seeks to maneuver toward a predominance of power, Paal said.

"Instead, we should work together with ASEAN, Japan, Australia and others for regional security and prosperity through the ASEAN Regional Forum and the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, " he said.
Paal said it is important for China to resolve its differences with Taiwan peacefully because its choices about Taiwan will send an important message.
Paal made the remarks while delivering a speech at the Asia-Pacific Security Forum 2005 held in Taipei by the Institute for National Policy Research.
He emphasized the need for the United States, Japan and China to cooperate on both regional and global challenges, saying there are many common interests and opportunities for cooperation.
He said China has many opportunities to be a responsible stakeholder, one of most pressing of which is North Korea.

China has played a constructive role in the six-party talks on the Korean peninsula nuclear issue, where an agreement on the goal of "verifiable denuclearization of the Korean peninsula in a peaceful manner" was achieved last month, he noted.
"But the hard work of implementation lies ahead, and China should share our interest in effective and comprehensive compliance, " he added.

In terms of the energy policy, Paal suggested that China work with the United States and other countries to develop diverse sources of energy, including through clean coal technology, nuclear, renewables, hydrogen and biofuels.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT CHAIRMAN TO EMBARK ON SECOND TRIP TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Former opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will leave for China Friday for a two-week private visit, a KMT spokesman said Thursday.

Lien, now honorary chairman of the main opposition party and chairman of the KMT-affiliated National Policy Foundation, will visit Shengyang, Liaoning Province, in northeastern China -- the land of his 97-year-old mother -- where he will take part in a family reunion Saturday.

Lien will proceed to Shangdong, Hunan and Sichuan provinces, accompanied by his wife and children. It will be Lien's second visit to China after his first trip in late April, when he was still the KMT head before passing on the baton to Ma Ying-jeou, who is also mayor of Taipei, in the middle of August.

Lien's first China trip was dubbed by the KMT as a "journey of peace" that signified a major breakthrough in relations between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) -- long-time rivals since 1949 when the KMT retreated to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the CPC in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MONGOLIA SHOULD EXCHANGE HIGH-LEVEL VISITS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh called for Taiwan and Mongolia Thursday to bolster bilateral exchanges, saying that in addition to accelerating economic, medical and cultural ties, the two sides should also have high-level exchanges, including premier-level visits.
Receiving a group of Mongolians visiting Taiwan for public administration training, Hsieh said he would like to visit Mongolia if given the chance.

Hsieh offered his appreciation for Mongolia's support for Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization and related activities and said he is pleased to see closer medical exchanges between the two countries.
He extended a welcome to the visitors, saying that Taiwan and Mongolia are actually "emulating each other" when they engage in exchange programs.
In addition, he said, Taiwan also offers 20 scholarships to outstanding Mongolian students annually, allowing Mongolian young people to come to Taiwan to gain a better appreciation of the country.

Speaking on the same occasion, Hsu Chih-hsiung, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, noted that Taiwan has offered training to Mongolia in the economic, judicial and administration fields over the last 15 years, training more than 1,200 people who have in turned contributed significantly to the development of Mongolia and its efforts to improve the welfare of its people.

A total of 26 Mongolians came for this year's public administration training courses. Members of the group included 10 governors, eight provincial assembly speakers and officials from the city government of Ulan Bator, the Mongolian parliament and even the Presidential Office, according to Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWITZERLAND `MIRROR FOR TAIWAN': CEPD REPORT

TEXT.P: With only one-third of Taiwan's population and mountainous country "similar to that of Taiwan, " Switzerland represents a miracle that provides a great deal from which Taiwan can learn, according to a government report issued Wednesday.

Switzerland's per-capita income -- US$37,083 -- is nearly triple Taiwan's, and the country enjoys a prosperous economy with an unemployment rate lower than 1 percent while boasting the world's best living environment, according to the report by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The report attributes Switzerland's success to what it described as "a comprehensive and sophisticated programming of national territory that allows the country to turn its unique cultural and geographic features into prosperous businesses."

Switzerland, though poor in natural resources and fertile soil like Taiwan, is strong in the upscale financial-service and high-end precision instrument industries, after having gone through five decades of development that initiated in the 1950s, the report says.

In addition to luring a large number of business visitors thanks to its role as a leading world conference center, Switzerland also attracts millions of tourists every year from around the world who come to see its magnificent natural scenery, half of which is 1,200 meters above sea level and includes mountains, glacier, forests and farms, it elaborates.

In light of Switzerland's success both in high technology, conservation and tourism, Taiwan should consider how to blend its competitive edges into a national territory programming to further upgrade its developments on a wide range of fronts, it suggests, adding that this would also create many jobs for its people.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S POLITICAL MANEUVERING COMPLICATES PANDA ISSUE: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made its stance clear on the idea of accepting a "gift" of pandas from China and the Chinese authorities' recent political maneuvering will only further complicate the issue and will not help cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.

The MAC issued a news release amid reports that China's selection of a pair of pandas to be sent to Taiwan is nearing the final stage and that a spokesman for Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council also expressed hope Thursday that Taiwan will make the necessary preparations to facilitate the delivery.
Beijing first mentioned sending a pair of the endangered animals to Taiwan as a goodwill gesture following a visit to China by former opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan in late April.

The MAC said the government's stance on the issue is based on an assessment of the following four conditions: qualified groups seeking to house the pandas should make the application according to wildlife conservation laws; the applicants should have a good environment for pandas; the way of transporting the pandas should conform with the law; and world wildlife conservation organizations and opinions should not be opposed to their coming to Taiwan.
Beijing has recently continued to use the opposition parties to engage in political maneuvering on the issue, causing the issue to deviate from professional considerations, the news release said.
Meanwhile, Taipei and Taichung are gearing up for a competition to house the pandas.
A Taipei city government official said it applied to the Council of Agriculture to take the pandas earlier in the day after collecting all necessary documents.

However, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, who is in China to take part in a regional conference, has instructed his deputy, Hsiao Chia-chi, to make preparations before seeking to house the pandas. Hu's efforts, however, were dismissed by his two rivals in the year-end elections -- Lin Chia-lung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and Shen Chi-huei of the People First Party -- as mere election gambits, an unsurprising accusation, given that Taichung has no zoo.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTED TO EXPORT 300 TONS OF RICE TO JAPAN THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's planned export of 300 metric tons of locally grown rice to Japan this year is expected to be realized by the end of the year, a spokesman for the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.

Based on the good performance of 126 metric tons sold to Japan last year -- the first Taiwanese rice on the Japanese market in 33 years -- the COA is confident that Taiwan's exports of its high quality rice to Japan will top 300 metric tons this year, the COA spokesman said.

Meanwhile, the spokesman said, prices for local rice had risen to an average of NT$19.37 per kilogram as of early October, up 17 percent from the average of NT$16.5 per kilogram posted over the past five years since Taiwan was admitted into the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. FORENSICS EXPERT LEE TO SPEAK IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Internationally known forensic science expert Dr. Henry Lee is scheduled to return to Taiwan early next month to speak on the relationship between violent crime and domestic violence, sources from the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday.

According to officials from the MOI Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB), criminal investigations and studies have shown that most of the criminals who commit crimes involving physical assaults were victims of domestic violence when they were young.

Lee, who helped investigate the election-eve assassination attempt on President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu last year at the invitation of the CIB, is expected share with his Taiwan audience his research on the origins and motives of crime, the relationship between domestic violence and causes of crime and how Taiwan people should pay closer attention to domestic violence and its prevention, CIB officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER CALLS FOR CHINA'S SUPPORT FOR HIS APEC PRESENCE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday he "looks forward to China's support" for his attendance at this year's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum as President Chen Shui-bian's proxy.

Wang made the appeal after China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said earlier in the day that it opposes Wang's attendance at the 2005 APEC summit to be held in the second-largest South Korean city of Busan in November.
According to Wang, China should have "long been aware" of Chen's decision to send him to represent Taiwan at the upcoming APEC summit.
In the end, Wang said he believes it's not up to Taiwan to decide whether he can attend the APEC summit on Chen's behalf.
"I think it will hinge on interaction between the United States and China," he went on.
Wang, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) heavyweight, said KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou promised him in a phone conversation earlier in the day to assist in seeking China's support for his APEC attendance.
Noting that national interests should take precedence over partisan interests, Wang said he believes his presence at the APEC summit would benefit both the nation and the KMT.
"I take it as a great honor and an opportunity to serve our country. I'm hopeful that China will not hinder the realization of this perfect mission," Wang said.
According to Wang, Chen asked him in July whether he would be willing to represent Taiwan at this year's APEC summit if Chen was still barred from attending in person.
"In August, Chen formally informed me of his decision to name me as his envoy at the APEC summit, " Wang recalled, adding that Chen's sincerity in sending him is unquestionable.

Commenting on China's claim that an APEC memorandum of understanding restricts Taiwan to sending only ministerial-level economic officials to take part in APEC activities, Wang noted that many years have passed since 1993, when the first APEC informal leadership meeting took place.

"The times have changed. Given the ever-increasing civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, China should change its way of thinking and adjust its stance to forge goodwill and mutual trust, " Wang said.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that admit both Taiwan and China. Because of China's opposition, Taiwan's president has been barred from attending the annual APEC summit and has had to name a surrogate to attend on his behalf.

In the past few years, Chen appointed Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, to be his envoy to the annual APEC informal leadership meeting. This time around, Lee politely rejected Chen's invitation to serve as his envoy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES ESTABLISHMENT OF ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian suggested Thursday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should invite people recognized as having good reputations to form an independent, objective commission against corruption.

Speaking to the DPP elite at a special meeting, Chen said the proposed commission should have the authority to accept petitions and hear complaints from all sectors and to investigate charges of corruption against any DPP members working in government posts, including himself.

He assured fellow DPP members that he is not involved in any way in an illegal profiteering case brought to light by the Aug. 21 riot of Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project, and said he is not covering up wrongdoings by anyone else.
Chen claimed that if what he said proves to be contrary to the results of investigation, he would be willing to resign.

Chen said he understands that people are anxious to see results from the public prosecutors' investigation of the profiteering case and he expressed regret that legislation on the establishment of a commission against corruption failed to materialize in 2001.

The DPP meeting took place amidst pressure from within the party calling for a "new DPP movement" to clear the party's image, which has been soiled by a series of scandals and disputes linked to charges of corruption. Those present at the meeting included Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA DELIBERATELY DISTORTING SPIRIT OF APEC MOU: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: China is deliberately distorting the spirit of a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on Taiwan's participation in the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, a Presidential Office spokesman said Thursday.

Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang was responding to a claim by China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs earlier in the day that according to an MOU signed before Taiwan joined APEC, Taiwan can only send its "minister in charge of APEC-related economic affairs" to attend APEC activities, and that since then, APEC "has operated on this basis."
China's claim came a day after President Chen Shui-bian said he had decided to name Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to attend this year's APEC summit on his behalf.
According to Huang, the MOU only prescribes that Taiwan's foreign affairs minister should not attend the annual APEC ministerial-level meeting.

With South Korean assistance, Huang said, Taiwan, China and Hong Kong managed to join APEC simultaneously in 1992. At that time, the highest-level APEC event was the annual meeting of economic and foreign affairs ministers of all APEC member economies. Taiwan has traditionally sent economics and finance ministers to take part in APEC ministerial meetings.
Noting that APEC began to hold an annual informal leadership meeting in 1993, Huang said he does not think the MOU is applicable to Taiwan's representation in this event.
Because of China's opposition, Taiwan's president has been barred from attending the annual APEC summit and has had to name a surrogate to attend on his behalf.

In the past few years, Chen has appointed Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel prize in chemistry, to be his envoy at the annual APEC informal leadership meeting. This time around, Lee declined Chen's invitation to serve as his proxy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS RESOLVE TO CARRY OUT 'SIX REFORM PRIORITIES'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his commitment Thursday to materializing the "six reform priorities" outlined in his Doble Ten National Day message, stressing that if the reform projects are not completed as scheduled, relevant department heads should be held responsible.

Chen made the reaffirmation during a dinner party with senior administration officials and influential politicians from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), including Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang, DPP lawmakers, DPP local government chiefs and candidates for the year-end mayoral and magistrate elections.
Noting that pursuing power is not the DPP's goal, Chen said he has never wavered on his determination to push for sweeping reform in various fields.

"Reform is our ultimate goal, not just a slogan to gain power. We pursue power simply for promoting reform. Power is not our goal, " Chen said. Stressing that the "six reform priorities" elaborated in his National Day message aim to balance "economic prosperity" with "social justice" in Taiwan's comprehensive development, Chen said all government departments should work hard to realize them.

The Six Reform Priorities are: financial reform, tax reform, reform to change the preferential interest rates of 18 percent, media reform, investigation into properties inappropriately seized by political parties, and constitutional reform.
Chen said he looks forward to see the completion of the some second-phase financial reform programs, including cutting the number of state-owned banks by half by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 14, or the 12th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: Dwight D. Eisenhower, U.S. military commander in Europe during World War II and two-term president of the United States after the war, is born.
1912: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, is shot in an attempted assassination prior to his assuming the presidency. He won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese war.
1915: The Ministry of the Interior of the Republic of China government orders a halt to the practice of binding the feet of women.
1920: Oxford University, the oldest university in Britain and one of the world's most famous institutions of higher learning, grants degrees to women for the first time.
1933: Nazi Germany walks out of the Geneva Disarmament Conference and withdraws from the League of Nations.
1939: The British Royal Navy battleship HMS Royal Osk is torpedoed and sunk at Scapa Flow, killing 810 people on board.
1944: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, summons 100,000 young intellectuals to join the army and organizes them into an expeditionary force of 10 divisions.
1944: Field Marshall Erwin Rommel, one of Nazi Germany's finest military leaders known as "Desert Fox," dies at the age of 53.
1947: The Bell X-1 becomes the first aircraft to fly faster than sound when the rocket-powered plane, piloted by U.S. Air Force Maj. Charles Yeager, is taken to a height of 9,700 meters under a B-29 Superfortress mother-plane. The test begins at 22,700 meters and the maximum speed achieved is Mach 1.05, which is held for several seconds.
1964: Martin Luther King Jr., American cleric who formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1973: Thanom Kittikachorn is forced to resign as prime minister of Thailand after violent clashes between troops and student protesters.
1977: The much-loved entertainer Bing Crosby collapses and dies after completing a round of golf near Madrid. He was 73. One of his most successful films was "High Society, " with Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra.
1991: Aung San Suu Kyi, Burmese pro-democracy leader held under house arrest for more than two years by Burmese military rulers, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: The United Nations General Assembly ends a two-week general debate during which a total of 23 nations express their support for the Republic of China membership in the world body.
1999: A delegation from the Republic of China takes part in the 26th International Small Business Congress held in Toronto, Canada.
2000: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji says in Tokyo that Beijing will take a cautious attitude to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully, but he adds that this issue should not be prolonged indefinitely.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man knows that the accomplishment of great things consists in doing little things well. He knows that great effects are produced by small causes. He knows the evidence and reality of what cannot be perceived by the senses. Thus he is enabled to enter into the world of ideas and morals."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT'S U.S. VISIT PRIVATE IN NATURE: STATE DEPT.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct.13 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department reiterated Thursday that former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's current visit to the United States is private in nature.

In response to a question raised regarding China's dissatisfaction with Lee's U.S. visit at a regular press briefing, State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli pointed out that "we've said this is a visit by a private citizen, and that's what we consider it."
China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Taiwan Affairs Office made it clear earlier in the day that they are strongly opposed to Lee's visit.
Lee is currently in Anchorage, Alaska on the first leg of his two-week U.S. visit that will also take him to New York, Washington, D.C. and Los Angeles.

DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Religious Extremism Finds Fertile Ground
The indiscriminate suppression of "unofficial" Islamic organizations in Kabardino-Balkaria combined with poverty and historical grievances have created fertile ground for a virulent strain of religious extremism, as manifested in Thursday's violent raids..

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIZATION THE GRAVEST THREAT TO CHINA: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Anchorage, Alaska, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chen and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The gravest threat that the regime in Beijing faces is democratization, and not the Taiwan people determining their own future, former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said Thursday.

Lee, who is currently in Anchorage, Alaska on the first leg of a two-week trip to the United States, made the remarks while delivering a speech at the World Affairs Council on "Democracy in Taiwan and the Asia-Pacific Region." Alaska Governor Frank Murkowski was on hand to listen to the speech.

Pointing out that establishing a democratic system and democratic values in Taiwan was a difficult process, Lee said that Taiwan still faces tough challenges posed by the totalitarian regime in Beijing and its ambition to "swallow" the island.
China has been deeply worried about Taiwan's democratic development as this development has served as a beacon of hope for Chinese living on the mainland and in the Asia-Pacific region, Lee said.

Admitting that international support, especially from America, has been an important factor in Taiwan's democratization, Lee said that because of this support and the Taiwan people's determination to pursue democracy and be their own master, Beijing had to restrain itself from taking further action during the 1996 missile crisis in the Taiwan Strait and the 2000 presidential election in Taiwan.

He further said that China's use of the threat of force against Taiwan to attain its so-called goal of reunification is aimed at covering up the "irrationality and fragility of the totalitarian regime."

"The gravest threat the Beijing regime faces is not the Taiwan people determining their own future, but rather democracy which has given power to the people, which threatens the legitimacy and existence of the totalitarian regime," Lee said.

Although U.S. efforts to push for democratization in various parts of the world have gradually borne fruit, there has been virtually no progress on democratization in China, Lee claimed, adding that the international community and the United States have done nothing to call for Beijing to follow the global democratic trend.

As Taiwan is on the front line against the totalitarian Chinese regime, the island's democracy and existence have significant meaning to the future democratization of China and Asia, Lee claimed, adding that to the United States, the existence of democratic Taiwan also represents the existence of the expansion of democracy in the Asia-Pacific region as well as a foundation of U.S. interests and security in the region.

Claiming that the basic values of freedom and democracy have been the foundation of economic and security relations among allies, Lee said that the common values of democracy and freedom shared by Taiwan and the United State have been the reasons why the two countries have been able to maintain a stable friendship.
"Creating a democratic environment and a democratic alliance in the Asia-Pacific region is the real basis for peace in the region, " he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO SPEAK ON SIX REFORM PRIORITIES SUNDAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will speak on his "Six Reform Priorities" on television Sunday, and afterwards will travel around Taiwan to explain them directly to the people, participants in a high-level meeting said Thursday night.

They were quoting Chen's remarks during a dinner party with senior administration officials and influential figures from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , including Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang, DPP lawmakers, DPP local government chiefs, and candidates for the year-end mayoral and magistrate elections.
President Chen also expressed the hope that all DPP legislators will defend the reform priorities whenever the chance arises, the participants said.

The Six Reform Priorities are: financial reform, tax reform, reform to change the preferential interest rates of 18 percent for retired military personnel, civil servants and teachers, media reform, investigation into properties inappropriately acquired by political parties, and constitutional reform.

Participants also quoted Premier Hsieh as saying that the Executive Yuan will continue to defend its policies, adding that although the public has been critical of his Cabinet, some of its policies have won a positive response, such as the passing of the first-phase constitutional reforms under which the nation will see a dramatic change in the system for electing legislators and the halving of the number of seats in the legislature, as well as a new pension system for laborers.

The government will continue pursuing the assets inappropriately acquired by the Kuomintang (KMT) and working to prevent the KMT from selling the assets and using the funds for campaigning for the year-end elections, Hsieh said.

Also speaking at the meeting, Vice President Lu said that she regretted that meetings were only held after a flurry of scandals such as the controversial insider stock trading scandal and the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit construction project scandal, urging party members not to underestimate the adverse impact of these scandals on the party.
"Reforms are good things, and they will never be too late, " Lu was quoted by the participants as saying.

Lu also expressed the hope that the DPP will take heed of the KMT's three-stage strategy to sweep the DPP out of power, namely winning the year-end elections, the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections in 2006, and the next presidential election in 2008.

The vice president said she wants to see the communications mechanism between the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan and the DPP improved, as well as to see legislators sharpen their professional expertise.
She also said that some of the reform priorities unveiled by President Chen are old issues and that she wonders why they have yet to be carried out.
Lu also called for serious consideration of a Cabinet reshuffle before or after the year-end elections. Neither the president nor premier responded directly to the suggestion.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 CRUCIAL YEAR FOR APEC: PUNDIT

TEXT.P: The year 2005 is a key one in the development of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum as it faces several unprecedented challenges both within and without the region, Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) President David S. Hong said Friday.

Speaking at the opening of a symposium on "APEC Under Global Change and Taiwan's Participation in APEC" hosted by the Chinese Taipei APEC Research Center, Hong said that Taiwan must pay very close attention to these factors and their impact on APEC's development.

Hong said that APEC has faced several unprecedented economic and non-economic challenges over the last 10 months, including the stagnation of the multilateral World Trade Organization talks, global terrorism, the spread of epidemic diseases, and a string of natural disasters, including tsunamis, typhoons and hurricanes.
As a result, Hong said, APEC members have strengthened their level of cooperation in dealing with problems both within and without the region and have included more issues into APEC discussions.

At the same time, APEC has continued to reform itself, adjusting its administrative structure, distribution of tasks and missions, financial management, as well as appropriation portfolio, Hong noted.
More importantly, he pointed out, APEC is facing a serious threat to its existence as the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) integrates with China at an alarming pace.

Noting that APEC is one of the most important channels for reaching out to the world for Taiwan which faces a difficult diplomatic situation due to Beijing's unrelenting suppression, Hong said Taiwan should keep closely abreast of all the latest developments in APEC.

Fortunately, he said, Taiwan has actively participated in various APEC activities over the past year, including sponsoring or taking part in APEC meetings and seminars on development of small- and medium-size enterprises and the information technology industry.

"An important supporter of the APEC spirit and contributor to APEC activities, Taiwan must maintain a high level of sensitivity regarding APEC's position and functions and efficiently grasp all the latest developments," Hong said.
TIER is one of the major sponsors of the Chinese Taipei APEC Research Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 8.96 points to close at 5,969.07.
The bourse opened at 5,987.05 and fluctuated between 6,006.96 and 5,967.71 during trading. A total of 2.77 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$59.56 billion (US$1.78 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2.3 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1.2 percent, textile stocks at 1.1 percent, cement stocks at 0.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.1 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down at 0.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares losing 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 530 to 169, with 405 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ACHIEVES MORE BALANCED DEVELOPMENT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The government's efforts to divert more of its resources from northern Taiwan to the south over the past few years has helped creat more balanced development in the country, President Chen Shui-bian said Friday.
Chen made the remarks while presiding over the opening of a new section of the Hsinchu-based Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), which is located in Liuchia in southern Tainan County.
Chen pointed out that the ITRI has been the prime mover promoting the upgrading and innovation of Taiwan industries since it was established more than 30 years ago.

The ITRI has assisted in the development of the information, electronics, semiconductor, IC design and flat panel display industries in the country, with 17 Taiwan products now claiming the world's largest market share and 11 products ranking second or third, Chen said.
According to the president, industrial competition in the future will not only involve lowering production costs but also boosting innovation and research and development and creating value.
The "2008 national development project" promoted by the government in recent years is aimed at leading Taiwan industries to advance toward global competition in the 21st century, Chen said.

He said that the ITRI's Tainan section will focus its research and development on the themes of "digital life," "health and safety," and "green future" and serve as the fountainhead of industrial innovations and development in southern Taiwan to enhance the international competitiveness of Taiwan industries.

Chen said he hopes the ITRI will assist small- and medium-sized businesses and traditional industries in southern Taiwan to map out a new development model in addition to seeking breakthroughs in the development of high-tech and high precision industries.

The ITRI's Tainan section covers an area of 47 hectares and has the capacity to accommodate 1,500 people. It comprises seven research centers on networking and communications, micro/nano systems, advanced materials and processing, energy and environment, advanced processing, optoelectronic application, and applied microbiology.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR CABINET RESHUFFLE AT THIS STAGE WOULD CAUSE PROBLEMS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that adjusting the lineup of his Cabinet at this stage would lead to problems, suggesting that the Cabinet should not be reshuffled if there isn't an urgent need to do so.
Premier Hsieh noted that many of the current bills and budgets have been proposed by incumbent ministerial-level heads and that replacing these ministers now would cause problems in the system.

Hsieh made the remarks during a legislative interpellation session when asked by Legislator Huang Tsung-yuan of the Taiwan Solidarity Union about Vice President Annette Lu's suggestion the previous day that there be a Cabinet reshuffle before or after the year-end city and county chief elections.
The premier has made minor reshuffle of his Cabinet since assuming the post in February this year.

Huang said that President Chen Shui-bian won re-election in 2004 because of the public's support for his advocacy of "believe in Taiwan and insist on reforms, " but a flurry of scandals, including an insider stock trading scandal involving a ranking official of the Financial Supervisory Commission, have hit the headlines recently.
Huang asked if Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng and Taiwan Stock Exchange Chairman Wu Nai-jen should take responsibility for their alleged involvement in scandals.
Hsieh stressed that the prosecutors have already looked into the matter and that he hopes they will reach a conclusion on the matter soon, adding that he cannot interfere in the process.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PUSHES FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Responding to President Chen Shui-bian's recent calls for six reform priorities, leaders of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus pushed for the establishment of an independent anti-corruption commission Friday.

Chao Yung-ching, DPP legislative party whip and William Lai, a DPP legislative caucus secretary, both said that if the opposition is resolved to unearthing the truth behind irregularities and corruption scandals, they should support the establishment of an anti-corruption commission, instead of continuously obstructing the passage of a bill governing its establishment.
Chao said the DPP legislative caucus fully supports Chen's remarks made a day earlier that "the DPP pursues power simply for promoting reform and the DPP should conduct self-examination."

The DPP legislative caucus called for the DPP nerve center to move immediately to initiate the six reform priorities that Chen has instructed, beginning with members of the DPP hierarchy averting interest conflicts and investigations into whether DPP members have exerted pressure on executives in public offices, Chao added.

Lai ridiculed the opposition "pan blue alliance's" contradiction, saying that while continuously revealing irregularities and corruption scandals, the "pan blue" legislators have blocked the passage of the bill governing the establishment of an anti-corruption commission, flunking it at the legislative Rules Committee 74 consecutive times.
The "pan blue" legislators have also refused to give their consent to a name list of a new Control Yuan nominated by Chen for nearly one year, Lai added.
Meanwhile, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said in Tainan, southern Taiwan Friday that the DPP is not divided on Chen's directives and will offer its full support.
Su also called for Premier Frank Hsieh to help implement the directives.

Chen reaffirmed his commitment Thursday to materializing the "six reform priorities" outlined in his Double Ten National Day message, adding that if the reform projects are not completed as scheduled, he will hold the relevant department heads responsible.

The Six Reform Priorities are: financial reform; tax reform; reform to change the preferential interest rates of 18 percent; media reform; investigation into properties inappropriately seized by political parties; and constitutional reform.
