DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: House of Deputies approves electoral reform bill.
The House of Deputies approved a draft bill proposed by the ruling coalition on electoral reforms Thursday. The bill is to introduce a proportional system for parliamentary elections instead of current one which allocates 25 percent of parliamentary seats by proportional representation and the rest with a single-seat constituency system. Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi hailed the green light in the house as a great show of ruling coalition's solidarity. On the contrary, the opposition Union, which refused to vote on the reform, accused the government of changing electoral rules right before next spring's general elections. The bill is pending to be approved by the Senate.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Scandals Take Toll On Bush's 2nd Term.
A series of scandals involving some of the most powerful Republicans in Washington have converged to disrupt President Bush's agenda, distract aides and allies, and exacerbate political problems for an already weakened administration, according to party strategists and White House advisers, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WITHOUT NEW GOVERNMENT MONEY HIGH SPEED RAIL PROJECT WILL FALL APART

TEXT.P: Without new government investment, which has been widely criticized by the opposition, construction of the Taiwan high speed railway would have had to stop and the entire project would have become an "iron scrapheap, " Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.

Hsieh made the remarks at the legislature in reply to a question from Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmaker Huang Tzung-yuan concerning the government's decision to come to the rescue of the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC), which has announced a delay in the launch of service for a year until Oct. 31, 2006.

The government recently told China Aviation Development Foundation and CTCI (China Technical COnsultant, Inc.) Foundation, both under its control, to chip in NT$7.5 billion to make up for the capital shortfall for the project, incurring opposition criticism.

Hsieh said that if the government had not invested new money, THSRC would not have been able to pay its bank loans and the building work would have had to stop immediately, leading to a host of disputes.
Hsieh promised to step up government monitoring of government shares in the high speed rail project by sending more representatives to the corporation's board of directors and supervisors.

THSRC was founded in 1998 by five prominent local business groups -- Continental Engineering Corp., Evergreen Marine Corp. (Taiwan) Ltd., Fubon Insurance Co., Ltd., Pacific Electric Wire & Cable Co., Ltd. and Teco Electric & Machinery Co., Ltd., and now has over 35,000 shareholders.

The government has been participating in the private sector project, currently the largest build-operate-transfer railway project in the world, as outlined in the Statue for Encouragement of Private Participation in Major Transportation Infrastructure Projects.

In Feb. 2000, THSRC secured a total of NT$323 billion-worth of credit by signing the Tripartite Agreement and the Credit Syndication Contracts with a syndicate of 25 local banks, including the Chiao Tung Bank, the Bank of Taiwan and the International Commercial Bank of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLIANCE PROPOSES EXPANDING APPLICABILITY OF PROTECTIVE ORDERS

TEXT.P: A local alliance against domestic violence unveiled Friday a proposal to amend the Domestic Violence Prevention Act to expand the applicability of protective orders to cover victims in a cohabitation relationship.

Others to be covered by protective orders will include social workers, clinical psychologists and educators, according to the proposal put forth by the alliance, which comprises private groups including the Modern Women's Foundation, the Taipei Awakening Association and the Garden of Hope Foundation.
Also, the alliance proposed changing the law to grant the police the power to make non-warrant arrests on those who inflict violence.
Lai Shu-ling from the Taipei Awakening Association said the change will better protect victims because the police will be able to make immediate arrests and issue warrants later.
Meanwhile, under the alliance's proposal, people who ignore a court order requiring them to hand over the victim's children will constitute a violation of protective orders.
To help the victims achieve financial independence, the alliance suggested that sheltering and employment services also be made available to them.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANDA ISSUE BE TACKLED ACCORDING TO INTERNATIONAL PRECEDENT: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The issue of China's "gift" of pandas to Taiwan should be solved in accordance with international norms and the precedents of cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges, Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.

Responding to opposition People First Party Legislator Shen Chih-hui on whether the administration is prepared to give a green light to Taiwan's acceptance of two pandas from China as a "gift, " Hsieh said that the government has set no prerequisite on the issue.

Hsieh said that since both Taiwan and China are World Trade Organization (WTO) members, he suggested that panda affairs be tackled according to international and WTO norms, adding that "the administration is taking the issue in stride."

The panda story has been a hot topic in recent days as China's selection of a pair of pandas to be sent to Taiwan is nearing the final stage, with Taipei and Taichung cities competing to playing host to the furry guests.

Meanwhile, Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Lee Chin-lung said that as pandas are protected animals, recipients must be academic or research institutes or publicly or privately run zoos according to regulations of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) . This means the delivery of the two pandas to Taiwan must come together with export and import permits issued by CITES, Lee noted.
He added that so far, only Taipei City Zoo has filed for an import permit from the Taipei city government but the application has yet to be referred to the COA.

Also commenting on the issue, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said the MAC will not spell out its "political guidance, " at this moment since preliminary technical affairs regarding the issue have not yet been resolved.

Beijing first mentioned sending a pair of the endangered animals to Taiwan as a so-called "goodwill gesture" following a visit to China by former opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan in late April.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN TO REPLACE APEC SUMMIT ENVOY: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng is a good candidate to represent President Chen Shui-bian at this year's Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum summit and the government has no plans to replace him, despite Beijing's opposition to his attendance, a presidential aide said Friday.

James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said Chen's decision to send Wang to take part in the summit on his behalf has gained support from the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and that Beijing's suppression of Wang will only provoke resentment among the people of Taiwan. Wang is a KMT heavyweight who once served as KMT vice chairman.
Huang blamed China for twisting history and the spirit of an APEC memorandum of understanding (MOU) by making comments intended to "mislead the international community."

A spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry bluntly opposed a day earlier Wang's participation in the informal APEC leadership meeting slated for mid-November in Busan, South Korea, citing an APEC MOU stipulation that says Taiwan can only send officials in charge of economic affairs to APEC-related activities.
Based on the "routine" that Taiwan has practiced in compliance with the rule, China is opposed to Wang's attendance as Chen's envoy, the Beijing official said.

Claiming that the Beijing official's view is contradictory to the facts, Huang pointed out that Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh has represented Chen at the APEC summit three times, while the late Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman C.F. Koo also has acted as an APEC presidential envoy. Neither Lee nor Koo are or were responsible for economic affairs, he pointed out.

According to the presidential aide, the MOU only stipulates that Taiwan cannot send its foreign minister to take part in APEC ministerial-level meetings, and it also rules that Taiwan, Hong Kong and China are entitled to participate in APEC activities on an equal footing with the current APEC participants. He appealed to the South Korean government to help Wang take part in the summit.
With assistance from South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and China entered APEC in 1992 under a set of terms documented in the MOU that was agreed upon by the three sides in 1991.

One of the terms says that Taiwan "shall be represented at ministerial meetings only by a minister or ministers in charge of APEC-related economic affairs, while its "foreign minister" or "vice foreign minister" shall not attend APEC meeting. Taiwan's delegation may include officials of foreign and other ministries at or below the level of department director.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN VISITOR ARRIVALS UP FOR JAN.-AUG. PERIOD: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Foreign visitor arrivals to Taiwan in the first eight months of this year totaled 2.19 million, up 16.2 percent over the figure for the same period last year, according to the latest government statistics.

Japan, Hong Kong and Macau, and the United States were the top three sources of foreign visitor arrivals to Taiwan, making up about 60 percent of the total, according to the tallies released by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Japanese visitors made a total of 719,000 visits to Taiwan for the January-August period, while those from Hong Kong and Macau made 293,000 visits, and those from the United States 262,000 visits.
Some 860,000 of the more than 2 million foreign visitors were tourists, a jump of 39.6 percent over the year-earlier level. About 633,000 were business visitors.
Meanwhile, Taiwan people made more than 5.68 million visits abroad in the first eight months of the year, for a year-on-year increase of 7.4 percent, according to the statistics.

Hong Kong was the leading destination, seeing 1.92 million arrivals from Taiwan. South Korea saw the biggest annual growth in Taiwan visitors at 25.5 percent, while Thailand saw the steepest decline, at 38.4 percent, largely as a result of last December's tsunami disaster in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT HEAD ARRIVES IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Former opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan left Taipei for Shengyang, in northeastern China's Liaoning Province, for a two-week visit Friday.

Chen Yun-lin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, as well as other Chinese officials, were on hand at the Shengyang airport to greet Lien, his wife, children and son-in-law.
Lien, now honorary KMT chairman and chairman of the KMT-affiliated National Policy Foundation, is visiting Shengyang to take part in a family gathering Saturday.
Lien's 97-year-old mother, Chao Lan-kun, asked Lien to attend the gathering on her behalf because she is not fit for long-distance travel.
The Liens will then proceed to Shangdong, Hunan and Sichuan provinces before returning to Taiwan Oct. 28.
It is Lien's second visit to China after an earlier trip in late April when he was still the KMT head before passing on the baton to Ma Ying-jeou in August.

Lien's first China trip was dubbed by the KMT as a "journey of peace" that signified a major breakthrough in relations between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) -- long-time rivals since 1949, when the KMT fled to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the CPC. Lien met with Chinese President and CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao during the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HELPLESS IN APEC ENVOY PROBLEM

TEXT.P: There is hardly anything the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) can do since Beijing voiced its opposition to President Chen Shui-bian's decision to appoint Legislative Speaker Wang Jing-pyng as his envoy at the informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Busan, South Korea.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen played down a report Friday that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will try to convince Beijing to withdraw their opposition through the party's communication channels with the Communist Party of China, saying there is little leeway for mediation because Chen announced his decision in public Thursday without testing the political water first.

Citing a statement by Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Department, she said that "once the Chinese leaders have made up their minds, even the gods cannot make them turn around."
After five years as president, Cheng said, the president really should know better than to make a decision like this without consulting the relevant parties first.

Citing the president's bungling in 2001 when he named former Vice President Li Yuan-zu as his envoy to the APEC summit in Shanghai only to be rejected by China, which resulted in Taiwan's non-appearance, Cheng said Chen obviously has not learned his lesson.
The KMT spokeswoman said Taiwan cannot afford to miss the summit in light of the fact that APEC is one of the few international organizations to which Taiwan has access.

It is widely known that Taiwan should consult with the United States and win the understanding of Beijing about its envoy to the summit, and while the KMT would like to help, Chen's unilateral announcement of his decision has made it too late for any negotiations, Cheng said.
Given the fact that Taiwan has already locked horns with China on this issue, Cheng said it would be impossible for her party to sort it out easily.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S GERMANY REPRESENTATIVE PUSHES FOR OFFICE NAME-CHANGE
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to Germany said Thursday that he will strive during his term in office to push for a name change for his office from the present "Taipei Representative Office in Germany" to the "Taiwan Representative Office in Germany."

In an exclusive interview with CNA, Shieh Jhy-wey said that the title "Taipei Representative Office " does not represent Taiwan. Since using the name "Republic of China Representative Office" will presumably not be accepted by the German government as Germany does not recognize Taiwan, the use of "Taiwan Representative Office" is the only pragmatic option, he added.
Only by naming it the "Taiwan Representative Office" can the interests of Taiwan's 23 million people be represented in Germany, according to Shieh.

Shieh, who obtained a PhD in German literature at the Ruhr University in 1987, said he will start this effort himself, describing himself on his name cards, letterheads or meetings as the "Taiwan representative" instead of the head of the "Taipei Representative Office."

He noted that his office has received complaints from Taiwan students in Germany complaining that their "country of origin" is mistakenly changed to "China" when they file for visa extensions with Germany's immigration authorities.

He said he will write to all German offices responsible for immigration affairs around Germany to inform them that Taiwan is not a part of China and that Republic of China passport holders are from Taiwan and not from China, to prevent any recurrence of the "mistakes."
Hsieh added that his pushing for a name change is not meant to undermine Germany's relations with China, nor to challenge the "one China" policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PARAGUAY BUSINESS MEETING OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 7th joint meeting between the Taiwan and Paraguay business councils opened Friday in Taipei.
The meeting was held by the Taipei-based Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA) and Paraguay's Confederation of Production, Industry and Commerce.

The theme of this year's meeting is to examine how Taiwan businesses can make use of Paraguay's industrial advantages to expand their business opportunities in the Americas and to make Paraguay a springboard for Taiwan businesses to advance into the vast South American market.

CIECA officials pointed out that there are 34 countries in North, Central and South America with a combined population of approximately 500 million, and that the Americas are expected to become the world's largest economy under a new free trade agreement framework.

It will facilitate express marketing of Taiwan products to the rest of the world if Taiwan businesses can make early access into Paraguay -- the only South American nation to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan, the officials said.

Noting that the economic structures of Taiwan and Paraguay complement each other very well, they said Paraguay's low production costs and advantages in the Southern Common Market are a perfect combination with Taiwan's experience, capital and technology.

According to official statistics, bilateral trade between Taiwan and Paraguay amounted to US$35.62 million between January and July this year, up 34.99 percent compared with the same period of last year.
While exports to Paraguay rose 52.17 percent to US$32.43 million, imports from Paraguay declined 37.21 percent to US$3.18 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 17 points to close at 5,968, with 14,179 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 18 points to end at 5,969, with 3,250 contracts traded, while December futures lost 17 points to finish at 5,970, with 25 contracts traded. March futures moved down 20 points to close at 5,970, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,985 for October, 5,987 for November, 5,987 for December, 5,990 for March and 5,980 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

October TE futures moved down 1.75 points to close at 247.2, with 3,368 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 1.4 points to finish at 247.5, with 1,196 contract transactions. December TE futures moved up 0.1 points to end at 248.8, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

October TF futures gained 8.4 points to finish at 904.4, with 3,530 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved up 9.4 points to end at 905.6, with 1,303 contracts traded. December TF futures moved up 12.2 points to close at 904.8, with eight contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: `REGIONISM' NOT EXPECTED TO OVERSHADOW APEC: ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: The status of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum is not expected to be eclipsed by the emerging regionism in Asia immediately, an economist said Friday.

Chiang Chi-chen, a researcher at the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said at a seminar that the trade complementary index compiled by the World Bank in October, 2003, shows that the index among the newly developed economies in Southeast Asia has increased from 51.2 in 1985 to 67.3 in 2003, which indicates a greater growth pace and a greater interdependence than that of the European Union and the North American Free Trade Zone.

Thanks to China's rapid economic growth, Chiang said, Southeast Asia has transformed into a diversified and dynamic economic region, which in turn has led to vociferous calls for the establishment of trade blocs via free trade pacts, as well as the emergence of regionism.

The regionism that came along with the formation of trade blocs, however, will not threaten APEC because of the wide variety of culture, society and economic development among countries in the region, as well as hostility between the countries, he said.

Furthermore, Chiang claimed, no country in the region can provide leadership for other countries in the region, which makes it impossible for any trade blocs in this region to replace APEC in the foreseeable future.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.019 to close at NT$33.450.
A total of US$510 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.469 and hit a low of NT$33.432.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR PUNISHES TWO SENIOR OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Claiming that she wants to "firm up the institution and kick out the culture of sycophancy," acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan demoted Friday two senior officials who have broken administrative rules.
Yeh accepted city government adviser Lee Wen-liang's resignation, demoting the former chairman of Taiwan Water Corp. to the position of "adviser without pay."

Lee broke the rules by moving his office to that of Chao Chih-chiang, deputy director of the Bureau of Transportation, Oct. 11 and hanging a sign reading "Office of City Government Adviser" before starting work in the office.
Chao was disciplined with a major demerit and demoted to a non-executive position. He complained that giving up his office was not his decision, but one from "higher above."
Still, the acting mayor, who claimed she will not seek any elected office in the future, determined it was Chao's fault for moving out of his office without following proper procedure.

Yeh took over the post from Chen Chi-mai, who resigned over the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit scandal, amid expectations that she will reform the city administration and restore public confidence in the Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR NAMED TO TRACE MRT SCANDAL-INVOLVED FUNDS IN THAILAND

TEXT.P: Wang Chun-li, a Kaohsiung district chief prosecutor, was designated Friday to trace alleged kickbacks that a Taiwanese manpower brokerage company received from Thai laborers before they were introduced to Taiwan to work on the mass rapid transit system in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

A judicial investigation was launched in late August into the Kaohsiung MRT scandal concerning a profiteering racket between the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. and the manpower company, Huapan Administration Consultant Co. Ltd., that allegedly exploited the Thai laborers.
The scandal broke out following an Aug. 21 riot by the workers in protest of poor living conditions and maltreatment by their management firm.

According to a special team in charge of the probe, prosecutors and police believe that before the Thais were brought to Taiwan, they were forced to pay kickbacks to Huapan. However the team failed to acquire information regarding the illegal funds, even after trying to seek assistance from the Thai authorities, a member of the team said.

Wang said he will try to collect information during his stay in Thailand, despite voicing doubts that he will get little assistance from the Thai authorities as Thailand maintains no diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO HEIGHTEN GUARD AGAINST CHINA

TEXT.P: The public should be on guard against China's relentless international boycotting of Taiwan, a ranking official in charge of China policy said Friday.

You Ying-lung, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks in the wake of vehement opposition by China to President Chen Shui-bian's appointment of Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to take part in the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on his behalf.

China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said a day earlier that according to a memorandum of understanding (MOU) signed before Taiwan joined APEC, Taiwan can only send its "minister in charge of APEC-related economic affairs" to attend APEC activities, and that since then, APEC "has operated on this basis."

You pointed out the "conflicting nature" of Beijing's remarks, saying that China has deliberately distorted the spirit of the MOU to mislead the international community, noting that Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tse, as well as the late chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Koo Chen-fu have both served as envoys to the summit meeting on half of the Republic of China head of state.
He said China has no reason to oppose Wang's attendance and that he believes the international community will also not accept it if Beijing continues to oppose Wang's participation.

For this reason, he pointed out the double-handed approach of Beijing since its enactment of the Anti-Session Law March 14. On one hand, it has used pandas to try to woo the Taiwan people, while on the diplomatic front, it has relentlessly stifled Taiwan's maneuvering space.
He said that the MAC will consider the panda issue from the angle of professional and legal aspects, adding that China's use of the issue for political maneuvering only complicates things.

China, which first spoke of "giving" the endangered animals to Taiwan after then-opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China in late April, is reported to have picked 11 pandas from which to choose a pair to send to Taiwan in what it calls a "goodwill gesture to the Taiwan people." A spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, also urged Taiwan to make necessary preparations to facilitate their delivery.

You reaffirmed the four conditions regarding acceptance of the pandas: qualified organizations stipulated under the wildlife conservation law should make the application to receive the animals; the applicants must have good environment in which to keep them; the delivery should conform to current legal regulations; and the views of world wildlife protection groups and opinions must be respected.

He also said qualified organizations must apply to the Council of Agriculture and Forestry Bureau and that the handling process will take at least four months. As far as he knows, Taipei Zoo, which is keen on housing the pandas, has nowhere to keep them and is stepping up construction of housing facilities.
"I can't answer the question on when or whether the pandas can come to Taiwan judging from the four conditions and related developments," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REITERATES NON-EXISTENCE OF '1992 CONSENSUS'

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official dismissed an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) proposal Friday that Taiwan and China resume dialogue based on the so-called "1992 consensus, " saying that such a consensus never existed.

According to MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung, the deadlock in relations between Taiwan and China lies in the fact that Beijing denies the existence of the Republic of China, refuses to renounce the use of force to resolve cross-Taiwan Strait differences, and rejects dialogue with the elected leader and government of the Republic of China on Taiwan.
You urged the KMT to identify the real problem in cross-strait relations, instead of repeatedly asking the government to make the "1992 consensus" the foundation of cross-strait dialogue.
You was referring to comments made by KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou during an interview with the Hong Kong-based Ming Pao daily.

Ma said both sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume dialogue as soon as possible based on the "1992 consensus, " which the KMT claims was established between representatives of Taipei and Beijing in landmark talks held in Hong Kong in 1992 during the former KMT government.
According to Ma, the consensus means that the two sides are allowed to maintain their respective interpretations of the meaning of "one China."
Differing from what the KMT says, Beijing claims that Taiwan and China both agreed to the "one China" principle in 1992.
In light of the differences displayed by the KMT and Beijing on the issue, the current Democratic Progressive Party government has argued that the "1992 consensus" means "no consensus" at all.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILIPINOS COULD TEACH ENGLISH IN TAIWAN: PHILIPPINE LABOR MINISTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Emerson Lim and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Philippine Ministry of Labor and Employment has suggested that Filipinos able to teach English should be allowed to do so in Taiwan because of the shortage in Taiwan.

Citing sources from the labor affairs center at the Manila Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei, a ranking ministry official said Thursday that Taiwan's Ministry of Education will soon launch a campaign to recruit qualified English teachers.
Although Taiwan has hired many English teachers on a contract basis from countries like Australia, Britain and Canada, the official said that Taiwan still desperately needs English teachers.
Starting salaries for English teachers from the Philippines would be around NT$25,000 (US$750) per month, about half that of monthly salaries offered to other English-speaking natives, he said.

According to the official, Taiwan was the world's fifth-largest overseas job market for Filipino workers for the first seven months of this year. A total of 27,151 Filipinos headed for Taiwan to work during the January-July period.

Quoting statistics offered by the Philippine Overseas Employment Administration under the labor ministry, he said that at least 170,000 Filipinos currently live in Taiwan -- some 154,000 of whom are workers on contract, while 1,500 are legal immigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO HOLD ANTI-CORRUPTION MARCH IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will hold a march Sunday in Kaohsiung in the hope of prodding the government to take concrete measures to wipe out corruption, PFP Policy Center Director Chang Hsien-yao said Friday.

Chang, who is also a legislator from Kaohsiung, made the announcement at the Kaohsiung City Council, with various PFP Kaohsiung city councilors backing the rally at a time when several serious scandals allegedly related to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have erupted, involving the building of a
mass rapid transit system in Kaohsiung -- Taiwan's second-largest city where the DPP has long enjoyed firm support.

According to Chang, as many as 63 percent of Kaohsiung citizens are disgruntled with former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, now premier, according to the results of a PFP public opinion poll. Most of those who answered the poll think Hsieh should take the blame for the corruption allegations surrounding the project.

Commenting on President Chen Shui-bian's call a day earlier for the formation of an anti-corruption task force within the DPP to probe the case, Chang criticized the approach as lacking genuine resolve to find the truth and punish corrupt officials with ties to the scandal, as the commission will not have any judicial powers.
Chen must display wholehearted determination to deal with the scandals to regain public confidence, he said, adding that thousands of people are expected to show up for the demonstration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASKS WTO MEMBERS TO IMPROVE COMMUNICATIONS SERVICE REGULATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has submitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) a proposal for member economies to streamline their legal systems regarding the communications service sector, officials said Friday.

The proposal, offered last month by the Directorate General of Telecommunications under the ROC Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), hopes to address the situation where some WTO members have employed vague regulations and laws governing communications services, including the issuance of certifications, trade on the Internet, and foreign investments.

The proposal could liberalize the global communications services trade under the WTO framework, and is supported by several WTO members, including the United States and Norway, MOTC officials said, adding that if the proposal is adopted, all WTO members would be obliged to follow it.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CALLS FOR DONATIONS TO HELP SALVADORAN HURRICANE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) urged local people Friday to donate money to help with post-disaster relief programs in El Salvador.
According to the ministry, 69 people have been killed and 70,000 have been displaced by the aftermath of Hurricane Stan and a volcanic eruption.
The disasters have also caused tremendous damage to the country's infrastructure and crops.

MOFA officials said President Chen Shui-bian and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen have expressed condolences and sympathies to their Salvadoran counterparts on behalf of the Republic of China government and people.
In addition, the ROC government has offered US$300,000 in emergency humanitarian aid for post-disaster relief work in El Salvador.

Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca has declared a state of emergency in the Central American country and observed a three-day national mourning period in memory of the volcano and flooding victims.

Noting that Taiwan and El Salvador have maintained longstanding cordial ties, MOFA officials said local people are welcome to make donations to help finance post-disaster relief and reconstruction projects in the Central American country.

Prospective donors are advised to remit funds to the Salvadoran embassy's bank account at the First Commercial Bank branch in Taipei's Tienmu district. The account is named "Embajada de El Salvador" with a number "190-10-110064."

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS UNEARTH THAI WORKERS' PETITION THAT PREDATES AUGUST RIOT

TEXT.P: Prosecution authorities investigating the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) scandal have unearthed a petition started by a Thai worker in April, long before Thai workers rioted in protest against their inhumane treatment in August.
The petition warned that if their ordeal continued and their pleas for redress fell on deaf ears, as all their previous petitions had, "What will happen if 1,500 people act in concert?"

On Aug. 21, around 100 of the roughly 1,500 Thai workers living in the dormitory rioted, triggering a political storm as authorities have been forced to investigate what went wrong in the management of the foreign workers and in the construction of the MRT system.
The petition letter was found at a labor official's office. The official, a section chief of the Bureau of Labor Affairs, evaded media inquiries Friday.
Prosecutor Chung Chung-hsiao said he will question labor officials concerning the petition to find out why it had been hidden for so long.
Meanwhile, an ad hoc group was formed Friday to monitor the progress of the MRT construction and ensure its safety.

The "Kaohsiung MRT Monitoring and Promotion Group" is made up of seven experts and scholars and the group has the backing of acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan, who encouraged the group to give their professional recommendations freely.

The city's senior technical advisor, Liao Ching-lung, will be the leader of the group, with other members including Lin Jen-yi, president of National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences, and professors Yang Ming-chien, Tseng Kuo-hung and Shen Mao-sung.
Acting Mayor Yeh said Kaohsiung's MRT system has become the focus of the nation's media since late August and everyone participating in the project is under psychological pressure bordering on shame.
How to keep Kaohsiung citizens informed of the progress of the MRT project and ensure its quality and safety is the group's main task, she added.
She urged the members of the group to speak up on whatever subject they think should be improved, adding she will accept their views wholeheartedly.
The group will focus on four areas: safety of construction, mechanical and electronic systems, transportation and train stations.

Yeh said she hopes the monitoring group will help the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. successfully complete the project so that Kaohsiung residents will soon enjoy a safe and comfortable rapid transit system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DESIGN EXPO TO OPEN SUNDAY IN KAOHSIUNG COUNTY

TEXT.P: The third Taiwan Design Exposition will open Oct. 16 in the southern county of Kaohsiung, with over 1,000 creations by artists from 11 countries on display.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsin met with local and foreign architects who helped build the 2005 exposition, titled "Discover the New Home in Asia, " Friday at a former military base that now serves as a commercial and leisure-oriented area.

Yang said he expects the expo to be the most splendid of its kind, since a group of world-renowned designers and architects, including Hsieh Ying-chun, Liu Kuo-tsang and Lin Sheng-feng of Taiwan; Marco Casagrande of Finland; and George Lovett and Michael Cross of Britain, will be involved in a one-week "street-reforming" program as part of the exhibitions.

With the experts' creations, the old Hsinjen community surrounding the expo's exhibition center, Fenglin Square, has been transformed into an avant-garde district while still keeping its traditional atmosphere. A total of 19 theme pavilions have been erected to feature design ideas in a wide range of fields including fashion, commercial design, creative life and future trends.
The expo will run through Oct. 30 and is free.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET RESHUFFLE TO BE MULLED AFTER YEAR-END ELECTIONS: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh will consider the possibility of a partial Cabinet reshuffle after the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Friday.

Cho's remarks came a day after Vice President Annette Lu suggested a partial Cabinet reshuffle during a meeting of influential politicians from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chaired by President Chen Shui-bian.

The DPP meeting took place amidst pressure from within the party calling for a "new DPP movement" to clear the party's image, which has been soiled by a series of scandals and disputes linked to charges of corruption.
Cho said now is not the best time for a Cabinet reshuffle as the Legislative Yuan is screening the government's budget for the coming year.

"A changing of the guard in any government agency at this moment would definitely affect that agency's budget screening. Therefore, we believe it is more suitable to consider any personnel changes after the year-end elections for mayors, magistrates, city and county councilors and township chiefs," Cho said.
Meanwhile, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said President Chen didn't respond to Lu's "Cabinet reshuffle" proposal during Thursday's meeting.
In his view, Yu said, he feels that no Cabinet personnel changes should be made before the "three-in-one" elections.
"Stability is the most important thing before the elections. A stable environment is critical to ensure smooth proceedings of various reforms and development projects," Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS HE HAS NO INTENTION OF RESIGNING

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday he has no intention of resigning.

Hsieh made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session where opposition Kuomintang Legislator Su Chi asked Hsieh whether he would step down after Vice President Annette Lu called for a Cabinet reshuffle a day earlier.

Lu's appeal came during a meeting of influential politicians of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chaired by President Chen Shui-bian. The DPP meeting took place amid pressure from within the party calling for a "new DPP movement" to clear the party's image, which has been soiled by a series of scandals and disputes linked to charges of corruption.

In response to Su's question, Hsieh said if he were to resign now, detractors could dismiss it as a gesture of grandstanding or even speculate that he resigned out of fear of exposing his role in alleged scandals related to one of his pet projects during his tenure as mayor of Kaohsiung -- the city's mass rapid transit system.
At present, Hsieh said, the legislature is screening the central government's 2006 budget bill. A changing of the guard in the Cabinet would affect the budget screening, he said.

In his view, Hsieh said, a comprehensive review is needed before a Cabinet reshuffle. If the legislature passes bills regarding restructuring of the Executive Yuan and the creation of a National Communications Commission during its current session, a Cabinet reshuffle may be inevitable.
Moreover, Hsieh said it may be possible that the Cabinet is reshuffled in the future in line with the principles of a coalition government that he has been advocating.
"Anyway, I must take into account my responsibilities, my own conscience and life goals in determining when I should quit, " Hsieh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FINANCIAL CHIEF RINGS OPENING BELL AT NYSE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng rang the opening bell at New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) Friday.

Kong was the first Taiwan official to ring the bell to start the day's trading session at the Big Board. Kong was accompanied by four Taiwan business executives, including Chinatrust Financial Holding Group Chairman Jeffrey Koo, at the ceremony. NYSE Chief Executive Officer John Hain was also on hand to greet Kong.
Kong is currently in New York to attend a seminar on Taiwan's investment environment, organized by Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC.
The Oct. 13-14 seminar, dubbed "Taiwan: the Gateway to the Region, " is aimed at introducing Taiwan's ongoing financial reforms and investment incentives to attract foreign investment in Taiwan.
Kong's mission is composed of government officials, bankers and business executives.

Senior executives of nearly 20 top-notch Taiwan high-tech companies, telecommunications conglomerates and financial holding groups introduce their corporations' development prospects during the seminar to attract foreign investors. The delegation will leave for London Saturday to attend a similar forum scheduled for Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCTOBER 15 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, October 15:
09:00, Defense Minister Lee Jye will inspect a special army academy in Taoyuan.
10:00, Environmental Protection Administration minister Chang Kuo-lung will speak on Taiwan's environmental problems at Ketagalan Institute.
11:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend an aboriginal festival at Alishan in Chiayi County.
11:30, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the inaugural ceremony for a new hospital in Chinshan, Taipei County.
17:10, Premier Hsieh will attend a cultural festival activity in Hsilo, Yunlin County.
18:40, President Chen will attend the opening ceremony for the 2005 National Sports Games in Tounan, Yunlin County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 15, or the 13th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
70 B.C.: Virgil, Roman epic, didactic and pastoral poet, is born. His greatest work was the epic poem "Aeneid," which tells of the wanderings of Aeneas after the sack of Troy.
1821: The Central American Federation wins independence from Spain.
1925: During the warlord era in China, Sun Chuan-fang, superintendent of Chekiang Province, appoints himself as the commander in chief of a military alliance force of five provinces in central China to launch an expedition against Chang Tso-lin's army in Manchuria.
1928: The airship "Graf Zeppelin" lands in New Jersey after making its first transatlantic crossing from Germany.
1945: Pierre Laval, the French politician who led the Vichy government which collaborated with Nazi Germany during World War II, is executed.
1946: Nazi war criminal Hermann Goering commits suicide by poisoning himself one day before his scheduled execution.
1950: The first popular elections of magistrates in Taiwan Province are held in Hualien and Taitung. There is a poor voter turnout and new elections are scheduled for Oct. 22.
1955: A single Republic of China air force Saber jet, piloted by Capt. Sun Szu-wen, shoots down one MiG-17 in a dogfight with 12 Chinese Communist MiG-17s north of Matsu.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the late president of Academia Sinica, is buried in a cemetery in Nankang.
1964: Nikita Khrushchev is replaced by Leonid Brezhnev as First Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, with Alexei Kosygin becoming prime minister.
1969: The biggest antiwar demonstration in U.S. history is staged as millions of Americans take part in organized rallies and marches to voice their disapproval over their country's continuing involvement in the Vietnam War.
1973: The Sino-Paraguayan Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1973: U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and Vietnamese political leader Le Duc Tho share the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the U.S.-North Vietnam cease-fire. But Le refuses it on the grounds that peace is not yet established in South Vietnam.
1973: Y.T. Wong, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, leaves for Los Angeles to attend a seminar on Sino-American trade.
1974: A 15-member national team leaves Taipei for Seoul to take part in the First Asian Taekwondo Championships.
1975: A martial arts contest is held in Tainan with 400 people from 11 countries attending.
1980: Lt. Gen. Armando Reyes Villa, defense minister of Bolivia, visits the ROC army headquarters and also the ROC navy headquarters.
1986: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang, presided over by KMT Chairman Chiang Ching-kuo, unanimously passes a resolution of political reform to institute the National Security Law during the period of Communist Rebellion and allow the formation of new political parties and organizations.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh, an Academia Sinica member, wins the 1986 Nobel Prize for chemistry. President Chiang Ching-kuo would send a letter of congratulations to Lee on Oct. 17.
1987: The ROC Executive Yuan passes regulations governing the applications of local residents wishing to visit relatives in mainland China.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: South African President F. W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela share the Nobel Peace Prize for their work toward ending apartheid and laying the foundations for democracy in South Africa.
1997: Steven Chu, a member of Academia Sinica and a professor at Stanford University, becomes one of the two co-winners of the Nobel Prize for physics.
1999: A Mirage 2000-5 fighter jet of the Republic of China crashes while on a routine training mission off the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan.
2000: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, urges the government to pay more attention to the nation's economic problems.
2001: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi and Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Po-chih arrive in Shanghai to attend a series of ministerial meetings under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum slated for Oct. 15-18.
2001: Gen. Chang Hsueh-liang, who briefly kidnapped Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in 1936 at the peak of the Chinese civil war, dies in Hawaii at the age of 101.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man must examine his own heart and see that he has no cause for self-reproach, that he has no evil thought in his mind. Wherein the moral man is superior to other men consists even in that which is not seen by men."
