DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: 90 Die as Militants Stage Series of Attacks in Russia.
Islamic militants staged coordinated attacks on police and government buildings in Russia's North Caucasus region Thursday in a new wave of violence spilling over from war-torn Chechnya that killed more than 90 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Postal bills become law
The hotly contested postal privatization bills that have been at the center of a political firestorm this year were finally approved Friday, passing through a House of Councilors plenary session with relative ease.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ENVOY'S WARNING TO CANADIAN GOV'T 'UNWISE': CALGARY HERALD
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By S.K. Wu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A Canadian newspaper said editorially Friday that the warning by Beijing's top envoy in Ottawa to the Canadian Parliament not to pass an act aimed at improving relations between Taiwan and Canada represented bullying and was unwise.

According to the editorial in the Calgary Herald, Chinese Ambassador to Canada Lu Shumin warned Wednesday that passage of Bill C-357 (the Taiwan Affairs Act) would undermine 35 years of diplomatic attempts to foster trade between Canada and China.

The bill, put forward by Member of Parliament Jim Abbott, is aimed at providing a better framework for further economic, trade and cultural exchanges and other initiatives between the people of Taiwan and the people of Canada.

Addressing a luncheon at the Canadian National Press Club Wednesday, Lu not only warned against passing the act, but also said that a change in Canada's "one China" policy would certainly affect relations between the two countries as their diplomatic relationship is based on a consensus on the Taiwan issue.
Canada switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1970.

Criticizing Lu's remarks, the Calgary Herald editorial said that although the bill introduced by a private member of the Canadian Parliament is unlikely to go very far, "the belligerent reaction to its mere introduction provoked in Beijing should be a salutary reminder to Canadians of the kind of regime their government is cultivating."

"Surely, therefore, we can spare some vinegar for a regime whose human rights record is among the worst in the world, whose justice system evokes the show-trial world of Stalinism, and which routinely persecutes Christian churches, as well as its own pacific cult, the Falun Gong," it said.

The editorial further said that the Canadian government's hope is to help the country's businesses get a piece of what is promised to be the world's largest market, adding however, that "if it is, it has yet to deliver." It noted that "if Canada multiplies its exports to China ten-fold in 10 years, they will still be worth less than one-fifth of Canada's exports to the United States right now."

Pointing out that Ottawa's biggest concession to Beijing has been the acquiescing to its one-China policy, the editorial said that this policy "treats Taiwan as a non-country, with no diplomatic presence in Canada and its leaders barred from visiting and trade not encouraged."

"This leaves Canada in the invidious position of earnestly courting a brutal dictatorship, while shunning an emerging liberal democracy, " it said, adding that "for small reward, unless growing imports of Chinese products to the detriment of Canadian competitors is the desired policy end."

"When Beijing's ambassador threatens Canada with serious "consequences, " its time for Canadian Prime Minister Paul Martin to make the same kind of speech he recently made for an American audience: Canada will not be pushed around," the editorial said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By C.Y. Chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui and his wife arrived in New York Friday on the second leg of their two-week private trip to the United States.

Lee and his wife were greeted by Tsai Jen-tai, an advisor to President Chen Shui-bian; Chang Ya-feng, chairwoman of the Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association in New York; and nearly 30 of Lee's supporters in the city.
Before coming to the Big Apple, Lee visited Anchorage, Alaska where Governor Frank Murkowski, a staunch supporter of Taiwan, gave him a warm welcome and played host.

During his stay in New York, Lee is scheduled to visit "Ground Zero, " where the World Trade Center once stood, on Saturday. He will tour the Metropolitan Museum Sunday before attending a grand dinner party held by Taiwanese expatriates associations that evening.
While in the U.S. capital from Oct. 17-20, Lee is scheduled to give a speech at the National Press Club.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN GOVERNMENT URGED TO SUPPORT TAIWAN'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By S.K. Wu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A medical professionals leader from Taiwan expressed Friday the hope that Ottawa will comply with the resolution passed by the Canadian Parliament in 2003 to support Taiwan's bid to gain observer status in the World Health Organization (WHO).

Wu Shui-min, chairman of the board of directors of the Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan, made the appeal while meeting with local scholars and media representatives in a forum held in Ottawa.

While expressing his gratitude for the Canadian government and people's assistance to Taiwan in public health matters, particularly in the fight against the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003, Wu said he hopes the Canadian government will work to help Taiwan become an observer in the World Health Assembly (WHA), the highest decision-making body of the WHO.
The Canadian Parliament passed the resolution in support of Taiwan's WHA bid in 2003 at the height of the SARS outbreak on the island.
Wu is currently heading a delegation of the foundation on a visit to Canada to drum up support in the country for Taiwan's WHO bid.
"Although helping Taiwan to gain WHO observer status is our responsibility, China's continuous obstruction has prevented Taiwan from gaining such status, " he said.

Noting that disease knows no boundaries, Wu said that Taiwan's exclusion from the WHO has prevented the island's 23 million people from being able to receive international medical and health assistance. "This is due to political factors and Beijing's hindrance, which is unfair to the people of Taiwan," he added.

Several of the Canadian scholars and media representatives at the forum echoed Wu's appeal, saying that Taiwan has a basic right to join the WHO as participation in the organization will allow the Taiwan people to be able to share international medical and health resources with other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CGA SEIZES FOWLS SMUGGLED FROM CHINA IN TAICHUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) announced Saturday the seizure of some 1,500 fowls, rodents and turtles aboard a Panama-registered cargo ship in Taichung Harbor, central Taiwan.

Tipped off recently that someone was attempting to use a cargo ship to smuggle precious fowls and pets from China into Taiwan via the third places, the coast guard went on high alert. They made the seizure Friday night.
In view of the recent reports of avian flu in Asia and Europe, coast guard officials wore full protective gear when they boarded the ship anchored at the No. 22 wharf in Taichung Harbor.

Chen Xi, a Chinese second mate on the ship, admitted that he had transported the fowls and other animals from Fuzhou, Fujian in southeastern China. The ship had sailed around Japan's Ishigaki Island before coming to Taiwan.

The case has been turned over to the Taichung Prosecutors' Office. Chen has been charged with smuggling as well as with violating wildlife conservation and prevention of infectious disease from animals regulations.

The CGA launched a drive in mid-August against Chinese fishing vessels and ocean survey ships intruding into waters near Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu. The operation is also aimed at cracking down on smuggling, including human trafficking, across the Taiwan Strait and preventing the possible spread of avian flu into Taiwan.

CGA officials reported that the coast guard has chased 929 Chinese fishing vessels out of Taiwan waters and seized 1,489 kg of catch from poachers over the past two months. They also seized 4,500 smuggled fowls aboard a ship in Kaohsiung Harbor in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS TO BE LINKED WITH ELECTIONS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: With the introduction of a new system requiring that proposed constitutional amendments be ratified through referendum, the nationwide legislative elections are expected to be the most likely occasion when a constitutional referendum will be held in the future, an official said Saturday.

According to a package of constitutional amendments adopted in June, future constitutional amendment proposals will be put to referendum after they have obtained the consent of at least three-quarters of the legislators.
In a referendum, the approval of more than half of all eligible voters is required in order for any amendment to be considered passed.

Speaking during a seminar held by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy on the impact of the amendments, Research, Development and Evaluation Commission Chairman Yeh Jiuun-rong said the high threshold will make future constitutional reforms difficult.

It will be "logical" for a constitutional referendum to be held alongside a national-level election because otherwise, it will be difficult to attract such a large number of voters to come out to the polls, Yeh said.
Also, reforms covering multiple issues will be more likely than those focusing on a single issue to accumulate the momentum required to obtain the necessary number of votes in a referendum, he said.

He predicted that there will likely only be a chance to amend the Constitution once every three or four years at most in light of the long process of agenda setting and discussion involved in constitutional reform.
He said that future reforms will be based on public consensus achieved through extensive public discussion and participation, and no longer dominated by political elites.
President Chen Shui-bian has unveiled a plan to promote a second phase of reforms to give Taiwan a new constitution that is "timely, relevant and viable" by the time he steps down in 2008.

The next phase of reforms is expected to address issues such as whether to change the country's political system to a presidential system or parliamentary system; lowering the voting age from 20 to 18; and adopting a voluntary military service system.
Officials have promised that they will not involve sensitive issues such as changes to the country's status, territorial boundaries or official designation.

Also during the seminar, Academia Sinica research fellow Lin Cheng-yi and National Sun Yat-sen University professor Lin Wen-cheng said that when promoting the next phase of constitutional reforms, Taiwan will need to communicate with and win the support of the United States, besides watching the possible reaction of Beijing.
They said it is completely reasonable for Taiwan to draw a new constitution since the Republic of China Constitution currently enforced in Taiwan was enacted in 1946 in China.

However, if Taiwan seeks to promote a new constitution to establish Taiwan's status as an independent sovereign state, Taipei will almost certainly be subjected to heavy pressure from both Beijing and Washington, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Alarm over bird flu in Europe.
Alarm is growing in Europe over a possible spread of bird flu following the outbreaks in Turkey and Romania. Health Minister Antonio Storace affirmed that the government is prepared and that his ministry will draw up a plan together with regions next week to be presented for approval at the Regional Conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE BUST DRUG RING

TEXT.P: Police announced Saturday that they have broken a drug ring which smuggled heroin from Vietnam into Taiwan.

According to police, the ring was led by 50-year-old Huang Wen-hung, who had established drug-purchasing channels in Vietnam through his Vietnamese wife. Huang then hired drug addict Wu Wei-kuang through the help of Cheng Tien-ming to carry the goods into Taiwan.

Police intercepted Wu upon his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Friday afternoon and seized a total of 812 grams of heroin that he had hidden in his pants and shoes. The heroin has an estimated street value of nearly NT$10 million (US$299,401).
Police later arrested Cheng in a KTV parlor in Yungho, Taipei County, and nabbed Huang at his residence in neighboring Tucheng.
The police said the ring had successfully smuggled drugs into Taiwan on several occasions in the past for sale in northern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR PROMOTES CITY'S PRODUCTS IN SHANGHAI

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu lauded the central Taiwan city's premium products at a trade promotion activity held in Shanghai Saturday.
A total of 11 Taichung manufacturers, including world-renowned bicycle producer Giant and local delicacy "Sun Cake" bakery took part in the activity.
Hu said that Shanghai's change has been stunning and that he hopes Taichung can witness the same kind of drastic changes, although the city should also retain its distinctive features and style.
He vowed to make Taichung into the hottest industrial corridor in Taiwan, as well as "the heart of Taiwan" in various industries.

Yang Jianrong, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of Shanghai, expressed the hope that Saturday's activity would not only be a promotion activity but would also be a platform for exchanges between Shanghai and Taichung. Noting that this is the first time a Taiwan city has held such a promotion activity in China, he also expressed welcome for related activities in the future.

Hu, a former foreign minister, came to China in 2005 mainly to attend the Asia-Pacific Mayors Summit held in Chongqing, Sichuan Province in western China Oct. 11-14, with more than 100 city chiefs in the region participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INCREASE STOCKPILES OF TAMIFLU

TEXT.P: Taiwan is planning to dramatically increase its stockpiles of Tamiflu and other flu-fighting medicines in the latter half of 2006, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday.

CDC officials made the remarks amid reports that the global alarm over the spread of avian flu has sent nations on a Tamiflu buying spree. Tamiflu is considered the most effective medicine against the flu, and the Roche, the manufacturer of Tamiflu, has increased its production by nearly 10-fold over its 2003 level.

According to U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates, up to 5.3 million people in Taiwan would be infected in a major avian flu breakout, with 70,000 of that total having to be hospitalized and more than 14,000 dying.

The CDC officials said that Taiwan currently has 1.6 million doses of Tamiflu, enough for 160,000 people, or 0.7 percent of the total population. Taiwan's current stockpiles of Tamiflu would be unable to meet needs in the event of an avian flu outbreak on the island.
The officials said that they are planning to boost Tamiflu stockpiles to cover 4 percent of the total population in the second half of 2006.
In addition, the officials said that Relenza, which is manufactured by British Glaxo Wellcome, is as effective as Tamiflu, and that they will consider stockpiling some in the future.

They said that their preparations have followed the World Health Organization's suggestions, and that although Tamiflu and Relenza are equally effective, the former, in capsule form, is more easily stored and therefore a better option.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA SETS GOAL OF CUTTING AIR POLLUTION IN HALF IN 3 YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's environmental protection minister said Saturday that his administration is determined to cut air pollution in metropolitan areas around the island by half in three years.

Chang Kuo-lung, head of the Environmental Protection Adminstration (EPA), announced the goal in his speech to participants in the Ketagalan Institute's civil education program on the topic of national leadership and development strategy on the first day of classes.

Noting that air pollution has resulted in one in three children in Taiwan suffering from asthma or some other forms of respiratory illness, the minister said he knows of no other country with such a high ratio of asthma patients.

Pointing out that air pollution is mainly caused by automobile emissions, Chang blamed the high level of pollution on low gasoline prices. He suggested that local people have never been taught to value resources.
Chang said the EPA has mapped out several strategies to reduce emissions, including introducing liquefied gas to replace gasoline.

Meanwhile, the minister also said that the negative effects of environmental pollution have been clearly visible in Taiwan since at least 1982 when cancer was listed as the No. 1 killer of Taiwanese people. Since that time, cancer has remained at the top of the list.

Describing how badly Taiwan is polluted, Chang cited soil pollution as an example, noting that laboratory studies have put Taiwan at the top of the list among industrialized countries around the world in terms of dioxin contamination of soil.
Dioxin is a highly poisonous hydrocarbon that occurs as an impurity in some herbicides, defoliants and other chemical compounds, and sometimes as a byproduct of incineration.
Such contamination can be seen in many areas in the counties of Taipei, Taoyuan and Taichung, and the problem has been expanding to the counties of Changhua and Yunlin, he said.
Besides dioxin, Chang noted, Taiwan's soil has also been poisoned by mercury and other hazardous chemicals. "The situation is so complicated that there is no easy way to solve the problem," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY PLEDGES TO CONTINUE TO DISPOSE OF OUTDATED AMMO IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: The military will continue to dispose of outdated ammunition, land mines and vacant barracks on Kinmen to help boost development and tourism on the frontline island, a military official said Saturday.
Wu Ta-peng, commander of the Kinmen defense command, pointed out that the command has since April shipped 3,300 tons of unserviceable ammunition from Kinmen to Taiwan for disposal.
While 1,800 tons of outdated ammunition has been destroyed so far on Kinmen, the command is planning to dispose of another 1,000 tons next year to reduce the danger to local residents, Wu said.

Meanwhile, Wu continued, the military completed in May an inspection of the minefields on Kinmen and decided to funnel NT$470 million starting next year to clear the land mines over a three-year period.
As to the vacant barracks, Wu said the military will release all 240 unused barracks later this year and return the properties to their original owners.
Wu made the remarks during a military parade held as part of the National Day celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LOCALLY-PRODUCED BRAND NAME LINE OF COSMETICS HITS STORES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's cosmetics market saw the introduction Saturday of a new line of products which was not only developed and manufactured by a local biotechnology company but which has also been given a brand name of its own -- Nugen.

With the cooperation of the Industrial Technology Research Institute in the technological development of the new line, the Hsinchu-based Nugen Bioscience Co. introduced its Nugen cosmetics at five department stores in Taipei, Hsinchu, Tainan and Kaohsiung.
The company hopes that the brand name products will generate revenues of around NT$80 million (US$2.39 million) this year, Nugen Bioscience President Chang Chue-chien said.

Meanwhile, the company is also planning to form an alliance with other Taiwanese makers of brand name products, such as Formosa Plastics Corp., Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp. and Taiwan Sugar Corp., in an effort to make inroads into international markets, Chang said.
Chang indicated that the Nugen products, made with hyaluronic acid, are scheduled to go on the market in Hong Kong, China and Southeast Asian countries next June.

Hyaluronic acid is a component of connective tissue whose function is to cushion and lubricate. It has been nicknamed by the press as the "key to the fountain of youth" because it has been noted that at least some people who ingest a lot of it in their diets tend to live to ripe old ages.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Sunni Bombs and Guards Greet Iraq Vote; Disaffected Minority Attacks Party Offices, Secures Polls on Eve of Ballot on Charter.
Iraq's Sunni Arab minority made a violent reentry into politics Friday, bombing offices of a political party that urged support for a new U.S.-backed constitution while posting insurgents and tribal fighters at some polling places to ensure that Sunni voters could vote safely Saturday against the proposed charter.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL FORUM ON LEGAL AID OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A three-day forum on legal aid opened in Taipei Saturday, with 24 experts from 17 countries around the world attending.

The forum, organized by the Legal Assistance Foundation (LAF) , offers a conduit for local and foreign legal professionals to share their experiences in legal aid to the disadvantaged, a foundation spokesman said.
The LAF was established July 1, 2004 with funds from the Judicial Yuan. The foundation has so far received more than 17,800 applications for legal aid, and 7,640 of them have been approved.
Addressing the opening ceremony, Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng said the legal aid system is aimed at assisting disadvantaged people and foreign laborers.

Noting that the legal aid system has only been in place in Taiwan for slightly more than one year, Weng said foreign legal aid experts are welcome to offer their counseling to help Taiwan improve its nascent system.

Speaking on the same occasion, Alison Hannah, a legal aid specialist from Britain, said lawyers are no longer the only source of legal assistance in advanced countries. In New Zealand and Canada, for instance, community legal education networks have been established to offer easy access to legal information via phone or computer.

Foreign legal experts from Germany, Britain, the United States, Japan, South Korea, Vietnam and South Africa are among those attending the forum. During the three-day gathering, they will report on the current state of legal aid in their countries. They are also scheduled to pay a visit to President Chen Shui-bian, a lawyer-turned-politician Sunday.
A joint statement will be issued at the end of the forum Monday by all participants to reaffirm their commitment to promoting mutual cooperation in legal aid operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 20% OF TEENAGE GIRLS HAVE THOUGHT ABOUT SUICIDE: POLL

TEXT.P: A total of 10.5 percent of teenaged boys and 18.7 percent of teenaged girls in Taiwan have thought about committing suicide, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

The survey was conducted by the psychiatry department of National Taiwan University Hospital recently on more than 10,000 students aged between 10 and 18 around the country. The students were asked if they had thought about killing themselves at any time over the past month.
According to the survey, 5.99 percent of teenaged female respondents said they once attempted suicide, compared with just 0.34 percent of teenaged boys.
Nevertheless, official statistics showed that three times as many teenage boys committed suicide than teenage girls did in 2004.

Presenting the survey results during a seminar on depression among children and teenagers and suicide prevention, psychiatrist Chiu Yen-nan said that children suffering from depression usually display symptoms such as refusing to eat, irritability and slow development, and that they often are not able to verbally express their emotional state.

According to Chiu, loneliness, conflicts and sense of loss from family or inter-personal relationships, as well as pressures from study or illness are common factors leading to suicide among teenagers.
He proposed that the government set up a network to promote the mental health of children and teenagers to help them out of depression.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE CLARIFIES REPORTS ON CSC CHAIRMAN'S STOCK BONUS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said the company stock bonus China Steel Co. Chairman Lin Wen-yuan received was not in the form of cash and therefore could not possibly have been funneled into the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) campaign fund, the Department of Public Affairs of the Presidential Office announced Saturday.

Department officials were responding to media reports that President Chen said in a meeting Thursday prior to a seminar with DPP lawmakers and DPP local government chiefs that returning the CSC stock bonus worth more than NT$40 million (US$1.2 million) to the nation's coffers as demanded by some "pan-green" legislators of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, could "pose difficulties in practice."
President Chen also reportedly said that Lin is not a greedy man and that he has contributed a lot to the party's campaign funds.

Department officials said that it was actually other participants in the meeting who took the initiative to say that Lin is not greedy and that he had assisted some in the party to solicit election campaign donations. As for the issue of Lin's high salary and huge stock bonus, it is in line with the current system, they added.
According to the officials, the president said that Lin has yet to sell the stocks he received as a bonus and therefore could not possibly have funneled the money to the DPP campaign fund.

Commenting on the media report, DPP Legislator Jao Yung-chin, one of the participants in the meeting, said that President Chen had not claimed that returning the money Lin had supposedly funneled to the DPP campaign fund "could pose difficulties in practice."

The president only said that "everyone knows the character of Lin, and that he has in the past contributed a lot to the party. The matter of the stock bonus should be viewed from the angle of system," according to Jao.
Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang claimed Saturday that the government's representatives in the listed companies are like sitting on "gold mines."

They pointed out that nearly 20 chairmen or presidents who represent the government in listed companies obtain more than NT$112 million per year in salaries. Among them, CSC Chairman Lin concurrently holds 17 titles, including chairman of six companies, while Lin Tzong-yeong, chairman of the International Commercial Bank of China, concurrently holds 25 titles.

KMT Legislator Pan Wei-kang asked Lin to explain whether he has funnelled the money from his stock bonus to the DPP campaign fund, adding that if he has and if the money cannot be returned to the nation's coffers, then the move "is tantamount to sending the money straight into party coffers."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ATTENDS ABORIGINAL FONA FESTIVAL ACTIVITY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh attended an aboriginal Fona Festival activity on Alishan, a mountain resort in the southern county of Chiayi, Saturday to show his concern for the well-being of the people of the Tsou tribe.
Tsou is a relatively small tribe among Taiwan's aboriginal groups. The tribe has traditionally populated in the Alishan area and now has slightly more than 3,000 members.

Addressing a wedding ceremony for 12 Tsou tribal couples held in connection with the Fona Festival, Hsieh said he looks forward to seeing the Tsou population grow as fast as the number of foreign tourists visiting Alishan.
Fona, a creeping plant commonly seen in the mountainous area of Alishan, is known as the "life bean" among members of the Tsou tribe for its ability to grow in barren land.
Hsieh said he hopes the Tsou population grows and prospers. In the past five years, only 45 babies have been born to Tsou people.
Hsieh presented ocarina performances during a traditional Tsou wedding banquet to entertain the aboriginal newlyweds.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSC CHAIRMAN RESIGNS OVER STOCK BONUS CONTROVERSIES

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp. (CSC) Chairman Lin Wen-yuan said Saturday he has decided to resign from his current post with an aim to quell controversies surrounding the stock bonus he has received as the company's chief executive officer (CEO).
Lin also told a news conference held at the CSC's Taipei office that he would donate all the stock bonus to charity organizations after deducting taxes.
Lin represents the government in the Kaohsiung-headquartered steel company, which has been privatized but the government still holds a controlling stake in the firm.
Thanks to a steel industry boom in recent years, Lin has received stock bonus worth more than NT$4,000 from the company's 2004 earnings.
Critics, including lawmakers from both ruling and opposition camps, have been pushing Lin to return the funds to national coffers.

Lin said CSC has implemented a stock bonus system since it was privatized in 1995. According to current regulations, remunerations paid by the company to members of its board of directors and supervisors belong to institutional investors, but stock bonus belongs to individual directors or supervisors.

Both of his two predecessors -- Wang Chung-yu and Kuo Yen-tu -- pocketed stock bonus in line with the corporate rules, Lin said, adding that his stock bonus has become an issue mainly because the amount is too fat.

"The stock bonus generates from CSC's handsome earnings and a steep rise in its share prices on the stock exchange," Lin explained. He further said both of his two predecessors received 20.83 percent of the total stock bonuses for commissioned CSC managers.

"After I took CSC's helm, the ratio for CEO was cut to 20.14 percent in 2003 and further trimmed to 20.12 percent in 2004. In terms of the ratio, I received less than my two predecessors. This indicates that I have not tried to gain illicit profits," Lin said.
During his three-year tenure as CSC chairman, Lin said he has introduced a number of new ideas, concepts and systems.

"Over the past three years, CSC has set a string of new records in production, sales, revenues and profits. Some people may attributed the achievements to a global steel boom. But I think I deserve some credits judging from the facts that CSC has broken 27 records in steel production and its affiliates have all set new records in sales and earnings," Lin said.

Lamenting that the enormous barrage of criticism over his stock bonus in the past two weeks has overshadowed him and his family, Lin said he has decided to quit to defend his personal dignity and integrity.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSC WILL NOT LOSE ANYTHING FROM INVESTING IN HIGH-SPEED RAIL: LIN

TEXT.P: Outgoing China Steel Corp. (CSC) Chairman Lin Wen-yuan said Saturday the company will not incurre any financial losses from its investment in the high-speed railway project.
"CSC has invested in preferred shares of Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC). This guarantees our gains from the investment, " Lin said.
Nevertheless, Lin said he feels regret that the high-speed rail project, like the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system, has been stigmatized and scandalized for political reasons.

As a civil engineer-turned-business executive, Lin said he is fully aware that the high-speed railway's civil engineer work is impeccable. Some opposition politicians have claimed that the rail system's civil engineering work was defective and awful.
Lin also defended CSC's investment in the problem-ridden Kaohsiung MRT system, saying that the investment has a long historical background. He didn't elaborate.
CSC, which used to be a state-owned enterprise but was privatized in 1995, holds a 31 percent stake in Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC).

KRTC has come under fire after an Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working for the project over unfair and unjust treatment by management. Judicial authorities are investigating whether any kickbacks or profiteering irregularities were involved in the project.
Lin said CSC will assume its responsibility if judicial authorities find it should be held responsible.
Lin announced his resignation from CSC chairmanship earlier in the day to quell controversies surrounding the stock bonus he has received as the company's chief executive officer (CEO).
Lin said he would donate all the stock bonus to charity organizations after deducting taxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 16, or the 14th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1758: Noah Webster, American lexicographer responsible for the first American dictionary, is born.
1793: The execution of Marie-Antoinette, 38, queen-consort of the late King Louis XVI, and the prospects of further executions by guillotine of both counter-revolutionaries and revolutionaries suggest that France is slipping even deeper into anarchy.
1846: American dentist William T. G. Morton successfully uses an anesthetic (diethyl ether) for the first time and removes a tumor from a young man's jaw at Massachusetts General Hospital.
1886: David Ben-Gurion, first prime minister of Israel, is born in Poland. He was a leading force in the creation of the Israeli state.
1906: British New Guinea becomes part of Australia.
1933: Republic of China government troops launch a fifth all-out offensive against communist rebels by adopting a fort-blockade policy of moving carefully and steadily in a step-by-step fashion.
1946: Ten leading Nazis found guilty some two weeks earlier of crimes against humanity by the International War Crimes Tribunal are hanged in the gymnasium of Nuremberg Prison.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek presents the Chinese communists with eight conditions for a nationwide cease-fire.
1949: The Kuomintang establishes the Revolutionary Practice Institute with party leader Chiang Kai-shek as its president.
1951: Liaquat Ali Khan, prime minister of Pakistan, is shot dead while addressing a public meeting in Rawalpindi.
1959: George C. Marshall, American soldier, diplomat and politician, dies at the age of 78. As U.S. secretary of state, he organized the European Recovery Program, often called the Marshall Plan, for which he received the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize.
1963: Ludwig Erhard succeeds Konrad Adenauer as chancellor of West Germany.
1964: Communist China explodes its first atom bomb at the Lop Nor test site in Sinkiang.
1972: President Dawda Kairbr Jawara of Gambia arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives a 30-member delegation of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. The group is headed by Eastern Washington State College President Emerson C. Shuck.
1978: Polish Cardinal Karol Wojtyla is elected pope, the first non-Italian pope since 1542 and the youngest this century.
1979: Wei Jingsheng, noted human rights activist in mainland China, is sentenced to 15 years imprisonment by a "people's court" in Beijing for "anti-revolutionary" activities.
1981: Moshe Dayan, Israeli politician and minister of defense, dies of a heart attack at the age of 66. He directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old mainland Chinese air force pilot, flies his MiG-19 to a U.S. military base outside Seoul in South Korea.
1982: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, 1970 Nobel Prize winner for literature, arrives in Taiwan from Tokyo at the invitation of the Wu San-lien Literary Foundation of the Republic of China.
1984: Chiang Nan, pen name of Chinese writer Liu Yi-liang, is shot and killed by an assassin at his home in San Francisco.
1987: The worst storm to hit Britain in 300 years lashes southern Britain, demolishing buildings, blacking out London and killing 18 people.
1989: A committee of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, meeting in Lausane, Switzerland, votes 76-11 in favor of a ban on international trade in ivory.
1999: The ROC navy's destroyer "Kunyang" is formally decommissioned after 31 years of service.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh says that he feels no remorse for having thrown his weight behind President Chen Shui-bian in the later stages of the presidential campaign in March of the same year.
2001: Taiwan atmospheric scientists successfully obtains vital typhoon data by flying two remote-control aircraft close to the depression's eyewall, a world first for any flying object collecting meteorological information.
2001: A Taipei delegation leaves for Indonesia to attend the 46th Asia Pacific Film Festival in Jakarta.
2001: Taiwan's Picvue Electronics, Ltd. invests US$12 million to engage in research and development of crystal display plates with two Scottish manufacturers.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, even when he is not doing anything, is serious; and, even when he does not speak, is truthful."

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DAMAGE REPORTED AFTER 7.0 QUAKE JOLTS N.E. TAIWAN

TEXT.P: No casualties or damage were reported in Taiwan as of Sunday morning after an earthquake with a magnitude of 7.0 on the open-ended Richter scale rattled northeastern Taiwan at 11: 51 p.m. the previous evening, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

Taiwan was spared from the major devastation that could have been caused by a 7.0 magnitude earthquake because it was centered far out to sea and deep -- with an epicenter around 185 km east of the northeastern city of Keelung and an undersea depth of 181.4 km, said Kuo Kai-wen, director of the CWB Seismology Center.
The temblor was the strongest earthquake monitored in the Taiwan area so far this year, equivalent to the energy released by the explosion of 16 atomic bombs at once, according to Kuo.

The quake was felt almost everywhere around the island. It had an intensity of 3.0 in Ilan, Hualien and Taitung counties in eastern Taiwan, Taichung County in central Taiwan and Miaoli County in western Taiwan; 2.0 in Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu counties in northern Taiwan and Nantou County in central Taiwan; 1.0 in Keelung City and Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties in southern Taiwan.
There was no danger of tsunamis because of the depth of the quake, Kuo added.

Taiwan sits on the Circum-Pacific Belt, which encompasses fault lines stretching from the coast of Chile to California and around through Japan and Taiwan. The belt is, along with the large European Alpida Belt, responsible for 95 out of every 100 earthquakes that occur around the world.

Taiwan experienced its deadliest earthquake in five decades Sept. 21, 1999, when a 7.6 magnitude temblor struck central Taiwan, killing 2,415 people and injuring more than 10,000. It also caused tremendous damage to property and infrastructure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOLD ANTI-AVIAN FLU EXERCISE

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will hold a supra-ministerial exercise Oct. 19 in which customs, coast guard, health, defense and transportation officials will take part in a simulation of fighting an outbreak of avian flu, COA officials said Sunday.
Participants in the exercise will simulate killing affected birds, burying or burning the culled birds, and managing their own health risks, according to the officials.

As the highly infectious disease has been found in recent years in Asia, Europe and the Americas, the COA said Taiwan must increase its preparations against a possible flu epidemic caused by the H5N1 virus.
Health experts have warned that if the virus mutates into a strain that can jump to humans and become infectious among humans, it could cause widespread chaos and heavy casualties.
Some Asian countries have already reported cases of bird flu and now is the season for migratory birds to pass through Taiwan in their journey south, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEOUL TO MAKE STANCE KNOWN OCT. 20 ON TAIWAN APEC REP CONTROVERSY
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: South Korea, the host of the 2005 informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, is expected to make its stance on Taiwan's representation at the summit known Oct. 20, diplomatic sources said Sunday.

South Korean Foreign Minister Ban Ki-moon is expected to make known the nation's position on whether it will accept Wang Jin-pyng, speaker of Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, who has been named by President Chen Shui-bian as his proxy at the summit to be held in Busan in November, sources said.
In line with long-established protocol, the 2005 APEC summit organizing committee sent a special APEC envoy to Taipei in July to forward an invitation to Chen.

Yun Hai-Jung visited Taipei again Oct. 12 to meet with Chen to put the final touches on Taiwan's presentation at the summit. Chen reportedly told Yun during the meeting that he looked forward to attending the summit meeting in the name of the leader of "Chinese Taipei" -- Taiwan's official APEC designation.

Wang's appointment turned into a controversial issue after Beijing voiced its opposition, complaining that Taiwan can only be represented at APEC-related activities by officials responsible for economic affairs.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that admit both Taipei and Beijing. Because of Beijing's opposition, the Republic of China's head of state has been unable to attend previous APEC annual informal leadership meetings and has instead had to name a proxy to attend on his behalf. Lee Yuan-tseh, Nobel laureate and the president of nation's highest research institute Academia Sinica, has represented Chen over the past few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Christian Democratic Union party secretary general Marco Follini quits.
Christian Democratic Union (UDC) party secretary general Marco Follini announced his resignation Saturday in the party's National Council meeting. He criticized the party for being tarnished and submissive. His criticism was soon rebutted by other party members in the government. The UDC is one of the four-party ruling coalition.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE ACTIVIST GROUPS OPPOSE CHINA'S PANDA GIFT

TEXT.P: A group of social and environmental activist groups voiced opposition Sunday to the idea of Taiwan accepting two pandas that China is planning to give to Taiwan as a "gift."
The activists argued that only by allowing pandas to live and reproduce in their natural, original habitat can the endangered animals be protected.

The activists, representing the Environment and Animal Society of Taiwan (EAST) , the Society of Wildlife and Nature (SWAN) , the Homemakers' Union and Foundation, the Humanistic Education Foundation and the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan, stressed that keeping pandas in Taiwan would be counter to the ideals of wildlife protection.
They said that if the Taiwan people indeed like pandas, they should seek to adopt the animals by offering financial support while allowing the animals to stay in their natural habitat.

The Taipei city government has been making plans to house the pandas in the city zoo, where a 5,500-square-foot enclosure will be built for the pair with a donation of NT$200 million from the Shinkong Group.

But according to EAST President Chu Tseng-hung, China's panda conservation authorities in Sichuan Province have expanded their panda enclosure to a semi-open area in excess of 240,000 square feet, while maintaining a semi-open environment for pandas requires only about one-sixteenth of the cost of housing them indoors.

SWAN Secretary-General Tsai Hui-ching suggested that if Taiwan accepts the pandas, it should make sure the animals are kept in their natural habitat in Sichuan and could send students or researchers there to learn and monitor the animals.

Beijing first mentioned sending a pair of the endangered animals to Taiwan as a so-called "goodwill gesture" following a visit to China by former opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan in late April.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP PEACE BILL DESCRIBED AS ECHO OF BEIJING'S WILL

TEXT.P: Ketagalan Institute Director Lee Hung-hsi brushed aside Sunday a cross-Taiwan Strait peace promotion bill proposed by the opposition People First Party (PFP) , saying that it codifies Beijing's "one China" principle and echoes China's will-to-power over Taiwan.

Commenting at a Ketagalan Institute forum on an upcoming showdown at the Legislative Yuan over the bill, Lee said that a bill that involves the Constitution and sovereignty should not be decided upon solely by the legislature.
Instead, Lee said, the issue should be tackled by all of the people of Taiwan, promoted via a bottom-up approach.
He said it is "simply wrong" that an opposition-dominated legislature can control and manipulate a bill in such a way.

Most importantly, Lee claimed, in the face of China's increasing hostility toward Taiwan, it is unforgivably wrong that Taiwan's legislators are trying to rein in Taiwan independence ideology via legislation.

You Ying-lung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, told the forum that even if the PFP version clears the floor of the Legislative Yuan, it will not help solve the cross-strait dispute and create peace.
He added that the government is not opposed to the legislation of a law aimed at promoting peace across the Taiwan Strait, but the PFP-proposed bill is definitely not what the country wants.

DOC.HEADLINE: LACK OF DRUGS, VACCINES TAIWAN'S ACHILLES HEEL IN FIGHTING AVIAN FLUBy S.C. ChangCNA Staff Reporter

TEXT.P: As the world prepares itself to battle an avian flu epidemic, Taiwan is grappling with a lack of drugs and vaccines and working hard to find solutions to the shortages.

Before the solutions can be reached, the government is adopting a "four-cordons" defense strategy to keep the much-feared H5N1 virus and its possible mutations from entering the country -- stopping it offshore, at customs, in communities, and within the health care system.

The Department of Health said it has stockpiled only 160,000 doses of Tamiflu, a drug seen to be effective against H5N1, far short of the 5 million that it estimates the country needs to fight a bird flu outbreak.

As the patent owner of Tamiflu, Roche Holding AG, is not yet ready to release the patent to the World Health Organization (WHO) , the government must resolve the patent issue before the National Health Research Institute (NHRI) , which has the technology to make Tamiflu, can help local drug manufacturers mass produce the drug.

Officials said that acquiring and stockpiling Tamiflu is not Taiwan's problem alone; many countries have asked the WHO to persuade Roche into giving up the patent. Roche is willing only to "donate" a certain amount of the drug to the WHO, they said.

Taiwan could go ahead with producing Tamiflu before getting a permit to do so. Taiwan could also follow its own stockpiling action by negotiating terms of compensation to the patent owner. At the same time, the DOH is looking to buy another anti-flu drug called Relenza, which is more expensive than Tamiflu.

A DOH official said Taiwan cannot reply on just one or two drugs to fight avian flu. "We will revise our stockpiling policy as we see fit, " said Lin Ting, deputy director of the Center for Disease Control under DOH.

Another way of fighting a bird flu epidemic is to vaccinate the population. Taiwan needs 4 million flu vaccines every year. Last month, Europe's largest drug manufacturer, Sanofi-Aventis, indicated to Taiwan that it had signed a contract with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to invest US$100 million in producing avian flu vaccine.
The company's Taiwan branch said the vaccine that Sanofi-Aventis is aiming to produce has been tested on 400 people for preventing H5N1 infection, with good results.

As of the end of September, only two drug makers in the world had announced a successful testing of anti-avian flu vaccine. But neither of them have a large-scale human testing report, and even if their R&D proves effective, Taiwan would have to vie with a host of other countries waiting to buy the new product.
Therefore, Taiwan should set up its own vaccine-producing facilities to avoid over-dependency on other countries, health officials said.

Taiwan's research institutes have been cooperating with foreign partners in the study of H5N1 vaccines. For instance, the NHRI is in the preliminary stage of building a vaccine plant, while the DOH Center for Disease Control is planning to match domestic and foreign drug makers in joint-venture projects to mass produce vaccines in Taiwan starting in 2010.

Lin Lung-tsan, bio-medical research project manager at the Institute of Industrial Research, said setting up a production facility in Taiwan would be best for national security, as foreign manufacturers, out of market consideration, might not make their vaccines exclusively for fighting the virus strains hitting Asian countries.

As the weather is gradually turning colder and migratory birds are flying to Taiwan on their journey south, health authorities are reminding people to maintain good hygiene, such as washing hands, avoiding uncooked meat and eggs and wearing masks in public places.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP: PEACE BILL WOULD ALLOW PEOPLE TO MONITOR CROSS-STRAIT POLICY

TEXT.P: In response to ruling camp criticism of the opposition People First Party's (PFP's) cross-Taiwan Strait peace promotion bill, PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said the bill is aimed at speeding up peaceful interaction between the two sides of the strait and enabling Taiwan's people to monitor cross-strait policy.
Hsieh accused the DPP of "smearing" the PFP bill in an attempt to divert the public's attention from the ruling party's scandal-ridden administrative record.

He said the bill contains a proposal for setting up a peace-promotion committee staffed with ruling and opposition members, an idea that was originally put forward by President Chen Shui-bian himself.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said the PFP has been acting in concert with Beijing's "three-step" strategy to assimilate Taiwan -- first, legislating the Anti-Secession Law; then, inviting Kuomintang and PFP leaders to visit China; and seeing the PFP propose its peace-promotion bill.
The PFP bill completes China's "three-step strategy" to swallow Taiwan, Su said, warning that if the bill is passed, Taiwan will never be a sovereign country.

According to Su, accepting China's "one China" principle and its version of the so-called 1992 consensus, as proposed in the PFP bill, would mean that Taiwan would become a special administrative region of China like Hong Kong, something that no-one is willing to accept in Taiwan.

Hsieh said the 1992 consensus and "four-noes policy" have been reiterated time and again by the DPP government and its predecessor, the KMT government, and that he does not understand why the DPP keeps distorting these two policy goals.

He claimed that the PFP is willing to negotiate with all other parties on the details of the bill in order to reach a consensus, but said the time has already passed for such negotiations, so that PFP must insist on pushing the bill through the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGOTIATIONS TO BE HELD ON NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION BILL

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng will chair negotiations among the political parties Monday on a controversial bill that has pitted the ruling Democratic Progressive Party against the bill's authors, the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party.

The sticking point in the bill, which calls for the establishment of a national communications commission, is the appointment of the members of the proposed commission. The opposition insists that the members should be named by the various political parties in the legislature in proportion to the number of seats they hold in the legislature.
However, the DPP believes the members should be chosen and named by the Executive Yuan.

Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, the whip of the KMT legislative caucus, claimed Sunday that giving political parties a say in choosing the commission's members would keep it independent of the ruling party's manipulation.

An independent communications commission charged with regulating the country's media is vital to keeping the government from meddling with the media and to ensuring the freedom of the press, the KMT lawmaker claimed.
However, Tseng said his party would like to hear the DPP's opinions about how to sort out the differences between the two sides.

The DPP, which has twice blocked a showdown vote on the bill in the legislature by violence, said it will offer in Monday's negotiations to have the members chosen jointly by the Executive Yuan and the legislature rather than by the Executive Yuan alone.

Dismissing the DPP's offer as nothing new, PFP legislator Sun Ta-chien said the ruling party should promise not to resort to violence in the legislature before any meaningful negotiations can take place.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL ELECTION ASPIRANTS JUMP GUN TO START CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: With one-and-a-half months to go before the year-end elections of county and city chiefs, county and city councilors and chiefs of rural townships, many election aspirants started their election campaigns Sunday, well ahead of the legal period when they are allowed to do so.

Teng Tien-you, a spokesman of the Central Election Commission (CEC), said Sunday that local governments should restrict candidates' campaigns until the legal period, which according to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, is 10 days before the elections.

As the candidates' campaign rallies, billboards, and campaign trucks are already common around the island, Teng said violators can be fined according to the law concerning noise, advertising billboards and parades and rallies.

Meanwhile the CEC unveiled Sunday an amendment to the existing laws to allow televised debates among candidates for county and city chiefs, if two-thirds of the candidates in the same constituency agree to it, although some constituencies had already staged such debates Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSPECTS DIM FOR LOW-INCOME FAMILIES: YOUTH COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Children of low-income families have fewer opportunities to get education, and poor education in turn leads to poorer-paying jobs or even keeps them from getting jobs, making the prospects for them to get out of poverty dimmer and dimmer, according to the National Youth Commission.

The commission quoted a Ministry of the Interior survey as showing that 31.9 percent of people aged 15 or above with high school or higher education come from low-income families, while 58.2 percent are from other families, indicating that there is room for improving education opportunities for members of low-income families.

It quoted another survey as showing that 74.3 percent of people aged 15 or higher in low-income families are not working, much higher than the 45 percent in other families. The survey also shows that 30 percent of low-income families are single-parent.

The commission said the gap between rich and poor in Taiwan has been widening in recent years, as has the gap of education opportunities and resources, making it ever more difficult for the poor to get out of poverty.

Some social groups blamed the government's high tuition policy for widening the rich-poor gap. They cited government statistics as saying that over the past 10 years, tuition for public and private universities has risen 70 percent and 20 percent respectively while the overall consumer price index has gone up only 10 percent.
Lin Po-yi, a graduate student of social science at National Chengchi University, said tuition has been rising faster than children of poor families can ever hope to catch up.

He quoted Taipei City government figures as reporting that in August, pawnshops lent out a total of NT$227 million, more than any other month, with the average loan at NT$50,000 to NT$60,000, "precisely the amount for paying university tuition."
Moreover, he pointed out, children of poor families often have to work through the university years, knowing that without a university degree it will be difficult for them to find jobs.

Lee Chun-ta, a philosophy major of Soochow University, said he uses up his NT$50,000 student loan every semester, accumulating a debt of NT$500,000 before graduating; and to make his own living, he has to work 100 hours a month in order to earn a wage of NT$10,000.

Lin and Lee, attending a seminar on high tuition and the declining value of degrees, said education supposedly will give poor people a chance to improve their fortunes, and yet they are being burdened by the high cost of higher education.

The participants quoted government statistics as pointing out that 7,129 college and university students asked for a long leave of absence on economic grounds in academic year 2003, up from 2,664 in 1998.

They further cited Ministry of Education figures as saying that in 1993, the government spent an average of NT$200,500 on each university student, but the amount fell 26 percent to NT$150,000 in 2002.
This means that while uinversities are charging sutdents higher tuition than ever, the educational resources they are getting in return are shrinking, they said.
If the Ministry of Education does not figure out ways to re-allocate resources, the rich will get richer and the poor will simply copy poverty generation after generation, they claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PANNED FOR OBLIGING PARTY PUBLIC OFFICIALS TO DONATE TO IT

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was lambasted by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Sunday for obliging party public office holders to give a part of their income to the party as its war chest for campaigns.

KMT Legislator Pan Wei-kang claimed the DPP's practice of forcing public office holders to contribute to its campaign funds is running against the law governing the political donations, and provides the DPP a chance to line its pocket with the government funds.

Pan made the comment after Lin Wen-yuan, the DPP-appointed chairman of the China Steel Corporation, caused an alarm after newspaper reports said he earned about 1.6 million shares of his company as bonus-- with a market price of about NT$40 million-- during his three-year in office.

Lin quit his job and donated his bonus to charity Saturday three days after 93 lawmakers, mainly from the DPP, asked him to return the bonus. These lawmakers claimed that as a chairman who owed his post to the government, Lin is not entitled to the bonus meant to reward the professional managers.

Before Lin gave up his post, news reports said Lin had difficult returning his bonus because part of it has already been diverted to the DPP as political donations according to a DPP mechanism which forces DPP public office holders to share the party's expense.
KMT Legislator Joanna Lei said the DPP is sponging on the government through officials appointed by it for political purposes.

Independent Legislator Chiu Yi claimed Lin is not the only one who share his income with the party, Chen Min-hsien, the former vice chairman of Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corporation who quit because of financial scandal is also suspected of giving political donations to DPP in exchange for government's preference in awarding contracts, and the DPP owes the public an explanation.

DOC.HEADLINE: POETS, SONGSTERS SEND ANTI-WAR MESSAGES FROM KINMEN

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan poets and song writers gathered at a fortification in Kuningtou, where the Nationalist and Communist troops massacred each other in the 1950s, to send their anti-war messages to people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait Sunday.

Hu Teh-fu, Lin Huan-chang, Kuan Kuan, Pai Ling and others read their poems and sang songs of peace in the event dubbed "the crossing of thunder and buds, " part of the 2005 Kinmen Cultural and Arts Festival activities.
Facing Xiamen, China, Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng said 10 years ago, he had to travel 2,000 km via Hong Kong or Macao to visit the Chinese city which is but 10 km away.

Now, he needs just to take a boat under the government's "mini- three links" program to travel to Xiamen, he said, adding that the triangular fort that used to see ROC-PRC confrontations has been turned into an arts exhibition ground.

Song writer Hu Teh-fu, a Pei-nan tribe aboriginal, said his wife Mo Wa is from the Pu-nong tribe, which had been in war with Pei-nan for more than 200 years before both tribes finally learned to live in peace.

"So the tens of years of military confrontation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is nothing compared with the long history of war between the two aboriginal tribes. The Han Chinese should learn from Taiwan's aborigines as to how to live in peace together, " Hu said.
The Hu couple sang a number of native-language songs and U.S. anti-war song "Where Have All the Flowers Gone" to express their wishes for peace.

Some of the poets had served as soldiers on the "front-line" islets, writing poems commemorating their life and thoughts during that time, poems that they read aloud to share with the audience and the people on both sides of the Strait Sunday.

The poems included Lin Huan Chang's "Waiting, " Pai Ling's "The Drowning Line near the Triangular Fort, " Kuan Kuan's "A Pear Tree from a Ming Dynasty Village in Kinmen, " and A Tun's "When the Bullet Shoots Through My Left Chest."

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Monday, October 17:

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Rice: Iraq Consititution Likely Approved;
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Sunday initial assessments indicate that Iraqis had probably approved a controversial constitution, although the turnout alone showed the fragile new political process has taken hold despite a deadly insurgency.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DEFENDS HIS POLICY IN TV INTERVIEW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made a pitch Sunday for the six reforms spelled out in his National Day address on Oct. 10, and defended his administration which was dogged by scandals recently.

In an interview with a cable TV station, the SETTV, the president took pains to defend Lin Wen-yuan, who was named by Chen's administration as the Chairman of the China Steel Corporation three years ago but quit the previous day after being criticized for taking huge bonus from the corporation.
The president said it is the practice which rewards generously the executives of corporations which should be blamed, not Lin himself.

The president also defended his former adviser Chen Che-nan who was embroiled in the scandal surrounding the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corporation, saying Chen gave up his post as his adviser at the hint of the president's aide.
The president said his administration examines its officials by the highest moral standards.

He also took pains to explain the necessity for the six reforms, namely the financial reform, tax reform, reform to change the preferential interest rates for retired government officials, media reform, investigation into properties inappropriately seized by political parties, and constitutional reform.
As to the financial reform which was criticized for letting a few business groups to take over the state-run banks, the president urged the public to respect the principle of laissez-faire.
In order to highlight his determination to press ahead of the financial reform, the president said any member of his ruling team who is not confident of carrying out the reform should quit.

Chen took a jab at the opposition which initiated a controversial bill on the organization of a national communications commission during his explanation of this media reform, saying the opposition's idea of the commission runs against the practice of advanced countries.
The TV station broadcast only the first part of the president's interview on Sunday, the second party will be aired on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 17, or the 15th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Charles II, King of England, sells Dunkirk to the French.
1849: Frederic Chopin, Polish-born French composer and virtuoso pianist of the romantic era, dies of tuberculosis in Paris at the age of 39. His music, written chiefly for the piano, is noted for its expressiveness.
1855: Englishman Henry Bessemer patents his process for making steel.
1912: The first Balkan War breaks out when Bulgaria, Serbia and Greece declare war on Turkey.
1919: Zhao Ziyang, former Chinese Communist Party chief, is born. As prime minister in the 1980s, he pioneered bold economic reforms. He was swept from power in the political crisis sparked by the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations centered in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
1920: Hsieh Wen-ta, Taiwan's first aviator, flies his aircraft over Taichung in central Taiwan.
1945: The first batch of ROC government troops aboard some 40 U.S. Navy ships arrives at Keelung in Taiwan, which reverts back to Chinese rule after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1956: Calder Hall, Britain's first nuclear power station, is opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
1963: The Hong Kong government sets up the Chinese University of Hong Kong.
1964: Construction of a cross-harbor bridge on Penghu (the Pescadores) is started.
1966: Lesotho and Botswana are admitted into the United Nations.
1967: Henry Puyi, formerly Hsuan Tung, the last Ching ruler, dies in Beijing at the age of 61.
1972: President Park Chung Hee declares martial law in South Korea.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center is inaugurated in Shanhua in southern Taiwan.
1973: The ten Arab members of OPEC announce an enormous 70 percent hike in oil prices and a cutback in production in response to America's support for Israel in the Yom Kippur War.
1974: The Asian Christian Federation opens its first conference on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei with 200 delegates from 15 Asian countries attending.
1977: Akira Nishiyama, former Japanese ambassador to South Korea, arrives in Taiwan to assume his duties as director of the Japan Interchange Association's Taipei office.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for caring for the world's "unwanted and unloved."
1981: A group of more than 100 former officers of the U.S. Air Force's 14th squadron, better known as the Flying Tigers, arrives in Taipei to visit Chinese friends.
1989: An earthquake rocks northern California, killing more than 60 people.
1994: Israel and Jordan initial a historic peace treaty, ending their 46-year state of war.
1995: The Republic of China and Macau establish a five-year renewable air pact allowing Eva Airways, TransAsia Airways and Air Macau to fly routes between Taiwan and Macau.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks security chief Alexander Lebed one day after Lebed is accused of building his own army in an attempt to seize power.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan calls on Cardinal Paul Shan to express gratitude for the 921 earthquake relief assistance provided by the Catholic community in Taiwan.
2000: The Republic of China's Central News Agency enters into an agreement with France's Agency France-Press at a ceremony that ROC Vice President Annette Lu says signifies Taiwan's future leadership role in global Chinese news networks.
2001: The two-day ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum begins in Shanghai with foreign ministers, trade ministers and representatives from the 21 member economies participating.
2001: The 2001 Taipei International Electronics Products Exhibition opens with 806 domestic and foreign manufacturers participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, without the inducement of rewards, is able to make the people good; and without a show of anger, to awe them into fear more than if he had used the most dreadful instruments of punishment."

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC VICE CHAIRMAN SEES A BRIGHT FUTURE FOR ROC-E.U. COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A high-ranking official of the Republic of China's National Science Council (NSC) said Sunday that he hopes to see better and further scientific and technological cooperation between Taiwan and member states of the European Union in the future.

Shieh Ching-jyh, vice chairman of the council under the Executive Yuan, at the head of a seven-member NSC delegation, arrived in Milan earlier in the day to seek cooperation with those in the local science and technology circles.

The vice chairman said in a telephone interview with the CNA that as the E.U. is expected to start from 1997 its scientific research and development "Framework Program 7, " he and his delegation's current tour in Europe is aimed at seeking E.U. members to jointly put forward research plans with Taiwan to the E.U. headquarters.
"I hope that Taiwan and E.U. nations can better their understanding and opportunities of further cooperation in the future through direct contact, " he said.

According to Hsieh, about 40 percent of all the research projects jointly proposed by Taiwan and E.U. member states have been accepted by the E.U. headquarters, which he said is much higher than the headquarters' average acceptance rate of 19 percent for other projects.
"This is why many E.U. members now would like to cooperate with Taiwan," he added.

Even though Taiwan cannot gain any subsidies from the E.U. authorities if joint projects put forward by the island and its E.U. partners are accepted, Taiwan's development in science and technology can make strong and rapid progress through international cooperation, and that's why the ROC government has actively worked on pushing the internationalization of the country's research in science and technology.

He further said that despite the fact that Taiwan has only had minor cooperation with Italy in science and technology in past years, the great achievement of the Italians in creative design and the remarkable performance of Taiwan in creativity as well as in research and development, particularly in the information technology sector, will "surely provide a huge amount of room for the two countries to cooperate."

In Milan, Hsieh and members of the delegation will meet with members of the local science and technology community in a workshop set to be held Monday at Politechnic University of Milan. They will also visit the design college of the university before heading to Poland later the same day.
Italy is the fourth leg of Shieh and his delegation's current tour in Europe, which has already taken them to Britain, Belgium and Spain.

Shieh said that a cooperation project between Taiwan and Spain is expected to be completed within the coming one or two months and that Taiwan's Representative Office in Poland is also expected to set up a science and technology division at the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: PNP firm on rally policy
The Philippine National Police (PNP) led by Director-General Arturo Lomibao is determined to impose the "no permit, no rally" policy of the government amid criticisms and legal challenges hurled by several sectors following the violent dispersal operation of an alleged religious mass action near Mendiola Street in Manila last Friday night.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Fight between Arroyo and Church looms, says bishop
A BISHOP drenched with a water cannon last Friday said the police dispersal of a religious procession was likely to unify prelates in what he described yesterday as a looming battle between the Holy Spirit and President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo.
The Philippine Star: Allies urge GMA: Review CPR
Two pro-administration congressmen from Mindanao urged President Arroyo yesterday to review the government's controversial "calibrated preemptive response" or CPR policy in the wake of clashes between the police and street protesters.
The Manila Times: Dispersal threatens Church-Palace truce
THE dispersal of a rally near Malacanang on Friday could disrupt the fragile truce between the Arroyo administration and the Catholic Church.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The China Times: Lepers in Taiwan and South Korea confined by Japan before World War II may claim compensation from Tokyo authorities.
The United Daily News: President Chen offers to waive executive immunity and subject himself to investigation if found to have any involvement in KRTC scandal.
The Liberty Times: President urges voters to wake up KMT with ballots.
The Taiwan Daily: President urges voters to make KMT get tough with China with ballots.
The Central Daily News: Ma: DPP rapidly sinking into corruption.

The Taiwan News: Chen promises to tackle scandals
The Taipei Times: US ratchets up the pressure on Iran

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Singapore team produces early alert cancer test.
A research team here has developed a new, accurate cancer test kit, which can give warning signs of the disease years before the first physical signs appear by detecting minute chemical changes in a patient's DNA.
The Institute of Molecular and Cell Biology ( IMCB) team, which counts top-notch Japanese cancer researcher Professor Yoshiaki Ito as its adviser, has been working with electronics giant Hitachi on the joint project since April last year.
The Lianhe Zaobao: 2007: A Singaporean National Day Parade on water.
The annual National Day Parade will be take to a new floating stage to be build on the waters of Marina Bay from 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Putin Praises 'Ruthless' Operation
President Vladimir Putin vowed to show no mercy toward insurgents and praised law enforcement agencies for their ruthlessness in quashing a raid by scores of militants in the Kabardino-Balkarian capital of Nalchik.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Iraq charter seen passing despite high Sunni turnout
Iraq's Constitution seemed assured of passage Sunday despite strong opposition from Sunni Arabs who turned out in surprisingly high numbers in an effort to stop it.
