Los Angeles Times: Sunnis Join Millions for Iraq Charter Vote.
Sunnis Arabs voted in large numbers Saturday in a nationwide referendum on a new constitution , injecting a measure of uncertainty into the fate of the U.S.-backed charter that Iraq's disaffected minority had largely condemned.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD TIGHTENING BORDER CONTROLS AGAINST BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) has tightened border controls aimed at barring the entrance of smuggled poultry and meat to try to prevent the spread of avian flu to Taiwan as the world prepares to battle a possible bird flu pandemic, CGA officials reported Monday.

The CGA is also preparing to activate an anti-bird flu contingency plan based on a "four-cordons" defense strategy mapped out by the Council of Agriculture (COA) to keep the much-feared H5N1 strain of the virus and any possible mutations from entering the country -- stopping it offshore, at customs, in communities, and within the health care system.

The "four-cordons" defense strategy is a set of measures similar to those adopted in the country two years ago during the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak in Taiwan and neighboring countries, the officials said.
Members of the front-line coast guard force have been instructed with health and quarantine protection tips and are ready to further strengthen controls against smuggling, CGA officials said.

Experts from the COA Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine have given lectures to the CGA patrollers on quarantine efforts and how to bolster their own protection during patrolling missions.

The deadly H5N1 strain has decimated flocks around Asia and killed dozens of people. Authorities around the world fear it could mutate into a deadly form of the flu that is easily transmitted among humans, leading to a pandemic which some say could kill millions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 142.8 points to close at 5,826.27.
The bourse opened at 5,990.23 and fluctuated between 5,991.35 and 5,826.27 during trading. A total of 3.02 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$69.21 billion (US$2.06 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.9 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 2.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 2.7 percent, construction issues at 2.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.9 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.7 percent, and cement stocks and foodstuff issues both at 1.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 941 to 98, with 71 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Iraqi Constitution Appears Headed For Voter Approval; Sunni Opposition Is Seen Falling Short.
Iraq's war-battered voters apparently approved a new constitution in voting Saturday, preliminary and unofficial results showed Sunday, but disaffected Sunni Arabs proved unexpectedly formidable in their first venture into post-Saddam Hussein politics with a strong vote against the U.S.-backed charter, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prodi leads in opposition leader primary.
Former prime minister Romano Prodi is leading overwhelmingly in the primary organized by the opposition center-left Union Sunday. Prodi obtained with 74.6% of votes after more than 90 percent of ballots cast in the one-day primary were scrutinized. A total of seven candidates were in the race for the opposition leader election which attracted a turnout of more than 4 million supporters around the nation. The voting ended at 10:00 p.m. local time.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE' PROTESTS AND 'PAN-GREEN' WELCOME AWAIT LEE IN D.C.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: "Pan-blue" Taiwanese expatriates in the United States are preparing a series of demonstrations against former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's upcoming visit to Washington, D.C., while "pan-green" supporters are getting ready to give Lee a royal welcome.
Taiwan's former head of state is scheduled to arrived in the U.S. capital Monday for the third leg of his two-week private visit to the United States.
Ahead of Lee's arrival, the "pan-blue" expatriates and "pan-green" expatriates each placed an ad in the Chinese-language Washington News daily.

The ad placed by the "pan-greens" featured a grand welcome to "President Lee Teng-hui -- Mr. Taiwan Democracy and our hero, " while the "pan-blue" ad read "Lee Teng-hui, you are not welcomed in the U.S." The two ads were published on the same page in the Sunday edition of the daily.

"Pan-blue" refers to the "pan-blue alliance" of the two largest opposition parties in Taiwan, namely the Kuomintang and the People First Party, and the tiny pro-unification New Party, while "pan-green" means the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and some pro-independent political parties, including the Taiwan Solidarity Union which regards Lee as its spiritual leader.

Meanwhile, the Washington, D.C.-headquartered Formosa Association for Public Affairs is organizing a grand welcome dinner party at the Hilton Washington hotel Oct. 19. Hundreds of Taiwanese expatriates are expected to attend the $100-a-plate dinner.

At the same time, the "pan-blues" have planned two separate protest demonstrations, with one set to take place Oct. 19 in front of the Hiton Washington hotel, and the other to take place in front of the National Press Club Oct. 20 when Lee is scheduled to deliver a speech there.
Lee will stay in Washington, D.C. Oct. 17-20 before heading to Los Angeles, the last leg of his U.S. trip that has already taken him to Anchorage, Alaska and New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INITIATE BIRD FLU MEDICATION PROJECT AT APEC MEETINGS: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan is planning to initiate an anti-avian flu medication development project during the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum meetings, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Monday.

A series of APEC meetings, including an informal leadership summit, is scheduled to be held in South Korea's second largest city of Busan in November. The prevention and control of bird flu is expected to be one of the major issues to be tackled during the APEC meetings.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Kau said that Taiwan is aiming to propose that distribution of anti-bird flu medication and development of such medication, including the development of bird flu vaccines, can be promoted via the APEC mechanism.

Kau said that APEC has perceived the gravity of a possible global pandemic of bird flu and believes that the development of bird flu vaccines is a pressing issue. Against this backdrop, Kau said, Taiwan should propose that a bird flu vaccine development plan be initiated by selected APEC countries which have ready and commendable medical research strength, such as Taiwan.

Kau pointed out, however, that since the development of bird flu vaccines will be a costly and painstaking task which will require the concerted efforts of several nations, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is currently contacting Japan, South Korea and the United States about the plan in the hopes that bird flu vaccine development project can be initiated jointly by these countries.

The world is gearing up to battle a possible bird flu pandemic as the deadly H5N1 strain has decimated flocks around Asia and killed dozens of people there. Authorities around the world fear it could mutate into a deadly form of the flu that is easily transmitted among humans, leading to a pandemic which some say could kill millions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO REVIEW AWARDING OF BONUSES TO GOV'T-APPOINTED EXECS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh vowed Monday to review the current practice in which government-appointed executives in state-controlled companies receive lucrative bonuses from the companies they serve.

Two days after Lin Wen-yuan, chairman of the China Steel Corp. (CSC), quit his post amid criticism over the NT$44 million worth of stock he earned in bonuses from the company, the premier said it is the established practice of offering such generous rewards to the managers that should be criticized, and not Lin himself.
Hsieh said his administration will make changes to the state-controlled enterprises' established practice of giving managers bonuses in addition to their lucrative salaries.
The premier added that his administration wouldn't resist any changes as long as they improve the current system.
Lin's critics said he is not entitled to the bonus because he was appointed to his job by the government which is the biggest stake holder in CSC.

Lin donated his bonus to charity before tendering his resignation Saturday. Prior to his resignation, he pointed out that the practice of awarding bonuses to managers is common among local businesses. Many other government-appointed managers in state-controlled companies have also received such bonuses, but he was singled out as the whipping boy.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN SHOULD ADDRESS ITS WARTIME PAST SQUARELY: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Monday expressed the hope that Japan would address its wartime past squarely in the wake of Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visit to a controversial war shrine in Tokyo.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks shortly after Koizumi paid his fifth visit to the Yasukuni Shrine since taking office in April 2001. The shrine honors 2.5 million Japanese war dead, including some notorious Class-A war criminals. Koizumi's visit to the shrine has caused vehement protests from neighboring countries that suffered tremendously during Japanese invasions in World War II. This year's visit takes on special significance as this is the 60th anniversary of the end of the World War II.

Lu said that Taiwan and Japan have friendly relations, and both sides should work toward strengthening bilateral ties. On Koizumi's controversial visit, he expressed the hope that Japan can address history squarely and be forward-looking.
As a big power in East Asia and the second-largest economy in the world, Japan has the ability as well as responsibility to play a pivotal role in regional and world peace and stability, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH COULD PRODUCE FLU DRUG LOCALLY IN PANDEMIC

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has contingency plans to help Taiwan secure enough medication against a possible pandemic of avian flu, a health department official said Monday.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO) , "Vaccines effective against a pandemic virus are not yet available. Vaccines are produced each year for seasonal influenza but will not protect against pandemic influenza. Although a vaccine against the H5N1 virus is under development in several countries, no vaccine is ready for commercial production and no vaccines are expected to be widely available until several months after the start of a pandemic."

However, the seasonal flu drug commercially known as "Tamiflu, " could improve the survival prospects of persons infected with the H5N1 virus, if it is administered in a timely fashion, according to the WHO.

With this in mind, Liao Chi-chou, director of the DOH Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, said Taiwan's health department has earmarked NT$400 million (US$11. 97 million) to be used next year to purchase Tamiflu and materials, should a pandemic occur. Half of the money will go toward buying Tamiflu from its manufacturer, the Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche, and half will be used to purchase raw materials from the company to produce the drug in Taiwan.
As the world gears up to battle a possible bird flu pandemic, Taiwan is grappling with a lack of drugs and vaccines and working hard to find solutions to the shortages, he said.

The health department has contracted the Taiwan Clinical Pharmacy Association to provide training courses to local pharmacies around the country, including those on outlying islands, to enable them to know how to formulate the drug before the end of the year, Liao noted.

Health department authorities said Sunday that they have stockpiled only 160, 000 doses of Tamiflu, far short of the five million that it estimates the country would need to fight a bird flu pandemic.

As the weather is gradually turning colder and migratory birds are flying to Taiwan to overwinter, health authorities are reminding people to maintain good hygiene, such as washing their hands and avoiding uncooked meat and eggs.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION DISMISSES PRESIDENT'S OFFER TO GIVE UP IMMUNITY

TEXT.P: Opposition lawmakers on Monday dismissed as political rhetoric President Chen Shui-bian's offer the previous night to give up his executive immunity and to subject himself to judicial investigation if there is evidence suggesting he was involved in the mushrooming scandal around the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corporation (KRTC).

Cheng Li-wen, a spokeswoman for the opposition Kuomintang, said the president's immunity from judicial investigation is provided in the Constitution and cannot be waived, and any university freshman who has studied the Constitution would know this.
Cheng said the prosecutors would break the Constitution by investigating the president for any crime other than rebellion or treason.

Chen's offer to give up his immunity, made in an interview with a local cable TV station, is political rhetoric intended to pull the wool over the eyes of people who don't know the contents of the Constitution, the spokeswoman said.

Legislator Sun Ta-chian from the opposition People First Party said Chen's offer highlighted the president's intention to stop speculation about his role in the scandal rather than his determination to mend his ways, but "it is doomed to be useless."
Chen's statement won't help clear the image of himself and his party, Sun claimed.

Annoyed by speculation suggesting his role in the KRTC scandal, the president said last night that he has recommended that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party form a commission to look into corruption allegations regarding any party members.
The president said he would step down if he were found to be involved in the case despite his executive immunity.

However, the country's prosecutor-general, Wu Ying-chao, told the legislature Monday morning that the president's constitutional right cannot be waived, adding that the president's statement was meant to give a free hand to prosecutors investigating the KRTC scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 153 points to close at 5,815, with 26,245 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 149 points to end at 5,820, with 12,663 contracts traded, while December futures lost 149 points to finish at 5,821, with 81 contracts traded. March futures moved down 155 points to close at 5,815, with 20 contracts traded, while June futures moved down 113 points to close at 5,850, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,968 for October, 5,969 for November, 5,970 for December, 5,970 for March and 5,963 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

October TE futures moved down 7.8 points to close at 239.4, with 4,249 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost eight points to finish at 239.5, with 1,946 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down five points to end at 243, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

October TF futures lost 17.4 points to finish at 887, with 4,787 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 17.8 points to end at 887.8, with 3,352 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 14 points to close at 890.8, with 16 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR REMAINS UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar remained unchanged against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday to close at NT$33.450.
A total of US$568 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.450 and fluctuated between NT$33.355 and NT$33.495.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY HOSPITAL OFFERS TRANSLATION SERVICES TO NEW IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Hospital has formed a new section to offer language translation services to new immigrants, specifically local people's Vietnamese and Indonesian spouses, to help them communicate with physicians and healthcare personnel.
Any immigrant who needs a translator when going to see a doctor can first made a request by calling 02-2192-6068 ext. 2813, officials of the Taipei City Department of Health said Monday.
The hospital is equipped with volunteer Vietnamese and Indonesian translators to offer the service, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS ALLEGE POLITICAL INTERFERENCE BY MILITARY

TEXT.P: Several opposition lawmakers on Monday asked the Ministry of National Defense (MND) to investigate a high-ranking military official's remarks that apparently violated the military's stance of remaining politically neutral over the arms purchase plan.

At a session of the legislature's National Defense Committee, several opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) lawmakers expressed their concern over a recent appeal made by Lt. Gen. Chen Kuo-hsiang, director of the Political Warfare Department of the MND's Armed Forces Reserve Command, calling for the public to vote for those in support of the MND's arms purchase package from the United States in the year-end, three-in-one elections.
High on the MND's arms procurement list are eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the U.S.

It was said that Chen, who was upset about the arms procurement budget's being stalled in the legislature by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" for more than a year, urged the public to vote for those candidates who are in support of the arms deal, and turn away from those who are against it, in a seminar held recently.
KMT Legislator Ting Shou-chung said that Chen's remarks apparently violated the National Defense Law by politicizing the arms purchase question.
Although Chen said his remarks were just "personal opinion, " PFP Legislator Lin Yu-fang insisted that military personnel should not be involved in political issues.
In response, Vice Chief of the General Staff Tseng Chin-ling said he was not well informed of Chen's remarks, but added that Minister of National Defense Lee Jye has promised to look into the matter.
However, Tseng said if this was what Chen actually said, his comment were "inappropriate and unnecessary."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HELP EL SALVADOR BUILD VOCATIONAL TRAINING CENTER IN 3 YEARS

TEXT.P: The ROC is prepared to donate over US$8 million to help its diplomatic ally El Salvador build a vocational training center, an economics official said Monday.
The three-year plan is part of the "Rong Bang co-prosperity project" announced by President Chen Shui-bian during the fifth ROC-Central American leadership meeting in Nicaragua in late September.

The planned vocational training center will be built in a planned industrial park -- the "Taiwan Park in El Salvador" initiated by the ROC government to encourage Taiwanese businesses to invest in El Salvador.

The minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), Hu Sheng-cheng, doubles as the executive director of the team in charge of the establishment of the industrial park, while the Council of Labor Affairs has been assigned to build the vocational center.

According to the CEPD, the construction of the vocational center is divided into two stages, with work on the first stage to center on facility planning and market surveys. In the second stage, efforts will be made on facility construction and the establishment of a set of training systems and standards.

The training center is aimed at assisting El Salvador to integrate its need for professional industrial manpower with the existing educational system and to help the country improve industrial technologies as part of its efforts to boost national competitiveness, CEPD officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER MAKES SUGGESTION TO SORT OUT DIFFICULTIES OVER APEC ENVOY

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition Kuomintang suggested Monday that Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng serve as a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian to help sort out difficulties in attending the informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in South Korea.

KMT Legislator John Chiang made the remarks during a legislative committee meeting in which Vice Foreign Minister Michael Y.M. Kau and MOFA-affiliated International Cooperation and Development Fund Secretary-General Chen Cheng-chung reported on the implementation of MOFA's foreign aid budget.

Chiang inquired about South Korea's response toward President's Chen's announcement last week that Wang will serve as his envoy to attend the APEC summit meeting. China has voiced vehement opposition to Wang's assignment, saying that according to a memorandum of understanding signed in 1992 before Taiwan -- formally designated in APEC as Chinese Taipei -- joined the organization, Taiwan can only send its "minister in charge of APEC-related economic affairs" to attend the meeting, and that since then, APEC "has operated on this basis."
Kau said that response from South Korea on Wang is negative, showing the effect of China's attitude.
"Taiwan is currently negotiating with South Korea on this matter," adding that he has learned indirectly that South Korea hopes the envoy will have a financial or economics background.
For this, Chiang said the MOFA should provide correct information to the president so that "his choice of envoy won't be rejected outright," which could hurt national dignity as well as Wang.

Chiang said that if President Chen still wants Wang to go, he can invite Wang to serve as a senior adviser and go in that capacity, noting that C. F. Koo, the late chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, went to the APEC summit meeting in his capacity as a senior adviser to the president before.
"If Wang still can't go, a second candidate can be P.K. Chiang," Chiang also suggested.

P.K. Chiang, currently a KMT vice chairman and a legislator, once served as the chairman of the nation's economic planning agency -- the Council for Economic Planning and Development. P.K. Chiang attended the APEC summit meeting in 1993 on behalf of then-President Lee Teng-hui.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOW-INCOME FAMILIES ON RISE IN TAIWAN: DGBAS

TEXT.P: There were 81,215 low-income families in Taiwan as of the end of June this year, with state aid to these families amounting to NT$2.49 billion (US$75 million) , according to the latest government statistics.

The number of low-income families was up by 3.6 percent year on year and represented 1.12 percent of the total number of households in Taiwan as of the end of the first half of the year, according to the tallies released by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show.
The number of low-income family members also grew by 4.3 percent to 200,555 year on year, accounting for 0.88 percent of the country's total population, the same tallies show.

Government subsidies for the poor families and their children in education during the January-June period totaled NT$2.49 billion (US$75 million), an increase of 5.6 percent over the previous year's figure.

Of the more than 80,000 low-income families, 4,068 families, or 4,387 people, belong to "category one, " meaning that every member of the family is unable to work, or has no work income and no property, according to the statistics.
A majority of 57,218 of the poor families belonged to "category three, " meaning that all of the working family members have an average income of between NT$7,750 and NT$13,560 per month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES ENTERPRISES TO ENTER HIGH-VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTION MODE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Monday urged small- and medium-sized enterprises to develop information-based core technologies and establish a high-value-added production mode.
The president made the remarks while honoring 11 winners of the National Award of Small- and Medium-sized Enterprises in a ceremony in Taipei.
Chen noted that small- and medium-sized enterprises are the basis of the vibrant economic development of Taiwan and the bedrock of Taiwan's successful story.

Small- and medium-sized enterprises are synonymous with Taiwan, the president said. To help more people fulfill their dreams of starting their own businesses, the government has coordinated with local banks to provide an additional NT$200 billion (US$6 billion) in loans.

Taiwan businessmen residing overseas have more experience in the international market; therefore, to encourage them to bring their valuable experience home, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has formulated an incentive project, hoping that their return will inject new life and creativity into Taiwan's economy, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NON-DEMOCRATIC PARTIES' MUST NOT RETAKE PRESIDENCY: LEE TENG-HUI
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Y. C. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui urged full support for Taiwan's "indigenous political parties" Sunday in New York, saying that the Taiwan people must not allow non-democratic political parties to take back power in 2008.
Lee made the appeal while giving a one-hour speech to about 1,000 Taiwan expatriates during a dinner banquet.

It is critically important to continue Taiwan's democratization and make the island into a sound country, Lee stressed. He said that the core issue is not whether the country should declare independence from China; rather, it is a question of what the country should be called instead of the Republic of China.

Taiwan does not need to declare independence since it is already a sovereign and independent state, but the existing ROC Constitution, although amended six times, is still not suitable for Taiwan, which he called a temporary shelter for the ROC government, which fled China in 1949.

Warning that the 2008-2010 period could be a window for Beijing to attack Taiwan, the former president encouraged Taiwan people living overseas to unify and serve in the diplomatic vanguard to make Taiwan's voice heard around the world.

He called on the Taiwan people both at home and abroad to throw their support behind "indigenous political parties" in the 2008 presidential election, because "Taiwan is our motherland where we have our roots, and we must not allow non-democratic parties to return to power."

A "Republic of Taiwan" will eventually be set up, but this will take time as there are difficulties to overcome, he said, emphasizing that "Taiwan is Taiwan and China is China. We are strongly opposed to China's swallowing up Taiwan and all the Taiwan people should loudly voice their opposition."
Lee is slated to proceed to Washington, D.C. via Philadelphia Monday, the third leg of his current U.S. tour after Anchorage, Alaska and New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO SET UP 10 AD HOC GROUPS TO PUSH FOR REFORMS

TEXT.P: A high-ranking ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Monday that the party will set up 10 ad hoc groups to push for the various reforms including those outlined by President Chen Shui-bian recently.
Chao Yung-chin, a whip of DPP's legislative caucus, made the remarks after convening a meeting of DPP cadres and senior lawmakers from various factions held earlier that day.

The meeting was aimed at establishing a negotiation mechanism within the country and studying the future direction of the party, with the participants also including those legislators who recently endorsed a declaration calling for a new DPP movement to revive the party's core values at a time when the party is mired in allegations of scandals.

Chao said in a press conference following the meeting that the party will establish 10 ad hoc groups responsible respectively for financial reform, tax reform, reform to change the preferential interest rates of 18 percent for retired military personnel, civil servants and teachers, media reform, investigation into properties inappropriately seized by political parties, constitutional reform, reviewing the bonus system for government officials in enterprises with government shares, avoiding retired government officials to receive extra pay or pensions in other government agencies, as well as reviewing the salary structure of senior advisers to the president and national policy advisors to the president.

Chao stressed that now that both the legislature and the DPP are troubled with many problems, the DPP will strengthen communications within the party in the future to keep pushing for reforms and will convene such a meeting at least once every two weeks in the future.

As for the "new DPP movement," a term that the opposition parties have used to cause misunderstanding among the public, Chao said, the participants decided not to mention it frequently in the future, and just focus on reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST JUNK MAIL FLOWING TO TAIWAN FROM ASIA: SURVEY

TEXT.P: As much as 60 percent of the junk mail flowing into Taiwan is from Asia, with China taking the largest share of 25 percent, according to an analysis recently conducted by Openfind Information Technology Inc., a local company that provides mail protection systems.

Paraguay and Uruguay are the second-largest sources, which together sent out 17.8 percent of the junk mail arriving in Taiwan, followed by the United States with 8 percent, and India and South Korea each with more than 5 percent, Openfind researchers said, adding that Taiwan is also one of the major sources, generating 16.5 percent.
The amount of junk mail is usually 10 percent or 15 percent higher on holidays than on weekdays, according to the analysis results.

Junk mail has been growing at an alarming rate in recent years, and has accounted for 90 percent of the total number of e-mails sent since the beginning of this year compared to last year's level of 50 percent for the same period, the researchers pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD PASSES US$22.95 M. PROJECT TO IMPROVE ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING

TEXT.P: The government will spend NT$764.4 million (US$22.95 million) over the next five years to improve environmental monitoring, according to an environmental quality monitoring project submitted by the Environmental Protection Administration and passed Monday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
Under the project, the government will spend NT$764.4 million between 2006 and 2010 to phase out obsolete air and water monitoring equipment and buy new equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA SIGNS COOPERATIVE PACT TO PROMOTE WIMAX TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) signed a cooperative agreement with Intel Corp. of the United States to jointly promote WiMAX wireless technology, which provides high-throughput broadband connections over long distances.

WiMAX, an acronym that stands for Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access, is a wireless metropolitan area network (MAN) technology that can connect IEEE 802.11 (Wi-Fi) hotspots to the Internet and provide a wireless extension to cable and DSL for last-mile broadband access.
The agreement was signed by Economics Minister Ho Mei-yueh and Sean Maloney, Intel's executive vice president and general manager of Intel Communications Group.

Under the terms of the agreement, the MOEA will promote the development of WiMAX equipment and service industries with the aim of providing highly cost-efficient WiMAX products, equipment and solutions to the fast-growing global telecommunication market.
The MOEA will also coordinate distribution of domestic airwave frequencies and offer resources and assistance for WiMAX field trials.

For its part, Intel, the world's leading manufacturer of microcomputer components for desktop and server systems, will assist Taiwan in developing WiMAX technologies that meet IEEE 802.16 standards and will help Taiwan's ODM makers develop advanced WiMAX broadband devices and solutions.
Intel also promises to help ensure conformity and interoperability of locally produced WiMAX equipment with telecommunications networks in other countries.

Ho said at the signing ceremony that the cooperative program offers a good opportunity for Taiwan to not only take part in equipment manufacturing but also in the development of WiMAX standard specifications, system establishment and information services.

According to Ho, the government has drafted a five-year plan to offer wireless Internet connectivity to 8 million households. If all goes well, she said, WiMAX infrastructure will be in place in 15 demonstration areas in 10 cities around Taiwan by 2007 to allow for initial testing.

"Few countries have begun this kind of testing at present. With a well-developed information technology industry and local people's obsession with things new, Taiwan is well-equipped for wireless broadband communication testing," Ho said.

Speaking on the same occasion, Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Feng-ching said the government will invest up to NT$37 billion between 2005 and 2008 for its ambitious Mobile-Taiwan (M-Taiwan) project aimed at establishing a comprehensive wireless broadband mobile communication network and environment.
"WiMAX is the most important technological option for the M-Taiwan project," Lin said.
With a view to making Taiwan the world's largest WiMAX industry base, Lin said the government will offer NT$1.1 billion in subsidies for establishing WiMAX platform technology and key components.
Lin also urged city and county governments interested in establishing wireless broadband communications networks to file applications with the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: FENNEL NO PROTECTION AGAINST FLU: DOH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Monday that fennel, a common vegetable that also produces seeds that are used as a spice, is nothing like the flu drug Tamiflu and that there is no point in eating or stockpiling it to ward off flu.

DOH officials made the remarks as fears over avian flu heightened after health experts warned of a pandemic, with cases being reported in Europe after first being detected in Asia. The pharmaceutical giant Roche, which produces Tamiflu, cannot meet the demand for the flu vaccine, even if production is stepped up several-fold.

Tamiflu uses shikimic acid that is extracted from fennel and then undergoes several production processes to produce its main ingredient, oseltaminvir phosphate. When details of the process were reported, the local price of fennel jumped.
But DOH officials pointed out that the chemical structure of the shikimic acid in fennel is greatly different from the product used to make Tamiflu.
The officials said the public should not be misled into thinking that their consumption of fennel will help them against avian flu and warned that over-consumption could even cause adverse effects.

Meanwhile, acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan motioned in a joint meeting of Kaohsiung city, county and Pingtung county government chiefs Monday that the three administrations should set up a cooperative mechanism to combat avian flu within a week. Her suggestion won the support of Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH ASKS TAMIFLU MAKER TO GRANT TAIWAN PRODUCTION LICENSE

TEXT.P: The minister of the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday that he has sent a letter to Franz B. Humer, chairman of Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche, expressing Taiwan's desire to have the company's license to produce Tamiflu, the only vaccine against a possible pandemic of avian influenza.

Hou Sheng-mou said that protecting people's lives is the government's priority. Should a regional human-to-human avian flu pandemic break out, Taiwan will "do whatever it can" to secure enough vaccine, implying that the country will produce Tamiflu by itself with or without a license from Roche.
Taiwan has stockpiled just 160,000 doses of Tamiflu, far short of the amount the nation needs to fight the pandemic.

To secure enough medication, the health department has earmarked NT$400 million (US$11.97 million) to be used next year to purchase Tamiflu and materials should a pandemic occur. Half of the money will go toward buying Tamiflu from Roche and the other half will be used to purchase raw materials from the company to produce the vaccine in Taiwan, according to the DOH.

Hou said that even though there is still time before the avian flu virus mutates into the one that is capable of passing from human to human, the DOH still hopes Roche will grant Taiwan its Tamiflu production license as soon as possible.

According to patent laws, Roche will not be protected in terms of patent rights under the situation in which the country is faced with an emergent crisis or that a non-profit usage of its patented product is needed for the promotion of public health.

TEXT.P: Taipei will host the annual general meeting of the Asian Bankers Association in 2006, according to a resolution passed by the participants of the 22nd annual meeting of the association Monday.
The 22nd annual general meeting of the Asian Bankers Association opened that day in Melbourne, Australia, with representatives from the banking sectors of nearly 20 countries participating.
Jeffrey Koo, founder of the association and its honorary chairman, as well as chairman of the Taiwan-based Chinatrust Financial Holding Company, addressed the two-day meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU SUPPORTS ESTABLISHMENT OF ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Ching-chiang expressed Monday his support of President Chen Shui-bian's call for the establishment by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of an anti-corruption commission.
However, at a meeting of the TSU's Central Executive Committee, Su said that such commission should not be formed only by DPP members, but also by people of good reputation from various fields.
At the meeting, the party members reaffirmed their determination on reforms and their hate of corruption.

They also criticized several allegations in a number of scandals involving the DPP, including the illegal profiteering exposed by the Aug. 21 riot of Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project and the huge stock bonus received by former China Steel Corp. Chairman Lin Wen-yuan in his capacity as the company's chief executive officer, as well as the "double-dipping" scandal in which some retired government officials still receive pay or pensions from various after-retirement posts in addition to pensions from their original jobs.
In addition, Su also suggested that the subjects of investigation should not be limited to current government officials and lawmakers, but should also include retired or other related figures.

Meanwhile, referring to former President Lee Teng-hui's present visit to the United States, Su urged the public to express more recognition of Lee's long-term efforts in promoting Taiwan's causes in the international community.
Noting that the promotion of diplomacy is not just the government's job but a task of all the people, including the opposition parties, Su expressed support for Lee's plan to visit Japan next year.
Criticizing China's protest against Lee's visits abroad, Su noted that Lee is an ordinary citizen and claimed that Beijing's obstruction will just deepen the hatred of China by the Taiwan people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT FORUM IN NEW YORK RECEIVES WARM RESPONSE

TEXT.P: A forum held Oct. 13-14 in New York City aimed at attracting global investment to Taiwan's financial market has received a warm response from international investors, officials of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Monday.

A Taiwan delegation composed of government officials, FSC officials, bankers and business representatives traveled to New York to attend the seminar dubbed "Taiwan: the Gateway to the Region, " which was organized by Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC, EII.

In the two-day forum, Taiwan officials responsible for financial affairs introduced the reform projects in financial internationalization and liberalization being carried out by the FSC and the trade opportunities derived from those reform projects.

According to FSC officials, representatives from several international investment corporations were excited by the chance to receive first-hand information from Taiwan's financial officials and to exchange points of view with Taiwanese business leaders on the nation's industrial prospects.
The investors suggested that Taiwan convene more such forums to attract more global investment.

However, they also expressed concern about the limitations on foreign capital entry into Taiwan's financial market, and whether foreign banks will be given a fair chance in the mergers of banking institutions being promoted by the government.
After their stay in New York, the delegation will proceed to the United Kingdom to conduct a similar seminar Oct. 17-18 in London.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO RENEW PUSH FOR ANTI-CORRUPTION AGENCY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will discuss a draft bill at its weekly meeting Wednesday to pave the way for creating a new agency under the Ministry of Justice to fight corruption and establish clean politics, a ruling party lawmaker said Monday.

Legislator William Lai, a whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus, said the Cabinet will submit the draft bill to the Legislative Yuan after a further discussion at Wednesday's weekly meeting.
Lai made the remarks after a policy coordination meeting of officials from the administration and the DPP legislative caucus and party headquarters.

The Cabinet referred a similar bill to the previous legislature that expired early this year. The Rules Committee of the opposition-controlled previous legislature rejected putting it on the legislative agenda 74 times.

As the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party continues to hold a slim majority in the present legislature, it "remains unclear" whether the draft bill can clear the legislative floor this time around.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMBINED SERVICES COMBAT COMMAND MECHANISM FUNCTIONS WELL: MND

TEXT.P: After four years of development, testing and improvement, the military's combined services combat command mechanism is now functioning smoothly, Vice Chief of the General Staff Tseng Chin-ling said Monday.
Speaking at a Legislative Yuan Defense Committee meeting, Tseng said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) began to design a combined services combat command mechanism in February 2001.
"The mechanism has since been tested in three consecutive annual Han Kuang military exercises. After remodeling and improvements, the mechanism is now operating well," Tseng told lawmakers.
In the future, Tseng said, the military will continue to upgrade its combat prowess and accelerate beefing up its counterattack forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN VOWS TO COMPLETE REFORM OF PREFERENTIAL INTEREST RATES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has reaffirmed his commitment to completing reform of the preferential interest rates for retired civil servants, military servicemen and public school teachers by the end of this year.
Chen made the reaffirmation in a taped television interview broadcast on SETTV, a cable news channel, Monday night.
Chen said the 18 percent preferential interest rate for pensions of retired public functionaries, which has been implemented for more than 20 years, is unfair and unjust.

"The preferential measure should be revised before the end of the year or even earlier. The proposed reform is not to remove the 18 percent preferential interest rate. What the government plans to do is to improve it so that the income replacement rate for retired civil servants, military personnel and teachers will be capped at 90 percent. This is the world's highest rate. In many other countries, the maximum ratio is 70 percent," Chen said.
If the proposed reform plan can be implemented smoothly, Chen said the government will be able to save NT$700 billion in interest rate subsidy over the next 20 years.

"This means we'll be able to save NT$35 billion annually. The saved money will be used to finance free lunches for schoolchildren from poor families, extension of compulsory education and increase of living subsidy for senior farmers," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN PANS OPPOSITION PARTIES OVER ARMS PROCUREMENT BOYCOTT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian slammed two major opposition parties Monday for their obstinate opposition to his administration's plan to procure a robust package of weapons from the United States.
Chen fired barrage the of criticism of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) in a taped interview broadcast late Monday night on SETTV, a cable news channel.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP has used its slim majority in the Legislative Yuan to prevent the arms procurement package from being put onto the legislative agenda more than 30 times in the past year.

Claiming that the two parties have opposed the package for partisan reasons, Chen said he sees little possibility that the legislature's rules committee would place the arms bill onto the legislative agenda before the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections.
Listed in the arms package are eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.
Chen said all of the three big-ticket weapons in the package were broached by the previous KMT administration.
"It is regrettable that the KMT and its splinter group -- the PFP -- have changed their position after losing power," Chen said.
In the face of China's military threat, Chen said Taiwan badly needs new weapons to safeguard its national security. Chen said he aspires to listen to public opinion about the issue.
Noting that his term of office will expire on May 19, 2008, Chen said his administration's push for the arms procurement package is not for partisan interests but purely for national defense needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGED TO HELP PUSH FOR WANG TO ATTEND APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Ma's predecessor Lien Chan Monday to help push for Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to attend the upcoming informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on his behalf.
Chen made the appeal in a taped interview broadcast on SETTV, a cable news channel.
Chen said he had obtained Wang's consent before announcing his decision last week to name Wang as his proxy at the 2005 APEC summit to be held in Busan, South Korea in November.
Moreover, Chen said he had sought U.S. opinions about his plan to appoint Wang to attend the APEC summit on his behalf.
"U.S. authorities have given a positive response, terming it as a creative option," Chen said.
Chen went on to say he had asked ROC Representative to South Korea Lee Tsai-fang to inform South Korean authorities of his decision before making a public announcement.
Chen said he didn't know that China would oppose Wang's attendance as KMT Chairman Ma claimed.
Chen said he never thought that he should have consulted with China before choosing his proxy at the APEC summit.

APEC is one of the few international bodies that admit both Taiwan and China. Because of China's opposition, the ROC president has been barred from attending the APEC summit in person and has to instead name a special envoy to attend on his behalf.
Chen said he is hopeful that the KMT can use it friendly ties with the Communist Party of China to persuade Beijing not to oppose Wang attendance at this year's APEC summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 18, or the 16th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1405: Pope Pius II, originally named Enea Silivio Piccolomini, is born. He was noted for his unsuccessful attempt to lead a crusade against the Turks.
1860: Invading British troops burn the Yuanmingyuan, the imperial summer palace in Beijing, to the ground.
1867: The United States purchases Alaska from Russia for US$7.2 million.
1873: Delegates from Columbia, Princeton, Rutgers, and Yale universities meet and formulate the rules for American football.
1898: The United States takes possession of Puerto Rico from Spain.
1907: The first plans are announced for an International Court of Justice to be set up in The Hague.
1922: Tsai Yuan-pei, a scholar and the president of Peking University, resigns in the wake of student protests against an extra levy on professor's handouts.
1926: The will of Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian founder of the Bolshevik party, leader of the Russian Revolution and first head of the USSR, is made public to the world in the New York Times.
1931: Thomas Alva Edison, America's most prolific inventor, dies at the age of 84. His inventions include the phonograph, the microphone and the kinescope.
1941: General Hideki Tojo becomes prime minister of Japan and begins planning for war against the United States.
1944: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt cables Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government and supreme commander of the China theater of war, regarding his decision to appoint Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China theater of war to succeed Gen. Joseph Stilwell.
1946: The Chinese communists reject the government's latest peace offer presented by Chiang Kai-shek on Oct. 16.
1967: Venera 4, a Soviet spacecraft, enters the atmosphere of Venus and transmits data back to earth.
1970: Vice President Yen Chia-kan, who concurrently holds the post of premier, leaves Taipei for New York to attend the 25th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations.
1974: Acting for President Chiang Kai-shek, Vice President Yen Chia-kan accepts the credentials of Maj. Gen. Ismael D. Lapus as the Philippines ambassador to the Republic of China.
1974: The ROC national taekwondo team returns from Seoul after taking second place in the First Asian Taekwondo championships.
1976: Chinese-American scientist Samuel Chao Chung Ting and his colleague Burton Richter share the 1976 Nobel Prize for physics for their discovery of an elementary nuclear particle called the "psi," or "J particle."
1987: The United States attacks an Iranian oil rig in revenge for strikes against its shipping operations by gunboats.
1989: Erich Honecker, 77, East Germany's hardline ruler who failed to respond to the desire among East Germans for change, is ousted from the post he held for the previous 18 years.
1989: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer match in Guatemala. Eighty-three people are killed and nearly 200 others are injured.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Council is established under the Executive Yuan to formulate and implement mainland policy, with Vice Premier Shih Chi-yang serving as its chairman.
1998: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC's Straits Exchange Foundation, crowns a six-day visit to mainland China by meeting with President Jiang Zemin, marking the highest-level contact between the two sides since 1949.
1999: Two more Knox-class frigates leased from the United States are commissioned in order to help beef up the Republic of China's naval defense capabilities.
2000: A seminar on trade and economic cooperation among the three Chinese communities -- Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong -- opens in Beijing.
2001: "President A-bian's Electronic Paper, " an online newspaper published by the Presidential Office is formally launched.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reiterats the long-standing relations between the Republic of China and Paraguay when he receives visiting National Asuncion University President Paul Battilana.
2001: Several hundred Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan, Europe and the United States gathers in front of the mainland Chinese embassy in Belgium to protest Beijing's suppression of the movement.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, by living a life of simple truth and earnestness, alone can help to bring peace and order in the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROCHE DECLINES TO COMMENT ON TAIWAN'S REQUEST TO MAKE TAMIFLU LOCALLY
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A spokeswomen for the Swiss pharmaceutical maker Roche declined Monday to comment on Taiwan's reported request for authorization from the company to manufacture Tamiflu locally as the company has still not received a request from the island's health authorities.
Roche is the sole manufacturer of Tamiflu, one of only a handful of influenza drugs that help fight certain strains of H5N1 infection.
The spokeswoman said that the company will not close the door to the possibility of future discussions with Taiwan on the matter.

Hou Mou-sheng, minister of the Republic of China's Department of Health (DOH) under the Executive Yuan, said the same day that he has sent aletter to Roche President Franz B. Humer requesting that the company and the DOH discuss allowing Taiwan to produce Tamiflu on the island in order to increase stockpiles to a sufficient level to deal with a possible avian flu outbreak.

Pointing out that she could not make any concrete response to the island's request, the spokeswomen said basically, Roche does not exclude the possibility of discussing cooperation in manufacturing Tamiflu with foreign companies in the future.
She further said that her company will discuss with the Taiwan government relevant issues after becoming fully aware of the island's stance.

Asked whether Roche will likely agree to authorize foreign companies to produce Tamiflu, the spokeswoman said that no foreign pharmaceutical companies have yet demanded that the company authorizes them to produce the drug.

Currently, Taiwan only has a stockpile of 160,000 doses of Tamiflu. It has ordered 780,000 more doses of the drug from Roche. It is expected that the island's stockpiles of the drug by the middle of next year will reach 4 percent of the population, far behind the safe level of 10 percent suggested by the World Health Organization.

Taiwan has announced twice during the past 30 days that it has the ability and technology to produce Tamiflu and that it has considered breaking patent laws to manufacture the drug. This evoked a negative response from the Swiss company, which said the island's consideration is "unrealistic."

According to the Treaty on Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) , compulsory licensing and government use without the authorization of the rights holder are allowed, but are made subject to conditions aimed at protecting the legitimate interests of the rights holder.

The treaty also says that as a general rule, such licenses should only be granted if an unsuccessful attempt has been made to acquire a voluntary licence on reasonable terms and conditions within a reasonable period of time, adding, however, that it is not necessary for those countries that are in an emergency situation to acquire a voluntary license first.
According to the treaty, the rights holder should receive appropriate remuneration for both voluntary licenses and compulsory licenses.
Tamiflu has become the most popular drug in the face of a threat currently posed by a possible worldwide outbreak of the avian flu pandemic.

With fears growing around the world of the possible outbreak of the disease, orders for Tamiflu have shot up. Roche, which has been unable to meet this growing demand, has come under increasing pressure to authorize companies in other countries to manufacture Tamiflu.
