DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 4.52 points to close at 5,830.79.
The bourse opened at 5,853.28 and fluctuated between 5,865.24 and 5,805.7 during trading. A total of 2.58 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$62.59 billion (US$1.87 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 0.4 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 0.7 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent.
Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 491 to 451, with 176 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT GROUP TO HEAD TO CHINA TO DISCUSS TOURIST EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) group will leave for Beijing Wednesday to help push for Taiwan's opening to Chinese tourists as early as possible, KMT Policy Executive Committee Director Tseng Yung-chuan said Tuesday.

Speaking at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan prior to their departure, Tseng called on the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to send ranking officials to travel to Beijing with them.

KMT Legislator John Chiang, KMT Mainland Affairs Department Director Chang Jung-kung, who will accompany Tseng on the trip, were also present. They are slated to meet the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen Yunlin Thursday in Beijing.

At a time when Taiwan and China have had limited contact and have failed to come up with concrete results on the tourist issue, the KMT wants to gain a better understanding of Beijing's viewpoints and to help explore the feasibility of allowing Chinese tourists to come to Taiwan for the mutual benefit of the two sides, Tseng said.

Pointing out that opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists is expected to generate at least NT$50 billion in tourist dollars and business opportunities worth more than NT$100 billion (US$3 billion) at home, he called it the right path to revive the dwindling domestic economy.
The KMT also hopes to promote tourist charter flights across the Taiwan Strait to facilitate two-way tourist exchanges, Chiang said.

Responding to questions from reporters, Chiang also ruled out the possibility that the KMT mission will take the initiative to discuss with Beijing officials President Chen Shui-bian's idea of dispatching Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT heavyweight, to serve as his envoy at this year's informal leadership summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum set to be held Nov. 12-13 in Busan, South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FACES MARGINALIZATION THREAT AFTER CHINA-ASEAN FTA: SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By C.C. Hwang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: With China and the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) having signed a free trade agreement, Taiwan could face a crisis of marginalization, a British scholar warned Monday.
Christopher Dent, a senior lecturer on the Southeast Asian economy at the University of Leeds, made the warning at a forum on "Taiwan's Global Investment" being held in London.

Talking about the close trade relationship between Taiwan and China, Dent, who has done much research into Taiwan's political and economic situations, said that China is the island's largest export market and that the number of Taiwanese businesspeople in China and the total amount of their investment on the mainland is considerable.
However, he said that an FTA among China, Japan, South Korea and the ASEAN countries, which would create the largest free trade zone in the world, could be harmful to Taiwan's economic development.
However, although claiming that Taiwan faces the threat of marginalization, the scholar said he has confidence in the island's ability to " turn bad luck into good fortune. "
According to Dent, small and medium enterprises have formed the most important part of the Taiwan's economy and have given the island the flexibility to respond rapidly to outside changes or shocks.

Meanwhile, Yen Ching-chang, former ROC permanent representative to the World Trade Organization, who also attended the forum, said that a successful Doha Round trade negotiations would reinforce the global multilateral trade mechanism. He said that success would not only affect the trade systems of the WTO members, but would also help multinational companies reduce their costs of doing business overseas.
Claiming that success of the new round of trade talks would help liberalize world trade, Yen said that bilateral FTAs would not undermine the fruits of success of the Doha talks.
"Taiwan is a WTO member. It certainly has the same rights as the other WTO members and is not worried about the FTA signed between China and ASEAN," Yen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MAY REVIEW PARTY FUNDRAISING SYSTEM: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is amenable to taking a second look at its system to raise funds as it applies to public office-holders, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday.

The ruling party's fundraising system, under which public office-holders must contribute a certain amount to the party coffer, has become the focus of media attention after President Chen Shui-bian disclosed during a TV interview that China Steel Corp. Chairman Lin Wen-yuan had been "paying the dues for some Cabinet members."
According to Chen, "Lin has helped the pan-green camp of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union a lot, " but his payments have been misinterpreted as "political donations."

Opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Lin Teh-fu asked the premier if Lin was allowed to make political donations in his capacity as CSC chairman. Hsieh said, "As chairman, no; but as an individual, yes."
The premier said the DPP does not own any profit-making businesses, but it has a good system to regulate raising and using membership dues and campaign funds.

Campaign funds should be raised in accordance with the political donations law, which must be followed by all politicians, Hsieh said, adding, "If Lin helps raise funds at luncheons or dinner parties, he is not violating the law."

Because Lin Wen-yuan was seen to have used his huge bonus and high salary at CSC to help pan-green politicians, the PFP's Lin demanded that the government investigate whether the CSC chairman had violated the political donations law.
Minister of Finance Lin Chuan and Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said they will act according to law; however, it was not clear if this meant that an investigation into the matter would be started.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST-EVER KMT-CPC ECONOMIC FORUM SLATED FOR DECEMBER IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The first-ever economic cooperation forum between the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) is slated to be held in mid- December in Taipei, a KMT official said Tuesday.

KMT Mainland Affairs Department Director Chang Jung-kung said that his party will invite Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the Chinese State Council -- Beijing's No. 1 official responsible for charting policy toward Taiwan -- to take part in the activity. A KMT-affiliated think tank will apply for an entry visa for Chen with the government, he noted.

The news came at a time when former KMT Chairman Lien Chan was visiting Dalian in the northeastern Chinese province of Liaoning, from where he will proceed southward to Qingdao, Shangdong province and where he will meet Chen.
According to Chang, Lien will not discuss issues related to the forum during his meeting with Chen, as Lien's current China visit is private in nature.

KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang is also planning to lead a KMT delegation to Beijing late this month, where he will jointly hold a forum with Beijing officials to forge consensus and iron out concrete measures on the protection of Taiwan business interests in China, Chang revealed.

Lien, now the honorary KMT chairman, made what the party dubbed as an historic "journey of peace" to China from late April to early May, when he was still head of Taiwan's largest opposition party. The KMT-CPC forum idea was first put forward during a meeting between Lien and CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao in Beijing in late April.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA SETS UP COMMITTEE OF JAPANESE AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) set up the Committee of Japanese Affairs on Oct. 15 to strengthen ties with Japan, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said Tuesday.

Lu noted that the committee, with Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen being its convener, is divided into sections responsible for political, economic, educational, cultural affairs, as well as information.
According to MOFA officials, the country's dealing with Japan used to be managed by MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs and the Association of East Asian Relations.

To avoid the duplication of human resources and to integrate the efforts in promoting relations with Japan, the Presidential Office asked MOFA to map out a viable way to resolve the situation a year ago.
MOFA officials noted that the establishment of the Committee of Japanese Affairs will help boost Taiwan-Japan relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.129 to close at NT$33.579.
A total of US$877 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.450 and hit a high of NT$33.586.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved up 24 points to close at 5,839, with 15,703 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved up 29 points to end at 5,849, with 11,877 contracts traded, while December futures gained 17 points to finish at 5,838, with 43 contracts traded. March futures moved up 25 points to close at 5,840, with 11 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,815 for October, 5,820 for November, 5,821 for December, 5,815 for March and 5,830 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

October TE futures moved up 1.65 points to close at 241.05, with 3,125 contracts traded, while November TE futures gained 1.7 points to finish at 241.2, with 3,032 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down one point to end at 242, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

October TF futures lost 2.4 points to finish at 884.6, with 2,647 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 4.4 points to end at 883.4, with 2,917 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down four points to close at 884, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: RANKING MOTC OFFICIAL TO BE QUESTIONED IN KAOHSIUNG MRT SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Deputy Minister of Transportation and Communications Chou Li-liang will be questioned for suspected involvement in the Kaohsiung rapid transit scandal, a leading prosecutor said Wednesday.

Tseng Yung-fu, chief prosecutor at the Supreme Prosecutor's Office of the Ministry of Justice, would not confirm whether the joint prosecution-investigation task force of the Kaohisung MRT scandal will question former presidential adviser Chen Che-nan.

Independent Legislator Chiu Yi said the task force should find out the connections between Chen, Chou, Chen Min-hsien and Huapan Administration Consultant Co., which has been under investigation on charges of maltreating Thai workers brought in to build the Kaohsiung MRT system. Chen Min-hsien, vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC), is also being probed.
Whether to probe Chen Che-nan will be decided by prosecutors, Tseng said.

Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said the task force is pro-actively investigating the case, and he hopes people will not "disturb" the investigation, which includes evidence-gathering activities abroad.
The investigation is ongoing, and the Ministry of Justice respects the schedules of the investigators, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO ANTE UP DAMAGES CLAIM IN DEFAMATION LAWSUIT AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) indicated Tuesday that it will sue President Chen Shui-bian on charges of "aggravated defamation" and seek a large amount in damages because he still refuses to apologize for his remark that PFP Chairman James Soong met with a high-ranking Chinese official in secret in the United States earlier this year.

Soong already filed a civil suit in June at the Taipei District Court, seeking a symbolic NT$1 in compensation from Chen over his claim that the PFP chairman had met with Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council.

Soong, who returned from a visit to the United Kingdom Monday, and PFP officials were furious after learning that the president renewed his claim during an interview with a cable TV channel that there is a basis for his saying that Soong had met with Chen Yunlin in the United States early this year, and that he would present the evidence in court if need be.

The president questioned in the interview why Soong changed his previous position after his visit to the United States and began to oppose a proposed constitutional amendment that would allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments.
When asked to comment, Soong called the president a "liar" and challenged him to present the evidence right away.

Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP Policy Center, said that in addition to changing the charge in the lawsuit to "aggravated defamation" and seeking a large amount in compensation for damage to Soong's reputation, members of the PFP caucuses at the legislature and the Taipei City Council will go to the Presidential Office Wednesday to demand that the president substantiate his claim with evidence.

Chang also threatened that the PFP legislative caucus will try to freeze the next fiscal budget for the Presidential Office because it is really not necessary to "spend so much money to support someone who creates political turmoil."

PFP spokesman Chin Chin-sheng claimed that in view of the fact that the president has discredited Soong's name repeatedly with untruths, all PFP party officials and PFP members in government posts will stop calling Chen "President Chen" from Wednesday, and will refer to him as "liar Chen."
Chin explained that the PFP was against amending the Constitution in a flippant manner from the very beginning, and that this position had nothing to do with Soong's visit to China in May.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng said that he did not want to get involved in the dispute between Soong and the president, but declined to say whether the president showed him the evidence of Soong's meeting with Chen Yunlin.

In his interview with SETTV Monday, the president told the host of a talk show that he had let a heavyweight figure of the opposition Kuomintang see the evidence. He, however, did not name the person.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DOESN'T HAVE TO DECLARE INDEPENDENCE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said Monday in Washington, D.C. that Taiwan doesn't have to declare independence so long as it is a normal country.
Lee made the remark after visiting the Jefferson Memorial, which is dedicated to Thomas Jefferson, one of the writers of the U.S. Declaration of Independence.
Lee was on the third leg of his two-week U.S. visit which has already taken him to Alaska and New York.

Noting that both Taiwan and the United States are immigrant societies, and that the people of both countries seek freedom, the former president said the urgent task is to give people a chance to understand Taiwan's identity and its future direction.
"Taiwan doesn't have to declare independence, so long as it is a normal country, it is a good country, " Lee said, adding that Taiwan is not yet normal and that everyone should work toward that goal.
Lee went from New York to Washington, D.C. by car in the morning, stopping at Philadelphia on his way to take a look at the Liberty Bell.
He noted that every important event in the U.S. is related to the symbolism of the Liberty Bell, as the U.S. has been built around the idea of liberty, and that liberty is also a universal value.
Lee arrived at a hotel near the White House in Washington, D.C. at 1 p.m. to the warm welcome of around 100 Taiwanese expatriates.
Lee and his wife first visited the National Archives where they took a close look at the original copies of the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution of the United States.

Lee noted that each day around 5,000 people visit the National Archives to see the historic documents, which can be said to be the pride of the United States and speaks much about the country's national identity. It is a pity that Taiwan doesn't have a similar chance to let the public know of its direction, he said.
Freedom and democracy are universal values and it is unreasonable to suppress people under the pretext of patriarchy and unification.

He also said that the U.S. is great because of the lofty ideals of its founding fathers, and the National Archives is a great way of getting this concept across, adding that Taiwan's education on national identification is seriously insufficient, and there is not enough Taiwan history in the education system. Taiwan people don't know where they come from and the diligence of their ancestors, he said.
Lee will stay in Washington, D.C. Oct. 17-20, during which time he will deliver a speech at the National Press Club.

He reportedly will promote Taiwan's democratic experience and call the international community's attention to China's threat to the peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, the Asia-Pacific region and the entire world.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC HOPES TO START CONSTRUCTION OF NEW GENERATION SPEED BOATS SOON

TEXT.P: Officials of the state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) expressed their hope Tuesday that they can start as soon as possible the construction of 30 missile speed boats ordered by the country's navy.
The CSBC officials made known their hope after a private ship building company was launching maximum efforts to persuade the related agencies to change the decision of the navy on the contract.
The CSBC gained the contract for 30 new generation missile speed boats worth more than NT$10 billion (US$297.88 million) in June this year.
However, a private ship builder, Jong Shyn Shipbuilding Co. Ltd., was still trying to affect the contract by asking the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission to overrule the navy's decision.

Han Pi-hsiang, chairman of Jong Shyn Shipbuilding Co. Ltd., noted that the contract involves complicated manpower and the construction of the 30 missile speed boats is expected to help ship building development for domestic private ship builders.

Noting that they have the experience in building similar missile speed boats as well as constructing cruising boats for the Coast Guard Administration, Han stressed that their capability of building ships is not inferior to that of the CSBC, and most important is that the prices they charge are lower.

Amid the strong lobbying and competition from Jong Shyn, the CSBC officials noted that the CSBC has been cooperating with the navy for many years, stressing that it has the capability to complete the production of the speed boats with the best quality and within the expected time.

The new generation, 100-ton speed boats can be equipped with four missiles, compared with the 50-ton speed boats currently used by the Republic of China Navy, which can only be equipped with two missiles, and have more powerful deterrence capability, according to the CSBC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BOOSTS INCENTIVES FOR INVESTMENT IN LATIN AMERICAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) unveiled a set of financing and subsidy measures Tuesday aimed at increasing the incentives for Taiwan investors to set up operations in the country's diplomatic allies in Central and South America.

The measures are part of the "co-prosperity project" announced by President Chen Shui-bian during the 5th ROC-Central America Summit held Sept. 26 in Nicaragua, under which the government will establish a fund of US$250 million to help develop the economies of its diplomatic allies in the region.

According to Cho Shih-chao, head of MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, the ministry has revised a related regulation to expand the industrial categories eligible for government subsidies to include the media, oil exploration and financial service sectors. In the past, only the manufacturing sector was entitled to the subsidies.
While pay and rental subsidies have been increased from 20 percent to 30 percent, the loan interest subsidy has been raised to 50 percent, Cho said.

Also, the subsidy ceiling has been hiked from NT$15 million (US$447,761) to NT$20 million, Cho continued, adding that applications will be accepted one year after operations start and that the subsidy duration will be five years.
The revised regulation will be promulgated for implementation between late October and early November after it is finalized by the Cabinet, Cho said.

He pointed out that the Cabinet's Development Fund and International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) have earmarked NT$5 billion and NT$2.5 billion, respectively, as government capital to be funneled into various investment partnerships with the private sector.

Meanwhile, the Development Fund is planning to provide low interest financing for investors, and the ICDF, Overseas Chinese Credit Guarantee Fund, and Small and Medium Business Credit Guarantee Fund will also review their loan guarantee systems to facilitate local investors' plans to invest in Central and South America, he said.
The ROC's embassies in the 12 Central and South American countries with diplomatic relations with Taiwan have also set up investment service teams to serve Taiwan investors, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSTRUCTS MOTC TO FIND OUT SALARIES OF THSRC EXECUTIVES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that he will ask the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to look into the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp (THSRC) and find out the salaries of the company's executives.

The premier made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan amid reports that the THSRC's president and 16 other executives received a combined salary of NT$90.83 million (US$2.72 million) last year, averaging NT$5.34 million per man per year. This, coupled with payments to the board chairman, independent board members and supervisors, has pushed the total payments to over NT$100 million.
Compared with their colleagues in the sea and air transportation sectors, the income of the THSRC executives are the highest, according to the reports.

Hsieh said that Taiwan has no experience of building high-speed railways and that the salary payments have to be considered in the context of social factors and market forces, as well as whether the executives are hired from overseas.

Noting that the THSRC will convene a provisional shareholders' meeting in the near future, the premier said the government has asked the company to increase the number of board members and supervisors, as well as independent directors, to step up supervision work.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said the THSRC is a private company and that he has sent ministry officials to gain an understanding of the operations of the company.

The Cabinet set up a special task force to help tackle a host of problems involved in the nation's first high-speed railway construction project after THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing announced late last month that completion of the project would be postponed for one year until October 2006.

The task force's main functions include supervision of the progress of the railway construction, crisis management, crafting a comprehensive supervisory mechanism and land development in the vicinity of various high-speed rail stations.

The administration has come under fire recently for its decision to help bail out the cash-strapped THSRC, claiming that Taiwan's international reputation will be at stake if the railway cannot be completed.

The bail-out came in the form of two government-related foundations -- the China Aviation Development Fund (CADF) and the China Technical Consultant Inc. (CTCI) -- which were told to invest a total of NT$7.5 billion in the project.

Noting that the 345-km railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south will form the backbone of western Taiwan's mass rapid transportation network, Hsieh said that if the project cannot be completed smoothly, western Taiwan's development will be affected and the people's confidence will be dented.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING TO CHINESE TOURISTS GOVERNMENT POLICY: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Bracing for tourists visiting from China is a set government policy and the government welcomes every move that is conducive to that end, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu said Tuesday.

Liu made the remarks following a meeting at the MAC with a group of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) members scheduled to leave for China the following day for talks on the issue with Chinese officials in Beijing, including the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen Yunlin, Beijing's top official responsible for Taiwan policy, and National Tourism Administration Director Shao Qiwei.
KMT Policy Executive Committee Director Tseng Yung-chuan and KMT Legislator John Chiang were present to exchange views with Liu.

According to Tseng, the KMT wants to gain a better understanding of Beijing's viewpoint and to help push for allowing Chinese tourists to begin coming to Taiwan as soon as possible for the mutual benefit of both sides.

Opening up to tourists from China is the right path for the government to revive Taiwan's sliding economy, Tseng said, adding that it will help create large amounts of revenue and business opportunities.

Taiwan and China have had limited contacts for discussion on the issue, and a major breakthrough is needed to break the current impasse, Chiang said, adding that they will ask China to come up with a set of complementary measures to help facilitate the tourist visits to Taiwan, such as opening to tourist charter flights across the Taiwan Strait.
Asked whether he will invite Shao to participate in an international travel fair slated for next month in Taipei, Chiang said they will first exchange opinions with Shao.

Meanwhile, speculation has been rampant in Taiwan's tourism sector that Chinese experts will be invited to take part in the Taipei travel fair in mid-November for the first time in anticipation of the opening to Chinese tourists.
However, officials of the Taiwan Visitors Association (TVA) , which will organize the fair, dismissed the rumors, clarifying that the Chinese visitor to the fair will be a scholar.
According to TVA officials, 59 countries and areas will take part in this year's Taipei travel fair, an increase over last year's 51.

President Chen Shui-bian told Reuters during a recent interview that a Chinese official in charge of tourism will visit Taiwan in the near future, while travel industry insiders also speculated that Shao will lead a delegation to visit Taiwan in his capacity as head of the Chinese National Tourism Administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO KICK OFF TRUCK CAMPAIGNING TOUR FOR DPP CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will kick off a round-the-island campaign tour on the back of a truck Saturday in southern Taiwan, hoping to directly appeal to the people.

The president will talk about the government's determination to implement reforms and drum up support for the candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the year-end city and county chief elections.
Chen, who has a lot of experience in campaigning, held several large rallies with magnificent sound and light shows in the run-up to the 2004 presidential election.

For this campaign, however, he has decided to adopt a more low-profile approach, hoping to remind the public of the time when the DPP was still a "tangwai" (an outside dissenter) in its burgeoning years, when it gathered the bulk of its support from the grassroots.

The barnstorming approach is actually a follow-up to a series of local seminars held in the wake of China opening to Taiwan's agricultural products in August, when the president visited rural areas to talk with local DPP officials to communicate with them on the government's stance, advising them not to fall into the trap of China's "charm offensive," which is said to have been effective.
His more-than 30-stop barnstorming tour will start in Chiayi County, Tainan City and Tainan County, and will continue to Hualien County, Taichung City and Taichung County Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNG CHENG ARMED FORCES PREPARATORY SCHOOL TO BE PHASED OUT

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Jye told legislators Tuesday that the Chung Cheng Armed Forces Preparatory School in Fengshan, Kaohsiung County, will be phased out.

Lee was replying to a question during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan from Legislator Yen Wen-chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on whether the school's continued existence is necessary.

Yen pointed out that the school, with a 70.5-hectare campus and many modern facilities, including 32 basketball courts and four standard-sized swimming pools, has only 1,141 students, while the campuses for the 12,300 students in the 14 public and private high schools in Kaohsiung County total only 63 hectares in area.

Lee explained that the facilities of the military school have been added in stages over a long period since it was founded by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) in 1976 to provide free education for would-be cadets in the academies of the armed forces. He acknowledged that with enrollment declining at the school, the hardware is too luxurious and excessive for the number of students.
However, Lee said the MND needs more time to phase out the school because those students still at the school must graduate and the faculty staff must be relocated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 32ND IN 2005 WORLD CORRUPTION PERCEPTION INDEX

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked 32nd, with a score of 5.9, among the 159 countries surveyed in Transparency International's (TI's) 2005 Corruption Perceptions Index, up three notches from last year's survey, TI Taiwan said Tuesday.
More than two-thirds of the 159 nations surveyed scored less than five out of a possible 10, indicating serious levels of corruption in a majority of the countries surveyed.

Among Asian countries, Singapore was the least corrupt country, with a score of 9.4. Other Asian countries with a score of five or above include Hong Kong (15th), Japan (21st) , Malaysia (39th) and South Korea (40th). China scored 3.2, ranking 78th.
Except for Singapore, all "clean countries" with a score of nine or higher are developed countries such as Iceland, Finland, New Zealand, Denmark and Switzerland.
The 2005 Index bears witness to the double burden of poverty and corruption borne by the world's least developed countries.
"Corruption is a major cause of poverty as well as a barrier to overcoming it," said TI Chairman Peter Eigen.

"The two scourges feed off each other, locking their populations in a cycle of misery. Corruption must be vigorously addressed if aid is to make a real difference in freeing people from poverty, " he said.
Among the countries included in the index, corruption is perceived as most rampant in Chad, Bangladesh, Turkmenistan, Myanmar and Haiti-- also among the poorest countries in the world.
Moreover, extensive research shows that foreign investment is lower in countries perceived to be corrupt, which further thwarts their chance to prosper.

"Corruption isn't a natural disaster. It is the cold, calculated theft of opportunity from the men, women and children who are least able to protect themselves, " said David Nussbaum, TI's chief executive.

An increase in perceived corruption from 2004 to 2005 can be measured in countries such as Costa Rica, Gabon, Nepal, Papua New Guinea, Russia, the Seychelles, Sri Lanka, Suriname, Trinidad & Tobago and Uruguay.

Conversely, a number of countries and territories show noteworthy improvements -- a decline in perceptions of corruption -- over the past year, including Estonia, France, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kazakhstan, Nigeria, Qatar, Taiwan and Turkey.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Iraq Election Commission Checking Ballots
A sandstorm that had closed Baghdad's airport cleared Tuesday, allowing officials to resume flying ballot boxes to the capital Tuesday so "unusually high" vote totals in 12 Shiite and Kurdish provinces can be checked by election officials.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: GM, Amid Industry Overhaul, Cuts Health Benefits for Retirees
GM said it will slash health-care coverage for unionized retirees, cutting liabilities by about $15 billion. The move came as the auto maker posted a $1.63 billion loss amid deteriorating sales of trucks and SUVs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CONDEMNS PRESIDENT'S CALL TO BLOCK BILL BY `FOUL MEANS'

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) condemned President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday for vowing to block with bloodshed if necessary a PFP-driven bill purporting to improve peace with China.
PFP spokesman Chin Chin-shen said violence should not be allowed in society and certainly not in the legislature.
He said the PFP is worried that violence will be the order of the day in the Legislative Yuan as a result of Chen's encouragement.

The PFP spokesman said that Chen, who made the controversial remarks in a TV interview the previous night, was obviously making a desperate attempt to revive the sagging popularity of his administration, but his encouragement for violence has shamed his people.

Instead of addressing the issues facing the nation, Chin said Chen's interview focused on the opposition, and his broadside against the opposition made him more like an DPP campaign manager than the head of state.

Chin disputed the president's claims that the PFP is holding hostage its opposition ally the Kuomintang (KMT) and has forced the KMT to support its peace-promotion bill in exchange for the PFP's support for the KMT in its fight against the government's attempts to force the KMT to return its illegally obtained assets, saying the president should look at his own corruption-riddled administration and at the people, who are in the grip of misery.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS TECHNOLOGY TO PRODUCE TAMIFLU: DOH

TEXT.P: The National Health Research Institute is technically capable of producing Tamiflu, an anti-viral drug for the treatment of influenza, and will be granted a special permit to mass-produce the drug in the case of an avian flu outbreak among humans in Taiwan, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Hou Sheng-mou said Tuesday.

Hou told lawmakers during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan that the DOH has written to Franz B. Humer, chairman and CEO of the Swiss pharmaceutical company Roche, to express Taiwan's intention to negotiate with the company for a licensing agreement to produce Tamiflu.
Hou pointed out that Roche has so far only agreed to donate to the World Health Organization enough of the drug to treat 3 million people and has refused to license its patent rights to others.
Taiwan has stockpiled just 160,000 doses of Tamiflu, far short of the amount the nation needs to fight a pandemic.
If necessary, Taiwan will start mass production of Tamiflu in accordance with Article 76 of the Patent Act, Hou said.

The article stipulates that in order to cope with a national emergency or in the case of an applicant's failure to reach a licensing agreement with the patentee concerned under reasonable commercial terms and conditions within a considerable period of time, the patenting authorities may, upon an application, grant a right of compulsory licensing to the applicant to put the patented invention into practice.

Upon receipt of a written application for such compulsory licensing, the patenting authorities shall send a duplicate copy thereof to the patentee, requesting that a response be filed within three months. If no response is filed within the specified time limit, the patenting authorities may decide the matter at its own discretion, according to the article.

Also Tuesday, Center for Disease Control Director-General Kuo Hsu-sung said a pandemic of avian flu will come "sooner or later" and warned that its impact on Taiwan's society and economy will be 10 times more serious than the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome outbreak of 2003.

Delivering a speech on the issue to officials at the Kaohsiung city government, Kuo said the government has adopted measures such as increasing the country's stockpile of anti-flu drugs and developing new anti-flu vaccines to cope with a possible pandemic.

The government will also step up quarantine inspection in an attempt to prevent the virus from entering the country from abroad and strengthen disease control and prevention efforts in local communities, Kuo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE MILK TO BE OFFERED TO UNDERPRIVILEGED CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Eight local dairies will provide a total of 700,000 packs of milk free of charge to orphans and children from low-income families, the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Tuesday.
COA officials said that 32 orphanages and 1,168 elementary schools nationwide have registered to join the program, which will last 11 weeks.
They estimated that more than 23,000 children will benefit from the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S GROSS ENROLLMENT RATIO FOR AGE 6-21 HIGHEST IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Human Development Index (HDI) was ranked 25th in the world in 2003, with its gross enrollment ratio for the 6-21 age group at 97 percent, the highest in Asia, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Tuesday.

DGBAS officials said that the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) has since 1990 released the HDI, which measures the average achievements of a country by three basic aspects of human development -- life expectancy, knowledge and standard of living measured by GDP per capita.
As Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, the island's ranking was calculated by the DGBAS according to the U.N.'s HDI formula, DGBAS officials said.
Among the 177 countries surveyed in the 2003 report, Norway topped the list, followed by Iceland and Australia.
Ranked 25th among the countries surveyed, Taiwan belonged in the category of high human development as defined by the United Nations.
Among the various categories measured, the life expectancy of Japanese citizens was 82 years, while that of Taiwanese people was 76.1 years, a slight increase over the 2002 figure.
Meanwhile, deducting those aged over 65, the adult literacy rate in Taiwan was 99.1 percent.
Concerning the combined primary, secondary and tertiary education gross enrollment ratio, Britain topped the list with 123 percent, with Taiwan ranked 10th in the world and top in Asia.

In terms of GDP per capita, which can reflect the purchasing power of each country, that of Luxembourg topped the list, with US$62,298, while Taiwan's GDP per capita stood at US$23,911, 22nd in the world.

The officials noted that the GDP ranking does not necessarily equal the HDI ranking, which means countries not included at the top of the income pyramid can also achieve high human development, as evidenced by Sweden.
Singapore's HDI was ranked 26th, South Korea's was 29th, while that of Hong Kong was ranked 22nd in the report.
Taiwan's HDI was ranked 28th in 1990.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS NOT GIVEN MONEY TO ANY INDIVIDUAL IN MALAWI: MOFA

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Tuesday that Taiwan has never given money to any individual in Malawi, although the country has signed many cooperation projects with the southern African country.

Lu made the remarks after foreign wire services reported that former Malawi President Bakili Muluzi was being investigated on corruption allegations that might involve millions of dollars said to have been received from Taiwan, Libya, Morocco and other donors.

Muluzi, who was Malawi's president from 1994 to 2004, reportedly has business interests in transport, real estate, media and retail sales and pocketed nearly US$12 million between April 1999 and November 2004.

Lu noted that the Republic of China has signed several cooperation projects with Malawi, a staunch diplomatic ally of Taiwan, over the years and that the ROC government has implemented these projects as planned, but has never funneled money to any individual.
However, he noted that if Malawi asks for help from Taiwan in the investigation, the MOFA will respect the judicial system of Malawi and will offer necessary assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ELECTION' GETS 11 GOLDEN HORSE NOMINATIONS

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong film "Election" topped 55 other feature film entries in the 2005 Golden Horse Awards Film Festival with 11 nominations, according to a list of nominees announced by the panel of judges Tuesday.

The film, directed by Johnny To, has been nominated for best feature film, best director, best actor, best supporting actor, best cinematography, best original film song, best original film score, best sound effects, best original screenplay, best action choreography and best make-up and costume.
Following "Election" in close second place is "Kung Fu Hustle," another Hong Kong film directed by movie actor Stephen Chow, with 10 nominations.
"Three Times, " directed by Taiwan director Hou Hsiao-hsien, was placed third with nine nominations.
Both "Kung Fu Hustle" and "Three Times" are competing in the categories of best feature film and best director.
"The Myth," directed by Chinese director Stanley Tong and featuring world-famous movie star Jackie Chan, flopped completely with no nominations at all, despite high expectations.

Chen Yao-chi, a veteran movie director who heads the 11-member screening committee, said there are so many great films this year that "The Myth" was edged out of the nominations by very slight margins.

Altogether there are 80 films competing for 21 awards. The entries consist of 56 feature films, 17 short films, three documentaries and four animated films. Taiwan has 39 entries, including 18 feature films.

This year's panel of judges includes musician Shih Chieh-yung, writer Lao Jia-hua, actress Chen Chiu-yen, cinematographer Chen Huai-en, Shih Hsin University Professor Tseng Hsi-pa, playwright Liming Huang, film critic Wen Tien-hsiang and Hong Kong film director Weng Wei-chuan. Two foreign judges will join the final stage of the evaluation.
The winners will be announced at a ceremony Nov. 13 at the Keelung Cultural Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN URGES CHINA TO ALLOW APEC ENVOY TO ATTEND SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Instead of offering to give Taiwan a pair of pandas, China should show its goodwill by allowing Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to attend the next informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday.
Chen has named Wang as his proxy at the 2005 APEC summit to be held in Busan, South Korea in November, a choice that has been bitterly opposed by China.
Su said that Taiwan, as a full APEC member, should be entitled to rights equal to those enjoyed by other members, arguing that Beijing has no right to interfere in who represents Taiwan.

He said Wang's credentials and status as leader of the legislature make him a perfect candidate for the president's envoy and he urged everyone in Taiwan to support Wang's attendance at the APEC summit.

APEC is one of the few international bodies that admit both Taiwan and China. Because of China's opposition, the Republic of China president has been barred from attending the APEC summit in person and has to instead name a special envoy to attend on his behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD RAISES DAMAGES CLAIM IN SECOND SUIT AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Lawyers of People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong filed a second lawsuit in four months against President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday for claiming that Soong met with a ranking Chinese official in the United States early this year.

In the second lawsuit, Soong raised the damages claim from NT$1 to NT$50 million, in addition to demanding that Chen run apology advertisements in major Taiwan and foreign newspapers for three consecutive days.
Lawyer Lee

Fu-tien said Soong sued Chen June 3 for libel, and yet Chen kept on claiming Soong met with Chen Yun-lin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, in the United States in January.
During a TV interview Monday, the president claimed that his statement about the Soong-Chen meeting was "based on something" and not groundless, furthering angering the PFP.
In his lawsuit, Soong demanded that the president be summoned to appear in court to provide evidence of what he was basing his allegations upon.
Soong said as a policial leader, Chen's words and actions attract attention and that his "reputation damaging" statements have hurt the image of the PFP caucus and members.

In his second lawsuit, Soong demanded that Chen publish a half-page statement of apology for three days in a row on the front pages of the Liberty Times, China Times, and the United Daily News of Taiwan; on the front pages of the New York Times of the U.S. and the Financial Times of London; and right below the titles of Le Figaro of France and the Yomiuri Shimbun of Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISIT BY SENIOR CHINESE OFFICIAL MUST BE OFFICIALLY SANCTIONED: MAC

TEXT.P: Any senior Chinese official's request to visit Taiwan should be examined by a government panel organized by the Immigration Office under the National Police Agency and should be negotiated by government agencies of both sides, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday.

In response to news report that the opposition Kuomintang is planning to invite China's top Taiwan affairs official, Chen Yunlin, to attend a forum in Taiwan next month, Wu said Chen's request, if presented by the KMT, must first be examined by the Immigration Office.

Although officials representing different government agencies in the panel might have different opinions about Chen's trip, Wu said he is sure the panel will not impose extraordinary restrictions on Chen's entry.

As the director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's Statue Council, Wu said, Chen's safety in Taiwan is of great concern to the government and should be guaranteed through negotiations between government agencies of both sides.

He suggested that the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) would be able to facilitate Chen's trip to Taiwan if it were to take part in the proposed bilateral negotiations, although there is no sign that Beijing will give up its refusal to have any contact with the SEF.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 19, or the 17th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1216: King John of England, known as John Lackland, dies at the age of 49. During his reign, the English lost most of their possessions in France. The nobility rose up against John and forced him to sign the Magna Carta, a cornerstone of English political and civil liberties.
1781: General Charles Cornwallis, British commander, unwittingly delivers his 8,000 troops into the hands of the besieging American forces at Yorktown in Virginia, allowing Gen. George Washington to win the War of Independence for the American colonists.
1812: Tsar Alexander's refusal to negotiate, along with renewed Russian military activity to the south of Moscow, leaves Napoleon Bonaparte with no alternative but to begin retreating from Moscow, which was captured by the French.
1872: The Holtermann Nugget, a slate weighing 235.14 kilograms, is found in New South Wales, Australia. It contains 82.11 kilograms of gold, the largest single mass of gold ever found.
1901: Alberto Santos Dumont, a Brazilian aviator, circumnavigates the Eiffel Tower in his airship to win the Deutsche Prize, the first aviation prize.
1925: Chiang Ching-kuo leaves Shanghai for Moscow to study at Sun Yat-sen University.
1935: The League of Nations imposes sanctions against Italy following its invasion of Ethiopia.
1936: Chou Shu-jen, a modern Chinese writer who used the pen name Lu Hsun and was admired most by the Chinese communists, dies of illness in Shanghai at the age of 56.
1937: Ernest Rutherford, New Zealand-born British physicist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize in chemistry, dies at the age of 66. He is regarded as the founder of modern atomic theory.
1940: The Burma road is reopened after the British had closed it for three months.
1947: The Taiwan Provincial Government opens Keelung and Kaohsiung as international seaports.
1950: The North Korean capital of Pyongyang falls during the Korean War.
1960: The U.S. State Department establishes an embargo on Cuban-bound shipments of all goods except medicine and foodstuffs.
1960: Mauritania proclaims independence from France.
1963: Sir Alec Douglas-Home succeeds Harold Macmillan as British prime minister.
1968: Republic of China athlete Chi Cheng wins a bronze medal in the women's 80-meter low hurdle event with a time of 10.4 seconds at the 19th Olympic Games held in Mexico City.
1973: Dr. Li Yuan-zu is appointed president of National Chengchi University.
1975: A total of 5,462 athletes begin seven days of competition at the Second Taiwan Area Games in Taipei.
1979: Lord Killanin, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1981: San Antonio Mayor Henry Cisneros declares that the historic city in Texas will establish sisterhood ties with the city of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan.
1987: Wall Street experiences the worst day in its history, known as "Black Monday," with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting a record 508.32 points, knocking US$500 billion off share values. The decline is 22.6 percent, almost 10 percent greater than the stock market crash of 1929, which heralded the Great Depression.
1990: Mikhail Gorbachev, leader of the USSR, wins parliamentary approval for a plan to switch the centrally planned Soviet economy to a market economy.
1999: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese for their enthusiasm in providing assistance to Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: The ROC's opposition Kuomintang expels Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi from the party, chiding him for "severely opposing KMT policies and impeding the interests of the people."
2001: Vice President Annette Lu receives 1998 Nobel laureate in medicine, Dr. Ferid Murad, at the Presidential Office.
2001: U.S. President George W. Bush tells reporters that in a meeting with his mainland Chinese counterpart, he reiterated Washington's stance on the Taiwan issue, namely "one China" and "a resolution of differences through peaceful means."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the Book of Songs it is said: `I keep in mind the fine moral qualities which make no great noise or show.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CONDUCT ANTI-AVIAN FLU EXERCISE: OIE
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The International Office of Epizootics (OIE) said Tuesday that it has been informed by Taiwan that it will conduct an islandwide anti-avian flu exercise Wednesday.

OIE authorities said that they have been informed by Dr. Chang Tien-jye, the standing OIE representative in Taiwan, that the island's Council of Agriculture (COA) is scheduled to hold a supra-ministerial exercise Wednesday in which customs, coast guard, health, defense and transportation officials will take part.

The exercise is aimed at testing Taiwan's capability in preventing an avian flu outbreak and controlling the spread of H5N1 -- the strain of avian flu considered most likely to mutate into one that is easily transmitted among humans.

Since 2003, the H5N1 strain has killed thousands of migratory birds in western China, led to the culling of millions of chickens in China, Thailand and Romania, and resulted in the death of at least 60 people.

Participants in the Taiwan exercise will simulate culling affected birds, burying or burning the culled birds, stemming the flow of poultry and meat smuggling, and protecting their own health as well as the health of locally-raised animals and poultry, OIE officials said.

They noted that although the H5N1 strain has raised fears around the world, there have only been 117 confirmed cases of humans being infected by the virus to date. Basically, H5N1 is still a disease among animals, the officials said.

The OIE, which is on the front line in the global effort to prevent the spread of avian flu, has worked in close collaboration with the World Health Organization. The WHO has focused its attention mainly on preventing the spread of avian flu among humans.
WHO experts have warned that if the virus mutates into a strain that is easily transmitted among humans, this could lead to a major global pandemic which could kill millions of people.
Taiwan is at particular risk during the current season as migratory birds pass through the island on their journey south at this time of the year.
Both Taiwan and China are full members of the OIE. Taiwan is represented in the world animal health organization under the title "Taipei China."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FACES ATTACK IF IT REFUSES REUNIFICATION WITH CHINA: SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By C.C. Hwang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: China will swallow Taiwan by force within the next 10 to 15 years if the island does not accept reunification on Beijing's terms, a European scholar warned Tuesday.
The scholar, who currently teaches in Stockholm, said that China's military threats against Taiwan are "absolutely not a joke but a real and serious issue."

He who has done much research into cross-Taiwan Strait relations, made the comments while speaking at a seminar in London on "Taiwan-China Relations: What Role Can the European Union Play? " currently being held by the European Institute for Asian Studies (EIAS) and the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS) of the Univeristy of London.

One should pay proper heed to the phenomenon that the ambiguous tactics which have been adopted by the United States towards the cross-strait issue have turned the situation in China's favor, the scholar said.

He added that the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the United States and the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq have left Washington with too few military resources to do as much as it would like to maintain security in the Taiwan Strait.

These factors, in addition to the international community's recklessness in pursuing their business interests in the Chinese market without giving sufficient support to Taiwan, have escalated tensions in the strait, he also said.

He further said that people should not turn a blind eye to the military threat posed by China to Taiwan as Beijing has tried to legitimize the use of force against the island through its Anti-Secession Law passed in March of this year.

Furthermore, the scholar continued, the increasing influence of the People's Liberal Army in China's politics as well as its modernization which is aimed at challenging the United States' leadership in the world also poses a threat to Taiwan.

Noting that China has bluntly stated that it will not allow the current situation between the two sides of the strait to remain indefinitely, the scholar said that if Taiwan refuses to reunify with China on Beijing's terms, then China will use ballistic missiles to attack the island by 2014 or set up a naval blockade of the island.

He concluded that if the communist regime in Beijing remains unchanged and if no international forces intervene to prevent a possible conflict and resolve the cross-strait issue, then there are only two possible outcomes -- namely, Taiwan's status will be downgraded at the expense of Beijing, or armed conflict between China and Taiwan will break out.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SIX REFORMS BACKED BY THE PEOPLE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The six reforms spelled out by President Chen Shui-bian in his Double Ten National Day address have the support of the majority of the people, Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday in a Cabinet meeting.

Citing a survey conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan, the premier said that the proposed reshaping of the mass media received the highest level of support at 72 percent, followed by reform of the tax system, at 67.6 percent.
He said the survey shows that the people, regardless of their political affiliation, are looking forward to a revamping of the country's regulation of the mass media and the nation's tax system.

Pointing to an opposition-sponsored bill on the formation of a national communications commission which has been blocked twice in the legislature by the lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the premier said the differences between the ruling and opposition parties over the appointment of the commission's members should be sorted out through negotiations.

Even the administration's second-phase financial reform, which has been widely criticized for giving a few business groups the chance to corner the financial market, got the support of 51 percent of those surveyed, the premier said.

Although the public is split on the issue of financial reform, the premier said he is confident his Cabinet members will boost public support for it in a televised debate against the critics of the reform set for later this afternoon.

As to the president's other proposed reforms, 61.2 percent of those surveyed said they support reform to change the preferential interest rate of 18 percent for bank deposits of retired government employees, while 59.6 percent said they support investigation into assets inappropriately acquired by political parties, and 51.1 percent support constitutional reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD DECLINES TO CONFIRM REPORTS ON KMT DAILY PRINTING IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou declined to confirm news reports Wednesday that the KMT-owned Central Daily News is planning to begin publishing in China.
Ma said that there are currently four or five plans concerning the future development of the Central Daily News, and releasing the newspaper in the Chinese market is only one of the proposed plans.

Meanwhile, Ma confirmed that an economic cooperation forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) is slated to be held in Taipei in mid-December, marking the first ever meeting of its kind.

Ma noted that the forum is part of the efforts to materialize the "five consensuses" that former KMT Lien Chan reached with CPC General-Secretary Hu Jintao in Beijing during his historic "journey of peace" to China from late April to early May when he was still the KMT chairman.

According to Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT Mainland Affairs Department, the KMT will invite Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, to take part in the forum.
