DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. ARMS BAN ON CHINA UNLIKELY TO BE LIFTED BEFORE MID-2006: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Several European scholars said Tuesday that Taiwan will face an increasing military threat from China if Beijing succeeds in its lobbying to have the European Union lift its arms sales ban on China.

The scholars made the comments while attending a seminar on "Taiwan-China Relations: What Role Can the European Union Play? " which is currently being held in London by the European Institute for Asian Studies (EIAS) and the School of Oriental and African Studies of the University of London.
At the same, the scholars predicted that the possibility of the E.U. lifting the arms sales ban before next July is minimal.

According to Sebastian Bersick, a research fellow at the EIAS, even though Beijing has lobbied hard for a lifting of the ban, the E.U. has delayed doing so due mainly to a lack of improvement in China's human rights situation.

Also, although France and Germany, the two leading E.U. members, have voiced their support for a lifting of the ban, Britain, which currently holds the rotating presidency of the union until the end of the year, reportedly is opposed to it. Austria which will hold the presidency for the first half of next year, is also against it, so their is little chance that the ban will be lifted before next summer, Bersick said.
He added that the E.U.'s main allies, the United States and Japan, are also strongly opposed to a lifting of the ban.

Nevertheless, Bersick also pointed out that it will be difficult for Taiwan to make a major diplomatic breakthrough in its relations with the E.U. as the member states have adopted the "one China" policy.

Meanwhile, a Swedish scholar who has done much research into cross-Taiwan Strait relations, said that if the E.U. lifts the arms ban, Beijing will be able to acquire high-tech military equipment and thereby bolster its level of deterrence against possible U.S. intervention, which he said would pose a greater threat to Taiwan.

Talking about the role that the E.U. can play in cross-strait relations, the scholar, who preferred to remain anonymous, said that the E.U. can safeguard and legitimize Taiwan's current status of autonomy by helping expand Taiwan's room to join the international community.

The E.U. can also make it clear that if China launches an attack against Taiwan, it will join the United States, Japan, the Association of South East Asia Nations (ASEAN) and Australia to initiate an economic embargo against China, he said. He added that the E.U. should also contemplate ways to prevent and resolve possible cross-strait conflicts in the future.

The scholar further said that the political dispute between the ruling and opposition parties in Taiwan has been a continuing source of tension in cross-strait relations, stressing that the parties should work together as well as reach a consensus on the cross-strait issues and express a clear and united stance that "Taiwan hopes to maintain its political autonomy" rather than "explain their own position" while facing the international community.

Liu Shyh-fang, former secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, who also attended the seminar, called for the E.U. to play a more active role in helping resolve the problems between the two sides of the strait and in maintaining the current status quo in the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL PEACE CORPS GIVES UP RELIEF TRIP TO PAKISTAN

TEXT.P: Members of the private Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps decided Wednesday to abandon plans to travel to Pakistan to provide medical relief to victims in Kashmir in the wake of a deadly earthquake Oct. 8.

Taiwan Roots President Liu Chi-hsiang quoted Adam Fields, a U.S. national who has been a Taiwan Roots' volunteer, as saying after arriving in Pakistan a day earlier that the Pakistani government welcomes humanitarian relief and medical aid from around the world to its earthquake refugees, but will not issue visas to relief personnel from Taiwan, India or Israel.
Fields was told by the Pakistani authorities that if Taiwan groups plan to enter Pakistan for relief work, they should first obtain permission from Beijing, according to Liu.

Liu lashed out at the Pakistani government for politicizing a pure humanitarian aid issue, saying that linking humanitarian work to politics is the last thing that the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps would like to see and runs counter to the spirit in which the group was established.

Liu said that his group decided to go to Pakistan immediately after an area straddling India and Pakistan was rocked by a magnitude 7.6 earthquake Oct. 8, in which nearly 1,000 Pakistani hospitals were reportedly ruined and many medical professionals were killed.

Liu added that members of the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps, who traveled to the India-controlled area of Kashmir between late June and early July this year to offer free medical treatment to the people there, were planning to head to Pakistani Kashmir after the Oct. 8 earthquake, since that area was reportedly the hardest-hit.
The death toll might exceed 80,000 but the exact number is likely to never be known.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO EARMARK NT$20 BILLION FOR BIRD FLU PREVENTION

TEXT.P: The government is planning to funnel NT$20 billion (US$597 million) into avian flu prevention and control, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Hou Sheng-mou said Wednesday.

Briefing a group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators on the issue, Hou noted that the DOH has also drafted a bill on avian flu prevention and control and that it is currently being screened by the Cabinet.

Hou previously confirmed that the DOH has requested negotiations with the Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche on a licensing agreement to mass-produce Tamiflu, an anti-viral drug for the treatment of influenza, in Taiwan in order to ensure that the country has sufficient stockpiles of the drug to cope with a potential bird flu outbreak among humans.

According to Su Ih-jen, director of the Division of Clinical Research at the National Health Research Institutes (NHRI), Roche is considering licensing countries that have the capability to produce Tamiflu, and Taiwan is the first of such countries that has requested licensing.
Su said this is a good development, although Roche has not made a final decision on the matter.
He said the NHRI is able to produce enough 99.5-percent pure Tamiflu to treat one million people in three to five months to increase the country's stockpiles.

With a stockpile sufficient only to treat 160,000 people at present, Taiwan will purchase another 780,000 doses next year to make the reserves enough for use on 4 percent of the population, which will still be far below the 10 percent suggested by the World Health Organization, he pointed out.
While no avian influenza infection in humans has been detected in Taiwan so far, January to March 2006 -- the next peak influenza season -- will be a critical period for observation, Su said.

Former DOH Minister Lee Ming-liang said there are two possible patterns of avian influenza transmission: the first is the spread of the virus by migratory birds to Taiwan poultry and then to humans; and the second is for the virus to spread to Taiwan through human-to-human transmission in the wake of an avian influenza outbreak in Southeast Asia.
Lee predicted that the second transmission pattern is more likely than the first and warned health authorities to pay extra attention to the occurrence of cross-border infections.

Also Wednesday, Council of Agriculture officials said the council has had the Wild Bird Federation Taiwan step up its monitoring on migratory birds to prevent the invasion of the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain of the virus.
The federation is expected to examine 2,000 to 3,000 bird stool samples a year, the officials said.
Meanwhile, the government will continue to crack down on smuggling activities to try to prevent the possible invasion of the virus through smuggling channels, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 136.63 points to close at 5,694.16 due largely to global bird flu worries and a dropping U.S. stock market.

The bourse opened at the day's high of 5,788.83 and fluctuated between 5,692.28 and 5,788.83 during trading. A total of 3.23 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$72.65 billion (US$2.16 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 4.1 percent, followed by paper and pulp stocks at 3.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 2.7 percent, banking and financial stocks at 2.6 percent, textile shares at 2.5 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.3 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 1.0 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 927 to 108, with 88 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY CHEMICAL FORCE JOINS ANTI-AVIAN FLU DRILL

TEXT.P: Members of the army's chemical force took part in a nationwide anti-avian flu exercise held Wednesday in Hsinchuang, Taipei County, according to military sources.

The supra-ministerial exercise, sponsored by the Council of Agriculture, called together personnel from the Ministry of the Interior, Ministry of National Defense, Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Coast Guard Administration, the Department of Health and the Environmental Protection Administration, as well as city and county governments around the nation.

The exercise was aimed at testing Taiwan's ability to prevent an avian flu outbreak and control the spread of H5N1 -- the strain of avian flu considered most likely to mutate into a form that is easily transmitted among humans, officials said.

Since 2003, the H5N1 strain has killed thousands of migratory birds in western China, led to the culling of millions of chickens in Thailand, Romania and a number of other Asian and European countries, and resulted in the death of at least 60 people. Taiwan is at particular risk, as many migratory birds pass through the island on their journey south at this time of year.

Participants in the exercise simulated culling affected birds, burying or burning the culled birds, stemming the flow of poultry and meat smuggling, and protecting their own health as well as the health of locally raised animals and poultry.

World Health Organization experts have warned that if the H5N1 virus mutates into a strain that is easily transmitted among humans, it could lead to a major global pandemic that could kill millions of people.

Meanwhile, officials from the Veterans Affairs Commission urged the country's veterans and their dependents to observe a 10-day self-health monitoring program after returning to Taiwan if they travel to Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia or Cambodia. Home-bound people are required to wear face masks and fill in health report forms if they cough, have fever or suffer a sore throat during their flights or after arrival, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DROP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 161 points to close at 5,678, with 16,491 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November dropped 161 points to end at 5,688, with 32,601 contracts traded, while December futures lost 144 points to finish at 5,694, with 128 contracts traded.
March futures moved down 140 points to close at 5,700, with 22 contracts traded, while June futures lost 154 points to close at 5,700, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,839 for October, 5,849 for November, 5,838 for December, 5,840 for March and 5,854 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
October TE futures moved down 5.60 points to close at 235.45, with 4,834 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 6.75 points to finish at 234.45, with 6,553 contract transactions.
March TE futures moved down 5.85 points to end at 233.05, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures lost 28.6 points to finish at 856.0, with 2,421 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 26.4 points to close at 857.0, with 3,306 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved down 27.8 points to close at 857.2, with 12 contract transactions, while March TF futures lost 20.0 percent to close at 864.4, with two contract transactions.
June TF futures dropped 22.8 points to close at 862.4, with three contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.099 to close at NT$33.678.
A total of US$1.07 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.579 and hit a high of NT$33.726.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU PUSHES FOR MASS PRODUCTION OF TAMIFLU

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will request the legislature to pass a resolution demanding that the Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche license Taiwan to mass-produce Tamiflu, an anti-viral drug for the treatment of influenza, to cope with a possible pandemic of avian influenza, a TSU lawmaker said Wednesday.

Citing an estimate by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) , Legislator Lai Hsin-yuan said that approximately 5.3 million people in Taiwan will be infected in the case of an avian influenza pandemic, with 14,000 fatalities.

If the government fails to take proper precautionary measures in advance, 5 million people could be infected within two weeks of the first case of infection detected in Taiwan and 2.65 million people will die from the disease, Lai said.

Lai pointed out that according to a World Health Organization recommendation, Taiwan should stockpile enough Tamiflu to treat at least 2.3 million people and that there are still 2.14 million doses short.
Even if Taiwan starts mass-producing the drug now, the production will only finish in April next year, which will pose a serious gap in the prevention of a bird flu outbreak, Lai said.
The DOH has requested negotiations with Roche on a licensing agreement to mass-produce Tamiflu in Taiwan. Roche reportedly is considering Taiwan's request.

Department of Health Minister Hou Sheng-mou said Tuesday that if necessary, the government will grant the National Health Research Institute (NHRI) a special permit to mass-produce Tamiflu in accordance with Article 76 of the Patent Act, in the absence of Roche's licensing.

According to Su Ih-jen, director of the NHRI's Division of Clinical Research, unlike the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, virus which is transmissible only after an infected person comes down with a fever, the bird flu virus is transmissible even during the incubation period.
Su predicted that the infection rate of avian influenza can be kept below 3 percent if proper public health measures are taken.

The cure rate will reach over 90 percent if a bird flu patient takes Tamiflu within two days of the appearance of symptoms and the rate will top 70 percent if the drug is taken within five days, Su said.
However, Tamiflu will have no effect on the bird flu virus if a patient takes the drug one week after the appearance of symptoms, he said.
He said the NHRI has cooperated with several private pharmaceutical companies and would be able to produce 200,000 doses of Tamiflu in two to three months.
It will take five months to produce one million doses, he added.

Meanwhile, Deputy CDC Director-General Lin Ting said the DOH has prepared more than 3,000 isolation wards, 3.74 million N95 masks, 4.89 million protective gowns and more than 21 million surgical masks as precautions.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO READY TO FIGHT AVIAN FLU: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh claimed Wednesday that there is "no need for panic" as the government is well prepared to combat avian flu and that the public needs to simply wash their hands and take other common sense personal hygiene measures.
Hsieh offered his reassurances after listening to a joint report by the Department of Health (DOH) and the Council of Agriculture (COA) on their preparations for a possible outbreak of bird flu.
"We should all be confident, as Taiwan is one of the few countries in the world capable of mass producing Tamiflu," a patented drug said to be effective in curing flu, Hsieh said.

He said he has told the DOH to stage a simulation of class-B and class-C level onslaught of new flu viruses with the participation of all related government agencies. He also said a "war conference" should be held to decide on detailed steps to fight avian flu.

Now is the time that migratory birds make their south-bound journeys through Taiwan, Hsieh said, so the COA should step up efforts to monitor fowl-slaughtering and pigeon-raising businesses and to urge local governments to carry out quarantine and other epidemic-prevention measures.
The Coast Guard authorities should work harder to crack down on smuggling, including using the NT$20 million reward as an incentive to encourage tipping off the authorities, said the premier.
He added that the Ministry of Justice should also raise penalties by amending existing laws and regulations as part of the effort to deter would-be offenders.

Should it become necessary to slaughter migratory birds, he said, this should still be done on the principle of "least disturbing and minimizing sacrifices" by, for example, widening the quarantine areas while limiting the slaughter.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER: EDUCATION REFORMS SHOULD CONTINUE

TEXT.P: The 10-year-old educational reform program is moving in the right direction and deserves to be carried on, Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said Wednesday, although he admitted that they could be improved upon.
Fielding questions from lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan, the minister refused a demand for an apology from an opposition lawmaker for what the lawmaker called the failure of the education reforms.

Citing fact-finding trips to elementary and junior middle schools around the island in the last year, Tu said he is encouraged to find that the reforms are taking hold in elementary schools, with students more interested in learning and teachers having more leeway in organizing their teaching programs and materials.

However, the minister said, the positive changes brought about by the reforms in elementary schools do not extend to junior middle schools because their students are gearing themselves up for senior high school entrance examinations.
The cause of the problems hindering the reforms lie mainly in the way the reforms are implemented and this could be amended to improve their effects, Tu said.

Also, the eventual success of the reforms depends partly on changes in public opinion about education to make parents realize that education should be more than just giving students degrees or preparing them for a prosperous career.
The minister claimed that the reform program is worthy, judging by its results thus far.

The opposition lawmaker demanded the apology on the grounds that the mastermind of the reform, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, said at the legislature Oct. 13 that he was sorry because the program had failed to live up to public expectations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAIL-BLAZER OF TAIWAN'S ATOMIC SCIENCE DIES

TEXT.P: Dr. Sun Kuan-han, an atomic scientist known as the father of Taiwan's atomic science, died at a hospital in Taipei Oct. 14 from pneumonia and meningitis at the age of 92, according to a statement issued Wednesday by the National Tsing Hua University in Hsinchu city, where Sun worked before retiring.
A funeral committee chaired by Tsing Hua President Dr. Frank Hsia-san Shu said a memorial service will be held Oct. 23 at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei where Sun died.

Born 1914 in Xaoxing, in southern China's Zhejiang Province, Sun earned a doctorate in Physics from the University of Pittsburgh in the United States and developed an international reputation as the first person to detect the neutron with a scintillation counter.
He worked as a visiting professor of Tsing Hua in 1959, and was tasked to set up its Atomic Science Graduate School, which boasts the country's first atomic reactor.
In addition to being an excellent scientist, Sun was known as a human rights activist who led a 10-year campaign to demand the release of Taiwan's well-known political dissident Bo Yang in the 1980s.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE

TEXT.P: Our Oct. 17 CEP No. 30 contains a mistake in the second paragraph -- "Paraguay" should read "Brazil."

A corrected version follows:
MOST JUNK MAIL FLOWING TO TAIWAN FROM ASIA: SURVEY

Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) As much as 60 percent of the junk mail flowing into Taiwan is from Asia, with China taking the largest share of 25 percent, according to an analysis recently conducted by Openfind Information Technology Inc., a local company that provides mail protection systems.

Brazil and Uruguay are the second-largest sources, which together sent out 17.8 percent of the junk mail arriving in Taiwan, followed by the United States with 8 percent, and India and South Korea each with more than 5 percent, Openfind researchers said, adding that Taiwan is also one of the major sources, generating 16.5 percent.
The amount of junk mail is usually 10 percent or 15 percent higher on holidays than on weekdays, according to the analysis results.

Junk mail has been growing at an alarming rate in recent years, and has accounted for 90 percent of the total number of e-mails sent since the beginning of this year compared to last year's level of 50 percent for the same period, the researchers pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Miers Backed Abortion Ban in 1989. As a candidate for the Dallas City Council in 1989, Harriet E Miers stated that she was deeply opposed to abortion and assure an anti-abortion group that she "actively supported" legislation to outlaw the procedure if the Supreme Court ever overturned the Roe VS. Wade decission.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT REPS BANNED FROM TAKING BONUSES FROM STATE ENTERPRISES

TEXT.P: The government ruled Wednesday that government-appointed board members of state-run enterprises should not take any bonuses and that money or assets given in forms other than bonuses should be returned to the state coffers.

After a Cabinet meeting, Premier Frank Hsieh also announced that retired officials who continue to work at government-subsidized non-profit organizations can take a maximum monthly salary of NT$31,200 and that anything other than that must also be returned to the government.
Those already working at government-funded groups must sign an affidavit promising to be paid NT$31,200 per month at the most, otherwise they will not be re-hired when their contracts expire.

The premier made the decision in the wake of controversy surrounding China Steel Corp. Chairman Lin Wen-yuan's fat yearly stock bonus valued at NT$44 million and "double dipping" government retirees working at government-funded foundations or think tanks.

The policy takes effect immediately, meaning that from now on, Lin's replacement and others appointed to profit-making state-run businesses will not be able to enjoy their fat cat bonuses and the much-reviled practice of "double dipping" will finally come to an end.

Retired government employees, including teachers and soldiers, already have a retirement fund, part of which bears an annual interest of 18 percent under a special program funded by the Taiwan tax payer. If they are hired by government funded groups, they are paid a second full-time job salary -- thus the term "double dipping."

Hsieh said current laws do not ban government-appointed members on the boards of state-run enterprises from taking bonuses, but after a review by the Ministry of Finance, the government decided to stop them from taking any profit other than their fixed salaries.

Therefore, he noted, even if some corporations attempt to give cash to board members using other titles such as "performance rewards" or "incentives, " such profits must be coughed up and handed back to the government coffers.
The new rule applies to all government-invested enterprises and non-profit organizations, including special funds, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD LEARN FROM U.S. DEMOCRACY: FORMER PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D.C., Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chen, Oliver Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: As a young democracy, Taiwan should learn from the U.S. example, specially in terms of its passing the history, values and ideals of democracy to future generations, former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said in the U.S. capital Tuesday.

Lee said that in order to deepen and consolidate its democracy, Taiwan needs more time and effort by its government and people, as well as the support of its American friends and Taiwanese expatriates overseas.
According to Lee, the constitution passed recently by the Iraqi people is a great achievement for the United States in promoting democracy to the rest of the world.
He said freedom and human rights are universal values and rights that people around the world should be entitled to.
Lee made the remarks while addressing a dinner hosted by ROC representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee at his official residence in Washington, D.C.

Also invited to the event were Congressional Taiwan Caucus co-chairs Steve Chabot and Dana Rohrabacher; former American Institute in Taiwan Chairmen Therese Shaheen and Natale Bellocchi; and Randal Schriver, former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state in charge of East Asia and Pacific affairs.
Washington is the third leg of Lee's two-week U.S. visit, which has already taken him to Alaska and New York.

Lee is expected to attend a welcome reception hosted by a group of U.S. congressional members at Capitol Hill Wednesday and to deliver a speech at the National Press Club Thursday before flying to Los Angeles.
Earlier Tuesday, Lee held talks with scholars during a seminar held at the Heritage Foundation.
According to participants, Lee talked about issues relating to Taiwan's national identity and displayed optimism about the country's future.
He also expressed his concern about China's military buildup and said he believes China's democratization will take a very long time, they said.
Calling Lee a democratic hero in Asia, Heritage Foundation senior research fellow John Tkacik said he is glad Lee was able to visit the United States.

Schriver, who also attended the seminar, praised Lee as a serious, experienced and wise politician who enjoys important status in the history of Taiwan, saying it is worth listening to his speech regardless of whether he agrees or disagrees with Lee's opinions.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'RICE BOMBER' SENTENCED TO SEVEN-AND-A-HALF YEARS

TEXT.P: A panel of Judges at the Taipei District Court sentenced "rice bomber" Yang Ju-men Wednesday to seven-and-a-half years in prison, plus a fine of NT$100,000, for placing 16 bombs in public places in northern Taiwan during a one-year period from November 2003.
The 26-year-old poultry merchant can still appeal his case to a higher court.

Yang, a resident of Keelung, turned himself in to the police in November last year. Police said that tests on DNA specimens collected from some of the crime scenes showed they matched his DNA. Police also found that he had received explosives training while serving in the marine corps.

Yang later admitted to leaving 16 home-made explosive devices in parks, trains, railway stations and mobile toilets in an attempt to call the government's attention to the plight of rice farmers caused by imports of rice under World Trade Organization rules. Some of the bombs went off, but no one was injured.

Conspicuously present in the courtroom and outside the court building Wednesday were hundreds of farmers and social movement workers, each wearing a yellow ribbon, in support of Yang. There was a commotion when the supporters became emotional upon hearing the sentence, but it did not turn into disorder.

Farmers organizations had urged the authorities not to treat the terrorist as such, claiming he had "no intention of hurting anyone" and would always leave a note or a letter at the scene, identifying himself as an opponent of the government's rice import policy.
Some 30,000 farmers have signed a petition calling for his release, and many have donated money for his legal battle.
The farmers have also called on the government to ease their plight caused by imported rice. Taiwan imports 147,000 metric tons of rice a year -- about 8 per cent of the island's total consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITU RANKS TAIWAN WORLD'S 7TH IN NARROWING DIGITAL DIVIDE

TEXT.P: The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) ranked Taiwan the world's seventh in its Digital Opportunity Index, a reflection that Taiwan has made remarkable efforts in the field, according to Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching.

The ITU, an international organization within the United Nations System where governments and the private sector coordinate global telecom networks and services, placed Taiwan seventh in its global Digital Opportunity Index which was issued in June, Lin said.

During this year's May 31 economic ministers and senior officials' meeting sponsored by the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, attendees loudly praised Taiwan's contribution and sharing in the APEC Digital Opportunity Center (ADOC) , Lin surther said, adding that their comments were documented in a joint declaration of the meeting.

The Peruvian press has made an extensive report about Taiwan's assistance in helping the country set up an ADOC, and Peruvian Congress Speaker Antero Flores-Araoz sent a letter in May this year expressing his gratitude to APEC, Lin pointed out.
Taiwan has also helped the Philippines, Vietnam, Indonesia, Chile and Papua New Guinea established ADOCs in an effort to help these countries bridge their digital divides, he said.

ADOC is an independent, non-profit organization funded by Taiwan, which put forward the idea of transforming digital divides into digital opportunities at the 11th APEC economic leaders' meeting in Bangkok in 2003. It was initiated in 2004.

At home, the broadband coverage rate has reached 99.1 percent, close to the 99.6 percent target set for 2008, he said, noting that the government has refurbished relevant facilities at 389 remote elementary and high schools nationwide and opened 33 digital opportunity centers in areas hit by the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake in Yunlin, Changhua, Pingtung and Penghu counties and aboriginal villages across the country in July.

Earlier this year, the Environmental Protection Administration donated 1,500 computers and the Ministry of Education also gave away 1,000 second-hand computers to poor families in rural areas, he went on, spelling out the government's hope of building the entire country into a wireless space where people can easily log on the Internet and watch television on every corner.

The government has in recent years subsidized more than 30,000 aboriginal families in mountainous areas in improving the quality of the image that they receive on their TV sets, he said. Some 15,000 of those families now enjoy better quality, with the remaining 20,000 households set to get better service by the end of next year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA DEMANDS THAT FREIGHTER SEEPING CHEMICALS BE MOVED SOON

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) demanded Wednesday that the South Korean freighter that collided with a Liberian freighter earlier this month in waters near Taiwan to be moved away soon due to worries of chemical leakage.
The 2,761-ton South Korean freighter "Sam-ho Brother" was hit by the Liberian-registered freighter Oct. 10 in waters off Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan.

Several days after the accident, experts found that there was a small amount of benzene leakage from the cargo ship, which was carrying 85 tons of fuel oil, 16 tons of diesel and 3,000 tons of methyl benzene when it was passing through Taiwan Oct. 10.

Though the EPA officials estimated that the amount of benzene leakage is not expected to affect Taiwan proper and its nearby coast now as the freighter is still 17 or 18 kilometers away from the island, the officials are still asking the shipowner to move the boat as soon as possible to avoid polluting the nearby coast.
It was reported that the shipowner may scupper the ship where it is.
However, as there were no complementary contamination prevention measures presented by the shipowner, the EPA has asked for more information.

EPA officials stressed that since this was a rare, serious accident for chemical freighters within and without the country, the agency will strictly supervise the movement of the ship and may fine the shipowner NT$1.5 million (US$44,682) should the freighter cause contamination of marine resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT FAILS TO DEAL WITH ASSET QUESTION AS EAST GERMAN COMMUNISTS: DPP

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is inferior to the German Communist Party in terms of the handling of its ill-gotten party assets, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus in the Taipei City Council said Wednesday.

Chen Cheng-teh, the DPP caucus whip, said that after the reunification of Germany in 1990, the German Communist Party, better known as the DKP (Deutsche Kommunistische Partei), supported the passage of a law governing political parties and political groups that required all German parties to reveal their assets and refrain from operating any profit-making enterprises.

In line with the law, Chen said, the German federal government has continued to dig into the DKP's ill-gotten assets. In 1998, an independent commission came up with an investigative report saying that the DKP, which is still a force in German politics today under the designation of the Party of Democratic Socialism, had accumulated a stash of US$60 billion in ill-gotten assets during its rule of East Germany. In 2003, the commission furnished the German parliament with another report that the DKP had additional assets in Luxembourg, Austria, Switzerland and Hungary. Up until now, the commission remains operational.

In contrast, Chen said, the KMT has consistently resisted the appeal for returning its ill-gotten party assets to national coffers. In March 1992, then-DPP Legislator Peng Pei-hsien first brought up the KMT's ill-gotten assets issue during a legislative interpellation session.

Another DPP legislator, Lai Ching-lin, came up with a draft bill on the disposition of the KMT's ill-gotten assets and the establishment of a political party development fund in March 2000 after the KMT lost a presidential election earlier that month.

"So many years have passed, the KMT still drags its feet on disposing of its ill-gotten assets. The party has joined with its 'pan-blue alliance' ally, the People First Party, to stonewall the inclusion of a Cabinet-proposed bill on the disposition of political parties' ill-gotten assets into the legislative agenda," Chen said.

Quoting official tallies, Chen said, the KMT, which fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a bloody civil war to the Chinese communists on the mainland and ruled Taiwan uninterruptedly until May 2000, has so far returned a marginal 1. 3 percent of its ill-gotten real estate back to the national coffers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Hussein Faces Tribunal Today In First Trial for Actions in Iraq.
Almost two years after U.S. forces captured a disheveled Saddam Hussein hiding in a hole in the ground on a farm near his home town of Tikrit, the former Iraqi president will appear Wednesday before a five-member panel of his countrymen in the first criminal case brought against him and seven Baath Party associates, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU AIMS TO BE AMONG WORLD'S TOP 100 UNIVERSITIES IN 10 YEARS

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) -- Taiwan's top-ranking university -- has mapped out a detailed plan to advance itself into the world's top 100 universities in 10 years, NTU president Li Si-chen said Wednesday.

Answering questions at a joint meeting of the legislature's Education and Culture Committee and Budget and Final Accounts Committee, Li said NTU had begun its planning six years ago, and that the persistent efforts have borne fruit this month, with the Ministry of Education earmarking NT$6 billion (US$180.7 million) over two years for NTU's further enhancement.
The funds came under a government plan to appropriate NT$50 billion over five years to help Taiwan's top universities improve their international rankings.

Li said NTU plans to seek breakthroughs in 10 to 15 fields of study and will use the funds to improve the software and the infrastructure of the school and create a better research environment so that the university can achieve its goal of presenting more than 5,000 academic theses in the next five years.
He said he is confident that NTU will be ranked among the world's top 100 universities within the next decade.

According to the 2005 Higher Education Supplement compiled by The Times of London, NTU ranks 102nd among world universities. However, in the Academic Ranking of World Universities by the Institute of Higher Education of Shanghai Jiao Tong University, NTU is placed 183rd.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN CHARTER FLIGHT TO HONG KONG 70 PERCENT FULL

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines is set to ply the first charter flight from Taichung in central Taiwan to Hong Kong Thursday, with the plane 70 percent full, a spokesman for the aviation company said Wednesday.

About 70 passengers, mainly members of a tour group organized by a tourist agency based in Taichung, will board the plane, which is slated to depart Chingchuankang Airport in Taichung at 5: 00 p.m. and to return from Hong Kong empty later the same day, the spokesman said.

Mandarin Airlines was granted the approval late Tuesday to run two charter flights to Hong Kong by the civil aviation authorities in the territory, with the second flight set for Sunday, which will bring back the tour group to Taichung, he said.

The approval came at the last minute and was a surprise to Mandarin Airlines, which filed an application with Hong Kong a few months ago, leaving very little time for the Taipei-based carrier to lure a larger number of passengers, he noted, pointing out that the company might not apply for flights next month during the low season.
Meanwhile, UNI Airways has yet to receive Hong Kong's permission to operate Taichung-Hong Kong charter flights Oct. 27 and Oct. 30.

Although Chingchuankang Airport is dubbed as an international airport by Taiwan's civil aviation authorities, it can only accommodate short-range charter flights to Hong Kong, South Korea and Japan due to its limited facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR TRACING ALLEGED KICKBACKS PAID IN THAILAND IN KRTC CASE

TEXT.P: A prosecutor from the Kaohsiung District Prosecutors' Office is in Thailand to trace alleged kickbacks paid before introducing Thai laborers to work on the mass rapid transit system in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Wang Chun-li, chief prosecutor of Kaohsiung District Prosecutors' Office, arrived in Thailand last week to look into an alleged illegal profiteering case exposed by the Aug. 21 riot of Thai laborers working for Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC).

Investigators believe that the kickbacks received by the Taiwanese manpower brokerage Huapan Administration Consultant Co. Ltd. from Thai workers were already paid in Thailand before the workers came to Taiwan in an attempt to avoid detection.

Wang said to have been sending information he collected in Thailand back to Taiwan during the last few days, and the investigation task force in Taipei summoned an accountant of Huapan Wednesday for more questioning.
However, the investigation task force in Taipei would not reveal too much about the progress in the case or when Wang would return to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FATE OF VICE MINISTER OF TRANSPORTATION HANGS IN THE BALANCE

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Wednesday that he will decide within one week whether his deputy, Chou Li-liang, should step down and face investigation by public prosecutors for profiteering involving the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project.

Replying to questions from Legislator Huang Chao-shun during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Lin said he did not know whether the vice minister had been summoned to explain to the public prosecutors about the role he played while he was chief of the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit Department under the Kaohsiung City Government.
Lin said he will complete a review within one week and then decide if Chou should "avoid serving in his current post."

Chou was promoted to his present post in February this year amid criticism after he resigned as the Kaohsiung MRT department chief last year under pressure because of a series of landslides and other accidents at MRT construction sites.

A leading prosecutor revealed Tuesday that a task force formed by the Department of Justice will question Chou about his suspected involvement in the profiteering scandal, which was brought to light by the Aug. 21 riot of Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project to protest their inhumane treatment by their employers and a manpower management company.

DOC.HEADLINE: IRREGULARITIES IN NAVY BOATS CONTRACT WILL BE INVESTIGATED: MND

TEXT.P: If any irregularities are found to have taken place in the bidding for 30 missile-equipped ROC Navy speedboats, the defense ministry will refer the case to prosecutors, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye told lawmakers Wednesday.

Lee made the remarks at the National Defense committee of the Legislative Yuan in reply to Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lee Wen-chung, who said there were several "suspicious points" regarding the ROC Navy's Kuang Hua No. 6 Shipbuilding Project.

The minister said he was not aware of the review process that was handled by the Cabinet's Public Construction Commission (PCC), but he admitted that there may be "something strange" about the fact that a company offering a lower price did not win the bid.
He emphasized that there had been no so-called "pressure from above" during the bidding process.
Although China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) was awarded the contract for the vessels, controversy surrounds the nature of the rankings for two other companies that did not win the bid.

Lee Wen-hung pointed to two unusual things about the bidding process: according to a PCC report, of the 10 review committee members, five gave Ching Fu Shipbuilding Co. a first-place ranking while the other five ranked it third.
These 10 members, five from the private sector and five from the military, did just the opposite for Jong Shyn Shipbuilding Co. -- with five ranking it first and five putting it third.

He pointed out that the five who gave Ching Fu full marks were from the military while those placing it third were private-sector experts. The two groups made the exact opposite assessment of Jong Shyn.

He said the authorities should look into the original bidding files to see if there had been any problems with the two companies and their connections with these two groups of review committee members.
Opposition People First Party Legislator Sun Ta-chien suspected that the two companies might have known beforehand the identities of the 10 people who were going to vet the tenders.

Sun claimed at a news conference at the legislature that Ching Fu Chairman Chen Ching-nan has close ties with President Chen Shui-bian, while Jong Shyn Chairman Han Pi-hsiang is well connected to first lady Wu Shu-jen and Vice President Annette Lu, resulting in a bidding race that more resembled a "duel between two factions inside the court," instead of a business deal.

He said Ching Fu has an "extremely poor record" of building frigates for the navy, and yet the five military experts still ranked it No. 1. This seems to indicate that its chairman must have had access to the list of the review committee members, which should have remained confidential, he asserted.

In the end, CSBC won the bidding by beating out Ching Fu and Jong Shyn. However, Sun said, Jong Shyn's appeal to the PCC did not complain about the CSBC but instead focused criticism on Ching Fu, meaning that CSBC was kept out of the fray.
He urged the prosecution to investigate the PCC's decision-making process, adding that the defense ministry should also explain why the navy has suddenly suspended the procurement process.

Even though the CSBC, by all reports, was given the contract, the building project was halted after Jong Shyn launched a publicity campaign to sway the awarding of the contract on the grounds that it can do the same job at a lower price.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND-PHASE REFORM AIMED AT MEGA-MERGERS, COMPETITIVENESS: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i defended the government's policy Wednesday to carry out the second-phase of financial reform, underlining the urgent need for Taiwan's banks to merge and sharpen their competitive edge internationally.

Stressing that Taiwan's banks are not competitive either at home or abroad due to their relatively small scale and assets, Wu said that the government means to make domestic banking institutions bigger and stronger through the second-round of reform to tackle aggressive foreign competition.
For instance, Wu said, the five largest banks in South Korea take a combined 79 market share at home, while Taiwan's five biggest banks only grab a 37 percent market share, he pointed out.

Smaller asset holdings also drag down the competitiveness of Taiwan's banks, he said, adding that the Citibank Group of the United States has US$1 trillion in assets, far ahead of the Bank of Taiwan, the most representative state-run bank that has NT$2.5 trillion in assets (US$74 billion) , the world's 125th, while Cathay Financial Holdings, Taiwan's largest financial services company, has US$80 billion.

Wu made the remarks during a televised debate with opposition lawmakers over the government's second-phase financial reform plan, which has drawn flak from the opposition camp that accuses the government of intending to sell state property cheaply to special vested groups.

Speaking on the same occasion, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said that the second-round financial revamp plan is meant to build Taiwan into a financial hub in the Asia-Pacific region.

Taiwan's financial industry must seek to catch up with the pace of the domestic manufacturing sector that has for some time engaged in global market deployment, Hu said, stressing that the domestic financial services sector should also branch out to better serve Taiwan companies abroad.

To be competitive in foreign markets, Taiwan banks must gain momentum through mergers to sustain scale operations overseas, he argued, claiming that 41 state-run banks, though slashed from originally 47, are still too many compared to those in other countries such as Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Singapore and South Korea.

Responding to the question of whether the deadline set for the end of this year is too early and the process has been clumsy, the CEPD head pledged that the government will review relevant measures and make necessary adjustments toward its ultimate goal of making Taiwan a regional financial center.

Financial reform has been one of the government's top priorities since President Chen Shui-bian first came to power in 2000. The first-phase financial overhaul successfully wrote off much of Taiwan banks' bad loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA MINDFUL OF RUMSFELD'S CHINA VISIT: FOREIGN MINISTRY SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has expressed to U.S. authorities Taiwan's stance on U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld's current visit to China, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said Wednesday.

"We have asked the United States not to promote its ties with China at Taiwan's expense during Rumsfeld's visit, " Lu said, adding that MOFA has been closely monitoring Rumsfeld's ongoing China visit.
According to Lu, the United States will follow the traditional protocol of briefing Taiwan on the event before and after Rumsfeld's visit.

"Our present observation is that Rumsfeld has continued to reaffirm the established U.S. policy on relations across the Taiwan Strait which emphasizes maintaining the present cross-strait status quo," Lu said.

Rumsfeld is currently in Beijing for his first-ever trip to China in his capacity as the Pentagon chief. During his Oct. 18-20 China visit, Rumsfeld will meet Chinese President Hu Jintao, Defense Minister Chao Gangchuang and other senior officials.

In addition to expressing his concern about China's "rapid, non-transparent" military buildup, Lu said, Rumsfeld is also expected to seek common China-U.S. interests in political, economic and military fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRUMPS CHINA'S 'ONE-CHILD POLICY' BY ADVOCATING THREE KIDS

TEXT.P: The "one-child policy" may be fine for China, but Taiwan's falling birthrate has prompted officials to advocate three-child families, with the slogan: "Two kids are happy, three kids are lively."
Vice Minister of the Interior Chang Wen-ying said Wednesday that the ministry has recently published two brochures on population affairs, with one focusing on new immigrants and the other on locals.
Chang pointed out that Taiwanese families have been leaning toward having only a single child, and the ministry has for some time been asking families to consider having two children.

However, according to Chang, the birth rate in Taiwan has been declining significantly in the last decade, with the number of newborn babies dropping from 325,000 in 1996 to only 115,000 in the first seven months of this year.
Taiwanese women are inclined to have fewer children due largely to economic factors and increasing concerns about raising a child, Chang said.
Chang said if the situation continues, the economic burden for the new generation in caring for their elderly parents in the future will increase dramatically.

In addition, more and more government statistics are showing that Taiwan's population is aging rapidly, with the island expected to become an "aged society" by 2018, causing many complicated problems for the society.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE DEAD, TWO MISSING IN ANTI-SUBMARINE HELICOPTER CRASH

TEXT.P: An ROC Navy anti-submarine S-70C helicopter with three crew members aboard crashed into waters off the Tsoying naval base in southern Taiwan Wednesday, killing one officer and leaving the other two missing, military authorities said.

The body of co-pilot Lt. Commander Yang Shun-yuan was recovered some 45 minutes after the anti-submarine helicopter went down 34 nautical miles from the Tsoying naval base near Kaohsiung, the Navy General Headquarters said in a news release.
A search was under way for the other two crew members, identified as Navy Lieutenant Sung Yu-shao and Master Sergeant Huang Hsien-hua, the statement said.

Initial investigations showed that the S-70C might have developed mechanical problems on its way back to a shipboard base after completing a nighttime training mission, the statement said, adding that the real cause of the accident is still under investigations.
The Coast Guard Administration said it has sent two patrol vessels to assist in the search and rescue mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST BECOME MORE DEMOCRATIC TO RESIST CHINA'S PRESSURE: CHIOU

TEXT.P: Taiwan would be better able to resist China's pressure through becoming more democratic, more open and more liberal, National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen said Wednesday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan budget screening session, Chiou said a certain number of retired military, police and security officers have indeed traveled to China and offered Taiwan-related intelligence to Chinese authorities in exchange for personal benefits.
"As Taiwan has become an open, democratic country, we cannot illegally wiretap anyone," Chiou said.

Nevertheless, he said, the government has stepped up national security measures to cope with the new situation. As part of this campaign, Chiou said President Chen Shui-bian recently called a high-level national security conference and urged the executive branch to look into the inroads of Chinese underworld figures into Taiwan.
In the face of China's threat, Chiou said he is convinced that Taiwan must become even more democratic, more open and more liberal if it wants to head off China's pressure.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, October 20:

DOC.HEADLINE: MND VOWS TO EXPAND MILITARY EXCHANGES WITH NEIGHBORING COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will strive to forge military cooperation and exchanges with neighboring countries through official or non-official channels, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Wednesday.
Lee made the remarks while delivering a report at the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee on the MND's work agenda and budget plans for 2006.

With a view to upgrading Taiwan's international visibility and presence, Lee said, the MND will pull out all the stops to foster cooperative ties with peripheral countries and seek opportunities for observing each other's military exercise programs.
Lee further said the military will continue to promote a volunteer service system, with volunteer soldiers accounting for 60 percent of all military personnel by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 20, or the 18th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1818: Britain and the United States establish a border along the 49th parallel west of the Great Lakes.
1827: The Battle of Navarino in Greece comes to an end as British, French and Russian fleets annihilate the Turkish and Egyptian fleets.
1890: Sir Richard Burton, British explorer, soldier, diplomat and scholar, dies of a heart attack in Trieste at the age of 69. He discovered Lake Tanganyika and translated the 16-volume "Arabian Nights".
1891: Sir James Chadwick, English physicist, is born. He won the 1935 Nobel Prize in physics for the discovery of the neutron.
1935: Mao Tse-tung and his communist forces end their so-called "Long March" in Yenan in Shensi Province. On Oct. 10, 1934, the main forces of the Chinese communists fled their bases in Kiangsi Province to the northwest, launching the "Long March."
1935: Arthur Henderson, British politician and founder of the Labor Party, dies at the age of 72. He won the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize for his contributions as president of the World Disarmament Conference.
1943: The Republic of China signs a new Sino-Belgium Treaty and a new Sino-Luxembourg Treaty in Chungking.
1943: The United Nations War Crimes Commission is formed.
1944: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines with 250,000 troops to fulfill his promise of returning that he made at the time when his forces were forced to retreat in the face of advancing Japanese forces.
1949: Britain recognizes the People's Republic of China under Mao Tse-tung.
1950: The ruling Kuomintang sets up the Taiwan Province Reform Commission with Nieh Wen-ya serving as its chairman.
1951: Governor Wu Kuo-chen of Taiwan presides over a ceremony marking the completion of the Akungtien Reservoir in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.
1955: President Chiang Kai-shek permits self-renewal for General Sun Li-jen, former commander-in-chief of the ROC Army, without taking disciplinary action against him after an investigation commission submitted a report on a sedition case.
1957: President Chiang Kai-shek is reelected Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang.
1962 Some 20,000 Chinese troops launch an offensive on Indian military posts along the Himalayan border.
1964: Herbert C. Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, dies at the age of 90. After the stock market crash of 1929, he was unwilling to finance employment through federal intervention and lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.
1968: Jackie Kennedy, widow of late U.S. President John F. Kennedy, marries multi-millionaire Aristotle Onassis.
1971: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts at improving relations between communist and non-communist nations.
1973: Queen Elizabeth II officially opens the Sydney Opera House in Australia.
1973: Yang Liang-kung, new president of the Examination Yuan, assumes office, while Liu Chi-hung takes office as vice president.
1975: The Fourth Pan-Pacific Conference on Regional Science opens in Taipei with more than 100 experts from Japan, the United States, Singapore and the ROC attending.
1982: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a soccer match in Moscow. A total of 340 people are killed.
1999: The ROC government extends its congratulations to Indonesian President-elect Abdurrahman Wahid for his election victory.
2000: Tseng Chu-wei, a professor of finance at National Chengchi University, urges the Democratic Progressive Party government to stop presenting any new policy initiatives in order to revive public confidence and maintain domestic stability.
2000: The U.S. Senate passes by a unanimous vote a House concurrent resolution in support of Taiwan's participation in the United Nations.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) says that the "no haste, be patient" policy on investment in mainland China is outdated and vows to replace it with a more aggressive approach.
Confucius lesson of the day: "Among the means for the regeneration of mankind, those made with noise and show are of the least importance."

Supreme Court nominee Harriet E. Miers told a conservative group in 1989 that she opposed abortion and would "actively support" legislation to severely restrict the procedure should the Supreme Court overturn Roe vs. Wade, documents released Tuesday showed.
