Aomori gov. Shingo Mimura announced Wedhesday his prefecture has decided to let two energy companies build a facility there to store spent nuclear fuel.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OPPOSED TO FORMER ROC PRESIDENT'S NAME CHANGE PROPOSAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin, S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: In response to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's proposal to drop the country's official title of "the ROC" in favor of "the Republic of Taiwan, " the U.S. State Department said Wednesday it is opposed to any moves that would seem to unilaterally change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.

Lee, who is currently visiting the U.S. capital, said in a Washington Post interview which was carried in the paper's Wednesday edition that "Taiwan is already an independent country" and that what is needed now is for the official name of the country to be dropped in favor of one that accurately reflects reality.

Commenting on Lee's proposal, the State Department said the United States does not support Taiwan independence. It added that Washington is against any moves that appear to unilaterally change the status quo, including changing Taiwan's official title.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Defiant Saddam pleads not guilty.
As Iraqis and much of the Arab world watched intently on TV screens, a defiant Saddam Hussein appeared in court here yesterday, challenged its legitimacy, and finally pleaded not guilty to crimes against humanity.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Saddam defies court in the century trial.
Saddam Hussein on Wednesday defied the authority of a US-sponsored Iraqi court set up to judge crimes during his regime, and he pleaded not guilty in this century trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPY AGENCIES DENY PROVIDING 'SOONG-CHEN MEETING' INFO TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Eight intelligence agencies denied Thursday that they had provided any information about the alleged secret meeting between People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong and Chinese official Chen Yunlin in the United States to President Chen Shui-bian.

Officials from the eight units, including the National Security Bureau (NSB) , the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice, and the Military Intelligence Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense, also denied that the Presidential Office or National Security Council (NSC) , which is headed by the president, had ordered them to check the allegation.
The officials were invited to a breakfast meeting by the PFP's legislative caucus, during which they all denied that they had given any such information to the president.

During two recent TV interviews, President Chen claimed that Soong met with the director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office in the United States in January. Soong has filed two libel suits against the president, demanding NT$50 million in compensation and an apology published in major newspapers for three days in a row.

NSB Chief Secretary Lin Cheng-tung said his bureau, which gathers all sorts of intelligence from other spy agencies, sends to the president only the information that it regards as valuable. And what his bureau has presented to the president does not include the so-called "Soong-Chen (Yunlin) meeting," he added.

NSB Director Hsueh Shih-min had earlier told the legislature that if the NSB had given any information about the alleged "Soong-Chen meeting" to the president, he would step down to take responsibility.

PFP Legislator Chang Hsien-yao asked Lin Cheng-tung and other spy agencies' representatives at the breakfast meeting if they had been asked by the Presidential Office or the NSC to double-check the validity of the president's allegation. The reply was a unanimous "no."
Lin said, besides the eight units being represented at the breakfast meeting, "there should be no other government units in Taiwan whose mandate is intelligence gathering and analysis."

Chang said that since the eight units claimed they had neither supplied to the president nor checked the alleged information, the president might have disclosed a piece of "false information" that had not been confirmed, indicating he had "poor judgment in trying to use false information as a political tool."
As to the president's claim that his allegation "was based on something, " Chang said that "something" could be "fabricated" in the event that the president were forced to show it.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Rove Told Jury Libby May Have Been His Source In Leak Case; Top Aides Talked Before Plame's Name Was Public.
White House adviser Karl Rove told the grand jury in the CIA leak case that I. Lewis "Scooter" Libby, Vice President Cheney's chief of staff, may have told him that CIA operative Valerie Plame worked for the intelligence agency before her identity was revealed, according to a source familiar with Rove's account, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO JOIN POST-PACIFIC ISLAND FORUM DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Taiwan will take part in the post-forum dialogue of the 36th Pacific Island Forum (PIF) set for Oct. 25-29 in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

The Taiwan delegation will be headed by MOFA Secretary-General Chen Yeong-cho and be comprised of six other ministry officials and six ROC ambassadors to the country's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, according to Lin Song-huann, director-general of the MOFA's Department of East Asia and Pacific Affairs.

The delegation will join representatives of various regional organizations under the PIF and of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific in reviewing existing cooperation programs and exploring future opportunities for bilateral or multilateral cooperation, Lin said.

Lin noted that the PIF is the highest governmental organization in the Pacific region, which provides member nations with the opportunity to express their joint political views and to cooperate in areas of political and economic concern.
Taiwan was invited to become a post-forum dialogue partner in 1992 and took part in the dialogue for the first time in 1993, Lin pointed out.
This will be the 13th consecutive year for Taiwan to participate in the event, he said.
Other post-forum dialogue partners include the United States, China, Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN HOPES KOREA WON'T CAVE IN TO CHINA'S PRESSURE ON APEC ENVOY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday urged South Korea, the host of this year's annual informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, not to cave in to Chinese pressure and to respect his decision to send Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to attend the meeting on his behalf.
President Chen made the remarks while receiving a parliamentary and academic delegation from South Korea at the Presidential Office.

His words came after China voiced vehement opposition to the idea of Wang serving as the president's envoy to the summit which is set to take place in the southern Korean port city of Busan Nov. 18-19.

Beijing argued that according to a memorandum of understanding signed in 1992 before Taiwan -- formally designated in APEC as Chinese Taipei -- joined the organization, Taiwan can only send its "minister in charge of APEC-related economic affairs" to attend the meeting, adding that APEC "has operated on this basis" since then.

President Chen noted that he had told South Korean APEC envoy Yun Hai-Jung, who was sent by South Korean President Roh Moo-hyun to Taipei last week to deliver an invitation from APEC, that he was keen on attending the Busan summit meeting.
As the serving president of the Republic of China, he has the same rights and obligations to attend the meeting as any of the other heads of state of member countries, the president told Yun.

He claimed that Beijing's rhetoric that there was a tacit agreement or understanding when Taiwan was admitted into the regional organization that Taiwan's head of state would not attend the summit meetings "is completely wrong."

In 1991, South Korea used its political acumen and diplomatic tact to help Taiwan, China and Hong Kong enter APEC simultaneously the following year, Chen noted, adding that the understanding involved only whether foreign affairs ministers from Taiwan should attend the summit meetings.

At the initiative of former U.S. President Bill Clinton in 1993, an APEC informal leadership meeting was inaugurated, Chen noted, adding that the issue of whether Taiwan's head of state could attend such meetings had not been discussed when the island entered the organization.

Chen stressed that Taiwan does not want to see South Korea cave in to Chinese pressure, adding that China's obstruction has prevented him from attending. He pointed out that he decided not to push to attend the summit because he didn't want to put Seoul in a difficult position and that he therefore appointed Wang as his envoy.

Chen said that Wang, a heavyweight of the main Kuomintang (KMT), has gladly accepted and that the KMT is happy to see him go. Wang's attendance at the summit "is an aspiration shared across the party spectrum," the president claimed.

He further said that he regrets that Beijing openly expressed its opposition to Wang's attending the meeting, saying that the APEC forum belongs to all members, including Taiwan, and that Taiwan's head of state, and not Beijing authorities, should decide who his envoy to the summit will be.

APEC, which is dedicated to promoting free flow of information, trade and investment, groups 21 economies, including Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 53.84 points to close at 5,748.
The bourse opened at 5,719.03 and fluctuated between 5,763.72 and 5,647.92 during trading. A total of 3.73 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$86.13 billion (US$2.56 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.8 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent.

Five other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues and cement stocks both moving down at 1.5 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.4 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 512 to 454, with 161 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LACK OF IDENTITY BIGGEST THREAT FACING TAIWAN: FORMER PRESIDENT LEE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D.C., Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Winnie Chi and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's own lack of identity, rather than Beijing's united front tactics, is the biggest threat facing the country, former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said Wednesday in Washington, D.C.

Speaking to hundreds of Taiwan expatriates during a dinner banquet, Lee said that China has been using every means at its disposal to try to "lure" Taiwan into unification, adding that the people of Taiwan must not give up the battle despite mounting difficulties and must continue "sticking to the right path to make Taiwan a normal and happy country."

The greatest challenge facing Taiwan is not China's military intimidation, rather it is the country's own lack of identity, Lee said, adding that the major purpose of his current visit to the United States is to help Washington better understand the prime threat facing Taiwan. He stressed that "Taiwan is Taiwan, and it is by no means a part of China."
Lee urged the banquet attendees to be "new era Taiwanese" and encouraged them to wholeheartedly support Taiwan's "native regime" to counter China's ambition to "swallow Taiwan up."
The former president also received a copy of the U.S. Declaration of Independence as a gift from the attendees in recognition of his contribution to Taiwan's cause.
Lee is slated to give a speech Thursday at the U.S. National Press Club.
Washington, D.C. is the third leg of Lee's two-week U.S. visit, which has already taken him to Alaska and New York. The final leg of the former Taiwan head of state's trip will be Los Angeles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL NOT BE DISCRIMINATED AGAINST IN TAMIFLU TALKS: ROCHE

TEXT.P: The Swiss pharmaceutical firm Roche will not discriminate against Taiwan in considering its request for licensing to mass-produce Tamiflu, an anti-viral drug for the treatment of influenza, a company official said Thursday.

According to Tsai Chao-cheng, spokesman for Roche's Taiwan branch, when considering similar requests put forth by various countries, the size of these countries and whether they are a member of the World Health Organization are not Roche's concern.
The company will negotiate details related to royalties with these countries individually based on their conditions and the situation of avian influenza outbreaks in their countries, Tsai said.

The Department of Health (DOH) has asked to negotiate with Roche for licensing to mass-produce Tamiflu in Taiwan to increase the country's stockpiles of the drug, as a precautionary measure against a possible bird flu pandemic.

A spokesman with Roche's headquarters in Switzerland told CNA earlier this week that any country cooperating with Roche in producing Tamiflu must follow proper quality standards and safety guidelines.
The DOH has coordinated with the Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs to prepare for matters involving the negotiations.
Also, the DOH has authorized ScinoPharm Taiwan and Yung Zip Chemical Co. to start trial production runs.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF WOMEN DRUNK DRIVERS UP IN TAIPEI OVER THE PAST THREE YEARS

TEXT.P: Taipei police statistics have shown that the number of women caught drunk driving in the last three years has increased significantly in spite of the fact that harsher penalties for the offense have been imposed.

Statistics compiled by the Taipei Municipal Police Department show that the number of drunken drivers on roads around Taipei over the last three years still centers on the age group between 31 and 50.

Taipei police officers noted that since stiffer penalties were imposed in 2002 for drunk drivers in Taipei, the number of young drunk drivers is still increasing, with 18- to 20-year-olds accounting for the bulk. Those between 21 and 30 also increased slightly by 2 percent over the last three years.
Meanwhile, the ratio of women drunk drivers rose significantly from 5.9 percent in 2002 to 7.4 percent this year, the police officers added.

The statistics also showed that the number of drunk drivers caught in Taipei in the first nine months of this year totalled 14,000, a growth of 12 percent over the same period of last year, or an increase of 1,500 cases.

Police officers expressed concern that the number of drunk driver will rise further over the next few months as that is the peak season for drunk driving due to several Chinese traditional festivals, including Chinese Lunar New Year.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has instructed traffic policemen to strengthen anti-drunk driving campaigns and to catch those violating regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FORGING CONSENSUS ON EX-PRESIDENTS' BENEFITS LAW

TEXT.P: Reviewing the law governing benefits for former presidents and vice presidents is consistent with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) image as a party of integrity and reform, so the DPP legislative caucus will try to forge a consensus on amending the law Friday, said caucus secretary-general William C.T. Lai Thursday.

The law became an issue after DPP Legislator Lin Chuo-shui proposed looking into the appropriateness of using taxpayers' money to pay for life-time preferential treatment of former presidents and vice presidents of the nation.

Under the current law, a former president and vice president together get an annual pension of NT$52 million (US$1.54 million) ; with an annual 3 percent growth adjusted for inflation, it will cost the government NT$8.5 billion (US$252.33 million) for five pairs of them in 30 year, Lin said.

He cited 2001 U.S. figures as saying that five former U.S. presidents were paid altogether only US$2.5 million (NT$82.25 million) a year, while Taiwan' s ex-president and ex-vice president are together getting NT$52 million a year. U.S. vice presidents do not get more than a seven-month relocation allowance.

If five pairs of former presidents and vice presidents were to be paid in a similar manner, it would cost Taiwan NT$260 million (US$7.72 million) a year. However, the per capita GDP in the U.S. is three times that of Taiwan, meaning Taiwan's ex-presidents and vice presidents would be paid nine times their U.S. counterparts, Lin said.

Lin accused the KMT, which was the ruling party until 2000, of "tailor-making" the law to include former vice president Lien Chan in the beneficiaries, so that Lien, now honorary chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , has been receiving NT$470,000 (US$13,952) a month in retirement benefits, including NT$220,000 (US$6,531) generated under a special "18 percent annual interest program."
DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Lien's 18 percent benefit is larger than that for the incumbent and retired presidents, an obviously unreasonable situation that calls for a change.

The KMT legislative caucus said Lien had been in government service for several decades, and what he is getting is entirely legal. "If the law or the system has any problem, that can be discussed, " said Pan Wei-kang, deputy secretary-general of the caucus.

In order not to increase the country's financial burden, she said the law should indeed be amended. The KMT Central Policy Committee is studying the issue and is expected to come up with a proposal to amend the law, she added.

As the amendment will also affect former President Lee Teng-hui, the spiritual leader of the minor opposition party Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , people are watching how it will respond to the DPP initiative.
Ho Min-hao, convener of the TSU legislative caucus, agreed with DPP's Lin that the law must be changed to meet people's expectations for the sake of social justice.
"We will make a proposal at the legislature for changing the law, if no other caucuses do it, " Ho said, acknowledging that this would shrink Lee's benefits.
"We are aiming to build a long-lasting system, not aiming at any particular person," he added.

Lai agreed with Ho, saying if the amendment passes the legislature, as it now looks likely, the retirement benefits for Lee, Lien and former vice president Lee Yuan-zu, as well as DPP's Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu will all be reduced.
"So it will be a change of the system that is issue-oriented rather than individual-oriented," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CANNOT ACCEPT 'DOMESTIC ROUTE' FOR 2008 OLYMPIC TORCH

TEXT.P: The Olympic torch will not pass through Taiwan in 2008 if Beijing insists on designating Taiwan as part of China's "domestic route, " officials from the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports said Thursday.

Taiwan will not accept a "domestic route" invitation, said Chang Fen-fen, director of the council's International Affairs Department, adding that so far, Taiwan has not received any information about arrangements for the 2008 Olympics torch relay.

Reports from Hong Kong said that Hong Kong's Secretary for Home Affairs Patrick Ho told members of the Legislative Council Wednesday that Hong Kong will be one of the stops that Beijing has committed to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) for the 2008 Olympics torch relay, which will also include stops in Tibet, the Yangzi River, the Yellow River, the Great Wall, Macau and Taiwan.

Commenting on the latest reports, Chang said that according to Olympic protocol, the Olympic torch relay is divided into a "domestic route" and "international route." While the host country can choose freely the cities where the torch relay will pass, the "international route" must be decided upon by the separate national Olympic committees of the various countries.

The host country should notify the separate national Olympic committees about where the "international route" will pass one year or one-and-a-half years ahead of time according to Olympic protocol, Chang said.

Chang added that her council contacted the IOC headquarters Thursday and was told that the IOC has yet to hear anything from the Chinese Olympic Committee about details of the "international route" of the 2008 Olympic torch relay.

Meanwhile, Chu Shou-chien, vice chairman of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, said that the Chinese Olympic Committee has continuously released news since March this year that the 2008 Olympic torch will be relayed to Taiwan from Hong Kong or Macau, apparently including Taiwan into the "domestic route" arrangement, which is absolutely unacceptable to Taiwan.

Chu said that both Taiwan and China are separately registered members of the IOC and Taiwan enjoys equal status to China on the IOC, stressing that Taiwan will not accept Beijing's "domestic route" plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DEVELOPS EMERGENCY BIRD FLU VACCINE

TEXT.P: The National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) has developed an avian influenza vaccine that is intended for emergency use in the case of a bird flu outbreak in Taiwan, an NHRI official said Thursday.

The achievement was made in cooperation with Chang Gung University, using the H5N1 strain of the virus from Vietnamese patients, which was obtained by the Department of Health (DOH) through the help of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, according to Su Ih-jen, director of the NHRI's Division of Clinical Research.
Su said the vaccine is only good for emergency use and may not be effective in preventing the disease because the H5N1 virus strain is still mutating.
Only vaccines produced one year after an epidemic will have preventive effects, Su noted.
Meanwhile, the NHRI is constructing a pilot vaccine plant, which will serve as a bridge between experimental vaccines and commercial vaccines. The plant is expected to be completed in 2007.
The DOH is also considering cooperating with international pharmaceutical companies in establishing a vaccine plant in Taiwan, with potential partners including sanofi-aventis and GlaxoSmithKline.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN URGES EARLY REVIEW OF ARMS PROCUREMENT FOR SAKE OF THE NATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday urged the Legislative Yuan to review the arms procurement package as soon as possible, saying that continued boycotting of the package by the opposition will put the future of Taiwan in jeopardy.

President Chen reaffirmed the importance of the arms procurement package from the United States when he received representatives of overseas Chinese associations from the United States. The package has been stalled in the legislature for more than a year due to the opposition of "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party.
The package includes eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries.

The president said lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait will rely on the democratization of China, the goodwill of China toward Taiwan and the strengthening of Taiwan's self-defense capabilities, although the first two things are not within Taiwan's control.

He criticized the opposition parties for basing national security on the goodwill of the nation's enemies, saying that individuals' political gambling on public security will put the future of the nation in jeopardy.

The president said the most likely flashpoints in the Asia-Pacific region are the Korean Peninsula and the Taiwan Strait, adding that the dispute across the Taiwan Strait is not an internal affair as claimed by China, but will directly impact peace, stability and safety of the whole region.

The president stressed that the international community is in lock-step that the status quo of the Taiwan Strait should not be unilaterally changed and that cross-strait disputes should be solved by peaceful means.

He said that the arms procurement project, which is crucial to upgrading military equipment and combat readiness, has been stonewalled for 33 times in a row in the legislature because of the boycott of the "pan-blue alliance" on various grounds, such as the price is too high, the items do not meet needs of the nation's defense, and that the money should not be listed in a special budget, but in the regular one.

However, he called these reasons "far-fetched, " adding that if there are differences on these issues, they should be put to the legislative defense committee for substantial review, instead of excluding them from the working agenda over and over.
This has highlighted the nature of "opposing for opposition's sake" of the "pan-blue alliance," he said.

The president said that another reason given by the "pan-blue alliance" comes from KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who has said that the government should actively pursue cross-strait peace, and not to engage in an arms race with the other side of the Taiwan Strait. This, however, is a "deliberate attempt to pit Taiwan Strait peace against the strengthening of national defense, and to deny the needs of Taiwan to upgrade combat readiness," Chen said.
The president stressed that national security should be the "common language" across the party spectrum, and that the public "should not take chances" on this issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT LEE WARNS OF DANGERS OF AN UNDEMOCRATIC CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Chen Yung-chan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui gave a speech Wednesday at the U.S. Capitol, warning that an undemocratic China threats world peace and is the prime factor for conflict in Asia.

Taiwan and the United States have long shared the same aspirations for democracy and freedom and for peace and security in the Asia-Pacific region, Lee said, adding that as a thick-and-thin partner of the United States, Taiwan treasures very much bilateral relations and has been committed to forging mutual benefits.
Out of a common concern over the situation in the region, Taiwan will do its best to stabilize cross-Taiwan Strait relations to protect the interests of both Taiwan and the U.S., Lee said.

However, he called attention to the rise of an authoritarian China, which has been expanding rapidly on both the economic and military fronts in recent years and fanning fresh uncertainties in cross-strait ties.

Stressing that he personally went through the pain of World War II and the ups-and-downs of Japan's militarism, he said he strongly believes that democratization is the answer to a country's progress and Asia's development as a whole. Therefore, China's democratization will be the key to avoiding conflict in Asia, he said.

The U.S. leadership role is indispensable in maintaining peace in Asia and Taiwan fully supports a continued U.S. presence as a peacemaker in the international community, he said, appealing for strong U.S. backing for Taiwan people's desire for peace and to maintain their own lifestyles.

Scores of U.S. Congressmen, including two Senators, George Allen (R-VA) and Tim Johnson (D-SD) -- co-chairmen of the Taiwan Caucus at the Senate, and four representatives, Steve Chabot (R-OH), Sherrod Brown (D-OH) , Robert Wexler (D-FL) and Dana Rohrabacher (R-CA) -- co-chairmen of the Taiwan Caucus at the House, were present on the occasion.
In a party they hosted in honor of Lee at the Capitol, the Congressmen praised Lee as a hero for Taiwan's democratization and presented a U. S. flag that had flown over the Capitol to Lee as a gift.
Lee is the first former president from Taiwan to address the U.S. Congress. He visited Anchorage, Alaska and New York before coming to Washington, D. C. on his current two-week U.S. swing.
Accompanied by David Lee, Republic of China Representative to the U. S., Lee also took part in a dinner banquet with more than 500 Taiwan expatriates later the same day at the Hilton Hotel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIRDWATCHERS TO GATHER DROPPINGS IN FIGHT AGAINST BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: Taiwan is enlisting birdwatchers in the fight against avian influenza by asking them to collect droppings from migratory birds in 10 cities and counties for testing, the Council of Agriculture announced Thursday.

The council's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine said Thursday that it has asked members of the Wild Bird Society of Taipei to collect bird droppings in the wetlands of the 10 cities and counties to be tested for the avian flu virus, H5N1.
These wetlands are located in the cities of Taipei and Tainan, and in the counties of Ilan, Changhua, Chiayi, Taichung, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Penghu.
A spokesman for the bureau said the birdwatchers will collect 3,000 specimens of bird droppings this year, up from last year's 2,000.
He added that measures are being taken at the same time to tighten controls on stores that sell pet birds and prevent the smuggling of birds from other countries into Taiwan.

According to a wire report, the coast guard seized birds being smuggled from China into Taiwan on Oct. 14 and tests confirmed that about 1,000 of the birds were infected with the H5N1 virus, the first time the strain had been detected on the island since late 2003.
The animals were destroyed and posed no health threat, said a health department official.

Meanwhile, Taipei City Government authorities urged Taipei residents not to catch or sell wild birds, as they face a fine between NT$60,000 and NT$300,000 under the Wildlife Conservation Act for doing so.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT CALLS FOR PASSAGE OF ARMS PROCUREMENT BUDGET
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui urged the people of Taiwan Wednesday to support the government's arms procurement package from the United States to show their resolve to defend their country.

Addressing a welcoming reception hosted by the Taiwanese expatriate community in the U.S. capital, Lee said the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan's blocking of the procurement has resulted in the misunderstanding that Taiwan is expecting Americans to go to war for the island.

However, Lee affirmed that regardless of whether there is any security commitment from the United States or the international community, the people of Taiwan will stick to their pursuit for democracy and independence in the face of the threat posed by the Chinese Communist regime.
Lee said the Anti-Secession Law enacted by Beijing early this year is intended as an excuse to attack Taiwan.
According to Lee, the military capabilities of China will be the most powerful from the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing to the 2010 Shanghai World Expo, which will make attacking Taiwan very simple.

It will only take one day for China to annex Taiwan if a pro-China government is elected in 2008 in Taiwan, Lee predicted, calling on the people to monitor the government closely and to support the continuation of a democratic, pro-Taiwan government.

Meanwhile, he expressed his disapproval of the belief that China will start democratization when its economy develops to a certain extent, saying that the strong economic power of China will only pose a greater threat to the world.

Washington is the third leg of Lee's two-week U.S. visit, which has already taken him to Alaska and New York. Lee delivered a speech on Capitol Hill earlier Wednesday and is scheduled to give another speech at the National Press Club on Thursday before flying to Los Angeles.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.003 to close at NT$33.681.
A total of US$745 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.602 and fluctuated between NT$33.591 and NT$33.705.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved up 84 points to close at 5,772, with 51,040 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December moved up 76 points to end at 5,770, with 257 contracts traded, while March futures lost 33 points to finish at 5,652, with four contracts traded. June futures moved up 57 points to close at 5,760, with seven contracts traded, while September futures moved up 220 points to close at 5,740, with 10 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,688 for November, 5,694 for December, 5,685 for March, 5,703 for June and 5,520 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

November TE futures moved up 6.05 points to close at 240.5, with 7,357 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 5.7 points to finish at 241.3, with 45 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 5.75 points to end at 240.2, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

November TF futures gained six points to finish at 863, with 3,861 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved up two points to end at 859.2, with 40 contracts traded. March TF futures moved down 12.2 points to close at 848.2, with seven contract transactions, while June TF futures lost 3.4 points to finish at 856.8, with one contract traded. September TF futures gained five points to close at 852, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD HAVE EQUAL RIGHTS AT APEC SUMMIT: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen has sent a letter to his South Korean counterpart expressing Taiwan's stance that the country should be given the same rights as that of other member economies of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

According to Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu, South Korean Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade Ban Ki-moon said at a news conference in Seoul Thursday that it will be in conformity with APEC's spirit and previous practices if Taiwan can send an official responsible for economic affairs to attend the annual informal leadership summit to be held in the South Korean port city of Busan Nov. 18-19.

Ban made the remarks following Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's decision to designate Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to attend the leadership summit on his behalf several days ago, a decision that China strongly opposes.
ROC presidents have had to name his special envoys to attend the APEC summit since 1993 due to the objections of China to his participation in the meeting in person.

Lu revealed that the foreign minister has sent a letter to Ban reaffirming the country's position that Taiwan should enjoy the same rights as that of other APEC members to have its top leader attend the summit.

Lu noted that Taiwan has been fighting with other APEC members against this unusual situation for many years. However, the efforts have failed again and again because of strong opposition from Beijing, Lu added.

Although the host country of this year's APEC leadership summit has expressed its stance in this regard, Taiwan will continue soliciting support from other APEC members to gain a solution which is to the greatest benefit of Taiwan, Lu stressed.

Other APEC members include Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T CAN'T FORCE KMT TO RETURN IMPROPERLY OBTAINED ASSETS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Vice Finance Minister Lee Ruey-tsang said Thursday that barring the legislation of a party asset bill, the government can only try to persuade, instead of forcing, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to return their improperly obtained party assets.
Lee made the remarks when he was invited by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to report on the handling of KMT assets.

Lee said that the ministry can only check the real estate and not the liquidity of the KMT. The KMT has used illegal means during its five decades in power to obtain around 144 hectares of real estate, which is worth around NT$21.9 billion (US$653.73 million) in market value, Lee said.
So far, the KMT has returned 1.8 hectares, or around NT$1.2 billion in market value, accounting for 1.7 percent of the total amount of the total it should return.

As for the five theaters with a market value of between NT$1 billion and NT$1.2 billion, which the KMT had originally agreed to return, the government had hoped to see either the return of the property or the equivalent in cash, but the KMT is only willing to return NT$300 million in cash and has sold only one of the theaters, Lee said.

DPP Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung said that the KMT is sitting on a gold mine, but is only willing to return a fraction of its ill-gotten assets. He is asking the party to think about the feelings of the public, and that the Ministry of Finance should use all its resources to go after the KMT's assets.

William Lai, a DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has repeatedly said that it is continuously returning the assets to the nation, but in reality, the amount is less than 2 percent of the total.
In addition, Ma said that the KMT will return party assets but on the other hand he is obstructing the passage of a party asset bill, which clearly shows "he lacks sincerity," Lai claimed.
In response, Ma said that if the DPP has any allegations regarding the KMT's handling of its party assets, they should "produce evidence, " instead of "just shouting slogans."
Chang Tzer-cheng, the KMT's deputy secretary-general, said that all KMT assets were "legally obtained."
Chang noted that Lee has based his calculations on information since 1949 when the KMT administration retreated to Taiwan after losing the Chinese civil war, saying that this was a "purge."
He questioned Lee's wording of "illegal means," claiming that all assets under the name of the KMT are backed by lawful certificates to prove that they were obtained legally.
He also said that the KMT has so far returned over 100 pieces of land, and Lee's remarks that the KMT has only returned 1.8 hectares is "very unreasonable."

DOC.HEADLINE: H5N1-INFECTED BIRDS SEIZED, TAIWAN REMAINS BIRD FLU-FREE: COA

TEXT.P: Taiwan remains avian flu-free despite cages of birds smuggled from China that tested positive for H5N1 -- the avian flu strain that poses the greatest threat of mutating into a form that could ignite a human pandemic -- officials from the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.

COA experts confirmed Thursday that 270 out of some 1,000 smuggled birds discovered in a Panama-registered freighter anchored in Taichung Harbor, central Taiwan Oct. 14 were believed to be infected with H5N1.

At a press conference held to address the crackdown on the largest-ever smuggling of birds to Taiwan from China, officials from the COA Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine said that most of the 1,000 birds, of 19 species, were dead when they were discovered by Coast Guard officials in Taichung Harbor.

Of the 19 species, three kinds -- Gracula religiosa, Oriolus chinensis and Leiothrix lutea -- were assumed to be H5N1 positive, as nine of the birds randomly selected from the three kinds, numbering about 270, tested H5N1 positive, the officials said.

All of the smuggled birds were destroyed by burning, the officials said, adding that another some 500 pet mice and tortoises also discovered in the same raid on the same freighter were also destroyed.

Meanwhile, according to the COA officials, the second mate of the freighter, a Chinese national, has been detained and kept under medical watch since he was the sole mastermind behind the smuggling and all of the smuggled animals were found in his cabin.

Health examination results showed that the second officer had not contracted bird flu. The officer, however, has been receiving doses of Tamiflu prescribed for him. He will be off the Tamiflu doses as of Oct. 25 if he shows no bird flu symptoms by then, the officials said.
The other 24 crew members were repatriated to Fuzhou in China, where the freighter departed for Taiwan via Ishigaki Island in Japan's Okinawa Prefecture around Oct. 12, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG CLAIMS HE HAS NO CHOICE BUT TO SUE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP), claimed Thursday that he has been left with no choice but to sue President Chen Shui-bian for alleging that he met with a ranking Chinese official in secret early this year in the United States.

Soong stressed that he did not meet with Chen Yun-lin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, during his visit to the United States, rebutting Chen's allegation made during a TV program May 8.
According to Soong, if he had not taken legal action, people would take it to mean a tacit acknowledgement from him that he did meet with the Chinese official.

The PFP chairman said he had offered the president a way out from the situation in a TV interview May 18, saying that he understood that the vast amount of information a national leader receives every day might not always be true and that he would not pursue the case if the president apologized after discovering that he had been wrongly informed.
He said he could not "let this thing pass, " although he claimed he did not like to be involved in a lawsuit with the president.
Soong filed a lawsuit June 3, seeking a symbolic NT$1 in compensation for defamation of his reputation, plus an apology in writing in the form of an advertisement in major newspapers in Taiwan.

However, after the president renewed the allegation in a TV talk show Oct. 18, Soong filed a second lawsuit, changing the charge to "aggravated defamation" and raising the damages he is seeking to NT$50 million.
The second lawsuit also demands that the president place apology advertisements in major Taiwan and foreign newspapers for three consecutive days.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTD-RENMINBI CURRENCY EXCHANGE SERVICES MULLED FOR TAIWAN PROPER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has promised to seriously consider allowing for new Taiwan dollar-renminbi currency exchange services to be implemented on Taiwan proper as soon as possible, a business leader said Thursday.

Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce Chairman Theodore M.H. Huang quoted Hsieh as saying that the government is mulling the possibility of introducing the service into Taiwan proper based on a trial that has been put in place on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu since early this month.
Huang made the remarks following a breakfast gathering attended by the premier and business community representatives.

Liao Yao-tsung, director of the Performance Evaluation and Overall Planning Department under the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said later the same day that no timetable has been set to that end and that amendments to the law will be needed to make the service possible in Taiwan due to the delicate relationship between Taiwan and China.
According to Liao, Taiwan and China must first work out and agree upon a set of currency settlement mechanisms to secure long-term and stable currency exchange services.

The NTD-renminbi currency exchange services that began on Oct. 4 on Kinmen and Matsu islands on a trial basis have gained warm public response, helping Taiwan people avoid having to convert the local currency to renminbi on the Chinese black market where fake notes are rampant.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT GROUP VISITS BEIJING TO DISCUSS TAIWAN-CHINA TOURISM EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By C.Y. Liao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: China has made necessary preparations for allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan and hopes to start bilateral talks on the issue as soon as possible, a Kuomintang (KMT) official said Thursday in Beijing.

Tseng Yung-chuan, head of the KMT's Policy Executive Committee and leader of a visiting KMT group that arrived in Beijing a day earlier to help push for tourism exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, made the remarks at a news conference following a meeting with Chinese officials on the issue.

According to Tseng, the Chinese tourism authorities have made full preparations for the opening and they hope that private-sector bodies from the two sides can launch negotiations as soon as possible.

KMT Legislator John Chiang said that China has come up with a detailed program and has urged the Taiwan authorities to quickly respond to the development by appointing a civic organization to hold talks with the Chinese side.

Shao Qiwei, director of the Chinese National Tourism Administration, is set to visit Taiwan next week at the head of a delegation comprising more than 60 provincial tourism officials, Chiang said, expressing his hope that they will be allowed to enter Taiwan without problems and have contacts with their Taiwan counterparts.
KMT Mainland Affairs Department Director Chang Jung-kung called for a swift opening by Taiwan to Chinese tourists, as part of the government's drive to double the number of tourist arrivals.
Shao's Taiwan visit should help boost mutual understanding and clear the way for follow-up talks, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRAISES CULTURE, ARTS AWARD WINNERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian praised the five winners of the 9th National Culture and Arts awards Thursday as "cultural heroes" who have enriched Taiwan's cultural environment.

Chen made the remarks while addressing the presentation ceremony of the awards in the southern city of Kaohsiung. Winners of the awards are theater arts professor Wang An-chi, choreographer Lin Li-chen, film director Hou Hsiao-hsien, novelist Chen Ching-wen and composer Chien Nan-chang.
According to Chen, the reputations enjoyed by these artists have helped make the arts achievements of Taiwan known overseas.
He said culture is the nutrient that strengthens the development of a country and that society needs arts and culture to shape people's taste and enhance its humanistic values.

He said cultural and artistic creations flesh out the living environment and allow the people to appreciate the beauty of culture, which he said is the most important implication of the idea of "building the country on culture" promoted by the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REMAINS AVIAN FLU-FREE: EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan remained avian flu-free as of Thursday, six days after cages of birds smuggled from China tested positive for H5N1 -- the avian flu strain that poses the greatest threat of mutating into a form that could ignite a human pandemic -- an Executive Yuan spokesman said Thursday.

None of the H5N1-infected birds made it onto Taiwan soil and none of the 40 Taiwan personnel who took part in a crackdown on bird smuggling Oct. 14 had shown any bird flu symptoms as of Thursday, said Executive Yuan Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai.

The personnel included 31 coast guard officers, six from the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture (COA) , and three from the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health.
All of them, however, have been asked to begin a 10-day self-health monitoring program just in case.

Meanwhile, Cho said, the administration has raised the cash reward for tipoffs on animal or meat smuggling to NT$20 million (US$595,238) to encourage more people from all walks of life to join the nationwide pandemic-prevention drive.
Smugglers or related violators, if nabbed, will face three-year prison terms, Cho added.

COA experts confirmed Thursday that 270 out of some 1,000 smuggled birds discovered hidden aboard a Panama-registered freighter anchored in Taichung Harbor, central Taiwan Oct. 14 were believed to be infected with H5N1.

At a press conference held to address the crackdown on the largest-ever smuggling of birds to Taiwan from China, COA officials said that most of the 1,000 birds, of 19 species, were dead when they were discovered by coast guard officials.

Of the 19 species, three kinds -- Gracula religiosa, Oriolus chinensis and Leiothrix lutea -- were assumed to be H5N1 positive, as nine of the birds randomly selected from the three kinds, numbering about 270, tested H5N1 positive, the officials said, adding that all of the smuggled birds were destroyed by burning.

Commenting on the confirmation of H5N1 infection among smuggled birds that would otherwise have entered in Taiwan if they had not been seized, Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, said that judging from the high percentage of H5N1-infection among the destroyed birds smuggled from Fuzhou, southern China, it is safe to predict that the avian flu epidemic is more serious around China than the Chinese authorities have reported and that the epidemic is not confined to Inner Mongolia and the northwestern province of Qinghai, as the Chinese authorities have claimed.
Shih called for all Taiwan citizens who travel frequently across the Taiwan Strait to heighten their vigilance against flu.

According to Shih, the second mate of the freighter, a Chinese national, has been detained in a Taichung jail and kept under medical watch, since he was the sole mastermind behind the smuggling and all of the smuggled animals were found in his cabin.

Health examination results show that the second officer has not contracted bird flu. However, he has been receiving doses of Tamiflu. He will be taken off the Tamiflu doses as of Oct. 25 if he shows no bird flu symptoms by then, Shih said.
The other 24 crew members were repatriated to Fuzhou, where the freighter departed for Taiwan via Ishigaki Island in Japan's Okinawa Prefecture around Oct. 12, Shih said.

He added that currently, passengers from Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia are asked upon arrival to conduct a 10-day self-health monitoring program after entering Taiwan, while passengers from China are asked to be mindful of their health condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH KOREA URGED NOT TO SUCCUMB TO CHINA'S PRESSURE

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) officials urged South Korea Thursday not to succumb to China's pressure on opposing Taiwan's designated envoy to this year's leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in the South Korean port city of Busan in November.

DPP Secretary-General Li Yi-yang said that Taiwan, a formal member of APEC, has the right to participate in APEC-related activities and the right to name an envoy to attend the leadership summit on behalf of the country's head of state.

Li's remarks came after South Korean Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade Ban Ki-moon said at a news conference in Seoul earlier that day that it will conform with APEC's previous practices if Taiwan can send an official responsible for economic affairs to attend the APEC annual informal leadership summit.
President Chen Shui-bian has named Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to attend this year's APEC leadership summit on his behalf, a decision China strongly opposes.
Li stressed that as the organizer of this year's leadership summit, South Korea should treat all the member economies equally and should not impose different criteria on different members.
"The DPP expresses regret that South Korea has not demonstrated courage by resisting the pressure from China," Li said.

Li noted that China's repression of Taiwan in APEC proves that its promise to help Taiwan participate in international organizations following visits to China by Taiwan opposition leaders earlier this year was a lie.

"China is using a carrot-and-stick strategy against Taiwan by promising a gift of pandas and allowing fruit imports from Taiwan while squeezing Taiwan's development in the international community, " Li said, adding that a proposed economic forum to be organized jointly by the opposition Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China is not expected to serve as a bridge in promoting cross-Taiwan Strait ties, but is just for show.

According to Li, Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Department, had said that Wang may attend the APEC summit as long as Chen steps down. Chen is considered by China as a separatist and a pro-independence advocate.
Li said that China is increasing its hegemonic behavior with the support of Taiwan's opposition parties.

Meanwhile, William C.T. Lai, the DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said Ban's remarks are the result of pressure from China and he urged the opposition parties not to dance to Beijing's tune but to try and help Wang attend the summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: FATHER COMMITS SUICIDE AFTER LOSING TWO DISABLED SONS

TEXT.P: A father who for 16 years had taken loving care of his two disabled son and encouraged them to live normal lives, took his own life Thursday after losing both sons in less than two years to a rare inherited disease -- Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

Li Tien-yu, a professor at the Department of Information and Computer Education of National Taiwan Normal University in Taipei, jumped to his death from his 11th-floor apartment in Panchiao, Taipei County, shortly after the death of his 20-year-old younger son Chih-wei earlier that day.

Barely two years ago in December 2003, his first son, 22-year-old Chih-jen, died of the same disease. Both sons suffered from the inherited disorder, which began to affect them from age of five or six with progressive muscle weakness.
Li and his wife Wang Mei-ying did everything possible to give their two sons a normal life, taking them to school every day and encouraging them to live life to the full.

They attended to every detail in the lives of their sons, and the family's love for life and strong will to fight the rare disease won a number of awards from both the government and the private sector, including the 2003 Presidential Education Award for Chih-jen upon his death.

Armed with their experience in taking care of their own sons, the couple even found time to join charity organizations to fight for the rights of other disabled children. Their unselfish love earned them the "Great Love Award" for parents of physically and mentally challenged children.
Li's wife also tried to kill herself but was prevented from doing so by firefighters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CONTINUE NEGOTIATING WITH SOUTH KOREA ON APEC ENVOY

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue negotiating with South Korea, organizer of this year's informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, on who will represent Taiwan at the meeting, the Presidential Office said Thursday.

Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang made the remarks after South Korean Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade Ban Ki-moon said at a news conference in Seoul earlier that day that it will conform with APEC practice if Taiwan sends an official responsible for economic affairs to attend the summit to be held in the South Korean port city of Busan Nov. 18-19.

Huang said that although President Chen Shui-bian had expressed his strong wish to attend the summit in person, he named Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to attend on his behalf as "a gesture of goodwill" toward China.
Republic of China presidents have had to name special envoys to attend APEC summits since 1993 due to the objections of China to the participation of the country's head of state.
According to Huang, Lee Yuan-tseh, a Nobel laureate in chemistry and president of Academic Sinica, has represented Chen at APEC summits for three years, and like Wang, has no background in economics.
Huang said the government had informed South Korea and the United States on the representative of Taiwan at the summit in advance, and did not receive a negative response from either country.
The change of South Korea's attitude was unveiled after China expressed its strong opposition to Wang's participation, Huang said.
As to whether there are any other candidates who could attend the summit instead of Wang, Huang declined to answer.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE JOURNALIST TRYING TO BLOCK SFCC-ROC PRESIDENT TELECONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The correspondent of the Beijing-based People's Daily in Seoul is striving to prevent the Seoul Foreign Correspondents' Club (SFCC) from holding a videoconference with Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, the head of the association said Thursday.

SFCC President Lee Su-wan told CNA that the club's managing director, Lee Byung-jong, who is also Newsweek's correspondent in Seoul, came up with the proposal in late September that the club hold a videoconference with Chen.
However, Lee Su-wan said the proposal met strong opposition from People's Daily correspondent Xu Baokong when it was discussed at a SFCC board meeting.
Lee Su-wan said he fully supports the holding of a SFCC-Chen videoconference and that if the event cannot be held inside the SFCC headquarters, he would be willing to hold the event at another venue.

He said behind-the-scenes discussion on the proposal is still ongoing and added that he and several other board members are considering revising SFCC regulations to allow for the smooth holding of the proposed videoconference.

In his view, Lee Su-wan said the SFCC should be an open forum and that journalists should be free from political restrictions and should be free to meet with any news source. He said he will do his utmost to implement the videoconference plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR RENEWS CALLS FOR OPENING OF DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou renewed calls Thursday for the opening of direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait to help accelerate Taiwan's economic and trade development.

Speaking about the development of the Taipei Sci-tech Corridor and the future of Taiwan's industrial development in a lecture chair program sponsored by the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, Ma said he has believed for years that Taiwan can turn itself into a global operations center for Taiwanese businessmen operating in China and an Asian operations hub for foreign corporations.

Ma said that although Taiwan still has many advantages over other countries, the country needs to catch up, particularly in developing a skilled and knowledge-based workforce, if it intends to become a world IT design and research hub.
To reach that goal, Ma said, Taiwan must maintain fast-track connections with the world, including China. Only by maintaining such links can Taiwan compete with other countries, he said.

He lamented that membership of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taiwan and the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei has continued to slide. These members have pointed out that if direct cross-strait transportation links remained blocked, Taiwan will lose its international competitiveness, Ma said, adding that under those circumstances, American and European businessmen see Taiwan as at best a "local market" rather than a "regional operations center."
Ma said he made the call for opening cross-strait direct air and shipping links purely for the benefit of Taiwan, without any political consideration.
Strengthening Taiwan's international competitiveness is the responsibility of all government officials, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA URGES CHINA TO ENHANCE TRANSPARENCY IN AVIAN FLU PREVENTION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) urged China Thursday to maintain transparency about its avian flu situation and avoid a repeat of its initial coverup of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak in 2003.

The ministry made the appeal after Council of Agriculture officials said that 270 out of some 1,000 birds smuggled from China and discovered aboard a Panama-registered freighter anchored at Taichung Harbor, central Taiwan Oct. 14 were believed to be infected with H5N1.
It was the second time in a year that smuggled birds from China had tested H5N1-positive.
H5N1 is the flu strain in birds that is most likely to mutate into a form that may easily spread from person to person, causing a pandemic.
MOFA officials said the seizure of the infected birds indicates that there may be an avian flu outbreak in China.

"It is hoped that China can honestly publish comprehensive information about its avian flu situation to facilitate global cooperation in averting any possible outbreak of the disease," a MOFA official said, adding that the World Health Organization should initiate a field survey in China.

In 2003, China initially tried to cover up a SARS outbreak in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong, which later led to outbreaks in several neighboring countries, including Taiwan, and claimed hundreds of lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF FOREIGN CAREGIVERS EXCEEDS 120,000: DGBAS

TEXT.P: With aged population growing steadily, the number of foreign caregivers in Taiwan has exceeded 120,000, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Thursday.

The number of those aged 65 or older had reached 2.18 million as of the end of June this year, accounting for 9.6 percent of Taiwan's total population, DGBAS officials said, adding that the ratio marked a 0.3 percent growth year-on-year.

The continued growth in aged population has given rise to the demand for foreign caregivers. According to DGBAS tallies, the number of foreign caregivers had risen to 124,000 as of the end of June, up 5 percent from the year-earlier level.

The ruling coalition is in favor of the bill, while the opposition union is mulling to initiate a referendum to stop it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 21, or the 19th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Ferdinand Magellan, Portuguese navigator, and his expedition team are blown by storms into a strait that separates South America from Tierra del Fuego and other islands south of the continent and that also connects the southern Atlantic and Pacific oceans. The strait now bears his name.
1727: The Ching court and Russia sign a new border treaty at the trading town of Kiakhta in Outer Mongolia.
1833: Alfred Nobel, Swedish industrialist and chemist who invented dynamite, is born. He founded the Nobel Prize to award to the world's leading scientists, artists and peacemakers.
1879: Thomas Alva Edison, U.S. inventor, successfully tests an electric incandescent lamp with a carbonized filament at his New Jersey laboratory.
1934: Government troops capture Juichin, the Chinese communist's capital in Kiangsi. The main force of rebels is wiped out and the remaining ones flee to the northwest.
1938: Japanese troops finally capture the Chinese city of Canton after months of bombing.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, and Madame Chiang arrive in Taiwan for the first time for an inspection tour.
1950: Communist Chinese forces begin their occupation of Tibet.
1952: The first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference opens in Taipei.
1953: The first Overseas Chinese Day is celebrated in Taipei.
1954: The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France agree to end the Allied occupation of Germany.
1958: John Foster Dulles, U.S. secretary of state, arrives in Taipei for a visit. He pursued a policy of opposing the USSR largely through economic and military aid to U.S. allies.
1960: Queen Elizabeth II launches the HMS Dreadnought, Britain's first nuclear submarine.
1960: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Mali.
1964: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC decathlon champion who won the ROC's first Olympic silver medal in 1960, announces his retirement after winning fifth place at the Tokyo Olympics.
1973: The fifth general meeting of the Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations opens in Taipei with more than 400 delegates from 50 countries and areas participating.
1975: The second naphtha cracking plant of the Chinese Petroleum Corporation begins production.
1976: Ding Mou-shih, director general of the Government Information Office, returns from a week's visit to the Republic of Korea.
1979: Israeli Prime Minister Moshe Dayan resigns over the government's refusal to negotiate with Palestinians.
1979: Willy Brandt is elected chancellor of West Germany.
1987: Ho Ying-chin, a Chinese general who received the formal surrender of Japanese forces in China from Gen. Okamura in Nanking on Sept. 9, 1945, dies at the age of 97.
1994: The United States and North Korea sign a landmark deal under which Pyongyang is to freeze and then dismantle its nuclear program.
1999: Far East Transport Corp. begins flight services between Taipei and Kota Kinabala in Malaysia.
2000: Chinese Taipei's Chiang Chih-chung breaks the world record in men's Class 12 javelin with a throw of 57.228 meters to capture Taiwan's first gold medal at the Sydney Paralympics.
2001: Asia-Pacific leaders pledge to prevent "all forms of terrorist acts" and to strengthen cooperation to catch those who carry out such crimes in a joint statement after ending a two-day informal leadership summit in Shanghai.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In another place in the Book of Song it is said, `His virtue is light as hair.' Still a hair is something material. `The workings of Almighty God have neither sound nor smell.' There is nothing higher than that."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STANCE OF OPPOSING TAIWAN NAME CHANGE REMAINS SAME: STATE DEP'T
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department on Thursday reiterated that its policy of opposing a change to Taiwan's official name remains unaltered.

In response to a question raised at a regular press briefing regarding remarks made earlier in the day by former ROC President Lee Teng-hui that Taiwan should change its official name from the "Republic of China" to the "Republic of Taiwan, " State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said that there's been "no change in our policy."

Lee said after addressing the National Press Club that as the international community has failed to recognize the ROC, the nation should change its official name in order to gain the acceptance of other countries.
According to Lee, he had done all he could during his time as president to gain international recognition for the country, but to no avail.

"The international community does not only refuse to recognize the ROC, it also confuses the name of the People's Republic of China with that of the Republic of China, or even considers that Taiwan is part of the PRC, " he added.

In an interview with the Washington Post which was carried by the newspaper Wednesday, Lee said that Taiwan is already an independent country and that all that is required now is for the country to change its official name to reflect reality.

The U.S. State Department also made it clear Thursday that it does not support Taiwan independence, nor any actions that might represent a unilateral change to the current status quo in the Taiwan Strait, including a change to Taiwan's official name.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK ADJUSTS DOWNWARD 2005 ECONOMIC GROWTH FORECAST TO 3.53%

TEXT.P: The Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER) on Friday adjusted downward its forecast for Taiwan's economic growth for this year to 3.53 percent from 3.8 percent.
CIER officials attributed the downward adjustment to lower than expected growth in the first two quarters of the year.
They forecast growth of 4.07 percent and 4.4 percent for the third and fourth quarters, respectively.
Taiwan is forecast to see a growth of 4.02 percent for 2006, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S TOP TOURISM OFFICIAL TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: China's National Tourism Administration (NTA) Director Shao Qiwei will travel to Taiwan for a 10-day visit later this month, Taiwan's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) confirmed Friday.

MAC officials said that Shao, at the invitation of Taiwan's Travel Agent Association, will lead a 66-member delegation, including NTA deputy directors, tourism officials from various provinces, and representatives of major travel agents in China, to visit Taiwan Oct. 28 to Nov. 6.
The purpose of the delegation's visit is mainly to inspect the scenic spots and related tourism facilities in Taiwan, and there are no other activities on the itinerary, the officials added.
Meanwhile, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun denied that the Chinese government has officially relaxed rules to allow its citizens to go to Taiwan for tourism.

Liu made the remarks during a public hearing on opening Taiwan up to mainland Chinese tourists to help boost Taiwan's economy. The public hearing was jointly held by Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the Kuomintang's (KMT's) Policy Committee, and KMT Legislator John Chiang.

Tseng said in the hearing that China's Taiwan Affairs Office under its State Council confirmed that China decided to allow citizens to take pleasure trips to Taiwan on May 3 when former KMT Chairman Lien Chan concluded his visit to China. Tseng urged the government to consult on this matter as soon as possible.

However, Liu said that he has checked the information on Chinese Web sites, and the latest updated information on Sept. 15 showed that Taiwan is not included in its tourism destinations, even if Taiwan is counted as a region of China as Hong Kong and Macau are.
China even notified its travel agents to ban Chinese citizens from traveling to Taiwan for tourism, Liu said.

Chiang, who together with Tseng called on Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council in Beijing Wednesday during their just concluded trip, said that there is a gap between China's views and the MAC's perceptions.

Chiang said that China does not view Taiwan as a nation, and this is why it is not listed in the tourism destinations, but Chen told them in person that he hopes Taiwan will commission a private party to engage in related consultations as soon as possible, adding that China has made all the preparations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE TO TEN DRUG COMPANIES IN TAIWAN CAPABLE OF PRODUCING TAMIFLU

TEXT.P: There are five to ten pharmaceutical companies in Taiwan that have the technical capability to produce Tamifu, according to pharmaceutical industry sources.

Tamiflu, which is used to treat influenza, has been in short supply as countries have raced to stock up on the medicine amid fears of a looming bird flu pandemic. Roche, the only producer of Tamiflu, has been unable to keep up with the global demand for the medicine.
Taiwan has been seeking authorization from Roche to produce the medicine on the island.

Sinphar Pharmaceutical Co., which is one of the local pharmaceutical companies listed by the sources as capable of producing Tamiflu, confirmed Friday that its subsidiary in China and its Taiwan factory are both capable of manufacturing the medicine.

China Chemical & Pharmaceutical Co., another of the pharmaceutical companies listed by the sources, said Friday that it will be able to roll out its first batch of Tamiflu four months after it receives licensing to produce the medicine.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. URGED TO PLAY MORE ACTIVE ROLE IN TAIWAN STRAIT MATTERS
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China scholar called for the European Union Thursday to play a more active role in maintaining security in the Taiwan Strait.

Tsai Ming-yeng, an assistant professor at National Chung Hsing University, made the appeal while attending a seminar on "Taiwan-China Relations: What Role Can the European Union Play? " which is currently being held by the European Institute for Asian Studies (EIAS) in Brussels with about 50 China and Taiwan-problem experts from various countries around the world, E.U. officials and media representatives taking part.
The scholar also urged the E.U. to maintain its arms exports ban on China and to establish a new framework for its relations with Taiwan.

Noting that the E.U. should be able to play a more active role in dealing with matters across the Taiwan Strait, Tsai said that by doing so, the union will not only help maintain security in East Asia but will also better safeguard its own interests in the region.

In response to the scholar's appeal, a European Commission official said that the E.U. has made two statements regarding the Taiwan Strait since the beginning of this year, with one being issued when Taiwan and China launched direct Lunar New Year charter flight services, and the other being issued when Beijing passed its "Anti-Secession Law" in March.

"The E.U.'s longstanding stance is to urge both sides (of the strait) to engage in a peaceful dialogue. The E.U. at least has expressed its stance on the cross-strait issue and will probably talk more about the issue in the future," the official said.

Nevertheless, Huang Wei-Feng, vice chairman of the ROC's Council of Mainland Affairs, who also attended the gathering, said that although Taiwan has always welcomed suggestions to engage in a dialogue with China, Beijing's refusal to give up the preconditions it has made for cross-strait talks has prevented Taiwan from taking further steps to hold negotiations with the mainland.

"Abandoning political preconditions will allow the two sides to negotiate and cooperate on a practical and functional basis, " he said, adding that the "launching of direct charter flight services has set a good precedent."

Echoing Hwang's remarks, Chang Wei-wei, a senior research fellow from the Research Center for Comtemporay Asian Studies in Geneva, said that China and Taiwan should jointly create economic and other interests for themselves by developing practical and functional cooperative relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERSONNEL IN POULTRY INDUSTRY URGED TO WEAR PROTECTIVE GEAR

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) on Friday urged laborers and other personnel in the poultry farming and marketing industry to wear protective gear during work and to more thoroughly wash after work to prevent the spread of avian flu.

Officials from the CLA Institute of Occupational Safety and Health urged workers and personnel on poultry farms and at slaughterhouses, as well as veterinarians and public health workers to step up measures to protect themselves against bird flu.

With fears growing around the world of a possible bird flu pandemic, CLA officials said that owners of poultry farms or slaughterhouses should provide protective gear and related cleaning equipment to workers so as to help prevent the workers from coming into direct contact with birds which might be carriers of the deadly H5N1 strain of the avian flu virus.
The officials said that members of the high-risk groups mentioned above should head to hospital immediately if they develop influenza symptoms, such as fever, respiratory problems or eye infection.
They should also avoid coming into direct contact with bird droppings and avoid uncooked meat and eggs, the officials added.

Meanwhile, officials from the CLA Employment and Vocational Training Administration said that bird flu prevention literature will be translated into several languages for distribution to foreign workers in Taiwan.
