DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FORGES BUSINESS COOPERATION PACT WITH BRAZILIAN STATE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) entered a cooperative agreement with the Industry Federation of Brazil's southern state of Santa Catarina Friday to help boost business and industrial exchanges.
The agreement was jointly endorsed by Donald Lu, acting executive president of TAITRA, and Alcantaro Correa, president of the Santa Catarina Industry Federation, TAITRA officials said.

TAITRA officials said that Santa Catarina State is the seventh-largest industrial center in Brazil and the Santa Catarina Industry Federation, established in 1950, has been instrumental in helping the Brazilian government in planning industrial development policies and carrying out them, contributing to boosting Brazil's export trade and business expansion.

Under the agreement, Taiwan and the Brazilian state of Santa Catarina are expected to further strengthen trade, industry and investment exchanges, including exchanges of information and visits, as well as sponsorship of seminars and workshops, TAITRA officials said.

Brazil is the largest country in South America with a population around 185 million, TAITRA officials said, adding that with rich deposits of natural resources, the country is known for its potentially large and lucrative markets.

Brazil is also Taiwan's largest trading partner in Latin America. Taiwan exports to Brazil amounted to US$1.33 billion last year, representing an increase of 45.57 percent over the year-earlier level, while its imports from Brazil totaled US$700 million, up a whopping 57.53 percent from that of 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 9.24 points to close at 5,738.76.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 5,678.62 and hit a high of 5,761.16 during trading. A total of 2.84 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$67.15 billion (US$1.99 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 0.7 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.4 percent, cement stocks and textile stocks, both at 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares, both at 0.1 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down at 0.6 percent and machinery and electronics shares dropping 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 478 to 468, with 188 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT SAYS HE HAS NEVER PROMOTED TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Thursday that he has never promoted independence for Taiwan because Taiwan is already an independent country.
Instead, what he has been promoting is to make Taiwan "a normal country," Lee said.
Lee was responding to a question on how he would promote Taiwan independence, after giving a speech on "The Path of Taiwan Democracy" at the National Press Club in the U.S. capital.
According to Lee, the campaign calling for changing Taiwan's official name and for enacting a new Constitution for the country is not aimed at declaring independence.

Lee said the government of Taiwan does not even have a "correct name, " pointing out that the name "Republic of China" is recognized by none, not even the United States, and that everyone calls Taiwan "Taiwan," and not "the Republic of China."
Also, a new Constitution is required because the ROC Constitution currently in use in Taiwan does not cover Taiwan and offers no protection for the people of the island, Lee continued.
The former president noted that he made every possible effort but failed to have the international community recognize the country during the 12 years of his presidency.

The international community always confuses the "Republic of China" with the "People's Republic of China" and even thinks the "Republic of China" is part of the "People's Republic of China, " he said.

In the face of this predicament, he suggested, there are two options for Taiwan: one is to continue to request that the world recognize the name "Republic of China" and the other is to change the name to make it acceptable to the international community.

However, he said, only the second option will work because the first is totally infeasible, pointing out that during his current visit in the United States, everyone has been calling him a former president from Taiwan, instead of the Republic of China.
Asked if he has met with any U.S. officials during the trip, Lee said that this is a private visit and that he has not met and has no plans to meet any U.S. officials.
Lee said the main purpose of the trip is to observe the operations of U.S. democracy.
In his speech, Lee mentioned that the ethnic confrontation that started in the 1940s in Taiwan began to be resolved in the process of democratic development.

However, such confrontation has been reignited and worsened to become a conflict of national identity as a result of vicious struggles between the ruling and opposition parties after the Democratic Progressive Party came to power in 2000, Lee said.

He said that in light of this problem, he has put forth the concept of "new era Taiwanese, " which he said means that all 23 million people now living in Taiwan are Taiwanese regardless of whether their ancestors came to Taiwan 400 years ago or just 50 years ago.
The differences in terms of national identity are the greatest problem that the country needs to resolve to protect its democracy, he said.

He alleged that some politicians who have been rejected by the voters are trying to divide Taiwan society and are allying with the communist Chinese regime against Taiwan, which he said has intensified the crisis facing the country.

Washington is the third leg of Lee's two-week U.S. visit, which has already taken him to Alaska and New York. Lee flew to Los Angeles Thursday for the final leg of his trip after wrapping up his visit to Washington, D.C. Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 43% SAY LEGISLATURE SHOULD SCREEN CONTROL YUAN NOMINEES SOON: POLL

TEXT.P: Forty-three percent of respondents to a poll commissioned by the Control Yuan said the Legislative Yuan should screen President Chen Shui-bian's nomination list for the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, as soon as possible.

The legislature has stalled the confirmation of the list mainly because opposition legislators are dissatisfied with the nominees, especially Clement C.P. Chang, who has been named as Control Yuan president. The opposition lawmakers demand that the president make a new list.
The positions of the Control Yuan have been left unfulfilled since the six-year term of the last Control Yuan expired at the end of January.

Tu Shan-liang, secretary-general of the Control Yuan, said that President Chen was anxious about the situation, and hopes that the Control Yuan members can be confirmed quickly so that they can start to look into the public's complaints and major derelictions by civil servants and give him an "objective report."
The Control Yuan-commissioned survey, released Friday, collected 1,069 effective samples and had a margin of error of 3.06 percent.

On the effects on the protection of human rights and monitoring the government, the survey showed that 52.8 percent of the people said it will have an effect, compared with 28.3 percent who said this would have no effect.

On who should bear the most responsibility for not being able to produce members for the Control Yuan, 35.8 percent of the public said the president should bear the greater responsibility, followed by the Legislative Yuan (22 percent), and the Executive Yuan (4.3 percent), the opposition parties (0.9 percent) , and the ruling party (0.7 percent) and the Control Yuan members (0.2 percent).

Around 43 percent said that the legislature should screen the nominations as soon as possible, but not to confirm those who are unqualified for the posts. Almost 29 percent said that the legislature should return the list to the Presidential Office for a new one.

Five precent of the polled also said that the legislature should review them as soon as possible and confirm them all, while 2.3 percent said the legislature should screen them as soon as possible, but reject them all.

But if the public discovers major problems with civil servants, 58.4 percent said they don't know where to report to. Around 9 percent said they would report to the Ministry of the Interior, 6.7 percent said they would report to the superiors of the related civil servants, next would be ethic departments of various levels (5.7 percent), and the Control Yuan (5.3 percent).

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGERS ARE FORBIDDEN TO CARRY BIRDS IN BUSES AND PLANES

TEXT.P: Due to avian flu concerns around the world, passengers are prohibited from carrying domestic and wild birds on mass transport systems in Taiwan, according to officials of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

MOTC officials sent notices to road, marine and air transport authorities Thursday, asking them to inform passengers not to carry birds, whether domestic or wild, on buses, ships or airplanes starting that day.

Regarding taxis, which are not included in the category of mass transport systems, MOTC officials said taxi drivers can refuse any passenger carrying birds. However, the MOTC has no regulations governing this.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO APPLY TO MAC FOR BEIJING OFFICIAL'S VISIT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Kuomintang (KMT) think-tank will submit an application with the administration shortly for permission for a high-ranking Beijing official to come to Taiwan to take part in a cross-strait economic forum scheduled to be held in December, a KMT official confirmed Friday.

The KMT-run National Policy Foundation is expected to submit the application with the Mainland Affairs Council to pave the way for Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, and some 50 others from China to take part in an economic cooperation forum slated to be held in Taipei in mid-December, said Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT Mainland Affairs Department.

Chang declined to speculate whether Lien Chan, the honorary chairman of the KMT, who is currently visiting in China, has extended an invitation to Jia Qinglin, chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, to come to Taiwan also for the forum -- the first of its kind co-sponsored by the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) since the KMT fled to Taiwan in 1949.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said the other day that the holding of the KMT-CPC economic cooperation forum is part of efforts to materialize the "five consensuses" that former KMT Chairman Lien Chan reached with CPC General-Secretary Hu Jintao in Beijing during Lien's historic "journey of peace" to China from late April to early May when he was still the KMT chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS URGE REVISION OF LAW TO SCRAP INHERITANCE TAX

TEXT.P: Several Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators said on Friday that they will propose a revision of the law to scrap inheritance taxes.
DPP Legislator Huang Chien-hui pointed out that between 2000 and 2004, the ratio of inheritance taxes to total tax revenues has been averaging less than 2 percent.
Moreover, rich conglomerates often do everything they can to evade tax payments, and the government has failed to collect inheritance taxes from their top executives, Huang said.

The government currently can only go after the inheritance taxes of the middle-class, which he termed as being unfair, adding that Hong Kong and Canada have stopped collecting inheritance tax, and the United States is going to scrap it in 2010. The inheritance tax in Singapore is only 5 precent, showing that the scrapping of inheritance tax is a world trend.

Huang stressed that after Singapore adjusted it inheritance tax downward, more money was available in the country as wealthy people did not have to "hide" their money overseas, which has reinvigorated its capital market and helped the development of various industries.

Two other DPP legislators, Hsueh Ling and Wu Fu-quei, also said that Taiwan could turn into a capital haven in Asia if the government does not tax money coming into the country as it would help investment and capital markets in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Senators Reject Miers' Replies to Questions. The Supreme Court nomination of Harriet E. Miers, already troubled by a lack of enthusiasm on Capital Hill, ran into more rough ground Wednesday when senators from both parties rejected her responses to a questionnaire as insufficient.

DOC.HEADLINE: 40 ANTI-AVIAN FLU WORKERS UNDER CLOSE WATCH FOR POSSIBLE INFECTION

TEXT.P: Forty people who dealt with birds smuggled into Taiwan recently -- eight of which were found to be carrying the avian influenza virus -- are being monitored, but none of them have shown any signs of flu, a government health official said Friday.

The official acknowledged that some of the men did not wear protective clothing during the mission to seize the birds smuggled in a Panama-registered cargo ship in Taichung Harbor a week ago. However, he added, they were not in direct contact with the 1,037 smuggled birds from China, which were destroyed after eight of the 276 dead birds were found to be infected with the H5N1 avian flu virus.
The spokesman said health authorities are watching the conditions of the workers closely and that so far none of them has developed any flu symptoms.

The 40 men are from the Coast Guard Administration, the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health, and the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture.

Taiwan has remained avian flu-free despite the seizure of smuggled birds that tested positive for H5N1. The 1,037 birds destroyed consisted of 19 species and were part of the smuggled shipment aboard the Panama-registered ship.

A Chinese second mate on the ship admitted that he had transported the birds and other animals from Fuzhou, Fujian in southeastern China. The Taichung Prosecutors' Office is charging him with smuggling and violating laws governing wildlife conservation and prevention of infectious disease from animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS MRT SUPERVISION MAY HAVE BEEN LAX, BUT NOT SCANDALOUS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh admitted Friday that it was possible that he might have been negligent in his supervision of some Kaohsiung City Government agencies regarding the construction of the mass rapid transit (MRT) project in Kaohsiung, but this would not constitute a "scandal."
Hsieh was Kaohsiung mayor until he assumed the premiership this February. He was referring to the Bureau of Labor Affairs and the Department of Rapid Transit System in the city government.

Hsieh made the remarks as acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan was about to unveil the investigation results of a five-member team on the administrative responsibility of the MRT project later in the day. The project has aroused serious concerns after a series of irregularities were revealed following a riot on Aug. 21 by Thai laborers working for the MRT system to protest unreasonable treatment and exploitation.

In a question-and-answer session in the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh said that documents containing the formulation process of the MRT project can be dated back six or seven years, and that he had no access to them now.
"It is good that Yeh's team can examine all related documents, " Hsieh said.

The premier stressed that at that time, the central as well as local governments were pushing for the BOT (build-operate-transfer) model, or the private sector building and operating a construction project before transferring it to the government after a certain period of time, and that the public should not see this in a negative light.

Media reports said Yeh's investigation will find former Kaohsiung mayors Wu Den-yih -- now a legislator of the opposition Kuomintang -- and Hsieh were guilty of "some flaws" in the formulation of the BOT model, but these are not to be construed as administrative negligence.

However, discipline might be dispensed to Chou Li-liang, former director of the Department of Rapid Transit System, and Fang Lai-chin, the former director of the Bureau of Labor Affairs of the Kaohsiung City Government.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR UNVEILS INVESTIGATION REPORT

TEXT.P: A five-member team headed by acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan unveiled its investigation report on the mass rapid transit (MRT) project in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan Friday.

At the instruction of President Chen Shui-bian, Yeh, who is also the convener of the team, two deputy mayors, Cheng Wen-lung and Tang Chin-chuan, secretary-general of the Kaohsiung City Government Hao Chien-sheng and Department of Civil Service Ethics Director Hwang Sheng-yih formed the team and gave the report after a two-week investigation.

Among the seven issues under investigation, three items will be turned over for further judicial investigation, including six public bids on the project as well as matters pertaining to train door specifications.

On the part of management flaws of the Thai laborers, whose riot on Aug. 21 to protest harsh treatment and exploitation revealed a series of irregularities in the project, reportedly involving Taiwan and Thai officials and labor brokerage firms, the team said that it will pursue the responsibility of those officials who were in charge.

As for the formulation of the BOT (build-operate-transfer) model to construct the system, the team said that it has found no kickbacks surrounding the project, and whether or not to use BOT should be part of the government's public policy.
Yeh stressed that for those agencies involved in administrative responsibility, there will be a personnel review meeting to dispense discipline.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.048 to close at NT$33.633.
A total of US$579 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.681 and fluctuated between NT$33.607 and NT$33.683.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved down 37 points to close at 5,735, with 30,574 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December moved down 34 points to end at 5,736, with 149 contracts traded, while March futures lost 12 points to finish at 5,740, with three contracts traded. September futures moved down 15 points to close at 5,725, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,772 for November, 5,770 for December, 5,752 for March, 5,760 for June and 5,740 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

November TE futures moved down 2.05 points to close at 238.45, with 4,739 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 3.05 points to finish at 238.25, with 18 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down 1.85 points to end at 237.45, with two contracts traded, while September TE futures moved up 2.55 points to close at 237.85, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

November TF futures lost 2.6 points to finish at 860.4, with 2,106 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved down 2.4 points to end at 859.2, with 28 contracts traded. June TF futures moved up nine points to close at 861.4, with one contract transaction, while September TF futures lost 7.8 points to finish at 844, with 15 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER JOBLESS RATE LOWEST IN NEARLY FIVE YEARS: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate hit a low of 4.14 percent in September, down by 0.36 percentage points from the same month last year and marking the lowest single-month record in nearly five years, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Friday.

The number of jobless people in the country stood at 430,000 in September, while the unemployment rate averaged 4.19 percent in the first nine months of this year, down by 0.33 percentage points from the same period last year, DGBAS officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU THREATENS GOVERNMENT OVER LACK OF ACTION ON KMT ASSETS

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solitary Union (TSU) legislators issued an ultimatum Friday to the government, claiming it will seek to cut budgets of the ministries of finance and justice should the government fail to reclaim the country's assets "illegally seized" by the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) during its years of rule.

The TSU's legislative caucus invited officials of both the ministries of finance and justice to report their handling of the KMT's alleged ill-gotten party assets at the caucus office at the Legislative Yuan.

Vice Finance Minister Lee Ruey-tsang indicated that the KMT has used illegal means during its five decades in power to obtain around 144 hectares of real estate, worth about NT$21.9 billion (US$653.73 million) in market value.
So far, the KMT has returned 1.8 hectares, or over NT$1.2 billion in market value, accounting for 1.7 percent of the total amount of what it should return.

Lee said since the legislature has failed to pass a draft bill on statutes governing ill-gotten party assets, his ministry possesses no weapons to back its move to force the KMT to return their improperly obtained party assets.
The existing Land Act protects the rights of the KMT, which has land in its name that "belongs to the country," he added.

A TSU caucus whip, Ho Min-hao, said he believes there are plenty of existing laws for the government to take advantage of in handling the issue. However, the government has shown weakness on the issue since the KMT and its political ally, the People First Party, jointly control a slim majority in the Legislative Yuan.

"The government has been advocating reforms, and the party assets issue is the best start for it to push for reforms, " Ho said, urging the government to "do something" in demanding the KMT to return "ill-gotten" party assets as soon as possible; otherwise, the TSU will act to force the government to include seeking to cut the budgets of relevant authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURGEON DISCIPLINED DURING SARS OUTBREAKS SUES FOR COMPENSATION

TEXT.P: A surgeon who was disciplined in 2003 during the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) for failing to undertaking quarantine measures required by the Taipei City Government filed a civil suit against Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and the city government Friday, asking for NT$21.25 million (US$640,629) in compensation.

Chou Ching-kai, a former surgeon of the Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital, accompanied by his wife and lawyer, filed the suit with the Taipei District Court against Ma and his government, claiming that his career was ruined after being branded by the city as the surgeon who deserted his post at the Hoping Hospital.
As a result, Chou claimed, he could neither land a job as a surgeon at any hospital nor attract patients in private practice.

The dispute dates back to April 24, 2003, when a cluster of SARS cases were found in Hoping Hospital, and the then-health chief of Taipei City Chiu Shu-ti, ordered the closure of the hospital and the quarantine of all medical staff and patients in the hospital.
As a leading surgeon at Hoping, Chou refused to subject himself to quarantine; rather, he went into hiding until May 1 when the city authorities asked police to help locate him.
Afterward, Chou was fired by the hospital and was forbidden by a medical council to practice medicine.

Chou, who argued that he didn't return to the hospital for quarantine as requested because the hospital was not equipped for that purpose and the quarantine order was ill-conceived, appealed against the decision to a court which overruled the medical council's decision to forbid him from practicing medicine in September.

Following his success in winning back his right to practice medicine, Chou said he wants to reinstate his reputation by claiming compensation for damage against the mayor and the Taiwan City authorities.
SARS, which flared up in Taiwan between March and June in 2003, claimed the lives of 37 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES 7,000 BLANKETS TO QUAKE DISASTER VICTIMS IN PAKISTAN

TEXT.P: Victims of the massive earthquake in Pakistan will be getting 7,000 blankets from the people of Taiwan soon.
Taiwan's China Airlines and Pakistan Airlines have agreed to transport the blankets for free after Taiwan's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation initiated the charity move.

Distribution of the blankets will begin immediately in the disaster areas after the off-loading, according to organizers at Tzu Chi, who responded to an urgent request from disaster victims suffering from near-freezing temperatures at night.
Tzu Chi, Taiwan's largest charitable organization well-known for its relief activities around the world, sent a 15-member team to Islamabad Oct. 19 to join the relief operations.

The team consists of Tzu Chi volunteers, medical personnel and journalists from Taiwan, Jordan, Turkey, Malaysia, and Indonesia. They brought 700 kilograms of relief materials and medicines to Muzaffarabad, capital of Pakistani-controlled Kashmir, to help the local residents needing help.
In addition to the 7,000 blankets, Tzu Chi is preparing 220,000 ready-to-eat vegetarian meal packages for shipment to the disaster areas by air.
According to official figures released by the Pakistan government, the death toll caused by the earthquake has surpassed 48,000 people, with more than 3 million homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN INSISTS ON SENDING WANG TO APEC SUMMIT: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian remains firm in his determination to send Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng to present him at this year's APEC summit meeting, and the government will talk to South Korea over the issue despite Seoul's rejection of Wang a day earlier, a presidential aide said Friday.

James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said that the Presidential Office will continue seeking support from South Korea for Wang's attendance as the president's envoy at the APEC summit meeting slated for Nov. 18-19 in Busan, stressing that the president's choice of Wang is "suitable and appropriate" and that Beijing has no right to meddle.

On Thursday, South Korea turned down President Chen's initiative to have Wang take part in the upcoming informal APEC leadership meeting on his behalf, requesting Taiwan instead to send an economic official in compliance with APEC's spirit, functions and precedents.

Noting that Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh has served as Chen's envoy three times at the annual APEC summit meeting, Huang said that Lee is not and has never been an economic official. The APEC memorandum of understanding (MOU) signed in 1991 by Taiwan, Hong Kong and China has no power over the summit meetings that began in 1993.

With assistance from South Korea, the three sides agreed to enter APEC in 1992 under a set of terms documented in the MOU, with one of the terms stipulating that Taiwan shall be represented at ministerial meetings only by a minister or ministers in charge of APEC-related economic affairs, while its "foreign minister" or "vice foreign minister" should not attend APEC meetings.

Answering questions from reporters at the Legislative Yuan the same day, Wang said that he will try to relay his willingness to participate in the APEC summit to South Korea and expressed his belief that President Chen will adequately handle the issue should he be banned from taking part.

"I believe that President Chen will deal with the matter properly to secure Taiwan's presence in the high-profile international activity, " he said, adding that he is quite familiar with economic issues after having served at the Legislative Yuan for more than 20 years. The reason for rejection given by South Korea can be fairly commented on by the public, he argued.

To coordinate inter-ministerial efforts to tackle suppression from Beijing, officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Economic Affairs briefed Wang on possible countermeasures earlier the same day.
Relevant government agencies have prepared for the worst-case scenario in this regard, but the government will not let go any opportunity to make every possible effort, government officials said.

William C.T. Lai, caucus leader of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the Legislative Yuan, said that the DPP will introduce a proposal to garner support from opposition parties for Wang's attendance at the APEC summit.

As a veteran at the Legislative Yuan, Wang, the leader of Taiwan's top lawmaking body, has deep knowledge of the country's economic policies and laws, Lai said, adding that Wang's participation at the meeting will undoubtedly help APEC move ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO REINITIATE DESALINATION PLANT PLAN FOR HIGH-TECH PARK

TEXT.P: In a bid to stabilize water supply for the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park (HSIP) in northern Taiwan, the government has decided to reinitiate a plan to build a desalination plant for Taiwan's leading high-tech park, according to government officials.

According to officials of the Water Resources Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the administration will try to persuade companies based at the park to agree to the plan, which has failed to win total support due to the higher water fees involved and fears that a higher degree of borax contained in desalinated water might affect their manufacturing.

The plan was almost set to be finalized last year with completion slated for the end of 2008, but it came to a halt as a result of the two aforementioned factors, the officials said, adding that the administration is now determined to reinitiate the project to ensure water supply during the dry seasons.

The plant will be able to increase water supply by between 30,000 tons and 90,000 tons per day for the park, but the cost of each water reading will be at least NT$0.5 higher, the officials explained, adding that the plant will be of great help after the park's third expansion has been completed when the park's daily water consumption is expected to grow to 175,000 tons from the current level of 123,000 tons.

The HSIP is Taiwan's most representative high-tech park, which heavily relies on stable water supply to maintain smooth operations of the companies, mainly in the semiconductor and computer-related sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REQUESTS CONSULTATIONS WITH CHINA ON OFFICIAL'S VISIT

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Friday requested consultations with Chinese authorities on the possible visit to Taiwan by a high-ranking Chinese official.
Chen Yunlin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, has been invited by the opposition Kuomintang to visit Taiwan later this year to attend an economic and trade forum hosted by the party.
According to MAC Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu, the government needs to make proper arrangements and provide the necessary assistant if a Chinese official ranking as high as Chen is to visit Taiwan.
Therefore, consultations and contact between the two sides on the matter will be necessary, Liu said.

On the planned Taiwan visit on Oct. 28 by Shao Qiwei, director of China's National Tourism Administration, Liu said Shao's trip will be simple and will not involve matters of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations.
The purpose of Shao's visit is mainly to inspect the scenic spots and related tourism facilities in Taiwan, according to MAC officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT 'BANDITS' FOR REFUSING TO RETURN ILL-GOTTEN ASSETS: DPP

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) officials accused members of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Friday of acting like "bandits" and "rascals" for refusing to return the party's ill-gotten assets to the national coffer.

They said KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou was lying when he claimed that the sale of the land occupied by the KMT's National Development Institute (NDI), the party's school for nurturing future leaders, was completely lawful.
The DPP has argued that the KMT has no right to sell the land because like many other properties now owned by the KMT, the piece of land is supposed to belong to the government.

Citing data from the Ministry of Finance, DPP Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin said the KMT has obtained 679 pieces of land with a total area of more than 144 hectares with a listed value of NT$21.9 billion (US$651.78 million) through improper means.
However, the party has only returned 57 pieces totalling eight hectares worth NT$1.2 billion, according to Yen.
For 118 hectares out of these 144 hectares of land in question, the KMT has either transferred the ownership or gotten compensated for a requisition, Yen said.
As to the five theaters with a combined listed value of nearly NT$900 million, the KMT is only willing to return NT$300 million in cash, he said.
He said by selling the piece of NDI-occupied land, the KMT was acting like a thief who was "selling their stolen goods quickly after the theft was uncovered."

Meanwhile, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said the purchase of the land now occupied by the KMT headquarters may look lawful, but the KMT actually bought the land at a price equal to 10 percent of its market value.
Also, Cheng pointed out, while the land is designated for official use, the KMT is obviously not a government agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO SET UP 11 AD HOC GROUPS TO PUSH FOR REFORMS

TEXT.P: A high-ranking ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Friday that the party will set up 11 ad hoc groups to push for various reforms, which may include the reduction in the lifetime pensions for former heads of state.

William C.T. Lai, the DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said at a news conference after convening a meeting of the legislative caucus that the DPP fully supports the 11 reforms, including six that were outlined by President Chen Shui-bian recently and five being promoted by the caucus.

Lai noted that the DPP will set up ad hoc groups responsible for financial reform; tax reform; changes to the preferential interest rate of 18 percent for retired military personnel, civil servants and teachers; media reform; investigation into properties inappropriately seized by political parties; and constitutional reform as outlined by President Chen.

The party will also establish five groups to review the bonus system for government officials in enterprises with government shares, avoid the "double-dipping" situation in which some retired government officials still receive pay or pensions from various after-retirement posts in addition to pensions from their original jobs, promote legislative reform, as well as review the salary structure of senior advisers to the president and national policy advisors to the president and the lifetime pensions for former presidents and vice presidents.
Chao Yung-chin, a whip of DPP's legislative caucus, noted that the various ad hoc groups may come up with concrete projects for those reforms within two weeks.
Chao added that the DPP legislative caucus will fully cooperate with the administrative sector to carry out those reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES COMING TOGETHER OVER WANG AS ROC'S APEC REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: Support is growing across party lines for Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng to be the president's representative at the informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum (APEC) in November, William Lai, a whip of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus, said on Friday.

Lai said that lawmakers of the largest opposition Kuomintang, the People First Party and the Taiwan Solitary Union are behind the DPP-drafted proposal to pass a resolution in support of Wang's attendance at the upcoming APEC summit as President Chen Shui-bian's envoy.
Efforts are being made to get the support of independent legislators, Lai added.

The DPP proposal says that as a full APEC member, Taiwan enjoys the same rights as those of other members, including the right for it to have its head-of-state attend the annual informal summit. However, out of respect to the meeting's host, the ROC president had never attended the event, but has had a representative take part.

The 2005 APEC leadership meeting will take place in Busan, South Korea, which has delivered an invitation to President Chen out of international protocol. Chen has designated Wang to attend the meeting on his behalf.

The DPP-drafted proposal says that Wang, as the leader of Taiwan's law-making institution, is the most qualified person for the APEC meeting since he has managed many bills concerning economic and trade affairs, and has also been involved in the formation of many economic and trade policies of the country.

South Korean Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade Ban Ki-moon expressed a day earlier that he affirms Taiwan's commissioning a person with an economic background for the Busan meeting, saying such a move is in line with APEC's ideas and conventions.
Because of China opposition, Taiwan's president has been barred from APEC Summit, and has had to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT, PRIVATE SECTOR MIXED ON GROWTH RATE FORECASTS

TEXT.P: The government and the private sector had mixed reactions Friday to economic growth rate forecasts released earlier the same day by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, with the private sector showing less optimism for Taiwan's economy.

Chen Wen-liang, a researcher at the Fubon Financial Holdings Corp., said that he predicts that the domestic economy will expand only a little more than 3 percent this year due to sliding exports of memory chips and compact discs in recent years.
Despite the fact that Taiwan's fourth quarter exports have been estimated to improve, he said that it takes more time to observe whether the trend will continue.

Pointing out that the Chinese economy is expected to cool off next year and that international oil prices are likely to continue to remain at high levels, Chen said that the two factors will negatively affect Taiwan's economy, although he acknowledged that he does not know to what extent.
The Chung-hua Institution for Economic Research made public earlier Friday its forecasts for Taiwan's economy -- a 3.53 percent growth rate for all of 2005 and a 4.02 percent expansion for 2006.

In contrast, Hung Ruey-pin, director of the Economic Research Department under the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, argued that the predictions are somewhat underestimated, basing his optimism on the government's incentives to prop up business conditions. For instance, tourist arrivals to Taiwan are likely to be over three million this year, he added.

Lu Chih-min, a section chief at the Bank of Taiwan was in the middle, claiming that he is optimistic about Taiwan's economy this year sustained by brisk exports in the second half thanks to the strong U.S. economic performance.

However, Lu also voiced concern over Taiwan's long-term economic development. Mass relocations by Taiwan companies to China and their successful integration and transformation there have taken their toll on suppliers of semi-finished products remaining at home, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES PUBLIC TO HEIGHTEN ALERT FOR BIRD FLU ON VISITS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: An official from the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Friday urged the public to be alert for avian influenza during visits to China.
MAC Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu made the appeal after eight of some 1,000 birds smuggled into the country on a freighter from China were confirmed to have been infected with the H5N1 avian flu virus.
The eight were from 270 dead birds that Taiwan quarantine agents found on the Panama-registered cargo ship anchored in Taichung Harbor last week.
The more than 1,000 smuggled birds were all destroyed.

Liu noted that the quarantine efforts by the Coast Guard Administration, the Department of Health and the Council of Agriculture are proving effective in preventing the N5N1 virus from entering Taiwan proper.

According to Liu, the crew members are from Fuzhou, China, and the mastermind of the smuggling was detained, with the others innocent of smuggling the birds and the cargo ship being repatriated to China.

As the H5N1-infected birds came from China and there were cases of bird flu infection among birds in Inner Mongolia, Liu urged the public to keep on high alert and take sufficient prevention measures during their China visits.

Taiwan has informed mainland authorities about the case in conformity with the regulations of the World Health Organization, and has also passed the information to various Taiwanese trade associations scattered in the mainland, Liu said
Meanwhile, being a member economy of the Asia-Pacific Economic and Cooperation (APEC) forum, Taiwan has also informed other APEC member countries about the bird flu case.

DOC.HEADLINE: REAL-TIME OPERATION SYSTEM OPERATOR SEEKS TO OPEN MARKET IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Canadian QNX Software Systems Ltd. is making efforts along with its regional distributor SPA Computers from India to promote its unique real-time operating system (RTOS) software in the Taiwan market, an SPA executive said Friday.

The 25-year-old QNX Software Systems, headquartered in Ottawa, is the world's leading provider of RTOS, development tools and services for embedded design. Its RTOS, named QNX Neutrino, is a microkernel operating system which performs well in information security.
Cisco, Delphi, General Electric, Siemens and Texaco are among its numerous clients from around the world, the SPA executive said.

As an effort to make inroads into Taiwan, QNX and SPA have held a series of seminars in Taipei in the north, and in two other major cities in the central and southern parts of the island in the past week to introduce QNX products to leading industrial businesses and technology research institutions in Taiwan, including Formosa Plastics, China Steel, the Industrial Technology Research Institute and the Aerospace Industrial Development Corp.

The chief architect of QNX Software Systems, Peter van der Veen, said he sees a good market for QNX real-time operating systems in Taiwan in the fields like "networking and telecommunications, defense and military and industrial automation and we have good response from IC design houses."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA VISITS TO BE BANNED IF BIRD FLU STARTS JUMPING BETWEEN HUMANS

TEXT.P: Department of Health Minister Hou Sheng-mou said Friday that the government will prohibit local people from visiting China if bird flu infections begin to be passed between humans.

Hou made the remarks in the legislature in response to questions from opposition Kuomintang Legislator Kuo Su-chun who expressed concern that thousands of birds were found dead due to infection with the H5N1 bird flu strain in China's Inner Mongolia.
Hou noted that although there are birds infected with H5N1 avian flu virus in China, there are so far no cases of bird flu infections between humans.
However, due to the lack of transparency of China's medical and quarantine information, the government will try to keep up with the real situation in China, Hou added.

Meanwhile, Hou also remind people just returning from their visits to Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, and Cambodia to monitor their health for 10 days after coming back to Taiwan as there were also cases of bird flu infections in these Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITY COUNCILORS DISSATISFIED WITH REPORT ON KAOHSIUNG MRT ISSUES

TEXT.P: A group of opposition Kaohsiung City councilors said Friday they were disappointed at a newly released investigation report on suspected irregularities or scandals involving the half-built mass rapid transit (MRT) system in the southern Taiwan port city.

The city councilors from the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said the report prepared by a five-member team was too sketchy and failed to clarify controversies surrounding the hiring of Thai laborers to work on MRT project.

The city councilors, including Lin Kuo-cheng of the KMT and Kuo chien-ming of the TSU, claimed that the skimpy report reflected the team's critical weakness -- lacking in comprehensive understanding of the utterly complicated project.
The five-member team was formed two weeks ago at the instruction of President Chen Shui-bian to look into snowballing allegations tied to the MRT project.

Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan served as the convener of the team and its four other members included her two deputies -- Cheng Wen-lung and Tang Chin-chuan -- as well as Secretary-General of the Kaohsiung City Government Hao Chien-sheng and Department of Civil Service Ethics Director Hwang Sheng-yih.
After two weeks of intensive work, Yeh unveiled the team's findings at a news conference held at the city headquarters at 3 p.m.
Yeh said the team will transfer its findings about four of the seven key points subject to inquiry to judicial authorities for further investigations.

The seven items included management of the Thai laborers; open tenders for six civil engineering bids; suspected price rigging in Kaoshiung Rapid Transit Corp.'s (KRTC's) premixed concrete procurement; MRT train carriage door specifications; price adjustments; public art installations and formulation of the BOT (build-operate-transfer) formula for the MRT construction.
"Our findings regarding the first four items will require further judicial probes to determine whether any kickbacks or irregularities were involved," Yeh said.
Moreover, Yeh said the team found that the city government's Bureau of Labor Affairs should be held responsible for lax supervision of the KRTC's labor management flaws and irregularities.

While judicial authorities are pursuing whether any Taiwan officials were involved in exploitation of Thai laborers working for KRTC and other irregularities coming to light in the wake of the Aug. 21 riot, Yeh said the city government will call a personnel review meeting next week to dispense discipline for labor affairs administrators in terms of the team's findings for their lax supervision.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN MAY OPEN TO CHINESE INVESTORS ON EXPERIMENTAL BASIS: HSIEH

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday if the government is to open the door to Chinese investments, the frontline island of Kinmen should be the first to be selected to experiment with such a policy.

Hsieh made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session where opposition New Party Legislator Wu Chen-tien from the Kinmen constituency asked about the government's stance on allowing Chinese investments in Taiwan.

Hsieh said the government may consider the issue in the future and that if it decides to lift the ban on inbound Chinese investments, he would propose experimenting the measure in Kinmen before the open-door measure is implemented on Taiwan proper.

Noting that Kinmen, which lies closer to China's Fujian province than to Taiwan, has played a special role in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Hsieh said the government will consider the feasibility of allowing Chinese investments in Kinmen on an experimental basis to help boost the island's development.
For decades, Kinmen has relied heavily on military personnel stationed on the island for its economic activities.
Under a military restructuring and troops-reduction plan, Hsieh said, the number of military personnel stationed on Kinmen will be trimmed substantially in the coming years.
To sustain Kinmen's development, Hsieh said the government will come up with a new strategy with a forward-looking vision.
"More liberal, fewer restrictions and more openness will be features of our new strategy," Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG WILL ADVOCATE BIRD FLU PREVENTION MEASURES AT APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday that he will advocate bird flu prevention measures at this year's informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum if he is permitted to attend the meeting.

Wang made the remarks after listening to reports from various ministries at the Presidential Office in his capacity as special envoy of President Chen Shui-bian to the APEC summit, although China has expressed strong opposition to his attendance at the meeting to be held in the South Korean port city of Busan Nov. 18-19.
Wang noted that Taiwan's delegation at last year's APEC meetings had presented measures against avian influenza; however, the proposals did not get much attention.

If Taiwan, which has experience in dealing with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), can increase global cooperation against bird flu at this year's APEC summit, it will increase the country's position in the international community, Wang said.

Concerning the remarks by South Korean Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade Ban Ki-moon Thursday that it will conform with APEC practice if Taiwan sends an official responsible for economic affairs to attend the summit, Wang noted that China is South Korea's largest trading partner, and it would be difficult for South Korea to resist Beijing's pressure in this matter.
Republic of China presidents have had to name special envoys to attend APEC summits since 1993 due to the objections of China to the participation of the country's head of state.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEH CALLS FOR FAIR REVIEW OF MRT INVESTIGATIVE REPORT

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan said Friday she hopes local politicians and ordinary citizens as well can give a fair review of a newly released investigation report on suspected scandals involving the half-built mass rapid transit (MRT) system in the southern Taiwan port city.

Yeh, who led the five-member team that authored the investigation report, said the main purpose of forming the special task force two weeks ago to look into controversies surrounding the MRT project was to present facts for public judgment.

"Since the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working for the city's MRT system against harsh treatment by their employers, the project has been scandalized due to snowballing allegations involving the project's building formula, construction bidding and hiring of foreign laborers, " Yeh lamented. The team has presented its findings after two weeks of hard work in an impartial, objective and non-partisan manner, Yeh said.
"We didn't have any bottom line, preset stance or political consideration," Yeh stressed.

As the team didn't have judicial power, Yeh said, it is not in a position to criminalize any person. Yeh said the team will transfer its findings about four items subject to inquiry to judicial authorities for further investigation.
Commenting on the investigative report, former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Duen-yi, who is now an opposition Kuomintang legislator, said the report failed to live up to public expectations.
"The report has deliberately skipped critical points, particularly those involving suspected bidding scandals. Yeh has let down me. She is incompetent, " Wu said.

Opposition People First Party Legislator Chang Hsien-yao echoed Wu's views, claiming that Yeh is not sincere in finding the truth. Chang said the report didn't give a detailed account about the application of the Government Procurement Law in various MRT procurement projects and serious flaws in employing Thai laborers for the project.

Some observers said they wonder why the report didn't mention whether Premier Frank Hsieh, who was Kaohsiung mayor before assuming the premiership this February, was negligent or derelict in his duties in supervising the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) operations.
Responding to this, Hsieh said he welcomes further investigations.
President Chen Shui-bian directed Yeh to look into snowballing allegations tied to the MRT project two weeks ago.

Yeh Chu-lan served as the convener of the team and its four other members included her two deputies -- Cheng Wen-lung and Tang Chin-chuan -- as well as Secretary-General of the Kaohsiung City Government Hao Chien-sheng and Department of Civil Service Ethics Director Hwang Sheng-yih.
After two weeks of intensive work, Yeh unveiled the team's findings at a news conference held at the city headquarters at 3 p.m.

Moreover, Yeh said the team found that the city government's Bureau of Labor Affairs should be held responsible for lax supervision of the KRTC's labor management flaws and irregularities.

While judicial authorities are pursuing whether any Taiwan officials were involved in exploitation of Thai laborers working for KRTC and other irregularities coming to light in the wake of the Aug. 21 riot, Yeh said the city government will call a personnel review meeting next week to dispense discipline for labor affairs administrators in terms of the team's findings for their lax supervision.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 22, or the 20th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1721: Peter I, known as "Peter the Great," is proclaimed Emperor of all of Russia. He extended his territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores and reformed the administration of the state.
1835: Sam Houston, U.S. politician and general who fought in the Texan struggle for independence from Mexico, is sworn in as president of the Republic of Texas.
1873: The emperors of Russia, Germany and Austro-Hungary form an alliance.
1906: Paul Cezanne, French painter and leading post-impressionist figure, dies at the age of 67. His most famous paintings include "Mont Sainte-Victoire" and "The Card Players."
1909: Elise de Laroche, French aviator better known as Baronne de Laroche, becomes the first woman to fly solo.
1944: The Military Committee of the National government begins drafting young intellectuals for military service after Chairman Chiang Kai-shek on Sept. 14 urged 100,000 young men to enter the army.
1947: Pakistan and India begin a war over Kashmir.
1947: Japanese spy Yoshiko Kawajima is sentenced to death by a Chinese military court.
1950: Popular elections of magistrates are held in Taiwan Province, with Yang Chung-ching being elected chief of Hualien County and Chen Chen-chung being elected chief of Taitung County.
1951: A strong earthquake rocks Hualien, killing 43 people and destroying many houses.
1953: Laos gains independence from France.
1962: U.S. President John F. Kennedy makes his first major move in the showdown with the USSR over the building of ballistic missile sites in Cuba by announcing that Cuba will be placed under a naval "quarantine" -- a blockade -- until the Soviets remove the missiles.
1964: Jean-Paul Sartre, French writer, rejects the Nobel Prize for literature by saying it would reduce the impact of his writing.
1966: KGB master spy George Blake, who had spied for the Russians for 12 years and in 1962 had been sentenced to 42 years in prison, escapes from the maximum security wing of Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London.
1975: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and philosopher, dies at the age of 86. His "Study of History" explores patterns of growth and the decay of civilization.
1976: The 34,000-ton tanker Tsaineng (Talent) calls at Taichung port, becoming the first vessel to enter Taiwan's fourth international seaport.
1977: The first generator of the first nuclear power plant in Taiwan becomes operational.
1978: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea agree to exchange information on the development and preservation of energy resources at their 13th annual ministerial economic conference.
1986: Yeh Chien-ying, one of the senior leaders of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 89. With the support of Yeh, who commanded a wide following in the army and among senior cadres in 1976, Hua Kuo-feng was able to purge the "Gang of Four" and become Mao Zedong successor.
1992: Belgian Foreign Trade Minister Robert Urbain visits Taipei to relay a message of welcome to Taiwan business leaders intending to invest in Belgium. He also pledges support for the ROC's bid to join GATT.
1993: Boris N. Yeltsin, president of Russia, signs a decree governing private farms, paving the way for the breaking up of state-controlled farms and the move toward a free market economy.
1995: Independent presidential candidate Chen Li-an names Wang Ching-feng, a Control Yuan member, as his running mate.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew rushes to Chiayi immediately after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the southern city at 10:19 a.m. and injured more than 320 people.
2000: Industrial sources say that Taiwan's exports in personal and notebook computers have increased by more than 40 percent over last year, with local notebooks accounting for 60 percent of the global market.
2001: After years of preparations, a group of scholars, social workers and medical specialists form the "Taiwan Health Reform Foundation" to monitor the operations of the nation's medical system.
2001: Lien Chan, chairman of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), urges the public during a video shot for an ad to put their love of Taiwan into action by joining volunteer services.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO EARLY FOR EXPERTS TO BE SENT TO TAIWAN: U.S. CDC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By J.L. Che and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: It is still too early to say whether the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) will send experts to Taiwan to help prevent the island from being affected by avian influenza, a spokeswoman of the center said Friday.

Christine Pearson made the comments in response to a question raised by the Central News Agency regarding whether the center will dispatch experts to Taiwan if the island sees an outbreak of the bird flu.
The CDC sent several of its experts to Taiwan during the outbreaks in 2003 of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).
According to the spokeswoman, the CDC has sent its experts to various disease-affected areas around the world to help prevent further expansion of disease.

Despite the fact that the world is paying much attention to the possible outbreak of bird flu in Asia, Pearson said that it is difficult to predict now the situations regarding any future outbreaks and expansion of bird flu in the region; therefore, it is still premature to talk about whether the center will send anyone to Taiwan.

Wild birds are the hosts of the H5N1 virus that transmits the disease. Although the virus does not typically infect humans, in 1997, however, the first instance of direct bird-to-human case was documented during an outbreak of avian influenza among poultry in Hong Kong.
According to the center, from Dec. 30, 2004 to March 17, 2004, 12 confirmed human cases of avian influenza were reported in Thailand and 23 in Vietnam, resulting in 23 deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR FAIRNESS IN CUTTING EX-PRESIDENTS' BENEFITS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged lawmakers Saturday to be fair and just in seeking to cut back on the benefits enjoyed by former presidents and vice presidents.

Pointing out that President Chen Shui-bian and herself agreed to a reduction of their salaries soon after they took office, Lu called on those who are promoting the reforms to set a good example by reducing their own pay first.
The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has proposed amending the law governing benefits for former presidents and vice presidents to reduce their pensions.
The proposal has won the support of opposition parties.

Under the current law, a former president and vice president together get an annual pension of NT$52 million (US$1.54 million) . The DPP is arguing that the situation is unreasonable compared with that of the United States, where only former presidents are paid a pension and former vice presidents do not get more than a seven-month relocation allowance.
Also on Saturday, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang blamed the former ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , which pushed the law through the legislature, for deliberately including former vice presidents.

As a result, former vice president Lien Chan, now honorary chairman of the KMT, has been receiving NT$470,000 a month in retirement benefits, including NT$220,000 generated under a preferential 18-percent annual interest rate for government employees, Su noted.
The amount is much higher than that received by the incumbent and retired presidents, Su pointed out.
