First cases of bird flu were discovered in Croatia Friday. Some 12 swans were found dead in a reservation area near Zdenci city, in eastern part of the country, according to Mlanden Pavic, spokesman of the Croatian Ministry of Agriculture.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT KICKS OFF 'TRAIN OF HOPE' TOUR IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's round-the-island tour on a mobile stage kicked off in southern Taiwan Saturday to drum up support for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) candidates in the year-end elections.
Officials from the DPP's Chiayi Chapter said that the "train of hope" was converted from a 6.5 tonne truck. The president's first stop is the parking lot behind the railway station in Talin, Chiayi.
The president will elaborate on the government's policies and the determination to pursue reforms in a 40-minute speech starting at 4:20 p.m. party officials said.
They noted that the president hopes the use of the truck will resonate with grassroots voters as this type of vehicle is identified with local campaigning.
Chen, who has a lot of experience in campaigning, held several large rallies with magnificent sound and light shows in the run-up to the 2004 presidential election.
For this year's campaign, however, he has decided to adopt a more modest, low-key approach, hoping to highlight the government's determination to pursue reforms, they said.
Before President Chen's speech, DPP candidates for Chiayi County magistrate and township will canvass votes in the area.

President Chen's barnstorming approach is actually a follow-up to a series of local seminars held in the wake of China opening to Taiwan's agricultural products in August, when the president visited rural areas to talk with local DPP officials on the government's stance, advising them not to fall into the trap of China's "charm offensive," which is said to have been effective.
His more-than 30-stop barnstorming tour will then proceed to Tainan city and county, and will continue to Hualien County, and Taichung city and county Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTABLISHMENT OF A HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION A PRIORITY: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Saturday urged the government to accelerate the establishment of a National Human Rights Commission, saying that the Presidential Office's Human Rights Board has been pushing for this for several years.

Lu made the remarks while addressing the opening of the two-day Conference on National Human Rights in the Asia-Pacific, which was co-hosted by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy and the Taiwan Society of International Law at the Taipei-based Civil Service Development Institute.

Lu, doubling as the board's chairwoman, said Taiwan acquired its freedom and democracy after a long period of struggle. Despite the fact that it has being barred from the United Nations due to its controversial political position, Taiwan still follows the U.N.'s "Paris Principles, " which feature the ideas and importance in the promotion of human rights commissions of all countries around the world.
In August, 2002, the board finished drafting the organic law and the duties enforcement act of Taiwan's National Human Rights Commission, Lu noted.

Under the draft, the commission is authorized to map out relevant regulations and policies regarding human rights, to oversee human rights measures of government agencies and civil organizations, to engage in investigations into human rights violations, to release the country's annual report on human rights, to promote human rights education and publicize human rights ideas, and to push for exchanges and cooperation between local and foreign human rights institutions.
The draft bill will be delivered to the Legislative Yuan next month, the vice president said, urging lawmakers to pass the bill as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT GOAL OF CUSTARD APPLES TO BE DOUBLED NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Taitung's custard apples have been so well received overseas that the export goal for the fruit next year has been doubled to 85 tons, the Taitung District Agricultural Research and Extension Station under the Council of Agriculture said Saturday.
Station officials said that they will target Singapore, Hong Kong, Canada, Malaysia and China.

Custard apples, a specialty of Taitung, eastern Taiwan, is a favorite both at home and abroad because of its unique flavor, texture and shape. Recently, the fruit was crossed with pineapples and the resulting taste is distinctive.
The officials said that harvest time for custard apples is between December and April, and this year's export goal was set at 25 tons. Because of its immense popularity, 42 tons were exported.

Exporters had hoped that exports for 2006 could be increased to 100 tons, but for the sake of steady growth and familiarizing farmers with export operations, the goal has been set at 85 tons, the officials said.
Custard apples have been exported to Singapore, Hong Kong, Canada, and Malaysia on a trial basis and have been met with a good response. The next target will be China, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T REFORMS, DOMESTIC INVESTMENT KEY TO 2006 GROWTH: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Successful government reforms and increased domestic investments could drive up Taiwan's 2006 economic growth rate to 4.51 percent from the current forecast of 4.02 percent, according to the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) Saturday.

If reforms and investments do not materialize or if Taiwan fails to sign regional free trade agreements (FTA) , the economic growth will drop to 3.65 percent, the institution said. The 2005 economic growth rate was estimated at 3.53 percent.

CIER's Center for Economic Forecasting Director Chou Chi said there are many factors making up the calculation, each of which is capable of effecting the economic development of Taiwan in the coming year. They include high gasoline prices, the year-end local elections, cross-strait exchanges, and the most influential -- the possible outbreak of an avian influenza pandemic.

Chou indicated that his center has built two different scenarios to foresee Taiwan's economic activities in 2006. The first assumes that " government reforms are implemented well, domestic investment willingness is growing, global economic growth is on the rise, and technology industrial giants act to expand their operational lines on the island."

Under this scenario, domestic investment will record a growth of NT$10 billion (US$297.6 million) each quarter, beginning from the first quarter of 2006, while a similar growth will also be registered in exports.

Chou said based on these calculations, civilian consumption growth in 2006 is expected to increase to 3.04 percent from the original forecast of 2.81 percent, while the growth rate of domestic investments will expand to 8.74 percent from 6.54 percent.

As to the second scenario, the researcher noted the assumption is that Taiwan fails to enter regional FTA zones. Under this situation, its 2006 exports will suffer a drop of NT$10 billion per quarter, likewise with domestic investments.

Therefore, civilian consumption growth is expected to drop from 2.81 percent to 2.63 percent, while the domestic investment growth would be expected to move lower to 6.31 percent from 6.54 percent, Chou added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL WOMEN'S LEAGUE OF ROC TO RETURN OFFICE LAND TO MILITARY

TEXT.P: The National Women's League of the Republic of China will relocate and return the land it currently occupies to the military, league chairwoman Cecilia Koo said Saturday.
Koo made the remarks at a memorial service held to mark the second anniversary of the passing of Soong Mayling, also known as Madame Chiang Kai-shek, who helped found the league in 1950 in Taipei.
Up until 1964, the league was called the Chinese Women's Anti-Aggression League.

Koo said that the establishment of the league aimed to serve military personnel, and that it helped sew millions of military uniforms and set up nurseries for the children of military personnel over the years.

But she noted that nowadays the living conditions for those in the military are good, and that the league can do little in the way of assistance. There is no more reason to occupy the land owned by the military to use as a league office, she said.
The league will relocate to Chingtao East Road from its current premise at Changsha Street by the end of this year, Koo said.
The office desk and chairs used by Madame Chiang will also be moved to the new site for memory's sake, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT URGES ASIAN DEMOCRACIES TO RESIST CHINA'S ENSLAVEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui called on democratic countries in Asia Friday to enhance their cooperation to counter the system of enslavement enforced by Communist China and to "push the flame of freedom to the darkest corner in Asia."
Lee made the remarks while delivering a keynote address on "A Strategy for Freedom in Asia" at the Formosa Foundation in Los Angeles, the final leg of his two-week U.S. visit.

According to Lee, as the wave of democratization moves toward the Asia-Pacific region, China -- the last fortress of communist enslavement -- is also rising in Asia, making the region the focal point where freedom confronts enslavement.

As to whether the rise of China will be peaceful or military will depend on the choice of the Chinese government and its people and on what strategy is adopted by the governments of free and democratic countries, especially the United States, towards the future development of China and the region, Lee said.

Lee argued that free countries in the Asia-Pacific region lack a concerted strategy towards the rise of China mainly because Beijing has followed a strategy different from that of the former Soviet Union -- which took an anti-America position and advocated the burial of capitalism.

Instead, China has established "constructive cooperation" with the United States and is absorbing U.S. and international capital to expand the economic, military, technological and diplomatic power of its enslavement system, Lee said.

Lee stressed that free and democratic countries enjoy an advantage over those embracing enslavement, with China and North Korea being the two isolated islands in the ocean of freedom and democracy in the region.
He claimed that the concept of "multi-polarity" promoted by China is aimed at driving a wedge between democratic countries to isolate the United States -- the leader of these free countries.
Taiwan has emerged as a fledging democracy in the third global wave of democratization, amid the military threat from China and the obstruction by the remnants of an alien power, he said.
While the people of Taiwan will fight for their freedom, they need the support of the United States and of all free people around the world, he said.
Lee said people in Asia are expecting the United States to form a strategic alliance with Asian democracies such as India, Japan, Taiwan and South Korea to open a new era of cooperation.

The alliance should work together to resist the expansion of China's military hegemony and to support the Chinese people to struggle for freedom and against enslavement to force Beijing to reform its politics and terminate the tyranny in China, he added.

Also on Friday, Lee encouraged the people in Taiwan to enhance their national identity and stick to their pursuit of democracy. He was addressing a welcome reception hosted by Wei Wu-lien, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles.

Comparing the present situation in Taiwan to the 40-year exile of the Israeli people following their exodus from Egypt, as recorded in the Bible, Lee said a number of people in Taiwan are disoriented and are thinking about going back to slavery in China, just like the Israeli people back then.
While it took 40 years for the Israeli people to reach their promised land, Taiwan cannot wait another 40 years, Lee said.
Having been ruled by foreign powers for more than 300 years, Taiwan must stand firm to its belief that "Taiwan is Taiwan, not a part of China" in order to secure its autonomy, he asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: URBAN RENEWAL SEMINAR TO BE HELD NEXT MONTH IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A seminar on strategies for urban renewal and the Asian experience in practice will be held next month, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Saturday.

Council officials said that the seminar, to be co-sponsored by the CEPD and the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , will invite scholars, experts and figures from private enterprises at home and overseas for the Nov. 10-11 seminar.
Hopefully, a consensus can be forged on the strategy of urban renewal in Taiwan through the exchanges of the participants, the officials said.

They noted that Taiwan will undergo dramatic changes in population growth and living environment in the next 50 years. To enhance the living quality in cities, use urban land wisely and achieve the goals of sustainable development, the CEPD has worked with the MOI to propose an urban renewal project in which it was decided that not only will the central government create a specific agency to see to the matter, but it will also work with the private sector.

They noted that urban renewal will bring huge benefits to the nation, including the development of idle lands, increase revenues from national assets, promote key industries, reinvigorate the real estate market, upgrade the living quality of the people and beautify the urban landscape.
Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore and other neighboring countries have set good examples in this regard, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JAN-AUG ENERGY CONSUMPTION UP 2.78 PERCENT FROM LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's energy consumption in the first eight months of this year was 71.18 million kiloliters of crude oil equivalents (KLOEs), up 2.78 percent from the same period last year, according to a report released Saturday by the Bureau of Energy.
Meanwhile, energy supplies between January and August decreased 1.45 percent from last year to 88.61 million KLOEs, 97.98 percent of which was imported.

Of the imported energy supplies, oil products were down 9.81 percent compared with last year's level, crude oil up 0.07 percent, coal down 5.58 percent, coke down 3.43 percent, liquefied natural gas up 5.05 percent, and nuclear power up 0.85 percent.
In terms of locally produced energy, hydroelectric power increased by 23.12 percent, while natural gas decreased by 32.27 percent.

Meanwhile, the energy consumption of the industrial sector rose 2.15 percent, the transportation sector increased 1.84 percent, the commercial sector jumped 6.22 percent, the agricultural sector fell 1.27 percent, and the household sector rose 6.39 percent.
Owing to the hike in oil, liquefied natural gas and coal prices, the total value of energy imports was up 30.93 percent in the eight months to August compared with the same time last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALACE MUSEUM-COLLECTED ARTIFACTS ON DISPLAY IN CHIAYI COUNTY

TEXT.P: For the first time, the secretive life of emperors of the last Chinese dynasty, the Ching, is on public display as the National Palace Museum opened an exhibition of artifacts of the Ching court Saturday in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan.

A total of 131 artifacts left by Ching emperors including Kang Hsi, Yung Cheng and Chien Lung -- three emperors who lived at the height of Ching power -- are displayed at the exhibition held at the Chiayi County Art Center.

National Palace Museum Director Shi Shou-chien said some of the artifacts, including a portrait of the Chia Ching Emperor, the son of Chien Lung, are being shown for the first time since they were locked in storerooms of the museum located in suburban Taipei.
Shi noted that even he had never seen them until the exhibition.

Besides the Chia Ching's portrait, the display includes the imperial decree marking the enthronement of the Tung Chih Emperor and a stone ink-slab presented by Kang Hsi to his son, Yung Cheng, as a gift.
The exhibition will run through Nov. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR JASON HU OPENS REELECTION CAMPAIGN OFFICE

TEXT.P: Jason Hu, mayor of Taichung City, inaugurated his reelection campaign office with hoopla Saturday, vowing to make the city a metropolis matching Taipei if he wins another term.

Touting the advancements the city has made during his past four years in office, Hu said he has fulfilled only half of his 2001 campaign promise of making the city a rival of Kaohsiung and Taipei, the two special municipalities of the country, as Taichung has already caught up with Kaohsiung in the last four years in terms of infrastructure.

Now, the city is on its way to catching up with Taipei, the former foreign minister said, asking the voters in the city to give him another four years to fulfill his promise by making Taichung a city that will hold its own against not only Taipei but any other international metropolis.

The inauguration attracted many of Hu's supporters, including Lien Sheng-wen, the son of KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, and Hsu Li-nung, the former leader of the minnow New Party.
Lien Sheng-wen congratulated Hu on behalf of his father, who is currently visiting the mainland.

The inauguration ceremony was rounded off by an appearance by KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who arrived a little behind schedule because of his tight itinerary, and many of the spectators waited patiently just for a glimpse of the KMT political star.
Ma heaped praise upon Hu for his achievements over the last four years, not least his efforts to cast the city into the international limelight.

Although Hu leads his rivals in the race in opinion polls, Ma cautioned Hu's supporters not to take any chances and be sure to do their best to help Hu win another four-year term, adding that "supporting Hu is supporting me, because we are of the same group."
The election of city and county chiefs is set for Dec. 3 and will be held together with two other local elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN MORE TIRED THAN MEN: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan women, regardless of their age, occupation, status, education and working hours are more tired than men, according to a survey released Saturday.

The survey, jointly conducted by the Institute of Health Policy and Management of National Taiwan University and the Council of Labor Affairs, also found that young employed women, especially those under the age of 45, are the most tired group of people, probably because women in this age group have parents and children to care for.
By the same token, men of this age group are on average more tired than their counterparts in other age groups.
Also, the more education the women have, and the higher their status in the office, the more tired they say they are, according to the survey released Saturday in a seminar on public health.

In general, people of either gender who have to work more than 49 hours a week, or have old people or small children to care for at home, are most vulnerable to tiredness, the author of the survey said.

The survey conducted among 8,906 men and 6,382 women between the ages of 25 and 65, asked the interviewed to rank their tiredness on a scale from zero to 100, with 100 representing the most tired. It was found that women are on average two to three points more tired than men.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S WHISTLESTOP TOUR TO BE FINANCED BY RULING PARTY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will finance President Chen Shui-bian's island-wide whistlestop tour aimed to win over voters for DPP in the year-end elections, DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said Saturday.

Hours after the president embarked on the tour by delivering a speech from the back of a truck in Chiayi, Lee said the tour, compromising 35 stops around the island, will cost his party about NT$2 million, with about NT$50,000 for each stop.
However, the Presidential Office will provide the president with an airplane, the Air Force One, to carry him and his bodyguards around the island during the tour, according to Chen's aides.
DPP officials and Chen's aides who travel alone with the president aboard the airplane will have to pay their own flight tickets, the aides said.

In an attempt to hark back to DPP's humble origin as an opposition party, Chen chose to stump for the ruling party on the back of a truck during his whistlestop tour which started from Chiayi Saturday, followed by a stop in Tainan.
It will bring the president to Hualien and Taichung on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SUPPORTS CUT ON BENEFITS TO EX-PRESIDENTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday he fully supports the proposal to cut the pension and benefits to retired presidents and vice presidents.

Speaking in Tainan, southern Taiwan on the second leg of his island-wide whistlestop tour, the president said he didn't serve the country for money, and would not take issue with any idea to slash the pension and benefits to retired presidents although he himself would step down after two years.
Citing as proof, thep president said he has cut his salary voluntarily from NT$800,000 to NT$400,000 ever since he took office in 2000, and couldn't care less about his retirement benefits.

He challenged the opposition Kuomintang, whose honorary chairman Lien Chan is a former vice president, and People First Party to support the idea aired by a lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party with the purpose of saving the government's cost.
Under the current law, a retired president qualifies for a monthly pension of about a half his salary in office as well as allowances for office space, staff and other expenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 23, or the 21st day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1812: An anti-Napoleonic faction in Paris headed by Gen. Claude Francois de Malet tries to mount a coup d'etat, believing Napoleon to be dead in Russia.
1924: During China's warlord era, Feng Yu-hsiang, Hu Ching-yi and Sun Yueh form an allied force to launch a military coup that results in the resignation of Tsao Kun who was elected president of the Beijing government Oct. 5, 1923.
1926: Leon Trotsky is expelled from the Soviet Communist Party.
1928: The Republic of China government formally establishes the Ministry of Education.
1948: Changchun, a city in Kirin Province, northeastern China, falls to communist troops.
1952: Ukrainian-born microbiologist Selman A. Waksman wins the Nobel Prize for physiology or medicine for discovering the antibiotic streptomycin, an agent effective in the treatment of tuberculosis.
1955: Ngo Dinh Diem is elected president of South Vietnam.
1956: Hungarian students and workers demonstrate in Budapest against the Soviet occupation.
1957: ROC Vice President Chen Cheng is elected deputy director general of the Kuomintang.
1958: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles issue a joint communique reaffirming solidarity between the two countries and stating that the islands of Kinmen and Matsu are "closely related" to the defense of Taiwan and Penghu under present conditions.
1966: The Ministry of the Interior proclaims today (the ninth day of the ninth lunar month) as Double Nine Festival, also known as the Chung Yang Festival, to honor senior citizens.
1968: Nigerian President Hamani Diori arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1969: The United States starts pulling its troops out of Vietnam.
1973: The ROC suspends diplomatic relations with Upper Volta following Ouagadougou's recognition of Beijing.
1974: Brig. Gen. Abboud Salem Hassan, commander in chief of the Royal Jordanian air force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: The first Chung Cheng Cup Martial Arts Tournament opens at the Taipei Athletic College with Wang Sun-teh, president of the Taipei Martial Arts Association, presiding.
1980: An economic cooperation agreement is signed in Taipei between La Chambre de Commerce of D'Industrie de Marseilles of France and the Far East Trade Service of the ROC.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize in literature, delivers a speech entitled "To Free China" at Taipei City Hall.
1983: Muslim suicide bombers blow up the U.S. and French headquarters in Beirut, killing more than 200 U.S. marines and French paratroopers.
1992: Emperor Akihito of Japan arrives in Beijing for a six-day visit.
1997: Hong Kong's stock market falls victim to Southeast Asia's economic turmoil, with the Hang Seng index falling more than 10 percent in its biggest crash in history.
1998: A Tokyo court hands down the first death sentence to a member of the Japanese doomsday cult that carried out the 1995 Tokyo subway gas attack.
1999: Taiwan finishes second with 15 medals at the 1999 Pan Pacific Master Swimming Championship held in Perth, Australia.
2000: The 15th Belgium-Republic of China Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Brussels to discuss ways of bolstering economic cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Paraguayan Vice Foreign Minister Rigoberto Gauto Vielman arrives in Taipei at the start of a five-day visit to the Republic of China.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung agrees to call mainland China "the People's Republic of China (PRC) " rather than "communist China."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA WARNS AGAINST BRINGING ANIMALS, PLANTS INTO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) warned people Sunday not to bring any plants, animals or specimens of them into the country without permission, or they could face imprisonment for up to three years or a maximum fine of NT$150,000 plus community service.
The COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine issued the warning amid heightened international alert against the possibility of an avian flu pandemic.

The bureau indicated that it is particularly concerned about news reports that certain professors at veterinarian departments of Taiwan's universities have collected specimens of avian flu virus in China and plan to bring them into Taiwan for tests in an attempt to develop flu vaccines.
Officials at the bureau pointed out that such specimens could spread the bird flu virus and pose a high risk to the health of birds, other animals and humans in Taiwan.

The officials cautioned that people bringing animals or plants into Taiwan without permission will be prosecuted for violation of the Statue for Prevention and Control of Infectious Animal Disease and the Plant Protection and Quarantine Act.
They also said the COA is planning to ask legislators to amend the law and increase the penalty as a deterrent to such violations.
Meanwhile, the COA set up a special direct phone line for people to report suspected violations at 0800-039131.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO PLAY ACTIVE ROLE IN U.S.-JAPAN SECURITY ARRANGEMENTS

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 23 (CANA) Taiwan should play a more proactive role in the U.S.-Japan security arrangements in the Asia-Pacific region, a researcher with the private policy research institute Taiwan Thinktank said Sunday.

Lai I-chung, director of Taiwan Thinktank's International Affairs Department, said that Taiwan should not simply envisage that a U.S.-Japan-Taiwan triangular structure can form a security bloc against China. Instead, he opined, Taiwan should actively help implement the U.S.-Japan security arrangements so that an Asia-Pacific strategic order conducive to the development of maritime democracies can be built in the region.

Once a new Asia-Pacific strategic order is built, Taiwan can engage in exchanges with other countries in the region more freely, which will in turn help deepen Taiwan's democratization and accelerate economic and social reforms at the same time, Lai said.

According to Lai, Taiwan Thinktank, which is patterned after the U.S. Rand Corp., has successfully integrated opinions in Taiwan and led the common attention on a "U.S.-China-Taiwan" triangular relations framework in the past to a new "U.S.-Japan-Taiwan" strategic vision.

Currently, Taiwan Thinktank is working on a two-year program aimed at working out a three-side cooperation agenda among Taiwan, Japan and the United States after the establishment of the U.S.-Japan Security Consultative Committee late last year, Lai said.

The program is aimed at establishing areas for cooperation among the three potential strategic partners; finding out ways to build a composite security consultative mechanism; and tapping the possibility of such cooperation, Lai added.

Lai said that Taiwan Thinktank is scheduled to sponsor a symposium, entitled "U.S.-Japan-Taiwan Strategic Dialogue, " at the Westin Taipei Monday and Tuesday, to allow strategists from the three countries to exchange views on U.S.-Japan-Taiwan alliance relations in the wake of the establishment of the U.S.-Japan Security Consultative Committee, particularly on issues pertaining to security, economic and political integration.

Noted figures expected to attend the symposium include Randall Schriver, formerly a U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian Affairs; Robin Sakoda, a top aide to former U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage; Rupert J.N. Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council: John Tkacik Jr., a research fellow in China policy with the Heritage Foundation; Hisahiko Okazaki, former Japanese ambassador to Thailand; and Sumihiko Kawamura, a retired general with Japan's Defense Agency.

In the Asia-Pacific security area, Lai said that with China's increasing military expansion toward the western Pacific, the military imbalance in the Taiwan Strait has become even more obvious. He added, however, that the U.S. military presence in the Asia-Pacific region plus the stepped-up U.S.-Japan security alliance have created new opportunities and challenges regarding the prospects of U.S.-Japan-Taiwan security cooperation.

In the Asia-Pacific economic cooperation area, Lai said, the economic alliance landscape in the region has been reshaped sharply since China began actively taking part in regional economic groupings in early 2005. With a new economic order facing Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum member countries, the rebuilding of economic structures in the region would be a challenging issue for the U.S.-Japan-Taiwan cooperation, he added.

In the area of Asia-Pacific politics, he added that in the face of Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering and Japan's new constitutional agenda, as well as the leadership changes in Taiwan and the United States in 2008, the United States, Japan and Taiwan need to build mutual trust via institutional systems the sooner the better.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANDIDATES SHOULD FOCUS ON PEOPLE'S LIVELIHOOD: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh lambasted Taiwan's print media and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Sunday while calling on campaigning candidates in the year-end city and county elections to focus their attention on proposing good policies rather than on the ideologies of their political parties.

Taiwan's print media need assistance, otherwise they will attempt to "council" the president and the premier as to how to rule the country, Hsieh said while stumping for ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate for Taipei County magistrate, Lo Wen-jia, at his campaign headquarters.

By giving assistance to the print media, Hsieh said he meant readers should read more than just one or two newspapers so they can grasp the full picture of important happenings. Otherwise, they will be misled by each newspapers's biased reports, he noted.

Hsieh said Taiwan's major newspapers can only keep their "old readers, " and as a result, they have lost their competitive edge against a Hong Kong newspaper. In making the comment, Hsieh did not directly name the China Times and the United Daily News, two Taiwan major dailies that have lost market share to Apple Daily from Hong Kong.
Hsieh noted that when he told the Legislative Yuan that Taiwan's unemployment rate in September hit a five-year low of 4.14 percent, no newspapers reported it.

He claimed that Taiwan's newspapers have become kind of like "propaganda fliers" because they dare not carry stories that their "old readers" may not like, and as a result, they are losing market share to "the daily from Hong Kong" which at least carries more news photos.

The premier said Taiwan's Legislative Yuan has achieved nothing in terms of passing any bills since June 1, and foreign media have focused on the lawmakers' recent "school yard brawls" at the legislature.
In fact, there has been positive news in Taiwan, such as its ability to produce Tamiflu, a drug capable of fighting avian flu, and the declining jobless rate, according to the premier.
If the lawmakers really want to serve the people, Hsieh said, they should pass his special budget bill for flood control.

The premier said that the lawmakers must put the people's livelihood above all else, including their own party's fortunes. "What does trying to win the local elections simply for the purpose of boosting the chances of their respective parties in the 2008 presidential election have to do with the people's livelihood? " he asked.

In response to a KMT legislators' accusation that the government's flood-control bill represents "pork barrel" politics, Hsieh asked what the connection is between the bill and so-called pork-barreling.

If his administrative bills can be questioned, Hsieh said, then he can also question KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's actions. "Why did Ma, as mayor of Taipei, sell the Taipei Bank to Fubon group? Why wasn't there a public bidding? Why did Ma go to a luxury club to enjoy a shark's fin banquet? Why did he make the decision (to sell the city-run bank) in spite of the bank union's opposition? And why did he fire the union's leader?" Hsieh asked.

The supreme court has just ruled that the union leader won his suit against the city government, "so we can keep lambasting Chairman Ma for a whole day. But we know this won't do anything to help resolve the issue. As a member of the ruling party, we don't want to do that," the premier said.

Hsieh called on candidates in the county and city elections to focus their attention on the people's livelihood and to put aside the ideologies of their political parties. After all, the county and city elections do not necessarily have anything to do with the next presidential election which is more than two years away, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT CONTINUE BICKERING OVER BUDGET FOR FLOOD CONTROL

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) reiterated its claim Sunday that the NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) special budget in the Cabinet-proposed eight-year flood-control bill is "pork-barreling" intended to boost the ruling party's chances in the year-end county magistrate and mayor elections.

KMT Legislator Lo Shih-hsiung told a press conference that at least 19 categories in a detailed plan submitted by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government for the use of NT$12 billion of the proposed budget are not related directly to flood control.

These categories are mainly about planting trees to improve the views and ecology along some of the river banks and providing driveways and rest areas for motorists, Lo said, adding that the DPP apparently is trying to use the budget to curry favor with the voters.

Pan Wei-kang, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, said the opposition is asking the Cabinet to rewrite its plan and that at the same time, the KMT will also introduce its own version of a flood control plan.

In response to the KMT claim, the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs denied that the money set aside for improving the views and ecology along river banks amounts to pork barrelling, saying that the spending will account for only 10 percent of the total budget.

At a separate press conference, DPP Legislator Cheng Yun-peng acknowledged that 63 percent of the total budget will be spent on flood control in DPP-controlled cities and counties. He explained that this is simply due to the fact that most of the flood-plagued areas in Taiwan are in the central and southern parts of the country, where the DPP happens to have more voter support.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST FAMILY HAS NEVER PLANNED TO BUY LUXURY MANSION

TEXT.P: The first family has never planned to buy a unit of a luxurious mansion to be built in the high-priced area along Taipei City's Jenai Road, the Presidential Office reported Sunday.

Officials at the Presidential Office Department of Public Affairs discounted a tabloid report that President Chen Shui-bian and his family are planning to buy a Jenai Road mansion unit, worth some NT$100 million (US$2.98 million) , to be used as a residence after Chen's presidency ends.
The officials said that Chen's wife, Wu Shu-jen, has never visited the construction site of the luxurious mansion and that the first family has never had any plans to do so.

Referring to a recent visit by Chen's son-in-law, Chao Chian-ming, to a showroom for the construction site, the officials said that Chao made the visit purely out of curiosity and that he has not talked about it with any member of the first family, including his wife -- Chen Hsin-yu -- Chen's only daughter.
The officials described the tabloid report as "meaningless and unnecessary."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T SHOULD MINIMIZE INTERFERING IN EDUCATION MARKET: EX-MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Chao Yen, S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Education is increasingly regarded as a service industry in the free market, so the government should open up the market and refrain from planning out or interfering in its development, former Education Minister Kuo Wei-fan said Sunday.

Kuo, one of the 51 Taiwan participants in the 2005 cross-Taiwan Strait basic education forum being held in Shanghai, made the remarks while speaking on "Social Changes and School Leadership." A total of 400 scholars and experts were in attendance for Kuo's speech.

He said the trends of trade and educational globalization have resulted in increased cross-border flows of education personnel as more and more students and professors have been visiting other countries on study or exchange programs, becoming so-called "knowledge migrants."

He noted that since 2002, when Taiwan and China joined the World Trade Organization, education has been regarded as a kind of service industry. He suggested that education officials and school leaders make policies and strategies from the standpoint of "education globalization."
While advising the government authorities not to meddle in the development and operations of higher education institutions, Kuo also warned against running higher education like a pure enterprise.

He cited the example of some well-known universities that have been trying hard to lure top students by hiring world-class professors and offering handsome scholarships and that have consequently given people the perception of "corruption at higher education institutions."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL MISSION HELPS SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE CONTROL MALARIA

TEXT.P: By Sofia Wu CNA Staff Writer

Taipei, Oct. 23 (CNA) The Republic of China medical mission stationed in Sao Tome and Principe deserves credit for helping bring malaria under control in the West African state, the Sao Tomean ambassador to Taipei said over the weekend.

Speaking in an interview with CNA, Ambassador Ladislau F. Dalmeida said he had fallen victim to malaria numerous times since childhood, but never after 2003 when a new campaign against the life-threatening vector-borne disease was launched in his country with assistance from Taiwan.

During ROC President Chen Shui-bian's state visit to Sao Tome and Principe in July 2002, he promised to assist in ridding the African ally of malaria. Diplomatic and public health officials from both countries then began working on a viable collaborative program to that end.

Located in the Gulf of Guinea near the equator, Sao Tome and Principe boasts beautiful scenery and is one of the world's major cocoa producers. But malaria has persistently presented obstacles to its social and economic development.
In the summer of 2003, Lien Jih-ching, a National Taiwan University medical professor versed in malaria control, traveled to Sao Tome and Principe to assist in combating malaria.

Besides spraying alphacypermethrin -- a highly active broad spectrum insecticide, Lien also employed smoke and insect growth regulators (IGR) to inhibit larval mosquitoes from growing to maturity. Some mosquitoes are capable of transmitting malaria, so larvae control is very important in malaria eradication.

The three-way approach had amazing results. By November of that year, a 35-bed hospital in Principe which had always been packed with malaria patients, was empty of patients. The extraordinary event caused a stir throughout Africa at the time.

Between 1980 and 1982, the World Health Organization (WHO) conducted a disinfection program in Sao Tome by spraying DDT. The program indeed helped cut the malaria incidence rate from 19.2 percent to 0.6 percent. However, the program had a horrific side-effect -- nearly all poultry raised by the country's residents died after eating DDT-contaminated "American cockroaches, " as did cats which ate DDT-contaminated mice. The residents were so scared that they refused to accept further DDT spraying.

In the late 1990s, Sao Tome and Principe joined a "Roll Back Malaria" project co-sponsored by the WHO and several other U.N.-affiliated organizations to help all African countries reduce the human and socio-economic costs of malaria. The WHO's goal is to cutting the malaria incidence and death rates by half by 2010.
However, the WHO campaign didn't seem to deliver on its promises. By 2002, the incidence rate in Sao Tome was even higher than before.

Analyzing the differences between the WHO-sponsored and Taiwan-invented malaria-fighting programs in his country, Dalmeida said WHO medical experts couldn't stay long enough to assist in the implementation of practical programs.

In contrast, Dalmeida said, Taiwan medical professionals have taken up residence in the country on a long-term basis. They joined the efforts at the grass-roots level, conducting field surveys, disinfecting all corners of the country, controlling the growth of vector insects, and prescribing medication to in-patients and out-patients.

"Before I traveled to Taipei to take up my post, I toured the Taiwan medical mission's laboratory. I was surprised to find there were live vector mosquitoes in specially designed cases for experimentation. I think that superior professional expertise and wholehearted devotion are the factors behind the Taiwan medical team's success," Dalmeida said.
With malaria brought under control, Dalmeida said Sao Tome and Principe has seen significant progress in its tourism and economic development.

"We have seen the return of European tourists. Our people have become healthier and are now strong enough to work. Job opportunities have increased, as have incomes. Child mortality has dropped and the survival rate is up. They can safely go to school. All these are good things and benefits that come with the control of malaria, " Dalmeida said.

He went on to say that his country is set to explore the rich oil reserves beneath its territorial waters. The country is also pulling out all the stops to attract foreign investment to boost the development of financial and banking services, power generation, telecommunications, tourism and the fishing industry.
"Foreign investors no longer have to face the risk of coming down with malaria. Without the control of malaria, our economic take-off program would have always remained just a dream," Dalmeida said.

Professor Lien, who is currently in Taipei, echoed Dalmeida's view, saying that the control of malaria has brought tremendous economic benefits to Sao Tome and Principe, which consists of two main volcanic islands and several small islets.

"When I made my first visit to Sao Tome, there were few cars in the streets. But now, taxi cabs are everywhere. The room rate at Sao Tomean hotels was about 50 euros a night in the past, but the rate has surged to 85 euros. The Sao Tomean government is planning to build a five-star tourist hotel to attract more foreign visitors. This was beyond imagination just a few years ago, " Lien said.

Noting that malaria is a centuries-old infectious disease, Lien said that science still has no silver bullet for it and that many doubt whether there ever will be one. Nevertheless, effective low-cost strategies are available for treatment, prevention and control of malaria, Lien explained.

With their bitter memories of the DDT disinfection program, Sao Tomeans were initially skeptical about his malaria-control measures. "Once the effectiveness became evident, Sao Tomeans developed respect and affection for all of our medical mission members. They now call us 'amigo' (friend) whenever they meet us, " Lien said.
According to Lien, Sao Tomeans are receptive to his malaria-control methods because the insecticides used are not detrimental to the health of poultry and other animals.
Since an additional nationwide disinfection campaign in Sao Tome and Principe in 2004, Lien said, the number of hospitalized malaria patients has dropped further.

Touching on the Taiwan media mission's future work goals, Lien said he hopes the malaria incidence rate among Sao Tomeans younger than nine years of age can be cut to 1 percent from the current 10 percent by 2006 and that all present malaria patients can be cured.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TRACES OF BIRD FLU VIRUS FOUND IN WILD BIRD DROPPINGS TESTED TO DATE

TEXT.P: None of the wild bird dropping samples tested in Taiwan so far this year have tested positive for the presence of the bird flu virus, an official with the Wild Bird Society of Taipei said Sunday.

The Wild Bird Society of Taipei has been commissioned by the government since 1997 to monitor wild or migratory birds visiting Taiwan for the purpose of keeping avian flu and other fowl diseases at bay after 18 people in Hong Kong were infected with the H5N1 strain of the bird flu virus that year, said Ho I-hsien, a quarantine expert with the wild bird society.
During the 1997 bird flu outbreak, six out of the 18 people died as a result of being infected, Ho said, adding that some 1.5 million birds were destroyed to prevent the spread of the disease.
Since 1997, Ho said, the Wild Bird Society of Taipei has each year hired 40 volunteers to collect more than 2,000 wild bird dropping samples islandwide, testing samples three times per month.

This year, the Tamshui Livestock Disease Control Center under the Council of Agriculture has adopted even high standards, with samples being sent to the center for testing four times a month and the annual total being boosted to 3,000 samples.

Liu Hsin-pai, president of the society, called for the Taiwan public to refrain from having direct contact with birds, freeing birds into the wild, purchasing poultry meat of unknown origin, coming into contact with poultry meat, and visiting crowded public places.
Meanwhile, Liu said, people should also get into the habit of washing theirs hands more frequently, as well as receive a flu shot and closely monitor their own health.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO SEIZE OPPORTUNITY TO ENTER CHINA'S CULTURAL MARKET

TEXT.P: As China gradually opens up its cultural market, Taiwan, with its advantages in such areas as creativity and software design, should seize the opportunity to enter that vast market full of potential, the founding president of Fo Guang (Buddha Light) University said in Shanghai Sunday.

Kung Peng-cheng made the remarks at a cross-Taiwan Strait cultural industry development forum attended by more than 50 specialists and officials, including Su Chung, a department director of Taiwan's Council for Cultural Affairs.

Kung said China's cultural market is being opened up, including its printing and retail sectors, adding that for those sectors not yet liberalized, Taiwan could try to break into them by forming joint ventures with Chinese partners.

Taiwan's businesspeople have a chance to enter China's cultural market if they want to develop their own brands or run their businesses independently, he said, noting that the only taboo right now is ideology.
He envisioned a day when China will take a more open attitude toward its cultural industry, at which time Taiwan's cultural businesses may move to China.
"This is nothing to worry about, " he said, citing the example of the U.S. cultural industry within which "publishers do not all operate inside the United States."
He said Taiwan's cultural industry will be able to "keep its own style" when operating in China, as long as it can keep its advantages in creativity, information and software design.

Asked if Taiwan's prospects of making inroads into China's cultural market would be affected by the so-called "de-sinicization" campaign espoused by some people on the island, Kung said that it would pose only a "temporary obstacle" as "people would think for themselves and find a way out."
Those trying to stop Taiwan's cultural industry from "going west" should look at the future from the standpoints of cultural and industrial development, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC REVAMP CRITICAL TO TAIWAN'S FUTURE: FORMER PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Visiting former ROC President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday that economic reinvigoration is critical to Taiwan's future and survival in the face of China's ambition to annex the country.

Addressing more than 2,000 Taiwan expatriates attending a dinner party held in his honor in Los Angeles, Lee said Taiwan's present predicament is due to three factors -- a lack of strong national identity among its people, an ignorance of China's true nature, and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's inability to end the opposition camp's boycott against its policy initiatives at every turn.

Lee, an outspoken advocate of rectifying Taiwan's official title -- the Republic of China -- to substantiate its separate national identity, reminded the DPP administration that if it cannot improve the economy, it won't be able to enhance the Taiwan people's national identity.
Lee, the first Taiwan-born ROC president, said he is worried about the prospects of Taiwan's "native regime" -- referring to the DPP administration -- in the 2008 presidential election.

Quoting forecasts by a Taiwan research institute, Lee said Taiwan's economic growth rate is estimated at a mere 3.5 percent for this year. In terms of Taiwan's economic strength and its past records, Lee said the growth rate should reach 6 percent or 7 percent.
Lee said the DPP administration should make an overall review of its economic development policy and make necessary amendments in order to rev up the sluggish economy.

Touching on China's "magnetic effect" in attracting foreign capital, Lee criticized the DPP administration's replacing his administration's "no haste, be patient" policy on China-bound investments with a "proactive opening, effective management" one. "The DPP administration, while actively liberalizing China-bound investments, fails to effectively manage such activities, resulting in a massive exodus of various Taiwan industries," Lee said.

In the future, Lee said, Taiwan should restrict outbound relocation of high value-added and high-tech industries while investing heavily in "star industries of tomorrow" by integrating optoelectronics, laser and semiconductor technologies.
After five years in power, Lee said, the DPP can no longer claim it is inexperienced in managing the nation's economy.

"The DPP should sort out a new direction for Taiwan's economic development. So long as Taiwan can consolidate its young democracy and revitalize its economy, China would have little chance of annex Taiwan," Lee said.
While China has deployed 700-plus missiles against Taiwan, Lee said he doesn't think that China would launch a large-scale amphibious attack on Taiwan.
"It is most likely to launch a surprise attack on Taiwan similar to the strategy used by Japan in attacking Pearl Harbor during World War II," Lee said.
More worrisome is that China is adopting a "divide-and-conquer" strategy by "colluding" with Taiwan's opposition parties to obstruct the DPP administration's major policy initiatives.

"For instance, the opposition 'pan-blue alliance' has gained an initial success in blocking the passage of an arms procurement package in the legislature, " Lee said, adding that Beijing now is stepping up efforts to tempting Taiwan's legislators and city/county councilors into cooperating with it to sway Taiwan's policy lines.
Lee said China can now even influence Taiwan's news media, citing as proof that major Taiwan media outlets have refrained from giving prominent coverage of his current U.S. visit.
Earlier in the day, Lee delivered a speech on Taiwan's future at a seminar held at the Pasadena Convention Center.

Following the end of the Cold War in the 20th century, Lee said the world is shaping a new order. It is possible that a new cold war may come forth. In his view, Lee said, the tide of democracy should be in favor of Taiwan.

"Taiwan, at the forefront of the fight against China, will face unprecedented challenges and tests. We should carefully monitor international situation, the U.S. global strategy and China's Asia strategy in order to work out feasible countermeasures," Lee said.
Los Angeles is the fourth and last leg of Lee's current two-week U.S. visit which already took him to Anchorage, New York and Washington, D.C. He is scheduled to depart for home Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY EMPLOYEES ASSOCIATION FORMED

TEXT.P: The Education Ministry Employees Association was formed Sunday with more than 1,200 members who will be able to negotiate terms of working conditions and to participate in policy making at the units they are working at.
Of the 1,200 members, more than 300 work at National Taiwan University, over 100 at National Taiwan Normal University, with the rest coming from other national universities and high schools.

Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said, previously, public service employees' rights and duties had been regulated from top down, now the process is reversed. "As long as rights and duties are clearly defined, the association should be a positive force in promoting the ministry's administrative work," he added.

Chu Nan-hsien, director of personnel of the education ministry, said that in addition to the National Teachers' Union, the ministry now has one more "counterpart" group to talk with. He said he hopes the association will forward grass-roots messages to the ministry.

Within 30 days of launching, the association should call a board of directors and supervisors meeting and register itself with the government, following which it will have the power to negotiate and put forward policy proposals to the ministry.

If the negotiations break down, the association can ask for mediation; if mediation also fails, it can ask for a dispute arbitration. Arbitration will be binding on the association as well as the government agencies.

If the arbitration is not honored, the Ministry of Public Service under the Examination Yuan will send the case to the Control Yuan, which is responsible for disciplining rule-breaking public functionaries.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO ADOPT POSITIVE STANCE ON CHINESE OFFICIAL'S VISIT

TEXT.P: An official in charge of national security affairs suggested Sunday that the government adopt a positive stance on a senior Chinese official's proposed visit to Taiwan.
The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, was referring to a planned visit to Taiwan by Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council.

The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday it will invite Chen Yunlin to attend an economic forum to be sponsored by the party and its adversary-turned-partner -- the Communist Party of China (CPC) -- in Taipei in December. If the invitation materializes, Chen Yunlin will be the highest-ranking Chinese official ever to visit Taiwan.

The KMT's announcement came amid a new low ebb in cross-Taiwan Strait relations due to Beijing's opposition to President Chen Shui-bian's decision to name Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to attend the upcoming informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on his behalf.

According to the national security official, there are pros and cons within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to Chen Yunlin's visit. "The government has yet to make a final decision on the issue," he said.
As for his personal opinion, the official said the DPP administration's international image would be tainted if it rejects Chen Yunlin's visa application.
"And if the government accepts his visit, it would bring Taiwan into the limelight in international media coverage and glorify the government's open and liberal image," the official said.

The visit will also enable Chen Yunlin to see for himself Taiwan's pluralistic society in action as both proponents and opponents would definitely swarm to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to welcome or protest Chen his arrival.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS IMPROVEMENT IN CRIME RATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that thanks to police officers' concerted efforts, Taiwan has made progress in lowering crime rate and improving public order.

Chen made the remarks while attending a garden party organized by the Ministry of the Interior at the Presidential Office plaza in down Taipei to promote healthy living and accentuate its determination to crack down on crime and create a safe, secure living environment.

With the arrests of several notorious fugitives in the past year, Chen said Taiwan's crime rate has declined. Nevertheless, he said, the government will not be complacent about its current achievements and will even redouble its efforts to fight criminal activities.

Later in the day, Chen continued his nationwide barnstorming campaign tour to stump for ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidates for the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections for city/county chiefs, city/county councilors and township chiefs.

Chen took advantage of a campaign rally in Taichung County in central Taiwan to criticize an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) advertisement in which the former ruling party "claims to win back Taiwan" in 2008 by winning the year-end elections as the first step.

Claiming that the KMT advertisement depicts Taiwan's current situation in a negative perspective, Chen said Taiwan has actually obtained good ratings in various international surveys, including ranking fifth in the global growth competitiveness and topping the list of government digitalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 24, or the 22nd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1632: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the Dutch microscopist who was the first man to see bacteria, is born.
1648: France and the Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War.
1861: The chief justice of California sends the first U.S. transcontinental telegram from San Francisco to President Abraham Lincoln in Washington.
1901: Ann Edison Taylor, 43, a teacher, is unhurt after going over Niagara Falls in a padded barrel to raise money to help pay her mortgage.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung is opened to traffic. An inauguration ceremony is held at the Taichung Park.
1922: The Irish parliament adopts a constitution for an Irish Free State.
1929: Share prices collapse as nearly 13 million shares change hands in panic selling on the New York Stock Exchange in what became known as "Black Thursday."
1931: Notorious Chicago gangster Al Capone, who has dominated organized crime for the past six years, receives an 11-year sentence and an US$80,000 fine for tax evasion.
1931: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: New Zealand aviator Jean Batten breaks the record by flying from Australia to England in just five days, 18 hours, and 18 minutes.
1944: The Japanese battleship "Musashi," one of the largest ever built, is sunk by U.S. planes during the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
1945: The United Nations Charter, adopted by the San Francisco Conference in June 1945 and ratified by 26 nations, formally comes into force.
1945: Vidkun Quisling, former head of the puppet government established in Norway by the Nazis in 1940, is executed at Akershus Fortress in Oslo.
1957: French fashion designer Christian Dior dies at the age of 52. He was noted for his "New Look" of 1947 that emphasized narrow shoulders, tight waists, and long, full skirts.
1960: Communist China and Mali establish diplomatic ties.
1964: Northern Rhodesia becomes independent from Britain as the Republic of Zambia, with Kenneth Kaunda as president.
1976: Mainland China's Chiang Ching, who was dragged from her bed by armed guards Oct. 6 and charged with treason, finds the going rough now that her late husband Mao Tse-tung is no longer around to protect her.
1986: Cheng Tsai-tien, 26, a communist Chinese pilot, lands his MiG-19 jet fighter in South Korea after flying it from mainland China's Shantung peninsula to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: American television preacher Jim Bakker is sentenced to 45 years in jail and fined US$500,000 for swindling his followers out of millions of dollars.
1990: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes a partial revision of the Corporate Law.
1999: Gerardo Rocha, rector of the University of Santo Tomas in Chile, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The Asian Wheelchair Sports Federation is formally established, with Lai Fu-huan, deputy chairman of the ROC's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, elected as its chairman.
2000: Former ROC Premier Hau Pei-tsun issues a statement expressing regret that three of his former colleagues in the ROC Navy have been impeached by the Control Yuan for their connection with an arms purchase scandal 10 years ago.
2001: The Kaohsiung city government holds a ground-breaking ceremony attended by President Chen Shui-bian for the southern Taiwan city's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system.
2001: The 2001 Taipei Nuclear Insurance Pools Forum opens for a three-day discussion with 31 representatives from 21 national nuclear insurance pools around the world participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman of spirit or a man of moral character will never try to save his life at the expense of his moral character. He would prefer to sacrifice his life in order to save his moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PREFERENTIAL' INTEREST RATES FOR GOVERNMENT RETIREES TO BE CHANGED

TEXT.P: The long-criticized 18 percent preferential interest rate for government retirees will be changed to a "reasonable" level, but not abolished completely as rumors have suggested, Minister of Civil Service Chu Wu-hsien said Monday.
Chu made the announcement at a joint meeting of the Committee of Organic Laws and the Committee of Budget and Final Accounts of the Legislative Yuan.

Chu indicated that the ministry has been reviewing the government retirees pension system since 2001. Despite the fact that the long-term contributions of civil servants, teachers and military personnel to the country should be rewarded, the pension system, which has been criticized as a privilege that has cost tax payers a lot of money, should be reformed, he said.

At the end of August, he reported the planned reform to President Chen Shui-bian, who gave his support to the move, the minister noted, adding the ministry is still working out the details of the reform.

Many of Taiwan's government retirees receive a monthly pension payment and enjoy 18 percent interest on certain amount of their bank deposit, a privilege that has long been criticized by the general public.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, U.S., JAPAN URGED TO WORK TOGETHER FOR REGIONAL SECURITY

TEXT.P: At a time when the Asia-Pacific region is in a fluid state, it is imperative for Taiwan, Japan and the United States to work together to form a triangular dialogue mechanism, President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff said Monday.

"Taiwan is clear about its responsibility as part of the Asia-Pacific region and hopes that the United States, Japan and Taiwan strengthen their integration in the security, political and economic areas to work together to promote peace, security and stability in the region, " Yu Shyi-kun, Presidential Office secretary-general, said during a keynote speech at the opening of a symposium on "U.S.-Japan-Taiwan Strategic Dialogue" at the Westin Taipei Monday.

The geopolitical landscape of the Asia-Pacific region has been changing drastically over the last decade, with new variables popping up one after another, such as the rise of China and India, Taiwan's power transition, South Korea's new strategic position, the end of the Cold War in North Korea, and so on, Yu said.

He cited U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick as having said recently that China "will not necessarily rise peacefully, " and concurred with the high-ranking U.S. official's comment that China will not earn the respect of the international community unless it democratizes and becomes more transparent and takes up more responsibilities in the world.

China is the biggest security challenge to Taiwan, Yu said, adding that the crux of the cross-Taiwan Strait issue is not "independence" versus "unification, " but instead whether the regime in Beijing is willing to end one-party totalitarian rule and whether it will respect the reality of the existence of the 23 million people of Taiwan.
Yu stressed that besides maintaining military and security strength, seeking economic security is the most crucial task for Taiwan at present.

Against this backdrop, he pointed out, working out how to enhance economic cooperation among Japan, Taiwan and United States; helping Taiwan integrate into other economic and regional groupings in the region; and signing U.S.-Taiwan and Taiwan-Japan free trade pacts have become the most pressing missions of the envisaged U.S.-Japan-Taiwan security arrangement.
Yu called for the United States, Japan and Taiwan to accelerate their security, political and economic cooperation.

In security, he suggested that the three sides engage in deeper discussions in several areas, including military training and intelligence information exchanges as well as integration of warfare and military strategies.

In the area of economics, he suggested that the three sides meet and discuss response measures to the impact on the regional economic order of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, the prospective East Asia Summit, and the "ASEAN plus three" process.

As for political cooperation, he suggested that the three sides build mutual trust via institutional systems, discuss the building of a regular, single-track strategic dialogue mechanism or exchange views on whether to help Taiwan integrate into the U.S.-Japan-Australia strategic dialogue mechanism.
The "U.S.-Japan-Taiwan Strategic Dialogue" symposium opened at the Westin Taipei Monday under the sponsorship of the private policy research institute Taiwan Thinktank.

Noted personalities taking part in the two-day symposium include Randall Schriver, formerly a U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian Affairs; Robin Sakoda, a top aide to former U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage; Rupert J.N. Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council: John Tkacik Jr., a research fellow in China policy with the Heritage Foundation; Hisahiko Okazaki, former Japanese ambassador to Thailand; and Sumihiko Kawamura, a retired general with Japan's Defense Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAPABLE OF MASS PRODUCING TAMIFLU WITHIN 3 TO 5 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is capable of beginning mass production of Tamiflu, a drug used to treat influenza, within three to five months at the earliest, a researcher from the National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) said Monday.

Chang Chung-ming, director of NHRI Domestic Research Department, told a public hearing organized by the legislative caucus of the Democratic Progressive Party that it usually takes 15 months to mass produce an new drug.

Claiming that the NHRI had successfully synthesized 20 grams of Tamiflu in a laboratory in 18 days, Chang said the obstacles to the mass production of the drug lie in getting enough shikimic acid, one of the raw materials used to make the drug, and finding pharmaceutical firms with international accreditation to produce it.
With these two problems solved, Chang said, it would be possible to mass produce the drug in three to five months.

In the same hearing, Vice Minister of the Department of Health (DOH) Chen Tsai-ching said the DOH is working on a set of policies to help set up a vaccine producing industry in Taiwan in light of the emergence of a several new contagious diseases in recent years.
According to the policy in the works, Chen said, the government will offer vaccine producers tax breaks, licenses to produce, and guaranteed purchases of their product at set prices, Chen said.

The vice minister also said the DOH is planning to set up a pilot vaccine factory which will transfer technology to local firms in five years to grab a slice of the vaccine production pie which at present is virtually monopolized by foreign producers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFLUENZA VACCINE NOT EFFECTIVE AGAINST AVIAN FLU: HEALTH OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The influenza vaccine currently available on the market can't ward off avian flu which is transmitted through contact with birds, Vice Minister of Department of Health Chen Tsai-ching said Monday.
Noting that growing fears of a possible avian flu pandemic has sent local people scrambling to get flu shots, Chen said the vaccine is useless against the H5N1 strain of the avian flu virus.

The government has for years offered free flu vaccinations to people over the age of 65 and under the age of two and to anyone suffering from a serious disease. However, the flu vaccine is ineffective against bird flu.

Bird flu spreads quickly among poultry partly because of the farming system in which the animals are kept in small enclosed spaces and because of the unhygienic methods used to slaughter the animals, Chen said.
Before these two problems are solved, Chen said, avian flu can hardly be wiped out.

Wall Street Journal: Novel Way to Assess School Competition Stirs Academic Row
