DOC.HEADLINE: 70 MILLION VACCINES FOR POULTRY STORED FOR EMERGENCY: COA HEAD

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture has prepared 70 million doses of avian vaccines to address possible avian influenza outbreaks, council Minister Lee Chin-lung said Monday.

Mandatory vaccinations will be given in a radius of three kilometers of an avian-flu-affected farm or area that is expanding, Lee told lawmakers while giving a report at the Legislative Yuan's Committee of Economics and Energy on the council's measures to prevent and control an avian flu pandemic.
Lee said that the council "has done its best to prepare for the worst." However, he underscored that mandatory vaccinations will not be implemented until an outbreak begins to expand.

Song Hua-tsung, head of the council's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, explained that the cordon vaccinations would be based on common international methods in dealing with pandemic outbreak in animal populations.

Taiwan's poultry industry is worth about NT$25 billion (US$740.96 million) a year. Lee said his council has also organized a series of seminars and lectures as part of its efforts to equip local breeders and relevant business operators with knowledge and know-how in the prevention of an avian flu pandemic.

Lee noted that so far Taiwan is still a non-avian flu country and its poultry is perfectly safe for human consumption. He suggested poultry be cooked at 100 degree Celsius or more for one minute before serving since viruses can be killed at this temperature.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI LINKS' PASSENGERS MAY START SELF-HEALTH MONITORING: DOH

TEXT.P: Passengers entering the Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu from China will probably be asked to start a 10-day, self-health monitoring program, Taiwan's top health official said here Monday.

Department of Health Minister Hou Sheng-mou said that as soon as new cases of humans testing positive for bird flu are reported from China, passengers from the mainland will be asked to start 10 days of self-health monitoring upon their arrival in Kinmen.

Hou, who traveled to Kinmen Sunday and inspected operations of the health department's Center for Disease Control at Kinmen's Shuitou Seaport Monday, said that Kinmen and Matsu, the two frontline islands located nearest the Chinese mainland, are also on the forefront in the battle against epidemics such as avian flu.
Kinmen and Matsu are two ROC islands authorized to engage in direct trade, post and shipping links with Xiamen and Mawei of China's Fujian province, commonly known as the "mini three links."

Since Kinmen and Matsu are so close to China, they are being watched closely after birds were found to have been smuggled from China 10 days ago and were seized in Taichung, central Taiwan that tested positive for H5N1 -- the avian flu strain that poses the greatest threat of mutating into a form that could ignite a human pandemic, Hou said.

Officials from the Council of Agriculture confirmed Oct. 20 that 270 out of some 1,000 smuggled birds discovered hidden aboard a Panama-registered freighter anchored in Taichung Harbor Oct. 14, 19 species of birds, including -- hill mynahs (Gracula religiosa) , black-naped orioles (Oriolus chinensis) and Pekin robins, also known as Chinese nightingales (Leiothrix lutea) -- were assumed to be H5N1 positive, as eight of the birds randomly selected from the three kinds tested H5N1 positive, the officials said, adding that all of the smuggled birds were destroyed by burning.
None of the H5N1-infected birds made it onto Taiwan soil and none of the 40 Taiwan personnel who took part in an operation involving the birds have shown any flu symptoms as of Monday.

The health department's Center for Disease Control, which has implemented temperature-taking measures at Kinmen's Shuitou Seaport since April 2003 after an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , is preparing to make some 14,000 copies of self-health monitoring forms available to the public, according to health department officials.
Currently, passengers from Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia are asked upon arrival in Taiwan to conduct a 10-day self-health monitoring program as part of Taiwan's bird flu-response policy.
Also on Monday, Hou visited Kinmen Hospital, which was upgraded from a county-level hospital to a medical institution under the direct jurisdiction of the health department Oct. 1.
Hou promised to see to it that facilities at Kinmen Hospital are further increased and upgraded to help raise the standards of the hospital's medical services.

Yen Chung-cheng, head of the Kinmen local government, who was also present at the occasion, expressed his hope that services at Kinmen Hospital will continue to be expanded so that the hospital can accord medical services to not just the civilian and military patients from Kinmen alone, but also to Taiwan business people operating in China and patients from China's Fujian province.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN LEADS GROUP TO CHINA FOR TALKS

TEXT.P: A main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) group of think tank members and lawmakers will head for China Tuesday, where they will hold a series of talks with Chinese officials on the protection of Taiwan business interests.
KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, who will lead the group, made the announcement at the KMT headquarters Monday while explaining the group's itinerary at a news conference prior to the trip.

The mission will first visit Yangzhou and Wuxi in Jiangsu province and Shanghai to hold seminars with Taiwan businessmen, while it will take part in working meetings with Chinese officials from the Ministry of Information Industry and the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council late this month in Beijing to exchange views in bettering personal safety, tax incentives and soft loans for Taiwan investors.
Chiang said that they will present some actual problem cases that Taiwan businessmen have encountered in China to find solutions.

In response to questions from reporters that they might be attacked by the pro-independence "pan green" camp, which favors no contact with China, Chiang said that the KMT is willing to do its best to help better take care of China-based Taiwan businessmen because "Taiwan also gets hurt should Taiwan business interests be damaged in China."
China has been the top investment destination for Taiwan, but the many Taiwan investors there have long lacked adequate protection, he pointed out.

KMT Policy Executive Committee Director Tseng Yung-chuan, who returned to Taiwan from China over the weekend after having talks on tourists entering Taiwan with Chinese officials in Beijing, said that the KMT has forged ahead in promoting cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges since former KMT Chairman Lien Chan concluded a landmark "journey of peace" to China from April 26 to May 3.

Evidence can be seen in that China immediately announced its decision to allow Chinese tourists to sightsee in Taiwan the same day shortly prior to Lien's departure for Taiwan on May 3 and that Chinese National Tourism Administration Director Shao Qiwei will visit Taiwan this week to study local tourist spots and facilities, Tseng said.
The KMT also set up a Taiwan businessmen's service center in early August, which is directed by Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PANAMA DIPLOMATIC TIES STABLE: ROC OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Taiwan-Panama diplomatic ties remain stable despite some hearsay and speculation circulating in recent weeks, government officials said Monday.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu reiterated that relations between the two countries are solid, and he called recent media reports that bilateral diplomatic ties could be severed "groundless."

Lu's remarks came after a Panamanian daily newspaper, La Prensa, reported last Friday that a former Panamanian foreign minister and a legislative leader had asked President Martin Torrijos to cut diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

According to the report, their request might have had something to do with President Chen Shui-bian's talks at the summit meeting between the Republic of China and its Central American and Caribbean diplomatic allies held in late September in Nicaragua.

Citing explanations by Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan San Chen, Lu told the Central News Agency that opinions within the Panamanian government have been divided over shifting diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to Beijing and that it is normal in a democratic society that differences sometimes emerge on some issues. It is unnecessary for the outside world to speculate over this issue, Lu quoted Chen as saying.
Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, also said that Taiwan-Panama relations are sound and firm regardless of the speculation and rumors in the media.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR MOTC OFFICIAL RESIGNS OVER TRAIN DERAILMENT

TEXT.P: A department chief at the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) tendered his resignation Monday to take responsibility for a railway reconstruction site accident that caused the derailment of a cargo train between Sungshan and Nankang in Taipei.

Answering questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Communications Committee, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Hsieh Chao-yi, chief of the Railway Reconstruction Bureau, had tendered his resignation orally, and that the resignation will be accepted.
Lin also apologized to railway passengers for the inconvenience the derailment caused them.

The accident occurred at 4: 40 a.m. Monday when the steel wire of a cantilever crane working on the Nankang railway reconstruction project snapped, causing the cantilever to collapse onto the railway's electric wires.

A cargo train that happened to pass the scene at the time derailed, disrupting both north-bound and south-bound train services between the Sungshan district in Taipei City and Shihchih City in Taipei County.
Repair work began immediately but it took about 12 hours for the railway service to return to normal.

The Railway Reconstruction Bureau has been a target of criticism recently because of a number of construction accidents that forced the Taiwan Railway Bureau to alter its train schedule and caused great inconvenience to passengers.

Lin said the Nankang reconstruction project had been halted, pending an overall review of its safety led by his deputy, Ho Nuan-hsuan, who will present a report on the results of the review in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.137 to close at NT$33.770.
A total of US$1.1 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.633 and hit a high of NT$33.800.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved down 23 points to close at 5,712, with 2,0445 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December moved down 29 points to end at 5,707, with 93 contracts traded, while March futures lost 20 points to finish at 5,705, with two contracts traded. June futures moved down 33 points to close at 5,690, with two contracts traded, while September futures moved down five points to close at 5,680, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,735 for November, 5,736 for December, 5,725 for March, 5,723 for June and 5,685 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

November TE futures moved down 0.2 points to close at 238.25, with 3,509 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 0.25 points to finish at 238, with 25 contract transactions. September TE futures moved down 4.75 points to end at 233.1, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

November TF futures lost 9.4 points to finish at 851, with 2,563 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved down 9.2 points to end at 850, with 29 contracts traded. June TF futures moved down six points to close at 850, with one contract transaction, while September TF futures gain one point to finish at 841, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORTATION MINISTER NIXES FREEWAY PRIVATIZATION PLAN

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Telecommunications Lin Ling-san categorically denied news reports Monday that the government is planning to privatize the country's freeways, including the Sun Yat-sen Freeway, by allowing private businesses to take over their operations.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan Transportation and Telecommunications Committee, Lin said that the freeway privatization plan, which was first proposed by an official from the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development two years ago, was simply a "personal idea" and "is unworkable."

Lin said that after looking into the plan, officials from his ministry found it unworkable, for assorted reasons, including that the lands that the Sun Yat-sen Freeway occupy were all acquired from the private sector by the government via a requisition incentive program.
Lin also added that none of the country's freeway systems will be handed over to private operators, at least during his tenure.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MAKES PITCH FOR MINISTERIAL DIALOGUES WITH INDONESIA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made a pitch for the resumption of Taiwan-Indonesia ministerial dialogues to a visiting Indonesian business leader Monday.

Chen told Mohamad Hidayat, chairman of the Indonesian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ICCI) , that bilateral dialogues, especially between economics ministers, will promote the economic and trade exchanges between the two sides to the benefit of both.

During their meeting in Chen's office, The president thanked Jakarta for allowing his plane to stop in Bali to take refugee from Typhoon Longwang in September when Chen was on his way back to Taiwan after a visit to the United Arab Emirates.

The president pointed out that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Indonesia stood at US$6 billion last year, which represented a growth of 35 percent over that of the previous year, and expanded further by 19 percent to reach US$3.3 billion in the first half of this year.

Also, the president said, Taiwan, with an investment of more than US$13.1 billion in more than 1,000 projects in Indonesia, is the fifth-largest foreign investors in that southern Asia country, adding he is sure that more Taiwan businessmen will be attracted to the country as long as Jakarta keeps improving its business environment.
The president also touted his country's aid to Indonesia after the disaster caused by the killer tsunami on Dec. 26, 2004.
Although Taiwan has done its part in aiding Indonesia, the president said, Jakarta still spoke against Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization in Geneva in May to the regret of Taiwan.
Mohamad Hidayat is in Taiwan at the head of an ICCI delegation for a four-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: EFFORTS BEING TAKEN TO BUILD TAIWAN INTO FINANCIAL CENTER: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Building Taiwan into a regional financial center is a key goal, Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday of his administrative efforts.

Hsieh made the remarks while addressing the opening of the 22th Pacific Insurance Conference (PIC) at the Grand Hotel Taipei, which gathered 335 representatives of insurance businesses from 22 countries, including PIC state members, as well as Britain, Switzerland, Egypt, France, Spain and Germany.
The conference will run through Oct. 26.
The PIC, formed in Tokyo in 1958, is an international meeting of private organizations in insurance. Taiwan hosted the conference for the first time in 1991.

Hsieh said that as part of efforts to reach his goal, Taiwan has opened the door to foreign operators of life insurance, while organizing international conferences for foreign businesses to have a glimpse of Taiwan's market and for local businesses to learn from foreign experiences.

The premier also mentioned that in a world where liberalization and globalization are promoted under the World Trade Organization framework, Taiwan's financial insurance sector needs to upgrade itself to sharpen its global competitiveness. He suggested the insurance industry form strategic alliances with other financial sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NT$-RENMINBI EXCHANGE SERVICE ON TAIWAN PROPER AS YET: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: It is premature to talk about implementing new Taiwan dollar-renminbi currency exchange services on Taiwan proper, as a trial service has just recently begun on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Monday.

The government is still assessing the currency exchange service that kicked off early this month on a trial basis on the two Taiwan-controlled islands and no policy adjustments have been made to extend the service to Taiwan proper, Wu said, adding that a final decision must be made jointly by the MAC and National Security Council based on a comprehensive evaluation.

"We have so far not received any instructions from the Executive Yuan about the issue and it is important to closely watch how the service fares on the two islands before making the next move, " Wu said, dismissing a media report that the government has linked the issue to a planned opening to Chinese tourists.

Premier Frank Hsieh said earlier the same day at a financial industry meeting that the currency exchange service may be put in place in Taiwan as long as the trial on Kinmen and Matsu proves successful.

The absence of a currency exchange service between Taiwan and China has resulted in rampant black market trading and increased management difficulties for the government, Hsieh said, pointing out, however, that a service through a government channel will benefit both the government and the public.
For instance, he explained, the public will not have problems with being given fake notes, while the government will be able to earn some extra revenue.
But to make the service possible in Taiwan, the two sides need to first set up a set of currency settlement mechanisms in case of large scale operations, he added.

It was the second time the premier had made remarks about the issue within a week. He first mentioned the issue last Thursday during a breakfast gathering sponsored by the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce with business leaders, in which he promised to seriously consider allowing the practice in Taiwan as soon as possible.
Executive Yuan Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai told a legislative committee that the premier did not spell out a timetable or deadline for the implementation of the service in Taiwan at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES FORMER KRTC VICE CHAIRMAN TO TURN STATE WITNESS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday urged Chen Min-hsien, the former vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) suspected of involvement in the KRTC profiteering scandal, to turn public prosecutors' witness and reveal everything he knows about the case.

KMT Legislator Huang Chao-shun, who heads a KMT task force trying to investigate the KRTC scandal, told reporters that the report issued by a five-member team led by acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan Oct. 21 after a two-week administrative investigation did not touch the core problems of the scandal and appeared to blame Chen for most of the scandal.
Huang alleged that it appears to be a damage control tactic on the part of President Chen Shui-bian to sacrifice Chen Min-hsien and she urged the former KRTC vice chairman to turn state witness.

Chen Min-hsien, chairman of the Southeast Cement Corp., is under judicial investigation for suspected illegal profiteering from the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project and from the hiring of Thai laborers for the construction project. He resigned his post as KRTC vice chairman in September after the irregularities were brought to light by an Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers protesting their maltreatment by the KTRC employers and the Huapan Administration Consultant Co., which managed the workers.

The report issued by the acting Kaohsiung mayor and her team hints that Chen was the "influential figure" behind all KRTC operations. It suggested judicial probes into management of the Thai laborers, open tenders for six civil engineering bids, suspected price rigging in KRTC's premixed concrete procurement, and MRT train carriage door specifications, to determine whether whether any kickbacks or irregularities were involved.

In advertisements placed in three mass-circulation newspapers Monday as a rebuttal to the report, Chen denied that he was the influential figure mentioned in the report and he accused the Kaohsiung city government of using an "untrue" report to add to the disturbance.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO HOLD HEARING ON PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE ORGANIZATIONAL RULES

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold a public hearing on issues regarding the Presidential Office organizational rules, a caucus spokesman said Monday.

The spokesman made the remarks after the caucus held a meeting on the gist of Article 15 of the Presidential Office Organizational Law, which is concerned with the appointment of senior advisers and national policy advisers to the president.
In addition to DPP lawmakers, relevant Presidential Office personnel administrators also attended the meeting.

During the discussion, Legislator Lin Cho-shui suggested that the Presidential Office install a special adviser exclusively in charge of policy coordination between the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan.

Under the Constitution, Lin said, the nation's political system is a semi-presidential one. Therefore, he said, the Presidential Office needs an adviser to take charge of policy coordination with the Executive Yuan to ensure consistency and the practicality of major policy initiatives.
Lin said the ranking of the proposed policy coordination adviser can be equivalent to that of a vice minister.
With a view to soliciting opinions from a broad spectrum of society, the DPP caucus will also invite political scientists and legal experts and scholars to a public hearing on the issue.

The topics to be addressed at the hearing will include whether incumbent senior advisers and national policy advisers should all be unpaid positions. According to existing regulations, the roster includes both paid and unpaid advisers.

DPP Legislator Lin Tai-hua came up with a proposal last week calling for turning all presidential adviser posts into unpaid jobs and said Monday that she will go ahead with her plan to initiate a proposal to cull the budget for all presidential advisers from fiscal 2006.
"Despite differing views among my colleagues, I'll continue to seek endorsements for my proposal," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD SERVE THE GLOBE: FORMER U.S. OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A former U.S. official suggested Monday that Taiwan should make greater efforts diplomatically to tell the international community that it wants to play the role of a member of the global community.

Randall Schriver, former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state in charge of East Asia and Pacific affairs, made the suggestion while giving a speech at a U.S.-Japan-Taiwan Trilogue seminar held by the Taiwan Thinktank in Taipei.
Schriver was invited by the think tank to visit Taiwan for the Oct. 23-25 event.
He said Taiwan should not just set diplomatic goals of increasing the number of its foreign allies or striving for proper treatment for its head of state while visiting foreign countries.

He praised Taiwan's democracy and noted that it is also an ideal shared by the United States. However, he said he hopes Taiwan will avoid making its democracy into nothing but a propaganda slogan and suggested that Taiwan take more concrete action to deepen and consolidate its young democracy.

Schriver also spoke of Taiwan's "unique" political situation, including the inter-party rivalry between the "pan-green camp" headed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the "pan-blue alliance" led by the main opposition Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Wilma Lashes Mexico Resorts. Hurricane Wilma devastated the Yucatan Peninsula and its Riviera Maya resorts for a second day Saturday, dumping as much as 5 feet of rain, ripping roofs off buildings where people had taken shelter, and scraping tons of sand from some of its most popular beaches. At least seven people were killed, but many feared that the death toll would rise.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HAVE MORE WORLD-CLASS THEATERS, CONCERT HALLS

TEXT.P: The government plans to spend NT$17.56 billion (US$520 million) to build more world-class theaters and concert halls in both northern and southern Taiwan, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) announced Monday.

The CEPD said after a meeting that its members approved a proposed amendment to a plan by the Council for Cultural Affairs to build a "Greater Taipei New Theater" in Panchiao, Taipei County, at a cost of NT$8.36 billion and a "Weiwu Camp Arts and Cultural Center" bordering Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County at a cost of NT$9.2 billion.
The funds will come from a special budget under the government's 10 New Major Construction Projects program.
The new facilities are expected to be completed by the end of 2009 and will provide world-class concert halls and theaters, according to a senior official of the Council for Cultural Affairs.

The official said the National Theater and the National Concert Hall near the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei can no longer meet the increasing needs of the public because of their limited capacities and tight schedules.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO ASKS FOREIGN MEDIA TO CORRECT MISLEADING REPORT ABOUT BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) said Monday it has asked British news media to correct misleading reports that a South American parrot infected with the deadly H5N1 strain of avian flu picked up the virus from Taiwanese birds in British quarantine.

"The GIO staff stationed in London have issued clarifications and have asked British news media to publish corrections, " GIO Minister Pasuya Yao said, adding that the GIO will raise the level of its protest if relevant British news media fail to make the demanded corrections.

The British news media quoted British veterinary officials as claiming Sunday that the parrot imported from Suriname had tested positive for H5N1. But with no cases of H5N1 yet discovered in South America, British veterinary experts were quoted as saying they suspected that the parrot was infected when it was exposed to birds from Taiwan while being kept in mandatory quarantine.
Yao said that the British officials were "irresponsible" to make such hypothesis or speculation.
"Our staff in London will push British animal health officials to further check the origins of the infected parrot," Yao said.
Quoting Council of Agriculture (COA) officials, Yao said the birds from Taiwan were held in the same room, but not in the same cage, as the Suriname parrot at British customs.

H5N1 is the most virulent strain of bird flu and has killed more than 60 people in Asia since 2003. Experts are closely watching the disease for fear that it could mutate into a form easily transmitted among humans and cause a pandemic that could kill millions.

Stressing that quarantine and public health agencies are on full alert against the disease, Yao said the GIO has directed its overseas staff to monitor international media reports about the bird flu outbreaks in countries around the world as well as information about foreign governments' preventive and precautionary measures and relevant international cooperative programs.

On Sunday, the Council of Agriculture (COA) discounted the British health officials' speculation that a batch of birds from Taiwan might have passed avian flu to the parrot shipped to Britain when they were quarantined in British customs.

Watson Sung, director of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, said the death of the Suriname parrot has nothing to do with the Taiwanese birds because they were not held in the same cage at the British customs.

Meanwhile, Yeh Ying, the bureau's deputy director, said it is very dangerous and irresponsible for the British officials to make a statement implicating another country as a possible source of avian flu without solid evidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASKS BRITAIN TO CLARIFY AVIAN FLU ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative office in Britain asked the British Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA) Monday to explain why birds from different countries were not quarantined separately.
According to world animal quarantine regulations, birds from different countries should be quarantined at different places.

"We want to know why the batch of birds imported to Britain from Taiwan Sept. 27 were quarantined at the same place as a batch of parrots from Suriname Sept. 16," Lin Yi-hsiung, the Republic of China representative to Britain, said.
Lin said the representative office posed the question in a letter to the DEFRA.

The representative office took the move after British veterinary officials said a parrot imported from Suriname had tested positive for H5N1. But with no cases of H5N1 yet discovered in South America, British veterinary experts said they suspected that the parrot was infected when it was exposed to birds from Taiwan while being kept in mandatory quarantine.
According to ROC government export records, the birds exported to Britain in late September numbered 185. But DEFRA officials put the number at 216.
"We hope to know the exact number and how many Taiwan birds have died in British quarantine, " Lin said. "We ask the DEFRA to furnish us with an official investigation report."

Lin said the representative office told the DEFRA that a batch of H5N1-infected birds smuggled from China and caught at a Taiwan port have all died and that Taiwan's avian flu-free status remains unchanged.

In its letter the DEFRA, the ROC representative office said DEFRA chief veterinarian Debby Reynolds' claim that Taiwan birds might bring the avian flu virus to Britain has hurt Taiwan's international image and dealt a severe blow to its unrelenting efforts upgrade its public health and tourism. The representative office pushed the DEFRA to come up with a detailed report as soon as possible.

Avian flu is a highly infectious virus among both wild and domestic birds. H5N1 is the most virulent strain of bird flu and has killed more than 60 people in Asia since 2003. Experts are closely watching the disease for fear that it could mutate into a form easily transmitted among humans and cause a pandemic that could kill millions. Taiwan's quarantine and public health agencies have been on full alert against the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT RETURNS FROM U.S. VISIT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui returned to Taipei Monday after a two-week U.S. visit that took him to four U.S. cities -- Anchorage, New York, Washington, D.C. and Los Angeles.
Lee said he has taken advantage of his visit to urge the United States to assist in pushing China to move toward democracy.

In the face of China's rise, Lee said, the U.S.-led democratic camp should join forces to help the Chinese people pursue freedom and democracy. "Only be so doing can regional peace be maintained and military threat to Taiwan be eased," he added.
During his visit to Washington, D.C., Lee became the first former ROC president to deliver a speech at Capitol Hill.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCTOBER 25 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, October 25:
09:30, Vice President Annette Lu will visit an exhibition of historical archives and photos featuring Taiwan's development in the wake of World War II at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall's art gallery.
10:00, The Ministry of National Defense will hold a news conference.
10:30, Premier Frank Hsieh will visit a chicken farm in Yangmei, Taoyuan to inspect avia flu-fighting operations there.
10:40, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news briefing.
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will meet with U.S. and Japanese participants to a seminar on Taiwan-U.S.-Japan strategic dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 25, or the 23rd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1825: The Erie Canal, which connects the Great Lakes with New York City via the Hudson River, is opened, assuring the future prosperity of the upper Midwest region of the United States.
1825: Austrian composer Johann Strauss the Younger is born. He is best known for his waltzes, such as the ever-popular "The Blue Danube," and for operettas such as "Die Fledermaus."
1881: Pablo Picasso, Spanish painter, sculptor, graphic artist, ceramist, and designer, is born. He became one of the greatest and most versatile 20th-century artists.
1909: Prince Ito Hirobumi, former Japanese premier and resident-general in Korea, is assassinated by a Korean nationalist.
1914: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China, marries Soong Ching-ling in Tokyo, Japan.
1928: The Republic of China Nationalist government begins to implement the five-yuan system -- Executive Yuan (the Cabinet), Legislative Yuan, Judicial Yuan, Examination Yuan, and Control Yuan.
1936: Leaders from Germany and Italy meet to form the Berlin-Rome Axis, providing mutual assistance and opposition to communism.
1938: Chinese troops evacuate Wuchang and Hankow during the War of Resistance against Japan.
1938: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini formally declares Libya a part of Italy after years of slowly colonizing the country.
1945: Taiwan is formally retroceded to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation. Chen Yi receives the formal surrender of Japanese rulers at a ceremony held at the Chung Shan Hall. The Nationalist government declares Oct. 25 as Taiwan Retrocession Day.
1945: In order to obstruct ROC troops from entering Manchuria, the Soviet Union "voluntarily" pulls out its garrison troops from Yingkow, and allows Chinese communist troops to occupy the city in southern Liaoning Province.
1949: ROC government troops win a victory at Kinmen against a communist Chinese attack.
1950: Beijing launches a movement to resist U.S. aggression and to aid North Korea and Chinese communist "volunteer-troops" formally entering North Korea to join the Korean War.
1951: The Korean conflict truce talks, which began July 10 at Kaesong after Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, acting on instructions from Washington, suggested a meeting between Allied and communist military officers to discuss a truce, are moved to Panmunjom.
1952: The United States blocks communist China's entry into the United Nations for the third year in a row.
1966: The first open school in Taiwan is inaugurated at the Provincial Taipei College of Business.
1976: An eight-member ROC delegation leaves for the United States to attend the first World Conference on Agricultural Education for Youth and Adult Leaders.
1979: Military personnel and civilians on Kinmen celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Kuningtou victory.
1985: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to implement health insurance for farmers.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek returns from the United States for a celebration to mark the centennial anniversary of the birth of the late president.
1988: A comprehensive farmer health insurance plan is initiated in Taiwan.
1996: Israel begins redeployment of its West Bank troops to further a peace deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1999: Former U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger says in Taipei that Taiwan should make its own decisions and the United States has the obligation to help Taiwan with its defense capabilities.
2000: National Science Council Chairman Weng Cheng-i says that the ROC will gradually open its doors wider to mainland Chinese science-technology professionals.
2001: Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue affirms Pope John Paul II's statement regarding past Catholic "errors" in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: OIE AFFIRMS TAIWAN'S MOVE TO NOTIFY ORGANIZATION OF H5N1 CASES
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.c.Tang)

TEXT.P: The World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) on Monday affirmed Taiwan's move to notify the organization that several birds smuggled into the country from China were found to have been infected with the H5N1 strain of the bird flu virus.

The OIE made the affirmation at a time when Taiwan's image has been hit hard by recent international media reports that a parrot exported last week from Suriname to Britain contracted avian flu from the birds that the European country imported from Taiwan.

An OIE spokesman said that as OIE members have no obligation to notify the organization of the number of cases of a particular disease found in animals under quarantine, it was not necessary for Taiwan to inform the OIE of the discovery of the H5N1 infected birds.
However, the spokesman said that Taiwan's decision to notify the organization was certainly in the interests of upgrading transparency in the fight against epidemic diseases.
According to the OIE regulations, any avian flu cases discovered in animals under quarantine are not categorized as "official cases."

Taiwan's Council of Agriculture notified the OIE last Friday of the discovery Oct. 19 of avian flu in several birds smuggled in from China, through Chang Tien-Jye, Taiwan's representative to the organization. Chang is the dean of the College of Veterinary Medicine at National Chung Hsing University.

The British government announced recently that a parrot imported from Suriname died of avian flu during quarantine, saying that the parrot's death could possibly be related to the birds imported from Taiwan which were also put in quarantine in the same place.
The announcement was reported by the international media, leading many in the international community to mistakenly believe that Taiwan is a bird flu-affected area.

Taiwan's Government Information Office (GIO) requested Sunday that the media organizations that made the inaccurate reports should issue notices of correction as soon as possible. GIO Director-General Yao Wen-chih also warned that his office will issue a stronger protest against any media organizations that refuse to do so.
Neither the OIE nor the World Trade Organization's records have shown any official cases of avian flu in birds or humans in Taiwan to date.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 4.03 points to close at 5,721.31.
The bourse opened at 5,796.81 and fluctuated between 5,803.67 and 5,721.31 during trading. A total of 2.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$66.01 billion (US$1.96 billion).

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 0.9 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.8 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 481 to 447, with 210 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN URGES U.S., JAPAN TO CONSIDER SIGNING FTAS WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday urged the United States and Japan to consider signing free trade agreements with Taiwan, saying that only by having such agreements in place can the island's economy stand without heavily depending on China and can security and peace in the Asia-Pacific region be maintained.

The president made the appeal while receiving at the Presidential Office representatives from the United States and Japan who are in Taiwan to take part in the symposium on "U.S.-Taiwan-Japan Strategic Dialogue" being held at the Westin Taipei.

Chen also said that he feels great regret that Taiwan's head of state has been excluded from participating in the non-political economic summit of the Asian-Pacific Economic and Cooperation (APEC) forum in Busan, South Korea Nov. 18-19 as "APEC is an important cooperation mechanism in the region."
According to Chen, even though Taiwan has sent its representatives to take part in the APEC informal summit meeting, Beijing can still veto their participation.
"This is unbelievable since APEC belongs to all of its members rather than China," he added.

Talking about U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick's remarks made in a speech he delivered last month at a U.S. think tank that China should serve as an "interested party" in the international mechanism, the president said that "Taiwan affirms and supports what Zoellick said about the role China should play in the international mechanism."
However, Chen added that China's rise must be peaceful and accompanied by democratic development, saying that only then can China serve as an "interested party" in the international community.

Pointing out that he doesn't want to see Taiwan become the only country not to have an FTA with the United States, the president called for the United States and Japan to consider signing such agreements with Taiwan.

Touching on issues related to cooperation among the three countries, Chen expressed his gratitude for what the United States and Japan did during their Security Consultation Committee meeting held in Washington, D.C. in February of this year to include " issues concerning the Taiwan Strait as one of their common strategic goals.

Concluding the meeting, the U.S. and Japan officials had listed "encouraging the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue" in their join statement as part of their common strategic objectives in the Asia-Pacific region.

"Taiwan appreciates and supports what the United States and Japan did and will fully cooperate with them, " he further said, adding that "it is therefore important for Taiwan to contemplate ways of how to reinforce its cooperation with the United States and Japan in order to establish a normal mechanism of collective security dialogue among the three nations."

Meanwhile, he said that the Anti-Secession Law passed by China in March of this year as well as the European Union's consideration of lifting its ban on arms exports to China go against the common strategic goals of the U.S.-Japan Security Consultation Commitee meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: RANKING FSC OFFICIAL AND 4 OTHERS CHARGED IN INSIDER TRADING CASE

TEXT.P: Prosecution authorities charged former Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) director Lee Chin-cheng and four others Tuesday with leaking official information and insider trading offenses in what the chief prosecutor claimed to be "the foulest" case that he has ever handled.

Lee, former director of the FSC's Examination Bureau, was charged with leaking information to his stock-trader friend Lin Ming-ta and others, enabling them to make illicit profits. Prosecutors have demanded an eight-year prison sentence for Lee in the much-talked-about "Vultures case."

The prosecution also asked the court to sentence Lin, Taiwan Stock Exchange official Chang Hsi-kuan, stock trader Chen Chun-chi and Chen Yung-cheng, chairman of a broker house, to at least one year in jail on charges of violating the stock trading law, illegal use of computers, leaking information, profiteering, and perjury.
The anti-corruption center, which is working with the prosecution in probing the case, has questioned more than 160 people between June and October of this year.

Chief prosecutor Chen Jui-jen said this is the "foulest" case that he has ever witnessed in terms of the "unprecedented complexity of the suspected crime syndicate" and the members' "delicate ways of committing the crime."

He and other prosecutors said it has been extremely difficult to probe the case as the official in charge of maintaining stock trading order was involved and the case has been depicted by the media as intra-bureaucracy fighting between financial inspection and judicial investigation authorities.

The chief suspect in the scandal, Lee Chin-cheng, has been transferred from his director's post to the position of counselor at the FSC since investigations began into his role in the scandal, indicating his "good connections" with the top leadership of the FSC.

The most damning evidence against Lee is that he met with stock traders Lin Ming-ta and Chen Chun-chi 36 times at various restaurants or clubs between Jan. 7 and June 7 this year, 27 of which took place after March 10, when investigators were ready to investigate companies and individuals suspected of involvement in insider trading.

It was during these meetings, according to the prosecution, that Lee leaked critical financial inspection and prosecution investigation information to Lin Ming-ta, reminding him that he had been targeted by investigators.

Lee also allegedly leaked the sensitive information to Kao Nien-yi, a reporter at the United Daily News, on March 15. Kao's article the next day affected the stock price of Power Quotient International (PQI) , a well-known computer flash memory card maker, helping Lin and his cohorts to make NT$13 million in illicit profits.

In its indictment, the prosecution said Lee was supposed to be responsible for creating a clean and fair environment for the nation's securities, banking and insurance industry, but he used his position to help his own friends make illicit profits and to alert them of pending investigations.
Such behavior "has immensely damaged the government's image, " the prosecutors said in the indictment.

FSC spokesman Lin Chung-cheng said, according to law, the FSC cannot dismiss Lee unless he is being detained by police, is wanted for a suspected crime, or has been sentenced to a prison term. "If we were to dismiss him now, we would be violating the law, " the spokesman said.

Although public functionaries are protected by Article Three of the law on disciplining, which the spokesman cited, Article Four of the same law says that if a suspect is involved in "a major criminal case," his superior can suspend the suspect from his official duties.

Article 19 of the law also stipulates that leading suspects whose offenses are to be probed by the Control Yuan or the Public Functionaries Disciplinary Committee should be suspended from their current jobs.
Lee Chin-cheng, as a FSC counselor, has not been making any major decisions concerning financial supervision.

The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) cheered the prosecution and the anti-corruption center for laying the charges, and urged them to charge other suspects as the involvement of more companies in the Stock Vultures case has come to light.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, VIETNAM MARK 10 YEARS OF COOPERATION IN FAMILY PLANNING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) and Vietnam's Commission for Population, Family and Children jointly held a celebration Tuesday in Taipei to mark the 10th anniversary of cooperation between the two countries in a family planning program in Vietnam.
The DOH and the Vietnamese state-run commission signed a memorandum in December 1995 on cooperation on issues concerning family planning and children's welfare.

Since then, Taiwan has invited representatives of Vietnamese government agencies and civil organizations to visit the island every year as part of its efforts to assist the developing country in learning more about effective population control policies.

Addressing the ceremony, Deputy DOH Minister Wang Hsiu-hung said that through long-term efforts, Vietnam has made remarkable achievements in the promotion of family planning. He cited statistics showing that Vietnam's birth rate dropped from 30.04 births per 1,000 population in 1993 to 19.90 in 1999, while the country's population growth declined from 2.1 percent to 1.43 percent during the same period.
In 1999, the United Nations conferred the Population Award on the Vietnamese commission in recognition of its sustained efforts in the areas of population and development, Wang said.

Noting that the number of Vietnamese spouses in Taiwan has been increasing in recent years, Wang said that future Taiwan-Vietnam cooperation will include making efforts to assist the Vietnamese living on the island to adapt to local life.

From this year, the DOH will also organize groups of experts and scholars in family planning and women's and children's health care to pay visits to Vietnam, transferring their knowledge and experience to relevant Vietnamese units through the holding of seminars, Wang added.

During the celebration, the Vietnamese national commission awarded 15 Taiwanese personnel and government agencies for their contributions to Vietnam's population control and child health care efforts. They included former DOH Minister Chang Po-ya and former DOH official Tsai Jung-fu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO PURCHASED KIDD-CLASS DESTROYERS TO ARRIVE IN TAIWAN IN DECEMBER

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CMA) Two of the four Kidd-class destroyers Taiwan has purchased from the United States are expected to arrive in the country in December and to be commissioned at Suao, Ilan in northeastern Taiwan, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman said Tuesday.

In view of a resolution passed by the Legislative Yuan that the names of the new destroyers be related to Taiwan, the warships will be renamed "Keelung," "Suao," "Tsoyin" and "Makung," the spokesman said.

Taiwan purchased the four destroyers at a cost of NT$24 billion in June 2003. Taiwan naval officers and seed instructors, as well as repair and maintenance technicians have received training in the United States to prepare for the vessels' delivery.
Two of the destroyers are expected to be handed over to the ROC Navy on the east coast of the United States at the end of this month. The other two are expected to be handed over in March 2007.
The Navy said it hopes that the four destroyers will form the "outer peripheral" of the fleet, while its Perry-class, Knox-class and Lafayette-class frigates will play an "inner circle role."
The Kidd-class destroyers will be used to target enemy planes that have fired missiles, leaving other vessels to deal with the incoming missiles.

The Taiwan authorities submitted a shopping list in 2001 that included top-of-the-line U.S. Arleigh Burke-class destroyers equipped with the Aegis radar system. However, the Bush administration only approved the sale of the much older Kidd-class destroyers.

The purchase led to a fierce debate in Taiwan. Opponents of the purchase included members of the legislature's powerful defense committee, which made several attempts to block the sale. Critics cited the ships' age -- they were built in the late 1970s -- and their high cost, and suggested that Taiwan should push the U.S. to release the Aegis system sooner.
