DOC.HEADLINE: TRAVELLERS FROM CHINA ASKED TO MONITOR HEALTH FOR 10 DAYS

TEXT.P: In a bid to prevent the spread of avian flu into Taiwan, the Department of Health (DOH) announced Tuesday that travellers from China will be asked to monitor their health conditions for 10 days from the time of their arrival in the country.
The new policy will begin at midnight Tuesday and will affect travellers entering Taiwan from China via Hong Kong, Macau, Kinmen or Matsu, DOH officials said.

Under the policy, travellers displaying flu-like symptoms, such as fever, cough or soar throat, will be asked to fill in a questionnaire and notify airport quarantine staff of their condition. Also, all tourists from China will be requested to check their body temperatures twice a day during a 10-day period. If their temperature exceeds 38 degrees Celsius, they will be required to wear a surgical mask and report to local health authorities, who will assist them in seeking medical treatment.

A similar measure was adopted Oct. 10 for travellers from Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia and Cambodia. China was added to the list after birds smuggled from the country into Taiwan tested positive for the H5N1 strain of the avian flu virus. The H5N1 strain poses the greatest threat of mutating into a form that could trigger a human pandemic.
According to DOH Minister Hou Sheng-mou, the H5N1-infected birds may have come from Fuzhou, Fujian Province.
Although China has not reported any cases of H5N1 infection in humans, Hou said, it is necessary for Taiwan to stay alert in light of Beijing's lack of transparency in its disease control system.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR COMPENSATION FOR LEPROSY SUFFERERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the government should work out measures to compensate and take care of leprosy patients who might have been wrongly quarantined by the previous Kuomintang government.

Chen made the remarks after a Tokyo District Court judge ruled in favor of 25 Taiwan patients who were quarantined during the Japanese rule of Taiwan from 1895 to 1945. The judge said the Taiwan complainants are eligible for compensation from the Japanese authorities
However, according to a CNA report from Tokyo, another judge ruled against 117 Korean plaintiffs making similar claims, so the Japanese government might appeal the ruling on the Taiwanese.

The Public Affairs Department of the Presidential Office said the president was delighted to learn of the favorable ruling for the Taiwan complainants. It added that he had already apologized to the patients and their families.

The president instructed the government to design measures to compensate leprosy patients who continued to suffer from the wrong quarantine policy after the KMT government moved from China to Taiwan in 1949.
The compensation measures should be worked out from the standpoint of protecting human rights and caring for the less privileged, said the president.

Human rights groups in Taiwan, including lawyers working for the interests of leprosy patients, also called on the government to help the patients obtain "normal" treatment, as they have been discriminated against in society owing to the quarantine policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA RECOGNIZES TAIWAN SOY MILK AS 'WELL-KNOWN' TRADEMARK
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Chao Yen and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Yungho Soy Milk, a breakfast chain with more than 80 stores run by two Taiwanese brothers in China's coastal provinces, has been recognized by China's authorities and is expected to enjoy enhanced protection of its intellectual property rights.

Lin Chien-hsiung, president of Yungho Soy Milk's international chain stores, told the CNA Tuesday that the granting of the "well-known trademark" status by the Trademark Bureau under the State Administration for Industry and Commerce is a recognition of his company's reputation and efforts in expanding operations in China in the past decade.
He said that because counterfeiting is still a serious problem in China, his company usually has to fight trademark violations by filing lawsuits in different cities and provinces.

However, he added, after being recognized as a well-known trademark, the company can now take the cases directly to central government authorities, which will order local governments to investigate the violations.

Lin also said he will appeal two cases dismissed by a lower court in Ningbo, Zhejiang Province, involving the infringement of the Yungho Soy Milk trademark. He expressed confidence that armed with the newly recognized status, his company will be able to win the cases.

Soy milk is a popular breakfast drink among Chinese people. Yungho Soybean Milk, with its main store in Yungho, Taipei County, has enjoyed fame for several decades. The breakfast chain has more than 100 stores throughout Taiwan and more than 80 stores in various cities of China.
Besides soy milk, the stores offer a variety of popular snacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR TO CONTINUE SLIDING AGAINST GREENBACK: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar is likely to continue depreciating in the coming months due to eroding investor confidence, as evidenced by capital flight and a lackluster domestic stock market, according to foreign currency dealers.

They said that the local currency could dip to 34 against the U. S. dollar by the end of this year, when the U. S. Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates again, leading to fresh outflows of capital from Asian countries, including Taiwan.
This situation has put stronger pressure on Asian currencies to depreciate, they said, noting that the Japanese yen has already dropped to 116 against the greenback.

Taiwan's sluggish stock market is another factor driving capital out of the country in quest of profits, they said, pointing out that the domestic insurance industry has also sent out large amounts of remittance for investment overseas.

Cheng Cheng-mount, a leading economist at Citibank Taiwan, brushed aside negative sentiments and said that investors don't have to worry about the stock market or the foreign currency exchange as fourth-quarter economic figures will show marked improvements, noting that the final quarter of the year is traditionally a peak season.

According to the latest tallies made public Monday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , foreign orders worth a record high of US$23.78 billion were placed with Taiwan companies in September, up by 21.96 percent year on year. Export orders totaled US$182.5 billion for the January-September period, marking an annual increase of 17.57 percent.
MOEA officials attributed the growth to a weakened new Taiwan dollar and stronger demand for information industry products.

In the face of a sliding new Taiwan dollar, Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan told the business community last week that the value of the local currency should be decided by the market.

The new Taiwan dollar closed at 33.77 against the U. S. unit Monday on the Taipei foreign currency exchange market, a drop of NT$0.137 from last Friday's finish. It regained NT$0.029 Tuesday to end at 33.741.
Although the new Taiwan dollar is expected to continue depreciating for a while, CBC officials claimed that the local currency is relatively stable compared to other major Asian currencies.

For instance, CBC officials said, the local unit was 0.08 percent higher in value against the U. S. dollar Monday compared with the same day the previous year, while the South Korean won and the Japanese yen were up 7.81 by percent and by 7.01 percent, respectively, in value against the greenback.

Meanwhile, the results of a recent survey published by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research show that 57.7 percent of Taiwan companies think that business conditions in the coming six months will remain about the same, while 31.3 percent believe that they will improve, and only 11 percent have a pessimistic outlook.

Echoing the CBC view, the institute said that the new Taiwan dollar will remain stable in value in the short term despite trends showing that the U. S. dollar will get stronger thanks to higher U. S. interest rates and despite the fact that Taiwan's trade surplus for the first nine months was only US$1.94 billion, down by 69.5 percent year on year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY MOST COMPETITIVE IN GREATER CHINA: POLL

TEXT.P: Taipei city is the most competitive metropolis in the Greater China area, according to the results of a survey published Tuesday by the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development of the Republic of China.

The Taiwan largest city won a total score of 70.73 points to gain the first spot, beating Guangzhou with 65.52 points in second, Beijing in third, Hong Kong in fourth and Shanghai in fifth, the survey shows. The top five metropolises were named in the survey as the "leading cities."
Shenzhen, Dongguan, Macau, Taichung city, Hsinchu city and Kaohisung city ranked from sixth to 11th places and were described in the survey as "advantageous cities."

Taipei took the top place thanks to its role as Taiwan's economic, cultural and educational center, according to Lin Chu-chia, an economics professor at National Chengchi University, who was in charge of carrying out the poll.
Taipei is the strongest in terms of "industry and globalization" and "government and construction, " while Dongguan is top in terms of "market and consumption," according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX CUT FOR RICE WINE, LIQUOR UNDECIDED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that it has not been decided if the Cabinet will adjust downwards its tax on rice wine and other liquor.
Hsieh was responding to news reports that the Cabinet is mulling tax cuts to help stem the rampant bootleg rice wine production.
The premier said the government will have to consider if it is feasible to cut taxes for local as well as for imported products under the present World Trade Organization mechanism.

He said that because rice wine currently sells for what the public considers a hefty price, bootleg rice wine making is rampant, while the problem of private rice wine distilleries evading taxes is also serious.
Ministry of Finance officials said they are consulting with the Board of Foreign Trade to ascertain whether or not an adjustment of the taxes will require negotiations under the WTO framework.
The officials also pointed out that even if the tax cut decision is made, it will still need approval from the Legislative Yuan.

In line with the terms for entry to the World Trade Organization in 2002, Taiwan raised the tax on rice wine because it is listed as a distillery product and therefore subject to a high tax bracket. This has driven the price of Taiwanese rice wine from NT$21 per bottle to NT$130.

Winter is traditionally high season for rice wine because it is a major ingredient in many winter stews. Some bootleggers have been selling their rice wine at "extraordinarily low" prices, according to reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MUNICIPAL HOSPITAL CLINICAL RESEARCH CENTER FOR BIOTECH OPENED

TEXT.P: The Taipei Municipal Hospital clinical research center for biotechnology was officially inaugurated Tuesday with the aim of helping the development of Taipei City's biotech industry.
Introducing the new facility, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said the center will allow Taiwan's biotech industrial sector to conduct clinical experiments and to promote research and development.

Around half of the country's biotech businesses are based in Taipei City and Taipei County, while Taipei City accommodates seven medical centers, in addition to the prestigious Academia Sinica and the National Health Research Institute.
With all these facilities, Taipei deserves the title of Taiwan's biotech industrial hub, Ma said.
The biotech industry is one of several business sectors enjoying the government's full development support.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ADVOCATE COMMUNITY BUILDING AT APEC CONFERENCE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan will emphasize the concept of community building at the annual conference of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Busan, South Korea next month, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.
Chen Chung, director of the MOFA's Department for International Affairs, said in a news briefings that the theme of the conference set by the host this year is "Toward One Community."

In order to flesh out the concept of community, Chen said, Taiwan will raise the idea of community building, calling for the involvement of community leaders, not only officials and experts, in APEC activities.
Chen said the conference will begin with a meeting of senior officials from Nov. 12-13.

During this meeting, the officials will discuss ways to support the conclusions of the Doha Round of talks under the World Trade Organization, and take stock of the progress they have made toward the goals spelled out in the Doha Round.
After this meeting, there will be a ministerial-level meeting from Nov. 15-16, and finally an informal summit of economic leaders from Nov. 18-19.

Trade liberalization, counter terrorism and health security are dominant topics on the agenda of the summit, not least the avian flu poised to break out around the world with Asia as its epicenter, Chen said.

The official said the senior official meeting is expected to work out conclusions about precautionary measures against avian flu, which will be submitted to the ministerial meeting and then the informal leadership summit for approval.

As to Taiwan's representative at the summit, the official said MOFA is still working to have Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng attend, even though the host country has already said this would be inappropriate.
Taiwan used to be represented at the summit by a minister responsible for economy before 2000 because of Beijing's refusal to allow the country's head of state to attend in person.
President Chen named Academica Sinica head Lee Yuan-tse as his envoy to the summit in the last three years, and named Wang this year , which drew opposition from Beijing and put Seoul on the spot.

DOC.HEADLINE: POULTRY FARMS TO GET SUBSIDIES FOR NETS AGAINST MIGRATORY BIRDS

TEXT.P: The government will earmark NT$1 billion (US$29.67 million) to subsidize local poultry farms for nets around their facilities to prevent the incursion of migratory birds -- potential carriers of avian flu -- Premier Frank Hsieh announced Tuesday.

Making the announcement during an inspection of a chicken farm in Yangmei, in northern Taoyuan County, Hsieh said Taiwan is one of the few countries that has so far remained free of bird flu infection and must take precautionary measures to block the spread of the disease into the country.
To this end, the government will encourage poultry farms to set up protective nets around their facilities, in addition to continuing to monitor migratory birds, Hsieh said.

Hsieh also urged poultry farmers to improve their sanitation, pointing out that all birds in a farm will be slaughtered if even one is infected with the disease, which will mean great losses for the farmer and the country.

In an attempt to boost the local poultry sector, which has seen chicken prices drop almost 30 percent amid the bird flu scare, the premier said the government is trying to prevent the disease using the highest standards, and he urged the public not to be afraid of eating chicken.
He noted that many countries, including Japan, are importing chicken from Taiwan because they want to avoid the bird flu epidemic areas.
Some foreign media that previously mistakenly pointed the finger at Taiwan as an epidemic area of bird flu have corrected their errors, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO FORM ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party decided in a Central Standing Committee meeting Tuesday to form what it calls an anti-corruption commission.

The anti-graft commission will monitor DPP members serving in major party or public office posts, including the president, the vice president, mayors of special municipalities and city and county chiefs and councilmen, as well as presidential appointees and those who represent the government in state-owned enterprises.

President Chen Shui-bian recently demanded the formation of such a commission in view of the snowballing mass rapid transit profiteering construction scandal in Kaohsiung, hoping to highlight his determination to pursue reforms.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said the commission will be comprised of five to seven members nominated by party chairman. The members -- either professionals who have legal practice experience or those who are highly respected for their clean image -- will be confirmed by DPP Central Standing Committee.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said that if party or public office holders are suspected of being involved in graft, corruption, organized crime or money laundering, the commission will handle their cases and will have the authority to investigate them without consulting the Central Standing Committee first.

The commission can report to the DPP Central Standing Committee after completing its investigation and can suggest the dispensation of a warning, suspension of rights or removal of party membership for violations.

As for an investigation team set up within the party to look into whether Chen Tze-nan, a former deputy secretary-general of the president, is involved in Kaohsiung MRT scandal, Su said the party has put no pressure on the team and that the investigation report will be sent to the Central Standing Committee, although the contents will not be published during the course of the investigation process.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST KAOHSIUNG RESIDENTS STILL CONFIDENT OF MRT SYSTEM: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent of the residents of Kaohsiung who responded to a recent survey still have confidence in the city's mass rapid transit railway project, despite an ongoing judicial investigation into alleged profiteering involving the project, according to the survey results released Tuesday.

The survey was conducted by Taiwan Real Survey Co. Oct. 19-21 at the request of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Kaohsiung city government. The information was obtained from 1,071 respondents with a margin of error of 3 percent.
The survey results show that 86.7 percent of the respondents want the MRT construction to continue, with 69.6 percent saying they will use the system once it is completed.

Almost 50 percent of the respondents believe the profiteering scandal under investigation will affect the safety of the MRT system, but 50.6 percent say they are confident that a thorough examination of the structural safety of the system by a task force will be helpful in enhancing the safety of the network.

The profiteering scandal exposed by an Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers to protest their maltreatment by KRTC and Huapan Administration Consultant Co. has led to the resignations of Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu, acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai, his father Chen Che-nan, who is a national policy adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, and Chen Min-hsien, an adviser to the president.

Both the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice and the Public Prosecutors's Office in Kaohsiung are pursuing the case, probing possible irregularities, including kickbacks, money laundering and exploitation of the Thai laborers.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PASSES NCC BILL

TEXT.P: In a surprising turn of events, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party representatives ceased their physical assaults in the Legislative Yuan Tuesday and allowed the passage of the organic bill of the National Communications Commission (NCC) Tuesday, agreeing that its 13 members will have to go through two ballots by a review committee formed in accordance with proportional representation.
This means the opposition "pan-blue alliance" prevailed, although the DPP legislative caucus said it would consider requesting a constitutional interpretation of the legitimacy of the NCC law.

The legislative caucuses of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), which form the "pan-blue alliance, " declared the bill's passage a "victory of the media, for freedom of speech and for the people."

The "pan-blue alliance" and the "pan-green" camp, which include the DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union, had battled fiercely over the method of selecting NCC members. Legislators of the two sides had engaged in two days of scuffles in the legislature, leading to bloodshed, international ridicule and cries of "shame."

Under the NCC law, 15 members will be nominated by the legislature according to the share of seats held by each political party, and the Executive Yuan will recommend three. The commission's 13 members will be selected from among the 18 nominees by the review committee through open votes.
Successful candidates will be named by the premier, who will send the namelist to the legislature for approval before officially appointing them.

As to the composition of the review committee, its 11 members, all of whom will be professional experts and scholars, will be recommended by political parties again based on proportional representation.

A commission member must win 60 percent or more of the review committee ballots and if fewer than 13 are selected in this way, the shortfall should be made up by those who win over half of the 11 votes in the review committee.

NCC members must not participate in political party activities, work for any other government agency or state-run enterprises, or act as their advisers. They are also banned from taking full-time or part-time jobs at any communications business or lobby group.

Within three years of leaving the NCC, former members cannot serve as a board member or supervisor, manager, or adviser of a profit-making organization whose main business is directly related to the members' area of duties in the five years before he left the NCC.
In these three years, a former NCC member must not contact the institutions in which he or she served in the previous five years either for personal gain or for the benefit of others.
The NCC will make resolutions with a simple majority vote. A member can present a consenting or dissenting view on each resolution. These views, as well as the resolutions, must be published.

As the mandate of the NCC covers a wide range of media and telecommunications businesses that are at present governed by the Government Information Office (GIO) and the Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC) , the two will hand over all related duties to the NCC.

The NCC's mandate includes making, amending, abolishing and implementing telecommunications policies and regulations; supervising the operations of the communication businesses, including approval of operating licenses and checking equipment; mediating in major disputes between rival businesses and protecting consumer interests; promoting international cooperation; meting out punishments; and cracking down on lawbreakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET: NCC LAW EXTREMELY DIFFICULT TO IMPLEMENT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet claimed Tuesday that the National Communications Commission (NCC) law that passed the legislature earlier in the day will be "extremely difficult to implement" and that it will therefore seek "remedial measures."

Cho Jung-tai, spokesman for the Executive Yuan, claimed that the law runs counter to the goal of withdrawing political, partisan and military influences from the media, while the method of selecting NCC members is "regrettable."

He did not say whether the government will seek a Council of Grand Justices constitutional interpretation of the legitimacy of the law but the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus said it will consider doing so.

Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Pasuya Yao said the law contains provisions that could overthrow GIO decisions about radio frequencies and TV channels, provisions that are "unacceptable" to the GIO.

Yao also expressed his dissatisfaction over Article Four of the NCC law, which allows political parties to nominate NCC members as well as members for the review committee that would decide which nominees can sit as NCC members.

Cho explained that in voting for the members, the review committee needs just a simple majority vote in the second round, indicating that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" can dominate the nomination process.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SEEKS TO RENAME RETROCESSION DAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that it is necessary for the people in Taiwan to rethink and review the use of the word "retrocession" to refer to the handover of Taiwan from the Japanese colonial rulers to the Kuomintang-led Republic of China government in 1945.

Chen made the remarks during a reception held in the Taiwan provincial government headquarters in central Nantou County to mark the 60th anniversary of the handover, which is celebrated as Retrocession Day.
According to Chen, to some people in Taiwan, "retrocession" means the beginning of pain and suffering because what followed soon after that were the 228 Incident and the declaration of martial law.

Calling "retrocession" a word that carries specific political implications, Chen said it will be unhelpful to Taiwan's unity and will be against the mainstream value of "Taiwan first" if such a term remains highlighted.

According to Chen, the "true meaning" of Taiwan's retrocession does not lie in the complicated historical relations between Taiwan and China but in the right of the people in Taiwan to be their own masters.
He noted that the people of Taiwan, who supposedly are the most important part of the nation, were repeatedly excluded and dominated by outsiders, making them unable to determine their own destiny.

While the wish of the Taiwan people to determine their own destiny gave momentum in motivating Taiwan's development during the period of Japanese colonial rule, their aspirations for democracy, freedom and self-determination were not achieved after the retrocession, Chen said.
Instead, the foundation of democracy was damaged, and democratic activists were suppressed and persecuted, he pointed out.
He suggested that the people of Taiwan learn from history and interpret the meaning of Retrocession Day anew, using the historical perspective of the Taiwan people.

As there are some people in Taiwan who disagree with the term "retrocession" and cannot accept it emotionally, Taiwan society needs to review the use of the term to define the historical status of the occasion in an objective manner, he said.

He said history interpreted by the past authoritarian rulers does not represent truth and that the people should redefine and reassess historial events in order to mend the rift between the victims and their persecutors.
He said the history of Taiwan belongs to its people and must not be monopolized or interpreted in a one-sided manner by a minority of rulers.
However, he admitted that it will be difficult to find a uniform historical perspective of all 23 million of Taiwan or to shrug off the historical burden left by the past authoritarian rulers.

The president expressed his disapproval of those people who equate Taiwan's retrocession with the restoration of Hong Kong to China, saying these people are celebrating the occasion using the "greater China mentality" and are prepared to give Taiwan away to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL ON COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION SETS STAGE FOR PROTRACTED CONFLICT

TEXT.P: The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan passed a bill on the organization of the national communications commission (NCC) Tuesday, but the controversy surrounding it seemed to be far from over, with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (TSU) and its political ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) refusing to accept it.

Legislator Chao Yung-ching, the DPP legislative caucus whip, said the difference between his party and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) lies in the appointment of the members of the proposed commission.

Under the enacted bill, the 13 members of the commission will be chosen by a panel from 18 candidates--with 15 nominated by political parties in proportion to the number of seats they hold in the legislature, and three by the Executive Yuan.
The panel in charge of picking the commission members will consist of 11 scholars and experts, also appointed by political parties according to the proportional representation model.

The panel must make its choice through a three-fifths vote, but candidates who receive only a simple majority vote from the panel may also serve on the NCC if the number of candidates who won three-fifths of the votes falls short of 13.

Chao said his party insisted on having at least seven commission members selected by a three-fifths vote, but this was rejected by the KMT and PFP, which command a slim majority between them in the legislature.

DPP Legislator Kao Chih-peng branded the bill unconstitutional claiming that it trespasses on the authority of the Executive branch and opens the door for political party leverage on the NCC by giving the legislature the power to name the members.
Kao said the DPP legislative caucus might appeal to the Council of Grand Justices for an annulment of the bill.
The TSU echoed the DPP's position by demanding that the Executive Yuan return the bill to the legislature for reconsideration, threatening a boycott of the Executive Yuan's budget if it does not.
Meanwhile, the bill's sponsor, the KMT and PFP, touted the enactment as a milestone in the country's history, claiming that it offers the best guarantee of freedom of the press.

Jubilant lawmakers of the two parties congratulated the country's journalists in a news conference after the enactment of the bill, claiming that they are now free from meddling by the government, because the government, after being stripped of its authority to grant licenses to broadcast stations and newspapers, is no longer capable of controlling the media.
However, a private self-appointed media-reform group did not share the opposition's joy, claiming that the method of NCC appointment has obviously given politics a role to play.
The group nonetheless praised the political parties for consulting non-partisan groups during the process of the enactment in an attempt to break a political impasse over the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE AMENDMENT TO CUT BENEFITS FOR RETIRED PRESIDENTS

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) introduced legislation Tuesday aimed at drastically reducing the pensions and benefits enjoyed by retired presidents and vice presidents under the existing law.
The amendment proposed by Legislator Tsai Cheng-yuan was endorsed by scores of his colleagues from the legislative caucuses of both the KMT and its ally, the People First Party.
The law has been a target of criticism as it provides for the use of taxpayers' money to pay for lifetime preferential treatment for former presidents and vice presidents.

For example, the government's annual budget for former President Lee Teng-hui, so-called "spiritual leader" of the minor opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, amounts to NT$68.5 million (US$2.03 million) , twice that of former U.S. President Bill Clinton. The pension has an annual 3 percent growth adjusted for inflation.

In addition, retired presidents and vice presidents are entitled to government-provided housing, offices and unspecified numbers of cars, chauffeurs, security guards and office personnel. Lee has six cars, six chauffeurs, eight domestic servants and 60 security personnel.

The amendment would reduce the preferential treatment for retired presidents from lifetime to 10 years, while abolishing the pensions benefits for retired vice presidents completely. It would cut the housing benefit for former presidents and provide him with only one car and one chauffeur, plus two secretaries and two or three security guards.
The amendment would also stipulate that the monthly pension for a retired president should not exceed the monthly salary for the premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEVERS DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH SENEGAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan severed diplomatic ties with Senegal Tuesday.

A spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced the decision hours after Senegal Foreign Minister Cheikh Tidiane Gadio signed a comunique with his Chinese counterpart Li Zhaoxing in Beijing on the resumption of diplomatic ties between their two countries.

The comunique did not say whether Senegal had broken off diplomatic ties with Taiwan but it said Senegal acknowledges Beijing as the sole legitimate ruler of China, of which Taiwan is a part, a claim denied by Taiwan.
Senegal switched its diplomatic allegiance from Beijing to Taipei in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 26, or the 24th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1879: Leon Trotsky, Russian communist leader who, along with Lenin, organized the October Revolution, is born. He was forced into exile by Stalin, sentenced to death in a Soviet court, and murdered in Mexico, where he had found asylum.
1919: Francois Mitterand, French president from 1981, and founder of the French Socialist Party, is born.
1931: Japan turns down a proposal of the Council of the League of Nations which adopted a resolution on Oct. 24 urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: Chinese troops begin a withdrawal from Shanghai to the northern Soochow River after Japanese troops capture Tachang. Shanghai would be captured by the Japanese Nov. 11.
1942: The aircraft carrier USS Hornet is sunk after being attacked by Japanese aircraft in the Solomon Islands Battle.
1944: After three days, the Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines ends with victory for the United States. Over 30 ships are sunk in the great sea battle, most of them Japanese, including the Japanese navy's last four aircraft carriers.
1954: Britain and the United States end their occupation of Trieste and return control of the area to Italy.
1951: Winston Churchill is appointed British prime minister for a second time.
1955: The Republic of South Vietnam is proclaimed under Ngo Dinh Diem.
1961: Outer Mongolia is admitted into the United Nations.
1964: The Republic of China opens a consulate in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
1964: The Republic of China and Panama sign a trade agreement in Panama City.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Belgium as the latter establishes ties with mainland China.
1971: The Republic of China withdraws from the United Nations.
1973: President Richard Nixon prepares for the possible launching of World War III after hearing that the Russians are sending arms to the Middle East as war rages there.
1973: David M. Kennedy, the U.S. ambassador-at-large, arrives in Taipei for a three-day private visit.
1975: The First Taiwan Area Games opens in Kaohsiung with 4,980 athletes participating.
1979: Park Chung Hee, president of South Korea, is slain by Kim Jae Kyu, the head of the Korean intelligence agency.
1989: A China Airlines passenger plane crashes near Taiwan's Siulin Village in Hualien County on its way from Hualien to Taipei, killing 54 people on board.
1993: The ROC and Mexico sign a pact to promote bilateral investment and technology transfers.
1994: Israel and Jordan sign a peace treaty in a ceremony at their mutual border attended by U.S. President Bill Clinton, ending 46 years of hostilities.
1995: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is hospitalized in Moscow after an apparent heart attack, his second in four months.
1999: Nankang Software Park, the largest software manufacturing park in Asia, is opened by President Lee Teng-hui in suburban Taipei.
2000: Former Commander in Chief of the ROC Navy Adm. Yeh Chang-tung claims that he has been falsely accused in an impeachment brought against him by the Control Yuan.
2000: Morris Chang, chairman and chief executive officer of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., urges the government to open up to the mainland Chinese market or face the stifling of Taiwan's industry.
2001: A passenger ship sails from a harbor other than Liaolo directly to mainland China, marking a breakthrough in the "mini three links" implemented by the Republic of China government at the start of 2001 on a trial basis.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sages are of the same species as ourselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. OFFICIAL WELCOMES CHINESE OFFICIAL'S UPCOMING TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Randall Schriver, former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said Wednesday that he is happy to hear that a high-ranking Chinese official will visit Taiwan later this year and will have the chance to feel the air of freedom on the island.
Schriver made the remarks at a breakfast meeting held by the Taiwan Thinktank. Schriver was one the speakers at the Oct. 23-25 U.S.-Japan-Taiwan Trilogue symposium held by the think tank.

He was referring to the expected visit by Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, at the invitation of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang to take part in a cross-Taiwan Strait economic forum scheduled to be held in December.
Schriver said that he appreciates Chen's upcoming visit as it will allow the ranking official to feel the freedom and democracy in Taiwan first-hand.

However, Schriver also expressed concerns that Chen's visit could create division within Taiwan and that the Chinese official will only be exposed to the narrow views of a few instead of the overall views of the Taiwan public.

Meanwhile, John Tkacik Jr., a research fellow in China policy with the Heritage Foundation and one of the participants in the just concluded symposium, said that if Chen visits Taiwan, Taiwan should also request reciprocal treatment and ask that Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, be allowed to visit China.
"Let Taiwan's top China policy charter meet the leader of that country's opposition party to exchange views, " Tkacik said tongue-in-cheek.
He said that unless China agrees to give reciprocal treatment and allow a Taiwan official of the same level as Chen to visit China, Taipei shouldn't approve Chen's application to come to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 3RD IN ASIA IN BUSINESS ENVIRONMENT: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been ranked third in Asia in terms of business environment by the London-based Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU), Premier Frank Hsieh said at a weekly Cabinet meeting Wednesday.
Quoting the EIU's survey, the premier said Taiwan's overall rating has improved from "good" to "excellent."

Hsieh said the rankings are based on the business prospects over the next four to five years of the countries surveyed. He said that Taiwan's overall ranking would be higher if its political environment, ranked 23rd in Aisa, were better.
The premier noted that Taiwan ranked ahead of Japan in the survey, the details of which he didn't reveal.

Instead, he boasted about Taiwan's economic performance in September, saying that exports reached US$2.38 million, marking a single-month record high for the second straight month. He also pointed to the unemployment rate of 4.14 percent, which was lower than the previous month's level as well as that for the same month over the last five years.
Hsieh predicted that the unemployment rate would drop to below 4 percent for this month, which he said would make it lower than the jobless rates in Japan, the United States and Hong Kong.

The premier said that Taiwan, which has pursued balanced development in various economic sectors, has outperformed its neighbors overall, although the island may lag behind some countries in individual sectors.
