DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTS TO COOPERATE WITH BRITAIN IN BIRD FLU BATTLE: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan expects to cooperate with the British government in efforts to prevent a possible avian flu pandemic, Taiwan's representative in the United Kingdom said during an interview with the BBC Tuesday.

During a live interview with BBC Radio, Lin Chun-yi said that the government of Taiwan has attached great importance to public health and epidemic prevention issues and that to date, no cases of avian flu have been reported anywhere in Taiwan.

It is regretful that an official with the British Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA) charged without solid evidence Oct. 23 that imported birds from Taiwan were infected with the deadly H5N1 virus, Lin said.

Lin once again clarified that Taiwan is presently bird flu-free and that DEFRA official's accusation was "groundless, " particularly since DEFRA has not issued any investigation reports on the birds imported from Taiwan.

Lin's representative office in London wrote a letter to DEFRA Monday asking for a clarification after DEFRA chief veterinarian Debby Reynolds claimed Oct. 23 that two parrots imported from Suriname had tested positive for H5N1. With no cases of H5N1 yet discovered in South America, she said that experts from her office suspected that the parrots had been infected when they were exposed to birds from Taiwan while being kept in quarantine.
In the interview, Lin had two questions for DEFRA. Firstly, he asked, how could the Taiwan birds, which arrived in England Sept. 27, have infected the South American parrots, which died Sept. 19.

Secondly, Lin said, the Taiwan birds and the South American birds were kept in separate cages. He said there was no way to tell which birds were infected with H5N1 and which birds infected which other birds.

In Lin's letter to DEFRA, the Taiwan representative also said that DEFRA's claim that the Taiwan birds may have brought the avian flu virus to Britain has hurt Taiwan's international image and dealt a severe blow to its unrelenting efforts to upgrade its public health and tourism.

In the letter, Taiwan officials also asked DEFRA to explain why birds from different countries were not quarantined separately. According to world animal quarantine regulations, birds from different countries should be quarantined at different places.

"We want to know why the batch of birds imported to Britain from Taiwan Sept. 27 were quarantined at the same place as a batch of parrots from Suriname Sept. 16, " the letter said. According to ROC government export records, the birds exported to Britain in late September numbered 185. But DEFRA officials put the number at 216.
"We hope to know the exact number and how many Taiwan birds have died in British quarantine, " Lin said. "We ask DEFRA to furnish us with an official investigation report." Lin added.

Lin stressed in the interview with BBC Radio that his office has told the DEFRA that a batch of H5N1-infected birds smuggled from China and seized at a Taiwan port have all died and that Taiwan's avian flu-free status remains unchanged.

He added that under a stepped-up avian flu-response policy, Taiwan has asked passengers entering the country from China, Hong Kong and Macau to conduct a 10-day self-health monitoring program, including daily temperature taking, after arrival.
He said that it is indeed a challenge trying to keep avian flu from China out of Taiwan as increasing numbers of bird flu cases have been reported in China and as Taiwan lies so close to China.

Lin also emphasized Taiwan's difficulties in obtaining access to avian flu prevention and other medical information in the absence of membership in the World Health Organization, particularly at a time when fears have been growing around the world of a possible bird flu pandemic.

Avian flu is highly infectious among both wild and domestic birds. H5N1 is the most virulent strain of bird flu. It has killed more than 60 people in Asia since 2003. Experts fear the H5N1 strain could mutate into one that is easily transmittable among humans which could spark a global pandemic.
Lin's BBC Radio interview marked the second time in two days that he made Taiwan's stance clear to British media. He was interviewed by BBC's Asia Today a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA HEAD ASKS FOR 1 YEAR TO PROVE HE CAN DO THE JOB

TEXT.P: New Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Lee Ying-yuan on Wednesday asked for one year to prove he can do the job, saying that he will step down if opinion surveys on local laborers at that time reveal that they think he is unfit for the post.
Lee, who served as secretary-general of the Executive Yuan before assuming his current post last month, made the remarks while reporting on the CLA's plans and budget for the next fiscal year.

Legislator Ho Tsai-feng of the opposition Kuomintang questioned him about his announcement to relax restrictions on hiring foreign caregivers, asking if he is the head of local laborers or foreign laborers.
Lee responded by saying that "everything I do is based on the principle of promoting the employment of local laborers."
He said that his labor policy will stand up to local laborers' review, adding that if his policy results in higher unemployment, he will step down.

Lee announced earlier this month that the council will scrap the strict Barthel index used to determine whether a local family can hire a foreign caregiver. The Barthel index assesses the degree of disability in a particular individual. From now on, certificates issued by medical authorities will be used, Lee said.

Hopefully, he said the new review system will be put into place as soon as possible to remedy the situation of people with seriously ill family members having to cajole doctors into fudging medical reports so that they can qualify to employ a foreign caregiver.

In addition, the CLA will provide training to local people wishing to be caregivers and advertise for local workers when the need arises. The council is also studying the feasibility of subsidizing locals wishing to hire Taiwanese to work as caregivers to cover the difference in cost between employing local caregivers and employing foreign ones.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINTAINING SHARPNESS CHALLENGE FOR IC ASSEMBLY, TEST INDUSTRYBy Elizabeth Hsu CNA Staff Reporter

TEXT.P: Taiwan semiconductor companies in the field of back-end packaging and testing are under double pressure in maintaining their world's leading position in the industry, facing a growing demand for improved technology while a rising China threatens to seize global market share.

The packaging and testing industry plays a key role in back-end semiconductor manufacture. With improving technologies pushing the front-end silicon wafer manufacturing process from 0.25 micrometers to 90 nanometers and even to 60nm and 45nm, the sector in Taiwan is also faced with the challenge of technological improvement.

It is already essential for companies that do not want to be knocked out of the business to overcome their technological barriers and take advantage of the demand for "fine pitch" packaging services from leading wafer fabricators.
The existence and market prospects of the packaging and test sector -- an indispensable back-end semiconductor manufacture process -- is closely bound up with integrated circuit (IC) production.

According to statistics compiled in the Industrial Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS) program of the Department of Industrial Technology under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the output value of Taiwan's IC industry broke the NT$1 trillion (US$30.09 billion) mark to reach NT$1.99 trillion in 2004, representing growth of 34.2 percent over the previous year.

Some NT$156.5 billion of that amount was the output value of the IC assembly industry, while NT$57.7 billion was from the test sector. The two figures recorded year-on-year growth of 33 percent and 41 percent, respectively.

It has been assessed that the output value of Taiwan's IC manufacturing industry will surge to NT$1.279 trillion in 2005, while that of the packaging sector will rise to NT$178.1 billion at an expected annual growth rate of 13.8 percent, and that of the test sector will increase to NT$67 billion at a growth rate of 16 percent.

Historically, semiconductor companies designed, manufactured, packaged and tested IC chips in their own integrated device manufacture (IDM) facilities. As the industry expands under strong market demand, a trend is also growing for these companies to outsource stages of the manufacturing process, enabling them to focus on their core competencies such as design and integration, and meet increasing demand.

After development of nearly two decades, a complete up-mid-down stream of supply chain system was formed in Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturing industry. However, in the economic recession between 2000 and 2001, a large-scale company reshuffle occurred in the back-end packaging and test market, during which weak companies were either integrated or bought out by foreign or domestic enterprises.

Thus, professional and international IC assembly and test service providers emerged. The Kaohsiung-headquartered Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc. (ASE) replaced the U.S.-based Amkor Technology Inc. to become the world's largest supplier of outsourced semiconductor interconnect services in 2003. It has contracts with over 200 IDM and fabless factories from around the world, including Motorola, IBM, ATI, 3DFX, nVidia and AMD.

Taiwan's second-largest company dedicated to IC design, assembly and testing -- Siliconware Precision Industries Co. Ltd. (SPIL) -- trailed behind with revenue surpassing US$1 billion in 2003 for the first time since its establishment.

Meanwhile, thanks to fast expansion of the industry in the manufacture of thin film transistor-liquid crystal displays (TFT-LCDs) , the demand for driver ICs has surged in the past few years, leading to a boom in orders for driver IC packaging and test services. Driver ICs are one of basic key components of LCD displays.

It has been assessed that Taiwan's leading suppliers of driver IC packaging and test services, including Chipmos Technologies Inc., International Semiconductor Technology Ltd., Chipbond Corp. and SPIL, will cover more than 60 percent of global demand for some 2.2 billion large panel-used driver ICs this year.

With international IDM giants and semiconductor makers forced to outsource back-end lines to preserve their core competitiveness due to the evolution of the semiconductor manufacturing process toward the more sophisticated and delicate "nano" level, a market worth billions of US dollars exists for Taiwanese providers of packaging and test services.

According to corporate statistics, in 2004, the global market for semiconductor test and packaging services was worth approximately US$350 billion. Around 40.4 percent of the market was taken by professional packaging and test companies, representing a growth of 6 percentage points over the previous year. The ratio is expected to surge to 44.4 percent in 2006 and 46.2 percent in 2007.
Like the front-end manufacturers, the back-end businesses have also been seeking high-end and environmentally friendly lead-free packaging technologies to keep their clients.

However, for domestic providers of test and packaging services, their common concerns are not over the technological challenges but the government, which bans the sector from investing in China -- one of the world's largest economies.

A corporate source said local companies are worried that if they do not mark their territories in the Chinese market now, they will never be able to do so once China builds its own test and packaging lines for semiconductor products.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS DOH TO SET UP BIRD FLU INFORMATION CENTER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh ordered the Department of Health (DOH) on Wednesday to set up an information center to provide the media with accurate and updated news related to any avian flu outbreaks at home or abroad to avoid public panic.

Giving the directive during a weekly Cabinet meeting, Hsieh said that bird flu outbreaks are a global problem and that the public can easily be scared by the daily media reports on the issue, especially when the information is confused.

As an example, Hsieh pointed out that British authorities recently said they suspected a Suriname-imported parrot infected with the H5N1 strain of the bird flu virus picked up the virus from Taiwanese birds in British quarantine and that the misleading information was widely reported by international media, including AFP and BBC.

While the birds from Taiwan were determined by quarantine authorities to be healthy before they were exported to Britain, there was no evidence showing the sick parrot contracted the virus from the Taiwan birds, Hsieh said.
These media organizations have made corrections at Taiwan's request, Hsieh added.
According to Hsieh, if Taiwan becomes a bird flu-affected area, this will affect Taiwan's exports and image and undermine its interests.
Meanwhile, the premier instructed the DOH to prepare pamphlets to provide the public with basic knowledge about bird flu and to instruct them on how to monitor their own health condition.

He urged the people to take proper precautionary measures against bird flu and to avoid visiting China, saying that Beijing has failed to be transparent in its battle against bird flu outbreaks which have been reported in several Chinese provinces.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS OFFER TO TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR SEVERANCE OF RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Both top foreign affairs and security officials offered Wednesday to take responsibility for the severance of formal diplomatic ties between Taiwan and the West African nation of Senegal earlier in the day.
Reporting at a Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee meeting, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said the severance of Taiwan-Senegal diplomatic relations makes his "heart ache."
"There are many areas that need to be reviewed, and I'm largely to blame," Chen added.
Chen stressed that he is fully prepared to step down anytime to take responsibility.

Senegalese Foreign Minister Cheikh Tidiane Gadio signed a communique with his Chinese counterpart Li Zhaoxing in Beijing Tuesday on the resumption of diplomatic ties between their two countries. Senegal switched its diplomatic recognition from Beijing to Taipei in 1996.

The communique did not reveal whether Senegal had broken off diplomatic ties with Taiwan, but it did state that Senegal acknowledges Beijing as the sole legitimate ruler of China, of which Taiwan is a part, a claim which Taiwan rejects.

Commenting on the notion expressed by the Senegalese government recently that "there are no friends, only interests, in the international community, " Chen said that in the past, there were often many rumors about an imminent breaking off of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Senegal but that they all proved in the end to be "erroneous."
This time around, however, the rumors proved to be true, Chen said, claiming that his ministry was "fooled, " rather than "being slow" in grasping related developments.

Meanwhile, Hsueh Shih-min, director of the National Security Bureau, also offered Wednesday to take responsibility for the severance of relations, saying at the Legislative Yuan that his bureau failed to grasp the significance of related intelligence information in time.

Hsueh made the offer after Premier Frank Hsieh said earlier in the day that relevant government agencies should look into whether their efforts in gathering intelligence information regarding diplomatic ties need to be reinforced.

Hsueh said that the National Security Bureau had always issued warnings in previous years whenever it discovered negative signs regarding the state of Taiwan-Senegal diplomatic relations, and that all the warnings were heeded and used to remedy the situation.
This time around, however, Hsueh said, his bureau failed to detect negative signs early enough to issue any warnings.
"I will take responsibility for the failure and do not hesitate in seeing other lower-ranking foreign affairs and security officials also disciplined if required," he said.
He added that the information his office has gathered to date does not indicate that the severance of Taiwan-Senegal diplomatic ties will cause a "domino effect."

He admitted that in the face of Beijing's "stepped up 'dollar diplomacy' schemes, " Taiwan is having an increasingly difficult time in maintaining normal ties with its diplomatic allies, now numbering 25 in total following the severance of formal ties with Senegal.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange dropped Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 20.59 points to close at 5,700.72.
The bourse opened at 5,731.87 and fluctuated between 5,739.94 and 5,672.89 during trading. A total of 2.87 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$73.04 billion (US$2.16 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial issues moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 1.1 percent, textile stocks at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent.

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.6 percent, and paper and pulp stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 801 to 207, with 140 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Bush Picks Successor to Fed Chief Greenspan. President Bush on Monday dashed ahead of his own timetable for naming a successor to Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, picking former university economist Ben S. Bernanke to head the nation's central bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: House of Deputies OKs university reform bill.
Among the protest from a large number of professors, students and researchers in front of the parliament, the House of Deputies approved Tuesday a bill on university reforms introduced by Minister of Education Letizia Moratti. The minister said that the reforms will help rise the academic level of Italian universities to that of the advanced nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST BATCH OF CARRIAGES FOR KAOHSIUNG MRT SYSTEM ARRIVE

TEXT.P: The first batch of train carriages purchased by the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) for the southern port city's mass rapid transit system arrived at Kaohsiung Harbor Wednesday.

KRTC President Fan Chen-po led company officials to burn incense and pray for smooth operations according to local tradition upon the arrival at the harbor of the cargo ship "Monrovia" of the Orient Overseas Container Line carrying the six train carriages.
Kaohsiung City Government's Department of Rapid Transit System Director Lee Cheng-pin expressed the hope that the carriages will provide comfort, safety and quality rides to all citizens.

The train carriages were built by Siemens in Vienna, Austria at the end of May and then sent to Germany for a series of tests. The "Monrovia" set sail from Bremer, Germany with the carriages at the end of September.
Each carriage weighs 40 tons and is 21.9 meters long and 3.1 meters wide. Each has 126 seats and standing room for another 250 passengers.
The carriages will undergo a series tests at the end of this year.

The KRTC is scheduled to take delivery of six train carriages every month until next October, and then nine train carriages every month from November 2006. A total of 126 carriages, or 42 complete trains, will be delivered.

Construction on Kaohsiung's MRT system began in October 2001. Service on part of the system's Red Line is scheduled to begin in October 2006. The system's Red Line and Orange Line are expected to be fully operational by the end of 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved down 14 points to close at 5,704, with 30,395 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December dropped 21 points to end at 5,704, with 256 contracts traded, while March futures lost 35 points to finish at 5,695, with three contracts traded.
June futures moved down 35 points to close at 5,695, with two contracts traded, while September futures rose 27 points to close at 5,695, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,718 for November, 5,725 for December, 5,730 for March, 5,730 for June and 5,668 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
November TE futures moved down 2.60 points to close at 235.40, with 5,984 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 2.30 points to finish at 235.95, with 34 contract transactions.
March TE futures dropped 2.10 points to close at 235.85, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures rose 9.4 points to finish at 865.4, with 3,142 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved up 8.0 points to end at 864.0, with 21 contracts traded.
March TF futures moved up 12.6 points to close at 869.2, with four contract transactions, while September TF futures rose 12.6 points to close at 854.6, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.081 to close at NT$33.66.
A total of US$829 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$33.741 and hit a low of NT$33.625.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH HOLY SEE 'IN SOME DANGER:' FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's diplomatic ties with the Holy See are "in a bit of danger, " Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen admitted at the Legislative Yuan Wednesday.

In response to wire service reports earlier the same day that the Holy See is interested in resuming diplomatic relations with Beijing if the latter agrees to its terms, Chen told lawmakers that his ministry understands that Pope Benedict XVI is eager to start dialogue with Beijing.

Chen said Taiwan's ambassador to the Vatican "has been watchful everyday for any signs of a worsening in bilateral ties" and is aware that the pope is interested in forging diplomatic relations with Beijing.
Taiwan's diplomats in the Vatican are so concerned about the issue that "some of them can't sleep well at night, " the minister said.

Chen, however, refused to speculate on when a re-establishment of formal ties between China and the Vatican might occur, saying only that Taiwan's diplomats will do their best to dissuade the Vatican from hurting Taiwan while reaching out to Beijing and to keep Taiwan-Vatican ties intact for as long as possible.
The media reports came one day after Taiwan severed diplomatic relations with Senegal. On Tuesday, Senegal re-established diplomatic ties with Beijing.

When opposition lawmakers asked Chen whether he should resign to take responsibility for the end of formal diplomatic relations with Senegal, Chen said that he hasn't offered to do so but is "ready to step down at anytime."

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH DEPARTMENT PROMOTES SMOKE-FREE WORKPLACES

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) unveiled Wednesday a plan to promote smoke-free workplaces which is aimed at reducing non-smokers' exposure to second-hand smoke by 10 percent in five years.

According to a survey conducted by the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion, five million workers in Taiwan, or 25 percent of the country's total workforce, are smokers, with male white-collar workers accounting for 37 percent, male blue-collar workers accounting 46 percent, and female workers accounting for 5 percent to 6 percent.
However, most workplaces have not designated smoking zones to protect non-smokers from exposure to second-hand smoke.

The survey shows that 75 percent of the workers work in places that are not regulated by the Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act. Only 13.8 percent of workplaces are required by law to be non-smoking, while only 10.4 percent are required to set up smoking zones.

A total of 36.8 percent of the respondents said they smell smoke at their workplaces often or everyday, and 47.5 percent said they smell smoke occasionally. Only 15.8 percent said they are not exposed to second-hand smoke.

Su Hsin-yu, an official at the bureau's Community Health Division, pointed out that the Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act has very limited bonding effect on private workplaces and that unless company owners take the initiative to adopt a smoke-free policy, it will be difficult to reduce tobacco hazards in workplaces.

For example, Su said, Japan has banned smoking within three meters of office buildings to protect the right of non-smokers, and the Taipei City Government has also forbidden police officers from smoking while on duty.
Meanwhile, 50 percent of workers surveyed last year expressed their support for banning smoking at workplaces, Su noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL NOT BE ABSENT FROM APEC LEADERSHIP SUMMIT: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not be absent from the informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Busan, South Korea next month, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Wednesday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Chen said that the government is still making arrangements for Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to attend the Busan summit as President Chen Shui-bian has appointed Wang as his proxy for the meeting.
Taiwan will not be absent from the summit even if all of its efforts to have Wang attend the meeting fail due to Beijing's obstruction, the foreign minister said.
Beijing has said that it is opposed to Wang's attendance as he is not an official in charge of APEC-related affairs.

Chen made the remarks after opposition Kuomintang Legislator John Chiang called for President Chen to make sure someone attends the summit on his behalf to represent Taiwan. Chiang said that the Legislative Yuan will file for impeachment of President Chen for not protecting Taiwan's national interests if he fails to have someone attend the summit.
Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party echoed his colleague's calls, saying that Taiwan should not be absent from the APEC summit like it was in 2001.

Taiwan should strive to have a representative at the meeting even in the face of Beijing's strong opposition, Hsiao stressed, adding that Taiwan's absence from the summit is not acceptable to the Legislative Yuan.

In 2001, President Chen appointed former Vice President Li Yuan-zu to represent him at the informal leadership summit in Shanghai that year. Because of Beijing's refusal to accept Li as Chen's representative, Taiwan was absent from the two-day summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 'HOODWINKED' BY SENEGAL: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen admitted Wednesday that Taiwan had been "hoodwinked" by Senegal, an African ally that announced the establishment of diplomatic relations with China Tuesday without informing Taiwan in advance.
Five hours after Senegal's announcement, Taipei said it was terminating all aid programs to the African country.

In the face of mounting criticism from the legislative floor, Chen said Senegal had repeatedly reassured him that "there would be no such thing (as a severing of ties with Taiwan in favor of China)," and that "economics is one thing, while politics is another."
"Yes, this time we have been hoodwinked," Chen said.
Noting that Senegal's move could create a domino effect, Chen said he has instructed Taiwan's diplomats to beef up communications with the nation's allies.

In response to lawmakers jeering that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs was "the last to know" of Senegal's move to establish diplomatic ties with China, Chen said there are indeed many things that his ministry could improve on, "and certainly I must take a big share of the responsibility."
He said that if anybody in the government resigns over the diplomatic failure, "I myself will quit," and not the director of the Department of African Affairs, Lee Chen-hsiung.

Lee acknowledged that it had been "rather difficult to maintain ties with Senegal over the past few years," and whenever an emergency occurred in bilateral relations, "a lot of manpower and resources had to be mobilized" to maintain the formal ties which were established in 1996.

Just recently, Senegalese officials were visiting Taiwan, and whenever Taiwan officials tried to confirm whether Senegal and China were planning to establish formal ties, the Senegalese would say "no such thing," Lee claimed.

Deputy Foreign Minister Huang Lung-yuan said that under pressure from and allured by China, Senegal announced the re-establishment of diplomatic ties with China at 5: 30 p.m. Tuesday Taipei time. His ministry ended all aid programs to Senegal hours later.

Huang briefed Premier Frank Hsieh on the latest diplomatic setback Wednesday morning. Hsieh commented that the ministry should investigate and review why it did not have any "good information" and thus failed to gain any prior knowledge of Senegal's move.
At the legislature's Foreign Affairs Committee, one legislator after another lashed out at the ruling party and the government for being cheated by Senegal.

"Senegal is the first country that President Chen Shui-bian visited during his African tour, and he openly claimed that no allies he has visited have severed ties with Taiwan, " Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lai Shyh-bao said.

Since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) came to power in 2000, the foreign ministry has accumulated US$130 million (NT$4.1 billion) in debt -- presumably gone into secret aid to Third World allies, and "that makes people feel hurt," Lai said.

Legislator John Chiang, also of the KMT and a former foreign minister, expressed concerns that if the government does not change its policy, the total number of Taiwan's diplomatic allies could fall to below 20 by 2008. The figure currently stands at 25 following the severance of ties with Senegal. "Dollar diplomacy won't work, " he said.

Meanwhile, Legislator Bi-kim Hsiao of DPP said she does not think Minister Chen should step down for losing an important African ally, but added that his ministry must make improvements in its information gathering.

Legislator Tsai Tung-jung of the DPP said that compared with the KMT government, which on average lost one diplomatic ally per year, the DPP government has lost only four allies in over five years, adding that it "deserves a citation."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIRDS EXPORTED TO U.K. TESTED NEGATIVE FOR BIRD FLU VIRUS: COA

TEXT.P: The nation's top agriculture official reaffirmed Wednesday that the Taiwan birds exported to Britain tested negative for the avian flu virus, saying the results have been relayed to Taiwan's overseas missions to clear the island's name.

Lee Chin-lung, chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA), made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan in the wake of reports that an official with the British Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA) had claimed that imported birds from Taiwan were infected with the deadly H5N1 strain of the bird flu virus.

Lee noted that the DEFRA official claimed Oct. 23 that two parrots imported from Suriname had tested positive for H5N1. With no cases of H5N1 yet discovered in South America, the official said that experts suspected that the parrots had been infected when they were exposed to birds from Taiwan while being kept in quarantine. It was discovered later that the Taiwan birds arrived in England Sept. 27, more than a week after the South American parrots died.
Lee said that the COA sent experts to the farm that exported the Taiwan birds to collect specimens Tuesday and that the results of the tests were negative.

The COA has supplied information related to the number, category, and quarantine certificate of the Taiwan birds to the representative office in Britain to show that they were exported after meeting the quarantine requirements of the British side, Sung Hua-tsung, director of COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, said Wednesday.

Meanwhile, Lee said that he has full confidence about preventing avian flu from spreading to Taiwan, adding that the nation will nevertheless make the "best possible preparations to deal with a worst case scenario."

Lee noted that an international risk rating company has assessed that Japan, Australia and Taiwan have been the best Asian countries in terms of quarantine controls, adding that Taiwan has maintained its bird flu-free status for years.

Sung also said that the COA has asked the Coast Guard Administration and customs officials to step up their efforts against smuggling to stop birds from avian flu-affected areas from making their way into Taiwan.

In addition, the COA has asked wild bird societies to step up monitoring of bird droppings in 10 wetland areas as part of efforts to prevent the spread of bird flu to Taiwan via migratory birds. The number of specimens being tested has been increased from 2,000 per year to 3,000 per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VICE MINISTER TO VISIT PANAMA THIS WEEK
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Panama government announced Tuesday that Republic of China Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long will visit the Central American country later this week.

Heading an economic delegation, Chen is expected to meet Gisela Vergara, Panamanian vice minister of commerce and industry in charge of foreign trade, to exchange views on ways to strengthen bilateral trade within the framework of the free trade agreement (FTA) signed by the two countries, according to a press release from Panama's Ministry of Commerce and Industry.

Since the Taiwan-Panama FTA took effect Jan. 1, 2004, bilateral trade has increased drastically and Panamanian entrepreneurs have great expectations on trade with Taiwan, prompting them to ask their government to negotiate with Taiwan in order to increase the products that can benefit from the FTA.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CRACK KIDNAP FRAUD RING

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau of the National Police Administration announced Wednesday that it had cracked a fraud ring that had tried to extort ransom payments from victims by telling them via mobile phone that their relatives on overseas trips had been kidnapped.

The bureau began investigating the case only six days ago after learning from news reports that the mother of a professor at a private university was so shocked by two phone calls from the fraud ring in August about the kidnap of her son during his visit to the United Kingdom that she died from a stroke.
In one of the phone calls, the fraudsters threatened the 60-year-old woman that if she did not pay them NT$500,000 her son would be killed.
Police detectives working on the case screened mobile phone companies' records of more than 37,000 suspected phone calls from China and nailed an 11-member ring based in Hsinchu County.
By the time the ringleader, Lo Chih-hua, was found to be the mastermind behind the case, he had already been arrested for other fraud cases.

The 11 men have been referred to the Public Prosecutors' Office in Hsinchu on charges of a type of fraud that has plagued Taiwan cellular phone subscribers for many months, with little police progress.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER LASHES OUT AT UNIVERSITY STUDENTS' POOR ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT

TEXT.P: About 650,000 out of the country's 680,000 students of science and technology universities do not even meet the academic requirements for graduates of junior high schools, a lawmaker of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) claimed Wednesday.

TSU lawmaker Chen Cheng-lung claimed he tested "about 2,000" students from private science and technology universities with examination papers catering to junior high school students and found that only 2.1 percent of them reached a passing grade in English and 7.6 percent reached a passing grade in mathematics, which works out at an average pass rate of 4.8 percent.

The lawmaker claimed his findings vindicate a general public feeling that the academic achievements of students in science and technology universities that have sprouted in Taiwan over the last 10 years are declining rapidly.

In order to "cross-verify his findings, " Chen said he tested 50 junior high school graduates with question papers used by the Joint Entrance Examination for Science and Technology Universities and found that 80 percent of them reached a passing grade, compared to 14.7 percent of students who actually take part in the examinations.
He called on the Ministry of Education to improve the academic levels of these universities, claiming that their "unqualified graduates" will damage the country's competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD CLAIMS NCC BILL WILL ADD VALUE TO OPPOSITION PARTY'S ASSETS

TEXT.P: Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao claimed Wednesday that the passing of a bill on the organization of a National Communications Commission (NCC) will add several billion-worth of value to the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) assets.

Noting that Article 16 of the bill deals with a retroactive clause, Yao claimed that this is basically a "resurrection" and "value-protection" article for the assets of the KMT, in view of the current media environment.

He claimed that whether the KMT assets are ill-gotten will be "decided by the public, " but added that it affects the sale of its media assets such as the China Television Company and the Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC).

He pointed out especially that the BCC has taken nearly 40 percent of the available broadcast frequencies and that the GIO's efforts to streamline the frequencies so as to conform to the principle of fairness and justice might be disrupted because of this retroactive clause. Other reports, however, said the BCC will not be able to take advantage of the retroactive clause because it stipulates that those who have taken remedial measures will not be able to cite the clause and that the BCC is known to have filed complaints to the related agencies.

Yao said that the passing of the NCC bill will be tantamount to a "guarantee" for post-sale service, adding that the KMT will use its dominant NCC representation to guarantee related media transactions.
Quoting media reports, Yao said that after the passing of the bill, the transaction of the KMT assets could be increased by several billions of dollars.

Under the bill, the 13 members of the NCC will be chosen by a panel from among 18 candidates -- with 15 nominated by political parties according to proportional representation and three by the Executive Yuan.
The panel in charge of picking the commission members will consist of 11 scholars and experts, also appointed by political parties according to the proportional representation model.

The panel must make its choice through a three-fifths vote, but candidates who receive only a simple majority vote from the panel may also serve on the NCC if the number of candidates who won three-fifths of the votes falls short of 13.

Yao reaffirmed his opposition to the bill, claiming it will definitely be difficult to implement because it has turned against the tide of freeing the media from interference from military, partisan and government forces.

The Executive Yuan will consult with the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to decide whether to ask the Council of Grand Justices for an interpretation of the bill's constitutionality or to return the bill to the legislature for reconsideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TOURISM BUREAU CHIEF TO ARRIVE FOR 10-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: China's top tourism administrator is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Friday for a 10-day market inspection visit.

Shao Qiwei, director of the National Tourism Administration under China's State Council, will be visiting Taiwan in the name of president of the Chinese Tourism Association in line with Beijing's stance of no official contact with Taiwan.
He will be accompanied by a 66-member delegation composed of senior executives of travel associations and tourist agencies in various Chinese provinces and cities.

In preparation for his arrival, officials from the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Taiwan Visitors Association, the Mainland Affairs Council and the Aviation Police Bureau made a field survey of immigration operations at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Wednesday.
Airport officials said special staff will be assigned to guide the Chinese delegation through immigration.
According to Tourism Bureau officials, five Chinese journalists -- one from Xinhua News Agency and two each from China Central Television and China Travel News -- will accompany Shao.

The delegation is scheduled to stay in Taipei for three days and will then visit central, southern and eastern parts of Taiwan for two days each. The group will wrap up its visit and depart for home Nov. 6.
The visit is widely seen a prelude to China allowing its citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER SUGGESTS FOCUSING ON WEST, JAPAN FOLLOWING SENEGAL DEBACLE

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker suggested Wednesday that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) shift its focus to Japan, the United States and the European Union in the diplomatic battle against China following a diplomatic setback a day earlier.

Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lo Chih-ming issued the call during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan and urged the MOFA to place even more emphasis on these countries when seeking to explore international space for Taiwan.

Huge economic benefits rather than friendship between the peoples of the two countries are the main reason behind Senegal's decision to cut diplomatic ties with Taiwan and shift its recognition to China, Lo said.

He also questioned Foreign Affairs Minister Tan San Chen as to whether Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the Chinese State Council, should be allowed to take part in a forum here with Taiwan's opposition parties in December at a time when China is imperiously "digging at the walls of Taiwan."

MOFA announced the severance of bilateral diplomatic ties with Senegal late Tuesday after being notified by Senegal President Abdoulaye Wade earlier the same day of his decision to set up diplomatic relations with China, bringing the number of Taiwan's diplomatic allies down to 25.
For his part, Chen seemed to agree with Lo's idea, saying that "it might be a solution (to Taiwan's diplomatic wrangling with China) as long as national consensus is forged on doing so."
Chen also said he is willing to resign to take responsibility for Senegal's cutting ties with Taiwan.

Lawmakers of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) also harshly attacked MOFA for its failure to get information about Senegal's move at an earlier time, claiming that Wade's last-minute notice constituted an "insult" to Taiwan.

KMT Legislator John Chiang warned MOFA of a possible "domino effect, " expressing worry that the number of Taiwan's diplomatic partners might fall to fewer than 20 in the coming years if no policy adjustments are made. "Taiwan's diplomatic war against China cannot be simplified to just a race of dollar diplomacy," he argued.

KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao said President Chen Shui-bian has tossed away nearly US$130 million in "diplomatic bad loans" since he first came to power in 2000, which has deeply hurt the Taiwan people.
Chen embarked on a tour of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Africa in 2002, and Senegal was the first leg of that trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY UNDER ATTACK OVER SENEGAL TIES

TEXT.P: Two lawmakers from the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) demanded Wednesday that Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen resign to take responsibility over what they called the "humiliating process" involving the severance of diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and Senegal.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced a day earlier the government's decision to cut diplomatic ties with Senegal, hours after the African nation restored diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China. Ministry officials admitted that they were not informed beforehand of the development.

According to KMT Legislator John Chiang, a former foreign minister, the incident is the cruelest and the most disrespectful he has ever seen. He criticized the ministry for failing to react properly to the embarrassing situation by immediately recalling the ROC ambassador and aid missions to Senegal.

Accusing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government of adopting an erroneous foreign policy, Chiang warned that the incident will trigger a chain reaction and predicted that the number of the country's diplomatic allies will fall below 20 by the time President Chen Shui-bian steps down in 2008.

KMT Legislator Su Chi, who is a former chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said the incident has exposed the "intelligence failure" of the National Security Council and the MOFA and that both should be held responsible for the humiliating diplomatic debacle.

Echoing the KMT's opinions, Huang Yi-chiao, convener of the opposition People First Party's legislative caucus, urged the government to review its foreign policy and to "stop using checkbook diplomacy to win over allies."

Huang said that the financial aid offered by Taiwan and its democratic system have been two advantages enjoyed by Taiwan in expanding its foreign relations, but Taiwan is no longer in an advantageous position following the rise of China's economy and what he claimed is the "regression of Taiwan's democracy."
Instead of continuing to waste taxpayers' money in a diplomatic game with Beijing, the government should prioritize stabilizing its relations with China, according to Huang.
However, DPP legislators dismissed the claims by the KMT and PFP and condemned Beijing for continuing its double-handed strategy toward Taiwan.

William Lai, a leader of the DPP legislative caucus, said honorary KMT Chairman and former ROC Vice President Lien Chan, who is currently on a visit to China, should protest to Beijing or leave China immediately to express his anger.

Lai pointed out that Beijing celebrated Tuesday the 60th anniversary of Taiwan's retrocession from Japan as if Taiwan is one of its provinces, but the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, PFP and New Party did not voice a protest.
Pro-unification New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming even joined Beijing in the celebration, Lai noted.

DPP Legislator Tien Chiu-chin accused "pan-blue" politicians of kowtowing to Beijing by making 26 visits to China between July 2004 and September 2005, disregarding the fact that Taiwan was forced to withdraw from the United Nations 34 years ago because of the rivalry with China.
Meanwhile, Taiwan Solidarity Union legislative caucus convener Ho Min-hao joined the DPP in condemning Lien for not protesting to Beijing.

Ho also demanded that the government retaliate against Beijing's suppression of Taiwan by rejecting a possible visit to Taiwan by Chen Yunlin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, and scrapping its plan to recognize Chinese academic degrees.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE SALARY FOR OFFICE WORKERS UP 9% THIS YEAR: POLL

TEXT.P: The average monthly salary for domestic office workers with five years of experience reached NT$32,850 (US$976) this year, with people in information and sciences topping the list at an average of NT$36,874, according to a recent survey.
The results of the survey, conducted by 1111 Job Bank, show that the average salary for new office workers this year represented a growth of 9 percent over NT$30,207 registered last year.
The survey, conducted between May 20 and Oct. 20, received 7,374 valid responses with a margin of error of 1.1 percent.

Meanwhile, statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show that the average salary for all spectrums of workers in Taiwan totalled NT$35,590 as of August this year, a slight growth over NT$35,333 registered last year.

The survey also shows that workers in the commercial consulting sector earned the second-largest monthly salary of NT$35,440, with media and advertising workers receiving the third-largest salary of NT$33,532.
The average salary for the retail industry was bottom of the list with NT$28,601.
Among detailed job categories, system software developers topped the list with NT$41,130 per month, followed by engineering researchers with NT$40,211 and marketing planners with NT$39,830.

Newcomers in the job market received an average of NT$25,129 for their first jobs this year, a slight growth over NT$25,070 registered last year. The figure is much lower than the NT$40,000 for South Korean college graduates, NT$58,000 for Japanese graduates and NT$140,817 for American graduates, according to information from manpower data banks of these countries.

Wu Ruey-ying, a spokesman for 1111 Job Bank, said new college graduates should not pay much attention to the salary of their first jobs, but should instead focus on whether they can get promotion or pursue growth in their jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S NOTEBOOK OUTPUT SEEN TO TOP US$9 BILLION IN Q4

TEXT.P: Taiwan has shipped 13.35 million notebook personal computers in the third quarter of this year, an 84.4 percent share of the global market and a figure that is expected to rise to 84.8 percent with 15.15 million units, worth US$9.08 billion, in the fourth quarter, the Institute for Information Industry (III) said Wednesday.
III's Market Intelligence Center (MIC) estimated that in 2005, a total of 59 million notebook PCs will be sold on the world market, 49 million of which will be made in Taiwan.

MIC Deputy Director Chin Su-hsia said big brands such as Dell, HP and Acer have been pouring entry-level notebooks into the market, speeding up the effect of notebooks replacing desktops. As the market grows, Taiwan's OEM/ODM manufacturers are benefiting from the expansion.

Japanese brands such as Toshiba have also been supplying the market with low-priced notebooks, increasing the share of Taiwan's OEM/ODM output in the third quarter. Taiwan's Q3 share of the global notebook market showed a whopping 51.6 percent growth from the same quarter of last year and a 22.1 percent increase from the previous quarter, Chin noted.

The shining performance was not as impressive in terms of total output value because the famous brand names have cut their unit prices to an average of US$607, so the total value reached US$8.1 billion in the third quarter of 2005, up only 40.9 percent from the same period of last year.

With the approach of the Christmas holidays and as major manufacturers plan to stimulate the market with lower-priced products, shipments of notebooks are expected to remain brisk in Q4. In Taiwan, the notebook industry is forecast to ship 15.18 million units in this quarter, up 42.2 percent from the same period of last year and 13.7 percent up from the previous quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NT$-RENMINBI EXCHANGE SERVICE ON TAIWAN PROPER: MAC

TEXT.P: It is still premature to begin new Taiwan dollar-renminbi currency exchange services on Taiwan proper as it involves too many complicated issues, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday.

At a tea-party with local and foreign journalists, Wu noted that the government implemented NT$-renminbi currency exchange services on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu on a trial basis early this month and needs more time to evaluate the new measure.

The government inaugurated the currency exchange services Oct. 4, with travelers using the "mini three links" between Kinmen, Matsu and several mainland Chinese ports showing warm response to the policy, as they no longer have to exchange their renminbi on the black market.

Although many people believe that NT$-renminbi exchange services should be implemented on Taiwan proper due to frequent cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade exchanges, Wu said the issue needs more negotiation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and that it might also need a revision to Taiwan's regulations that govern cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS WANT TO INCREASE CASH ALLOWANCE FOR AGED FARMERS

TEXT.P: Opposition legislators introduced legislation Wednesday aiming to increase the monthly cash allowance for farmers aged 65 and over from the current NT$4,000 to NT$5,000.

The lawmakers of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) told a press conference at the Legislative Yuan that the move was made in line with a recent announcement by President Chen Shui-bian that the government will take better care of the welfare of elderly farmers.

They introduced an amendment to the current "temporary regulations governing welfare and allowances for aged farmers," which would ask the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) to raise the monthly cash allowance to NT$5,000 for elderly farmers from Jan. 1 next year.

The opposition legislators estimated that there is no need to increase the COA's total budget for fiscal 2006, which stands at about NT$100 billion, and that all the COA needs to do is adjust the priorities in the budget plan.
The amendment would ask the COA to resubmit its budget plan within one week.

In reaction, legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed that the move is "clearly unconstitutional" because the opposition lawmakers are trying to block the COA's budget in the name of the welfare of elderly farmers.
DPP Legislator Ker Chien-min said the DPP legislative caucus will also introduce a proposal next week to increase the monthly cash allowance to NT$5,000.
Meanwhile, COA Chairman Lee Ching-lung ruled out the possibility of the COA rewriting its budget plan.

He estimated that the increased allowances for some 700,000 elderly farmers will add a financial burden of NT$8.4 billion to the COA's annual budget and affect other priorities, such as the prevention of avian influenza and mud flows in mountainous areas.
Lee said the COA will not consider resubmitting its fiscal 2006 budget before the source of the funds is secured.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DISMISSES 'TRADEOFF' REPORT

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu ruled out Wednesday the possibility of a tradeoff between a senior Chinese official's visit to Taiwan and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng's attendance at the upcoming informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum as President Chen Shui-bian's proxy.

Speaking during an informal meeting with local and foreign journalists, Wu said that as an APEC formal member, Taiwan has the legitimate right to send a representative to attend the annual APEC summit.

"China is not in a position to dictate by whom Taiwan should be represented on the occasion, " Wu claimed, despite the fact that because of China's obstinate opposition, Taiwan's head of state has been barred from attending the APEC summit in person and has had to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

Chen has appointed Wang to represent him at the 2005 APEC summit to be held in Busan, South Korea Nov. 18-19, but China has voiced blunt opposition and has demanded that Taiwan be represented by an economic official.

Reporters had speculated that the government might allow Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, to attend a seminar in Taiwan in December in exchange for China's consent to Wang's APEC attendance.
"The reports are not true. A so-called tradeoff is out of the question," Wu said.

He confirmed that the main opposition Kuomintang had filed an application with the Immigration Bureau inviting Chen Yunlin and several other Chinese officials and experts to attend a seminar in Taipei in December.
Given Chen Yulin's special status in the Chinese government, Wu said, China should send working-level officials to Taiwan to flesh out technical details regarding such an unprecedented visit.

Noting that Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- negotiated for the late SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu to visit China in the past, Wu said the MAC will decide whether to approve Chen Yulin's visit in terms of the results of SEF-ARATS negotiations.

The KMT and its adversary-turned-partner, the Communist Party of China are scheduled to co-sponsor a seminar in Taipei in December. Under the present political circumstances, Wu said, it is inappropriate for any unauthorized political party or group to claim that it can represent the Chinese government to negotiate with the Taiwan government on political affairs.

Even though China's passage of its anti-secession law against Taiwan and its latest success in tempting the West African nation of Senegal to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing have had a negative impact on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Wu said the government is still willing to discuss with China the opening of direct cross-strait charter passenger and cargo flights and allowing Chinese citizens to sightsee in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECCT CALLS FOR LOOSER GOVERNMENT TRADE RESTRICTIONS

TEXT.P: The European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) suggested Wednesday in its annual report that Taiwan ease government regulations and improve its ties with China as a means of staying competitive regionally and globally.

The two negative factors have driven many multinationals out of Taiwan despite the fact that Taiwan is a good place to make money, ECCT Chairman Sager Dirk said, expressing worry that many European companies may opt to invest in other countries should Taiwan fail to address the problems in time.

For the time being, investments by ECCT member companies here have almost all come to a halt, evidence in Taiwan's lackluster economic indexes and flagging foreign direct investment in recent years, Dirk said, pointing to Taiwan's awkward and excessive laws and regulations and the country's abnormal relations with China as the key hurdles.

Many hindrances also arise from Taiwan's uncertain and peculiar political relations with China, the ECCT chairman said, noting that Taiwan's resistance to opening up to Chinese products -- as many as around 2,400 items so far -- not only violates its own promise made upon entering the World Trade Organization but has also caused marked losses for many foreign companies.

For instance, he said, European retail business has suffered losses of more than US$100 million in Taiwan as a result of Taiwan's ban on imports from China, which is a major manufacturing powerhouse around the world.
In addition, he pointed out, Taiwan's delays in joining the WTO Government Procurement Agreement have also frustrated many European enterprises, eventually driving them out of Taiwan.

Although Taiwan has been trying to transform from a manufacturing power to a service-oriented economy, he noted that the relevant environments and infrastructures have yet to be built to serve that end.
The ECCT chairman said that while Taiwan is still a good destination for foreign investors to make money, it needs to be better, stronger and more competitive.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPU TO CONVENE SYMPOSIUM ON BIRD FLU IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , a non-governmental organization inaugurated in Taipei in August, will convene a symposium on bird flu in Indonesia in November in an effort to prevent an epidemic.
Lu made the remarks while receiving Taj Hamad, secretary-general of the World Association of Non-Governmental Organizations (WANGO).

Lu said the DPU, a non-governmental organization designed to boost democracy, peace and prosperity for the Pacific Rim democracies, has presented several cooperation programs among member countries for the next two years, including a symposium on bird flu in Asia.
Experts invited to the symposium are expected to exchange views and discuss cooperation projects to fight against the disease in Asia and prevent a possible global pandemic, Lu added.
The DPU's plans also include the establishment of a women's development center and a disaster prevention center, according to Lu.
She hailed the contribution made by WANGO to global development by connecting NGOs and solving basic problems despite obstacles caused by race, religion and culture.

She expressed hope that the DPU, now boasting 28 member countries and with talent cultivation and environmental protection as its main goals in the near future, can make more contributions to the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS DEMAND FSC TOP LEADERS' RESIGNATIONS

TEXT.P: A number of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators demanded Wednesday that the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) chairman and vice chairman step down to take political responsibility for the "vultures" insider trading scandal.

Former FSC Examination Bureau Chairman Lee Chin-cheng was indicted on charges of leaking classified information to his stock trading friends who used the information make illicit profits from the stock market. Prosecutors demanded an eight-year jail term for Lee and a minimum of one year for four others Tuesday.

DPP Legislator Kuo Cheng-liang said a number of DPP lawmakers in the legislative caucus' financial policy group demanded that FSC Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng and Vice Chairman Lu Tung-ying resign for "using the wrong person" and "failing to supervise a key official."

Kuo said the scandal has become international news because the regulator of the nation's financial industry had broken the law he was supposed to impose on the whole industry. Likening Taiwan to a Third World corrupt African state, Kuo added: "Something of such a magnitude probably could only happen in an African country."
DPP Legislator Lin Chung-mo said that somebody should take the administrative and political responsibility for the scandal.

DPP lawmaker Chiang Chao-yi pointed out that when a lawmaker alerted the FSC of a possible irregularity inside the commission in March, the FSC took no action until the end of June and Vice Chairman Lu Tung-ying even praised Lee Chin-cheng as "a great asset" of the FSC, which Chiang claimed was an "obvious attempt to cover up his crime."
DPP lawmaker Wang Shih-chien said that if Kong does not quit, he will initiate a petition at the legislature to demand that the Cabinet dismiss him.
Lee, as a financial regulator, has helped his friends steal public money and has lied repeatedly to the nation, and yet Kong has backed him up, Wang said.
Kong was not available for comment. Lu, who was at the legislature, said he was not aware of the DPP lawmakers' demand and declined to respond.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ID CARDS TO BE ISSUED FROM DEC. 21

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior will begin issuing new ID cards to replace the existing ones from Dec. 21 this year to Dec. 31, 2006, a spokesman for the ministry said Wednesday.
The spokesman said each applicant for an ID card will have to pay NT$100 for photo-taking, except those in medium- and low-income households.

He said members of medium- and low-income households can go to their local household registration offices before Dec. 21 and present free photo-taking coupons to have their ID cards made. Otherwise, he added, they can have their photos taken at one of 4,000 designated photo studios anytime during the year after Dec. 21 and take them to their local household registration offices.

For disabled people who cannot apply for their new ID cards personally, their family members can make a request to send for local household registration officers to come to their houses to take their photos.
The new ID cards are expected to have 21 forgery-proof features, with the information written horizontally rather than vertically.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET OKAYS DRAFT BILL ON ANTI-CORRUPTION BUREAU

TEXT.P: The Cabinet passed a draft bill at its weekly meeting Wednesday on the establishment of an anti-corruption bureau as part of its efforts to achieve clean politics.

According to the draft bill, the new anti-corruption bureau will be put under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) . The bill still needs to be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval.
Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin said the proposed new bureau will "cooperate and compete" with the MOJ's Investigation Bureau to upgrade the efficiency in anti-corruption operations.

"We believe that the multichannel operations will facilitate the campaign against official corruption, " Shih said, adding that he hopes the two bureaus will maintain both "partnership and competitive" relations in their fight against corruption and the pursuit of clean politics.

According to the MOJ plan, the new bureau will set up investigative centers in northern, central and southern parts of the island, to be manned by officials from existing government ethics units. The staff of the new bureaus will be accorded "judicial police" status to facilitate their investigations.
With computer crime becoming ever-more rampant, Shih said both the Investigation Bureau and the new anti-corruption bureau are expected to enhance their proficiency in this field.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraqi Officials Declare Charter Has Been Passed
Iraqi electoral officials officially announced Tuesday that voters had passed a new constitution, paving the way for parliamentary elections in December. But the constitution narrowly escaped defeat, as Sunni Arabs turned out in large numbers to vote against it. While Sunni Arabs appear willing to participate, they remain hostile to Shiite and Kurdish rule. The Sun ni groups appear to be mobilizing for a large turnout in elections for the National Assembly in December, in order to make major changes to the constitution and to obstruct the aims of Shiites and Kurds by having a Sunni Arab voice in the government.
Wall Street Journal: Farmers, Charities Join Forces To Block Famine-Relief Revamp
American humanitarian groups, armed with food donated by the U.S. government, have fed millions of starving people around the world over the past half-century. Starting next year, t he White House wants to spend one-quarter of its food-aid budget to buy overseas goods to feed starving foreigners. The charities are opposing the shift because, for years, their humanitarian mission has been bound in an alliance with the American farmers, millers, port operators and shippers, who are paid by the government to produce food and haul it to hunger zones overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCTOBER 27 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Oct. 27:
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will meet with foreign dignitaries who are in Taipei to attend an international seminar on constitutional reform in emerging democracies.
10:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a news conference to introduce the 2005 Hakka Art Festival.
10:20, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news briefing at its headquarters.
14:20, Premier Hsieh will make an inspection tour of the national medical emergencies response center to look into its avian flu prevention measures.
18:30, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun will host a welcoming party at Taipei Grand Hotel for foreign participants to an international seminar on constitutional reform.
19:00, Premier Hsieh will attend a dinner party to be hosted by an Asia-Pacific construction industry association at Grand Hotel.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDICTED FSC OFFICIAL SUSPENDED JOB

TEXT.P: Lee Chin-cheng, a counselor with the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , was suspended his job Wednesday after he was indicted on charges of leaking classified in formation to his stock trading friends who used the information make illicit profits from the stock market.

Lee, who had been the FSC's Examination Bureau chief before he was demoted to the advisory post, was suspected of having offended Article 2 of the Public Functionaries Disciplinary Law for dereliction of duty, the FSC said in a press statement.

The FSC said it decided to suspend Lee's advisory job after receiving the prosecution authorities' indictment. Prosecutors demanded an eight-year prison term for Lee and a minimum of one year for four others Tuesday.

In addition to suspending Lee's job, the FSC said it will refer the case to the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, for further investigations to determine whether he break any civil service disciplinary rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 27, or the 25th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1728: Captain James Cook, English navigator, is born. His voyages on the ship Endeavour led to the European discovery of Australia, New Zealand and the Hawaiian Islands.
1858: Theodore Roosevelt, U.S. statesman and president, is born. He won the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts in ending the Russo-Japanese War in 1905.
1921: Yen Fu, a noted Chinese translator who introduced Western culture to China, dies in his hometown of Minhou in Fukien Province at the age of 67.
1922: The Italian government resigns under increasing pressure from the fascist movement under Benito Mussolini.
1927: Mao Zedong leads his followers and reaches Chingkang Mountain in Kianghsi Province to establish a stronghold for the Chinese Communist Party.
1930: The Wuhsheh Incident occurs when Taiwan's aboriginal inhabitants in the Wuhsheh area of Taichung County launch their resistance campaign against Japanese rule and kill 134 Japanese.
1931: Representatives from Nanking and Canton meet in Shanghai for peace negotiations.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States to address a joint session of the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives.
1947: The Ministry of the Interior announces that the "Democracy Alliance" is an illegal organization subject to being cracked down on in accordance with current laws.
1947: The Sino-American Relief Treaty is signed in Nanking under which US$30 million worth of relief goods are to be shipped to Taiwan.
1955: Taiwan's first sex-change operation is successfully carried out at the Army First Hospital.
1961: The 16th United Nations General Assembly votes in favor of the admission of Outer Mongolia. The Republic of China abstains from the vote.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a treaty of amity in Seoul.
1974: Teizo Horikoshi, president of the Interchange Association of Japan, and Sadan Iguchi, the association's director, arrive in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1978: President Anwar Sadat of Egypt shares the Nobel Peace Prize with Premier Menachem Begin of Israel.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on Korean Ambassador Ock Man Ho to express his condolences over the death of President Park Chung Hee.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan defends his decision to send a 2,000-strong force of Marines and Army Rangers to the Caribbean island of Grenada.
1986: An international conference on "Chiang Kai-shek and Modern China" opens in Taipei, with more than two hundred Chinese and foreign scholars attending the four-day meeting.
1987: A referendum in the Republic of Korea approves constitutional reforms, including the establishment of direct presidential elections.
1990: Moscow City Mayor Gavriil H. Popov arrives for a formal visit to the ROC to discuss the strengthening of ROC-Soviet trade relations.
1994: The Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the "Wildlife Conservation Law," greatly toughening penalties against violators and stipulating that the breeding of endangered animals in captivity must cease within three years.
1997: The Dow Jones index drops 554.26 points, its largest one-day decline in terms of points.
1999: The International Relations Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives amends and passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, aiming at extending U.S.-Taiwan security ties.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan hold their first meeting since Chen's election in March, in which Lien urges Chen to convene a National Unification Council meeting.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announces a decision to halt construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant, saying the move is the only choice for building a nuclear-free homeland.
2001: The 47th congress of the Asia Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy (APLFD) opens at a Auckland, New Zealand hotel with the participation of some 60 delegates from 15 countries.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sense of mercy is in all men; the sense of shame is in all men; the sense of courtesy and respect is in all men; the sense of right and wrong is in all men."

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Japan, U.S. agree on new Futenma site
Japan and the United States agreed Wednesday to move the U.S. Marine Corps' Futenma Air Station in Ginawan, Okinawa Prefecture, to Camp Schwab, possibly resolving a dispute that lasted nine years.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO CONTINUE TRAINING TAIWAN PILOTS: PENTAGON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The Defense Security Cooperation Agency of the U.S. Defense Department announced Wednesday that it has notified Congress of the continuation of a training program for F-16 fighter pilots from Taiwan.

The agency notified Congress Tuesday of a "possible foreign military sale" to Taiwan of 10 AIM-9M Sidewinder Missiles and 5 AIM-7M Sparrow Missiles, the continuation of a pilot training program and logistics support for F-16 aircraft, as well as related equipment and services. The price tag for all of the above would be about US$280 million.
Pointing out that notifying Congress of a potential sale is required by law, the agency said that the notice does mean the sale has been concluded.
In the notice, the agency also said that the missiles would be used by Taiwan pilots for live fire exercises at the Luke Air Force Base training facility in Louisiana.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENTIAL OFFICIAL'S FAMILY MUM ON SEOUL GAMBLING REPORT

TEXT.P: Family members of former presidential deputy secretary general Chen Che-nan said Chen was not at home Thursday and they did not know anything about Chen's reported visit to the casino at Sheraton Walker-Hill Hotel in Seoul Nov. 2, 2002.

Major newspapers carried a photo showing Chen Chen-nan and Chen Min-hsien, former vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) , at a gambling table together in the casino in the South Korean capital. Both were suspected of being involved in the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit scandal.
Chen Min-hsien is the leader of Southeast Cement Corp. in Kaohsiung. His secretary said he could not be reached for comment on the report.

Premier Frank Hsieh, who has apologized for his role as a former Kaohisung mayor and as leader of the Cabinet, said a news photo is not good enough to prove anything. The prosecution should determine whether the photo has any significance, he added.
Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said if new evidence has surfaced, investigators should double check the records of what the suspects said during questioning to see if they had lied.

Ma said he was not surprised that "new evidence" would continue to emerge after acting Kaohisung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan completed an administrative investigation report on the KRTC scandal. Yeh's report did not mention any wrongdoing by Chen Che-nan but implicated Chen Min-hsien.
