DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE CLAIMS NO RECORD OF FORMER ADVISER'S OVERSEAS TRIP

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office said Thursday that it does not have any record of former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan having asked for a leave or visiting a foreign country in November 2002.

The Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs made the statement in response to media reports that Chen and Chen Min-hsien, former vice chairman of Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) , were seen sitting together at a casino table at a Seoul, South Korea hotel Nov. 2, 2002.

Neither the office nor the president knew of Chen Che-nan's foreign visit, and there had never been any "inspection report on the foreign labor situation" allegedly presented to the president by Chen following his foreign visit, said Chen Wen-tzung, director of the department.
The director called on the public not to speculate on or play up the reports. "If you have any evidence, just refer it to the prosecution authorities so they can investigate, " Chen Wen-tzung said.

He reiterated President Chen Shui-bian's determination to uncover all the facts regarding the KRTC scandal. The president has also pledged that if he is found to have been illegally involved or to have covered up anything, he will gladly give up presidential immunity and step down as president, Chen Wen-tzung added.

In Kaohsiung, Chen Min-hsien, who was being probed by investigators, said he and his good friend Chen Che-nan did tour Cheju Island in South Korea in November 2002, pointing out that the media reports only prove that they were "enjoying a legal recreational activity."
"Chen Che-nan and I are good friends. We went to a recreational area, purely for tourism purposes. It's nothing. It has nothing to do with the KRTC scandal," he told the media.
Prosecutor Chung Chung-hsiao of Kaohsiung District Court said the photo would not change the direction of his investigation, which he said was focusing on the flow of money and funds.
The prosecution will try to determine whether the two Chens were being treated by the KRTC during their Korean trip, Chung said.
Meanwhile, acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan urged the media and the public not to "overstretch" their imagination about her city government's administrative investigation into the KRTC scandal.

In her special report on the incident, an anonymous letter was appended which claimed that Chen Min-hsien demanded NT$100 million in "public relations fees" from contractors interested in winning KRTC construction contracts.
Chen told them that he was responsible for collecting NT$5 billion in election campaign funds for President Chen Shui-bian, according to the letter.
In Taipei, Chen Wen-tzung categorically refuted the letter's allegations.
Yeh said the letter became part of her report because investigators had looked into the allegations and city council members had questioned the government about its credibility.
"We should present facts as they are and say nothing if we cannot support our statements with solid evidence," she said, calling on the people not to look at the report from "unhealthy" standpoints.
Yeh emphasized that she included that letter in her report to show that she has not hidden anything. The letter is not evidence, she asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: U.S. Death Toll in Iraq Hits 2,000.
The Pentagon announced Tuesday that three more Americans serving in Iraq had been killed, lifting the U.S. military death toll to 2,000 and triggering a new round of protest and debate in the United States over the 2 1/2-year conflict.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: NTUC proposes tweaking foreign worker quota.
The labour movement wants the Government to tweak its foreign-worker policy as part of an overall plan to help low-income workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DENIES PROVIDING FUNDS TO ZIMBABWE OPPOSITION
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Liu Cheng-ching and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official denied Thursday a report that Taiwan has provided funds to Zimbabwe's main opposition party.
"The Republic of China will not interfere in the internal affairs of other countries, let alone make political donations, " MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said.

Lu pointed out that the ROC is a country ruled by law, with the budget of the ministry subject to monitoring by the legislature. He said the ministry has always operated in accordance with this principle.
Meanwhile, ROC Representative to South Africa Richard Shih said he has no knowledge of the reported charges.

According to the foreign report, the Zimbabwean government has ordered a probe into charges that the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) received US$2.5 million in funds from Ghana, Nigeria and Taiwan.
The charges were made by MDC Legislator Job Sikhala. Both Ghana and Nigeria have denied giving any funds to the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY REGRETS BRITISH OFFICIAL'S REMARKS ON BIRD FLU
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By J.J. Hwang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top envoy in London said Wednesday that he feels great regret about a high-ranking British official's remarks that Taiwan birds might have infected two parrots imported from Suriname which later died of avian flu.
Edgar Lin, Taiwan's representative to Britain, expressed his regret in a letter he sent to Margaret Beckett, secretary of state of the U.K. Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (DEFRA).

Beckett reported the same day to the British Parliament that two parrots imported from the South American country of Suriname died after being infected with the H5N1 virus which they possibly had contracted from birds imported from Taiwan. The Taiwan birds and the parrots had been kept in quarantine together. Beckett provided no proof for her claims.
Pointing out that the secretary's remarks "obviously went against the facts," Lin said in the letter that so far, it still has not been proven that the Taiwan birds were carrying the avian flu virus.

He also told Beckett that currently, Taiwan is not a bird flu-affected area, stressing that any comments suggesting without evidence that the birds were infected with H5N1 could be harmful to the island's image and its reputation of attaching great importance to public health.
"In the interests of the two countries, I hope that the DEFRA can make relevant comments in accordance with facts and fairness, " he added.

In response to the British government's comments on the Suriname parrots, Lin further said that the island's Council of Agriculture sent a veteranarian Tuesday to the bird-raiser in Taichung, Taiwan who had sold the birds. The vet tested the birds raised there.

"The tests showed that all of the birds were in good health and did not have avian flu, " Lin said in the letter, adding that this "clearly shows that the death of parrots in Britain were not related to the birds from Taiwan."

The envoy also requested in the letter that the DEFRA provide Taiwan with an official examination report and relevant test results related to the death of the parrots for use in further investigations into the case in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Grand Jury Hears Summary of Case On CIA Leak Probe; Decision on Charges May Come Friday.
The prosecutor in the CIA leak investigation presented a summary of his case to a federal grand jury yesterday and is expected to announce a final decision on charges in the two- year-long probe tomorrow, according to people familiar with the case, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: English Migration Cards to Return The Russian-only migration cards that have caused chaos on incoming flights in recent weeks will be replaced with the old dual-language version, the Federal Migration Service said Wednesday. [By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SETS UP AD HOC GROUP TO PROBE KAOHSIUNG RAPID TRANSIT SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Thursday that his party has set up a task force that will "find out in the shortest possible time any law breakers who have attempted to lie to the public" with respect to the Kaohsiung rapid transit scandal.

Su made the remarks in the wake of media reports carrying a photo that shows former Presidential Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan and former Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien together at a casino in Seoul, South Korea. Both Chens are suspected of involvement in the KRTC scandal.

The scandal erupted after Thai laborers helping to build the rapid transit system rioted in protest against what they called poor living conditions and maltreatment by consultant companies contracted in August by the KRTC to manage foreign workers.
Su said the DPP task force will not limit itself when investigating the incident, which has damaged the ruling party's image as a clean and reforming political force.
Su made his remarks while stumping for Luo Wen-jia, DPP candidate in the year-end Taipei County magistrate election, in Dunshui, near Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi-Ciampi duel.
President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi lamented Italy's slow economic growth in recent years Wednesday when he gave a speech at an award ceremony for business achievement. He urged the government institutions to deal with problems based on the reality. Premier Silvio Berlusconi rebutted later that none of the governments had achieved what his administration had made over the past four and a half years. He said what his government has done is in need of the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S TOP TOURISM OFFICIAL'S VISIT SIMPLY TO CHECK OUT SITES: MAC

TEXT.P: China's top tourism administrator's upcoming visit to Taiwan will simply be to see first-hand the scenic spots and tourism facilities around Taiwan, Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday.
The government has no plans to try to arrange any official meetings with the visiting Chinese official, the MAC chief said.
Wu was referring to Shao Qiwei, director of the National Tourism Administration under China's State Council, at an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.
Shao will be travelling to Taiwan for a 10-day visit in his capacity as president of the Chinese Tourism Association in line with Beijing's policy of no official contact with Taiwan.

Shao's visit was arranged by private groups, and both sides agreed that the visit would be based on the "principle of simplicity, " Wu noted, adding that "if we ask for talks or meetings with him, it will mess things up."

On opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator David Huang's claim that it is "cozying up" to China to allow Shao's visit in the wake of Beijing's luring of Taiwan's African ally Senegal to severe diplomatic relations with Taipei, Wu responded that cross-strait policy should not be embroiled in an endless and senseless "tit-for-tat, " which he said would not be conducive to better cross-strait relations.

"Since opening up to Chinese tourists is an established policy and since Shao's visit will help the development of cross-strait tourism, " Wu said that the MAC will continue to promote the matter while weighing the benefits to the nation.
Wu expressed the hope that Shao's visit will lay a good foundation and pave the way for future consultations between Taiwan and China on tourism.
Shao will be accompanied by a 66-member delegation made up of senior executives of travel associations and tourist agencies in various Chinese provinces and cities.
The delegation is scheduled to stay in Taipei for three days before heading to the central, southern and eastern parts of Taiwan for two days in each region. It is scheduled to depart Taiwan Nov. 6.
The visit is widely seen as a prelude to China allowing its citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan.

Also speaking at the legislative interpellation session, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said that he would welcome a meeting with Shao if the latter were to express a desire for one.
However, Lin said that China has asked Shao to keep as low a profile as possible during his visit and that the officials he meets in Taiwan should not be higher than ministerial-level ones.
On cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday in 2006, Wu said that "barring a veto by China, there should be no problem."

Wu said that Taiwan is currently in contact with China regarding cross-strait cargo and passenger charter flight consultations, but if the consultations are too lengthy, the government will first deal with charter flights during Chinese New Year holiday.

Wu said that in the past, only China-based Taiwan businesspeople were allowed to use the Chinese New Year holiday cross-strait charter flight services. He said the government will weigh whether to allow foreign nationals to also use the flight services.
He said that this and other issues, such as the flight destinations and the allocation of flights and routes, will all have to be determined in further consultations with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 39.54 points to close at 5,661.18.
The bourse opened at 5,663.24 and fluctuated between 5,717.05 and 5,632.23 during trading. A total of 2.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$65.66 billion (US$1.95 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up 2.7 percent and plastics and chemicals shares rising 0.4 percent.

The other six major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 1.1 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent, and cement stocks and construction issues, both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 631 to 327, with 193 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT RESTRICTING CHINA TOURS AS HUNAN PROVINCE REPORTS AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not restrict its people from traveling to China even though Hunan Province has reported an avian flu outbreak which has killed hundreds of chickens and ducks, Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday.
"One province hit by avian flu does not mean other areas of China have been hit too," Hsieh said, urging China to truthfully report all avian flu cases to the World Health Organization.
He also urged the Taiwan public not to panic, pointing out that the government has not issued an advisory against travel to other Chinese provinces.
Hsieh said it is not clear whether the Hunan outbreak has been caused by birds or by humans, and "it is a question that we must try to understand further."
If it is confirmed that bird flu has begun to spread among humans, that "would be a serious matter for people around the world because we now live in a global village," Hsieh said.

Meanwhile, the premier announced that the government has negotiated a good price to purchase three tons of raw materials that can be used to make enough Tamiflu for 2.3 million people, or one-tenth of Taiwan's population.

Now, the government will try to gain authorization to mass produce Tamiflu from its patent holder, Roche Pharmaceuticals, he said, setting a timetable to mass produce the influenza medicine from the end of December to January next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHERMEN HIT ANNUAL CEILING ON WHALE SHARK CATCHES

TEXT.P: Taiwan fishermen are banned from catching whale sharks from now through the end of this year based on a yearly quota control system implemented by the government in line with international efforts to protect the biggest fish.

According to a notice issued Oct. 24 by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) , Taiwan fishermen have caught a total of 65 whale sharks since the beginning of this year, reaching the cap imposed by the COA on local fisherman for this year.

The yearly quota control system was set up in July 2002 by the COA in conjunction with a global conservation drive and marine resources management efforts. The COA first initiated a whale shark catch tracking system in 2001, requiring Taiwan fishermen to report their catch of whale sharks to the council.

From now through Dec. 31, Taiwan fishermen will not be able to catch, possess, sell or dispose of the fish, and those who accidentally catch whale sharks will have to set them back in the sea, live or dead. Fishermen who violate the rule will be sentenced to up to three years in jail or a punishment of community service plus a maximum fine of NT$150,000 (US$4,465).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLEDGES TO REALIZE 'DELIBERATIVE DEMOCRACY'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Thursday that the second phase of constitutional reforms will be carried out according to the concept of "deliberative democracy" to facilitate extensive citizen participation in the process.

Chen was speaking to a foreign delegation visiting Taiwan for an international conference on constitutional re-engineering, which has been organized by a Presidential Office panel promoting constitutional reforms.

Chen pointed out that the country achieved the first phase of constitutional reforms on June 7 by abolishing the National Assembly to allow for public referendums on future constitutional amendments, which will give the people the final say in any proposed amendments.

According to Chen, Taiwan may seem to have practiced constitutional democracy for more than 50 years, but as a matter of fact, the system has only been in practice for no more than 20 years because of the 38-year martial law period which followed soon after the Republic of China Constitution was promulgated in 1947.
Although seven rounds of constitutional reforms have been launched over the past 14 years, the people are still not satisfied with the results of the reforms, he claimed.
Chen noted that most of these seven rounds of reforms were motivated by political purposes and not participated in by the people.

As a result of such changes, the constitutional system in Taiwan appears "outlandish, " Chen claimed. He noted that the system is neither a presidential system, semi-presidential system nor parliamentary system, a situation that he said has led to political instability in the country.

Therefore, he stressed, the second phase of reforms is necessary in order to maintain national stability and competitiveness, and the concept of deliberative democracy should be employed in the next round of reforms to realize "true democracy."

The president pointed out that constitutional reforms are especially difficult to accomplish in Taiwan because people tend to link them with the issue of independence or unification. Even the government's plan to hold 10,000 seminars to invite public discussion on the reforms has been mistaken for promoting "populism," he said.
However, none of these accusations is true, he asserted, saying he believes the second phase of reforms will succeed with the support of the people.

The next phase of reforms is expected to address issues such as whether to change the country's political system to a presidential system or parliamentary system; lowering the voting age from 20 to 18; and adopting a voluntary military service system.
Officials have promised that the reforms will not involve sensitive issues such as changes to the country's status, territorial boundaries or official designation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER'S RESIGNATION 'WOULDN'T BE HELPFUL:' PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that it would not be helpful for Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen to resign over the severance of diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Senegal.
Hsieh made the remarks on the sidelines while attending a press conference to promote the Hakka Arts Festival.
Chen said Wednesday that he is prepared to step down anytime to take responsibility for the severance of diplomatic ties.

Senegalese Foreign Minister Cheikh Tidiane Gadio signed a communique with his Chinese counterpart Li Zhaoxing in Beijing Tuesday on the resumption of diplomatic ties between their two countries. Senegal switched its diplomatic recognition from Beijing to Taipei in 1996.
The premier said that officials "don't have to resign for everything," adding that "it is not the most correct approach."
"The more urgent task is to pinpoint the political responsibility," Hsieh said.
Hsieh said his Cabinet will first investigate to see whether any officials are responsible for negligence leading to the severance of diplomatic ties or if there are any flaws in policy-making.
Meanwhile, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said that ROC Ambassador to Senegal Huang Yun-cheh will return home in three days.
Lu said that in line with international practice, the two countries will close their embassies within one month.

After cutting diplomatic relations with Senegal, the ministry has asked Taiwan's overseas missions to be on high alert against China's efforts to "undermine" Taiwan's relations with its other diplomatic allies, Lu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PRESIDES OVER PRELUDE TO HAKKA ARTS FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh presided over a ceremony to introduce the 2005 A-Ha Hakka Arts Festival Thursday, which will include a series of Hakka art performances around the island over the next month.

Lee Yung-teh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs, noted that the organizer of this year's Hakka art festival will also invite world-renowned violinist Lin Cho-liang to play the newest Hakka music written by composer Chen Chien-tai.
This year's Hakka art festival, the third of its kind, will feature some 115 performing groups touring Taiwan to put on shows at some 25 locations around the island.
Lee said that the Hakka arts festival will not only focus on Hakka art, noting that it will also serve as a platform for different ethnic groups to appreciate one another's cultures.
Lee also revealed that Premier Hsieh has applied to participate in a Hakka language certification test, a move that Lee said shows "the premier's appreciation for Hakka culture."

The Chen Shui-bian administration has attached much importance to the development of the island's various cultures, including those of the Hakka and aboriginal people, since his first inauguration in 2000. The country's first television station broadcast entirely in the Hakka dialect began operations in July 2003, and the first television station for Taiwan's indigenous people went on air in July this year.
At the opening ceremony, Hsieh noted that the artistic level of the Hakka people is quite high. He later played a Hakka traditional song with a flute.

According to Lee, the "2005 A-Ha Hakka Arts Festival" will begin with a performance by several Hakka singers, bands and dance troupes in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, Nov. 5, while a performance by violinist Lin cho-liang and Evergreen Symphony Orchestra will conclude the festival Dec. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TRYING TO AMEND LAW ON LEGISLATIVE POWER TO QUESTION PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shu-bian and former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan could be called to the legislature for questioning about their roles in the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) scandal if the People First Party succeeds in amending a law governing the Legislative Yuan's investigative power.

PFP legislative caucus convener Huang Yi-chiao said Thursday that Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng has agreed to let lawmakers deliberate his party's proposal to amend the law governing the legislature's investigative power on Nov. 8.

According to a decision by the Council of Grand Justices on Dec. 15, 2004, the legislature has the authority to call witnesses and read all related documents when investigating a major scandal, Huang said.

He quoted "quite a number of TV critics" as alleging that Chen Shui-bian, his family and close aides have been suspected of taking bribes or being involved in other corruption cases, adding that the Presidential Office has reacted as if nothing has happened.

Huang said the Kuomintang (KMT) has agreed to support the PFP motion to amend the law governing the legislature's exercise of power. He added that his caucus is seeking support from the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) which form the "pan-green camp."
If the "pan-green" parties try to block the amendment efforts, they will be reasonably suspected of attempting to cover up a long series of high-level corruption cases, Huang added.

Once the legislature is given the power to call witnesses for questioning, the president, Chen Che-nan, Premier Frank Hsieh and former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, now a KMT legislator, will be invited to answer questions at the legislature regarding their roles in the KRTC scandal, he said.
When Huang and his PFP colleagues called at the DPP caucus, they were greeted by Lee Chin-yi, director of the caucus office, who said he could not promise anything.

The PFP caucus received better treatment at the caucus office of the TSU, whose convener Ho Min-hao and deputy convener Huang Shih-chuo greeted them with oranges, urging the "orange" party (referring to the PFP whose logo is orange-colored) to "turn green" and agree to the TSU's proposal for amending the constitution by changing the official name of the country from "the Republic of China" to "the Republic of Taiwan."

Ho said the TSU supports any effort to investigate corruption cases and strike at criminals, but the legislature's investigative power should be granted in the context of a new constitutional framework.

Prior to that, the PFP should agree to review the president's nominations of Control Yuan members so that the Control Yuan can work normally, including probing corruption cases involving ranking officials, Ho added.

PFP Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang said it would have been easy for judicial investigators to check the exit and entry records to find out how many times Chen Che-nan and other suspects have gone abroad, and yet Chen kept lying about the matter while the prosecution dared not question him on it.

The legislator called on the prosecution and police authorities to protect independent lawmaker Chiu Yi and TV talk show host Lee Tao because they had unveiled alleged "evidence" showing that Chen had lied and, he claimed, the authorities might attempt to assassinate them.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.006 to close at NT$33.666.
A total of US$736 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.660 and hit a high of NT$33.735.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved down 29 points to close at 5,675, with 28,506 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December moved down 23 points to end at 5,681, with 273 contracts traded, while March futures lost seven points to finish at 5,698, with two contracts traded. June futures moved down 37 points to close at 5,651, with 13 contracts traded, while September futures moved down 26 points to close at 5,638, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,704 for November, 5,704 for December, 5,705 for March, 5,688 for June and 5,664 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

November TE futures moved down 2.3 points to close at 233.1, with 6,660 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 1.8 points to finish at 233.4, with 31 contract transactions. March TE futures moved down 0.3 points to end at 234.8, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.

November TF futures lost five points to finish at 860.4, with 1,508 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved down four points to end at 860, with 16 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 0.2 points to close at 850.6, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: RFID TESTING FACILITIES TO BOOST TAIWAN'S COMPETITIVENESS

TEXT.P: The launch of Asia's first radio frequency identification (RFID) testing facilities in Taiwan is expected to reinforce the country's pivotal position in the Asia-Pacific supply chains and enhance the international competitiveness of Taiwan's RFID industry, officials said.

The Pacific RFID Performance Solutions, established by the Hsinchu-based Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) to test the readability of products tagged with the electronic product code (EPC), started operations on Wednesday.

It is one of the first four testing facilities, and the only one in Asia, that has been accredited by EPCglobal Inc., the U.S.-based non-profit organization that promotes the commercial adoption of the EPC in global supply chains.
RFID is an automatic identification method that relies on storing and remotely retrieving data using devices called RFID tags.

According to ITRI President Johnsee Lee, Taiwan has gained an edge over its competitors in the region following the establishment of the testing center, and the center will participate in the enactment of international standards on RFID applications in the future to keep Taiwan abreast of the leading RFID services around the world.

Chang Po-kuang, head of the Avionics Systems Department under the ITRI's Center for Aerospace and Systems Technology, pointed out that the U.S.-based retail giant Wal-Mart requires its suppliers to place RFID tags on their shipments, which affects thousands of companies worldwide.
He predicted that almost every industry will need to meet RFID standards in the future and that an industry will enjoy an advantageous position if they can comply with RFID systems early.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS FOR CONSULTATIONS FOR BEIJING OFFICIAL'S TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: An official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday that the DPP insists that official or government-authorized cross-strait dialogue be held on a possible visit to Taiwan by Beijing's top official in charge of Taiwan affairs, Chen Yunlin.
Chen, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, has been invited by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to visit Taiwan in mid-December to attend an economic and trade forum hosted by the party.

DPP Deputy Secretary-General Andes Yen said that Chen could be the highest-ranking Chinese official in charge of relations with Taiwan to ever visit to Taiwan and therefore the issue should not be considered as a simple event involving just the KMT and Communist Party of China (CPC).

Instead, Yen said, Chen's visit will be a matter of great security and safety concern, necessitating official consultations across the strait or at least prior arrangements made by government-authorized intermediary bodies such as Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Yen said that if a Chinese official as high-ranking as Chen is to visit Taiwan, the government will certainly accord high-level security protection to him and should prevent a similar accident from recurring as the one involving the death of a Beijing official in Taipei in September. Zhu Xiangdong, a deputy director of China's National Bureau of Statistics, died of heart failure while taking a hot spring bath on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei Sept. 2.

Meanwhile, Yen questioned the appropriateness of the KMT's invitation to Chen for the KMT-CPC forum, an event the KMT claims as "between parties." Quoting the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, Yen said that "party-to-party exchanges" as claimed by the KMT is not listed in the 19 "professional exchanges" programs stipulated in the statute.
This means that the holding of the KMT-CPC forum in Taiwan might be illegal, Yen said.

Yen added that the KMT's willingness to be "a Taiwan agent of the CPC" is one thing but Taiwan's dealing with such a visit according to the law is another. He called for the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- Taiwan's top China policy planner -- not to budge on Taiwan's stance on Chen's visit.

A KMT spokesman said last week that the KMT-run National Policy Foundation is expected to file for a permit from the MAC shortly to pave the way for Chen and some 50 others from China to take part in the economic cooperation forum slated to be held in Taipei in mid-December.
The forum will be the first of its kind co-sponsored by the KMT and the CPC since the KMT fled to Taiwan in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC MINISTER BARRED FROM VISITING AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Minister Chang Fu-mei said Thursday that her plans to visit Australia have repeatedly been blocked because of opposition by Beijing.

Chang told lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee that she visited Australia during her term in office as a Control Yuan member, but she has not been able to visit the country since she took up her present post.
Chang said she last applied for a visa to Australia in September but was rejected owing to a protest from Beijing.

Addressing the issue, opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lo Chih-ming urged Chang to continue to negotiate with the Australian government to seek to break through Beijing's blockage, in light of the large number of Taiwanese expatriates in Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH PURCHASES RAW MATERIAL FOR TAMIFLU DESPITE SOARING PRICES

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has urgently purchased three tons of shikimic acid, a raw material made in China used to produce the avian influenza-fighting drug Tamiflu.

DOH Minister Ho Sheng-mao said that with the rising global alarm over bird flu, Tamiflu is in short supply and the price of shikimic acid has also soared, adding that this batch of shikimic acid was double the price of the last one and could be even higher in the future.

Ho made the remarks after Premier Frank Hsieh revealed earlier in the day that the government has negotiated a good price to purchase three tons of raw materials that can be used to make enough Tamiflu for 2.3 million people, or about 10 percent of Taiwan's population.

The government will now try to gain authorization to mass produce Tamiflu from its patent holder, Roche Pharmaceuticals, Hsieh said, setting a timetable to mass produce the influenza medicine from the end of December to January next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SON-IN-LAW'S FATHER FILES DEFAMATION SUIT

TEXT.P: Chao Yu-chu, father of President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, went to the Taipei Prosecutor's Office Thursday to file defamation suits against an independent lawmaker and a political commentator.

Chao, a retired school principal, went to court after Legislator Chiu Yi claimed that Chen Che-nan, a former Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, went with a "retired school principal who is closely related to the Presidential Office" to Thailand in November 2004, and that the principal is the "influential figure" in the suspected Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) profiteering scandal.
Chen Che-nan is currently in hot water due to his alleged involvement in the snowballing scandal involving the mass rapid transit system in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Chiu and a political commentator, Hu Chung-hsin, have for several days been casting allegations in a TV talk show. They displayed a photo Wednesday showing Chen Che-nan and Chen Min-hsien, former KRTC vice chairman, gambling in a South Korean casino Nov. 2, 2002.
Chao claimed that he never went with Chen Che-nan to Thailand and that if Chiu has lied, he should step down to take responsibility.
Chao also delivered a three-point statement after filing the lawsuit.

Chao said that he is not the retired principal in question and that he has never gone overseas with Chen Che-nan, nor has he spoken with former Council of Labor Affairs Chen Chu. He said he "filed the lawsuit because he can no longer tolerate their frivolous accusations." Chen Chu reportedly said that an "influential figure" was involved in the hiring of foreign laborers for the MRT system.

The MRT construction scandal came to light in the wake of a series of irregularities exposed after Thai laborers working for the project rioted Aug. 21 to protest against their harsh management and exploitation.
A Supreme Prosecutor Office's investigation found that Chen Che-nan entered Thailand July 6, 2002 and Nov. 11, 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD URGES ECCT TO ELABORATE ON GOVERNMENT OVER-REGULATION

TEXT.P: In response to foreign business community criticism of excessive government regulations, an official said Wednesday that the government is willing to review its policy and urged the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) to come forth with details.

Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Vice Chairman Thomas M.F. Yeh made the comment after the ECCT said in its annual position paper issued earlier the same day that excessive government regulations have hindered Taiwan's economic development and undermined the country's competitiveness regionally and globally.

The government is happy to hear proposals by foreign companies, but they should point out and elaborate on what they called excessive government regulations or on which agencies have over-regulated to the extent that they have affected the country's economic development, Yeh said.

Citing the latest survey made recently by the Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI) , Yeh said that Taiwan is the world's fifth-best in terms of overall investment climate, after Switzerland, Singapore, Holland and Japan, among the 50 countries surveyed.
The BERI report also ranks Taiwan in the 1A category, which Yeh said means that investment and currency exchange risks in Taiwan are low and that the country is a good place in which to invest.

ECCT Chairman Sager Dirk said that he is worried that many European companies are choosing to move out of Taiwan and that should its government fail to address key issues in time to maintain its competitive edges, such as excessive government regulations and Taiwan's abnormal trade and economic relations with China, it will lose even more.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA NEGOTIATING WITH JAPAN ON TAIWANESE FISHING BOAT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative office in Japan has been negotiating with the Japanese authorities over a Taiwanese fishing boat that allegedly operated in disputed waters northeast of a Japanese island group, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday.

Lu said the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) has also sent a patrol boat to meet up with the Taiwanese fishing boat Tsengchinshun No. 168, which was finally intercepted by a Japanese patrol ship around 4: 25 p.m. Thursday for interrogation after being chased for more than two days in the North Pacific for fishing in waters 240 nautical miles northeast of Japan's Ogasawara Archipelago.

Taiwan and Japan have been in a long-running dispute over their overlapping economic zones, with many Taiwanese fishing boats being chased away or detained while operating in waters outside the temporary demarcation line.

CGA officials said they will try to protect the safety of the fishermen aboard the Tsengchinshun No. 168 without making concessions or causing conflict with the Japanese side, while urging both governments to maintain rationality in future fishing conferences.

Meanwhile, Lin Yueh-ying, an official of the Suao Fishery Association in Ilan County, strongly criticized what she described as the "hegemonic behavior" of the Japanese patrol ship, as the Tsengchinshun No. 168 was still chased after leaving the disputed waters.
Lin expressed hope that MOFA will lodge a protest with the Japanese government against this behavior.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO EXCEED SOUTH KOREA IN YEARLY LCD TV PRODUCTION: III

TEXT.P: Taiwan is forecast to exceed South Korea in the output volume of LCD TVs for the first time this year, with an estimated annual output of 5.61 million units compared to Korea's 4.12 million units, according to the newest tallies released by the Institute for Information Industry (III).

Taiwan's third-quarter production volume jumped by 282 percent over the year-earlier level, although the average Q3 unit price grew by only 0.6 percent over the Q2 average as a result of falling prices of flat displays globally, III statistics show.

In terms of production value, Q3 level reached US$790 million, a 242 percent expansion year on year and a 47 percent rise over Q2, thanks to a marked increase in the output of large flat displays, the same tallies show. Q3 shipments of 32-inch flat displays grew several-fold compared to the levels of the previous two quarters.

The III predicted that the world's overall output of LCD TVs for 2005 will hit 18.73 million units, up by 124.6 percent over the 2004 level. The figure will grow to 30.55 million for 2006, accounting for some 15 percent of the entire world's television sets.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANONYMOUS LETTER FUELS SPECULATION ON DPP CAMPAIGN FUNDING

TEXT.P: An anonymous letter included in an Oct. 21 report by a five-member team of the Kaohsiung city government on irregularities involving the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project is fueling speculation over how the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) obtained its campaign funding for the 2004 presidential election.

The letter, received by the civil service ethics office of the Kaohsiung city government Dec. 2, 2002, claims that Chen Min-hsien, vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) at the time, demanded NT$100 million in "public relations fees" from each contractor in return for helping them win their contracts, because he wanted to muster NT$5 billion to fund President Chen Shu-bian's election campaign.

The letter further claims that the Hwang Chang General Contractor Co. won the contract for one of the projects because the company paid Chen Min-hsien NT$2 million in "PR fees" before the bidding. A record of the bidding process shows that Hwang Chang's bid was 99.9 percent accurate compared with the base price.
Wang Lin-chiao, a member of the Kaohsiung city council, told reporters Thursday that she requested a photocopy of the letter from the ethics office but was denied.
Wang said that while acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan had assured that she would publicize all information about her investigation into the KRTC scandal, she was actually doing otherwise.
The city councilor said she believes that what was said in the letter is "highly credible."

Yeh, who headed the five-member team during the two-week investigation at the instruction of the president, said Thursday that the letter has been included in the team's Oct. 21 report because the team had investigated the matter and wanted to present the whole picture of the investigative process.

Yeh pointed out that the very presence of the letter in the report shows that she and her team have nothing to hide. However, she added, the public should not consider the letter as evidence of the KRTC scandal.

The irregularities involving the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project were exposed by an Aug. 21 riot in Kaohsiung County by Thai laborers working on the project in protest of their maltreatment by their employers, the KRTC, and their management, Huapan Administration Consultant Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.N. to Detail Kickbacks Paid for Iraq's Oil
More than 4,500 companies took part in the United Nations oil- for-food program and more than half of them paid illegal surcharges and kickbacks to Saddam Hussein, according to the independent committee investigating the program.
Wall Street Journal: Michelin, Bridgestone Promote Products at Formula One; Benefits Are Hard to Gauge
For the past five years, French tire maker Michelin SCA and Japan's Bridgestone Corp. have battled one another for the right to brag they produce the world's fastest Formula One racing tires. Both companies say Formula One helps them sell more regular tires. But from a marketing standpoint, it is unclear whether either company is winning anything. Michelin spends about US$70 million a year on Formula One, Bridgestone more than US$100 million, people familiar with the numbers say. Neither company can point to hard evidence of an impact on sales and profits.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS PUSH FOR STOP TO MARKETING OF LIVE POULTRY

TEXT.P: A group of legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) pushed Thursday for a halt to the selling of poultry either live or just slaughtered in traditional marketplaces.

DPP Legislators Cheng Yun-peng and Lin Dai-hua called for the government to ban the culling, handling and marketing of live birds in traditional marketplaces as one of the measures to prevent an avian flu epidemic in Taiwan, with fears growing around the world of a possible bird flu pandemic.

Showing a video tape recording the marketing of poultry in a Taipei traditional marketplace at a press conference, the legislators said that the poultry trade -- in which dealers slaughter, handle and market the poultry without wearing a face mask or any protective gear and no refrigeration -- could be an opening for a bird flu epidemic.
Cheng said that around 350 million chickens are killed and sold in Taiwan each year and about 80 percent of these are properly processed in slaughterhouses where refrigeration is available.
Although only about 20 percent of the poultry is sold live or just slaughtered in traditional marketplaces, they could pose an opening in Taiwan's bird flu-response network, Cheng warned.

Responding to the DPP legislators' call, Lee Yi-chian, an official with the Animal Industry Department under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said that the council will make efforts in this regard and at the same time call for consumers to change their preference for warm freshly killed poultry.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA URGED TO STUDY ALLOWING AIRPORTS TO BE RUN BY PRIVATE INVESTORS

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang legislator urged the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Thursday to study the feasibility of allowing private companies to operate commercial airports in an effort to help the government balance its books.

Legislator Wang Yu-ting proposed at a joint-committee session at the Legislative Yuan that the CAA conduct research and come up with a plan in six months to allow private companies to operate airports that are only for commercial air traffic around the country, currently numbering 18.

Of the 18 airports, according to Wang, only the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and Kaohsiung's Hsiao-kang Airport are profit-making, while Taipei's Sungshan Airport barely breaks even. The rest, mostly located in offshore areas, operate in the red, Wang said.

Wang said that for security reasons, the money-losing airports could be run by private investors while areas pertaining to public authority power, including navigation and control towers, airport security and quarantine affairs, could be still managed by the CAA.

Wang suggested that the CAA lease one or two money-losing airports to private operators for a period of time on a trial basis and have the companies report to the Legislative Yuan on their operations.
Wang's proposal was endorsed by seven legislators from across the political spectrum on the first day of its initiation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER OFFICIAL DENIES TRIP TO SOUTH KOREA WAS RELATED TO KRTC

TEXT.P: Former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan issued a statement Thursday admitting that he traveled to Cheju, South Korea in November 2002 with the then-vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC), but denied that the trip was related to KRTC's plan to borrow Korean experience in hiring Thai laborers.
Chen made an open apology because he did not report to President Chen Shui-bian about the trip, either beforehand or after he returned.

He explained that his trip to South Korea with Chen Min-hsien, vice chairman of KRTC at the time, took place Nov. 1-3, 2002 and was purely for pleasure. Therefore, he added, there was no need for him to submit a report to the president.

Chen Che-nan, who became a national policy adviser to the president in 2004, and Chen Min-hsien, chairman of the Southeast Cement Corp., who had been an adviser to the president since 2002, both resigned from their posts in the Presidential Office Oct. 5 amid wide speculation about their involvement in a scandal of the KRTC exploiting some 1,400 Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project.

Chen Che-nan released his statement after newspapers carried a picture showing him and Chen Min-hsien sitting at a gambling table in a casino on Cheju Island Nov. 2, 2002. He had previously denied that he had ever been on overseas trips with KRTC officials, admitting to only one trip to Thailand with a friend.

A spokesman for the Presidential Office said Thursday that there is no record of Chen Che-nan having asked for leave to visit South Korea while he was deputy secretary-general at the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP QUESTIONS RATIONALITY OF PENSION PAYOUTS FOR EX-KMT CADRES

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers questioned Thursday the rationality of the pension coverage for some retired civil servants for their years of service in the Kuomintang (KMT) , which ruled Taiwan for more than five decades until May 2000.

The legislators from the DPP's Justice Alliance faction said the previous practice of converting KMT cadres' years of service in party posts into years of government work was a tactic designed to siphon taxpayers' money into the KMT's coffers.

Legislator Jaw Yung-ching said the Examination Yuan passed a set of rules in 1971 to allow for the conversion of years of service in the then-ruling KMT and its affiliates, such as the China Youth Corps, into years of service in the government, for the benefit of its cadres who were later transferred to government posts. The preferential rules remained valid until 1987.
"Such provisions were remnants of the previous KMT authoritarian rule," Jaw said.
Among the numerous beneficiaries of those preferential rules is incumbent KMT Vice Chairman John Kuan, Jaw said.

"When Kuan retired from public service, his 10 years of service in the KMT was calculated into his years of service in the government. As such, the government has to pay out millions of additional dollars for his pension," Jaw said.
Jaw said he will ask the Ministry of Civil Service under the Examination Yuan to make an overall review of how many former KMT officials enjoy the same privilege.

Vice Minister of Civil Service Wu Tsung-cheng said KMT cadres who were transferred to government posts after the above-mentioned rules were abolished in 1987 are not eligible to receive the "conversion" privilege.
According to Wu, the government handles 300-400 civil servant retirement cases each year. Among them, only a very few are qualified for the "conversion" privilege.

In line with the principle of policy continuity or the "non-retroactiveness" principle, Wu said, the government must still give pension coverage for ex-KMT cadres who transferred to government posts prior to 1987.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORPORATIONS MORE PESSIMISTIC ABOUT PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's corporations are more pessimistic toward their business prospects for the next three months than before due to seasonal factors and mostly out of fear of a possible bird flu pandemic, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Thursday.

In a recent council survey of the private business and industrial sectors' business prospects for the next three months, CEPD officials found that only 9 percent of the respondents predicted that their business prospects will improve in the following three months, against 19 percent posted in July.
A total of 66 percent of the respondents said the business climate is expected to remain unchanged for the next quarter, as compared with 65 percent who responded in this way in the July survey.

The number of respondents who anticipated that their businesses will decline rose to 25 percent from 16 percent posted in July, CEPD officials said, adding that the 25-percent level marked a new high since May 2003.
As a result, they added, the number of pessimists was 16 percentage points higher than the number of optimists, representing a new high since October 2001.

CEPD officials attributed the gloomy prospects to a variety of reasons, including the anticipation of an end to the high season and spiralling commodity and raw material prices, as well as fears of a possible bird flu pandemic worldwide.

The survey also found that most of Taiwan's private corporations enjoyed better business performance, including sales, orders, equipment utility and profit margins, in September compared to August, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO LODGE PROTEST WITH JAPAN OVER FISHING BOAT INSPECTION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will lodge a protest with Japan over its coast guard officers' boarding of a Taiwanese fishing boat for inspection in international waters, fishery officials said Thursday.

Officials from the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture (COA) made the remarks after receiving reports from Taiwan's representative office in Japan confirming that the Tsengchinshun No. 168 was intercepted by a Japanese coast guard patrol for interrogation after being chased across the North Pacific for more than two days for alleged intrusion into Japan's exclusive economic zone.
As the Tsengchinshun was then on the high seas, the officials said, the Japanese coast guard patrol was in violation of international law by boarding the ship.
"We'll ask the MOFA to file a protest with Japan, " said a Fisheries Administration official.
He further said a Taiwan coast guard patrol is on its way to the site to push its Japanese counterpart into releasing the Taiwan fishing vessel and its crew.
The Tsengchinshun was spotted by the Japanese coast guard patrol Oct. 25 when it was allegedly fishing in waters 240 nautical miles northeast of Japan's Ogasawara Archipelago.
"It requires further checks to determine whether the Tsengchinshun was truly operating in Japan's economic zone, " the official said.

Taiwan and Japan have been embroiled in a long-running dispute over their overlapping economic zones, with many Taiwanese fishing boats being chased away or detained while operating in waters outside a temporary "demarcation line."

Coast Guard Administration officials said they will try to protect the safety of the fishermen aboard the Tsengchinshun without making concessions or causing conflict with the Japanese side, while urging both governments to maintain rationality in future fishery conferences.

DOC.HEADLINE: CASINO MAY NOT BE 'INAPPROPRIATE PLACE' FOR PUBLIC SERVANTS

TEXT.P: The Central Personnel Administration (CPA) under the Cabinet declined to specify Thursday whether public servants should avoid visiting casinos when they are on overseas trips, although the Civic Service Law prohibits such functionaries from going to "inappropriate places."
Chien Shih-chung, general secretary of the CPA, pointed out that the Civic Service Law does not provide a clear definition of "inappropriate places."
Nor does the Ministry of Civil Service under the Examination Yuan provide any guidelines on what constitutes an "inappropriate place, " he said.
Chien expressed concern that disputes could arise if tourist casinos, where people on sightseeing trips go for pleasure, are deemed "inappropriate places" according to the law.

The question of whether public servants are breaking the law if they visit a casino became a subject of debate after newspapers carried a picture Thursday showing two officials of the Presidential Office sitting at a gambling table in a casino on Cheju Island, South Korea, in November 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO PROPOSE LAW REVISIONS FOR LEGISLATIVE INVESTIGATIVE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will come up with draft law revisions to forge a framework for the Legislative Yuan to exercise its "investigative power," a DPP lawmaker said Thursday.

Legislator Ker Chien-ming, who concurrently heads the DPP's policy coordination department, said the DPP respects the spirit of a Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) constitutional ruling of Dec. 15, 2004 that allows for the Legislative Yuan to investigate certain cases with the consent of a majority of lawmakers.

Nevertheless, Ker said, many laws must be revised before such a ruling can be put into practice; otherwise, he said, the investigative power would become yet another tool for partisan wrangling and could even infringe upon many people's human rights.

If the legislature exercises the so-called "investigative power," Ker said, a number of statutes, including the law governing the legislature's exercise of power, the lawmakers' code of conduct and the law requiring public functionaries to avoid conflicts of interest, must be amended. If all goes well, Ker said, the DPP caucus can present a formal proposal next Monday to pave the way for revisions to all relevant laws to regulate the Legislative Yuan's exercise of "investigative power."
According to the Constitution, "investigative power" has traditionally rested with the Control Yuan, not the Legislative Yuan.

Quoting the CGJ's No. 585 Constitutional Ruling, opposition People First Party legislative caucus whip Huang Yi-chiao said earlier in the day that the legislature has the authority to call witnesses and read all related documents when investigating a major scandal.

Huang further said that Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng has agreed to let lawmakers deliberate his party's proposal to amend the law governing the legislature's exercise of its powers Nov. 8 in order to substantiate its "investigative power" as defined by the CGJ in its No. 585 constitutional ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITY OFFICIALS ON GUARD AHEAD OF CHINESE OFFICIAL'S ARRIVAL

TEXT.P: National security authorities have stepped up preparations for the arrival of China's top tourism administrator, industry sources said Thursday.
Shao Qiwei, director of the National Tourism Administration under China's State Council, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Friday for a 10-day market inspection tour.

Travel sources said the National Security Council invited officials from the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and other relevant government agencies to a meeting a few days ago to discuss security measures and emergency response programs.
According to the sources, security authorities would pull out all the stops to ensure that Shao's visit proceed smoothly and safely.
Shao will be visiting Taiwan in the name of president of the Chinese National Travel Association in line with China's stance of no official contact with Taiwan.
He will be accompanied by a 66-member delegation composed of senior executives of travel associations and tourist agencies in various Chinese provinces and cities.

Shao's visit was arranged by the Taiwan Visitors Association which has invited Taiwan's Tourism Bureau Director Hsu Wen-sheng to attend a dinner party in honor of Shao's mission Friday evening. Hsu will be the only Taiwan official that Shao would meet during his visit, the association said.
Shao's visit is widely seen a prelude to China allowing its citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, travel sources said national security officials are treating Shao's visit as a drill for a proposed visit by an even higher-ranking Chinese official-- Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council -- in mid-December.
The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has filed an application for Chen and other senior Taiwan Affairs Office officials to come to Taipei to attend a seminar in mid-December.
The seminar will be co-sponsored by the KMT and its adversary-turned-partner, the Communist Party of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWITZERLAND TO OFFER TAIWAN JUDICIAL AID IN LAFAYETTE SCANDAL PROBES

TEXT.P: The Swiss Federal Commission approved Thursday the handover of bank files to foreign judicial authorities concerning the controversial sale of French warships to Taiwan.

The Swiss commission rejected an appeal by fugitive Taiwanese arms broker Andrew Wang -- who is suspected of organizing massive rake-offs -- to stop judicial cooperation with Taiwan, France, and Liechtenstein.

A French judicial investigation was opened in 2001 into claims that a large part of the US$2.8 billion paid by Taiwan for the six Lafayette-class frigates in 1991 went on commissions to middlemen, politicians and military officers in Taiwan, China and France.

Wang, who fled Taiwan more than 10 years ago, had claimed that Switzerland's national interest was at stake when he argued against allowing foreign authorities to study Swiss bank documents related to the case.
But the seven-member Swiss governing commission said that failing to cooperate was not in Switzerland's interests.

Noting that all three countries had ongoing investigations into the Lafayette deal, the Swiss Federal Commission ruled that it was vital for Switzerland to ensure that its financial sector was not used for criminal purposes.

The commission's decision will open the way for judicial exchanges between Switzerland and Taiwan. It will be the first Taiwan-Switzerland judicial aid case. For fear of offending China, the commission said its decision doesn't constitute a diplomatic recognition of Taiwan.
Last year, Switzerland's highest court decided that there was sufficient evidence to implicate Wang in the affair and overruled his bid to keep the bank documents under wraps.

On Oct. 6 this year, the Swiss court further ruled that bank documents relating to the Lafayette kickback case should be turned over to Taiwan's government because its has guaranteed that it will not invoke the death penalty against Andrew.
Premier Frank Hsieh gave the "no death penalty" assurances Aug. 26 and the Swiss court was satisfied, enabling the transfer of the documents.
Taiwan has charged Wang with murder, corruption, money laundering and fraud. He was an agent in Taiwan for Thomson-CSF, the French company that sold the frigates to Taiwan.

Wang fled Taiwan following the death of ROC Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng, who was widely believed to have been murdered when he was about to blow the whistle on colleagues for allegedly taking kickbacks in the deal.
The ships had all been delivered to Taiwan by the mid-1990s, and both Switzerland and Liechtenstein have frozen funds in Wang's and his son's accounts that are allegedly linked to the case.
The investigations began when the Taiwanese authorities concluded from the inflated price that the deal constituted a serious case of international corruption.
France, Liechtenstein and Taiwan, investigating whether the case had violated their laws, asked the Swiss authorities to hand over the bank documents to facilitate their investigations.

According to media reports, some US$500 million remains frozen in 46 accounts with different banks in Switzerland as part of a Swiss investigation into alleged money laundering linked to the case. Authorities in neighboring Liechtenstein have frozen around US$27 million as part of their own investigations, the reports said.

Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-hua said earlier this month that the government should have Wang extradited back to Taiwan to serve as asuspect-turned-prosecution-witness to facilitate the probe into whether any Taiwan politicians or military officials obtained illegal kickbacks from the Lafayette deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 28, or the 26th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: Christopher Columbus discovers Cuba on his first voyage to the New World and claims it in the name of Spain.
1636: Harvard College is founded at Cambridge by the General Court of Massachusetts on the comparatively modest sum of US$740, part of US$1,440 bequeathed to the university by Mr. John Harvard, assistant pastor of the First Church of Charleston.
1746: An earthquake completely destroys Lima and Callao in Peru, killing more than 18,000 people.
1794: Robert Liston, the Scottish doctor who performed the first operation in Britain on an anesthetized patient, is born.
1886: A statue called Liberty Enlightening the World, the largest present ever sent to the American people from the French, is inaugurated on Liberty Island in the Upper Bay of New York Harbor by President Grover Cleveland.
1891: A strong earthquake rocks the Niphon Islands in Japan, killing 10,000 people and leaving more than 300,000 others homeless.
1901: Taiwan's first Shinto shrine is inaugurated on Yuanshan in Taipei during Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan.
1912: Sir Richard Doll, the British cancer researcher who proved the link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer, is born.
1914: Jonas Salk, the American microbiologist who developed a polio vaccine, is born.
1950: Finland establishes diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1953: A launch ceremony for the first batch of U.S.-provided fishing boats to Taiwan is held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
1962: Soviet leader Nikita Krushchev informs U.S. President John F. Kennedy that work on missile sites under construction in Cuba will be halted and that missiles already delivered will be shipped back to the USSR.
1966: Wu Chen-nan, former leader of the "Taiwan Independence Revolutionary Council" in Japan, returns to Taiwan.
1972: Two pandas, a gift from Communist China to Japan, arrive at the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo.
1973: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi and two other Japanese leaders arrives in Taipei to extend birthday congratulations to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1977: Taiwan's first experimental geothermal power plant goes into operation in Ilan.
1979: Movie star James Mason arrives in Taipei to attend the Golden Horse Awards presentation ceremony at the invitation of the Movie and Drama Association of the ROC.
1980: Asaad Abdul Aziz Al-Zuhair, the first resident Saudi Arabian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Felipe Gonzales, 40, becomes Spain's first Socialist prime minister in a landslide victory.
1992: Australian Tourism and Resources Minister Alan Griffiths visits Taipei to promote closer bilateral trade relations. He is the first Australian minister to visit Taipei since 1972.
1993: An explosion occurs at Taiwan Power Company's Hsintienlun power plant in central Taiwan, killing six people and injuring 26 others.
1993: Communist China resumes trade relations with South Africa, cut off since July 1960.
1999: Renowned Japanese writer Ayako Sono arrives in Taipei, bringing with her a cash donation of 300 million yen (US$2.88 million) and immeasurable compassion for Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: Former Finance Minister Paul Chiu is ordered to post NT$600,000 bail after he was formally questioned by a Taipei district prosecutor about his alleged wrongdoings during his tenure as finance minister.
2001: Amid increased exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Philippine Airlines begins operating flights on the Taipei-Manila-Shanghai route.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "He who attends to his smaller self becomes a small man, and he who attends to his greater self becomes a great man."
