DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BOAT RELEASED AFTER PAYING JAPANESE FISHERIES AGENCY
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, eastern Taiwan, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan fishing boat which was intercepted by the Japanese coast guard Thursday for allegedly intruding into Japan's exclusive economic zone was released Friday after family of the boat's skipper paid 500,000 yen (US$4,336) to the Japanese Fisheries Agency authorities, Suao Fishermen's Association officials said Friday.

The Suao-based "Tsengchinshun No. 168" was reportedly spotted by the Japanese coast guard patrol Oct. 25 fishing in waters 200 nautical miles northeast of Japan's Ogasawara Archipelago. It was intercepted in international waters after a two-and-a-half day chase.
The vessel was released around noon Friday after family of skipper Tseng Yung-chang remitted 500,000 yen to the Japanese authorities at 9 a.m. the same day, association officials said.

Officials from the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture (COA) said late Thursday that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will lodge a protest with Japan over its coast guard officers' boarding of the "Tsengchinshun No. 168" for inspection in international waters.
According to COA officials, Taiwan's representative office in Japan confirmed Thursday that the vessel was intercepted by Japanese coast guard forces after being chased for two-and-a-half days.
As the vessel was on the high seas when it was intercepted, the officials said, the Japanese coast guard patrol violated international law by boarding the ship.

Taiwan and Japan have been embroiled in a long-running dispute over their overlapping economic zones, with many Taiwanese fishing boats being chased away or detained while operating in waters outside a temporary "demarcation line."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS HE IS BEST MAN TO PUSH FOR CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he is the best man to push for constitutional reforms as the world's experience has shown that a re-elected president who no longer has the pressure of running for re-election is best suited to promote such reforms.

President Chen made the remarks while attending the opening of an international seminar on "Constitutional Re-engineering in New Democracies -- Taiwan and the World" in Taipei. More than 200 scholars and experts at home and abroad are attending the two-day event, which has been organized by a Presidential Office panel promoting constitutional reforms.

Chen, serving his second term since May 20, 2004, said he himself has no pressure of running again and "regardless of who serves as the next president in 2008, the timing to promote constitutional reforms couldn't be better than the present."

In the next two years, he will make every effort to be a constitutional reform crusader, noting that the government will recruit seed instructors, and hold 10,000 seminars to invite public discussion by 2007 in a constitutional reform awareness campaign to generate the highest level of social consensus on the scope and procedure of the constitutional reform.

He stressed the importance of his next stage of constitutional reform, adding that he will have no preset stance on the direction of reforms, and that he will give full support to whatever reforms supported by the majority of the people.
"By the time I complete my presidency in 2008, I hope to hand to Taiwan a new version of our Constitution -- one that is timely, relevant and viable," he reaffirmed.

He noted that since the beginning of 1990, at least 30 countries, including South Africa, Mongolia and Thailand have crafted new constitutions or amended their constitutions and upgraded their governance through constitutional re-engineering.

He said that after past rounds of constitutional amendments in 1994 and 1996, the election system of the president has been changed to popular election, and the president can appoint the premier without the consent of the Legislative Yuan. The nation's government system has tilted toward a presidential one, but the president has no right to veto bills passed by the legislature and can only dissolve the legislature after the legislature topples the Cabinet, he said.
Therefore, he said that if the president and the majority party in the legislature belong to two rival parties, the government could face total paralysis.

Citing the past five years which have seen endless squabbling between the ruling and the opposition parties as an example, he said that the nation's governance has stalled, which he asserted is "definitely related to our Constitution which can't provide a legal mechanism to solve political stalemates."
The president stressed that there are flaws and deficiencies in the present Constitution even after seven rounds of constitutional amendments over more than a decade.

He said the next phase of reforms is expected to address issues such as whether to change the country's political system to a presidential system or parliamentary system; protection of basic human rights and the rights of the disadvantaged; defining the rights and obligations of the central and the local governments; streamlining the government agencies; lowering the voting age from 20 to 18; and adopting a voluntary military service system.
"Even according to the most conservative estimates, more than two-thirds of the 175 articles in the Constitution need amendment, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO PITCH IN WITH BIRD FLU-RESPONSE WORK IN EVENT OF OUTBREAK

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will pitch in with avian flu-response work in the event of an outbreak in Taiwan, an official with Taiwan's top charter of mainland policy said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu said that currently, as Taiwan is bird flu-free but is preparing to battle a possible bird flu pandemic, the Council of Agriculture is handling all related matters.
In the event of an avian flu outbreak in Taiwan, the Department of Health will take the helm in the bird flu-response work, with the MAC pitching in any way that it can, Liu noted.

Liu quoted reports from China as indicating that so far, bird flu cases have been reported in Tibet, Inner Mongolia autonomous region and six Chinese provinces including Hunan, Anhui, Fujian, Jiangsu, Qinghai and Xinjiang.

Liu added that in a bid to keep bird flu at bay, Taiwan began on Oct. 26 to require that passengers from China, Hong Kong and Macau as well as people entering the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu from Fujian Province conduct a 10-day self-health monitoring program, including daily temperature taking, after their arrival.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEXT STAGE IN LAFAYETTE SCANDAL PROBE 'A TOUGHER CHALLENGE': ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top envoy in Berne said Thursday that he sees the next stage of retrieving the money payed out as kickbacks in the scandal surrounding the sale of French Lafayette frigates to Taiwan and of implementing the legal assistance offered by Swiss authorities to the island as "a tougher challenge."
Wang Shih-rong, Taiwan's representative to Switzerland, made the remarks after the Swiss Federal Council approved providing Taiwan with legal assistance.

In a press release it issued earlier in the day, the council agreed to hand over documents to the judicial authorities of Taiwan, France and Liechtenstein regarding the scandal. The Swiss government also rejected Taiwan businessman Andrew Wang's administrative appeal attempting to stop judicial cooperation among the three nations.
Andrew Wang, a major suspect in the scandal, said that providing legal assistance could go against the interests of the Central European country.

Refuting the businessman's claims, the council said that the Swiss financial center is not used for criminal purposes, but for improving the transparency of commercial transactions. It further said that the scandal involves money laundering, fraud and homicide, and also involves a criminal organization.

Saying that he "feels greatly relieved" after the Swiss government approved the hand over of documents to Taiwan, the Republic of China diplomat also expressed his highest respect for the Swiss government and its judicial body's spirit of venerating the law and putting the law above politics.

However, he said that the council's decision only represents the completion of the administrative and judicial organs' procedures, adding that the work of the next stage will be focused on how to carry out the judicial cooperation between Taiwan and Switzerland as well as on how to obtain evidence of Andrew Wang's crime in connection with the scandal.

As to Andrew Wang and his family members' deposit of about US$495 million in Swiss banks, which has been frozen on order by the Swiss judges, the envoy said that "getting the illegal commissions back is also the goal of future efforts, which will certainly be a tougher mission."

The representative also said that he will discuss with Swiss officials on how to carry out matters related to the legal assistance and will arrange for members of Taiwan's State Public Prosecutor General's Office under the Ministry of Justice to discuss with their Swiss counterparts details of implementing such assistance.

Wu Ying-chao, state public prosecutor general, has said that although his office has yet to receive official notification from the Swiss government, it can send its prosecutors to Switzerland any time to retrieve the relevant documents.
The French company Thomson closed a deal in 1991 with Taiwan for the sale of six frigates at a price of around US$2.5 billion.

According to the Swiss judicial authorities, although a clause in the contract expressly forbids the payment of commission, the Taiwanese authorities concluded from the inflated price that the deal constituted a serious case of international corruption.

Taiwan submitted on Nov. 6, 2001 a request for legal assistance from Switzerland in connection with the case on the grounds that it involved fraud, money laundering and corruption, also according to the Swiss judicial authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 28.21 points to close at 5,632.97.
The bourse opened at 5,646.8 and fluctuated between 5,690.98 and 5,618.9 during trading. A total of 2.94 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$68.19 billion (US$2.03 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up at 1.5 percent and plastics and chemicals shares gaining 1.1 percent.

The other six major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.5 percent, construction issues at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 592 to 373, with 181 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi criticizes EU accord.
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi criticized in a meeting in London Thursday the European Union accord that sets the government's budget deficit ceiling at three percent of the gross domestic product. He argued that the government should have the right to spend in deficit for maintaining its country's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Nomination Was Plagued By Missteps From the Start.
For Harriet Miers, the "murder boards" were aptly named. Day after day in a room in the Justice Department, colleagues from the Bush administration grilled her on constitutional law, her legal background and her past speeches in practice sessions meant to mimic Senate hearings, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush's Court Choice Ends Bid; Conservatives Attacked Miers
Harriet E. Miers abruptly withdrew her nomination for the U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday after withering attacks from conservatives and weeks of doubt from both political parties about her qualifications for the job. Her decision forces President Bush to s cramble for a new nominee at a time of growing disarray at the White House. Members of both part ies said that the most powerful factor for the withdrawal was the strong opposition from conservatives who questioned Ms. Miers's ideology on abortion and other social issues and saw her as an impediment to their decades-long goal of control of the court.
Wall Street Journal: Telecom Giant Gets Demands As It Negotiates TV Deals; Cameras for Santa's Visit Lining Up 10,000 Contracts
All over the United States, Verizon is squaring off against local governments, as it embarks on a high-stakes upgrade of much of its network. Aiming to offer Internet, phone and tele vision services, Verizon plans to spend up to $20 billion to lay thousands of miles of fiber- optic wires across its East Coast service area from Maine to Florida and into parts of Texas, California and elsewhere. Budget-strapped local officials, who have the final say over granting cable-TV-service franchises, are greeting the phone giant with expensive and detailed demands. In New York state, Verizon faces requests for seed money for wildflowers and a video hookup for Christmas celebrations. The battle is crucial for Verizon, which is rapidly losing its traditional customers in a new telecommunications free-for-all. The rivals include wireless phone companies, cable companies offering low-priced phone service, and Web companies such as Google Inc. offering voice services via the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: Widespread Sympathy for Kaloyev State Duma Speaker Boris Gryzlov said Thursday that Vitaly Kaloyev, who was sentenced by a Swiss court to eight years in prison for killing an air traffic controller, deserved his punishment, but other officials and the media suggested that the court should have shown leniency.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: New training system set up to help workers.
No Appropriate paper qualifications? No problem. Singapore is opening several training institutions which will take in any worker with the relevant practical experience.
They will be set up over the next three years under a new government initiative announced yesterday by Manpower Minister Ng Eng Hen.
The Lianhe Zaobao: S$100 million offer complete traning for workers.
Singapore Government will offer S$100 million to set up a new training system called the Singapore Workforce Skills and Qualifications System to train the people to be a qualified worker.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Tycoon Tsutsumi found guilty of fraud
The Tokyo District Court on Thursday handed Yoshiaki Tsutsumi, former chairman of Kokudo Corp. and Seibu Railway Co. a suspended 30- month prison term and fined him five million yen for falsifying financial statements and engaging in insider trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES CHINESE TOURISM OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu extended a welcome Friday to Chinese National Tourism Administration Director Shao Qiwei, who arrived in Taiwan in the afternoon for a visit.

Speaking at a weekly news briefing, Liu explained that the purpose of Shao's visit is purely to gain an understanding of Taiwan's tourist spots and relevant facilities, and he urged everyone to respect the purpose of his visit and not to interfere.

While in Taiwan, Shao will only meet representatives from the tourism industry and will not touch on issues related to cross-strait negotiations, Liu added, noting that the Chinese tourism official's visit is a requirement of the Chinese government before it decides to allow its people to sightsee in Taiwan.

The MAC vice chairman also urged China to speed up its pace in related preparations and pointed out that China is yet to add Taiwan to its overseas tourist destination list. Taiwan is poised to open up further to tourists from China after beginning to do so on a trial basis in 2002, he said.

Traveling at the head of a 66-member delegation of provincial tourism officials, reporters and industry representatives, Shao arrived Friday afternoon for a 10-day visit in his capacity as Chinese National Travel Association president at the invitation of the Taiwan Visitors' Association.
Taiwan Visitors' Association President S. L. Chang will host a dinner party for Shao Friday night in Taipei. Tourism Bureau Director General Hsu Wen-sheng will also attend the party.

Meanwhile, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san made it clear that he will not meet Shao during Shao's stay in Taiwan, as he has to make reports to the Legislative Yuan on his ministry's budget allocations.
Lin welcomed Shao's visit to the island and expressed the hope that he will be able to gain a detailed understanding of present-day Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved down 15 points to close at 5,660, with 23,730 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December moved down 24 points to end at 5,657, with 178 contracts traded, while March futures lost 37 points to finish at 5,656, with three contracts traded. September futures moved down 30 points to close at 5,600, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,675 for November, 5,681 for December, 5,693 for March, 5,659 for June and 5,630 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

November TE futures moved down 0.5 points to close at 232.6, with 4,506 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 0.6 points to finish at 232.8, with 28 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down 0.6 points to end at 231.3, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and September.

November TF futures lost 10.4 points to finish at 850, with 1,964 contracts changing hands, while December TF futures moved down 10.8 points to end at 849.2, with 38 contracts traded. March TF futures moved down 9.2 points to close at 850.2, with one contract transaction, while June TF futures lost 6.2 points to finish at 853, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED TO RESHUFFLE CABINET NOW: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that there is no need to reshuffle the Cabinet at present, saying that his administration team was doing a good job, although some Cabinet members have not actively defended its policies.
The premier made the remarks while fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan.

Hsieh said that the legislature is currently reviewing the budget submitted by the Cabinet and pointed out that since the budget has been submitted by the incumbent ministers, were those ministers to be replaced, lawmakers might ask for a resubmission of the budget, arguing that those who drew up the budget were no longer in place to answer questions about it.

The premier also said that with the current political stalemate, due to ceaseless bickering between the ruling and the opposition parties, even a good minister had a difficult time pushing for his work, and a problem couldn't be solved by replacing one or two ministers.

With the recent indictment of Lee Chin-cheng, a former Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) ranking official indicted on charges of insider trading, known as the "vulture case," some lawmakers have asked for the resignation of FSC Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng, who had openly endorsed Lee when the case first came to light early this year.
The premier said that he respected Kong's professionalism in his work, adding that Kong had been overseas for a long time and may not be familiar with local political culture.

Kong said the previous day that he felt regret about Lee, for whom the prosecutors have demanded eight year's imprisonment for leaking information and on other charges, and will wait for the judicial verdict on the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIMPLO'S BATTERY PACKS FOR NB COMPUTERS TO BECOME WORLD NO. 1 PRODUCTBy Lilian WuCNA staff writer

TEXT.P: Although small, Taiwan has seen quite a few of its products make it to No. 1 on the international stage, and Simplo Technology Co. -- a leading manufacturer of battery packs for notebook (NB) computers -- is expected to join the ranks of Taiwan's No. 1 products in 2006.

Taiwan began to actively produce NB battery packs in the 1980s. Because of the low threshold for capital and technology required, the number of manufacturers mushroomed to more than 100 at one time. A lot of smaller manufactures were eventually squeezed out because of steep competition and the remaining, bigger manufacturers now enjoy handsome profits.

Analysts have attributed the fast growth of Taiwan's NB battery pack manufacturers to low cost, flexibility, comprehensive service, and logistics management, and Simplo Technology has been outstanding in all of these.

With Taiwan's NB battery packs expected to reach a more than 50 percent world market share next year, Simplo is expected to reach a world market share of around 25 percent in 2006 from the estimated 20 percent this year, replacing Sanyo of Japan to become the No. 1 in the world.

Simplo, which until 1998 was a money-losing company, has seen its drastic transformation in a short time due to a number of key factors, including its high quality, punctual delivery, flexible production support and overall service, and last but not least, its president and chairman, Raymond Sung.
Sung, 56, worked at several U.S. companies, including Ampex Electronics, AST and Kingston Technology, for a quarter of a century, before joining Simplo.

Being content with "playing second-fiddle," Sung said that he had never thought of serving in his present position until "a good friend of mine came with the offer and I accepted it with the intention of testing my limits."

Sung said that when he came to the company in 1998, he found that the company has a solid basis in terms of battery pack technology, what seemed to be lacking, however, was a systematic management approach, and which "happened to be my advantage."
Sung often told his staff that they should not say that something is " impossible," adding, "I'm a man who can accept trial and error, but they should never say impossible before trying something."

Before entering Simplo, Sung said that he had mostly dealt with Japanese customers, and he said that Simplo's entrepreneurial culture must be the "efficiency of Americans and work ethnic of the Japanese."

He pointed out two major turning points in the company, saying that before 1999, the company had focused on original equipment manufacturering (OEM), mainly for Matsushita of Japan. But he knew at the time that if the company stuck to OEM, it would have limited growth and development.

This was why Simplo set up a research and development team in 1999 and moved toward original design manufacturering (ODM). In 2000, Simplo obtained orders from local second-tier NB computer manufacturers, laying a solid basis for getting orders from the top-notch NB computer manufacturers such as Acer and Quanta.

The second turning point for Simplo was receiving orders from HP in the fourth quarter of 2002, which was a major milestone, Sung said, because it symbolized the recognition of an internationally renowned company. Dell then joined HP to be Simplo's leading customers, he said.

In view of growing demands as well as cutting production costs, Simplo has moved its assembly lines to China. Its Shanghai complex began construction in early 2002 and the second factory in the complex was completed last year.

In the meantime, the revenues of Simplo have continued to grow, topping NT$1.1 billion in September, or a new high for three consecutive months. The revenues in the first nine months have totaled NT$7.75 billion (US$2.31 billion), up 18 percent from the same period the previous year and far ahead of its financial estimate.

Japan and Taiwan have been two strongholds of battery packs for global NB computers. Taiwan's production of battery packs for NB computers accounts for a global market share of around 40 percent this year, still lower than 60 percent for Japan.
It is expected that the production of Taiwan manufacturers will continue to grow, and will account for a world market share of more than 50 percent, while Japan will slip to below 50 percent.
Simplo has set the goal of producing 11 million units of battery packs for this year, and 15 million units next year, with a world market share of 25 percent in 2006.
The nation's Industrial Technology Research Institute has estimated that Taiwan will produce between 56 million and 58 million units of NB computers this year, and 68 million units next year.
Thanks to the steady growth of the NB computer industry, battery pack manufacturers are expected to continue to prosper, industrial analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENTIAL AIDE FACES PUNISHMENT OVER CONTROVERSIAL KOREA TRIP

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office will refer Chen Che-nan, one of its former deputy secretary-generals, to the Control Yuan for punishment for visiting South Korea in 2002 without asking for leave, an official said Friday.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said that Chen might have violated the Public Service Act.
According to Yu, President Chen Shui-bian is very unhappy with Chen Che-nan's behavior, which the president has said is unlawful and especially inappropriate for a political appointee.

At the center of a profiteering scandal surrounding the hiring of Thai workers for the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit project, Chen Che-nan admitted Thursday that he traveled to Cheju, South Korea in November 2002 with Chen Min-hsien, then vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC).
However, Chen Che-nan denied the trip was related to the KRTC's plan to make use of Korean experience in hiring Thai workers.

Chen Che-nan, who had previously denied having traveled overseas with KRTC officials, made the confession following the broadcasting on local TV of a picture showing him and Chen Min-hsien appearing in a casino on Cheju island on Nov. 2, 2002.

Chen Che-nan became a national policy adviser to the president in 2004, while Chen Min-hsien had been an adviser to the president since 2002. Both resigned from their posts on Oct. 5 after judicial authorities launched a probe into their roles in the scandal, which surfaced in the wake of a Aug. 21 riot by a group of Thai workers against exploitation and ill-treatment by their management.

Also on Friday, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang said the party's Central Standing Committee will meet Saturday night to discuss what disciplinary measures to take against Chen Che-nan.
Su said that the DPP will deal with the case with the highest standards and will consider handing down the sternest possible punishment, namely an expulsion.
Su said any party members who broke the law or behaved dishonestly would blemish the DPP's image.
The party's investigative panel is expected to release its report on the case in a couple of days, he said.
Meanwhile, a group of DPP legislators demanded that Chen Che-nan voluntarily resign from the party ahead of the investigative proceedings to protect the party's image.
Chen Chin-jun, a leader of the DPP legislative caucus, said the DPP adopted the highest moral standards towards its members and that Chen Che-nan must be responsible to his own behavior.
He also said the former presidential aide should make a public explanation and apology for visiting a casino.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR REGISTERS FOR BASIC HAKKA PROFICIENCY TEST

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that his aim of registering for the basic Hakka proficiency test was to seek progress through intensive preparation.

Both Ma and Premier Frank Hsieh have registered for the Nov. 5-6 test sponsored by the Council for Hakka Affairs to promote the tongue, the third mostly widely spoken in Taiwan, after Mandarin and Taiwanese.

Ma expressed the hope that he could make some progress because of the test, saying that he didn't care too much about the test result, and that if he fared poorly, he would simply give it another try next time.
Ma said that the preparations for the basic proficiency accreditation would force him to study in a systematic way.
"Even with a tight schedule, I'll squeeze in some time because of the upcoming test," Ma said, adding that he would attend both the oral and written tests.
Ma, tutored in Taiwanese in recent years, can now speak fluent Taiwanese and Hakka is obviously the next target for him.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.060 to close at NT$33.606.
A total of US$618 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.666 and hit a low of NT$33.600.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TOURISM OFFICIAL ARRIVES FOR 10-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Chinese National Tourism Administration Director Shao Qiwei arrived in Taiwan Friday for a 10-day visit at the head of a 66-member delegation.
Taiwan Visitors Association President S. L. Chang and Travel Agent Association of the R. O. C. President Tseng Sheng-hai met Shao upon his arrival at Chiang Kai-Shek International Airport.

In addition to visiting Taiwan's tourist spots and relevant facilities to make necessary preparations for Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan, Shao said that he hoped to personally feel and experience the atmosphere and attractions of Taiwan, such as its historic and cultural relics and religious activities.
Shao's delegation is composed of provincial tourism officials, reporters and industry executives.

Shao was invited by Chang to visit Taiwan in his capacity as Chinese National Travel Association president in a bid to make the visit "private" in nature. Tourism Bureau Director General Hsu Wen-sheng will be the sole government official who will meet Shao while the Chinese tourism official is in Taiwan.

China promised to allow its people to visit Taiwan for sightseeing early this year, but has failed to introduce practical measures to allow this until now. It is widely assumed that Shao's visit is aimed at paving the way for Chinese tourists entering Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TEENAGED HIV CARRIERS ON THE RISE

TEXT.P: The number of HIV carriers aged between 15 and 24 in Taiwan has been increasing on a year-on-year basis, posing an increasing challenge toward the country's AIDS prevention efforts, officials from the National Youth Commission said Friday.
The HIV incidence rate among those aged between 15 and 24 in 1989 was 0.0008 percent, but the proportion had increased to 0.2081 percent by 2002, Youth Commission officials said.
By 2002, the number of HIV carriers aged between 15 and 24 constituted roughly one-fifth of all HIV carriers in Taiwan, the officials said.
Ninety-eight percent of those found HIV positive aged between 15 and 24 said that they had become infected via sexual intercourse and most of them were heterosexual, according to the officials.
The statistics showed that sex education and gender relations were some of the most pressing issues facing the country's young men and women, the officials said.

The officials quoted results of a recent opinion poll conducted by the commission which indicated that the average age for first-time sex was 17 in the Taiwan area, with nearly 50 percent of this group having taken no safe-sex or birth-control precautions.

Also quoting results of a recent survey conducted by the Ministry of the Interior, the officials said that some 24,000 young women aged below 20 and unmarried, had abortions in 2002, with about half of them using RU486 to induce early-term abortions.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCALE OF TAIWAN ONLINE SHOPPING MARKET ON RISE: III

TEXT.P: The scale of Taiwan's online shopping market stood at NT$38.9 billion (US$1.158 billion) in 2004, and the figure is likely to exceed NT$90 billion for 2006, according to the Market Intelligence Center under the Institute for Information Industry (III).

The top three most popular items purchased over the Internet are books and magazines, computers and other hi-tech products and beauty care goods, the center reported, adding that on-line shops have become very popular in Taiwan in recent years thanks to cheaper product prices, easy and convenient access and home delivery services.

The public are also gaining greater confidence in online shopping, as more and more "bricks and mortar" shops have opened on-line branches and as supply logistics for the online shops have increasingly come of age, a business insider said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEAM READY TO GO TO SWITZERLAND OVER FRIGATE SALE INFORMATION

TEXT.P: State Public Prosecutor General Wu Ying-chao said Friday that he has yet to receive formal notification from Switzerland concerning the handover of bank files concerning the controversial sale of French warships to Taiwan, but his team is ready to pick up the information at any time.

Wu, who is leading a team investigating the case, made the remarks upon hearing the news that the Swiss Federal Council approved Thursday the handover of files and rejected an appeal by fugitive Taiwanese arms agent Andrew Wang to stop judicial cooperation with Taiwan, France, and Liechtenstein.

Wang was an agent in Taiwan for Thomson-CSF, the French firm that sold six Lafayette frigates to Taiwan for US$2. 8 billion. He fled Taiwan following the death of an R.O.C. Navy captain, Yin Ching-feng, who was widely believed to have been murdered when he was about to blow the whistle on colleagues for allegedly taking kickbacks in the deal.
d

Noting that Premier Frank Hsieh had assured the Swiss in August that Wang would not face the death penalty as a result of any prosecution in the case, which had enabled the transfer of the documents, Wu said that his task force has since been preparing to travel to Switzerland.
Though there is no extradition agreement between Taiwan and Switzerland, Taiwan is not ruling out the possibility of extraditing Wang back to Taiwan for trial, Wu said.

Taiwan has charged Wang with murder, corruption, money laundering and fraud. Both Switzerland and Liechtenstein have frozen funds in Wang's and his son's accounts that are allegedly linked to the case.
d
The investigations began when the Taiwanese authorities concluded from the inflated price that the deal constituted a serious case of international corruption.
France, Liechtenstein and Taiwan, investigating whether the case had violated their laws, asked the Swiss authorities to hand over the bank documents to facilitate their investigations.

According to media reports, nearly US$500 million remains frozen in 46 accounts with different banks in Switzerland as part of a Swiss investigation into alleged money laundering linked to the case. Authorities in neighboring Liechtenstein have frozen around US$27 million as part of their own investigations, the reports said.

A French judicial investigation was opened in 2001 into claims that a large part of the US$2. 8 billion paid by Taiwan for the six Lafayette-class frigates in 1991 went on commissions to middlemen, politicians and military officers in Taiwan, China and France.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO DE-LINK SISTER CITY TIES FROM DIPLOMATIC TIES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that Taipei will try to maintain sister city relations with foreign cities regardless of whether there are diplomatic ties between Taiwan and the concerned countries.
Ma made the remarks at a press conference held on the 2005 Taipei International Healthy Cities Conference, which is set to take place Oct. 29-31.
Leaders of nearly 50 cities are expected to attend the event, who include the vice mayor of the Senegalese capital of Dakar.
Taiwan severed diplomatic relations with Senegal on Tuesday after the African nation restored diplomatic ties with China.
According to Ma, sister city relations should be separate from diplomatic relations so that Taipei can win more friends.

Ma also said he had been promoting exchanges between Taipei and foreign cities but had not expanded the number of Taipei's sister cities because he believed the establishment of sister city relations was not the only way to enhance exchanges.
For example, Ma said, Taipei maintains close relations with Tokyo and Yokohama although they are not Taipei's sister cities.

Asked why no leaders from Chinese cities has been invited to participate in the conference, Teng Su-wen, deputy head of Taipei's Department of Health, said the city government had asked if Shanghai and Suzhou were interested in the event but both cities said it might not be convenient for them to attend.
Ma pointed out that China tends to avoid taking part in multilateral activities in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TVBS TO BE FINED FOR NOT REPORTING CHANGES OF STOCK OWNERS

TEXT.P: One day after a local cable station exposed former adviser to the president Chen Che-nan as a liar, it was fined for failing to report a change in its stock ownership in time.

On Thursday a photo, which appeared to be of Chen Che-nan visiting a casino on Cheju island in South Korea in 2002, was aired by TVBS a cable TV broadcaster, causing great embarrassment for the government and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) after Chen Che-nan had denied making a visit to South Korea at the time.

On Friday, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao announced that the station was facing a fine for failing to notify changes in its ownership when it applied for renewal of its licence in Taiwan earlier this year.
The amount of the fine would be NT$200,000 (US$5,951).
If, however, TVBS had been found to be deliberately keeping the GIO in dark about the change of its ownership, Yao said the GIO might even suspend its licence to operate in Taiwan.

He also said he would consult the Mainland Affairs Council about the question of whether Leung Nai Pang, a retired official of the Hong Kong government, could serve as TVBS' chairman. Yao made the statement after two DPP lawmakers accused TVBS of being financed totally by capital from China and harboring a design to topple the DPP administration.
They also claimed Leung, as a retired Hong Kong government official, was not qualified to serve as the chairman of a company in Taiwan.
TVBS has irritated DPP lawmakers for aggressively investigating the scandal surrounding construction of the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit in which Chen Che-nan is involved.

As an former confidant of President Chen Shui-bian, Chen Che-nan has been accused by his critics of playing a leading role in the scandal. It has been alleged that his trip to Cheju was at the expense of businessmen who profited from corruption in the construction project.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO HOLD TOP-LEVEL MEETING ON AVIAN FLU NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he will convene a National Security Council meeting next week to map out strategies against apossible avian influenza pandemic.
Chen unveiled the plan when receiving American Enterprise Institute President Christopher DeMuth at the Presidential Office.

That will be the second meeting of its kind in the past three months after avian flu began to be seen as a serious public health threat after taking many lives in other countries, especially in Southeast Asia.

Taiwan was badly damaged by the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) outbreaks in 2003, Chen said, noting that the painful lesson learned then was the reason why he called a top-level national security meeting in mid-August to discuss ways to strengthen the nation's preparations against a possible avian flu outbreak.
Chen added that how to fight avian flu effectively has become the world's No. 1 public health issue.

Chen said Taiwan's representative to the 2004 informal leadership meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, Lee Yuan-tseh, brought up the avian flu issue during the meeting, but it received little attention then.
Chen said he has appointed Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to attend this year's APEC summit on his behalf.
Wang is expected to bring up the issue when the summit convenes in Busan, South Korea Nov. 18-19, the president said.
Against the backdrop, Chen said he will invite Wang to take part in the next week's meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER URGES PRESIDENT TO STOP TALKING AND LISTEN TO SUPPORTERS

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Friday urged President Chen Shui-bian to stop giving campaign speeches from his bullet-proof truck and instead begin listening to the voices of discontent and impatience from DPP supporters concerning the nation's current state of affairs.

Legislator Lee Weng-chung, whose statement calling for self-reflection won support from more than 70 DPP lawmakers earlier this month, stressed at a press conference that the self-reflection process must begin with heeding what the people have to say.

Lee made the appeal to the president amid wide publicity about a profiteering scandal that has implicated Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan, who resigned early this month over his role in controversial hiring practices and exploitation of Thai workers by companies involved in the construction of the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system.

Despite Chen Che-nan's repeated denials of his involvement in the scandal, a photo publicized by news media Thursday provided hard evidence of his close relationship with the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) and manpower brokers who hired more than 1,400 Thai laborers for the KRTC.

Lee demanded an apology from those in power who gave Chen Che-nan the Presidential Office post. Although the DPP legislator did not specify who should apologize to the nation, he was obviously referring to the president.
In addition, he said, the DPP's anti-corruption commission and central advisory committee should take swift actions about Chen Che-nan's role in the scandal.
Asked whether Chen Che-nan should be stripped of his DPP membership, Lee said he was not opposed to the idea, but added that it was up to the Central Advisory Committee to make the decision.

Lee acknowledged that the new evidence about Chen Che-nan's close relationship with labor brokers was making it even more difficult for DPP candidates to fight an already uphill campaign for the Dec. 3 elections of mayors, magistrates, city and county councilors, and township chiefs.
He urged the government and the DPP to each promulgate a strict code of conduct governing the behavior of government officials and DPP office holders in their association with businesspeople.

In his statement on Oct. 5, Lee supported a new DPP movement to revive the party's core values amid public criticism that the DPP was becoming corrupt faster than the Kuomintang it replaced as the ruling party in 2000. The movement failed to materialize after the DPP leadership backed a reform agenda announced by the president.

The DPP government is plagued by a number of its officials being involved in corruption scandals, including stock market insider trading by the head of the Financial Supervisory Commission, who also leaked information to his stock-trader friends, and the profiteering scandal brought to light by the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit project in protest at inhumane treatment by their employers and management.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TIMES EXPRESS TO CLOSE AT END OF THIS MONTH

TEXT.P: China Times Express, one of the two major evening newspapers in Taiwan, will close at the end of this month after more than 17 years in the media market, its president Chen Kuo-hsiung announced Friday.
Chen said that the evening newspaper has been suffering from financial difficulties since last year and has tried every possible method to try to boost revenues.

It even negotiated a merger with its main rival -- the United Evening News -- to try to save it, Chen said, but due to a lack of confidence in the prospects for evening newspapers, as well as a sluggish stock market and economy, it has decided to scrap the cooperation deal and close the newspaper, Chen said.

The management of the China Times Group called all Express employees to attend an afternoon meeting where group chairman Yu Chien-hsin announced the paper's closure and explained the preferential severance package for the staff.

Chen said that the various departments in the group will do their best to accommodate some of the newspaper's staff, adding that 55 percent of the staff at the editorial department of the China Times Express will remain in the group.
The last edition of the Express will roll off the presses for the last time on Oct. 31 with a commemorative retrospective issue.

China Times Express was founded March 5, 1988, and saw its glory days during the years of the stock market boom when a wide readership was eager to see the latest stock news in the evening newspaper after the stock market closed at 1:30 p.m.

But in recent years, the newspaper has seen its position erode because of steep competition from electronic media which can provide real-time information as well as the onslaught of tabloid-style newspapers.
Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairman Lee Ying-yuan said Friday that the CLA will keep close tabs on developments surrounding the closure of the newspaper.

Lee was responding to questions by Legislator Hsu Shao-ping of the opposition Kuomintang concerning whether the abrupt announcement by the China Times Group has violated the regulation concerning large-scale layoffs, asking the CLA to assure the rights of those staff who are not leaving voluntarily.

Lee said that as far as he knew, exchanges between the management and labor representatives seemed to be amiable so far, and the Council hoped that both sides could work out differences.
If there were disputes, it was up to the Taipei City Government's Bureau of Labor Affairs to intervene in the first instance, Lee said, adding that the CLA would "follow closely the future development of the matter."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS PROBE INTO ALLEGED LEAKS BY PROSECUTORS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that he has ordered the Ministry of Justice to investigate allegations that prosecutors leaked details concerning their investigation into the suspected Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) scandal.

Hsieh was responding to recent moves by independent Legislator Chiu Yi, who has released through the media what he called evidence relating to the scandal and claimed that he obtained the information from prosecutorial and investigative authorities.

The evidence included a picture showing former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan appearing in a Casino together with then KRTC Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien in Cheju, South Korea on November 2, 2002. The pair are under investigation for alleged profiteering in the hiring of Thai workers for the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit project.

Hsieh told lawmakers during an interpolation session in the Legislative Yuan that if what Chiu said were true, it would undermine the credibility of the prosecutorial and investigative authorities, which are supposed to keep their investigation secret.
If the claim were false, Chiu could be charged with slander and insulting a government agency, Hsieh said.
Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said he had assigned State Public Prosecutor General Wu Ying-chao and Bureau of Investigation Director Yeh Cherng-maw to look into the matter.
Hsieh also accused those who had made allegations via the media of trying to influence and interfere in the investigation now being conducted by prosecutorial and investigative authorities
According to Hsieh, many legislators from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" had also tried to peddle their influence in the hiring of Thai workers for the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit project.
Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tu Wen-ching said at least 30 legislators were involved in the case and that most of them were from the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING TO CHINESE TOURISTS BENEFICIAL TO TAIWAN: CEPD OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists will increase the country's tourist revenue and help inject momentum to Taiwan's economy, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Vice Chairman Thomas M. F. Yeh said Friday.

Yeh said that the government was poised to make the opening to tourists from China and that the possible negative impact of the measure, such as the mass absconding of Chinese tourists in Taiwan, would be minimized as long as the government tackled the issue cautiously.

Yeh's comments came after Chinese National Tourism Administration Director Shao Qiwei arrived in Taiwan earlier the same day for a 10-da y visit at the head of a 66-member delegation to explore Taiwan's tourist market in preparation for the much-anticipated entry of Chinese tourists.

At the invitation of the Taiwan Visitors Association, Shao came here in his private capacity as Chinese National Travel Association president in line with Beijing's stance of no official contacts with Taiwan due to the delicate relationship between Taiwan and China.

Premier Frank Hsieh announced in May this year that the government was to allow as many as 1,000 tourists per day from China to come to Taiwan for sightseeing. In the past, only Chinese people living abroad or coming from a third country or area were permitted to visit Taiwan. But China has so far failed to add Taiwan to its list of approved overseas travel destinations.
In the face of the daily ceiling imposed by Taiwan, Chinese tour operators suggested Taiwanese counterparts design fine quality tours with versatile features for Chinese tourists.

As the number of potential Chinese tourists is much larger than Taiwan's set limit, they proposed that the Taiwan tourism industry adopt a "lean and mean" strategy to receive upscale visitors from China.

To attract top Chinese tourists over the long term, Taiwan tour operators must provide especially designed high-end products to fend off a price war, they contended, pointing out that "Taiwan should show something different to Chinese tourists."

Should Taiwan be capable of taking in around 400,000 tourists from China each year, their travel experience would be extremely important in helping Taiwan lure more and secure continued inflows of visitors by word of mouth, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WARNS CLOSURE OF TVBS WILL TRIGGER RECALL OF PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) warned Friday that if the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government dared to shut down cable TV broadcaster TVBS after its call-in programs exposed a number of corrupt government officials, the KMT would launch a campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
Pan Wei-kang, a KMT caucus whip, said at a press conference Friday that TVBS had been upholding justice by unearthing corruption in its programs during the past five months.

She said government talk of revoking the license of TVBS following the network's exposure of a photo showing two Presidential Office officials gambling in a casino in South Korea in November 2002 prompted suspicions about what the DPP government had to fear.

Kuo Su-chun, another KMT legislator, pointed out that TVBS' daily call-in programs are watched by millions of viewers, and that allegations by the head of the Government Information Office (GIO) that TVBS was a network fully funded by money from China was apparently a tactic to shift the focus of attention away from the corruption scandals involving the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit project.

Joanna C. Lei, a KMT legislator from Taipei County, pointed out that the newly adopted legislation providing for the establishment of a National Communications Commission is intended to prevent the GIO and the DPP from interfering with mass media.
She said that the government should not be allowed to silence the media, as the public prosecutors investigating the scandal do not have the people's trust.

The KMT legislators held the press conference after Premier Frank Hsieh endorsed a suggestion by the GIO chief that a probe is necessary to find out whether TVBS should be penalized for tax evasion or whether the TV network is under Chinese control.

The GIO chief and several DPP legislators launched their attacks on TVBS after the TV station exposed the close relationship between a deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office and labor brokers who brought in more than 1,400 Thai workers for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. but exploited and mis-treated them, resulting in their rioting in Kaohsiung County on Aug. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Massive Fraud in Iraq Oil Program. The United Nations' oil-for-food program was so badly managed and supervised that more than half of the 4,500 companies doing business with Iraq paid illegal surcharges and kickbacks to Saddam Hussein, an independent investigation into the program will announce today.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFERS CHARITY MEDICAL SERVICE AT REMOTE PHILIPPINE VILLAGES
DOC.DATELINE: Sorsogon, the Philippines, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Emerson Lim & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A medical service team organized by Taiwan's Chiayi Christian Hospital has provided free medical treatment at remote Philippine villages in Sorsogon in the past few days as a move to aid less-privileged people in the country, Taiwan officials stationed in the Philippines said Friday.

The 13-member team began its two-day medical service in the southern province of Sorsogon on Luzon Island Wednesday. Over 1,000 local people received treatment and free medicines, while at least five patients underwent surgical operations, a member of the group, former Chiayi Christian Hospital president Wung Juei-yi said.

Wung said that most of the patients suffered from malnutrition, influenza, tuberculosis and other infectious diseases. The team completely used up the medicines and medical appliances it brought with it, he said.
The province suffers from a lack of medical resources while its people live on low incomes, a situation similar to that in Taiwan around 30 years ago, Wung said.

Members of the medical team, led by Wung, include two physicians, one pharmacist and three nurses. Hsu Pei-yung, an official of the ROC representative office to the Philippines, served as the guide for the charity service-oriented trip.
This was the fifth free medical service trip to the Philippines arranged by the charity group from Chiayi, southern Taiwan. Participants were scheduled to return to Taiwan on Oct. 30.
Sorsogon, located at Luzon's southern tip, is situated around 600 kilometers from Manila, capital of the Philippines. Most of its residents live by farming and fishing.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRCRAFT MADE BY TAIWAN-U.S. JOINT VENTURE GETS FAA CERTIFICATE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Sino Swearingen Aircraft Corp. (SSAC) , a Taiwan-U.S. joint venture headquartered in San Anotonio, Texas, announced Friday that its SJ30-2 commercial aircraft has received a "Type Certificate" from the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).
By securing the FAA license documentation, SSAC Chairman Kuo Ching-chiang said, the company can now start volume production of this new type of commercial airliner.
It marks the first time in nearly 42 years that the FAA has issued such a certificate to a new type of commercial aircraft designed by a brand new aircraft company, Kuo said.

"The acquisition of the license is of great significance to Sino Swearingen as it will help bring more business opportunities to the company, " Kuo said, adding that the certification also marks a new milestone in Taiwan's aviation industry development.

SSAC has received orders for 280 SJ30-2s from the United States, Canada, Britain, Germany and Switzerland, Kuo said, adding that the company is scheduled to deliver its first airliner to a client next spring.
Noting that Taiwan holds a more than 95 percent stake in SSAC, Kuo said the company has set a viable model of using Taiwan's capital and U.S. technology to upgrade Taiwan's aviation industry.
SSAC senior vice president Alfred Baumbusch said the SJ30-2 is a high-performance commercial airliner capable of flying a distance of 2,500 nautical miles without refueling.

"The SJ30-2 is the world's fastest and best performing light business jet at the world's best price value. It has a high speed cruise above Mach 0.83. Equally important is its long range cruise speed of Mach 0.78 -- faster than many jets' 'high speed cruise,'" he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: F-16 JET FIGHTERS' COMBAT CAPABILITY UNDER QUESTION

TEXT.P: The combat capability of the Republic of China Air Force's F-16 jet fighters came under question Friday after it was revealed that two F-16s sent to sink an overturned cargo ship carrying a load of toxic chemicals off Hsinchu Thursday fired four laser-guided missiles but failed to accomplish their mission.
Asked how he felt about the performance of the planes' pilots at a question and answer session of the legislature, Minister of National Defense Li Jye said he felt bad and was "embarrassed."
Li said the two fighters fired four missiles, each weighing about 2,000 pounds, but scored only one hit.

He said that theoretically, a bomb of such caliber could blow a hole in a ship the size of a basketball court. However, he admitted that the hit failed to sink the ship, which carried a harmful chemical and posed a hazard to fishing boats operating in nearby waters.
The defense minister said military authorities will conduct a review of the failed mission and decide who should be held responsible.
The 3,561-ton South Korean cargo ship Samho Brother capsized Oct. 10 after a collision with the 13,629-ton TS Hongkong registered in Liberia. All 14 crewmembers were rescued.
In addition to 3,140 cubic meters of benzene, the Samho Brother was carrying 85 tons of fuel oil and 16 tons of diesel.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECULATION ABOUT PRESIDENT'S ROLE IN KRTC SCANDAL REBUTTED

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office Friday rebutted media speculation that President Chen Shui-bian might have been involved or at least aware of irregularities in the hiring of Thai workers by the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC), saying such speculation was far-fetched and incredible.

A TV talk show host displayed Thursday a duplicate copy of an official document issued by the Executive Yuan to the Council of Labor Affairs on Jan. 10, 2003 in which the Executive Yuan said the agreement on direct employment of Thai laborers had been approved and the instrument would be sent to the Presidential Office for the information of the president.

Based on the document, some TV commentators speculated that President Chen should have been be aware or might even have been involved in the suspected profiteering scandal brought to light by the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit project. The riot grew out of protests at unfair and unjust treatment by the workers' employers and management.
"Such speculation is far-fetched and unthinkable, " said Chen Wen-tsung, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department.

In line with government protocol, Chen Wen-tsung said, the Executive Yuan had consistently sent instruments of all approved agreements, treaties or memoranda of understanding with foreign governments to the Presidential Office to be forwarded to the president.
"Since President Chen assumed office in 2000, strenuous efforts have been made to cut red tape. Such documents are now only sent to the president's office," Chen Wen-tsung said.
He said the document concerned was received by then-Director of the president's office Ma Yung-cheng who is now a Presidential Office deputy secretary-general.

Chen Wen-tsung also said instruments of similar labor employment agreements signed by Taiwan with Mongolia, the Philippines and Vietnam in the past decade have all been sent to the Presidential Office for documentation.
"This practice has been in place for decades. Speculation about this kind of official document is far-fetched," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDICTED EX-OFFICIAL QUITS DPP

TEXT.P: Former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan withdrew from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Friday shortly after he was released on a NT$500,000 bail on charges of corruption.
Chen said he hopes his departure can help minimize damage to his beloved DPP.
Chen was indicted a day earlier for his alleged role in a suspected profiteering scandal involving the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system construction project.
The profiteering scandal brought to light by the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit project in protest at inhumane treatment by their employers and management.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 29, or the 27th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1618: Sir Walter Raleigh, English courtier, navigator, colonizer and writer, is beheaded in the Tower of London for treason against King James I at the age of 54. His literary works include poetry, memoirs, and a world history.
1863: Henri Dunant, Swiss philanthropist, founds the International Red Cross. He was a joint recipient of the 1901 Nobel Peace Prize.
1881: The first national political party is founded in Japan.
1911: Joseph Pulitzer, Hungarian-born American journalist and newspaper publisher, dies at the age of 64. He owned papers in St. Louis and New York City as well as established the Pulitzer Prize.
1923: The Republic of Turkey is proclaimed, with nationalist leader Kemal Ataturk as its first president.
1927: Russian archaeologist Peter Kozlov discovers the tomb of Genghis Khan in the Gobi Desert.
1929: "Black Tuesday" follows "Black Thursday" on Wall Street as the crisis of confidence hits the New York stock market, leading to the Great Depression of the 1930s.
1932: The Normandie, one of the three most luxurious ships ever built, is launched in France. The 300 meter-long vessel crossed the Atlantic Ocean in just over four days. A fire destroyed the ship while it was berthed in New York Harbor in 1942.
1942: Nazis massacre 16,000 Jews in Pinsk, Russia.
1944: In his capacity as supreme commander of the China Theater of War, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek appoints U.S. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China Theater of War. Meanwhile, U.S. Gen. Daniel L. Sultan is appointed commander in chief of the U.S. Expeditionary Forces in India.
1945: Anna Rosenberg is given the first U.S. Medal of Freedom ever awarded to a woman.
1953: The North American F-100 Super Sabre jet fighter sets a record by reaching a speed of 1,215 kilometers per hour, becoming the first jet capable of being operated at supersonic speeds.
1962: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a statement refusing to recognize India's position of using the "McMahon Line" as the border line between India and China.
1964: Tanganyika unites with Zanzibar, forming Tanzania.
1974: A five-member Korean parliamentary mission headed by the chairman of the Korean Democratic Republican Party, Rhee Hyo Sang, and 130 members of the Japanese Diet, arrive in Taipei to take part in celebrations marking President Chiang Kai-shek's 87th birthday.
1977: Taiwan's first IC (integrated circuit) plant, under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, is inaugurated in Chutung in Hsinchu County.
1980: A declaration by Deng Xiaoping, vice chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, that Mao Zedong made serious political mistakes during his rule, is made public.
1981: The Chinese National Federation of Industries and the Chamber of Industry of Guatemala sign a cooperation agreement to promote economic, trade and cultural relations.
1984: The Chinese team from Taiwan wins second place in the World Amateur Baseball Championship in Cuba.
1985: The first prototype of "Ching Kuo," the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, bursts its nose-wheel during a test flight at Chingchuenkang Air Force Base in Taichung.
1986: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that ROC-U.S. trade talks on wine and tobacco imports are in a stalemate. Washington charged that Taipei failed to keep promises of providing greater market access for U.S. beer, wine and tobacco, and said the United States would draft retaliatory measures against the ROC under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974.
1998: John Glenn, U.S. astronaut, blasts off aboard the space shuttle Discovery at the age of 77, 36 years after his first space mission.
1999: Carleton S. Fiorina, chief executive of Hewlett-Packard Co., the world's No. 2 computer maker, arrives in Taipei for a two-day whirlwind visit.
2000: Taiwan's China Airlines inaugurates a new flight route between Taipei, Penang in Malaysia, and Medan in Indonesia.
2000: A poll unveiled by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party shows that only 33.2 percent of the Taiwan public supports the Cabinet's decision to halt construction on the island's fourth nuclear power plant, while 47.5 percent oppose the decision.
2001: The Republic of China Ministry of Finance approves an application from Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp. -- the second-largest banking group in Japan and the world -- to upgrade its local representative office to a branch office.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "When a ruler regards his ministers as his hands and feet, they regard him as their belly and heart; when he regards them as dogs and horses, they regard him as a common citizen; when he regards them as dirt and grass, they regard him as a robber and enemy."
