DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT URGES DPP TO MAKE IMMEDIATE REFORMS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu suggested Saturday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) make immediate reforms to recover its image in the wake of a string of scandals involving government officials.

Lu was referring to profiteering allegations made against former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan in the hiring of Thai workers for the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit project, as well as an insider stock trading scandal involving Lee Chin-cheng, former director of the Financial Supervisory Commission's Examination Bureau.
Chen announced a day earlier his decision to quit the DPP amid demands from within the party that he be kicked out.
According to Lu, Chen "should have resigned from the DPP earlier" in an attempt to lessen the damage that the case has done to the party.

Pointing out that the principal ideals of the DPP are to make reforms, combat corruption and uphold social fairness and justice, Lu said any individuals who violate these ideals are not qualified to be DPP members.
However, Lu urged the public not to speculate before the concerned individuals are convicted.
As to the possible impact of the scandals on the DPP's showing in the Dec. 3 local elections, Lu said the DPP needs to reform itself in the remaining month before the elections.

Meanwhile, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said the party's Central Standing Committee will meet later in the day to discuss disciplinary measures against Chen, regardless of his decision to quit the party.
The investigative panel formed by the DPP will also release its report on the case in the meeting, Su said.
He said that as a party of ideals and discipline, the DPP will not tolerate any illicit conduct by its members.

Also Saturday, a leading DPP legislator apologized to the public on behalf of the DPP legislative caucus for failing to monitor the government properly and failing to meet public expectations for the party.

Caucus leader Chen Chin-jun said the DPP will accept public scrutiny using the highest of moral standards, and he urged the public to respect the judiciary and support their investigations into the scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGED TO CONFIRM CONTROL YUAN NOMINEES

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou should instruct KMT lawmakers to screen and confirm nominees of Control Yuan members so that the ombudsmen can monitor any irregularities, a spokesman of the Presidential Office said Saturday.
The confirmation of the nominees of the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, is stalled in the Legislative Yuan because of the opposition of the KMT and its ally People First Party.

Chen Wen-tzung, director of the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs, made the remarks after Ma questioned earlier in the day President Chen Shui-bian's determination to crack down on illicit practices.

Ma asked if Chen was unaware that his former aide, Chen Che-nan, was involved in the profiteering scandal involving the mass rapid transit construction project in Kaohsiung, adding that the snowballing scandal has made the people lose faith in the government and the nation's leader, causing a serious national crisis.

Ma, who is also mayor of Taipei, said on the sidelines of an international conference on healthy cities that as long as the government does not impose obstacles, the investigators and prosecutors will find out the truth.
In response, Chen Wen-tzung said the president has been relentless in the cracking down on unlawful deeds and has openly announced that there is no "bottom line" in the crackdown.

The president told Chen Che-nan, a former Presidential Office deputy secretary-general and a national policy adviser, to resign from his adviser post so as to give a free hand to the prosecution and investigative authorities in the case.

On Chen Chi-nan's trip to South Korea in 2002 without taking leave from the Presidential Office, the president also instructed that the matter be turned over to the Control Yun for violation of civil service regulations, Chen Wen-tzung added.
Chen Che-nan's visit to a casino Nov. 2, 2002 came to light after a photo of him with Chen Min-hsien, former vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp., was shown on a TV program Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF WARNS MOVE TO SUPPRESS MEDIA WILL TRIGGER PUBLIC PROTEST

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that if the government moves to kill off a cable TV station for exposing scandals involving the government, the public will protest.

Ma, who is also Taipei's mayor, made the comment while answering reporters' questions about a Government Information Office (GIO) move a day earlier to fine TVBS station for failing to report a change in its stock ownership when it applied for a renewal of its license earlier this year.

After exposing a number of corrupt government officials, including former Presidential Office deputy secretary-general Chen Che-nan, the media outlet was accused by GIO chief Pasuya Yao and several lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of being fully funded by money from China.
Quoting current regulations, Yao said if TVBS is really totally financed by China, its license could be revoked.
Ma said that the funding issue is a purely legal problem and that the government should not manipulate the law to satisfy its political desires.

Meanwhile, opposition People First Party spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping blasted the GIO's accusation as a tactic to shift the focus of public attention away from the corruption scandal surrounding the construction of the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system, in which Chen Che-nan is involved.

Hsieh said that in a democratic society, anyone has right to file accusations based on evidence. However, he added that if a government attempts to suppress freedom of speech by means such as suspending a media license, it is the mark of a dictatorship.
"The PFP will fight against such an system to the end, " he said.
Chen Chin-jun, a whip of the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said the ruling party absolutely respects the rights of the media.
"The fine slapped on TVBS was an effort to clarify the nation's legal system. Is it legal to have a totally China-financed media outlet at the moment?" Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT PROPOSES INDEPENDENT REGULATORY MECHANISM IN CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: A system for the formation of independent regulatory organizations should be enshrined in the Constitution in the next phase of constitutional reforms to provide a reliable buffer between the country, political parties and society, a local constitutional law expert said Saturday.
The proposal was put forth by Chang Wen-chen, an assistant professor at National Taiwan University's College of Law, during a conference on constitutional re-engineering held in Taipei.
Chang pointed out that all major public offices in Taiwan became elected posts following the country's successful democratic transformation in the 1990s.

However, since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won the presidency in 2000, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -dominated legislature has obstructed almost every major piece of legislation and every budget proposed by the Cabinet, which has led to a political deadlock, Chang noted.

Chang attributed the situation to the fact that many politicians tend to equate the number of votes they win in elections with the amount of political clout they should enjoy, believing that elections are the only source of "political legitimacy."

For example, Chang said, the KMT-led "pan-blue alliance" insisted that members of the National Communications Commission be nominated by the legislature according to the proportional representation system, while the DPP strongly opposed this and plans to request a constitutional interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices.

As another example, Chang pointed out that the "pan-blue alliance, " in order to secure influence in the latest round of constitutional reforms in June, insisted on raising the passage threshold for constitutional amendments to a three-quarters vote.

Expressing worry about the phenomenon, Chang said a system should be set up in the Constitution to govern the formation of independent organizations to prevent political parties from taking advantage of their majority status to take control of technical or regulatory organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH SPEED TRAIN ACHIEVES 300 KPH IN TEST RUNS

TEXT.P: A test train on Taiwan's high speed railway achieved 300 kph, the highest test speed so far, over a distance of around 25 km Saturday, the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) announced that same day in a press release.
The test took place on the Kueijen village section of the railway in Tainan County, southern Taiwan.
THSRC officials said that the tests are done mainly to check the trains' acceleration and braking systems, and their integration with the track, machinery and electronics system.
When the new 345-km railway is inaugurated, a trip from Taipei in the north to Kaohsiung in the south will take less than 90 minutes.

The high-speed railway, which will form the backbone of western Taiwan's transport network, will connect eight metropolitan areas between Taiwan's two largest cities. It will be able to transport at least 300,000 passengers daily when it becomes fully operational.

The first major infrastructure project built under the BOT (build-operate-transfer) model has encountered funding and integration problems, forcing the postponement of its inauguration by one year to Oct. 31, 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS WARN AGAINST SMUGGLING DOGS FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: Quarantine officials warned the public Saturday not to smuggle animals and plants from China into Taiwan and urged people to refuse to purchase a product if its origin cannot be determined, as reinforced measures were taken to prevent infectious diseases from being brought into the country.

The Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture has recently killed 20 dogs smuggled from China in an effort to prevent rabies from coming into Taiwan, bureau officials said.
Rabies is endemic in China but Taiwan is rabies-free.
According to bureau statistics, as of the end of October, a total of 96 dogs smuggled from China had been seized.
The bureau also called on people to inform of animal and plant smuggling through a telephone hot line at 0800-039-131.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Cheney Aide Charged With Lying in Leak Case
I. Lewis Libby Jr., Vice President Dick Cheney's chief of staff, was indicted by a federal jury on Friday on five felony charges of lying to investigators and misleading the grand jury in the C.I.A. leak case, deepening the air of political crisis afflicting the White House while leaving many questions unanswered. Libby, one of the highest-ranking and most influential officials in the administration, immediately resigned and left the White House.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Government adjusts next year's budget plan by reducing five billion euros in deficit.
The Cabinet meeting approved an amendament to the government's next year budget plan Friday by reducing five billion euros in deficit. Finance and Economics Minister Giulio Tremonti explained that the additional five billion euros will come from property sales, dividends of public investments, modification of tax bases and others.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TOURISM OFFICIAL HOPES TO INCREASE EXCHANGES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Chinese National Tourism Administration Director Shao Qiwei proposed Saturday that Taipei's National Palace Museum enhance its exchanges with Beijing's Palace Museum to attract more Chinese tourists.

Shao, who arrived in Taiwan a day earlier at the head of a 66-member delegation, made the proposal during a visit to the National Palace Museum, where a wealth of precious Chinese antiquities are displayed.
Shao later visited the holiday flower market under the Chienkuo overpass and the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall.
Shao was invited by the Taiwan Visitors Association to visit Taiwan in his capacity as president of the Chinese National Travel Association.
Beijing announced earlier this year that it will allow more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan and it is widely believed that Shao's visit is aimed at paving the way for this policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT APOLOGIZES FOR FORMER AIDE'S INVOLVEMENT IN MRT SCANDAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian apologized Saturday for the alleged involvement of one of his former aides in a profiteering scandal surrounding the mass rapid transport (MRT) construction project in Kaohsiung.

The president's apology came after days of public outcry over the role of Chen Che-nan, a former Presidential Office deputy secretary-general and national policy adviser, in a series of irregularities surrounding the project.

During a weekend barnstorming tour to drum up support for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chen said in Ilan, northeastern Taiwan, that "he felt very sorry for the lack of integrity of Chen Che-nan," who was questioned by prosecutors for the first time over the scandal Friday.

The scandal came to light in the wake of a series of irregularities surrounding the MRT construction project that were revealed after Thai laborers employed by the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) rioted Aug. 21 to protest against harsh management and exploitation.
The president apologized to the public and to Lin Yi-hsiung, former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, as well as to DPP supporters.

He also said that if he himself is found to have been involved in the scandal, he would be willing to step down, reaffirming that as long as there is solid evidence, the government will pursue its investigation relentlessly. He added that there is "no need to question" the government's determination to find out the truth.

He also said that "the DPP will reflect upon itself, engage in soul-searching and seek improvement, " adding that the party will never let down the public and asking for continued support to accomplish its reforms.

On a recently released photo showing Chen Che-nan in a casino in Cheju, South Korea, with Chen Min-hsien, a former vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp., taken Nov. 2, 2002, the president said Chen Che-nan did not report to him on the visit and did not request leave to make the trip, leaving him in the dark. The president also apologized for this.

The photo has cast a shadow across the ruling party as it establishes the close relationship between Chen Che-nan and Chen Min-hsien, who paid for their South Korean visit and who has already been questioned by the prosecutors four times over the scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAMBOO FESTIVAL KICKS OFF IN NANTOU

TEXT.P: The Nantou International Bamboo Cultural Festival kicked off Saturday in a "woody" atmosphere produced by a program of music made with bamboo and dances featuring bamboo at the modern Sheliao center in the town of Puli for exhibitions and trading of local agricultural products.

The festival, which will run until Nov. 13, features activities that include various exhibitions in the fields of traditional bamboo handicrafts, modern bamboo utensils and equipment, and bamboo charcoal and its appliances, as well as performances by foreign and domestic art groups and individuals including Canadian musician Matthew Lien.

Visitors will also be able to purchase locally made agricultural products such as liquor, vinegar, pickled plums, bamboo craftwork and state-of-the-art bamboo charcoal appliances ranging from underwear to shoes, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST STEP UP DEVELOPMENT OF INFORMATION-BASED INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to step up the development of its information-based industry if it wants to upgrade its international competitiveness, Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said Saturday.
Chen made the remarks while speaking at an economic seminar at Soochow University in Taipei.
Faced with global economic liberalization and the rise of China, Chen said, Taiwan faces several challenges, including the era of micro-profit in the high-tech industry.
The emergence of China with its powerful economic clout has posed a serious challenge, he added.
At the same time, the integration of regional economies and the rising consciousness with regard to environmental protection also threatens Taiwan's industry, he said.

But he pointed out that Taiwan still excels in its manufacturing and logistic abilities and its geographic location, adding that the government will gradually open up to imports of Chinese products and relax restrictions on Taiwan manufacturers investing in China to upgrade the nation's competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEALTHY CITIES CONFERENCE OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taipei International Healthy Cities Conference opened Saturday, bringing together the leaders or representatives of 47 cities around the world.
Mame Bousso Samb, vice mayor of the Senegal capital of Dakar, also attended the conference despite the recent severance of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Senegal.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said the event is aimed at enhancing inter-city exchanges and will focus on issues such as traffic, public order, environmental protection and culture rather than politics.
Ma said he will avoid discussing diplomatic issues in light of their sensitive nature.

Topics covered by the three-day conference include building an environment for healthy lifestyles; community safety and security; building synergy between public, private and non-governmental organization efforts; disaster prevention; cultural development, education and preservation; and public health management and disease prevention.
Ma will join the city leaders in a roundtable Sunday to exchange experiences in city development. They are expected to sign a joint declaration at the conclusion of the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEENAGE ACCIDENTAL DEATHS DROP, SUICIDES UP

TEXT.P: Teenage accidental deaths have declined but suicides have been rising steadily over the past decade, the National Youth Commission (NYC) said Saturday.

Quoting tallies compiled by the Department of Health, the commission said that 49.3 out of every 100,000 15-to-19-year-olds died in accidents in 1994, but the ratio dropped to 23 out of every 100,000 in 2003.

Despite the fall in proportion, accidents remained the top killer for this age group during the period, accounting for 51.8 percent of total deaths. Traffic accidents and drowning were the top two causes of teenage accidental deaths.
During the same period, suicide was the No. 2 cause of death for the 15-19 age group, accounting for 10.7 percent of the total deaths, with cancer third at 9.28 percent.
In 1994, an average of 2.74 out of every 100,000 15-to-19-year-olds committed suicide, and the ratio rose to 3.25 in 2003.
During the same period, the suicide rate for the 20-24 age group also surged from 6.17 out of every 100,000 to 8.49.

Compared with figures recorded in advanced Western countries, an NYC official said the suicide rate for the 15-24 age group was not especially high, but the upward trend deserves the attention of parents and relevant government agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI HOSPITAL SEEKS MORE ORGAN DONATIONS

TEXT.P: Officials of the Hualien Tzu Chi Hospital called on the public Saturday to become organ donors, saying that the hospital is still seeking an additional 300 donors.

The hospital has completed 39 organ donations and 38 tissue donations, including the first brain tissue donation in 2004, since the establishment of an organ transplant team more than nine years ago, according to the officials.
Team director Lee Ming-che said the hospital successfully performed the first kidney transplant in 1997 and the first liver transplant the following year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TVBS SHOULD ANSWER QUESTIONS CONCERNING TAX, FOREIGN INVESTMENT: PM

TEXT.P: A local cable station should answer questions about tax evasion and the ratio of stocks held by foreign investors, Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday.

The premier made the remarks on the sidelines of a campaign trail in Taichung, central Taiwan, to drum up support for candidates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the year-end elections.

Hsieh said he respects media freedom, noting that based on the spirit of democracy, the government will not give unfair treatment to TVBS, the cable TV station in question, simply because it criticizes corrupt government officials, especially a former confidant of President Chen Shui-bian, and casts the government in a negative light.

But he said that Taiwan has now developed a taste for an "exploding revelation" in everything and since there are questions about the TV company's taxes and the ratio of foreign investment, the company "might as well give a detailed explanation."
At issue is a prime-time call-in program that has been pursuing almost daily the profiteering scandal surrounding the mass rapid transit (MRT) construction project over the past two months.

The program has seen its ratings soar recently, especially after a revelation this week of a photo showing Chen Chi-nan, a former deputy secretary-general to President Chen, and Chen Min-hsien, a former vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) gambling at a casino in Cheju, South Korea Nov. 2, 2002, establishing the close relations between the two.

Chen Che-nan, who said repeatedly that he had never sought profits from his position, admitted Friday during his first interrogation by prosecutors that Chen Min-hsien paid for his South Korean trip, but he denied that this was the case with two other trips he made with Chen Min-hsien to Thailand.
The revelation of the photo cast a long shadow across the ruling DPP, causing great anxiety among the DPP in the run-up to the year-end elections.

Several DPP lawmakers questioned Friday if Leung Nai Pang, a retired Hong Kong official, is suitable to serve as TVBS' chairman. They also alleged that the company has been financed by China and is harboring a plan to collaborate with China to topple the Taiwan government.
A spokeswoman for TVBS said Friday that the company has met the requirements of the local media regulations that prohibit foreign investors to hold more than half of the shares issued.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, YOKOHAMA MAYORS EXCHANGE VIEWS ON CITY DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and his counterpart from the Japanese city of Yokohama, Hiroshi Nakada, met Saturday for talks on their ideas and efforts in city development.

Ma said that he wishes that the functions of Sungshan Airport, located in the heart of Taipei, will be separated from those of the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in the northern county of Taoyuan.

Under his idea, Ma explained, the domestic civil aviation hub of Sungshan Airport should be developed into a terminal concentrating on passenger traffic, with cargo shipments restricted to lighter high-tech goods with high added value.

During a city leadership dialogue, Nakada said his city grants a preferential 50 percent tax reduction to enterprises that relocate their headquarters to Yokohama and stay there for at least five years.
The program, aimed at attracting business giants, has won Nissan Motors for the city, Nakada said, adding that he hopes the program can help attract 600 enterprises to Yokohama in three years.

Speaking on Taipei's development, Ma said the best way to attract enterprises to Taipei is to open direct with China because that would make Taiwan into a regional springboard toward the large Chinese market.
Under those circumstances, foreign businesses would flow into Taipei, Ma said.
However, Taiwan has been keeping itself away from development, Ma said, referring to the government's long-term ban on forging direct cross-Taiwan Strait links.

DOC.HEADLINE: TVBS SHOULD EXPLAIN STOCK OWNERSHIP: GIO

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) will demand a local cable TV broadcaster explain its stock ownership as reports show that it is a 100 percent Hong Kong-owned enterprise, GIO Minister Pasuya Yao said Saturday.
Quoting a National Security Bureau report and information posted on a Web site, Yao said TVBS is fully owned by a Hong Kong company.

As such, Yao said TVBS is in violation of Article 10 of the Satellite Radio and TV Broadcasting Law which stipulates that foreign direct investments in a local television station should not exceed 50 percent of its total stake.
Yao said the GIO will ask TVBS Monday to furnish it with a report on its stock ownership. "We'll then discuss with relevant government agencies on how to address the issue," he added.

Noting that the GIO fully respects freedom of press, Yao said the GIO's move has nothing to do with the broadcaster's call-in programs that publicized evidence related to Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) project scandals. "We must defend the dignity of our law, " he stressed.

Yao criticized Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, for his warning against the GIO's "suppression" of TVBS simply because of the broadcaster's reports on government scandals.

Ma said earlier in the day that if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration continues to find faults with local the media, local citizens would take to the streets to vent their anger. Ma said the content of the media outlet's reports is more important than its stock ownership.
"It's weird for Ma, a Harvard-educated legal expert, to make such remarks. How can we ignore a law passed by our legislature, " Yao said.

Meanwhile, TVBS issued a four-point statement in the evening, claiming that the GIO's demand for it to re-summit its stock ownership data is unacceptable because it just passed a GIO committee's license renewal screening.

On Friday, the GIO slapped a NT$200,000 fine to TVBS for "not honestly reporting the transfer and background of its shareholders." The fine came as one of the station's talk shows exposed the close relationship between former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan and labor brokers who brought in more than 1,400 Thai workers for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. but exploited and mis-treated them, resulting in their rioting in Kaohsiung County on Aug. 21.

The GIO is also investigating whether TVBS Chairman Norman Leung, who is a former chairman of the Hong Kong Broadcasting Authority, is eligible to hold such a high-ranking position in Taiwan's media industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: NONE OF SUSPICIOUS FLU CASES TESTED H5N1 POSITIVE: CDC

TEXT.P: None of the 50 influenza cases that meet the requirements for avian flu testing were tested H5N1 positive, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health said Saturday.

CDC Deputy Director Lin Ting said the CDC's Kunyang laboratory and its 12 contract laboratories have established a speedy screening and testing system that can complete initial testing in three hours to determine whether a suspicious case belongs avian flu infections.

According to Lin, local medical institutions have been required to send specimens to the above-mentioned laboratories whenever they treat patients showing respiratory symptoms or high fever or having visited avian flu-affected areas or having come into contacts with birds or poultry.

"So far, 50 suspicious cases have been collected and none of them were tested avian flu positive, " Lin said, adding that Taiwan now maintains its avian flu-free status, with none of humans and animals on its territory have infected the virus.

Avian flu is a highly infectious virus among both wild and domestic birds. H5N1 is the most virulent strain of bird flu and has killed more than 60 people in Asia since 2003. Experts are closely watching the disease for fear that it could mutate into a form easily transmitted among humans and cause a pandemic that could kill millions. Taiwan's quarantine and public health agencies have been on full alert against the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OUTLINES PRINCIPLES FOR CHINESE OFFICIAL'S VISIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday the government will handle a senior Chinese official's application to visit Taiwan in line with the principles of "parity and reciprocity."

Addressing a campaign rally for ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidates for the year-end "three-in-one" elections in Taipei County, Chen said the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) application for Chen Yun-lin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, to visit Taiwan will be dealt with on a "parity and reciprocity" basis.

The KMT and its adversary-turned-partner -- the Communist Party of China (CPC) -- will co-sponsor an economic forum in Taipei in mid-December. A KMT think tank has filed applications with the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) for Chen Yun-lin and a large number of other Chinese officials in charge of Taiwan affairs to enter Taiwan to attend the seminar.

In his first public comment on the applications, President Chen said China has bluntly expressed its opposition to his appointment of Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to attend this year's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum on his behalf on the excuse that Wang doesn't have any "trade or economic backgrounds."
President Chen said he doesn't think that Chen Yunlin has any "trade or economic background."

On the principles of "parity, " Chen said the government cannot approve Chen Yunlin's entry if Wang is barred from attending the 2005 APEC summit to be held in Busan, South Korea Nov. 18-19 simply because of China's opposition.
Due to China's opposition, ROC president has been barred from attending the APEC summit in person and has to instead name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

President Chen further said if Chen Yunlin wants to visit Taiwan, China should allow his Taiwan counterpart -- MAC Chairman Joseph Wu -- to visit China to meet with Chinese dissidents or pro-democracy activists in accordance with the principle of reciprocity.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCTOBER 30 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Oct. 30:
09:30, An international seminar on Japan's Taiwan Study will open at the National Library in Taipei.
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a decommissioning ceremony for Kaohsiung Harbor's 13th pier.
15:00, President Chen will stump for DPP candidates in Makung, Penghu County.
15:00, Vice President Annette Lu will tour the 2005 Taiwan Design Fair at Weiwuying in Kaohsiung County.
20:00, President Chen will stump for DPP candidates in Homei, Changhua County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TVBS INSISTS ON NO BREACH OF LAW

TEXT.P: TVBS, a local cable broadcaster, insisted Saturday that it has not violated any existing laws regarding stock owership or stock transactions.

The TV station issued the statement after Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao said his office will demand TVBS explain its stock ownership as reports show that it is a 100 percent Hong Kong-owned enterprise.
Quoting a National Security Bureau report and information posted on a Web site, Yao said TVBS is fully owned by a Hong Kong company.

As such, Yao said TVBS is in violation of Article 10 of the Satellite Radio and TV Broadcasting Law which stipulates that foreign direct investments in a local television station should not exceed 50 percent of its total stake.
However, TVBS insisted that its Hong Kong shareholder only has a 47 percent stake in the company and that its remaining shares are held by a Taiwan-owned corporation.

On Friday, the GIO slapped a NT$200,000 fine to TVBS for "not honestly reporting the transfer and background of its shareholders." The fine came as one of the station's talk shows exposed the close relationship between former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan and labor brokers who brought in more than 1,400 Thai workers for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. but exploited and mis-treated them, resulting in their rioting in Kaohsiung County on Aug. 21.

The GIO is also investigating whether TVBS Chairman Norman Leung, who is a former chairman of the Hong Kong Broadcasting Authority, is eligible to hold such a high-ranking position in Taiwan's media industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN APOLOGIZES FOR CORRUPT PARTY MEMBER

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Su Tseng-chang apologized Saturday for a former senior government official's alleged involvement in a profiteering scandal surrounding the mass rapid transport (MRT) construction project in Kaohsiung.

Su made the apology after a provisional meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee during which all participants agreed to ask the party's disciplinary committee to expel Chen Che-nan, a former Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, for his alleged role in the Kaohsiung MRT scandal. Chen was indicted Thursday on charges of corruption and profiteering.
Noting that the DPP has pursued reform and clean politics, Su said the party is very sorry for Chen Che-nan's "lack of integrity."
"His inappropriate actions have seriously tarnished the party's image and impaired the public's trust in the DPP," Su said.
Meanwhile, a DPP official said the party's Central Advisory Committee will hold a meeting Sunday to make a formal decision to expel Chen.

During a weekend barnstorming tour to drum up support for DPP candidates in the year-end elections, President Chen Shui-bian also made an apology for the "lack of integrity" of Chen Che-nan who was questioned by prosecutors for the first time over the scandal Friday and was later released on a NT$500,000 bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 30, or the 28th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1735: John Adams, the second president of the United States, is born. He was one of the signatories to the Declaration of Independence, and he negotiated the end to the War of American Independence.
1910: Swiss philanthropist Henri Dunant dies at the age of 82. He founded the International Red Cross and shared the first Nobel Peace Prize with Frederic Passy of France in 1901.
1911: On the advice of the regent Prince Chun, Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, grants a constitution to combat growing support for the revolutionary forces of Dr. Sun Yat-sen.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party launches armed rebellions in Haifeng and Lufeng in Kwangtung Province.
1937: The National government decides to move the capital from Nanking to Chungking.
1952: The Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations is set up in Taipei following the first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference, which opened in Taipei on Oct. 22.
1953: Wu Ching-heng, former chairman of the Presidium of the Constituent Assembly, dies in Taipei at the age of 88.
1973: Tsengwen Dam and Reservoir, the largest in Taiwan, is completed and dedicated as a birthday present to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1973: Economic Minister Y. S. Sun leaves for Saigon to take part in the eighth Sino-Vietnamese Ministerial Conference on economic cooperation.
1974: Nobusuke Kishi, former Japanese prime minister, and Mitsujiro Ishii, former speaker of the House of Representatives, arrive in Taipei to join in birthday celebrations for President Chiang Kai-shek.
1974: The first F-5E Freedom jetfighter made in the Republic of China rolls off the assembly line.
1975: Ground for the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, named after the late president, is broken by Adm. Ni Yue-si, president of the ROC Amateur Athletic Federation, and Wang Yung-ching, the donor.
1975: Li Teng-hui, the ROC minister of state, leaves for Nakualofa at the head of an envoy to attend the 100th anniversary of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Tonga.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the establishment of National Chiang Kai-shek University in central Taiwan.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the code on gold trading and importation, to go into effect Nov. 1.
1986: The ROC-made "Sky Bow" and "Sky Sword" missiles are officially renamed the "Chung Cheng (Chiang Kai-shek) 100" series in a renaming ceremony presided over by Premier Yu Kuo-hwa.
1988: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, presides over one of the biggest mass wedding ceremonies in history, held in Yongin, South Korea, where 6,516 couples tie the knot.
1990: Communist China announces the results of a nationwide census which shows its population totals 1.13 billion people.
1990: The Republic of China establishes trade and consular ties with Bolivia.
1995: Voters in the province of Quebec vote in favor of remaining part of Canada in a referendum.
1995 Fire breaks out on a subway train below the streets of Baku, capital of the Republic of Azerbaijan, killing 337 people and injuring at least 270 others.
1997: Mary McAleese, a Belfast lawyer, is elected President of Ireland.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the Republic of China has never forsaken its goal of promoting eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: The ROC's opposition parties declare Premier Chang Chun-hsiung "persona non grata" for his announcement of a major policy turnabout that they say was not only "illegal," but also "sacrificed the public interest."
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen signs a memorandum on military cooperation with his Macedonian counterpart Ljuben Paunoski in Taipei.
2001: Microsoft Taiwan formally launches the new Microsoft Windows XP operating system at the Taipei International Convention Center, with thousands registered to try out the system.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "There never was a man trained to benevolence who neglected his parents. There never was a man trained to righteousness who made his ruler an after-consideration."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: U.S. to shift 7,000 marines from Okinawa to Guam.
Japan and the United States adopted on Saturday a realignment plan for U.S. forces aimed at promoting greater military integration between the two nations and lessening the burden on communities hosting U.S. bases, including a reduction of 7,000 marines in Okinawa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
President Chen Shui-bian apologizes twice a day for scandals.
The United Daily News:
Chen apologizes for Kaohsiung MRT development scandal.

The president apologizes for scandal involving his former deputy
chief of staff.

the country fooled.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Top Cheney Aide Indicted; CIA Leak Inquiry Continues. Vice President Dick Cheney's chief of staff, I. Lewis "Scooter" Libby, one of the most trusted and powerful aides in the White House, was indicted Friday on felony charges of obstruction of justice, making false statements and perjury in a case that has revived the debate over President Bush's reasons for invading Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA IMPORTING TAIWAN FRUIT A CONSPIRACY: VICE PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged the country Sunday not to be fooled by Beijing's allowing fruit from Taiwan to be exported to China, calling the gesture a conspiracy.

During a barnstorming tour to drum up support for Tainan county chief Su Huan-chih, who is seeking a second term in elections in December, Lu said that Taiwan's fruit, much of which is produced in Tainan County, is of world-class quality and that such produce should be exported to Japan, Europe and the United States, instead of China.

Lu said that shipping Taiwan fruit to China provided China's agriculture sector with opportunities to conduct research on the superior Taiwan produce with the intention of cultivating similar products over much larger areas at much cheaper cost and dumping them in the Taiwan market before long.

Lu called Beijing's decision to allow Taiwanese fruit to be exported to China a political conspiracy. The decision was made after opposition leaders visited China earlier this year, with the knowledge that most of the farmers in southern Taiwan are supporters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Lu said.

Meanwhile, Lu said, counterfeit products claiming to be high-priced Taiwanese fruit have appeared on the market in China, resulting in both in Chinese consumers being cheated and Taiwan's reputation being compromised.

Furthermore, Lu said, Beijing's refusal to talk with Taiwan authorities about fruit exports and allowing such talks only between the Taiwan Provincial Farmers' Association and its mainland counterpart appeared to be a plot to downgrade Taiwan's status to that of a "province of China."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S APOLOGY IS 'CORRECT FIRST STEP': KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's apology Saturday for the involvement of one of his aides in a profiteering scandal was "the first step in the right direction," although it came a bit late, Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Sunday.
Ma said, however, that people want the truth about the scandal concerning the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit project, and they would not be satisfied unless the whole truth was uncovered.

The KMT chairman, who is also mayor of Taipei City, urged public prosecutors to make a thorough investigation of the case. He also urged all related government departments to cooperate in order to restore the people's trust in the government.

The president's apology came two days after hard evidence surfaced showing Chen Che-nan, a former Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, visited a casino in South Korea with labor brokers for the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit project in November 2002. At the time, Chen Che-nan was considered the president's right-hand man. He became a national policy adviser to the president in 2004, but resigned his post in early October amid wide speculation about his involvement in the affair.

The profiteering case emerged after a riot by Thai laborers on Aug. 21 in protest against their maltreatment by their employers, the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp., and their management, Huapan Consultant Administration Co.

A photo shown on a TV program last week showed Chen Che-nan and Chen Min-hsien, former vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) , gambling in a casino in South Korea. Further evidence emerged later showing that a labor broker accompanied them on the trip and paid for their airplane tickets and hotel expenses.

The president made the apology when he addressed supporters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party during a campaign stop in Ilan. He also assured that if there was any evidence showing that he himself has been involved in the scandal, he will be willing to step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

La Repubblica: Berlusconi: I was against Iraq war.
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said in a television interview to be aired the coming Monday that he was against the Iraq war. According to a press release by the private Channel 7, Berluscon revealed that he tried many times without success to convince U.S. President George W. Bush not to invade Iraq. Berlusconi is to fly to Washington Monday for an one-day official visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PREREQUISITES' NOT CONDUCIVE TO TAIWAN'S DIPLOMACY: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's "prerequisites" for a visit to Taiwan by China's top official in charge of Taiwan relations are not conducive to the development of Taiwan's diplomacy, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday.

President Chen said Saturday that the administration will handle the request to visit Taiwan by Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, and some 50 Beijing officials responsible for Taiwan affairs, in line with the principles of "parity and reciprocity."

President Chen said that on the principle of "parity, " the government cannot approve Chen Yunlin's entry if Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng is barred from attending the informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Busan, South Korea Nov. 18-19 as his proxy simply because of China's opposition.

President Chen also said that if Chen Yunlin wants to visit Taiwan, China should also allow his Taiwan counterpart -- Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu -- to visit China to meet with Chinese dissidents or pro-democracy activists in accordance with the principle of reciprocity.
Chen Yunlin and the Beijing officials have been invited by the KMT to visit Taiwan in mid-December to attend an economic and trade forum hosted by the party.

In his first public comment on the applications, President Chen said China has bluntly expressed its opposition to his appointment of Wang to attend this year's APEC informal leadership summit on his behalf on the excuse that Wang doesn't have any "trade or economic background."
"I don't think Chen Yunlin has any trade or economic background either," President Chen said.
Commenting on the president's remarks, Ma said that while these "prerequisites" may serve to satisfy a desire for revenge, they were not helpful in improving Taiwan's diplomatic climate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CHE-NAN'S EXPULSION MEANS GARBAGE HAS BEEN CLEANED OUT: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu compared former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary General Chen Che-nan to a piece of garbage Sunday, saying that by expelling Chen, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has "swept away the garbage and is now clean again. "

Following the party's Central Standing Committee's decision to expel Chen Saturday night, the DPP's Central Advisory Committee also decided Sunday to kick Chen out of the party after he was questioned by prosecutors over his suspected involvement in the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) scandal.

In Tainan County, where she was stumping for DPP candidate Su Huan-chih who is seeking re-election in the December local government elections, Lu urged voters to remain calm in the face of a barrage of charges against the ruling party.

"We should all stand on the side of President Chen Shui-bian" who, Lu said, had apologized to the people for "something that has happened to the DPP, " adding that everybody makes mistakes and that "what is important is to apologize quickly and correct oneself. "
Lu said a house will be clean again as long as any garbage inside has been found and swept out.
"Some people are now waiting to usurp power, and we must not feel dejected," she said.

Lu said that the president had apologized with sincerity and determination, in addition to reassuring people that however close to the "emperor" one may be, he or she will be treated equally before the law.
In Kaohsiung, Premier Frank Hsieh stressed the sincerity of his own apology concerning the KRTC scandal, the details of which happened during Hsieh's incumbency as Kaohsiung City's mayor.

"I have offered my apology for the KRTC scandal, and I don't think I have to repeat that apology over and over again. The sincerity of the apology is more important, " Hsieh said, in reply to media questions.

As Chen Che-nan had been honored with a government medal on the ground that he had "boosted the Presidential Office's clean image, " both ruling party and opposition lawmakers saw the irony in the awarding of the medal and issued statements demanding an explanation from the Presidential Office.
The DPP's legislative caucus suggested that, in future, a check into the proposed recipient's moral character be done before deciding to present him or her with a national medal.

The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) legislative caucus accused the Presidential Office of indiscriminately giving out national awards to reward the president's personal friends, including Chen Che-nan, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang, acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan and National Security Council Secretary General Chiu Yi-jen.

In response to such criticism, the Department of Public Affairs of the Presidential Office said were Chen Che-nan to be convicted of a crime and deprived of his civil rights, his medal would be "withdrawn" along with the certificate proving its authenticity.
Chen Che-nan has repeatedly lied to the media concerning his foreign trips to Asian countries while denying that he has in any way been involved in the KRTC scandal.

Independent Legislator Chiu Yi, who exposed a damning photo showing Chen and former KRTC Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien, who is also being investigated, sitting together at a Korean casino, said Sunday he has more evidence to show Chen Che-nan had also visited Vietnam twice in June 2003 on what he called suspicious trips.
Chiu also ridiculed the prosecution for "following the media's footsteps in investigating the KRTC and other scandals. "
The DPP's legislative caucus said the prosecution should ask Chiu to help them investigate the case and Chiu on his part should cooperate with the prosecutors.
DPP Legislator Cheng Yun-peng said his party has not set any "limit" to the probe, and nor has the prosecution. "Otherwise, the scandal would not have grown to such a proportion," Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF PEOPLE HAVE LOST CONFIDENCE IN DPP GOVERNMENT: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Sixty percent of people in Taiwan have no confidence in the capacity of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to perform as the ruling party, according to results of a survey released Sunday.
The survey, conducted by the United Daily News, interviewed 1,117 people throughout Taiwan by telephone on Saturday night and has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.9 percent.

The mass-circulation daily conducted the poll shortly after President Chen Shui-bian's denial that he was aware that former deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office Chen Che-nan made a visit to South Korea in November 2002 and had a close association with labor brokers involved in a profiteering scandal and the exploitation of Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit project.

Chen Che-nan, who resigned his current Presidential Office post as national policy adviser to the president in early October amid speculation about his involvement in the scandal, admitted he took the trip to South Korea and two other trips to Thailand without asking for leave first from his superiors.

He withdrew his DPP membership Friday after being questioned by public prosecutors. However, in a special meeting Saturday, the DPP Central Standing Committee decided to strip him of his DPP membership anyway, making it impossible to restore his party membership in the next five years.

Asked whether they believed that the president had no prior knowledge of Chen Che-nan's irregular behavior as exposed by news media, 54 percent of the respondents said "no." Only 13 percent believed that the president had prior knowledge. Another 32 percent said they had no opinion.
Questioned about the president's performance, 56 percent of those polled said they were not satisfied, while 28 percent said they were satisfied.

On the performance of the DPP as a ruling party, 60 percent expressed discontent, up from the 56 percent indicated by a survey in early October. Only 25 percent said they were satisfied with the DPP's performance.
Fifty-two percent of the respondents saw the DPP as a corrupt political party, with 23 percent believing otherwise.
Asked whether they believed Chen Che-nan was clean, 62 percent said "no," with only 5 percent giving an affirmative answer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TWO-WAY TRADE WITH CHINA CONTINUES TO SURGE: BOFT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two-way trade with China grew 15 percent year-on-year in the first eight months of this year, surging to US$45.6 billion, officials from the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Sunday.
January-to-August two-way trade with China constituted 18.9 percent of Taiwan's entire foreign trade during that period, up one percentage point over the year-earlier level, BOFT officials said.

Taiwan's exports to China amounted to US$32.74 billion during the period, up 11.7 percent on the figure posted for the same period of 2004. This amounted to 27.1 percent of Taiwan's entire export trade in the period, marking a year-on-year increase of 1.2 percentage points in this area.

Taiwan's imports from China totaled US$12.87 billion in the same eight month period, up 24.5 percent on the corresponding period of 2004. This amount was 10.7 percent of all of Taiwan's import trade in the period, marking a year-on-year increase of 1.1 percentage points, BOFT officials said.
Taiwan thus enjoyed a trade surplus of US$19.87 billion with China in the first eight months of this year, the officials said, showing growth of 4.7 percent compared with the same period of 2004.
During the January-August period, electrical engineering equipment, optoelectronics, machinery, plastics, steel, chemicals and man-made fibers made the bulk of Taiwan's exports to China.

Meanwhile, electrical engineering equipment, machinery, steel, mineral fuel, optoelectronics, chemicals, plastics, metal products, cement, transportation vehicles and parts made the bulk of Taiwan's imports from China in the same period, the officials said.

They also quoted tallies compiled by the Chinese Customs authorities as indicating that Taiwan was China's third largest source of imports in the first eight months of this year, behind only Japan and South Korea, while ahead of the United States, Germany, Malaysia, Singapore, Australia, Russia and Thailand, in that order.
Imports from these 10 countries constituted 62.85 percent of China's entire import trade in that period, the Chinese Customs tallies showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT ADVISES AGAINST WATCHING 'LYING' MEDIA REPORTS

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui advised the public Sunday not to watch or read media reports that he claimed are mostly "lies" created by scoop-vying journalists and their executives.
Lee made his remarks while stumping for Chen Chien-ming, a Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) candidate for the year-end city and county elections. Lee is the TSU's spiritual leader.
Taiwan appears to be in turmoil because "too few people are willing to sacrifice themselves and too few people dare to do what is right," Lee said.
He criticized the media for negative reporting which he said made people feel depressed and caused them to lose confidence in the future of the country.
"My advice would be not to look at such reports since they are mostly lies, but non-truths seem to become truths after being reported so often," he said.
Lee said he personally just smiled at sensational media reports, many of which were often entirely invented.
Given that media's appetite for sensational scoops had made them play fast and loose with the truth, "people are feeling society is in chaos and wondering why Taiwan has become like this," Lee said.

Lee said he would call on the people to "remain calm and confident, and not to succumb to negative thinking but instead to feel positive, and unify together." That was his recipe for "hope for Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HAS TO MOVE ON AFTER 'STEPPING ON COW DUNG': PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Sunday urged citizens of Kaohsiung, where the construction of the mass rapid transit system has been at the center of a corruption scandal, to move on after stepping on a heap of cow dung.

Hsieh was the second Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) leader to use figurative language to describe the mess the party is in Sunday after Vice President Annette Lu said that by expelling former Presidential Office deputy secretary general Chen Che-nan, the DPP has "swept out the garbage and is now clean again."

Chen is being investigated over his suspected role in a scandal revolving around the hiring of Thai workers for the mass rapid transit project that erupted after the workers rioted in protest of poor living conditions and inhumane treatments.
He was recently found to have been lying to the public about a trip to South Korea he had made with labor brokers for the mass rapid transit project.

Like a mountain hiker who accidentally stepped onto a heap of cow dung, "we've got to move on after cleaning our shoes with stones or leaves and should not stay there to play with the dung," Hsieh said.

"As I have repeatedly stressed before, all the controversies will disappear while the construction will stay; pains will go but beauty will remain with us, " Hsieh said, adding that he believed all the disputes surrounding Kaohsiung's various city development projects will become a thing of the past as the citizens move on with their lives.
Hsieh made the remarks while attending a ceremony to retire Kaohsiung Harbor's No. 13 Wharf. President Chen Shui-bian also attended.

Hsieh used the opportunity to lash out at the "pan-blue" alliance of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party, claiming that the alliance, which enjoys a slim majority in the legislature, has blocked the Executive Yuan's proposal to develop Kaohsiung Harbor 52 times in the Legislative Yuan.

As a result, he said, most critics said handing over the No 13 Wharf to the city government would not happen until 2011. "But with the help of the president and cooperation between the central and local governments, we've moved that schedule ahead, an achievement that no one dared anticipate," Hsieh said.
Hsieh, a former mayor of Kaohsiung, urged the city's citizens not to lose confidence in the DPP government, telling them that they have a friend in the central government to cheer them up.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S BULLET TRAIN PASSES TEST RUNS AT 315 KPH

TEXT.P: The new 700T bullet train built in Japan for the Taiwan High-Speech Rail Corp. (THSRC) passed a series of test runs Sunday, increasing its speed to its maximum 315 kph, according to THSRC.

A spokesman for the operator of Taiwan's first bullet train said the tests had been conducted on a section of the high-speed rail track in Kueijen township in Tainan County, and that all three tests had run smoothly.

He said the test runs at the current stage are intended to not only check the train's ability to accelerate and brake, but also examine the structural health of the track and other hardware and the integration of the electric wiring and signals in relation to the high-speed train.
THSRC ordered 30 sets of the 700T rail cars from Japan and has already taken delivery of 20 sets. Each set consists of 12 carriages with seating capacity for a total of 986 passengers.
Construction of the track and stations is about 95 percent complete, though the start of services has yet to be decided after THSRC postponed its planned launch in October.

The 345 km railway will reduce the time for a journey between Taiwan and Kaohsiung -- Taiwan's two largest cities -- to 90 minutes. The cost of the project has grown to more than NT$500 billion (US$14.9 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO PROBLEMS FACING TAIWAN'S FIGHT AGAINST AVIAN FLU: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Two problems need to be addressed urgently in Taiwan's fight against avian flu, Dr. Wong Chi-huey, chief of the Genomics Research Center under Academia Sinica said Sunday.

The first problem is to stop contacts between poultry and people; the second is to locate drug companies or laboratories which meet the criteria of Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) to produce vaccine against avian flu, Wong said in interview with CNA, Sunday.
The current human avian flu cases reported in some Asian countries were caused by close contact between humans and poultry infected with the disease.
There is risk that the avian flu virus, H5N1, could mutate once entering into the body of human beings to allow human-to-human infection, Wong said.
The first line of defense in the battle against the flu is to prevent contacts between poultry and people, thereby denying the virus the chance to jump from birds to humans, Wong said.
The second problem is to manufacture vaccine against the disease in addition to stockpiling drugs for avian flu such as Tamiflu and Relenza.
Wong said Taiwan is technically capable of manufacturing vaccine but unfortunately it does not have pharmaceutical companies which meet GMP standards.

Only vaccine produced by GMP-accredited pharmaceutical companies can be used on humans, Wong said, adding that a simple way to solve this problem would be to help private pharmaceutical companies or the government's medical research institutes to upgrade their equipment and manufacturing practices to meet the GMP criteria.

Noting that the technology for producing vaccine is already in place, Wong said that the country needed to acquire proper production facilities, rather than research the way to produce vaccine from scratch.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HSIEH URGES TVBS TO SHOW SHAREHOLDER STRUCTURE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh urged TVBS, a cable TV channel which broadcast a political talk show exposing damning evidence concerning a senior former presidential aid's possible involvement in a profiteering scandal, to reveal its shareholder structure on Sunday.

If the TV company's shareholder structure violates the law, "then it must be dealt with according to law," Hsieh said while attending a ceremony to retire the No. 13 Wharf at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan.

The law stipulates that foreign investors must not possess more than 50 percent of a Taiwanese TV company; if that is felt to be unreasonable, efforts could be made to request that the Legislative Yuan amend the law, the premier said.
However, for the time being, law enforcement authorities must enforce the law as it is, he said.
Hsieh said initial government investigation showed a problem with TVBS' shareholder structure.
"TVBS itself should be more efficient in presenting a truthful report about this," Hsieh said.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) legislative caucus also demanded that TVBS explain who were its major shareholders.
Cheng Yun-peng, a DPP legislator, said radio and TV channels are "rare resources" that must be strictly regulated, and therefore it must use "high standards" to explain its shareholder structure.

The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) legislative caucus came forward in defence of TVBS, claiming that its Hong Kong-sourced capital cannot be seen as Chinese capital as the government had reached a conclusion on this issue before Hong Kong's return to China in 1997.

Lian Yee Production Co. which owns several TVBS channels has been suspected of being manipulated by China because 100 percent of Lian Yee's capital comes from Hong Kong, the Government Information Office has claimed.

Pan Wei-kang, deputy secretary of the KMT caucus, advised the ruling party and the government to spend their time and energy mapping out good strategies to revive the economy and improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations, rather than besmearing and persecuting a TV channel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RECEIVES NEW DESTROYERS FROM US
DOC.DATELINE: Charleston, South Carolina, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: In a ceremony presided over by R.O.C. Navy chief Adm. Chen Pang-chih Saturday, two US-made Kidd-class destroyers were handed over to Taiwan and made ready to head to their new home base.
Instead of donning his uniform, Adm. Chen appeared at the ceremony in civilian clothes to play down the military significance of his country's acquisition of the two warships.

Contrary to Chen's low profile, his US counterpart in the ceremony, Brigadier-General John Allen, the principal director for Asian and Pacific Affairs, International Security Affairs of the Office of the Secretary of Defense showed up in his uniform, and called on Taiwan politicians be more concerned about the safety of their country and deal responsibly with the Taiwan government's request to purchase a package of arms from the USA.
Allen was referring to the Taiwan government's request to buy US$16 billion worth of arms from the US, which has been blocked by the legislature more than 30 times.
The US general also said the destroyers, the first two of four purchased by Taiwan, would strengthen Taiwan's defense capability and improve its security.
Also present at Saturday's ceremony were David Lee, Taiwan's representative to the USA, and a group of journalists stationed by Taiwan media in Washington.
It has not been announced when The two destroyers, named by Taiwan authorities the Keelung and the Suao, will leave Charleston for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA'S FATHER IN SERIOUS CONDITION

TEXT.P: Ma Ho-ling, the 86-year-old father of Kuomintang Chairman and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, was sent to a hospital for emergency treatment after he collapsed while eating at a friend's home Sunday afternoon and was listed as in serious condition.

Doctors at Cathay General Hospital said Ma Ho-ling was breathless and without a pulse when he arrived at the hospital but was resuscitated after 12 minutes of emergency treatment. He remained, however, in a deep coma.

The cause of his collapse remains unclear, the doctors said. Food was found in his throat which might have choked the old man and led to the collapse, but since he had suffered a heart attack 12 years ago, he might have collapse because of the recurrence of the heart problem.
Ma Ying-jeou rushed to the hospital after learning of his father's collapse.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUCKRAKING NO REASON FOR MEDIA TO BREAK LAW: GIO

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) said Sunday no media should be allowed to use "exposing scandals" as an excuse to break the law.

The GIO was referring to a controversy over the shareholder structure of TVBS, a cable TV channel which broadcast a talk show exposing damning evidence concerning former Presidential Office deputy secretary general Chen Che-nan's alleged involvement in a profiteering scandal.

In the face of mounting criticism of the timing to investigate TVBS's capital source, the GIO claimed that no matter whether the major source of the TV station's capital comes from Hong Kong or China, it is "foreign capital" whose share of the total investment is clearly defined by law.

No media can claim that it is not regulated by law because it is exposing government scandals; and no media can break the law under the excuse that it is being besmeared as a pro-Communist business, said the GIO.
It said it respects freedom of the press and freedom of expression, and as part of the government, it is watched and supervised by the legislature as well as by public opinion.
Entrusted by the state, the GIO must not change its position of "carrying out its administrative duties according to law" and "not allowing anyone to enjoy legal holidays," said the GIO.

The GIO accused TVBS of not replying to its demand to explain whether it had violated Article 10 of the Satellite Radio and TV Broadcasting Law, which says foreign direct investment in a local TV station must not exceed 50 percent of its total stake.

GIO Minister Pasuya Yao has claimed that TVBS is fully owned by a Hong Kong company, and therefore is a 100 percent foreign-owned enterprise. Some DPP legislators suspected that China may be behind the stake holding company and trying to manipulate its operations.

Since TVBS has obtained its operation license based on the Satellite Radio and TV Broadcasting Law, naturally it should also be governed by this law, including the provision regarding foreign investment, said GIO.
It said different types of media or businesses are regulated by different laws. TVBS, as a TV broadcasting enterprise, certainly must be regulated by the Satellite Radio and TV Broadcasting Law.
It noted Apple Daily, a mass circulation newspaper in Taiwan that is also Hong Kong-invested, has been carrying out its media duties but apparently is not regulated by the same law as TVBS.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA GROUP RAPS GIO FOR STATEMENT ABOUT TVBS

TEXT.P: A self-claimed Campaign for Media Reform group rapped the Government Information Office (GIO) Sunday for what it called bungling the case involving a local cable station, TVBS, and making inappropriate statement about it.

Wei Ti, convener of the campaign said in a statement that GIO should not repeatedly warn that TVBS' license to operate in Taiwan could be suspended, because a panel organized by the GIO to review cable TV station's permits has already renewed that station's permit in August.

Even the license of TV stations could be withdrawn in case it was granted on the basis of false information provided by the stations, the decision should be taken by the review panel through legal process including careful investigation, the statement said.

The GIO Minister Pasuda Yao should stop repeating his warns that TVBS' license could be taken away should it be found lying about the changes of its ownership because it constitutes a threat to the TV station.

The Campaign for Media Reform also blamed some lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for branding TVBS an arms of China with the design to topple DPP administration in Taiwan, claiming that these lawmakers are trying to influence media for political purposes.
Legislators may disagree with media's reports but should not try to pressurize them into silence by calling them followers of Communist Party of China, the statement said.
The TVBS irritated DPP lawmakers after it covers intensively the scandal surrounding the Kaohsiung MRT project and criticizes the DPP administration's handle of it.

Noting that TVBS was financed with capital from China, two DPP lawmakers blamed TVBS for trying to oust DPP administration Friday after it claimed the previous day that a former adviser to President Chen Shui-bian played a vital role in the Kaohsiung MRT scandal.

The GIO Minister Pasuya Yao stepped into the dispute that day by announcing a fine of NT$200,000 on TVBS on the ground that it failed to reveal the changes in its ownership, which, Yao claimed, could cost that station its license.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR OCTOBER 31 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Monday, October 31:
10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive a group of Russian visitors invited to visit Taiwan by the Council for Cultural Affairs.
10:30, Vice President Annette Lu will receive a group of Finland parliamentarians in her office.
11:30, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference at its Taipei office.
14:00, The Central Election Commission will release an anti-fraud election commercials at its Taipei office.
15:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will showcase his administration's works in October in a news conference at the Executive Yuan.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at its Taipei headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 31, or the 29th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Martin Luther nails his 95 theses against papal corruption in Rome to the church door in Wittenberg.
1887: Chiang Kai-shek, the late president of the Republic of China, is born at Hsikou in Fenghua County, Chekiang Province.
1916: Gen. Huang Hsin, leader of the revolution that overthrew the Ching dynasty, dies in Shanghai at the age of 43.
1947: The United Nations sets aside Oct. 24 as "United Nations Day."
1952: The China Youth Corps is organized with Chiang Ching-kuo serving as director.
1957: Tsung Dao Lee and Chen Ning Yang share the Nobel Prize for physics for work disproving the law of conservation of parity.
1958: Nobel Prize winning author Boris Pasternak is expelled from the Soviet Writers' Union and faces possible exile for his "Dr. Zhivago."
1966: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Lesotho.
1971: China Television Service, the third commercial TV network in the Republic of China, begins regular programming.
1972: The Southern Cross-Island Highway, which took four-and-a-half years to build at a cost of nearly NT$500 million, is opened to traffic.
1974: People throughout the Republic of China celebrate the 87th birthday of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan addresses leaders gathered to pay tribute to President Chiang Kai-shek on the late leader's 90th birthday, then breaks ground for the Chung Cheng Memorial Hall to honor President Chiang.
1976: Taichung port in west central Taiwan is formally opened.
1978: The Taiwan Area Freeway, with a total length of 377 km, is fully opened to traffic on the 92nd anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1978: The Sino-Saudi Arabian Bridge over the Choshui River in central Taiwan, which was built with low-interest loans from Saudi Arabia, opens to traffic as a part of the newly completed North-South Freeway.
1979: Representatives of retired servicemen meet at the Taipei City Auditorium to mark the first Veterans Day, also marking the 25th anniversary of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen.
1981: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives J.A. Guevara Moran, the minister of agriculture and pasture of the Republic of El Salvador.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old MiG-19 pilot in the Communist Chinese air force who flew to a U.S. military base outside Seoul on Oct. 16, arrives in Taipei.
1983: Taipei's Kuantu Bridge, the first multi-arch steel bridge in East Asia, opens to traffic. The construction of the bridge, 809 meters long, took three years and cost NT$700 million to complete.
1984: Mrs. Indira Gandhi, Indian prime minister, is shot dead while walking in the garden of her home in New Delhi. She was 67.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek presides over and addresses a mass rally at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang.
1996: Former Polish President Lech Walesa visits the Republic of China.
1999: A delegation from the Taiwan Roots Medical Organization leaves for a visit to four African countries to evaluate the possibility of providing medical care to one of them.
2000: Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the opposition Kuomintang says that he is continuing to solicit more support for his proposal to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
2000: A Los Angeles-bound Singapore Airlines Boeing 747-400 jumbo jet crashes while taking off from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing 81 of the 179 aboard, leaving 44 injured and 54 others unhurt.
2001: Participants in a civil nuclear cooperation meeting between the Republic of China and the United States agree to increase exchanges on nuclear power plant safety and to establish formal communication channels regarding the matter.
2001: Former U.S. Secretary of Defense William Cohen, accompanied by a two-member entourage for a three-day visit in the Republic of China, calls on Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao and other high ranking officials.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "If you will practice a benevolent government, then the people will love all above them and will die for their officers."
