DOC.HEADLINE: TVBS CASE SHOULD BE DEALT WITH ACCORDING TO THE LAW: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that the case of TVBS, a local cable TV channel which has been accused by a legislator of being a 100-percent "Chinese invested" corporation, should be dealt with according to the law.
Hsieh made the remarks after attending an event promoting nationwide disaster-prevention efforts.

Taiwan law stipulates that foreign investors cannot have more than a 50-percent stake in a Taiwan TV company. The premier said that if this is considered unreasonable, then efforts can be made to request that the Legislative Yuan amend the law.

On Sunday, Hsieh called for TVBS, which broadcast recently a political talk show exposing evidence concerning a senior former presidential aid's possible involvement in a profiteering scandal, to reveal its shareholder structure.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Tsai Chi-fang said at a press conference held in the Legislative Yuan Monday that even if the TVBS shareholders are from Hong Kong instead of from China, as claimed by TVBS general manager Lee Tao, this is still in violation of the law.
"Hong Kong capital is Chinese capital, since Hong Kong is a special administrative region of China," Tsai said.
Tsai demanded that the Government Information Office (GIO) repeal TVBS' operating license. Otherwise, he said, "the case will be remain under the spotlight."

In the face of mounting criticism about the timing of the investigation into TVBS's source of capital, the GIO said Sunday that regardless of whether the investors are from Hong Kong or from China, it is still foreign capital, and the law is very clear on the ownership issue.

Members of the legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party said Monday that if the GIO scraps TVBS' satellite broadcasting license, the party will launch a rally of one million people to defend freedom of speech in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS RIGHT TO ATTEND APEC MEETING: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen told lawmakers on Monday that Taiwan is "a country and cannot accept interference from other countries."

Chen made the remarks in response to a question from opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator John Chiang on President Chen Shui-bian's recent comment regarding China's opposition to Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng attending on the president's behalf the informal leadership summit of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) set to take place in Busan, South Korea Nov. 18-19.

President Chen said Saturday during a public activity in Keelung, northern Taiwan that "if Wang can't go, then Chen Yunlin can't come," referring to the KMT's invitation to the head of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council to visit the island for a seminar co-sponsored by the KMT and its adversary-turned-partner, the Communist Party of China, in Taipei in mid-December.

Speaking at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session, the minister explained that what the president meant was that Taiwan has the legitimate right to attend the summit and cannot be stopped from taking part because of China's opposition.
"President Chen still hopes that Wang can attend the APEC summit on his behalf. He insists on that," the minister said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 131.33 points to close at 5,764.3.
The bourse opened at 5,692.82 and fluctuated between 5,774.61 and 5,681.2 during trading. A total of 3.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$73.18 billion (US$2.18 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 3.2 percent, followed by construction issues at 2.3 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.7 percent, cement stocks at 1.5 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.6 percent, textile stocks at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 877 to 160, with 126 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKS TO PRODUCE TAMIFLU UNDER 'COMPULSORY LICENSING'

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) submitted an application to the Intellectual Property Office (IPO) Monday for a "compulsory license" to allow Tamiflu, a Swiss-patented drug used to treat influenza, to be produced in Taiwan as part of efforts to battle a possible avian flu pandemic.

Health Minister Hou Sheng-mou said that it was hoped that the IPO under the Ministry of Economic Affairs would hand down its ruling about the compulsory license before the end of November, legitimizing the DOH to conditionally produce Tamiflu in Taiwan.

It is hoped that quantities of Tamiflu can be produced locally under a compulsory license to allow Taiwan to have enough Tamiflu doses for 3 million people, plus existing Tamiflu stocks, in the event of a bird flu outbreak, Hou said.
According to IPO authorities, if Tamiflu is produced locally under a compulsory license, the DOH will have to compensate Roche, the Swiss pharmaceutical giant which is the Tamiflu patent holder.

Hou said that in addition to seeking to produce Tamiflu under a compulsory license, the DOH is also working to arrange for consultations with Roche's management in Geneva to gain authorization from the Tamiflu patent holder to mass-produce Tamiflu directly in Taiwan.
Rising global alarm over a possible bird flu pandemic has caused a worldwide shortage of Tamiflu.

Roche has recently informed the DOH that it is willing to discuss cooperation programs with Taiwan over Tamiflu, but it is undecided so far when the consultations will take place and what details will be discussed, DOH officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA'S FATHER STRUGGLING FOR LIFE

TEXT.P: Ma Ho-ling, the father of Koumintang Chairman and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, remained in serious condition Monday following his sudden collapse Sunday, according to a doctor at Cathay General Hospital in Taipei where the older Ma was admitted.

Dr. Huang Cheng-hua, director of the Internal Medicine Department, said Ma Ho-ling had remained in the intensive care unit following his admission. He remained in a coma had made little improvement in the past 24 hours.

Huang said the prognosis for the senior Ma was not very good; patients of his age -- he is 86 -- usually have difficulty in making a complete recovery. All doctors could do at the moment was stabilize his breathing and heartbeat.

Ma Ho-ling collapsed while eating at a friend's home Sunday afternoon. The hospital said he was not breathing and had no pulse on arrival but doctors managed to resuscitate him after 12 minutes of effort.
He suffered from convulsions briefly on Sunday night as a result of brain damaged caused by oxygen starvation prior to his resuscitation, Huang said.

Before he was revived, the Information Department of the Taipei City Government released a mobile phone text message to the city's journalists saying that he died only to have to embarrassingly correct it minutes later.
According to analysis of his blood, Huang said Ma Ho-ling collapsed probably as a result of a 12-year old heart condition.
The mayor went to see his father at the hospital Monday morning but kept his afternoon schedule intact.

Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi issued a statement Sunday to express his support for Nicolo Pollari, chief of Italy's military intelligence service SISMI. Pollari is accused of allegedly delivering false documents on former Iraqi president Saddam Hussein's attempt to buy uranium in Africa to the U.S. government. Berlusconi said in the statement that he has always appreciated the work Pollari has done at SISMI and continue to do so. Berlusconi is to fly to Washington Monday for an one-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY WITHDRAWS FROM SHIP-SINKING

TEXT.P: The military has decided to withdraw temporarily from a mission to sink a capsized South Korean freighter carrying a cargo of toxic benzene off Hsinchu, northern Taiwan after conducting inter-ministry consultations, Vice Minister of National Defense Huo Shou-yeh said Monday.
The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) is currently working to come up with a more feasible plan to handle the capsized ship and its toxic cargo, Huo said at the Legislative Yuan.
The military will rejoin the EPA in the mission if requested to in the future and it is believed that military can successfully destroy the highly flammable benzene by setting it alight, Huo said.

The 3,561-ton South Korean freighter Samho Brother capsized Oct. 10 after a collision with the 13,629-ton TS Hongkong registered in Liberia. All 14 crewmembers were rescued. In addition to 3,140 cubic meters of benzene, the Samho Brother was carrying 85 tons of fuel oil and 16 tons of diesel.
After the mishap, the EPA decided that the benzene aboard the Korean ship would have to be burnt to prevent it from polluting the adjacent sea area off Taiwan's northwest coast.

Discounting media reports that the combat capability of the Republic of China Air Force and Army Aviation Force came under question after two F-16s jet fighters and one Army helicopter were sent to destroy the capsized ship last week but failed to accomplish their missions, Huo said that the four laser-guided missiles fired by the F-16s did hit the target, at both the ship's bow and stern.
The missiles failed, however, to ignite the benzene because it was carried in the hold under the deck, which the missiles did not hit, Huo said.
Huo said that, even if the missiles had hit the cargo hold, the benzene might not have exploded because there might not have been enough benzene vapor in the hold to facilitate an explosion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for November moved up 115 points to close at 5,775, with 27,380 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for December moved up 115 points to end at 5,772, with 311 contracts traded, while March futures gained 190 points to finish at 5,844, with four contracts traded. June futures moved up 112 points to close at 5,756, with nine contracts traded, while September futures moved up 77 points to close at 5,685, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,660 for November, 5,657 for December, 5,654 for March, 5,644 for June and 5,608 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

November TE futures moved up 7.1 points to close at 239.7, with 5,191 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 6.7 points to finish at 239.5, with 49 contract transactions. DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE SPENDING MORE TIME WATCHING CABLE TV PROGRAMS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Each person in Taiwan spends on average 90.1 minutes a day watching cable TV programs, according to a survey released Monday.
This marks an increase since a similar survey was conducted in May, of over two minutes a day.
The results are part of Taoyuan County-based National Central University's September survey on the general public's daily leisure activities.
The telephone survey was conducted Sept. 19-23 with 2,084 randomly chosen citizens aged above 20.
The survey has a margin of error of plus or minus 1.5 percentage points at a 95 percent level of confidence.

The survey found that ordinary people spent on average 57 minutes per day surfing the Internet, shorter than the level of 60.5 minutes in May, while 41.4 minutes on average was spent on reading books and 35.2 minutes spent on reading newspapers.

The September survey also showed that each cable TV recipient household paid a monthly fee of NT$501-NT$600 (US$14.9-US$17.9) . Broadband Internet users paid an average NT$1,003 for their hookups, the survey found.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANDIDACIES AFFIRMED IN ELECTIONS OF COUNTIES AND CITIES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Election Commission of the Taiwan Provincial Government, based in Nantou, affirmed on Monday the candidacy of 70 hopefuls seeking elections as county chiefs and the candidacy of 1,641 hopefuls to contest seats on local councils in the province's 21 counties and cities in elections to be held in December.

After a meeting of its members, the commission denied candidacy to only one would-be county chief candidate, Chen Chao-jung, on the grounds that he had entered his name as a candidate both for the Changhua County chief and county council races.
Three would-be candidates for council races, including Chen, were rejected.

Another would-be candidate in Penghu was denied candidacy for signing up for two races simultaneously, while it was found that another in Taitung County had been deprived of his right to run for public office by the judiciary.

The candidacy of one would-be candidate has yet to be confirmed. He was previously jailed by a military court and the commission has yet to complete checking with the military court to make sure he is qualified to stand, the commission said.
The order of candidates on ballots will be decided by drawing lots on Nov. 11.
The election will be held Dec. 3.
In addition to the 21 counties and cities in Taiwan province, Kinmen and Lienchiang counties of Fukien province will also elect their county chiefs and councilors on Dec. 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS WANT MEDALS REVOKED FROM ALLEGED PROFITEER

TEXT.P: Opposition lawmakers are urging the Presidential Office to revoke two medals of honor from a former national policy adviser to the president because of his alleged controversial role in a profiteering scandal involving the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project.

Chen Che-nan, who resigned his post as national policy adviser in early October, was expelled from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) last week after evidence came to light showing that he lied about his close association with a labor brokerage firm, Huapan Administration Consult Co., whose exploitation and maltreatment of some 1,400 Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project prompted their rioting on Aug. 21, denting Taiwan's global image.

President Chen Shui-bian presented Chen Che-nan with the Order of Brilliant Star Second Class Jan. 31, 2002, and the Order of Propitious Clouds Second Class May 19, 2004, while he was serving as the deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office. Both medals were awarded on the grounds that the recipient of the honor had "enhanced the image of the Presidential Office."

Opposition People First Party legislators Lee Ching-an and Ku Chung-lien, demanded Monday that the Presidential Office recall the two medals immediately because Chen Che-nan was "clearly involved" in the profiteering scandal.

Legislator Pan Wei-kang, a whip of the legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , KMT Legislator Joanna Lei and independent Legislator Chiu Yi also urged the president to demand that Chen Che-nan return his the medals to the Presidential Office.

The lawmakers told a press conference that since the president had already apologized to the nation for appointing an inappropriate person to the important post, the Presidential Office should take the medals back without delay.

At a separate news conference, the DPP legislative caucus defended the president, pointing out that the medals, awarded in recognition of the recipient's contribution to the nation, are not a guarantee of the recipient's integrity.

However, DPP caucus leaders added that the caucus will suggest to the president that when a medal of honor is awarded in the future, an investigation must be made first as to the recipient's integrity.

Chen Che-nan had previously admitted that he took two trips to Thailand with friends but denied a close relationship with Huapan Co. However, evidence emerged last week that he went with the owners of Huapan and Chen Min-hsien, former vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC), for a pleasure trip to a casino in South Korea, with his travel and hotel expenses paid by the labor brokers.
Chen Min-hsien is another controversial figure who resigned his post as adviser to the president in early October amid speculation of his involvement in the KRTC profiteering case.

A photo was published in the media last week showing Chen Che-nan and Chen Min-hsien gambling at a casino in South Korea in November 2002. Although the president said he had no prior knowledge of the trip because Chen Che-nan did not ask for leave before his departure, the exposure caused the approval rating of the DPP government to plunge even further.

In a campaign address last weekend, President Chen apologized to the people for his former aides' involvement in the profiteering scandal and urged the public prosecutors to uncover the truth about the case.

The public prosecutors office has assigned more than 20 investigators to pursue the profiteering racket in an attempt to trace the paper trail of kickbacks, money laundering routes and other irregularities.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE AUTHORITIES VOICE CONCERNS ABOUT OPENING TO CHINESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: Police authorities voiced concerns Monday about the possible impact on social order and national security of the expected opening of Taiwan to tourists from China in the near future.

The National Police Administration (NPA) remains reserved about the opening, as Taiwan and China are yet to come forth with a set of cooperative mechanisms on crime fighting, ranking NPA officials said.

As relevant arrangements are not in place, money laundering, financial fraud and forgery of official documents across the Taiwan Strait continue to be rampant, which will make it hard after the opening to verify the identity of visiting Chinese tourists and prevent infiltration by Chinese intelligence agents and criminals, the officials said.

At present, some 150,000 visitors from China enter Taiwan each year, and a full opening to Chinese tourists would make the issue even more complex and create a greater risk to Taiwan's national security and public order, the officials said.

To minimize the impact, the establishment of a special ad-hoc group composed of immigration, police, intelligence and investigation units is necessary to carry out the mission of safeguarding the country following the opening to Chinese tourists, they suggested.

For the time being, only Chinese people living abroad or coming from a third country or area are allowed to visit Taiwan. Premier Frank Hsieh said in May of this year that the government is poised to fully open Taiwan to tourists from China in response to a Beijing overture that China would allow its citizens to sightsee in Taiwan.
However, China has so far failed to include Taiwan in its list of approved outbound travel destinations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANCES SLIM FOR 'ASEAN PLUS 3': EXPERT

TEXT.P: The possibility of forming a bloc of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) plus China, South Korea and Japan by 2010 is not very likely, Fuhwa Financial Holdings Co. Chairman Yen Ching-chang said Monday.

Yen made the comment at a seminar on global market deployment when answering questions from local businessmen about whether Taiwan would become an outcast at a time when trade bloc groupings are increasingly taking shape around the world.
Yen said that the chances of the formation of the so-called "ASEAN plus 3" before 2010 were very slim due to rivalry between China and Japan.
Even were such a group formed in the near future, it would be a loose organization, he said.

In addition, he contended that the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) pacts China has signed with Hong Kong and Macau have had no noticeable impact on Taiwan's economy, mainly because of the territories' different industrial structures.
For example, Taiwan has a steel industry, unlike either Hong Kong or Macau, he said.
According to Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long, the economies of Taiwan and Hong Kong do not overlap in terms of agriculture and industry.

However, Taiwan's service-oriented businesses, such as the banking sector, have been more affected, he said, adding that some Taiwan-based banks have acquired Hong Kong-based banking institutions as a means of breaking into the Chinese market.

Meanwhile, an analysis published by Yang Ya-hui, a senior researcher with the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, in an electronic newspaper run by the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that Taiwan-funded banks are facing a problem of client flight due to their restricted operations in China.

As Taiwan-based banks are stilled banned from opening branches in China, the services they can provide fall far short of meeting the needs of Taiwan businessmen there, the report said, adding that Taiwan banking institutions have been troubled by an outflow of good clients because of their failure to offer adequate services.

Even though Taiwan banks have now been allowed to upgrade their offices in China to the level of branches, they encounter mounting difficulties in market exploration and sustainable development amid fierce foreign competition seeking to seize a bigger slice of the pie, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM INDUSTRY WORRIED ABOUT PRICE WAR OVER CHINESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tourism industry is not worried about the ability of local hotels and relevant authorities to handle an expected influx of tourists from China but it is deeply concerned about a vicious price war that could erupt in the battle for their custom.

Brushing aside speculation that Taiwan streets will be packed with hordes of tourists from China after the government allows the opening, Tseng Sheng-hai, secretary-general of the Travel Agent Association (TAA) of the Republic of China, described such rhetoric as "far-fetched."

As Taiwan is expected to allow as many as 1,000 Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan per day for a maximum stay of 10 days, only around 10,000 tourists from China would be in Taiwan on any given day, Tseng pointed out.

According to Chu Chung-hung, chairman of the Taiwan Scenic Spots Association, there are 22 listed recreational facilities in Taiwan that can accommodate a combined 15 million visitors per year -- a figure that is far beyond the annual limit set by the government for around 360,000 Chinese tourists.

In terms of hotel accommodation, Tseng reported that there are a total of around 22,000 hotel rooms around the country, more than sufficient compared to the level of about 4,000 rooms needed to house Chinese tourists in the initial stages of the opening.
Hotel owners in Taiwan's resort and tourists spots are keenly awaiting the arrival of Chinese tourists to fill rooms that are usually empty on weekdays.

Although local tour operators are confident of receiving as many as 400,000 tourists from China in line with the government's annual quota, they are nevertheless concerned about a price war that could break out to attract more Chinese tourists.

Despite the fact that the minimum cost of hosting one Chinese tourist is set by the TAA at around NT$2,000 (US$60) per day, they claimed that some tour operators are willing to drop their prices to as low as US$28 per head.

This cut-throat price is well under Taiwan's consumption level and they added that Taiwan's image would be seriously hurt if low-budget tours become out of control by forcing visitors to shop around or taking them to "low-class and vulgar sites."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI MEN'S SOFTBALL TEAM WINS GOLD IN EAST ASIA GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Oct. 31 (CNA) (By Li Chien-chung & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei won its first gold Monday in the fourth East Asia Games since the regional sports event kicked off Saturday in Macau.
The men's softball team earned Taiwan a gold by defeating Japan.
The East Asia Games will run through Nov. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR TAIWAN NEWSPAPER FOLDS

TEXT.P: The China Times Express, one of Taiwan's major evening newspapers, closed shop Monday after 17 years in business that saw the rise of new information technology as well as rapid changes in Taiwan society with which the newspaper was unable to cope.
In its final edition, the daily claimed that it has "dedicated 17 splendid years to Taiwan" and that its staff members "have fought a good war."

With the closure of the paper, the United Evening News becomes the only evening newspaper in Taiwan. The two dailies had tried to merge, but according to a China Times Express statement, the merger plan did not materialize because its assessment of the prospects for evening papers was not optimistic.

The staff were given the option to choose between leaving with a severance package and moving to the China Times, which vowed to become an even better "quality newspaper" with the injection of an "elite group" of journalists and staff workers from its sister paper.

The China Times Express was launched in 1988 when Taiwan was still reeling from the excitement of the lifting of the decades-old martial law imposed by the previous Kuomintang government, which fled to Taiwan from China in 1949.

The newspaper tried to play a critical role in the fast-changing Taiwan society with what its management claimed were daring and innovative reports and insightful academic and professional essays and commentaries that "helped forge Taiwan's mainstream public opinion."

The daily also staged satirical activities such as its annual "Golden Donkey Awards" presented to "outstanding" political figures and speeches selected by readers to mirror the absurdities in freewheeling Taiwan society, in the hope that "these donkeys would invite people to reflect on themselves."

"During the past 17 years, we have never budged in our efforts to find truth as we insisted on the principle of social justice and worked hard to maintain a liberal tradition, " said managing editor Yang Tu.
At its peak, the daily's circulation reached almost half a million copies. It did not disclose its current circulation.
The paper was unable to compete against the onslaught of market forces dictated by the development of new technologies and new forms of media such as the Internet.
Even the government's economic liberalization policy that extended the stock trading hours from noon to 1: 30 p.m. contributed to the shrinking of the market for evening newspapers.

Taiwan's economic stagnation and the rapid rise of the Chinese market was the straw the broke the camel's back, with changes in Taiwan's advertising market -- worth NT$95 billion in 1999 but declining to NT$56 billion in 2004. Of that figure, the slice for print media was halved from NT$30 billion in 1999 to NT$15 billion last year, making it ever-more difficult for newspapers to survive.
"Financial constraints are the main reason that we have to call it quits, " said the China Times Express in a long farewell statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 800 ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS FROM CHINA ARRESTED THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: A total of 893 illegal immigrants from China were arrested in the first nine months of this year, according to a report filed by the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Monday to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
The CGA report said that in the nine-month period, a total of 606 illegal immigration cases were successfully dealt with, with 254 Taiwanese found to be complicit in helping the illegal immigrants.

Five of the cases were illegal immigration in groups, while three cases were found to have been organized by crime rings involved in the brokerage of illegal immigrants and the sex trade, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR INTERNATIONAL MONITORING OF BIRD FLU IN CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the international community Monday to jointly monitor the avian flu situation in China to plug any possible holes in the global pandemic alert and response system.
Chen made the appeal at a high-level meeting on avian flu prevention amid mounting global concern about the possibility of an influenza pandemic.

Senior officials from the Department of Health, the Council of Agriculture and other relevant government agencies attended the meeting -- the second of its kind held in recent weeks -- to show government concern about the public health issue.

Noting that China boasts the world's largest bird and poultry population, Chen said the international community should jointly push China to make its avian flu situation transparent. A week earlier, the central Chinese province of Hunan reported an avian flu outbreak that has killed hundreds of chickens and ducks.
"The world should jointly monitor the avian flu situation in China and push China to honestly and promptly report any outbreak to the World Health Organization (WHO)," Chen said.

Taiwan has already had a taste of just how much devastation an infectious disease can cause, Chen recalled. In 2003, SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, emerged in China and spread rapidly across the world via air travel, killing nearly 800 people and causing millions of dollars-worth of economic losses. Taiwan was one of the hardest SARS-hit countries.

"The devastation was caused mainly because China failed to report the outbreak to the WHO in the first instance and even tried to cover it up, " Chen said, adding that similar mistakes should not be repeated.
Thanks to concerted efforts of local coast guard, customs, quarantine and public health agencies, Chen said, Taiwan has managed to keep its avian flu-free status.

On Oct. 14, coast guard officials seized more than 1,000 smuggled birds from China aboard a Panama-registered freighter anchored at Taichung Harbor, central Taiwan Oct. 14. Some 270 of the birds tested H5N1 positive and all of the smuggled birds were incinerated in line with the animal quarantine law.

Avian flu is a highly infectious virus among both wild and domestic birds. H5N1 is the most virulent strain of bird flu and has killed more than 60 people in Asia since 2003. Experts are closely watching the disease for fear that it could mutate into a form easily transmitted among humans and cause a pandemic that could kill millions. Taiwan's quarantine and public health agencies have been on full alert against the disease.

Chen said the coast guard authority deserves credit for the seizure and that the incident should inspire relevant government agencies to heighten alert on the possibility of animal smuggling becoming the culprit of an avian flu spread.
"We should review our regulations and make necessary updates and improvements to deter animal smuggling by raising the penalties, " Chen said.

At the moment, 18 countries have reported avian flu outbreaks, with China, Vietnam and Thailand listed by the WHO as high-risk areas. Chen said the government should fulfill its responsibility of informing local citizens bound for these three countries of the latest epidemic situation and preventive measures to protect them from coming down with the disease during their trips.

In addition to taking part in a global avian flu-fighting mechanism, Chen said the public health authorities should step up public health education, the stockpiling of antiviral drugs and the development of vaccines.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH-SPEED RAIL CORP. TO PUBLISH NEW FINANCIAL PLAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) will publish its new financial plan in mid-November, THSRC Chairperson Nita Ing told CNA Monday.

She said the new financial plan will not become big news. The major construction project, for which she is responsible, has become a "near-scandal" after she announced a delay in the launch of services for a whole year until the end of Oct., 2006 and the government ordered two public foundations to pour in new money to save the financially troubled corporation.
Asked if THSRC will need further new investment before it launches services, she did not give a clear answer, saying only that "the financial plan is not yet finalized."

The NT$7.5 billion that the government-subsidized China Aviation Development Foundation and China Technical Consultant Inc. (CTIT) Foundation were told to invest in the BOT (build, operation and transfer) project became the focus of controversy, with both the media and opposition party lawmakers questioning what happened to the largest BOT project in Taiwan's history and some experts expressing worry that it might become a financial abyss that the government will be forced to fill up with taxpayers' money.
Ing said she knew CTIT not happy about being "forced" to make the investment to make up for THSRC's financial shortfall.

When the project started, Taiwan's stock market was doing well and investors were confident about Taiwan's economic future, she said. However, she added, the overall economic situation has changed over the past few years, making it difficult for THSRC to attract new investment.
Ing said there is no urgent need to move the corporation's next board meeting forward to discuss a reshuffle of board members.

The government has asked that three seats be added to the 12-member board, with two appointed by the government and the other chosen by consensus between the government and THSRC. The Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC) has said it hopes the board meeting can be held in November.
However, Ing said it takes two months to prepare for a board meeting and that since a regular meeting is scheduled for May, there is "no need" to hold a provisional one.
On some lawmakers' demand that she be replaced by a government appointee, Ing claimed to have never heard of such a proposal.

She said the percentage of investment by the government has not reached a level to entitle it to take over the project and pointed out that if the government insists on buying a corporation, the prerequisite is that it has gone bankrupt.
She added that what that actually means is that the government would have six months to find another management team that could win assurances from a consortium of banks.
In her view, she said, the government has neither the capacity nor the willingness to take over the high-speed rail project.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY GOVERNMENT WANTS KRTC CHAIRMAN REPLACED

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government's Department of Rapid Transit System sent a letter to the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) Monday, formally asking the company's board of directors to replace its chairman, Chen Jen-yung.

The letter, signed by department chief Lee Cheng-pin, said that the change is necessary because problems arising from the KRTC's poor management recently have prompted public suspicion about KRTC's involvement in a profiteering scandal and have seriously damaged the image of the Kaohsiung city government.

Asked why the letter only asks for the replacement of the KRTC chairman, Lee said it is taken for granted that KRTC President Fan Chen-po will also have to go along with the chairman because they are a management team.

Chen, president of China Steel Corp., has been KRTC chairman since June 2001. However, he is apparently a figurehead because nearly all important decisions were made by KRTC Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien, who resigned in September after the profiteering scandal was brought to light by the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers protesting their maltreatment by the KTRC employers and a management company.

The Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project was meant to be based on a "build-operate-transfer" model, but of the NT$183.17 billion (US$5.46 billion) price ticket for the project, NT$150.8 billion came from the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUBSIDENCE WILL NOT THREATEN HIGH-SPEED RAIL: THSRC CHAIRWOMAN

TEXT.P: Subsidence in Yunlin, central Taiwan, will not be a danger for the high-speed train service planned for launch Oct. 31, 2006, Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) Chairwoman Nita Ing said Monday.
Overuse of groundwater by local farmers and factory managers is causing land to subside at an average of 10 cm per year, causing some people to worry that the railway in Yunlin will be dangerous.

During an exclusive interview with CNA, Ing claimed that the subsidence will not affect the safety of the high-speed trains but said that the loss of "national territory" is serious enough to merit government attention.

According to Ing, at the current speed, the land in Yunlin is subsiding so fast that in 200 years, a whole area might simply disappear and "that is a question much more serious than the safety of high-speed trains."
She said the engineers and workers took into account the subsidence when they laid foundations for the railway, so there will not be a safety hazard in Yunlin.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH RUSSIAN LIBRARY CURATORS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he looks forward to closer cultural and literary exchanges between Russia and Taiwan.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with the curators of three Russian literary museums dedicated to three famous Russian novelists -- the State Memorial and Natural Preserve Leo Tolstoy Museum-Estate Yasnaya Polyana, the Ministry of Culture of Russia State M.A. Sholokov Museum-Reserve, and the Pushkin State Museum.
Noting that Russian literature has a long and rich tradition, Chen said he admires Russia's literary achievements. All three of the Russian authors have many fans in Taiwan, he added.
Chen said the three writers had many things in common -- their concern for ordinary people, pursuit of world peace and exploration of the meaning of life.
Like realistic Russian literature, Chen said, the mainstream of modern Taiwan literature also attempts to describe daily life and social conditions.
Chen said he hopes the three curators can come to a better understanding of Taiwan people's true resolve to pursue peace during their visit to Taiwan.
At the meeting, Vladimir Illich Tolstoy, a great-grandson of Leo Tolstoy (1828-1910) , presented a special Tolstoy robe to Chen as a souvenir.
The two other Russian visitors were Alexander Michailovich Sholokhov, a grandson of Sholokhov (1905-1984), and Evgeny Anatollevich Bogatyrev, curator of the Pushkin State Museum.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TOP LABOR AFFAIRS OFFICIAL QUESTIONED OVER KRTC SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Former Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu was questioned by the Investigation Bureau's Kaohsiung office under the Ministry of Justice for 10 hours Monday as a suspect in a profiteering scandal and the exploitation of Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project.
Chen resigned in early September to assume political responsibility for the Aug. 21 riot in Kaohsiung County by the Thai laborers.

She told reporters following the questioning that she did everything according to the law while she was CLA chairwoman and that no one had interfered in the CLA's decision to allow Thai laborers to be brought into Taiwan to work for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC).
She said that as the employers, KRTC had the right to hire Thai laborers directly by itself or through a labor brokerage firm.

Also questioned with Chen as suspects in the same case were Kuo Fang-yu, a section chief of the CLA in charge of occupational training; Chen Yi-min, a former deputy section chief of the CLA's occupation training section; and CLA chief secretary Ho Jui-fan. They also denied any involvement in the scandal.
A spokesman for the Kaohsiung office of the Investigation Bureau said Chen Chu and the other three will be referred to the Kaohsiung District Public Prosecutors Office for further questioning.

Media coverage of the KRTC scandal has continued unabated for more than two months, fanning widespread speculation about a massive profiteering racket involving government officials, KRTC executives, construction companies contracted by KRTC and two illegal labor brokerage firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR TRUST IN LEGAL SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh urged the media Monday to respect the law that prohibits the premature revelation of criminal investigations.

Hsieh said the media has developed a taste for publishing "unfounded explosive revelations" of so-called scandals, including the controversy surrounding the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) system construction project.
He said the scandal actually refers to suspected irregularities involving the employment and management of Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) .
As the investigation is probing manpower brokerages in Thailand, Hsieh said, it will take time for prosecutors to get to the bottom of the matter.
Hsieh said he hopes the media will refrain from making unfounded accusations.

"Irresponsible accusations are tantamount to interference with legal investigations. If opposition lawmakers do not believe in the merits of confidentiality in the process of criminal investigation, then we may revise the law to that end. But until the law is revised, we should respect the confidentiality principle and give the prosecutors time to finalize a comprehensive inquiry," he added.
